Samuel did formulate: the moment is one in 56,848 of an hour<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Of this part there exist three Yerushalmi sources [the Talmud here, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Lamentations 2:19" href="/Lamentations.2.19"><i>Midrash Ekha rabbati</i> on <i>Threni</i> 2:19</a>. <i>Midrash Samuel</i> 3(1)], all of which have an identical text and the definition of the number of moments in an hour by Rebbi as 24<sup>3</sup>= 13824, by Samuel as 56848, and by others either as the time needed to say the word or as the blinking of an eye. In Babylonian sources (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 7a" href="/Berakhot.7a"><i>Berakhot</i> 7a</a>, <i>Abodah zarah</i> 4a) the numbers are quoted anonymously and are given as 58888 (printed editions), 56880 (Munich manuscript), 56800 (Koronel manuscript) in <i>Berakhot</i> and 53848 (printed editions), 56884 (R. Ḥananel), 56888 (Munich ms.) in <i>Abodah zarah</i>. In <i>Sefer Agadot Hatalmud</i> the reading is 5845. The opinion that a moment is the length of time needed to pronounce the word is attributed in the Babli to Rebbi Abin (who might be identical with Rabin, a Galilean authority who escaped persecution by an emperor and became an authority in Babylonia.) Only the numbers given in the Yerushalmi tradition are composites of simple numbers; Samuel’s number is 16×11×17×19, whereas the Babylonian numbers have no decomposition into small factors. Now most of the numbers in the Babylonian sources (who have been copied and edited much more than the Yerushalmi and, therefore, are more likely to contain scribal errors) are close to Samuel’s number. One may, therefore, assume that the original number in all Talmud texts was 56848.<br>In the Babylonian Talmud, the number given is from an anonymous Tannaïtic source which also adds: “Nobody can determine the moment exactly; only Bileam the sorcerer could do that.” In Antiquity (and the Middle Ages), all astronomical computations were done in the technique of the old Babylonians, in a number system based on subdivisions by 60. In general, divisions were executed only for numbers that have an easy reciprocal in the sexagesimal system, i.e., they are composed by factors of 60 (2, 3, 5, and their multiples). Instead of dividing, people looked up the reciprocal in a table and then multiplied. Samuel is the astronomer of most authority in the Talmud. Hence, it is reasonable to assume that his number, which is not invertible by the Babylonian method, is a good example that “nobody can exactly determine the moment” because 1/56848 is an infinite sexagesimal fraction. Hence, the comment of the Tanna, that “nobody can determine the moment exactly,” is implied in the number of Samuel and the Babylonian text is a derivative of the Yerushalmi text here.</i>. Rebbi Nathan said three: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Judges 7:19" href="/Judges.7.19"><i>Jud.</i> 7:19</a>) “at the start of the middle watch.”
Rebbi Zeriqan and Rebbi Ammi<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Ammi (or Immi) was the successor of Rebbi Yoḥanan as head of the academy of Tiberias. Rebbi Zeriqan was another student of Rebbi Yoḥanan. Their argument goes as follows: King David declares that he is used to get up at midnight and also that he gets up at the start of some night watch. But if midnight is the start of a watch then the number of watches has to be even. [The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 3b" href="/Berakhot.3b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 3b</a>) is a shortened version of the Yerushalmi (in particular, in the Ashkenazic manuscript tradition.)]</i> in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: The reason of Rebbi is (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 119:62" href="/Psalms.119.62"><i>Ps.</i> 119:62</a>): “At midnight I get up to thank You for Your just laws.” And it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 119:148" href="/Psalms.119.148"><i>Ps.</i> 119:148</a>): “My eyes preceded night watches.” Rebbi Ḥizqiah said: Rebbi Zeriqan and Rebbi Abba, one explained the reason of Rebbi, the other the reason of Rebbi Nathan. He who explained the reason of Rebbi: “at midnight”. He who explained the reason of Rebbi Nathan (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Judges 7:19" href="/Judges.7.19"><i>Jud.</i> 7:19</a>): “at the start of the middle watch.”<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">See the preceding paragraph.</i> How does Rebbi Nathan uphold the basis of Rebbi’s reason, “at midnight”? Sometimes “at midnight,” sometimes “my eyes preceded night watches.” How is that? When David had a state dinner, “at midnight.” When he ate by himself, “my eyes preceded night watches.” In no case did dawn come and found David asleep. That is what David said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 57:9" href="/Psalms.57.9"><i>Ps.</i> 57:9</a>): “Wake up, my honor, wake up, o harp and lute, I shall awake dawn.” My honor has to be awake because of the honor of my Creator. My honor counts for nothing before the honor of my Creator. I shall awake dawn, dawn will not awake me. His evil instinct was trying to seduce him and told him: David, usually dawn awakes kings and you say “I shall awake dawn!” Usually kings sleep until three hours into the day and you say “at midnight I get up!” But he answers, “for Your just laws.” What did David do? Rebbi Phineas in the name of Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Menaḥem<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Menaḥem was an Aggadist of the generation of Rebbi Ammi; Rebbi Phineas belongs to the following generation. A parallel Babylonian tradition is given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 4a" href="/Berakhot.4a"><i>Babli Berakhot</i> 4a</a>. The Yerushalmi version is also found in <i>Pesiqta dRav Kahana,</i>ויהי בחצי הלילה, 13 and in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 119" href="/Psalms.119"><i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 119</a>.</i>: He took a harp, put it on his headboard, got up at midnight and started playing on it so that his companions in the study of Torah should hear it. What were his companions in the study of Torah saying? When king David studies Torah, certainly we have to do it also! Rebbi Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The preacher in the academy of R. Yoḥanan. A shortened version, without the reference to the story of Elisha, is a Babylonian tradition, by contemporary Babylonian teachers, in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 3b" href="/Berakhot.3b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 3b</a>. The verse quoted talks about the prophetic extasy of Elisha before king Jehoshaphat. R. Elazar Azkari explains that the verse from Kings can be taken to be parallel to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 57:9" href="/Psalms.57.9"><i>Psalms</i> 57:9</a> since in the latter verse the harp is also addressed directly, as a living being.</i> said: a lute was hanging in David’s window and in the night the North wind was blowing and moving it and it was playing by itself. This refers to what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 3:15" href="/II_Kings.3.15"><i>2Kings</i> 3:15</a>): “It happened when the musical instrument was playing.” It does not say “when he played on the musical instrument” but “when the instrument was playing”; it was playing by itself.
How does Rebbi uphold the basis of Rebbi Nathan’s reason, “at the start of the middle watch”?<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">This is the logical end of the previous discussion that was interrupted by the aggadic interpretations of the verses sustaining the opinion of Rebbi. Both Rebbi Huna and Rebbi Mana belong to the fourth generation of Galilean Amoraïm, rather later than the authors of the previous section.</i> Rebbi Huna said: the end of the second and the start of the third split the night into two. Rebbi Mana said: Is this true? Does it say “watches”? No, it says “watch”! The first watch does not count since there the creatures are still awake.
<b>New Section.</b><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the next part of the Mishnah that is going to be discussed.</i> “But the sages say until midnight.” Rebbi Yasa<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yasa in the Yerushalmi is Rabbi Assi in the Babli, the head of the Academy at Tiberias after the death of R. Yoḥanan. It seems that the procedures which R. Yasa recommended to his colleagues were not explicitly given by Rebbi Yoḥanan but reflected the general tradition of the Academy of Tiberias. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 8b" href="/Berakhot.8b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 8b</a>), Rav Yehudah says in the name of Samuel that practice follows Rabban Gamliël who allows the recital of <i>Shema‘</i> after midnight in emergency cases. From the next “New Section” in the Yerushalmi it is clear that this is not the Israeli position; they forbid the recitation of the <i>Shema‘</i> after midnight. The opinion of Samuel represents either the autochthonous Babylonian practice or the teaching of the Academy of Nahardea founded by Ḥananiah ben Ḥananiah, the nephew of Rebbi Joshua, at the time of the revolt of Bar Kokhba.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Practice follows the Sages. Rebbi Yasa commanded his colleagues: if you want to study Torah then you should recite the <i>Shema‘</i> before midnight and then study<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">One talks here about studying in the night. It is stated in Mishnah <i>Šabbat</i> 1:2 that one interrupts everything he is doing to recite <i>Shema‘</i> at its proper time. Hence, we may assume that all these scholars did recite <i>Shema‘</i> in the synagogue. It was stated at the start that one reads <i>Shema‘</i> in the synagogue, when Minḥa and Maäriv services are held together while it is still before sundown, to stand in prayer after studying words of Torah. [This Israeli practice was followed by Ashkenazic Jewry, whose ritual basically was Galilean, until the sixteenth Century as can be seen from Rashi to the first Mishnah, <i>Ṭur Oraḥ Cḥayyim</i>235 and the glosses of R. Moshe Isserls <i>Oraḥ Cḥayyim</i> 235. Because of the disapproval of the main commentators of <i>Shulḥan Arukh, Magen Abraham</i> and <i>TaZ</i>, the practice has disappeared in all Ashkenazic congregations except those of the old German rite.] The question here is whether the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> after nightfall is needed in order to fulfill the obligation of <i>Shema‘</i> or whether it is needed to protect one’s sleep from evil influences. In the first case, one recites <i>Shema‘</i> as soon as possible and then continues one’s normal activities; in the second case one may say <i>Shema‘</i> only when one actually goes to sleep and then cannot say anything anymore before actually sleeping.</i>. His words imply that the practice follows the Sages. His words imply that one may speak after <i>Emet Weyaẓiv</i><sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babylonian ritual followed today, the benediction after <i>Shema‘</i> in the morning is אמת ויציב but in the evening אמת ואמוּנה; in Israel the same version, אמת ויציב, was recited morning and evening.<br>We find a disagreement between Rashi and his grandson Rabbenu Tam about the practice of praying Maäriv immediately after Minḥah, before sundown. According to Rashi on the Mishnah, the practice of reciting the <i>Shema‘</i> is exclusively to start the <i>Amidah</i> prayer after words of Torah. Hence, the only valid recitation is in the night. According to Rabbenu Tam (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Berakhot 2a" href="/Tosafot_on_Berakhot.2a"><i>Tosafot Berakhot</i> 2a</a>), the prayers are held after <i>plag haminḥah</i>, not more than 1.25 variable hours before sundown, and according to an opinion of R. Yehudah mentioned later in the Mishnah, both <i>Amidah</i> and <i>Shema‘</i> are valid prayers. According to Rashi, it is possible that the original <i>minhag</i> of the Jews in Israel did not imply that the benedictions before and after <i>Shema‘</i> were recited in the synagogue and that, therefore, they had to be recited at home and could be combined with other prayers. It follows that “one may speak after אמת ויציב” can mean that one does not have to mention the praise of God for the redemption of Israel from Egypt immediately before starting the <i>Amidah</i> prayer. This interpretation is given by several commentators of the Yerushalmi, foremost among them R. Eleazar Askari. However, since the obligation to “connect the redemption to the <i>Amidah</i>” in evening prayers is given in the name of R. Yoḥanan in the Babylonian Talmud (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 9b" href="/Berakhot.9b"><i>Berakhot</i> 9b</a>) it is difficult to state the opposite opinion here in the name of R. Yoḥanan.</i>. It was stated: He who reads the <i>Shema‘</i> in the synagogue during the morning service has fulfilled his duty; during the evening service he did not fulfill his duty<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">This supports Rashi’s opinion. However, <i>Raviah</i>, the foremost Ashkenazic authority of the early thirteenth century, writes that “I have received in tradition from Rabbenu Tam that practice does not follow any of these statements but R. Yehudah in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.1.1">Mishnah <i>Berakhot</i> 4:1</a>.”</i>. What is the difference between him who reads in the morning and him who reads in the evening?<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">This question has no answer in the text and seems to be a marginal gloss copied into the text since the quotes of this section in <i>Raviah</i> (#1, vol. 1, p.5) and in <i>Midrash Tehillim</i>(4[9]) do not contain the sentence.</i> Rebbi Huna in the name of Rav Joseph:<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Ḥuna is a younger Galilean Amora and is not to be confused with Rav Ḥuna, the student of Rav and leader of the second generation of Babylonian Amoraïm. Rav Joseph is the Babylonian (bar Ḥiyya), leader of the third generation in Babylonia. Rebbi Ḥuna often quotes Babylonian authorities and, therefore, possibly was a Babylonian immigrant to Israel.</i> Why did they say, a man has to read the <i>Shema‘</i> in his house in the evening? In order to make evil spirits flee. His words imply that one may not speak after <i>Emet Weyaẓiv</i>. The words of Rebbi Samuel ben Naḥmani say the same. When R. Samuel ben Naḥmani descended for the intercalation<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Shemuël bar Naḥmani (or Naḥman) was a student of the early Israeli Amora Rebbi Jonathan and one of the creators of the Midrash. The declaration of the addition of a month to the twelve month lunar year before the publication of the computed calendar was always made by an assembly of the leaders of the generation at a place called Callirrhoe (Ḥamat Gader). Rebbi Zeïra probably was too young at that time to be invited to the procedings but came to attend the gathering of the Sages, in order to learn from their ways.<br>While in the Babylonian Talmud נחת means “to leave the Land of Israel”, in the Yerushalmi it can mean simply “to descend”, in this case into the Jordan valley from his residence in Lod.</i>, he was received by Rebbi Jacob the groats miller. Rebbi Zeïra was hiding among the crates to hear how he read [the <i>Shema‘</i>]; he read it over and over again until he drifted away in sleep. What is the reason? Rebbi Aḥa and his father-in-law Rebbi Taḥlifa in the name of Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥmani (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 4:5" href="/Psalms.4.5"><i>Ps.</i> 4:5</a>): “Tremble, do not sin, talk in your hearts on your couches and be silent, Selah.”<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is the basis of <i>Rema</i>’s notes in <i>Shulḥan Arukh Oraḥ Ḥayyim</i> 239,1, as noted by the Gaon of Wilna.</i>
The behavior of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">One of the great sages of the first generation of Amoraïm. He lived in the valley of Beth Shean (<i>Demay</i>2:1). It follows that his way of reading the nightly <i>Shema‘</i>, which is the one followed today, is the oldest. In the Babylonian Talmud (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 4b" href="/Berakhot.4b"><i>Berakhot</i> 4b</a>) he is only reported to have stated the duty to read the <i>Shema‘</i> before sleeping, with the reason of R. Samuel ben Naḥmani given by a Galilean Amora by the name of R. Yose or R. Assi. The psalms read by R. Joshua ben Levi are detailed in Babli <i>Shevuöt</i> 15b where it is noted that, while it is forbidden to use Biblical verses as charms in healing, it is admissible to recite them for protection.</i> disagrees since Rebbi Joshua ben Levi read psalms afterwards. But have we not stated: One does not say words after <i>Emet Weyaẓiv</i>? He explains that as relating to <i>Emet Weyaẓiv</i> of the morning prayers<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Here it is obvious that “words after <i>Emet Weyaẓiv</i>” mean any insertion between the benediction גאל ישׂראל and the <i>Amidah</i> prayer. It does not follow that the expression must have the same meaning in the preceding section.</i>, since Rebbi Zeïra said in the name of Rav Abba bar Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">R. Abba bar Jeremiah seems to have been a Babylonian whose father (or uncle) was a contemporary of Rav and who was the teacher of Rebbi Zeïra (Rebbi Zera in the Babli) when the latter was still in Babylonia. The parallel teaching is mentioned, in the same wording but with a different meaning, in the Babylonian Talmud (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 42a" href="/Berakhot.42a"><i>Berakhot</i> 42a</a>) in the name of Rav.</i>: There are three immediacies: immediately after leaning comes slaughtering<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">In the usual process of bringing a sacrifice in the temple, the votary has to press with his hand on the head of the sacrifice before the slaughter.</i>, immediately after hand-washing comes benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear from the following that the meaning here is that immediately after washing one’s hands, while drying them, one has to pronounce the appropriate benediction. [Possibly, it could mean that immediately after washing the hands one has to pronounce the benediction over bread that starts the meal. The urgency of starting the meal directly after washing one’s hands is ascribed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 52b" href="/Berakhot.52b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 52b</a> to the School of Shammai; this interpretation of the Yerushalmi is implied by R. Aqiba Eiger in his notes to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 42a" href="/Berakhot.42a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i>42a</a>.] In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 42a" href="/Berakhot.42a">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 42a</a>, the same expression means that immediately after washing one’s hands <i>after</i> the meal one has to say Grace and is not allowed to eat anymore.</i>, immediately after redemption comes prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">This means that immediately after reciting the benediction: “Praise to You, o Lord, Who redeemed Israel,” one has to start the <i>Amidah</i> prayer. This creates no problems in the morning prayers but is impossible in the evening since after the benediction (starting <i>Emet Weëmunah</i> or <i>Emet Weyaẓiv</i>) there follows at least one more benediction and a <i>Qaddish</i> to separate the recital of <i>Shema‘</i> and its benedictions, an unconditional obligation at least from the institutions of the Men of the Great Assembly, and the <i>Amidah</i> prayer that in the night is of conditional Rabbinical character. When the principle “immediately after redemption comes prayer” was adopted also for the evening prayers (see preceding section), the intermediate pieces were declared to be “extensions of the thanksgiving for redemption.” The benediction immediately preceding the <i>Qaddish</i> was fixed by Babylonian Geonim to be a benediction for future redemption. The <i>Qaddish</i> itself may be a Gaonic institution.</i>. Immediately after leaning comes slaughtering: “He shall lean … he shall slaughter” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 1:4-5" href="/Leviticus.1.4-5"><i>Lev.</i> 1:4–5</a>)<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Leaning and slaughtering are two obligations of the votary given in two consecutive verses. (However, leaning must be performed by the votary himself but slaughtering can be delegated to a third party.)</i>. Immediately after hand-washing comes benediction, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 134:2" href="/Psalms.134.2"><i>Ps.</i> 134:2</a>) “Lift your hands in holiness and bless the Lord.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Hands lifted in holiness are washed hands. An allusion to this is found in the benediction that does not read “to wash the hands” but “to lift the hands.”</i>” Immediately after redemption comes prayer, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 19:15" href="/Psalms.19.15"><i>Ps.</i> 19:15</a>) “May the words of my mouth be for goodwill” and it is written after that (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 20:2" href="/Psalms.20.2"><i>Ps.</i> 20:2</a>) “May the Lord answer you on the day of worry.”<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">This derivation is a good example for the tendency of the Talmud to assume that everybody knows his Bible by heart and that it is enough to quote the start of a sentence in order to recall the entire sentence. The last sentence of Psalm 19 reads in its entirety: “May the words of my mouth be for goodwill before You, o Lord, my Rock and <i>my Redeemer</i>”. The next psalm, disregarding the title “For the director, a psalm of David,” starts: “May the Lord answer you on the day of worry.” Since psalms in ancient manuscripts were written without paragraph divisions, the description of God as redeemer and the mention of help through prayer are consecutive.</i> Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said: For anyone who immediately slaughters after leaning, no disqualification will appear regarding his sacrifice. For anyone who immediately pronounces the benediction after washing his hands, Satan will not find anything to accuse about at that meal. For anyone who immediately prays after mentioning redemption, Satan will not find anything to accuse him of the entire day<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">This third statement is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 9b" href="/Berakhot.9b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 9b</a>), in the name of the holy congregation of Jerusalem, i.e., the Tanna R. Yose ben Hammeshullam. To it is appended the story about Rebbi Zera (Zeïra)’s complaint, only there he had to bring myrrh to the king himself. Since R. Zeïra was a Babylonian immigrant to Israel, it is not clear whether his forced labor occurred in Babylonia, on the occasion of a visit of the Persian king, or in Galilee where he only had the opportunity to see the interior of the governor’s residence. The language of the story in the Yerushalmi points to its happening in Israel, while the language of the Babli points to the Persian empire. It cannot be decided where the incident happened.</i>. Rebbi Zeïra said, I am used to immediately pray after mentioning redemption and I was conscripted to forced labor, to bring myrrh to the Palace. They said to him: our teacher, that is an honor. There are people who pay money to see the inside of the Palace. Rebbi Immi<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babylonian Talmud, he appears as Rebbi Ammi, colleague of Rebbi Assi/Yasa. In the Yerushalmi, his name usually is Immi. His simile is quoted by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rashi on Berakhot 4b" href="/Rashi_on_Berakhot.4b">Rashi, <i>Berakhot</i> 4b</a>.</i> said: Anyone who does not immediately pray after mentioning redemption, whom is he to be likened to? To an acquaintance of the king who comes from afar to the king’s door. When the king comes to see what he wants, he finds that the person left. Hence, the king also leaves.
<b>New Section.</b> “Rabban Gamliel says until the first sign of dawn.” The statement of Rabban Gamliel is parallel to that of Rebbi Simeon, as we have stated in the name of Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rebbi Simeon bar Yoḥay, one of the students of R. Aqiba. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 8b" href="/Berakhot.8b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 8b</a>), the statement occurs in two versions, either “sometimes a person reads the <i>Shema‘</i> twice during the night”, or “sometimes a person reads the <i>Shema‘</i> twice during the day” and there they have to explain that either the few minutes before the start of dawn are already counted as day because some people already get up or that the first minutes of dawn are counted as night because most people still are asleep. The statement in its Babylonian form is also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:1" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.1">Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 1:1</a>); in general, our Tosephta seems to be a Babylonian version. The Yerushalmi version avoids the ambiguity but in parallel to the Babli one has to assume that R. Simeon accepts that one may read <i>Shema‘</i> twice within the span of a few minutes and fulfill two distinct obligations by the readings.</i>: “Sometimes a person reads the <i>Shema‘</i> [twice], once before dawn and once at dawn, and has fulfilled his obligation for day and night.” Hence Rabban Gamliel is like Rebbi Simeon for evening prayers, is he also like him in the morning? His position might be that expressed<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">The Aramaic/Hebrew כיי דמר should be read as equivalent of Babylonian: כְּהַאי דְּאָמַר.</i> by Rebbi Zeïra the Tanna<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning a person specializing in the memorizing and recitation of tannaïtic statements in the amoraïc period. A Tanna of the tannaïtic period never has the title “Tanna”.</i>, the brother of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">One of the foremost students of Rav in Babylonia.</i>, and of Rav Abba bar Ḥana<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">First cousin and colleague of Rav and student of their common uncle Rebbi Ḥiyya. Their statement, slightly enlarged, appears as an anonymous <i>baraita</i> in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 37b" href="/Yoma.37b">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 37b</a>. It seems to be a Tosephta from the collection of the Academy of Rav.</i>: He who reads with the men of the <i>Mishmar</i> did not fulfill his duty because they were too early<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Mishmar</i> were the priests who kept watch during the night at the Temple service. Since the Temple service started at the first signs of dawn, the men of the <i>Mishmar</i> [and the laymen accompanying them, the <i>Maämad</i>], had to <i>finish</i> their prayers before the start of service, i. e., before the first sign of dawn.<br>The Yerushalmi does not try to answer the question raised, whether Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Simeon are of the same opinion for morning prayers, since it already had decided in the preceding section that the practice follows the Sages and, therefore, one may not recite the <i>Shema‘</i> after midnight. Hence, the opinions of both Rebbi Simeon and Rabban Gamliel are of purely theoretical interest and no answer is required. In the Babli, the quote from Rebbi Simeon is given as a support to their decision that practice follows Rabban Gamliel. It seems to be the position of the Yerushalmi that in Temple times practice followed Rabban Gamliel in the Temple precinct and the Sages everywhere else.</i>.
Rabban Gamliel disagrees with the Sages and acts upon his opinion?<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:2" href="/Exodus.23.2"><i>Ex.</i> 23:2</a>) “to yield to the majority”, a religious authority is not allowed to act upon his personal opinion if it disagrees with the majority. This principle is then illustrated by several examples. It therefore is a big question why Rabban Gamliel’s action is mentioned in the Mishnah without a disapproving remark. [The position of the Babli here is quite different: Since the action of Rabban Gamliel is mentioned in the Mishnah without a disapproving remark, it follows that general practice follows Rabban Gamliel since the practice of a religious authority overrides theoretical arguments.]</i> Did not Rebbi Meïr disagree with the Sages and not act upon his opinion, did not Rebbi Aqiba disagree with the Sages and not act upon his opinion?
So we find that Rebbi Meïr disagreed with the Sages and did not act upon his opinion. We have stated: One rubs <i>olentia</i><sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>olentia</i> “sweet smelling things” (E. G.). There are at least two kinds, one mixture used for medical purposes, and one, mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 6:6:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.6.6.2-6">Halakhah 6:6</a>, to be used as air freshener in a house. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 140a" href="/Shabbat.140a">Babli (<i>Šabbat</i> 140a</a>) defines medical אלונתית as a mixture of wine, olive oil, and balsamum, used to reduce fever. [Brill derives the Hebrew word from Latin (<i>unguentum</i>)<i>oleamentum</i>, an ointment made with a base of olive oil. Jastrow (followed by Krauss, Löw, and Lieberman) derives the word from Greek οἰνάνθη, οἰ̓νανθίς, Latin <i>oenanthe</i>, which however means only “bloom of the wild grape” and clearly is inapplicable here.]<br>The entire quote is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Shabbat (Lieberman) 13" href="/Tosefta_Shabbat_(Lieberman).13"><i>Tosephta Šabbat</i> 13</a> where it belongs to a sequence of statements that one may not use edibles for medicinal purposes on the Sabbath except if used also as food. For example, for a toothache it is possible to rinse the tooth with vinegar on condition that the vinegar then be swallowed; it is not admissible to spit out the vinegar after use. Hence, it is not allowed to mix wine and oil with balsamum on the Sabbath since that would make it inedible. The parallel quote in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 134a" href="/Shabbat.134a">Babli is <i>Šabbat</i>134a</a>; the only difference in the texts is that the Babli and Tosephta have a purely Hebrew text while the Yerushalmi has the connecting remarks in Aramaic.</i> on a sick person on the Sabbath; but only if it was mixed with oil and wine before Sabbath eve. But if he did not mix it before Sabbath eve it is forbidden. We have stated: Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar said: Rebbi Meïr did allow to mix wine and oil and to rub it onto a sick persion on Sabbath. When he fell sick, we wanted to prepare the same for him but he did not let us do it. We said to him: Our teacher, are you going to invalidate your words when your life is in danger? He said to us: even though I am lenient for others, I am stringent for myself because my colleagues disagree with me.
So we find that Rebbi Aqiba disagreed with the Sages and did not act upon his opinion. As we have stated there (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Oholot 2:6" href="/Mishnah_Oholot.2.6"><i>Mishnah Ahilot</i> 2:6</a>): “Spine and skull from two dead bodies, a limb composed of limbs of two dead bodies, limbs taken from two living persons, Rebbi Aqiba declares them to be impure and the Sages declare them to be pure.”<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Purity and impurity mentioned here refer to transmission of impurity by a “tent”, since automatically everybody under the same roof with a corpse becomes impure; the “pure” bones mentioned here will still transmit impurity by touch. The conditions of impurity are spelled out in <i>Ahilot</i> 2:1. Flesh is causing impurity down to the volume of an olive but bones do so only if they are either the volume of a quarter <i>qab</i> (about .55 liter), most of the bones composing the skeleton in number or in importance, or skull and/or spine. [Whether one has to read שדרה וגלגולת as “skull <i>and</i> spine” or “skull <i>or</i> spine” is discussed inconclusively in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nazir 52b" href="/Nazir.52b"><i>Babli Nazir</i> 52b</a> ff.]</i> We have stated:<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Oholot 4:2" href="/Tosefta_Oholot.4.2">Tosephta <i>Ahilot</i> 4:2</a>; there the full name Theodoros is given to the chief surgeon. The Tosephta starts: “Rebbi Yehudah said: Six cases did Rebbi Aqiba declare impure and he changed his opinion; it happened …”, and ends: “Rebbi Simeon said: Until the time of his death did Rebbi Aqiba maintain that it should be impure; whether he changed his opinion when dying I do not know.” This means that according to Rebbi Yehudah, the vote at Lod showed that Rebbi Aqiba changed his opinion but, according to Rebbi Simeon, Rebbi Aqiba did not change his opinion, only he did not want openly to defy the opinion of the majority. We assume that the Yerushalmi here accepts the opinion of Rebbi Simeon, otherwise there is no proof here. It follows that also when the Yerushalmi quotes the Tosephta, sometimes the proof comes from the omitted parts.</i> “It happened that they brought a chest full of bones from Kefar Tabi<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Former Arab village Kafr Ṭab East of Lod.</i> to Lod and deposited it in the open air [the courtyard] of the synagogue. Theodoros the physician entered and with him all physicians. Theodoros declared that there was no complete spine from one dead person and no complete skull from one dead person. They said: Since we have here some who declare this pure and others who declare it impure, let us vote upon it. They started with Rebbi Aqiba and he declared it to be pure. They said: Since you had declared it impure, but now you vote for it to be pure, it is pure.”
So we find that Rebbi Simeon disagreed with the Sages and did not act upon his opinion. As we have stated there (<i>Mishnah Ševiït</i> 9:1) “Rebbi Simeon says: all aftergrowth is allowed except the aftergrowth of cabbage because nothing similar grows wild<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah deals with produce of the Seventh year offered for sale by an <i>Am Haäreẓ</i>, a Jew who cannot be trusted with the careful fulfillment of all his religious obligations. The Torah says not only that it is forbidden to plant and sow during the Sabbatical year but also (<i>Lev.</i> 32:5): “Do not harvest the aftergrowth of your harvest,” i. e., it is forbidden to commercially exploit the produce growing on one’s field from the seeds of the preceding year. It is, however, acceptable to collect from one’s fields small amounts for one’s daily needs (and even for storage as long as wild animals can find similar food on the fields.) Rebbi Simeon is of the opinion that a poor person may offer anything for sale since he might (or probably did) collect them from wild growing plants which do not fall under the prohibition. The only exception is produce which is never found growing wild; such vegetables are forbidden for commerce in the production of one’s own field. The Sages, while agreeing that Rebbi Simeon’s position is the one which follows the Biblical precept closely, nevertheless as a Rabbinic ordinance forbid any such buying from untrustworthy people since it is too difficult to enforce the fine distinction made by Rebbi Simeon.<br>Our example shows that Rebbi Simeon refrained from disagreeing in practice from the rest of the Sages even in purely Rabbinical ordinances. The man cursed by him probably did collect wild aftergrowth, or maybe was known to Rebbi Simeon as a landless person who, therefore, collected from growth on other people’s land that was declared ownerless (הפקר), otherwise his opponent could not have invoked R. Simeon’s own ruling. [This explanation follows Maimonides on the Mishnah. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 51b" href="/Pesachim.51b">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 51b</a> has a different text, see the discussion in Mishnah <i>Ševiït</i> 9:1, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 1:9:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.1.9.2-5"><i>Kilaim</i>, Halakhah 1:9</a>, and the notes to the Mishnah edition of the Institute for the Complete Israeli Talmud, <i>Ševiït</i> 9:1. The Rome ms. has here “forbidden,” influenced by the Babli.]</i>. But the Sages say that all aftergrowth is forbidden.” Rebbi Simeon bar Yoḥai acted on this in a Sabbatical year. He saw a man harvesting aftergrowth. He said to him: Is that not forbidden, is that not aftergrowth? The man answered him back: Are you not the one who allows it? He retorted: Do not my colleagues disagree with me? He recited over him (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 10:6" href="/Ecclesiastes.10.6"><i>Eccl.</i> 10:6</a>): “He who breaches a fence may be bitten by a snake”, and this is what happened to that man.
And Rabban Gamliel disagreed with the Sages and did act on his own opinion! There is a difference here since the recitiation of the <i>Shema‘</i> is for study<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">As explained at the end of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.2.1">Mishnah 5</a>.</i>. But then they could have read also after the start of dawn<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">And why did he tell them only to read before dawn? [Naturally, after dawn there already is an obligation to read the morning <i>Shema‘</i>; the question seems to be whether it is preferable to read the <i>Shema‘</i> twice if one forgot to recite it in the preceding period.] The question remains unanswered but this cannot be taken as rejection of the explanation.</i>. Some want to say that in the other cases it was possible to uphold the words of the Sages. But here it was after midnight and they could no longer fulfill the precept of the Sages; so he told his sons to act according to his opinion<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Sages will agree in this situation.</i>.
We have stated “the eating of the Passover sacrifice”. Some people do not formulate “the eating of the Passover sacrifice”. Who formulates “the eating of the Passover sacrifice”? The Sages. Who does not formulate “the eating of the Passover sacrifice”? Rebbi Eliezer.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">For the Sages, the obligation of eating the Passover sacrifices lasts during the entire Seder night; the limitation to the first half of the night is a Rabbinical ordinance. According to Rebbi Eliezer [and Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 9a" href="/Berakhot.9a">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 9a</a>], there is a Biblical prohibition of celebrating the Exodus after midnight. (Cf. the discussion in the author’s <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah</i>, Northvale NJ 1995, pp. 263–264.)<br>Rebbi Eliezer’s argument goes as follows: The Bible prescribes that the Passover sacrifice should be eaten “in that night.” It also reports that the death of the Egyptian firstborn was “in the middle of the night”. Since the second occurrence of “night” is qualified by “middle” but the first is left indeterminate, and we subscribe to the opinion that, unless explicitly given otherwise, words in the Pentateuch have an invariable meaning, the first occurrence must also mean “midnight.” The Sages follow Rebbi Aqiba in pointing out that the first Passover had to be eaten “in a hurry”, the hurry of the Exodus that happened only the following day. Hence, the notion of “night” here is opposed to “day” and not restricted to the first half.</i> What is the reason of Rebbi Eliezer? It is written here (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:8" href="/Exodus.12.8"><i>Ex.</i> 12:8</a>) “in the night”, and it is written there (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:29" href="/Exodus.12.29"><i>Ex.</i> 12:29</a>) “in the night”. Just as there it means midnight, so also here it means midnight. Rebbi Ḥuna<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">This is the form in which the name of the Galilean Amora R. Ḥuna appears most frequently in the Yerushalmi. It is probable that the Babylonian Amora Rav Huna (הוּנא) also originally was called חוּנא “the gracious one”, but in Babylonia every ח was pronounced as ה.<br>Rebbi Ḥuna points out that, since we are agreed that this Mishnah and the following one deal only with Rabbinical ordinances, the mention of the Passover sacrifice is impossible since, by Rabbinical ordinance, the Passover sacrifice is ritually impure after midnight, for the same reason that voluntary offerings cannot be eaten after midnight as explained in the next Halakhah. Here is another fundamental difference between the Yerushalmi and the Babli. According to the Yerushalmi both in <i>Berakhot</i> and in <i>Pesaḥim</i> (37d), the prohibitions mentioned in the Mishnah are Rabbinical. But the Babli in both cases (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 9a" href="/Berakhot.9a"><i>Berakhot</i> 9a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 120b" href="/Pesachim.120b"><i>Pesaḥim</i> 120b</a>) refers only to the opinions of Rebbis Eliezer and Eleazar ben Azariah that the prohibition is Biblical.</i> says: “The eating of the Passover sacrifice” cannot be here even for the Sages since we have stated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 10:7:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.10.7.2-5"><i>Pesaḥim</i> 10:9</a>) “the Passover sacrifice after midnight makes one’s hands impure.”<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the שׂרידי ירוּשלמי from the Cairo Genizah. The Leyden manuscript and the printed editions have קדשים קלים “simple sacrifices”. Zachariah Frankel already conjectured that the correct reading must be the one before us, as will be explained now.<br>There were four kinds of animal sacrifices in the Temple. Of certain sacrifices of atonement, only the blood was sprinkled on the altar; the rest was burnt outside the Temple precinct. The flesh of the עוֹלה, “holocaust” (totally burnt), was all burnt on the altar. The usual sacrifices of atonement had to be eaten by male Cohanim in the Temple precinct, except that blood, fat, and certain organs had to be burnt on the altar. These sacrifices are called “holiest of holies” and had to be consumed during the day of sacrifice or the following night. Family sacrifices, שׁלמים, “peace”, or “payment”, or “wholeness” sacrifices, were eaten by the family of the votary (except for the blood and fat, which was burnt on the altar, and certain parts which were to be eaten by priestly families.) These family sacrifices were called “simple sacrifices”; most of them had to be eaten during two days and the intervening night. The only “simple sacrifices” to be eaten during one day were thanksgiving sacrifices and the sacrifice of the <i>Nazir</i> at the end of his votary period when he cut his hair. Hence, <i>all</i> “holiest of holies” sacrifices are covered by our Mishnah but only a minority of “simple sacrifices”. There might be some justification for the reading “simple sacrifices” referring to the obligation of laity only who never ate “holiest of holies”; but then no special determination would be necessary.</i>
“All sacrifices that can be eaten during one full day only,” these are the holiest of holies.<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the שׂרידי ירוּשלמי from the Cairo Genizah. The Leyden manuscript and the printed editions have קדשים קלים “simple sacrifices”. Zachariah Frankel already conjectured that the correct reading must be the one before us, as will be explained now.<br>There were four kinds of animal sacrifices in the Temple. Of certain sacrifices of atonement, only the blood was sprinkled on the altar; the rest was burnt outside the Temple precinct. The flesh of the עוֹלה, “holocaust” (totally burnt), was all burnt on the altar. The usual sacrifices of atonement had to be eaten by male Cohanim in the Temple precinct, except that blood, fat, and certain organs had to be burnt on the altar. These sacrifices are called “holiest of holies” and had to be consumed during the day of sacrifice or the following night. Family sacrifices, שׁלמים, “peace”, or “payment”, or “wholeness” sacrifices, were eaten by the family of the votary (except for the blood and fat, which was burnt on the altar, and certain parts which were to be eaten by priestly families.) These family sacrifices were called “simple sacrifices”; most of them had to be eaten during two days and the intervening night. The only “simple sacrifices” to be eaten during one day were thanksgiving sacrifices and the sacrifice of the <i>Nazir</i> at the end of his votary period when he cut his hair. Hence, <i>all</i> “holiest of holies” sacrifices are covered by our Mishnah but only a minority of “simple sacrifices”. There might be some justification for the reading “simple sacrifices” referring to the obligation of laity only who never ate “holiest of holies”; but then no special determination would be necessary.</i> “In that case, why did the Sages say, etc.?” If you would say until the start of dawn, one might think that dawn did not yet start and it would turn out that he eats in sin.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">The determination of dawn was possible only for professional astronomers. In many cases, people would think that is was night when it was already dawn and then incur guilt by eating the sacrifices. In mid-month, with a large moon, the determination of the start of dawn is practically impossible for a non-professional. Midnight is no better defined than the start of dawn but a deviation from the true midnight would be harmless.</i> When you say to him: “only until midnight,” even if he does eat after midnight he will not incur guilt.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> From when on does one read the <i>Shema‘</i> in the morning? From when one can distinguish between dark blue<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">The translation of תכלת is problematic. It is defined in Babli <i>Menaḥot</i> as a color obtained by dying with the blood of some marine snail but since the snail has not been clearly identified, the color cannot be established by experimentation. From the second paragraph in the Halakhah, it would seem that תכלת could also be green, like color of the sea or like grasses. Since both in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 17a" href="/Sotah.17a">Babli (<i>Soṭa</i> 17a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 35b" href="/Menachot.35b"><i>Menaḥot</i> 35b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 89a" href="/Chullin.89a"><i>Ḥullin</i> 89a</a>, <i>Sifri</i> 115) and in Yerushalmi (here, <i>Bemidbar rabba</i> 14) sources the final comparison is with the sky, in modern Hebrew תכלת means “sky-blue” in contrast to כָּחוֹל “dark blue, color of <i>kohl</i>”.<br>The old Greek Septuagint translation gives ὑάκινθος “hyacinth, a blue stone, perhaps aquamarine; also a blue flower.” Ashkenazic tradition has the color of תכלת as almost black since the stripes of our prayer shawls that symbolize the unavailable תכלת stripes of the <i>tzitzit</i>, are traditionally dyed black. Hence the chosen translation of “dark blue”.</i> and white; Rebbi Eliezer says, between dark blue and the color of leeks; (he may read it)<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">The word in parentheses is found in the Mishnah preceding the chapter but is missing in the Mishnah here in the Halakhah. The word is also missing in most manuscripts of the Babli and in all early authorities, from <i>Halakhot Gedolot</i> to <i>Rosh</i>. For its meaning, I am following here Rabbenu Saadiah Gaon and Rabbenu Tam who admit לגמוֹר אח ההלל, “to read the Hallel”, as benediction of the Ḥazan even if only half the Hallel is recited.</i> until sunrise. Rebbi Yehoshua says, until three hours of the day since it is the rule of (sons of)<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Here again, the word in parentheses is found in the Mishnah preceding the chapter but is missing in the Mishnah here in the Halakhah, as well as in the Mishnah in the Babli. The story of the discussion of David with his יצר הר, fol. 2d, proves that the correct text does not contain the words “sons of”.</i> kings to rise at three hours. He who reads after that did not lose, he is like a man reading in the Torah.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> So is the Mishnah: Between its<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">“It” is the צצית, the fringes of the garment. We shall see later that the third section of the <i>Shema‘</i>, dealing with the obligation of <i>tzitzit</i>, was in Israel recited in abridged form during evening prayers. Hence, the <i>tzitzit</i> characterized the morning prayers. Each <i>tzitzit</i> contained three strands of white thread with one of <i>tĕkhēlet</i>.</i> dark blue and its white. What is the reason of the Rabbis? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:39" href="/Numbers.15.39"><i>Num.</i> 15:39</a>) “You shall see it”<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., the תכלת thread among the white threads of the <i>tzitzit</i>.</i>, from what is close to it. What is the reason of Rebbi Eliezer? “You shall see it”, that it should be recognizable among colors<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">That תכלת should be recognized not only as a color, but as its specific color.</i>.
We have stated in the name of Rebbi Meïr: It does not say “you shall see it”<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">In Rabbinic Hebrew, ציצית is clearly feminine, plural ציציוֹת. Rebbi Meïr notes that the verb referring to ציצית in this verse is in the masculine form. Usually, this is taken to mean that in Biblical Hebrew, ציצית is masculine (parallel to masculine קֹהֶלֶת “the preacher”); but many dictionaries of Biblical Hebrew refrain from assigning a gender to the word. Rebbi Meïr votes for taking ציצית as feminine; hence the suffix in “and you shall see” cannot refer to the <i>tzitzit</i>.</i> but “you shall see Him”. This tells you that anyone who keeps the obligation of <i>tzitzit</i> is as if he were admitted to the presence of God’s glory. This tells that <i>tĕkhelet</i> is similar to the sea. But the sea is similar to grasses, grasses are similar to the sky, the sky is similar to the Throne of Glory, and the Throne is similar to sapphire<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">The extended list is found only here; the other sources (quoted in the discussion of תכלת) only have the comparison of sea and sky.<br>The Gaon of Wilna has noted that the last two items in the list are in inverted order; one should read: the sky is similar to sapphire, sapphire is similar to the Throne of Glory. We are interested in connecting <i>tĕkhēlet</i> to the Throne of Glory, and the verse from Ezechiel provides the characterization as similar to sapphire.</i>, as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 10:1" href="/Ezekiel.10.1"><i>Ez.</i> 10:1</a>): “I saw, and here by the spread that was on top of the Cherubim like sapphire stone, the looks of the form of the Throne.”
Others say: “ ‘You shall see it’, that a man should be four <i>ammot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">The size of the Talmudic <i>ammah</i> (cubit) has not been definitely established; it is between 18 and 24 inches. It is uncertain whether the Galilean and Babylonian <i>ammot</i> were the same measurements.</i> distant from another man and recognize him.” Rav Ḥisda<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">One of the greatest of the students of Rab, a leader of the second generation of Amoraïm in Babylonia.</i> says: (the practice follows)<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">אמר in the Yerushalmi often can mean “establishes practice to be followed”, parallel to the statement of Rav Huna, contemporary of Rav Ḥisda, in the Babli: “The practice follows ‘Others’ ”.</i> the statement of “Others”. What are we talking about? If he knows the other person, even at a great distance he will recognize him. If he does not know him, even close by he will not recognize him. We must talk about an occasional acquaintance, like a man who visits a hostelry at intervals.
Some Tannaïm formulate: “Between wolf and dog, between domesticated and wild donkey.”<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning the earliest time for reading the <i>Shema‘</i>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 9b" href="/Berakhot.9b">Babli (9b</a>), the first criterion is given by Rebbi Meïr, the second one by Rebbi Aqiba, and both are given independently of the Mishnah. In the Yerushalmi, no names are attached since both opinions are identified as alternatives “between dark blue and leek colored”, which is not the practice anyway.<br>“Others” (אחרים) usually denotes Rebbi Meïr. In the Babli, the problem remains that the statement attributed to “Others” cannot belong to Rebbi Meïr. However, in the Yerushalmi it may well be that “between wolf and dog” is Rebbi Meïr’s restatement of Rebbi Eliezer’s criterion in the Mishnah, and “to recognize at 4 <i>ammot</i>” the same authority’s restatement of the criterion of the First Tanna in the Mishnah.</i> But some Tannaïm formulate: “That a man should be four <i>ammot</i> distant from another man and recognize him”. That is what we have<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pne Mosheh</i> (R. Moshe Margalit) reads הוּא בָּעֵי מֵימַר “he (Rav Ḥisda, mentioned earlier) wants to say.” Then the entire statement is tentative, and רב חסדא אמר will simply mean “Rav Ḥisda said”, not as an authoritative statement. However, the commentary <i>Pne Moshe</i> (R. Moshe ben Ḥabib) reads הווּן בּעי מימר “they (or we) want to say.”</i> to say that he who says between wolf and dog, between domesticated and wild donkey is parallel to him who says between dark blue and the color of leeks; he who says that a man should be four <i>ammot</i> distant from another man and recognize him is parallel to him who says between dark blue and white. But they said that its preferred obligation is at sunrise so that one may join the mention of redemption to prayer and pray at daytime<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">This is from the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:2" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.2">Tosephta (1:2</a>) and is the end of the statement that in the morning one may say the <i>Shema‘</i> as soon as one recognizes a person at a distance of 4 <i>ammot</i>. Hence, “they said” refers to those who adopt the criterion mentioned last. If one recites the <i>Shema‘</i> slowly at sunrise and then says the benediction of <i>Emet weyaẓiv</i>, he will just say the <i>Amidah</i> prayer when the sun is clearly above the horizon and it is visibly day.</i>. Rebbi Zeïra said: I found the reason (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 72:5" href="/Psalms.72.5"><i>Ps.</i> 72:5</a>): “They will fear You with the sun.”<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The same explanation is given in his name in the Babli, hence he is really the author and not only the tradent. Since the first section of <i>Shema‘</i> is “acceptance of the yoke of the kingdom of Heaven”, this is in essence fear of God, and, hence, the verse refers to the reading of <i>Shema‘</i> and not the prayer. It is clear that the prayer to be performed preferably at sunrise is the recitation of <i>Shema‘.</i></i> Mar Uqba<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Resh Galuta</i>, the Davidic ruler of the Jews in Babylonia, in the first generation of Amoraïm. It is interesting to note that this statement of the Babylonian Mar Uqba is reported in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 9b" href="/Berakhot.9b">Babli (9b</a>) in the name of the later Rebbi Yoḥanan. Maybe each Talmud wanted to ascribe the deeds of ותיקין to an external source, not to be held to their standards, as explained in the next section.<br>The explanation of ותיק has been given by A. Kohut in his ערוּך השלם, from the Arabic וַתִ֗ק “to have confidence, faith”. As explained by the Babylonian Talmud, they had faith in God that all the time spent in His service would not detract from their ability to earn a livelihood, and so they were rewarded with earning enough money for their needs in the time left over after religious services and deeds.</i> said: The very religious were getting up early and reading the <i>Shema</i>‘ so that they could follow it directly at sunrise with the <i>Amidah</i> prayer.
We have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:3" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.3">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 1:3</a>; there R. Aqiba (who was the greater scholar) is mentioned before R. Eleazar ben Azariah (the vice president of the Synhedrion), and it is spelled out that they were occupied to attend to some public needs. We have a principle that he who is fulfilling a religious duty is free from engaging in any conflicting religious duty. The two sages therefore would have had the possibility of not reciting <i>Shema‘</i> at all. The fact that they recited the <i>Shema‘</i> shows that they considered the obligation of this recitation in full force until the end of the third hour and that, therefore, their prior occupation did not reduce the later obligation. This is explained more thoroughly in the next section.<br>It seems that the text of the Yerushalmi is superior to the Tosephta since the vice president has precedence over a simple member and the mention of their being engaged in religious obligations is more to the point.</i>: Rebbi Yehudah said: It happened that once I was walking behind Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah and Rebbi Aqiba when they were occupied with duties and time came to recite the <i>Shema‘</i> and I got the opinion that maybe they had given up on reciting the <i>Shema‘</i>, so I recited it and went over my studies<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Reciting from memory the material he had learned earlier from his teachers.</i>; but after that they started and the sun was already over the mountain tops.
“Until sunrise.” Rebbi Zabida the son of Rebbi Jacob bar Zabdi in the name of Rebbi Jonah<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Of the leaders of the fourth generation of Amoraïm in Galilee. The first tradent was his student.</i>: until the sun starts to appear<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “drips”, meaning that the first rays of the sun start to appear at the lower parts of the mountain silhouette.</i> at the mountain tops. “Rebbi Joshua says, until three hours of the day.” Rebbi Idi, Rav Hamnuna, and Rav Ada bar Aḥava<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">The last name is correct in <i>Seridé Yerushalmi</i>. The name mentioned in the printed editions, אדא בר אחא, is not mentioned again in any Talmudic source. Rav Ada bar Aḥawa (Yerushalmi) is called Rav Ada bar Ahavah in the Babli; all teachers quoted here are students of Rav. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 10b" href="/Berakhot.10b">Babli (10b</a>), Rav Yehudah says in the name of Samuel: the practice follows Rebbi Joshua, without qualifications. It seems that in Israel one was reluctant to give up the recitation of the <i>Shema‘</i> at sunrise but in Babylonia the practice of very early prayers was never established.</i> in the name of Rav: The practice follows Rebbi Joshua for one who forgets. Rebbi Ḥuna told of two Amoraïm of whom one said ‘for one who forgot.’ His colleague responded: Do you ever fix practice for one who forgets<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Since rules are made to be followed, not to be forgotten.</i>? In fact, it is the practice. Why did they say, for one who forgot? That everybody should make an effort and read it at its best time.
There (<i>Šabbat</i> 1:2) we have stated: “One interrupts for the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> but one does not interrupt for prayer.”<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">It is implied by the following discussion that one talks about groups of people engaged in the study of Torah. This situation is made explicit in Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 9b. Of those who give the reasons for the difference in the treatment of <i>Shema‘</i> and <i>Amidah</i>, Rebbis Aḥa and Yose belong to the fourth generation of Amoraïm in Israel, hence Rebbi Abba will also belong to that group. [There were too many Amoraïm by the name of Rebbi Abba to clearly distinguish between them.]<br>The entire section here and the following one also appear in Yerushalmi <i>Šabbat</i> 1:2.</i> Rebbi Aḥa said: The recitation of <i>Shema</i>‘ is a Biblical obligation; prayer is not a Biblical obligation<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Everybody in this discussion seems to agree that the basis of the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> is Biblical, at least for the first verse [following the Babli (<i>Teshuvot ha Rashba</i>, #320)] or the first three verses [following the Yerushalmi, as seen here]. There is disagreement on the status of prayer. The Yerushalmi at the beginning of Chapter 4 follows the <i>Sifri</i> in the interpretation of the “service of the heart” mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 10:12" href="/Deuteronomy.10.12"><i>Deut.</i> 10:12</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:13" href="/Deuteronomy.11.13">11:13</a> as prayer, which, therefore, is Biblical. Rebbi Aḥa does not accept this derivation; similarly, the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 21a" href="/Berakhot.21a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 21a</a>) declares prayer to be a Rabbinical obligation.</i>. Rebbi Abba said: The time for the recitation of the <i>Shema‘</i> is fixed, the time for prayer is not fixed.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Abba is among those who accept prayer as a Biblical obligation. The clearest statement of that position is given by Maimonides (<i>Hilkhot Tefillah</i> 1:1) who writes: “It is a positive commandment that one should pray every day as it is said: ‘you shall serve the Eternal, your God.’ Tradition teaches us that this service is prayer, as it is said: ‘to serve Him with all your heart’; the sages explain that the service of the heart is prayer. But the number of prayers is not from the Torah, neither is the formulation of the prayer from the Torah. Prayer has no fixed time from the Torah.” [Everybody agrees that the obligation of offering prayer three times a day is historical (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 6:11" href="/Daniel.6.11"><i>Daniel</i> 6:11</a>) and the form of prayer is an institution of the Men of the Great Assembly.] This interpretation of the disagreement between Rebbis Aḥa and Abba is given by the great Sephardic commentators, Rabbis Eleazar Azkari and Moshe ben Ḥabib.<br>There is a different interpretation possible, namely that Rebbi Abba wants to state that the time of <i>Shema‘</i> is narrowly fixed, as we have seen, and once that time is passed, the omission cannot be repaired. For prayer, however, the rules are much more elastic. First, there is much more time given for the recitation; then it is possible to pray in advance of the time (as in the evening prayers held before sundown), and a missed prayer can be compensated for by praying the next time twice. Hence, in a real sense, even prayer in the Rabbinical sense has no fixed time compared to <i>Shema‘</i>.</i> Rebbi Yose said: The recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> does not need concentration, prayer needs concentration.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Abba is among those who accept prayer as a Biblical obligation. The clearest statement of that position is given by Maimonides (<i>Hilkhot Tefillah</i> 1:1) who writes: “It is a positive commandment that one should pray every day as it is said: ‘you shall serve the Eternal, your God.’ Tradition teaches us that this service is prayer, as it is said: ‘to serve Him with all your heart’; the sages explain that the service of the heart is prayer. But the number of prayers is not from the Torah, neither is the formulation of the prayer from the Torah. Prayer has no fixed time from the Torah.” [Everybody agrees that the obligation of offering prayer three times a day is historical (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 6:11" href="/Daniel.6.11"><i>Daniel</i> 6:11</a>) and the form of prayer is an institution of the Men of the Great Assembly.] This interpretation of the disagreement between Rebbis Aḥa and Abba is given by the great Sephardic commentators, Rabbis Eleazar Azkari and Moshe ben Ḥabib.<br>There is a different interpretation possible, namely that Rebbi Abba wants to state that the time of <i>Shema‘</i> is narrowly fixed, as we have seen, and once that time is passed, the omission cannot be repaired. For prayer, however, the rules are much more elastic. First, there is much more time given for the recitation; then it is possible to pray in advance of the time (as in the evening prayers held before sundown), and a missed prayer can be compensated for by praying the next time twice. Hence, in a real sense, even prayer in the Rabbinical sense has no fixed time compared to <i>Shema‘</i>.</i> Rebbi Mana said: I objected before Rebbi Yose: Even if you say that the recitation of the <i>Shema‘</i> does not need concentration, the first three verses need concentration. Since they are so few, one will concentrate upon their meaning.
Rebbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai: “For example we, who are engaged in the study of Torah, we do not interrupt even for the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>.” Rebbi Yoḥanan used to say about himself: “For example we, who are not engaged in the study of Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Since we spend some time every day not studying.</i>, we do interrupt even for prayer.” This one follows his own opinion and that one follows his own opinion. Rebbi Yoḥanan follows his own opinion since Rebbi Yoḥanan says: “if only a man would pray the entire day. Why? Because prayer is never in vain!”<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 17.</i> Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai follows his own opinion since Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai said: “If I had stood at Mount Sinai at the moment that the Torah was given to Israel, I would have implored the All-Merciful that he should create two mouths for man; one for him to exert himself in Torah and the other one for his other needs.” But he changed his mind and said: “With one mouth already the world almost cannot exist because of its denunciations<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>delatorius</i>, <i>a</i>, <i>um</i>, adj. to <i>delatio</i>, in late Latin <i>delatura</i> “accusation, information, denunciation,” the act of a <i>delator</i>, “government informer.” Because of an informer about his anti-Roman feelings, Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai and his son had to spend 12 years hidden in a cave (Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 33b, Yerushalmi <i>Ševiit</i> 9:1, fol. 38d). When he left the cave, he was so upset that people would engage in farming and commerce and not study Torah all day long that a heavenly voice ordered him back to his cave for another 12 months in order to get used to the world again. Both Talmudim consider his position appropriate only for exceedingly holy people.</i>; if there were two how much more would there be? Rebbi Yose said before Rebbi Jeremiah: The position of Rebbi Yoḥanan is identical with that of Rebbi Ḥanina ben Aqabiah, as we have stated: “The scribes of Torah scrolls, <i>Tefillin</i>, and <i>Mezuzot</i>, do interrupt for the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> but do not interrupt for prayer. Rebbi Ḥanina ben Aqabiah said: just as they interrupt for <i>Shema‘</i>, so they interrupt for prayer, <i>tefillin</i>, and all other commandments of the Torah”.<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">While we have the principle that “he who is engaged in the fulfillment of a commandment does not have to worry about other commandments,” this does not apply to people whose entire occupation is the fulfillment of a commandment.<br>The source is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:6" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.6"><i>Tosephta Berakhot</i> 2:6</a>, cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 26a" href="/Sukkah.26a">Babli <i>Sukkah</i> 26a</a>. The Tosephta also brings the opinion of Rebbi, that they do not interrupt for <i>Shema‘</i>, and a testimony that Rabban Gamliel and the Synhedrion at Yavneh did not interrupt sessions dealing with communal matters.</i> Would not Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai agree that one interrupts to make a <i>sukkah</i> or a <i>lulav</i>? Does not Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai make the distinction between one who studies in order to do<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">He who does is one who fulfills the commandments of the Torah. He who does not is one who does not fulfill the commandments of the Torah. Someone who studies Torah with the intent of not fulfilling its commandments certainly has no part in the future world since he does not have the excuse of everybody else that he did not know enough to fulfill all commandments. This is clearly spelled out in the following lines. The question here is, how can Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai take a position that for all practical purposes identifies the actions of the most holy man with that of the deliberate sinner?</i> and one who studies in order not to do? Because he who studies in order not to do would have been better off had he not been born. And did not Rebbi Yoḥanan say, he who studies in order not to do would have been better off if the afterbirth he was in was twisted around and he never would have entered the world? The reason of Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai is that this one is repeated study and that one is repeated study and he does not push aside one study for the other study.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">But he certainly will interrupt for all other obligations. In fact, the story of his stay in the cave notes that he and his son took off their clothes and sat covered with sand up to their necks in order not to wear out the clothes, and used them only for the times of prayer. This means that Rebbi Simeon did <i>not</i> recite <i>Shema‘</i> since its recitation was replaced by his studies, but he <i>did</i> pray, even though the Mishnah seems to indicate that one omits prayer more easily than <i>Shema‘</i>.</i> But did we not formulate:<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">In our Mishnah here in <i>Berakhot</i>.</i> “He is like a man reading in the Torah.” Hence, at the right time it is preferred to Torah. One is like the other.<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">This is a preliminary answer. Rebbi Yudan (Amora, colleague of R. Yose) tries to relativize the answer that it applies only to someone like Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai who spends his entire life studying and memorizing Torah. R. Abba Mari, one generation after R. Yudan, points out that this interpretation of the Mishnah is impossible but that one must take the statement of R. Simeon as an indication of his attitude in general.</i> Rebbi Yudan said that Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai, since he was permanently studying Torah, did not prefer <i>Shema‘</i> to the study of Torah. Rebbi Abba Mari said, did we not formulate: “He who reads (<i>Shema‘</i>) after that did not lose, he is only like a man reading in the Torah”? Hence, at the right time it is like Mishnah. Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai follows his own opinion since Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai said: He who studies the written Torah does himself good that is not so good. But the rabbis equate the study of the Bible with that of the oral law.<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Studying Scripture is equal to studying the Oral Law in merit. Hence, reciting the <i>Shema‘</i> in its proper time transcends both for everybody including scholars of the rank of Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai. Mishnah here stands for the entire Oral Law, which was called Mishnah in the time of Rebbi Simeon bar Yoḥai. (See the parallel in Babli <i>Baba meẓia‘</i> 33a.)</i>

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The school of Shammai say: In the evening, everyone must bend down<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Means to lie down on a couch, or as on a couch. “Reciting” always refers to the <i>Shema‘</i> since, as a technical term, it is used only for formal recitation of Biblical texts.</i> and recite and in the morning they should stand up since it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:7" href="/Deuteronomy.6.7"><i>Deut.</i> 6:7</a>): “when you sit in your house or go on the road, when you are lying down and when you are getting up.” But the school of Hillel say: everyone should recite in the position he is in, since it says “or go on the road.” In that case, why does it say: “when you are lying down and when you are getting up;” this means the time when people go to sleep and the time when they are getting up.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> They of the school of Hillel are able to explain both parts of the verse. How do those of the school of Shammai explain “when you sit in your house or go on the road”? “When you sit in your house”, to exclude those who are occupied with other religious commandments, “or go on the road” to exclude bridegrooms.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">An almost exact parallel is found in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 11a" href="/Berakhot.11a">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 11a</a>. The bride is exempt from reciting the <i>Shema‘</i> since women are freed from all positive commandments which have to be performed at set times. The bridegroom himself fulfills a divine commandment by getting married, but that fulfillment is really restricted to the short act of actual marriage and then to the first married intercourse; the exemption of the bridegroom from saying <i>Shema‘</i> refers to the entire wedding feast when he is unable to concentrate even on the first verses.</i>
We have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babylonian parallels (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 11a" href="/Berakhot.11a"><i>Berakhot</i> 11a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:4" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.4"><i>Tosephta Berakhot</i> 1:4</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 34" href="/Deuteronomy.34"><i>Sifri Deut.</i> 34</a>), R. Eleazar ben Azariah at first is sitting up and R. Ismael is reclining. This means that in the Babylonian version, the discussion was in the evening (also indicated in the Babylonian Talmud by a change in language, not “that they stayed at the same place” but that “they had dinner together.”) In our version, the discussion takes place in the morning.<br>While R. Ismael, after R. Aqiba the greatest scholar of his generation, did certainly exceed R. Eleazar ben Azariah in scholarship, the latter was the vice president of the Synhedrion; it is more likely that R. Ismael was sitting upright at the start. They might have got up very early, before the start of dawn, when it still was possible to eat before praying. It is impossible to decide which of the two versions is the original.</i>: It happened that Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah and Rebbi Ismael stayed at the same place and Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah was reclining while Rebbi Ismael was standing. When the time for the recital of the <i>Shema‘</i> arrived did Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah stand and Rebbi Ismael reclined. Rebbi Eleazar said to Rebbi Ismael, this is as when one says to someone in the market place, your beard is overgrown, and he says, that is against those who shave<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">I do it deliberately. Why did you do the opposite of what I am doing?</i>. I, who was reclining, stood up and you, who were standing, went on to recline. He answered him: You stood up following the school of Shammai, I reclined following the school of Hillel. Another explanation: That the students should not see me and make it the permanent practice to follow the school of Shammai.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Both explanations are necessary. R. Ismael did recline, not because it was required by the school of Hillel, but to spite the followers of the school of Shammai. He had to do this, even though the school of Hillel would have allowed him to continue standing, to give an example to the students. This shows that in all cases where there is a disagreement over practice, the actions of the leading Torah scholars count more than all theoretical arguments.</i>

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Ṭarphon<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">The oldest of the Tannaïm of the second generation, who started his studies still before the destruction of the Temple, at the time of the ascendency of the school of Shammai. It seems that he was slow to adapt the practices he had learned as a child to those of the school of R. Yoḥanan ben Zakkai of the school of Hillel which was the only one to survive the war against the Romans.</i> said: I was on the road and reclined to recite the <i>Shema‘</i> following the school of Shammai. There I put myself in danger because of the robbers. They told him: It would have served you right to be in mortal danger since you transgressed the words of the school of Hillel.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> In the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">This entire Halakhah, until the next Mishnah, really belongs to <i>Avodah zarah</i> 2:5 (fol. 41c) where <i>Song of Songs</i> 1:2, “May he kiss me with the kisses of his mouth since your friendship is better than wine”, is discussed. In the transcription here, the first word fell out. It should read: The fellows (of the Yeshivah) in the name of R. Yoḥanan.<br>In traditional interpretation, the Song of Songs is a dialogue between God and the people of Israel (represented by the girl); the question of the Mishnah was whether one reads דּוֹדָיִךְ (feminine) or דּוֹדֶיךָ (masculine) for “your friendship, your relations.”</i>: The words of the scribes are related to the words of Scripture and are pleasant like the words of Scripture. (<i>Song of Songs</i> 7:10) “Your throat is like the good wine”; Simeon ben Abba in the name of R. Yoḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">The members of the Yeshivah are of the second (colleagues of R. Yoḥanan) or the third (his students) generations of Amoraïm. R. Simeon bar Abba is one of the outstanding students of R. Yoḥanan.
