The two Amoraïm who explain the latter’s words are of the fourth and fifth generations, respectively.<br>The “throat” of the Jewish people are the sayings of its sages; wine in both verses are the words of the Torah.</i>: The words of the scribes are related to the words of Scripture and are more pleasant than the words of Scripture. (<i>Song of Songs</i> 1:2) “Since your friendship is better than wine”; Rebbi Abba bar Cohen in the name of Rebbi Judah ben Pazi: You can know that the words of the scribes are more pleasant than those of Scripture because if Rebbi Tarphon did not recite at all he would have transgressed only a positive commandment. But because he transgressed the words of the school of Hillel he should have suffered death since it says: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 10:8" href="/Proverbs.10.8"><i>Proverbs</i> 10:8</a>) “He who breaches a fence will be bitten by a snake.”
Rebbi Ismael did formulate: In the Torah there are forbidden matters and permitted matters. There are easy parts and severe parts. But in the words of the Sages all are severe<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Since their essential duty is to build “a fence around the Law”, it is in the nature of the institutions of the <i>Sopherim</i>, the men of the Great Assembly headed by Ezra and their successors before the period of the Rabbis, to be more restrictive than the original precepts of the Torah.</i>. You can realize that this is so since we have stated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.4.1">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 11:5</a>): “If he<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah speaks about the זקן ממרא, the rebellious religious leader, who does not accept the rulings of the supreme court sitting in the Temple court. If he asserts something that goes against the text of the Torah, he is not dangerous and not criminally liable since every child that has learned to read realizes his error. But if he asserts something in contradiction to an authoritative teaching of the oral law asserted by the Synhedrion, then he has committed a capital crime.<br>In the Babli, the reference is to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.4.1">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 10:5</a>. The interpretation of the law is much more restrictive in the Babli than in the Yerushalmi.</i> says there is no obligation of <i>Tefillin</i> against the words of the Torah he is not criminally liable. If he says that <i>Tefillin</i> have five sections, to add to the words of the Sages, he is guilty.” Rebbi Ḥananiah, the son of Rebbi Ada<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">A preacher of the fourth generation of Galilean Amoraïm whose name is quoted also as Ḥanina or Ḥinnena. His teacher R. Tanḥum bar Ḥiyya was from Kefar Agin (Umm Junia) South of the Sea of Galilee.</i>, in the name of Rebbi Tanḥum the son of Rebbi Ḥiyya: The words of the Sages carry more weight than those of the prophets, since it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Micah 2:6" href="/Micah.2.6"><i>Micah</i> 2:6</a>): “Do not preach, they preach; Do not preach to those, that shame does not reach you.<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Only false prophets will preach to such a generation, whereas the true prophet gets his orders from God not to preach. According to Rashi, טיף means “speak about your visions”, rather than the commonly used “preach”.</i>” And it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Micah 2:11" href="/Micah.2.11"><i>Micah</i> 2:11</a>) “I shall preach to you for wine and liquor.”<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">The real inference is from the rest of the verse that is not quoted but assumed to be known to every student: “You shall preach to this people.” It follows that the prophet sometimes is ordered to be silent and sometimes to speak but the sage is ordered to teach at all times.</i> The relation of prophet and scholar can be compared to the case of a king who sent two of his <i>palmatars</i><sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Arukh</i> notes the word but gives no explanation. Mussaphia, in his Notes to <i>Arukh</i>, proposes the impossible Greco-Latin hybrid πόλεμο-- <i>notarius</i>, “secretary of war.” The best explanation seems to be that of A. Kohut, <i>diplomatarius</i>; the first syllable <i>di</i> was interpreted as Aramaic relative pronoun (Hebrew שֶׁ) and, therefore, dropped. <i>Diplomatarius</i> is a late (Byzantine) form of <i>diplomarius</i>, the holder of an imperial <i>diploma</i>, a “doubly folded” imperial order or privilege which gave its holder the right to use the imperial mails for transportation. The two <i>diplomatarii</i> arrive in the province by imperial mail but this does not imply that they are plenipotentiaries (since, sometimes, the privilege of using the mails was given to private citizens.)</i> to a province. About one of them he wrote, if he does not show you my seal and σημαντήθιον<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Hebrew word (חוֹתם) “seal” and its Greek equivalent given as parallels.</i>, do not believe him. About the other one he wrote, even if he does not show you my seal, believe him without seal and σημαντήθιον. So about a prophet is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:2" href="/Deuteronomy.13.2"><i>Deut.</i> 13:2</a>) “He gives you a sign or miracle.” But here it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:11" href="/Deuteronomy.17.11"><i>Deut.</i> 17:11</a>): “According to the teachings that they will teach you”<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is to the tradition attached to v. 9, that obliges one in cases of doubt to go the the Temple and ask “the judge who shall be in those days”. Since it is impossible to ask a judge who does not live in one’s days, this is taken to mean that any chief judge, even if not the most competent one, has the same status as any other living in another time. (Babli <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 25b, <i>Sifri Devarim</i> 153).</i>.
That means<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Referring to the statement in the Mishnah, that Rebbi Tarphon was told that he incurred guilt by following the teachings of the school of Shammai (with which he probably grew up).</i> after the divine voice<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">A בת קוֹל, “daughter of a voice”, is a sound carrying information of indeterminate origin.</i> was heard. But before the divine voice was heard, <sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Eduyot 2:3" href="/Tosefta_Eduyot.2.3">Tosephta <i>Idiut</i> 2:3</a> (in a different version <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 2:3:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.2.3.2-3"><i>Sukkah</i> 2:3</a>). The main discussion in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 6b" href="/Eruvin.6b">Babli is <i>Eruvin</i> 6b</a>. The 24 instances of restrictions of the school of Hillel where the school of Shammai is more lenient are enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Eduyot 2:1-10" href="/Tosefta_Eduyot.2.1-10">Tosephta <i>Idiut</i> 2</a>. It is reported there that the most conscientious one of the followers of Shammai in the years before the destruction of the Temple, R. Yoḥanan ben Haḥoranit, followed the rulings of the school of Hillel in practice. The man who rebuilt Jewish learning after the destruction of the Temple, R. Yoḥanan ben Zakkai, was a student of Hillel.</i> it was said of anyone who wanted to restrict himself and follow the restrictions both of the school of Shammai and that of Hillel: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 2:14" href="/Ecclesiastes.2.14"><i>Eccl.</i> 2:14</a>) “the fool walks in darkness;” anyone who followed the leniencies of both of them<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">In the opinion of the Babli, only in the case of two leniencies whose theoretical bases contradict one another. Similarly, the fool is one who follows contradictory rigidities.</i> was called an evildoer. But one had to follow either the leniencies and restrictions of one school or the leniencies and restrictions of the other. That was before the divine voice was heard. But after the divine voice was heard<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">This is an explanation of the Tosephta, rather than a duplication of the earlier note on the Mishnah.</i>, practice always follows the school of Hillel and everyone who transgresses the rulings of the school of Hillel merits death. We have stated: “A divine voice came and said: Both of them are the words of the Living God but practice follows the school of Hillel”.<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">The same statement is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 6b" href="/Eruvin.6b">Babli <i>Eruvin</i> 6b</a>. The language is tannaïtic, but the origin of the phrase is unknown.</i> Where was the divine voice heard? Rebbi Bibi<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Since in Talmudic times every ב or בּ was pronounced /v/ in Galilee under the influence of Byzantine Greek, his name probably is a shortening of Latin Vivianus, חַיִּים. R. Bibi was one of the notable students of R. Yoḥanan.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: The divine voice came in Jabneh<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">The Synhedrion was at Jabneh between the two wars against the Romans and held there its first meeting when it was reconstituted after the persecutions that followed the war of Bar Kokhba. Afterwards, it moved to Galilee permanently. This gives a <i>terminus ad quem</i> for the adoption of the rules of the school of Hillel by all of Judaism. It seems that the exact point in time was the reconstitution of the Synhedrion after the war of Bar Kokhba.<br>While Talmudic literature is full of disagreements on practical points of Jewish practice, there is unanimity that the principles underlying all discussions are those fixed by the school of Hillel in Rabbinic (Pharisaic) Judaism. After the war of Bar Kokhba, we do not hear of any followers of the school of Shammai in practice, nor of Jews that are Sadducees in practice. In the Talmud (Babli <i>Nidda</i> 33b), R. Yose (ben Ḥalaphta) states that the Sadducees in his time follow Rabbinic practice. We know that the sect at Qumran were Sadducees and their <i>Tefillin</i> follow Sadducee rules; characteristically, they have many more Biblical quotes in addition to the required verses (cf. Y. Yadin, <i>Tefillin from Qumran</i>, Jerusalem, 1978). The <i>Tefillin</i> found with the Bar Kokhba letters in the caves of the Judean desert are of the same type. Hence, Sadducee practice did not completely stop until the war of Bar Kokhba. As far as Sadduceeism goes, its disappearance in practice can be dated to the aftermath of the war of Bar Kokhba.<br>It is not believable that a man of the stature of Rebbi Tarphon would transgress a generally accepted practice supported by a divine pronouncement and by popular consent. Hence, the episode of Rebbi Tarphon must be dated in time before the <i>bat qol</i>. It is generally accepted that Rebbi Tarphon did not live to see the war of Bar Kokhba. This narrows the time of the <i>bat qol</i> to close to that war.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> In the morning he offers two blessings before [the <i>Shema‘</i>] and one after. In the evening he offers two blessings before and two after, one long and one short. At a place where they<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">The men of the Great Assembly.</i> said to make it long he is not allowed to make it short, short he is not allowed to make it long. To seal<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">“To seal” means to start the last sentence of the benediction with the words “Praise to You, o Eternal, …”.</i> he is not allowed not to seal, not to seal he is not allowed to seal.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman: Because of<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">The reason is sought for benedictions before and after the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>. The first opinion, ascribed to an early Amora, gives the reason why the two recitations should be parallel and why each one has to include a benediction of thanks for the Torah, since the recitation of the <i>Shema‘</i> also helps to fulfill the obligation of Torah-study in a minimal way. The second opinion, by a late Amora in the name of one of the first ones, explains the asymmetry in the numbers since they must add up to the odd number of 7.<br>Since in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:6:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.6.2-11">Halakhah 9</a> (and in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 14b" href="/Berakhot.14b">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 14b</a>) it is reported that in Israel one did not recite the entire last section of <i>Shema‘</i> in the evening, Rebbi Simon also gives a reason for the asymmetry: In the evening one recites 4 benedictions and 2 sections, in the morning 3 benedictions and 3 sections, for a total of 6 morning and evening. In the next section it is clear that Rebbi Simon makes a distinction between the first two and the third sections of <i>Shema‘</i>, a distinction rejected by Rebbi Levi from the circle of Rebbi Yoḥanan.</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 1:8" href="/Joshua.1.8"><i>Jos.</i> 1:8</a>): “You should think about it day and night”, that the thinking of day and night should be equal. Rebbi Yose bar Rebbi Abin in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Because of (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 119:164" href="/Psalms.119.164"><i>Ps.</i> 119:164</a>): “Seven times a day I praise You for Your just laws.” Rebbi Nachman in the name of Rebbi Mani<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Usually, Rebbi Mani in the Yerushalmi is R. Mana the first, an Amora of the first generation. However, Rebbi Naḥman, the preacher, is an Amora of the last generation in Galilee, a student of Rebbi Mana the second. Hence, it is reasonable to assume that R. Mani here is R. Mana the second. However, since the late R. Yose bar Abin transmits in the name of the very early R. Joshua ben Levi, it is not impossible that the name of R. Mani is transmitted correctly.<br>The statement of R. Mani implies that anybody who recites <i>Shema‘</i> with its benedictions regularly, every evening and every morning, cannot be considered transgressing the obligation of Torah study even if he does not study otherwise. In contrast to the first two statements, this one has practical consequences.</i>: Everybody who keeps “seven times a day I praise you” is as if he kept also “you should think about it day and night”<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 99b" href="/Menachot.99b">Babli, <i>Menaḥot</i> 99b</a>, Rebbi Yoḥanan reports in the name of R. Simeon bar Yoḥai that reading the <i>Shema‘</i> alone is enough; no mention of the necessary benedictions.</i>.
Why does one read these two sections every day? Rebbi Simon says because they mention lying down and getting up. Rebbi Levi said, because the Ten Commandments are contained in them<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Since Rebbi Levi depends heavily on the third section of <i>Shema‘</i>, he cannot agree that in the evening one should recite only two sections. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 12b" href="/Berakhot.12b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 12b</a>), the third section of <i>Shema‘</i> is singled out for its importance because five of the Ten Commandments are alluded to in it.</i>. “I am the Eternal, your God.” - “Hear<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">As R. Shelomo ben Adrat (Rashba) points out, שמע can mean “hear, understand, or accept.”</i>, o Israel, The Eternal, our God.” “You should not have any other gods before me.” - “The Eternal is One.” “Do not take the name of the Eternal, your God, in vain.” - “You must love the Eternal, your God.” He who loves the king will not swear in his name and lie. “Remember the Sabbath day to sanctify it.” - “So that you shall remember;” Rebbi said: that is the commandment of Sabbath which is as important as all other commandments of the Torah together, as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 9:14" href="/Nehemiah.9.14"><i>Neh.</i> 9:14</a>): “You informed them about Your Sabbath, commandments, laws, and Torah you commanded them, …” to show that it is as important as the other commandments of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Sabbath alone is given a parallel status to “Torah” in this verse.</i>. “Honor your father and mother” - “So that your days and the days of your children should increase.<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">This promise is connected with honoring father and mother in the Ten Commandments of Deuteronomy.</i>” “Do not murder” - “You will soon be lost.” He who kills will be killed. “Do not commit adultery” - “Do not stray after your hearts and after your eyes.” Rebbi Levi said: heart and eye are the two agents of sin. It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 23:26" href="/Proverbs.23.26"><i>Prov.</i> 23:26</a>) “My son, give Me your heart; your eyes should watch My ways.” The Holy One, Praise to Him, says: If you give me your heart and eyes I know that you are mine<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">The connection seems to be from the following verse: “Because a dark ditch is the harlot and a source of trouble the strange woman.”</i>. “Do not steal” - “You shall harvest your grain,” not your neighbor’s grain<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">This contradicts the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 86a" href="/Sanhedrin.86a">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 86a</a>, that the Ten commandments forbid kidknapping, a capital crime like murder and adultery. The Babli’s opinion is found also in <i>Mekhilta deR. Ismael</i> (Jithro 5), which possibly was edited in the Academy of Rav in Babylonia. The same attitude as here, that all stealing is prohibited, is found in <i>Mekhilta deR. Simeon bar Yoḥai</i>, p. 153.</i>” “Do not testify against your neighbor as a false witness,” - “I am the Lord, your God.” And it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 10:10" href="/Jeremiah.10.10"><i>Jer.</i> 10:10</a>) “But the Lord is the God of truth.” What is truth? Rebbi Abun said: that (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 10:10" href="/Jeremiah.10.10"><i>Jer.</i> 10:10</a>) “He is God of life and king of the world.” Rebbi Levi said: The Holy One, praise to Him, said, if you gave false testimony against your neighbor, I count that against you as if you gave testimony against Me that I did not create heaven and earth<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">This argument is the base of Rashi’s commentary on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 14b" href="/Berakhot.14b"><i>Berakhot</i> 14b</a>, on the statement that one is required to end the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> with “the Eternal is the God of truth.” Rabbi Abun (Rabin) was a younger contemporary of R. Levi.</i>. “Do not covet your neighbor’s house” - “You shall write them on the doorposts of your house,” your house and not your neighbor’s house.
There it was stated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Tamid 5:1" href="/Mishnah_Tamid.5.1"><i>Tamid</i> Mishnah 5:1</a>): “The official in charge told them<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah deals with the details of the Temple service, in particular the prayers of the priests before the start of dawn and beginning of services. The official in charge was one of the small permanent staff of the Temple; the priests themselves were divided into 24 “watches”, one of which served in the Temple from the placing of new show-bread on the Sabbath to its removal the next week. These “watches” are remembered in several <i>kinnot</i> for the Ninth of Av.</i>: recite one benediction! and they recited one benediction.” What benediction did they recite? Rav Mattanah in the name of Samuel<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Rav Mattanah was a student of Samuel, the head of the Academy of Nahardea and representative of the Babylonian tradition in Talmudic studies.</i>: that is the benediction for the Torah. “Then they recited the Ten Commandments and the three sections of <i>Shema‘</i>.” Rebbi Ammi in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: that means that the benedictions are no obstacle<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is implied that the priests fulfilled their duty of reciting the <i>Shema‘</i>, it follows that the non-recitation of the benedictions preceding and following the <i>Shema‘</i> does not invalidate the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> itself.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 11b" href="/Berakhot.11b">Babli (11b</a>) has a totally different approach. First, they note that Rav Mattanah did not know what benediction was recited in the Temple and then they report that Rav Yehudah said in the name of Samuel that the second of the daily benedictions preceding the <i>Shema‘</i> was recited. Rebbi Ammi in the name of R. Simeon ben Laqish is quoted that “benedictions do not invalidate one another”, i. e., the recitation of the second before the first is not an obstacle. The essential difference is that for the Babli, the last benediction before <i>Shema</i>‘, which is praise for the Torah and its study, may take the place of the explicit benediction for the Torah (e. g., for somebody who came late to the Synagogue and is reciting that benediction before he had a chance to recite the benediction for the Torah), whereas the Yerushalmi requires two benedictions unless one starts studying after the recitation of the <i>Shema‘</i> without interruption; see below and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Berakhot 11b:10:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Berakhot.11b.10.1"><i>Tosaphot Berakhot</i> 11b, <i>s. v.</i> שכבר</a>.</i>. Rebbi Abba said: From here you cannot draw any inference because the Ten Commandments contain the essence of <i>Shema‘</i><sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Since the benedictions for the <i>Shema‘</i> were instituted for <i>Shema‘</i> only, they are not applicable to the Ten Commandments; hence, the Ten Commandments, if recited at the start of the service, require the benediction for the Torah. On the other hand, in the preceding section is was shown that <i>Shema‘</i> contains allusions to all of the Ten Commandments. Hence, <i>Shema‘</i> is in a sense a duplication of the Ten Commandments and a separate benediction would be out of place.</i>. Rav Mattanah and Rebbi Samuel ben Naḥman both say that it would have been logical to require that the Ten Commandments should be recited every day. Why does one not recite them? Because of the arguments of the Christians<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">מִין always denotes a Jewish Christian. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 12a" href="/Berakhot.12a">Babli (12a</a>) it is said that “the reading of the Ten Commandments was stopped because of the propaganda of the (Jewish) Christians.”</i>, that they should not say that only these were given to Moses at Sinai.
Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Yehudah bar Zebida<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the second generation, possibly a student of Rav in Babylonia. He is also the author of the parallel statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 12b" href="/Berakhot.12b">Babli (12b</a>). The statement of Rebbi Ḥuna is given in the Babli in the name of Rebbi Yose bar Abun. The reasons of Rebbi Yose bar Abun and Rebbi Eleazar in the Yerushalmi are missing in the Babli. The quotes in the Babli are all in the name of Galilean authorities.</i>: It would have been logical that one also would have to recite the chapter of Balaq and Balaam every day<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">The blessings of Balaam, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 23:7-24:25" href="/Numbers.23.7-24.25"><i>Num.</i> 23:7–24:25</a>.</i>. Why does one not recite it? Not to incommodate the public too much. Rebbi Ḥuna said, because it mentions lying down and standing up<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 23:24" href="/Numbers.23.24"><i>Num.</i> 23:24</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 24:9" href="/Numbers.24.9">24:9</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose bar Abun said, because it contains the Exodus and God’s kingdom<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 24:8" href="/Numbers.24.8"><i>Num.</i> 24:8</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 23:21" href="/Numbers.23.21">23:21</a>.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said, because it is written in the Torah, in the Prophets, and in the Hagiographs.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">In the Torah as indicated; in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Micah 6:5" href="/Micah.6.5">Prophets <i>Michah</i> 6:5</a>, in the Hagiographs <i>Neḥemiah</i> 13:2</i>
<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this piece would be introduced by גוּפא “let us return to our main theme.” Such a reference is always missing in the Yerushalmi. In the Babli, this argument is an anonymous tentative statement (12a). Rebbi Samuel, brother of Rebbi Berekhiah, is an Israeli Amora of the fourth generation. His brother, Rebbi Berekhiah, is one of the authors of the oldest sections of <i>Midrash Rabba</i>.</i>“The official in charge told them: recite one benediction! and they recited one benediction.” What benediction did they recite? Rav Mattanah in the name of Samuel: that is the benediction for the Torah. But they did not yet recite “Creator of the Lights!<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">The first benediction before the <i>Shema‘</i>, a celebration of God’s creation of the sun. The corresponding benediction in the evening is a celebration of God’s making the world revolve alternatingly into darkness and light.</i>” Rebbi Samuel, brother of Rebbi Berekhiah, said: there is no light yet and you want to recite “Creator of the Lights”?
(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Tamid 5:1" href="/Mishnah_Tamid.5.1"><i>Tamid</i> Mishnah 5:1</a>) On the Sabbath they add one benediction for the departing watch. What kind of benediction? Rebbi Ḥelbo<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">A Babylonian, student of Rav Huna and colleague of Rav Sheshet, who emigrated to Galilee and became student of Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman and Rebbi Ammi. He was the main teacher of Rebbi Berekhiah. His statement appears in the Babli in identical form (12a).</i> said, that is it: May He Who resides in the Temple plant among you brotherliness and love, peace and neighborliness.
Samuel said: If one got up early to study before he recited the <i>Shema‘</i> he has to recite the benediction. After the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> he does not have to recite the benediction. Rebbi Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">The opinion of the Yerushalmi is that the benediction before <i>Shema‘</i> is no substitute for the benediction on the Torah. The statement of Rebbi Abba, Babylonian immigrant to Israel, former student of Rav Yehudah, the student of Samuel, harmonizes Babylonian practice, expressed by Samuel, with Israeli theory by accepting the Babylonian practice but making it impracticable. על אתר is the same as Babylonian לאלתר “on the spot, immediately.”</i> said, that is only if he studied immediately. Rebbi Ḥuna<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">From the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 11b" href="/Berakhot.11b">Babli (11b</a>) and the order of statements it seems that “Rebbi” here in the Yerushalmi is a scribal error for Rav; the author of the statement is Rav Huna, the student of Rav from the family of the Resh Galuta. The discussion in the Babli is much more detailed, starting with the study of Scripture and going into the details of the sections of the Oral Law.</i> said: It is reasonable to say that for exegesis<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that here מדרש includes both exegesis of the Torah and exegesis of the Oral Law, anything that is not obvious either from a biblical verse or from a Mishnaic statement.</i> one has to recite the benediction, for practical rules<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Practical rules, הלכה, refers to the memorization of fixed statements which are immediately applicable, whether a Mishnah, Tosephta, or a deciding statement of an Amora.</i> one does not have to recite the benediction. Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Both for exegesis and for practical rules one has to recite the benediction. Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said: When we were sitting before Rav, he always required us to recite the benediction both for exegesis and for practical rules<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 11b" href="/Berakhot.11b">Babli (11b</a>), Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi, the student of Rav, notes that for his early morning class, Rav washed his hands, recited the benedictions, and proceded to teach the <i>Midrash Halakha</i> on the Torah, thus combining all aspects of Torah study. In the version of the Babli, the statement of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi is separate from the preceding discussion and seems to indicate that the different aspects of Torah study should not be separated, in contrast to the Yerushalmi version.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">A somewhat different version of this <i>baraita</i> is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 37b" href="/Yoma.37b">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 37b</a>.</i>: He who recites with the men of <i>Maämad</i><sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">The land of Israel was divided into 24 districts, corresponding to the 24 families of priests, and every week a select group of laymen from the district in charge of the week came to Jerusalem to be present at the sacrifices. Since public sacrifices were brought on behalf of the entire people, a sacrifice must be brought with its owners being present. The lay delegation, the <i>Men of Maämad</i>, were the representatives of the Jewish people at the daily sacrifices. Since these sacrifices started very early, the men of <i>Maämad</i> had to participate before they could hold their prayers. Therefore, they started their morning prayers only after the daily morning sacrifice was completed. By that time, it was later than three hours into daylight and anyone else would be too late in their recitation.</i> has not done his duty since they were too late. Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rebbi Ammi: In the days of Rebbi Yoḥanan we went out for a fast-day and recited <i>Shema‘</i> after three hours and he did not oppose us<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">In Israel, a fast day usually meant a day of fasting for rain. The services for these fast days were always held in the public square, therefore one had “to go out”. Also, the sermon was given before the start of prayers since a sermon after prayers would not do much good and on fastdays the regular service, with an extended <i>Amidah</i>, was said. By the time that a great many people were assembled and the sermon was given, it was rather late, later than three variable hours (one quarter of the time between sunrise and sundown).</i>. Rebbi Yose and Rebbi Aḥa went out for a fast-day. The public came and recited <i>Shema‘</i> after three hours. Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">The reading רב that is found in all printed editions and manuscripts is clearly a copyist’s error; the entire discussion is about rain fasts in Israel and only Israeli scholars are involved.</i> Aḥa wanted to oppose them. Rebbi Yose said to him: Did they not recite at its due time<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">At the time of the morning benedictions that were said at home, not in the synagogue.</i>, now they only recite it in order to stand in prayer after words of the Torah. He answered back: It is because of the uneducated, who should not say that the recitation was in its correct time<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">The disagreement between Rebbis Yose and Aḥa is not resolved in the Yerushalmi.</i>.
These are the benedictions that one makes long<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">In a different order (short, long, recognize) the statement is found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:6" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.6">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 1:6</a>. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:7" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.7">Tosephta 1:7</a>, the list of the short benedictions is repeated as that of benedictions which do not have a separate ending (where, however, Rebbi Yose Hagalili disagrees about the fourth benediction of Grace.) Towards the end of the <i>Halakhah</i> here, Rebbi Yudan will explain that <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:7" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.7">Tosephta 1:7</a> gives the definition of “short” in the Mishnah and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:6" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.6">Tosephta 1:6</a>; hence, it follows that “long” is identical with “having a separate ending: Praise to You, o Eternal, …” That identification has been accepted by most Medieval authorities.<br>However, originally the definition seems to have been the one given here and in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:6" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.6">Tosephta 1:6</a>, <i>viz.</i>, that there exist benedictions, those of <i>Musaph</i> of <i>Rosh Hashanah</i>, all prayers of <i>Yom Kippur</i> with the Confessions, and the additional benedictions in the prayer of a public fast for rain (a lengthened Seventh benediction followed by six additional ones, detailed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.2.4.1">Mishnah <i>Taänit</i> 2:4</a>) which were not those of the congregation, but of the cantor who in Israel at that time was supposed to present his own compositions, and those of the list had to be long. Then there exists a short list of short benedictions that may not be lengthened by poetic insertion. And finally, there exist the benedictions not mentioned here at all, like the benedictions before and after the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>, where it seems the cantor may produce poetic insertions without being characterized either as scholar or as uneducated.</i>: the benedictions for <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> and <i>Yom Kippur</i>, and the benedictions for a public fast day. From his benedictions one can tell whether someone is a scholar or is uneducated. These are the benedictions that one makes short: He who makes a benediction over a commandment and on fruits, the introductory paragraph of Grace<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Some Medieval authors (e. g. <i>Sefer Hamanhig</i>, <i>Hilkhot Seüdah</i>, #16) read “the benediction over food (מזון)” instead of <i>zimmun</i> (זימון), the introductory paragraph. This reading would explain the seemingly redundant “Grace after a meal” but is it not supported by any manuscript either of the Yerushalmi or the Tosephta. <i>Sefer</i><i>Hamanhig</i> explains this “benediction over food (מזון)” as the benediction <i>before</i> the meal.</i>, and the last benediction in Grace after the meal<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">The last benediction was originally only “Praise to You, o Lord, King of the Universe, Who is good and does good” (<i>Talmid Rabbenu Yonah</i>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 36a" href="/Berakhot.36a"><i>Alfassi Berakhot</i> 36a</a>). The extensions that today make the benediction short in form but long in text are mainly of Babylonian origin; cf. the discussion in the author’s <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah</i>, pp. 358–359.</i>. Hence, all other benedictions one should make long. Ḥizqiah<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">One of the twin sons of Rebbi Ḥiyya, collaborator of Rebbi Yehudah the Prince.</i> said: From what we have stated: He who makes it long is despicable, he who makes is short is praiseworthy, which means that this is not a principle<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">The benedictions not mentioned may be enlarged by poetic insertions but do not have to be long.</i>. We have stated: One has to make long the benediction “Who saves Israel” on a fast day<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">With poetic or Biblical insertions.</i>. Hence<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Since the next six benedictions are not mentioned in this <i>baraita</i>.</i>, the six additional benedictions he should not make long. Rebbi Yose said: You should not say: because this is part<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Of the everyday prayers. One has to assume that Rebbi Yose would classify the קרובץ insertions on Purim as short.</i> of <i>Shemoneh Esreh</i> one should not make it long, therefore it is necessary to say: One has to make long the benediction “Who saves Israel” on a fast day.
These are the benedictions for which one bows down<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Here one does not talk about the recitation of the <i>Shema‘</i> and its benedictions at all but about the eighteen benedictions of the <i>Amidah</i>, the subject of Chapters 3 and 4. In the Babli, the place of this discussion is in Chap. 4, p. 34a. The reason that the subject is taken up in this context in the Yerushalmi is that in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:8" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.8">Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 1:8</a>) it is dealt with immediately after the discussion of short and long benedictions. (In Tosephta and Babli, the verb “to bow down” is שחה, not שחח as in the Yerushalmi. This is another indication that the Tosephta in our hands today is a Babylonian edition of an originally Israeli text.)</i>: The first<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">At the very start of <i>Shemone Esre</i> and before the benediction “Shield of Abraham.”</i>, beginning and end; “thanks”, beginning and end. One who bows down for every benediction is taught that he should not bow down<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Either because he imitates behavior reserved for the High Priest or because he is ostentatious in his religiosity, an objectionable behavior.</i>. Rebbi Isaac bar Naḥman<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">One of the students of R. Joshua ben Levi in the early Talmudic period.</i> in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: The High Priest bows down at the end of every benediction; the king at the start and the end of every benediction. Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Once the king bows down deeply he does not get up until he finishes his entire prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">The origin of this short insertion is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 5:4:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.5.4.2-4"><i>Sukkah</i> 5:4</a> where it is reported that Rabban Gamliel, on occasion of the joyous dance for the drawing of water on Sukkot not only had a fire dance with eight different torches swirling in the air but also showed “bowing down to one’s knees” as making a push-up by supporting oneself not on two hands but only on two fingers. This introduction has fallen out here and the two termsכריצה, בריכה have been switched. What the Yerushalmi calls בריכה, the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 22b" href="/Megillah.22b">Babli (<i>Megillah</i> 22b</a>, also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 34b" href="/Berakhot.34b"><i>Berakhot</i> 34b</a>) calls קידה, “falling on one’s face”.</i>. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 8:54" href="/I_Kings.8.54"><i>1Kings</i> 8:54</a>) “It was when Solomon finished all this prayer and supplication to the Eternal, he got up before the Eternal’s altar and did no longer bow down on his knees.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">The origin of this short insertion is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 5:4:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.5.4.2-4"><i>Sukkah</i> 5:4</a> where it is reported that Rabban Gamliel, on occasion of the joyous dance for the drawing of water on Sukkot not only had a fire dance with eight different torches swirling in the air but also showed “bowing down to one’s knees” as making a push-up by supporting oneself not on two hands but only on two fingers. This introduction has fallen out here and the two termsכריצה, בריכה have been switched. What the Yerushalmi calls בריכה, the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 22b" href="/Megillah.22b">Babli (<i>Megillah</i> 22b</a>, also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 34b" href="/Berakhot.34b"><i>Berakhot</i> 34b</a>) calls קידה, “falling on one’s face”.</i> What is bowing down to one’s knees and what is kneeling? The great Rebbi Ḥiyya demonstrated kneeling before Rebbi, he got up lame and was healed. Rebbi Levi ben Sisi demonstrated bowing down to his knees before Rebbi, he got up lame and was not healed.
(<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 8:54" href="/I_Kings.8.54"><i>1Kings</i> 8:54</a>) “His hands raised to Heaven.”<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">This is the end of the verse quoted earlier for Solomon’s prayer. The text of the Venice edition here is inferior to that of the Rome manuscript that has been followed. (In the Venice print: הזהיר is missing, נטפו for ינטפו.) As Levy recognized, נטף is the same as טנף.</i> Rebbi Ayvu said: He was standing as if inanimate. Rebbi Eleazar bar Avina said: He made clear that these palms did not get at all dirty during the building of the Temple<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">He seems to emphasize that Solomon raised his “open hands”, not his “hands”, to show that from all the riches that David had assembled for the building of the Temple (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 29:1-9" href="/I_Chronicles.29.1-9"><i>1Chr.</i> 29:1–9</a>) not a penny was sticking to his own palms.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥalaphta ben Shaül<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the first generation in Israel who occasionally is quoted as a Tanna. His opinion is the only one given here, to the effect that one has to bow down at <i>modim</i>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 34b" href="/Berakhot.34b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 34b</a>) quotes that Rava, Rav Naḥman and Rav Sheshet actually fell down on their knees for <i>modim</i>; the Talmud quotes a <i>baraita</i> which explicitly forbids falling down on one’s knees. Louis Ginzberg assumes that in Israel, falling on one’s knees was always strictly forbidden since their synagogues were built of stone with stone floors and falling on one’s knees on a stone floor outside the Temple is forbidden. In Babylonia, where synagogues were brick with hardened dirt floors, falling on one’s knees was permitted.</i> stated: Everybody bows down with the cantor for the benediction of thanksgiving. Rebbi Zeïra said: But only for the word <i>modim</i>. Rebbi Zeïra was attentive to the Qeroba<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Qeroba</i> is the cantor, the שליח ציבור, who presents his own poetic <i>offering</i> of the prayer, the <i>qerovut</i>, קרובות or קרובץ, to the congregation for the repetition of the <i>Amidah</i>, as noted by L. Ginzberg. סבר here seems to mean “to be attentive”, as in the exclamation before the <i>qiddush</i> סברי “please pay attention”.<br>It seems that Rebbi Zeïra timed his thanksgiving, one of the longer texts given here, so he could end his benediction in unison with the cantor.</i> to bow his head at the beginning and at the end. Rebbi Yose when he came up here<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">“Coming up” means making <i>aliyah</i> from Babylonia to Israel. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 40a" href="/Sotah.40a">Babli (<i>Soṭa</i> 40a</a>) also reports very short texts by Rav, Samuel, Rebbi Simai (also of the generation between Tannaïm and Amoraïm) and a slightly longer one by Rav Aḥa bar Jacob (a student of Rav Huna, the student of Rav). Most of these texts are so short that they do not lead to the congregation whispering for any length of time.</i> saw them bowing down and whispering. He said to them: What is this whispering? He had not heard what Rebbi Ḥelbo, Rebbi Simeon said in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan, in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">A Tanna of the last generation, student of R. Yehudah ben Batyra.</i>, Rebbi Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi Miasha<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">One of the first Tannaïm with the title of “Rebbi”, from the last times of the Second Temple.</i>, Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Simai, and some say, the colleagues<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">The collective of scholars in the Yeshivah.</i> in the name of Rebbi Simai: We thank You, Master of all creatures, God of praises, eternal Rock, Life of the Universe, Creator, Who resurrects the dead, that You have made us alive, kept us, gave us merit, supported us, and brought us near to give thanks to Your name; praised be You, o Eternal, God of thanksgiving. Rebbi Abba bar Zavda<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">An Israeli Amora who received his training in the Babylonian academy of Rav.</i> in the name of Rav: We thank You since we are obliged to give thanks; may my lips sing, for I shall sing to You with my soul that You have redeemed; praised are You, o Eternal, God of thanksgiving. Rebbi Samuel bar Inia<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Rebbi Aḥa, Israeli Amora of the fourth generation. The name of his father cannot be determined with certainty; the form given here is from the Rome manuscript. In the Venice print it appears as Mina, at other places in the Yerushalmi it appears as Ina, ldi, Bina, Yonah, Yanna, Yannai. The fourth generation of Galilean Amoraïm saw the Roman empire become Christian and lived through the first persecutions that finally forced the following generation to abandon the work on the Jerusalem Talmud.</i> in the name of Rebbi Aḥa: Thanksgiving and praise to Your name, Yours is greatness, Yours is strength, Yours is glory! May it please You, o Eternal, our God and God of our fathers, that You may support us in our fall, straighten us up from our bent state, because You support the falling and straighten up the bent ones, You are full of mercy and nothing exists except You; praised are You, o Eternal, God of thanksgiving. Bar Qappara<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">A contemporary of Rebbi who also made his own compilation of Mishnayot. His full name was R. Eleazar, son of R. Eleazar the Qappar. Since his name is identical to that of his father it is clear that he was a posthumous child; cf. E. and H. Guggenheimer, <i>Jewish Family Names and Their Origins</i>, Ktav 1992, <i>Etymologisches Lexikon der jüdischen Familiennamen,</i> München 1996, both p. xviii.<br>While the previous texts were quoted in historical order, the text of Bar Qappara should have been the first. The reason may be his extensive use of Biblical verses that were a matter of controversy, see below (and in all Yerushalmi versions this is a formal benediction.)</i> said: For You we fall down, for You we bend down, for You we prostrate ourselves, for You we kneel, to You every knee should fall down and every tongue swears. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 29:11-13" href="/I_Chronicles.29.11-13"><i>1Chr.</i> 29:11–13</a>): Yours, o Eternal, is greatness, strength, glory, victory, and majesty, truly all that is in heaven and on earth; Yours, o Eternal, is the kingdom, and You lift Yourself over all as head. Riches and honor are before You, You rule over all; in Your hand is power and strength, it is in Your hand to make great and strengthen everything. And now, our God, we thank You and praise Your glorious name; with all our heart and soul we prostrate ourselves before You. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 35:10" href="/Psalms.35.10"><i>Ps.</i> 35:10</a>) My entire self shall say: O Eternal, who is like You, Who saves the destitute from one who is stronger than he is, the destitute and poor from the one who robs him. Praised are You, o Eternal, God of thanksgiving. Rebbi Yudan said: the rabbis used to say all of these<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Statement of Rav Papa in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 40a" href="/Sotah.40a">Babli <i>Soṭa</i> 40a</a>. It appears from here that Rav Papa (fifth generation in Babylonia) had good precedent for his ruling from Rebbi Yudan (fourth generation in Israel). The method of Rebbi Yudan/Rav Papa is more adequate to a collection of short statements as given in the Babli than to the very long pieces quoted here in the Yerushalmi.</i>. But some say, either one or the other.
We have stated: Only that one should not bow down too much<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">After the digression about the text of the private prayer during <i>modim</i>, the discussion now returns to the statement that one has to bow twice at the beginning and the end of the <i>Amidah</i>.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah said: On condition that one should not behave like that large lizard<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">Arabic חַרְד̇וֹן, חִרְד̇וֹן “large lizard”. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Berakhot 12b" href="/Tosafot_on_Berakhot.12b">Tosafot <i>Berakhot</i> 12b</a> in the Venice print quote this Yerushalmi as הירוגא and declares it to be the Yerushalmi translation of צָב (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 11:29" href="/Leviticus.11.29"><i>Lev.</i> 11:29</a>). In the Wilna Talmud Babli, the word was changed to הרדונא following our text. In the <i>Targum Yerushalmi</i> (<i>Pseudo</i>-<i>Jonathan</i>), the translation of צב is חַדְרוֹנָא. It seems that the <i>Targum Yerushalmi</i> takes Hebrew צב as parallel to Arabic צַ֗בּ “lizard” (of all sizes), not as “turtle” as in late Biblical and modern Hebrew.<br>Rebbi Jeremiah means that, while one should not bow down too much, on the other hand one should not behave like a lizard which keeps its body quiet and moves only the head when it is catching flies. He requires that one should bow down enough so that all bones of one’s spine are moved in God’s praise.</i>, but (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 35:10" href="/Psalms.35.10"><i>Ps.</i> 35:10</a>) “All my bones should say, o Eternal, who is like You?” The word of Ḥanan bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Ḥanan bar Abba appears in the Babli as Rav Ḥanan bar Rava, son-in-law of Rav and father-in-law of Rav Ḥisda. He disagrees with those who bow down at <i>modim</i> and remain bowed to the end of their private supplication, even though he formulates his statement in terms of the first benediction of <i>Shemone Esreh</i> which starts and ends with “Praised are You, <i>Hashem</i>”, but his statement is applicable to all other situations, that one never should be bowed when mentioning the Name.</i> disagrees since Ḥanan bar Abba said to the colleagues: I shall tell you one of the good things that I saw Rav do and, when I told it before Samuel, he got up and kissed me on my mouth. At “praised are You”, he bows down. When he comes to mention <i>Hashem</i>, he straightens up. Samuel said: I shall give the reason (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 35:10" href="/Psalms.35.10"><i>Ps.</i> 35:10</a>): “The Eternal straightens the bent ones.” Rebbi Ammi<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Since Rebbi Ammi and Rebbi Abun the first (Ravin) were contemporaries, R. Abun here is the first, not his posthumous son of the same name. Rebbi Ammi also is the contemporary of R. Ḥiyya bar Abba mentioned in the next section and, as successor of R. Yoḥanan as head of the Yeshivah of Tiberias, he is the higher authority.</i> said: It is not reasonable, but (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Malachi 2:5" href="/Malachi.2.5"><i>Mal.</i> 2:5</a>): “Before My Name he is low.”<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">The verse in Maleachi refers to Levi, son of Jacob, or Aharon, the High Priest. Most commentators of Psalms, including Rashi, derive נחת from the root חתת “to tremble” but the Amoraïm take it as derived from (Aramaic) נחת “to descend”.</i> Rebbi Abun said: If it were written “at My Name he is low” then you would be right, but it is written “before My Name he is low”, before he mentions <i>Hashem</i> he is low.
Rebbi Samuel bar Nathan<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">A student of R. Ḥama bar Ḥanina, the son of R. Ḥanina ben Ḥama of the generation of Rebbi. Since Rebbi Yoḥanan did know Rebbi Samuel bar Nathan in his old age, it follows that the two stories are complementary, not that there is a difference of opinion on who removed the cantor because of his excessive bowing. It is clear that we are talking about a cantor because only he can be removed from office by the Rabbi. This does not imply that any congregant would be allowed to bow down too much, only that he cannot be removed. This is the interpretation of Maimonides (<i>Hilkhot Tefillah</i> 9:4, see <i>Kesef Mishneh</i> on that text).<br>It is difficult to decide the opinion of the Yerushalmi about whether in practice one removes or simply scolds such a cantor since Rebbi Ammi is in general the higher authority but Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba is quoted in the last, preferred, position.</i> in the name of Rebbi Ḥama bar Ḥanina: It happened that one bowed down too much and Rebbi removed him. Rebbi Ammi said, Rebbi Yoḥanan did remove. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said, he did not remove but scold.
These are the benedictions one begins with “Praised”. All benedictions one begins with “Praised”, but a benediction following another one, e. g., the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> and <i>Amidah</i>, one does not begin with “Praised”.<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">This statement exists in two additional versions. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 46a" href="/Berakhot.46a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 46a</a>) it reads: All benedictions one begins with “Praised” except for benedictions over fruits, obligations, benedictions following another one and the last benediction of the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 1:9" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).1.9">Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 1:9</a>) it reads: All benedictions one begins with “Praised” except for benedictions following another one and the last benediction of the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>.<br>The versions of the Tosephta and the Babli are essentially identical, except that the Babli for completeness includes the short benedictions of one sentence for the execution of a <i>mitzwah</i> and for eating food, whose form otherwise is taken for granted. The main difference between the Babli/Tosephta and the Yerushalmi is that the last benediction for the <i>Shema‘</i>, the one recited after <i>Shema‘</i>, is considered by the Yerushalmi to be the continuation of the second benediction before <i>Shema‘</i> but for the Babli it needs special mention. The consequence is that for the Yerushalmi all prayer benedictions separated by Scriptural readings from a preceding benediction are considered consecutive (the benedictions after the morning Psalms and <i>Hallel</i>) whereas for the Babli each one needs special treatment. The first objection to the rule given in the next paragraph is therefore impossible for the Babli.</i>
Rebbi Jeremiah objected: But there is “redemption”<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">The answer shows that the question is about the benediction at the end of the recitation of the <i>Haggadah</i> in the <i>Seder</i> night: “Praised are You, o Eternal, our God, King of the Universe, Who has redeemed us and has redeemed our forefathers from Egypt and let us attain this night to eat <i>mazzah</i> and bitter herbs. May it please You, o Eternal, our God and God of our fathers, to let us attain in peace more festive seasons and holidays, when we shall rejoice in the rebuilding of Your city and enjoy Your service. There we shall eat from the family offerings and the <i>pesaḥ</i> sacrifice whose blood shall reach the wall of Your altar for goodwill. Then we shall thank You with a new song for our redemption and the liberation of our persons. Praise be to You, o Eternal, Who did save Israel.”<br>This benediction follows the recitation of the first two Psalms of <i>Hallel</i>. It is clear from here, and from the parallel in the last Chapter of Yerushalmi <i>Pesaḥim</i> that in Israel in Talmudic times one preceded the recitation of <i>Hallel</i> by a benediction (the details are discussed in the author’s <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah</i>, pp. 317–318). Hence, by the principle of the Yerushalmi, this benediction should not start with “Praised”.</i>. There is a difference since Rebbi Yoḥanan said<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 9:7:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.9.7.2"><i>Pesaḥim</i> 9:1,</a> fol. 37c. In Galilee there existed congregations which were illiterate except for the cantor, where no one could recite the <i>Hallel</i> or the entire <i>Haggadah</i> at home. For these people it was instituted that <i>Hallel</i> should be recited in the synagogue after evening prayers (with its benedictions before and after); then the people could go home and just recite the benediction for redemption, drink four cups and go to bed. The text there seems to imply that the required recital of the Exodus likewise was read to them in the synagogue. The generally accepted implication of this and the following arguments is that any benediction which under some circumstances could be recited by itself has the status of a benediction that is not following another one (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 36a" href="/Berakhot.36a"><i>Rashba</i> on Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 36a</a>).</i>: If he heard <i>Hallel</i> in the synagogue he has fulfilled his obligation. Rebbi Eleazar, the son of Rebbi Yose, objected before Rebbi Yose, but there is its ending.<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">There is much controversy about the meaning of this question; every commentator has another interpretation. In the author’s opinion, this is a complete parallel to the identical question asked later for <i>Qiddush</i> and refers simply to the concluding statement “Praise be to You, o Eternal, Who did save Israel.” Since this follows the entire text, it certainly is a benediction following another one, so why does it repeat “Praise be to You, o Eternal”?</i> He said to him: there are two, one for the future and one for the past.<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">A statement of Rava in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 117b" href="/Pesachim.117b">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 117b</a> notes that the benediction for redemption after <i>Shema‘</i> and in the <i>Haggadah</i> is גאל ישׂראל but that in the <i>Amidah</i> prayer is גואל ישׂראל. The same formulation, גאל ישׂראל, is found in the Mishnah <i>Pesaḥim</i> and is followed by the <i>Haggadah</i> texts with the exception of the Yemenite ones. The unvocalized text of Mishnah and Talmud is read גָּאַל יִשְׂרָאֵל in the past tense. Then Rebbi Yose’s statement makes sense. Since the text concentrates on the future after a perfunctory mention of the past, the conclusion by a benediction for the past is a change of theme and, therefore, the concluding phrase has to be considered a separate benediction. [Rebbi Yose belongs to those authorities who require that the topic of the final benediction should be repeated <i>immediately</i> before the final sentence. His opinion is superseded here by that of Rebbi Mana later in the discussion but is taken up again by Rebbi Aḥa.]<br>The very conservative Yemenite tradition, strictly based on the Babli, cannot be expected to disregard a prescription of that Talmud. Hence, it is possible that Rava did read גָּאֵל יִשְׂרָאֵל, a <i>pa’el</i> form of the present [cf. S. Morag, בנין פָּאֵל וּבנין נִתְפָּאֵל, <i>Tarbiẓ 26</i>(1957), 349–356 and the material quoted in the author’s <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah</i>, p. 322.] The Yerushalmi here shows that the Israeli reading was גָּאַל יִשְׂרָאֵל. Hence, identical (consonantal) wording in Babli and Yerushalmi does not necessarily imply same text and same meaning. Since Italian and Northern European Jewry obtained their prayer texts from Israel, probably in the Mishnaic period, it is the rule that their prayer texts follow Yerushalmi sources.</i>
They objected: There is <i>Havdalah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Havdalah</i> benediction at the end of the Sabbath is preceded by benedictions over wine, spices, and light. These are all short sentences and it is universally agreed that they should start with “praise”. The only problem is the <i>Havdalah</i> benediction itself, which follows the other ones. The answer is that the benedictions over spices and fire are recited in order only for convenience, not out of necessity, and that Rebbi did recite them separately. Hence, <i>Havdalah</i> is a potentially freestanding benediction, but it follows always the benediction for wine. The objection based on this is not raised, but it will be raised for <i>Qiddush</i> and the answer given there also applies here. It is explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 54a" href="/Pesachim.54a">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i>54a</a> that Rebbi was collecting the other benedictions on the cup for his family, not for himself.</i> There is a difference since Rebbi Abba bar Zavda said that Rebbi was dispersing them and collecting them on the cup. The great Rebbi Ḥiyya was collecting them<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">Being a Babylonian, he never gave up Babylonian practices even though he spent his life in Galilee.</i>.
They objected: There is <i>Nevarekh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">The introductory section of Grace after meals, known as ברכת הזימוּן, “the benediction of preparation”. This introductory paragraph is recited only when at least three people are eating together who are obliged to recite Grace in the same degree of obligation. Hence, Grace itself must start with “Praised”.</i> There is a difference, because if there were two sitting together and eating they would not say <i>Nevarekh</i>. There is “He Who feeds all”<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">This is the concluding benediction of the first paragraph of Grace; the question is parallel to that asked for the concluding paragraphs of “redemption” and <i>Qiddush</i>. The lack of an answer here is provisional; the final answer of the Amoraïm of the last Galilean generation covers all these cases.</i>; that is difficult.
There is “He Who is good and does good”<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">The fourth section of Grace that clearly follows the third but nevertheless starts with “Praised”. The answer is that the first three sections constitute Grace as required by the Torah, while the fourth starts Rabbinic Grace.</i>. There is a difference since Rav Ḥuna said: When permission was received to bury the slain of Bethar, “He Who is good and does good” was fixed, “He Who is good” because they did not rot, “He Who does good” because permission was received to bury them.
There is <i>Qiddush</i><sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">The main benediction follows the benediction over wine (or over bread) and, nevertheless, starts with “Praised”. The answer is that <i>Qiddush</i> during a meal does not require the benediction over wine even though there is an interruption in the meal since one is forbidden to eat and drink after sundown Friday night before making <i>Qiddush</i>. The Babli does not take up this question, hence practice follows this Yerushalmi, <i>Shulḥan Arukh Oraḥ Ḥayyim</i> 271, Sec. 4. The <i>Qiddush</i> starts with “praised” and its final sentence again starts with “praised.”</i>. There is a difference since if one was sitting and drinking when it still was day and the holy day came upon him, he does not say “Creator of the fruit of the vine.” But there is its final sentence? Rebbi Mana said, the type<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">Greek τύπος, “pattern, model, prescribed form”. Rebbi Mana was a student of Rebbi Yudan who uses the Hebrew מטבע “coin” for “form”. The students of Rebbi Mana were the collectors of the Yerushalmi in the form it came down to us. Hence, his answer is final: All long benedictions end with “Praise to You, o Eternal, …” as a matter of principle (going back to the Men of the Great Assembly). Between this sentence and the next, a “since” should be mentally interpolated.</i> of benedictions is like that. Rebbi Yudan said: A short form starts with “Praised” and does not end with “Praised”, a long form starts with “Praised” and ends with “Praised”.
All benedictions after their seals<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">This is a continuing discussion of the statement of Rebbi Yudan. The “seal” of a longer benediction is the last sentence “Praise to You, o Eternal, …” It is stated that this “seal” is what makes the benediction valid and it cannot be a Biblical verse.</i>; one does not say a verse as benediction. Rebbi Isaac ben Rebbi Eleazar objected before Rebbi Yose: Because you say after their seals, one does not say a verse as benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Since the two statements appear together in one <i>baraita</i>, there should be a logical connection between them but there seems to be none.</i>? They said, that young man is intelligent because he thinks! What is the meaning of “after their seals”? It is that when he was standing in the morning prayer and forgot and mentioned the text of evening prayers but he caught himself and finished with the text of morning prayers, then he did his duty<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">“They” are the members of Rebbi Yose’s Yeshivah. They do not disagree with the rule which they state, but they note that the <i>baraita</i> does not deal with it; its correct interpretation is by Rebbi Aḥa.<br>About the rule itself, there is disagreement between the Yerushalmi and the parallel <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 12a" href="/Berakhot.12a">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 12a</a>, where it is stated: “If in the morning one started with ‘Creator of light’ and ended with ‘Making evenings dark’, he did not do his duty. If in the evening he starts with ‘He Who makes evenings dark’ and ends with ‘Creator of light’, he did not do his duty. But if he started with ‘Creator of light’ and ended with ‘Making evenings dark’, he did his duty. The principle is: Everything is determined by the seal.” The Babli asserts that if in evening prayers one started out wrongly with the text appropriate for morning prayers then everything is O.K. if only the final doxology is correct. But the Yerushalmi speaks of one “who is standing in morning prayers and forgot”, i. e., that he started out correctly, forgot himself in the middle, and remembered in time to close with the correct text. The principles of prayer texts were instituted by the Men of the Great Assembly. They determined the contents of the prayers but not, in general, their texts. (For the <i>Amidah</i>, the Mishnah even reports that Rebbi Eliezer says that one who repeats the same text for more than 30 days cannot really be an honest supplicant). The question is whether, in addition to the contents, the Men of the Great Assembly only determined the “seals” (following the Babli) or also the introductory sentences (following the Yerushalmi).</i>. Rebbi Aḥa said, all benedictions in the kind of their seals.<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">The language is difficult. R. Eleazar Askari explains that Rebbi Aḥa insists that only the “seal” counts and, therefore, the text preceding the “seal” is unimportant; the text of the “seal” cannot be a verse. R. Shelomo Cirillo and R. Moshe ben Ḥabib explain, on the contrary, that the “seal” must fit the text of the benediction just preceding and that this text cannot be a verse. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 104a" href="/Pesachim.104a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 104a</a>) this principle is spelled out only for <i>Havdalah</i> [and in the Yerushalmi the treatment given for <i>Havdalah</i>, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 5:2:2-16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.5.2.2-16"><i>Berakhot</i> 5:2</a>, fol. 9b) supports R. Eleazar Askari.] Most Medieval authorities extend the principle of the Babli to all longer benedictions.</i> But those who say (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 12:6" href="/Isaiah.12.6"><i>Is.</i> 12:6</a>): “Jubilate and sing, inhabitant of Zion …” do not violate the rule that no benediction is a verse<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Ezra Fleischer (<i>Tarbiẓ</i> 41, p. 450) has published a Yerushalmi prayer text from the Cairo Genizah which uses this verse in the third benediction of the ‘<i>Amidah</i>, קדושת השם. From what is left of the original Galilean <i>minhag</i> it seems clear that the standard text of longer benedictions always ended with a Biblical verse just preceding the “seal”. For example, in Grace, the verses were <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 145:16" href="/Psalms.145.16"><i>Ps.</i> 145:16</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:10" href="/Deuteronomy.8.10"><i>Deut.</i><i>8:10</a></i>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 147:2" href="/Psalms.147.2">Ps. 147:2</a>. In the morning prayers, the verses have survived in the first benediction for <i>Shema‘</i> in all <i>minhagim</i> and for the benediction after <i>Shema‘</i> in most of them. The text states that the only acceptable place for a Biblical verse is <i>before</i> the “seal”. Even the Mishnah prescribes benedictions whose text is a Biblical verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 2:2:2-14" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.2.2.2-14"><i>Taäniot</i> 2:2</a>); what is prohibited here is using a verse in the final doxology.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One must mention the Exodus in the night. Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">A descendant of Ezra in the tenth generation who was appointed vice president of the Synhedrion at age 18 (according to the Babli) or 13 (Yerushalmi).</i> said to them<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">Neither the Mishnah in the Babli nor manuscripts of the Mishnah have “to them”; in the <i>Haggadah</i> the Yerushalmi text is preserved only in the text of Maimonides and the Yemenite <i>Haggadot</i>. Nevertheless, the phrase cannot refer to the discussion at Bne Beraq reported in the <i>Haggadah</i>. As R. Saul Lieberman points out, the Yerushalmi takes R. Eleazar ben Azariah at his word that he made his statement when he was close to 70 years old and it is quite impossible that R. Eliezer should still have been alive at least 50 years after the deposition of Rabban Gamliel and the elevation of Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah. The most likely interpretation is that the Israeli <i>Haggadah</i>, but not the Mishnah, read “to them” and that the copyist of the Yerushalmi followed his memory from the <i>Haggadah</i> instead of the text before him. For a similar occurrence in the Septuagint, see <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah</i>, p. 257–258.</i>: Here I am about 70 years old and I could not succed in proving that the Exodus must be mentioned every night<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">Everybody agrees that the third benediction of the <i>Shema‘</i> and the mention of the Exodus are obligatory as an institution of the Men of the Great Assembly. The only question is whether the benediction was instituted as a Rabbinic ordinance or was formulated in fulfillment of a Biblical commandment.</i> until Ben Zoma<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">A mystic of the first generation of Tannaïm who died young.</i> derived it from the verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 16:3" href="/Deuteronomy.16.3"><i>Deut.</i> 16:3</a>): “… that you should remember the day of your leaving Egypt the entire days of your life.” The days of your life - the days. The entire days of your life - the nights. But the Sages say, the days of your life - this world; The entire days of your life - this includes the times of the Messiah.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Even though he entered high office he lived long. This means that high office shortens one’s life.
There<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">“There” always means Babylonia; “here” is the Land of Israel.</i> they say one should not start <i>wayyomer</i><sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">The third section of the <i>Shema‘, Num.</i> 15:37–41. This is the only part of <i>Shema‘</i> that mentions the Exodus. The statement of “there” is reported in the Babli by Rav Cahana in the name of Rav (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 14b" href="/Berakhot.14b"><i>Berakhot</i> 14b</a>).</i> but if one did start he has to finish. The rabbis here<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">The Israeli practice is reported in the Babli (loc. cit.) as reciting only the first and last sentences of the section; our text also requires one to start, i.e., to recite the first verse, and to mention the Exodus, the last words of the last verse.</i> say one starts but does not finish. The Mishnah disagrees with the rabbis here<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">Both R. David Oppenheim and R. Moshe ben Ḥabib note that in this section and the next, “here” and “there” should be switched since the first question is against those who say that one does not have to recite the third section at all, against the Babylonian practice, and the <i>baraita</i> in the next section seems to imply that one does not mention the third section at all, against Israeli practice.</i>: “One must mention the Exodus in the night.” Rebbi Abba, Rav Yehudah in the name of Rav: We thank You that You took us out of Egypt and redeemed us from the house of slavery to give thanks to Your Name.<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">This is the proposed text of the evening benediction after the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>. It is the answer to the objection raised in the first sentence. The obligation of mentioning the Exodus does not refer to the recitation of the third section of <i>Shema‘</i> but to the benediction after the <i>Shema‘</i> and, therefore, would be fulfilled even if the third section were to be omitted completely. The text in the Babli is longer.</i> A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with the rabbis there: <i>Wayyomer</i> is used only during daytime. The entire section of <i>wayyomer</i> is used only during daytime<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote">But in the night one recites only first and last verses.</i>.
Rebbi Abba bar Aḥa<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">An early Israeli Amora who went to study in Babylonia, probably in the Yeshivah of Rav. Hence, he did not know of the rule established by Rav before he arrived at the Yeshivah.</i> descended there and saw them start and finish; he had not heard that there they say one does not have to start but if he started he has to finish. The rabbis here<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is superfluous here, it is inserted only in parallel to the previous section. This is frequent in the Yerushalmi and not a sign of dittography.</i> say one starts and does not finish.
They asked before Rebbi Aḥiyya ben Rebbi Zeïra: How did your father do in practice, like the teachers here or the teachers there<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Since Rebbi Zeïra was a Babylonian immigrant to Galilee. Note that they speak to his son in Babylonian Aramaic.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah said, like the teachers here. Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">Both Rebbis Ḥizqiah and Yose are from the fourth generation, students of Rebbis Jeremiah and Ilaï who in turn were students of Rebbi Zeïra. The answer of Rebbi Zeïra’s son has not been recorded.</i> said, like the teachers there. Rebbi Ḥanina said, it is reasonable like R. Yose, since R. Zeïra always chose the harder way<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">He tended to follow the stricter Babylonian rules, cf. later <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 8:6:2-12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.8.6.2-12"><i>Halakhah</i>8:7,</a> fol. 12c.</i> and they chose the harder way, so he did what he was used to, like them.
We have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">This section is composed of a Tosephta (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 2:1:2-20" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.2.1.2-20"><i>Berakhot</i> 2:1</a>) containing the statements of the anonymous first Tanna, Rebbi, and “Others” (usually: Rebbi Meïr), and then the comment by the Amora R. Joshua ben Levi. In practice, the ruling of R. Joshua ben Levi applies to both morning and evening prayers.</i>: “He who recites <i>Shema‘</i> in the morning must mention the Exodus in <i>Emet veyaẓiv</i>. Rebbi says, he must mention [God’s] kingdom. Others say, he has to mention the splitting of the Reed Sea and the slaying of the firstborn.” Rebbi Joshua ben Levi says, he has to mention all these and has to say “Rock of Israel and its Redeemer”.<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">The formula was the Israeli conclusion of the benediction of redemption, in contrast to the Babylonian “He Who redeemed Israel” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 117b" href="/Pesachim.117b">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 117b</a>). This formula has survived in the poetic forms of Ashkenazic evening prayers for the holidays, while in ordinary prayers the form prescribed by the authoritative Babylonian Talmud has prevailed.</i>
