Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi says: If someone did not mention Torah in the benediction on the Land<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Talmud started discussing required topics of otherwise personal texts, they continue with a discussion of the relevant parts of Grace. The benediction of the Land is the second benediction, and that on Jerusalem the third. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 48b" href="/Berakhot.48b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 48b</a>) is a Tannaïtic text in different order. The Amoraïc text of the Yerushalmi is in strict chronological order: R. Joshua ben Levi of the very early second generation, R. Abba bar Aḥa of the second, and Rebbi Ilaï of the third generations. The second statement of R. Abba bar Aḥa is attributed by the printed editions and most Medieval authors of the Babli to Rebbi Eliezer but in the Munich ms. to Rebbi, as in the Yerushalmi. The first statement is attributed to an otherwise unknown Tanna Naḥum the elder. The statement of R. Joshua ben Levi is attributed to Rebbi Yose (ben Ḥalaphta) but without the verse that gives the reason. The Yerushalmi gives a statement of Amoraïm, not to claim that the required topics were introduced by Amoraïm (that is quite obvious from the mention of Rebbi), but in order to point out the Scriptural basis and to fix the exact place where Torah has to be mentioned in Grace.</i> one tells him to repeat. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 105:44" href="/Psalms.105.44"><i>Ps.</i> 105:44</a>) “He gave them the lands of peoples”; why? “That they should keep His decrees and preserve His teachings.” Rebbi Abba ben Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Rebbi: If one did not mention the covenant in the benediction on the Land or the kingdom of David’s dynasty in “Builder of Jerusalem”<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">The old doxology of the third benediction was: “Praised be You, o Eternal, Builder of Jerusalem.” The final adoption of the text “He Who in His mercy builds Jerusalem” is on the authority of <i>Shulḥan Arukh</i>, cf. <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah</i>, p. 357–358.</i>, one tells him to repeat. Rebbi Ilaï said: if he said “He Who consoles Jerusalem”<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">In the text, not in the final sentence.</i>, he did his duty.
Bar Qappara<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">Bar Qappara belongs to the generation of transfer between Tannaïm and Amoraïm. In the Yerushalmi his words are presented as those of an Amora. The place was chosen here because we discussed required language for benedictions (<i>Shema‘</i> and Grace); now we turn to required language in general speech. In the Babli, the parallel (13a) appears also at the end of the first Chapter, somewhat disconnected. One may assume that it is mentioned in parallel to the Yerushalmi.<br>In the printed editions of the Babli, the text is: “Bar Qappara stated”, a Tannaïtic statement. However, in the Munich ms. and the <i>Pisqe RYD</i> the text reads דרש בר קפרא “Bar Qappara preached”, an Amoraïc statement. (It also seems that Rebbi Eliezer, who completes the statement of Bar Qappara in the Babli in parallel to Rebbi Levi in the Yerushalmi, is “Rebbi Eleazar, the son of Bar Qappara’s sister”.) The people who object are determined in the Babli to be Rebbi Yose bar Abin or Rebbi Yose bar Zabida, of the later generation of Galilean Amoraïm. The statements of Bar Qappara and Rebbi Levi/Rebbi Eleazar are not mentioned in any of the Medieval codes, <i>Halakhot Gedolot, Alfasi, Mishneh Torah</i>; their authors took also the text in the Babli as Amoraïc sermon.</i> said: He who calls Abraham Abram transgresses a positive commandment. Rebbi Levi said, a positive and a negative commandment. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 17:4" href="/Genesis.17.4"><i>Gen.</i> 17:4</a>) “Your name shall not in the future be called Abram”, that is the negative commandment, “But your name shall be Abraham”, that is the positive commandment. They objected: But the Men of the Great Assembly called him Abram, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 9:7" href="/Nehemiah.9.7"><i>Neh.</i> 9:7</a>) “You are, o Eternal, the God Who selected Abram”. There is a difference, while he was still Abram You selected him.
Similarly, does he who calls Sarah Sarai transgress a commandment? He<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham alone was commanded not to call Sarah Sarai as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 17:15" href="/Genesis.17.15"><i>Gen.</i> 17:15</a>): “God said to Abraham: Your wife Sarai, do not call her name Sarai but Sarah is her name.” The commandment to call Sarai Sarah was directed to Abraham alone.</i> was commanded regarding her. Similarly, does he who calls Israel Jacob transgress a commandment? The second name was given him in addition, the first was not taken away from him<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Torah continues to call him Jacob even after he received his new name of Israel.</i>.
Why were the names of Abraham and Jacob changed but Isaac’s name was not changed? The former were given their names by their fathers; but Isaac was called Isaac by the Holy One, Praise to His Name, as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 17:19" href="/Genesis.17.19"><i>Gen.</i> 17:19</a>) “You shall call his name Isaac”. Four were given names before they were born, and they are Isaac, Ismael, Josiah, and Solomon. Isaac, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 17:19" href="/Genesis.17.19"><i>Gen.</i> 17:19</a>) “You shall call his name Isaac”. Ismael as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 16:11" href="/Genesis.16.11"><i>Gen.</i> 16:11</a>): “You shall call his name Ismael”. Josiah, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 13:2" href="/I_Kings.13.2"><i>1Kings</i> 13:2</a>): “Behold, a son will be born to the dynasty of David; his name will be Josiah”. Solomon, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 22:9" href="/I_Chronicles.22.9"><i>1Chr.</i> 22:9</a>) “Solomon will be his name”<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">While in <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 12:24-25" href="/II_Samuel.12.24-25"><i>2Sam.</i> 12:24–25</a> it seems that David gave the name Solomon to his son and Nathan called him Yedidiah after his birth; it is clear from Chronicles that the name Solomon was not David’s invention but prophetically pre-ordained.</i>. All this for the just. But the wicked (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 58:4" href="/Psalms.58.4"><i>Ps.</i> 58:4</a>) “The wicked are perverted from the womb.”
Ben Zoma said: There will be a future time when Israel will no longer mention the Exodus. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 23:7-8" href="/Jeremiah.23.7-8"><i>Jer.</i> 23:7–8</a>) “Therefore, days will come, says the Eternal, that one no longer will say, by the Eternal Who brought the Children of Israel up from Egypt, but rather, by the Eternal Who raised and brought the descendants of the House of Israel from the Northern land …” They said to him, not that the Exodus will be eliminated but the Exodus will be additional to the Kingdoms<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">“Kingdoms” is short for שעבוד מלכיות “subjugation by alien kingdoms,” a general term for the sufferings of the Jewish people inflicted by Gentiles.</i>. The Kingdoms will be principal and the Exodus additional. And similarly it was said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 35:10" href="/Genesis.35.10"><i>Gen.</i> 35:10</a>): :Your name shall not be called Jacob anymore, but Israel shall be your name.” Not that the name Jacob will be taken away but Jacob will be additional to Israel. Israel will be principal and Jacob additional. And so it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 43:18-19" href="/Isaiah.43.18-19"><i>Is.</i> 43:18–19</a>): “Do not remember the first things”; this means the Egyptians, “And what was earlier do not dwell on”; this means the Kingdoms, “Behold, I create something new, now it will grow”; this refers to Gog. They gave a simile: to what can this be compared? To someone who encountered a wolf and was saved from it. He started telling about the wolf when he encountered a lion and was saved from it. He forget about the wolf and started telling about the lion.After that, he encountered a snake and was saved from it. He forgot about both of them and started telling about the snake. So it is with Israel, the last troubles make them forget the earlier ones.

Chapter 2



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If someone was reading in the Torah at the time of recital<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Time of the obligatory recital of <i>Shema‘</i>.</i>, if he read with intention<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The intention of fulfilling the commandment of reading the <i>Shema‘</i>.</i> he fulfilled his duty, otherwise he did not fulfill his duty. Between the sections<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Of the <i>Shema‘.</i></i>, one greets people out of respect and answers their greetings. In the middle of a section one may greet because of fear and answer, the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rebbi Yehudah says: in the middle of a section one may greet out of fear and answer for respect, between sections one greets for respect and answers greetings from everybody.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Abba said: This means that benedictions do not prevent<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">. Since the Mishnah allows one to concentrate on reading the Torah text as <i>Shema‘</i> without requiring an interruption for recitations of the benedictions, it follows that benedictions are a separate obligation. In a number of prayer texts from the Genizah, the recitation of the <i>Shema‘</i> has a separate benediction: “Praised be You, o Eternal, King of the Universe, Who sanctified us through His commandments and commanded us about the recitation of <i>Shema‘,</i> with a full heart to declare Him King over us, and willingly to declare His Unity.” While these texts are from a period about 500 years later than the text of the Yerushalmi, they show that recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> was then still considered an obligation separate from the benedictions mentioned in the Mishnah. The latter benedictions could then be recited before the <i>Amidah</i>. See Ezra Fleischer,תפילה ומנהגי תפילה ,ארץ־ישראליים בתקופת הגניזה Jerusalem 1988.<br>The paragraph has been explained as parallel to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 11b-12a" href="/Berakhot.11b-12a">Babli (11b–12a</a>) by R. Solomon ben Adrat (<i>Rashba</i>) in his responsa, vol. 1, no 319.</i>.
Rebbi Yose said: If you say that one needs to recite the benedictions; when he recited them he must focus his attention for the entire <i>Shema‘</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yose supports the statement of Rebbi Abba: If one would require concentration on what one recites for benedictions before and after <i>Shema‘,</i> certainly one requires total attention during the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>. As seen at the end of this paragraph, this is not the rule.</i>. They objected: Does he not interrupt and it does not appear in our statement?<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mishnah, it is assumed that one may recite the several sections of the <i>Shema‘</i> separately since they are written at different places in the Torah scroll. Since the Mishnah does not mention the necessary interruptions in the recital, it might be possible that the Mishnah contemplates interruptions for the recitation of the benedictions before and after <i>Shema‘</i>; hence, the inference of Rebbi Abba is not justified.</i> So here also, even though it has not been stated he must recite the benedictions. That means<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The argument would be good only if the statement of Rebbi Yose were true.</i>, one must focus one’s attention for the entire <i>Shema‘</i>. We may hear it from the following: Rebbi Aḥai<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Aḥai was “Tanna”, collector of <i>baraitot</i>, in the Yeshivah of Rebbi Ḥiyya. He belongs to the generation between Tannaïm and Amoraïm. His statement, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:2" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.2"><i>Tosephta Berakhot</i>2:2</a> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 13a" href="/Berakhot.13a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 13a</a>), shows that Rebbi Yose’s argument is correct and that Rebbi Abba stated the practice correctly. (In the printed editions of the Babli, the name is Rebbi Aḥa, but in the Munich manuscript, and in all manuscripts of the Tosephta, the name is correctly Rebbi Aḥai. Rebbi Aḥa is an Amora of the fourth generation.)</i> said in the name of Rebbi Yehudah: “He has fulfilled his obligation if he focussed his attention for the first paragraph, even though he did not focus his attention during recitation of the second paragraph”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">A natural question following the Tosephta of Rebbi Yehudah.</i>.
What is the difference between the first and second paragraphs?<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">A natural question following the Tosephta of Rebbi Yehudah.</i> Rebbi Ḥanina said: Everything mentioned in the first paragraph is mentioned in the second. In that case, should one have to recite only one of them? Rebbi Illa said: The first one is directed to the individual, the second one to the community; the first one concentrates on learning, the second one on doing<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The first paragraph is formulated in the singular, the second one in the plural. In addition, while the essence of the first paragraph is repeated in the second as a communal obligation, there are many topics in the second paragraph that are not mentioned in the first. In the language of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 14b" href="/Berakhot.14b">Babli (14b</a>), the first paragraph is the acceptance of the acceptance of Heaven, the second one the acceptance of the commandments of the Torah.</i>.
Bar Qappara said: One has to focus his attention only during the first three verses<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">This is the accepted practice for the Yerushalmi with no one objecting. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 13b" href="/Berakhot.13b">Babli (13b</a>), the statement is given in the name of an otherwise unknown Tanna Rebbi Zutra, and, even though it exemplifies the attitude of Rebbi Aqiba, it is later replaced by the statement of Rebbi Meïr that only the first verse, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:4" href="/Deuteronomy.6.4"><i>Deut.</i> 6:4</a>, must be recited with focussed attention. Another difference between the more demanding Yerushalmi and the Babli is that the Yerushalmi requires the rest of <i>Shema‘</i> to be “repeated”, i.e., memorized, whereas in the Babli it has only to be read.</i>. It was stated thus: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:7" href="/Deuteronomy.6.7"><i>Deut.</i> 6:7</a>) “You should repeat”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning, "memorize".</i> until there is the obligation of focussed attention; from there starts the obligation of repetition.
Rebbi Ḥunah, Rebbi Uri<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Uri is not known from any other source. The Rome manuscript of the Yerushalmi reads “Rebbi Ammi”; this might be a better reading but Rebbi Ammi was a student of Rebbi Yoḥanan who in the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 13b" href="/Berakhot.13b">Babli (13b</a>) is reported to require that a person walking has to stand still during recitation of the entire first paragraph of <i>Shema‘,</i> since he follows the ruling of Rebbi Aḥai in the name of Rebbi Yehudah that the entire first paragraph requires concentrated attention.</i>, Rav Joseph, Rav Yehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The most influential of all students of Samuel.</i> in the name of Samuel: One has to accept the Kingdom of Heaven standing. Does this mean that one has to get up when one is sitting? No, if one is walking he has to stand still.
It was stated: One has to prolong “is One”.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The last word of the first sentence of <i>Shema‘</i>. The composition here is difficult to understand since one starts with a tannaïtic statement (“It was stated”), continues with the opinion of an Amora (Rav Naḥman bar Jacob), and then returns to a Tanna (Symmachos, an outstanding student of Rebbi Meïr). The parallel <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 13b" href="/Berakhot.13b">Babli (13b</a>) starts with the statement of Symmachos and then continues with the statement of Rav Naḥman bar Jacob which is quoted there in the name of Rav Aḥa bar Jacob. It is possible that “Aḥa”, a name without meaning, is simply a form of endearment of the formal name “Naḥman”, and that in the Babli it is necessary to use the form of endearment to distinguish this Amora from Rav Naḥman, quoted without his father’s name because of his exalted status, whose full name seems to have been Rav Naḥman bar Jacob.</i> Rav Naḥman bar Jacob said: But only at the <i>daleth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The soft ד, without <i>dagesh</i>, was pronounced like an Arabic ذ, or a voiced English <i>th</i>, a sibilant sometimes close to ז. For example, the Aramaic די appears in the Elephantine papyri as זי. Hence, it really was possible to prolong the consonant <i>daleth</i> since it was not a plosive sound as it is today.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 13b" href="/Berakhot.13b">Babli (13b</a>), Rav Ashi adds that one should not omit to pronounce the ח. This was because in Babylonia, as in Medieval Ashkenaz, a ח was pronounced like a stronger ה and therefore tended to be silent in the middle of a word, as ה is mostly silent in the middle of a word in modern Hebrew. (Even the masters of the Massorah tried to counteract this tendency, e. g. by punctuating יִֽהְיֶה, to make the <i>Sheva</i> heard when it should be silent by grammatical rules, so that the Torah reader should be forced to pronounce the ה, but obviously to no avail.)</i> Symmachos bar Joseph<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A Tanna, student of Rebbi Meïr.</i> said: Anyone who prolongs “is One” has his days and years prolonged in wellbeing. Rebbi Jeremiah was prolonging very much. Rebbi Zeïra said to him: So much is unnecessary, only so long that you should think of Him as King of Heaven and Earth and the four directions of the world.
Rav asked Rebbi Ḥiyya: But I never see that Rebbi accepts upon himself the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven. He answered him: When you will see him cover his face with his hand, at that moment he accepts the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 13b" href="/Berakhot.13b">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 13b</a>. It seems that Rebbi started his Yeshivah classes early in the morning, before one could recite <i>Shema‘,</i> and continued until it was too late to recite <i>Shema‘</i> as “acceptance of the yoke of heaven”, but only as “reading from the Torah.”</i> He asked him back: Is it not necessary also to mention the Exodus? He answered him: It is impossible that he should not turn his words<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Turn his words to the Exodus. In the Babli, Bar Qappara reports that Rebbi never gave a class in which he did not mention the Exodus.</i>. Rebbi Tavyome<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">An Israeli Amora of the fourth generation who otherwise is quoted only in Midrashim.</i> asked Rebbi Ḥizkiah: Does this not mean that one has to focus attention only for the first verse?<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">If Rebbi recited the relevant portion of <i>Shema‘</i> while covering his face with his hand during his morning classses, he could not have spent much time on it and, therefore, Rebbi does not accept the opinion of Bar Qappara that the first three verses have to be recited with focussed attention.</i> He said to him: With that<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">While he was covering his face he could have recited all three verses and there is no proof that he disagreed with the ruling that requires concentration for the first three verses.</i> he might recite until “You shall repeat.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Here starts the discussion of the second part of the Mishnah, about the permitted interruptions in the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 18b" href="/Megillah.18b">Babli, <i>Megillah</i> 18b</a>, quotes both Rebbi Muna and Rav, but from a discussion of the rules of blowing the <i>shofar</i>, given below; they change the statement of Rav to “practice does not follow” and consider the statement here to be the opinion of Rebbi Yehudah only.</i> Rebbi Muna<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">This author, whose name appears in several forms here in print and in manuscripts, is Rebbi Muna, student of Rebbi Yehudah (Judah) and Tanna of the last generation.</i> said in the name of Rebbi Yehudah who said in the name of Rebbi Yose the Galilean: If one interrupted so that he would have been able to read all of it, he did not fulfill his duty. Rebbi Abba, Rav Jeremiah in the name of Rav: The practice follows Rebbi Muna who said in the name of Rebbi Yehudah who said in the name of Rebbi Yose the Galilean.
Rebbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Jehozadak: The same rule<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">That one has to start again if the interruption is so long that one could have finished the entire text in the meantime. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 34b" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.34b">Babli (<i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 34b</a>) quotes the same statement and declares that this is only the opinion of Rebbi Yoḥanan’s teacher but not his own, and, therefore, is not followed in practice, since arbitrary interruptions are allowed for blowing the <i>shofar</i>. The Yerushalmi differs from the Babli in that the principle of time limitation of interruptions in recitals is accepted without reservation; the blowing of <i>shofar</i> on Rosh Hashanah is not a recitation and, therefore, can follow different rules.</i> applies to <i>Hallel</i> and the reading of the Esther scroll.
Abba bar Rav Huna<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">He appears in the Babli as Rabba bar Rav Huna; he and Rav Ḥisda were the leaders of the third generation of Amoraïm in Babylonia.</i> and Rav Ḥisda sat together and said, the same rule applies to blowing the <i>Shofar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">That no interruption is allowed longer than what is needed to complete the entire ritual.</i>. They went up to Rav’s Yeshivah and heard Rav Ḥuna in the name of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">This must have been after the death of Rav when Rav Ḥuna was the head of the Academy. The text given here is from the Rome manuscript; the Venice print and Leyden manuscript have רַב חוּנָא בְשֵׁם רַב הוּנָא “Rav Ḥuna in the name of Rav Huna”, which certainly is a scribal error.</i>: Even if one heard it in up to nine hours he fulfilled his obligation<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">If one heard the nine sounds precribed for Rosh Hashanah on nine different occasions during the day (but in the correct order), then he has done his duty.</i>. Rebbi Zeiïa said: When I was there, this was a problem for me<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Whether the rule of interruptions applies to the blowing of the <i>Shofar</i> or not. This shows that Rav Ḥuna’s ruling was not widely accepted in Babylonia in his time.</i>. When I came here, I heard Rebbi Yasa<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">He is called Rebbi Assi in the Babli, student of R. Yoḥanan, and co-head of the Academy of Tiberias with Rebbi Immi (Ammi) after R. Yoḥanan. Both were Cohanim.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Even if one heard it during an entire day, one has fulfilled one’s obligation<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">As mentioned earlier, this is the statement quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 18b" href="/Megillah.18b">Babli (<i>Megillah</i>18b</a>, <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 34b).</i>. But only if one heard it in the correct order<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The basic obligation is to hear three times a straight note (תקיעה), followed by a broken sound, followed by a straight note. [Since there was diasgreement in practice whether the broken sound should be in three waves or in nine small variations, Rebbi Abbahu in the administrative center of Caesarea, where Jews from many different places came together, instituted the rule that one blows three times, each one of the two kinds of modulated sound and the third time the two sounds together.]</i>. Rebbi Yose investigated: If one needed to hear the first simple tone and another one the final simple tone, one blow of the <i>Shofar</i> serves the requirements of both of them<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">In fact, the benediction on Rosh Hashanah is not “to blow the <i>Shofar</i>” but “to listen to the sound of the <i>Shofar</i>”; hence, it is the personal obligation of each listener and does not depend on the intention of the blower.</i>.
Rebbi Abin bar Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">An outstanding student of Rebbis Yoḥanan and Zeïra who died young.</i> investigated: The recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> with its benedictions, it (the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>) without its benedictions, its benedictions without it<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Since we have decided that one has to start anew if he interrupted long enough to have finished the entire recitation during the interruption, does he count the time for <i>Shema‘</i> with its benedictions, or without benedictions, and does the rule of interruptions apply at all to the benedictions? The question remains unanswered.</i>? If he interrupted after a third, interrupted after a second third<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Do separate interruptions count as one or is every interruption a separate count of time? The question remains unanswered.</i>? Does one estimate by the reader’s speed or by the average speed of all men? Rebbi Mattaniah<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the last generation. In the parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 2:2:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.2.2.2-6"><i>Megillah</i>(2:2</a>), the reading is: Rebbi Mattaniah said: Is it not reasonable that …, with a rhetorical negation [interpretation of Rashba (Rebbi Shelomo ben Adrat) in his commentary to the Mishnah in <i>Berakhot</i>.]</i> said, it seems reasonable by the reader’s.
Rebbi Abbahu<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">A student of R. Yoḥanan who became the principal defender of the Jews in Israel before the Roman authorities. His father’s name is unknown. His school was at Caesarea Philippi [C. Paneas], seat of the Roman prefect for Galilee.</i> asked Rebbi Yoḥanan: Assuming that I am reciting <i>Shema‘</i> and interrupting while passing by stinking passage ways<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Where it is forbidden to study Torah or recite prayers, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 5:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.5.3.1">Mishnah 5:3</a>. This section is also discussed in Babli <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 34b, where, according to the theory of the Babli mentioned above, R. Yoḥanan answers only according to the opinion of those who think that after a longer interruption one has to start anew.</i>, do I fulfill my obligation? He answered him: Abbahu my son, if you interrupt enough that you could have finished all of it, you did not fulfill your obligation.
Rebbi Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">A Babylonian who first was a student and then became a colleague of Rebbi Yoḥanan. Even though he was the greatest of his generation after Rebbi Yoḥanan, he never became head of a Yeshivah since he died shortly before Rebbi Yoḥanan. He often follows Babylonian positions like the one presented here, where the position of Rebbi Eleazar is that which the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 34b" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.34b">Babli, <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 34b</a>, accepts as the re-interpreted position of Rebbi Yoḥanan.</i> went to pay a sick-bed visit to Rebbi Simeon bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">A fellow Babylonian who was a student of the great Amoraïm of the first generation, thus much older than Rebbi Eleazar.</i>. He said to him: Since I am weak, when I am reciting <i>Shema‘</i> I tend to slumber; do I fulfill my obligation? He said to him: yes. Rebbi Jeremiah asked before Rebbi Zeïra: Did Rebbi Eleazar give this ruling since he knew that Rebbi Simeon bar Abba is very scrupulous in the execution of his religious duties<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, will make an effort that his slumber periods will not be too long.</i>, or because he was so weak<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Since there is no other way he could fulfill his obligation he could claim an exemption from the general rule because of אוֹנס, an act of God.</i>? He answered him: They<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbis Yoḥanan and Eleazar, concerning whether a person who interrupted a recitation for a longer period and then continued where he interrupted, did fulfill his religious duty.</i> disagree explicitly; Rebbi Eleazar said he fulfilled his obligation, Rebbi Yoḥanan said he did not fulfill his obligation. They disagree for the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> since that is composed of separate chapters, but for the recitation of <i>Hallel</i> and the Esther scroll, Rebbi Eleazar will agree<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">That after a long interruption one has to start from the beginning again. This sentence is a comment by the editors of the Yerushalmi; it is not the Babylonian position.</i>.
It was stated: If someone wants to greet his teacher or anybody who his greater than himself in Torah, he is permitted to do so<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">To continue the discussion of the Mishnah, we now turn to the definition of what it means to interrupt “to greet somebody out of respect.”</i>. That implies that a person has to greet anybody who is greater than himself in Torah. And also from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">A similar but more explicit <i>baraita</i> is found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nedarim 87a" href="/Nedarim.87a">Babli <i>Nedarim</i> 87a</a>. A person stands at the deathbed of someone for whom he would be required to mourn. He must tear his clothes after the person’s death. In the case discussed here, he tore his clothes, thinking that the patient was dead but then the dying person showed signs of life. If the final death occurs within the time needed for “speech”, the first tear is sufficient. The <i>baraita</i> is quoted here only to introduce the standard for greeting, which is that the student is required to say: “Peace be with you, my teacher.” This is the standard of behavior for a student.</i>: If one tore his clothes and the soul returned, if it is instantaneous he does not have to tear again. If it is later, he has to tear again. How much is instantaneous? The time for speech. How much is time of speech? Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said: the time one needs to greet his friend<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">The greeting of a person to his friend is שלום עליכם “Peace be with you.” In the main parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 73b" href="/Bava_Kamma.73b">Babli (<i>Baba qama</i> 73b</a>), no names are given but it is stated that there are two measurements of “speech”, one from teacher to student, the same as a person to a friend, and the longer one from student to teacher.</i>. Abba bar bar Ḥana<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">He appears in the Babli as Rabba bar bar Ḥana; his father Rabba bar Ḥana was a nephew of Rav.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: the time for greeting between teacher and student, when he says “Peace be with you, my teacher.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) has the longer sentence שלום עליך מורי ורבי, “peace be with you, my instructor and teacher.”</i>”
Rebbi Yoḥanan was leaning on Rebbi Jacob bar Idi when Rebbi Eleazar saw him and hid himself before him<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">This story is inserted here to show that the obligation to greet one’s teacher was accepted in Babylonia only when the student could not hide from his teacher. Rebbi Yoḥanan also insists that all his teachings be reported in his own name; this is discussed in the next section. A psalm is quoted there to support Rebbi Yoḥanan’s position mentioning the Temple; the rôle of David in the building of the Temple is discussed in the third part of this aggadic insert.</i>. He said, these two things the Babylonian does to me: First, that he does not greet me, and second, that he does not teach the traditions in my name. He said to him, thus they behave among themselves; Zeïra did not greet Rabba<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The names here do not seem to be correctly transmitted. Rabba belongs to the generation after Rebbi Yoḥanan and Rebbi Zeïra studied under Rav Huna and Rav Yehudah in Babylonia. Therefore, it seems that the name is Zeïri, a Babylonian who studied under Rav and them emigrated to Israel where he became famous but did not acquire any rabbinic title. The second name, therefore, is Rav.</i> since they observe (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 29:8" href="/Job.29.8"><i>Job</i> 29:8</a>) “Boys see me and hide themselves.” As they were walking, he<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Jacob bar Idi.</i> saw a <i>Bet Midrash</i>. He<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Jacob bar Idi.</i> said to him: Here Rebbi Meïr sat and reported traditions in the name of Rebbi Ismaël but he never reported traditions in the name of Rebbi Aqiba. He<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yoḥanan.</i> answered: Everybody knows that Rebbi Meïr was the student of Rebbi Aqiba. He<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Jacob bar Idi.</i> retorted, everybody knows that Rebbi Eleazar is the student of Rebbi Yoḥanan. May one pass by a cursed<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The word אהדורי makes no sense. In the parallel sources in the Yerushalmi, <i>Sheqalim</i> 2:6, <i>Moëd qaṭan</i> 3:2, the word is ארורי “cursed”.</i> statue? He<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yoḥanan; the person who asks is Rebbi Jacob bar Idi who already knew the answer from Rebbi Joshua ben Levi, <i>Avodah zarah</i> 3:8.</i> said to him, do you want to honor it? Pass it by and blind its eyes! He<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Jacob bar Idi points out that one avoids only important people or circumstances. One “blinds the eyes” of the idol if one passes by it without taking any notice of it and the idol sees that it is not taken seriously.</i> said to him, Rebbi Eleazar did well that he did not pass before you. He said: Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The title “Rebbi” is missing in the Rome ms.; this is the better reading since the teacher will not adress his student (nor his equal) by his title.</i> Jacob bar Idi, you know how to pacify.
But Rebbi Yoḥanan required that traditions should be reported in his name. Also David begged for divine mercy in this respect, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 61:5" href="/Psalms.61.5"><i>Ps.</i> 61:5</a>) “may I dwell in Your tent forever!”<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The context of the Psalm excludes an interpretation that would refer the verse to the Future World since it directly refers to the earthly Temple.</i> Rebbi Phineas<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">R. Pinḥas bar Ḥama Hacohen, leading preacher of the fourth generation of Galilean Amoraïm.</i>, Rebbi Jeremiah, in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan; Could David think of living forever? Rather, David meant: May I have the merit that my words will be mentioned in my name in synagogues and houses of study. What good does that do to him? Levi, the son of the <i>Nazir</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">An author who is not otherwise mentioned in the Talmudim. In the parallels in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 96b" href="/Yevamot.96b">Babli (<i>Yebamot</i> 96b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 90b" href="/Sanhedrin.90b"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 90b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 31b" href="/Bekhorot.31b"><i>Bekhorot</i> 31b</a>) the statement is R. Yoḥanan’s in the name of R. Simeon (either ben Yoḥai or ben Yehoẓadaq) and the verse is quoted in the name of several authors, one of them Simeon Nazira who probably was the father of Levi, the son of the <i>Nazir</i> who is quoted here. (The <i>Nazir</i> may not cut his hair, drink wine, or become impure by a dead body. Since the destruction of the Temple, any vow of <i>nezirut</i> is permanent.)</i> said: If someone mentions a tradition in the name of its author, the latter’s lips whisper with him in the grave. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Song of Songs 7:10" href="/Song_of_Songs.7.10"><i>Cant</i>. 7:10</a>) “Dripping from the lips of the sleeping ones.” Like that bunch of grapes which drips by itself. Rebbi Ḥanina bar Pappai<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">A colleague of Rebbi Simon and Rebbi Abbahu, equally outstanding in practice and in <i>aggadah</i>. (“Spiced wine” from Latin <i>conditura</i> “condiment, spice.”)</i> and Rebbi Simon, one said, like one who drinks spiced wine, the other said, like one who drinks old wine, even though he consumed it, its taste remains in his mouth.
There is no generation without scoffers. What did the hooligans of that generation do? They went to David’s windows and said to him: David, when will the Temple be built, when will we go to the Lord’s house? But he said, even though they intend to enrage me, it comes over me that I am happy, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 122:1" href="/Psalms.122.1"><i>Ps.</i> 122:1</a>) “I enjoy it when they say to me: let us go to the Lord’s house.”<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Knowing that he would not build the Temple and not see it.</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 7:12" href="/II_Samuel.7.12"><i>2Sam.</i> 7:12</a>) “<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">The word והיה given here is not in <i>2Samuel</i>; the quote starts with the second word.</i> When your days will be complete”; Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥmani said, the Holy One, praise to Him, said to David: ‘I am counting full days for you, I am not counting missing days for you<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">This is one of the blessings bestowed at Mount Sinai on the Jewish people, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:26" href="/Exodus.23.26"><i>Ex.</i> 23:26</a>, that the Just will live complete years; as in fact Moses died on his 120th birthday. It is asserted here that David also lived complete years; his age is never indicated in <i>Tanakh</i>.</i>. Will not your son Solomon build the Temple to sacrifice? Law and justice that you are upholding is more to my liking than sacrifices.’ What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 21:3" href="/Proverbs.21.3"><i>Prov.</i> 21:3</a>) “Upholding justice and law is preferred by the Lord to sacrifice”.
<b>New Section.</b> “Between the sections one greets people out of respect, and answers them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">This is a quote from the Mishnah. The problem is that Rebbi Meïr does not indicate why one should answer. Since for Rebbi Yehudah the rules for answering are more lenient than for initiating the exchange, it follows that for Rebbi Meïr the rules for answering are not more lenient, but it is unclear whether answering and initiating have identical status or that the rules for answering are more restrictive than those for initiating a verbal exchange. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 13b" href="/Berakhot.13b">Babli (13b</a>) explains the words of Rebbi Meïr as meaning “one may start an exchange <i>and it goes without saying</i> that one may answer”, they seem to assume that it is obvious that the rules of answering cannot be stricter than those for starting. Also, the Babli takes the two parts together; it is possible that the unnecessary length in the statement of Rebbi Meïr is considered simply as a parallel to the necessary length of the statement of Rebbi Yehudah while for the Yerushalmi the two parallel statements of Rebbi Meïr represent two parallel problems which have to be solved separately. Hence the seemingly repetitous arrangement of the Yerushalmi here; but the first quote of Rebbi Meïr is in support of an argument while the second one presents the topic for further discussion; the two quotes of the identical text are of different status.</i> Why does one answer, out of fear or to show respect? We may hear it from this: “In the middle of a section one may greet because of fear and answer (for respect), the words of Rebbi Meïr.” Hence, in the prior case one may ask because of respect and answer out of respect.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Since in the middle of a section certainly more restrictive rules apply than between sections.</i> “In the middle of a section one may greet because of fear and answer, the words of Rebbi Meïr.” For what does one answer, out of fear or to show respect? We may hear it from this: “Rebbi Yehudah says: in the middle of a section one may greet out of fear and answer for respect.” Hence<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Since Rebbi Meïr disagrees with Rebbi Yehudah, and from the previous discussion we know that answering does not have more restrictive rules than starting the conversation, it follows that Rebbi Meïr must hold in all cases that answering and starting have the same status.</i>, in the first case one asks because of fear and answers because of fear.
So far in the middle of a section. Or even in the middle of a verse<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Do the rules given in the Mishnah apply only between verses in the middle of a section or even in the middle of a verse?</i>? Rebbi Jeremiah gave hints<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The text here is not uniform. The Leyden manuscript and the Genizah text are as the Venice print, מדמה, but in the quotes of this passage by Ramban, <i>Milḥamot Hashem, Berakhot</i> Chap. 2 and the authorities depending on him (Rashba and Rosh on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 14a" href="/Berakhot.14a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 14a</a>), the text reads מרמז. The meaning is in both cases that Rebbi Jeremiah did not talk but give greetings or instructions by pantomime.</i>. Rebbi Jonah made himself understood<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., he talked.</i>. Rebbi Ḥuna, Rav Joseph: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:7" href="/Deuteronomy.6.7"><i>Deut.</i> 6:7</a>) “You may talk <i>in</i> them”, from here that one is authorized to talk between them<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">In Hebrew, future, imperative, and subjunctive may have the same form. In general, the passage ודברת בם in <i>Shema‘</i> is translated “you must talk about them” (The Divine commandments), but Rebbi Ḥuna takes it to mean “you may talk in them”, i. e., while reciting the verses.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The following are “between the sections”: between the first benediction and the second, between the second and <i>Shema‘,</i> between <i>Shema‘</i> and (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:13" href="/Deuteronomy.11.13"><i>Deut.</i> 11:13</a>) “it shall be when you will really listen”, between “it shall be when you will really listen” and (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:37" href="/Numbers.15.37"><i>Num.</i> 15:37</a>) “the Eternal spoke”. Between “the Eternal spoke” and “true and outstanding<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The benediction after <i>Shema‘,</i> starting with a series of epithets of the Torah.</i>”. Rebbi Yehudah said, between “the Eternal spoke” and “true and outstanding” one may not interrupt.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Levi said<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 14a" href="/Berakhot.14a">Babli (14a</a>), the explanation is by R. Abbahu in the name of R. Yoḥanan. Since Rebbi Levi was preacher in the Yeshivah of Rebbi Yoḥanan, the explanation originated in that Yeshivah. In addition, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan in the Babli declares that the practice follows Rebbi Yehudah; this decision is missing in the Yerushalmi and, hence, it seems that in Israel one used to follow the majority opinion that an interruption is permitted between the last words of the <i>Shema‘</i> and “true”. Hence, the question asked in the Babli, whether after reciting “the Eternal, your God. True!” one stops and starts again “true and outstanding”, is irrelevant for the Yerushalmi. The question in the Babli is whether Rebbi Yehudah disagrees with the first Tanna in principle, that ‘between “the Eternal spoke” and “true and outstanding” ’ there is no interruption allowed or whether he simply moves the end of technical <i>Shema‘</i> by one word and then allows the regular interruptions there.</i>, the reason of Rebbi Yehudah: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:41" href="/Numbers.15.41"><i>Num.</i> 15:41</a>) “I am the Eternal, your God<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">These are the concluding words of <i>Shema‘</i>.</i>”, and it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 10:10" href="/Jeremiah.10.10"><i>Jer.</i> 10:10</a>) “But the Eternal is the true God”.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Ribbi Joshua ben Qorḥah<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">This shows that before the war of Bar Kokhba, the wearing of <i>tefillin</i> the entire day in the Land of Israel was not unheard-of.</i> said: Why does <i>Shema‘</i> precede “it shall be when you will really listen”? In order that one should accept the Kingdom of Heaven before he accepts the yoke of the commandments. And “it shall be when you will really listen” to “The Eternal said”? Because “it shall be when you will really listen” is applicable day and night<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to study the Torah and keep its commandments applies everywhere and at all times; the obligation to have <i>ẓiẓit</i> on one’s garment, expressed in the third section of <i>Shema‘,</i> is applicable only during daytime according to most opinions.</i>, “the Eternal said” is applicable only during daytime.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">A Tanna who lived from the times, of R. Aqiba to those of Rebbi; he is mostly known for his aggadic interpretations.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Why did they say, a man puts on <i>tefillin</i>, recites the <i>Shema‘</i> and prays? So that he first should accept upon himself the Kingdom of Heaven completely. Rav said, one reads the <i>Shema‘,</i> puts on <i>tefillin</i>, and prays<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to study the Torah and keep its commandments applies everywhere and at all times; the obligation to have <i>ẓiẓit</i> on one’s garment, expressed in the third section of <i>Shema‘,</i> is applicable only during daytime according to most opinions.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> of Rav himself<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the Leyden manuscript. In both Talmudim we hear that Rav and Samuel collected <i>baraitot</i>, tannaïtic statements not made part of the Mishnah.</i> disagrees with him: “If somebody was occupied with a dead person in his grave and the time for the recital of <i>Shema‘</i> arrived, he should move to a pure place<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Since a dead person can no longer pray, it is explained later in this <i>Halakhah</i> that praying in a graveyard would violate the verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 17:5" href="/Proverbs.17.5"><i>Prov.</i> 17:5</a>): “He who makes fun of the poor blasphemes his Maker”; hence one has to leave the graveyard if he wants to pray. The order of prayer given in the <i>baraita</i> is the one adopted by Rebbi Yoḥanan.</i>, put on <i>tefillin</i>, recite the <i>Shema‘,</i> and pray”. Does not the Mishnah support Rav: “In order that one should accept the Kingdom of Heaven before he accepts the yoke of the commandments”<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tefillin</i>, while mentioned in the first paragraph, belong to the execution of commandments. It follows that, in the opinion of the Yerushalmi, Rav recommended to put on <i>tefillin</i> between the first and second sections of <i>Shema‘</i>; otherwise, the Mishnah would not support his position. This contradicts the opinion of the Babli as quoted above; it eliminates the objection of the Babli that certainly Rav would not put off fulfilling the obligation of <i>tefillin</i> until after the recital of <i>Shema‘</i>.</i>?
Rebbi Yannai<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">The most important Amora of the first generation in Galilea, student of Rebbi and teacher of Rebbi Yoḥanan.</i> said: <i>Tefillin</i> need a clean body<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">The same rule is quoted in Rebbi Yannai’s name in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 49a" href="/Shabbat.49a">Babli (<i>Sabbath</i> 49a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 130a" href="/Shabbat.130a">130a</a>); there Abbai and Rava explain that one may not break wind while wearing <i>tefillin</i> and so may not sleep while wearing them. The Yerushalmi does not go into details. The connection with the previous text probably is the quote that one may not wear <i>tefillin</i> in a graveyard. This also counts as having an unclean body since on leaving the graveyard one has to wash his hands. A Mishnah in the next Chapter also implies that one may not wear <i>tefillin</i> when his body is not cleansed from an emission of semen. Some Medieval authorities imply from the statement of R. Yannai that while wearing <i>tefillin</i> one may not have unclean thoughts.</i>.
Why does one not hold on<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">There are two interpretations of this sentence. Rabbenu Yeruḥam [path 19, part 5] explains: Why does one not keep on his <i>tefillin</i> the entire day but takes them off after praying? <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Shabbat 49a" href="/Tosafot_on_Shabbat.49a">Tosaphot [<i>Šabbat</i> 49a</a>] explain: Why does one not consider a person wearing <i>tefillin</i> automatically as a trustworthy Jew who may be trusted to keep all <i>miẓwot</i>? The explanation of Tosaphot is easier to fit into our text but the explanation of Rabbenu Yeruḥam seems to have the correct historical background. Both the Roman and the Byzantine governments from time to time forbade the wearing of <i>tefillin</i>. Therefore, from the start of the reconstruction of Jewish life after the war of Bar Kokhba, <i>tefillin</i> were not worn publicly in the Land of Israel. The reading of the Rome manuscript, “Why does one not hold on to them in the Land of Israel?” seems to explain the situation from a Babylonian point of view where <i>tefillin</i> never were a problem with the government and where, in R. Sherira Gaon’s time at least, <i>tefillin</i> were worn by scholars all day long. But even in Babylonia in the first generations of Amoraïm Rav Sheshet is reported (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 118b" href="/Shabbat.118b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 118b</a>) of being proud that he wore <i>tefillin</i> the entire day, not just for a minimal time.</i> to them? Because of the impostors<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, wearing <i>tefillin</i> outside of times of prayer may make a person suspect of being a gangster impersonating a pious person.</i>. It happened that a man deposited something with another, and the latter then reneged on it. He said to him: Not you I thought trustworthy but those on your head I thought trustworthy.
Rebbi Yannai was wearing them after his sickness for three days, to show that sickness cleanses<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">This statement supports the interpretation that the “clean body” required from a wearer of <i>tefillin</i> is a body cleansed from sinful thoughts, since a person recovered from sickness is a person all whose sins have been forgiven. It is spelled out in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 103" href="/Psalms.103"><i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 103</a> that the first three days, R. Yannai wore his <i>tefillin</i> the entire day but after that he was putting them on only for prayer.</i>. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 103:2" href="/Psalms.103.2"><i>Ps.</i> 103:2</a>): “He Who forgives all my sins, He Who heals all my sicknesses.” Rebbi Yoḥanan ben Zakkai’s <i>tefillin</i> were not coming off from him either in summer or in winter. And so did his student Rebbi Eliezer after him.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">This shows that before the war of Bar Kokhba, the wearing of <i>tefillin</i> the entire day in the Land of Israel was not unheard-of.</i>
Rebbi Yoḥanan was wearing both of them<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Both <i>tefillin</i>.</i> in winter when his head was healthy. But in sommer when his head was not healthy he put on only that of the arm. But is not that forbidden because of nakedness<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Since the <i>tefillin</i> on the arm are worn under the coat or shirt, there is the possibility that no garment separates the holy <i>tefillin</i> from his genitals and that is forbidden as we shall see later. [Only in recent times have <i>tefillin</i> become so large that they cannot be covered by the coat sleeves and the bad habit of praying with the left arm uncovered has taken over Ashkenazic congregations.]</i>? Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said: He wore an undershirt<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">ἐπικάρσιον, τό, “striped garment”. This must have been a large undershirt reaching at least to the upper parts of his legs.</i> under his clothes. When he went to bathe, he was taking them off when he came to the oil sellers<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>olearii</i>.</i>. Rebbi Isaac said, he was wearing them up to Jacob, the bath master<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Greek θερμασία, ἡ, “warmth, heat.”. Rebbi Yoḥanan would trust his <i>tefillin</i> only into the hands of a reliable Jewish man.</i>. When he exited the bath, they brought them to him. When they were bringing them, he used to say: <sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>aggadah</i> appears several times: <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sotah (Lieberman) 4:7" href="/Tosefta_Sotah_(Lieberman).4.7">Tosephta <i>Soṭa</i> 4:7</a>, <i>Mekhilta Beshallaḥ</i> 1, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 13a" href="/Sotah.13a">Babli <i>Soṭa</i> 13a</a>. The Hebrew verb קנתר, a few times also קנטר, is probably from Greek κεντρόω “to sting, vex, goad”.</i> Two caskets were travelling with Israel in the wilderness, the ark of Him, Who is the Life of the Universe, and the casket of Joseph. The Gentiles were saying: What is the purpose of these two caskets? Israel was answering them, that is the casket of Joseph with the ark of Him, Who is the Life of the Universe. The Gentiles were taunting Israel and saying, how is it possible that the casket of a dead person is travelling with the ark of Him, Who is the Life of the Universe? But Israel were answering, because this one kept all that is written in that one. Why did he say that? Rebbi Ḥanania<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">A late Galilean Amora from Sepphoris (Ẓipporin), colleague of R. Mana.</i> said, in order to speak some words of learning. Rebbi Mana said to him: Did he have no other word of learning to say but that<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Since he went frequently, why did he have to repeat the same text over and over again?</i>? But that was sarcasm, to say that Joseph did only attain kingdom by keeping the commandments of the Holy One, praise to Him, and we received all that glory only because we kept the commandments of the Holy One, praise to Him, but you<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">For R. Yoḥanan, the Roman government under Diocletian; for R. Mana, the Roman government under the Christian emperors.</i> want to remove His commandments from us!
How does one make the benedictions on them? Rebbi Zeriqan<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora in the generation after R. Yoḥanan and R. Jacob bar Idi. The parallels in the Babylonian Talmud are all anonymous.</i> in the name of Rebbi Jacob ben Rebbi Idi: When he puts <i>tefillin</i> on his arm, what does he say:<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60b" href="/Berakhot.60b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 60b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 36a" href="/Menachot.36a"><i>Menaḥot</i> 36a</a>) the order of the first two benedictions is inverted; the third benediction never was recited in Babylonia (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 44b" href="/Berakhot.44b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 44b</a>). There is a disagreement in principle between the two Talmudim. It is clear that the Yerushalmi requires two separate benedictions for the two <i>tefillin</i>; therefore, the second one which completes the action is the important and complete one. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 36a" href="/Menachot.36a">Babli (<i>Menaḥot</i> 36a</a>) it seems that if both <i>tefillin</i> are put on together then only one benediction is needed; the first benediction is the one that counts and has to be recited. [This is Sephardic and Oriental practice today; Ashkenazim recite the second benediction, which is strictly required only if no <i>tefillin</i> are available for one’s arm, out of doubt about the situation. In any case, in the Babylonian style, the second benediction is the minor one. Ashkenazic practice is an uneasy adaptation of Yerushalmi practice to Babylonian rules.]</i> “Praised<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">In all formulas of benedictions, one has to add after “praised”: “are You, o Eternal, our God, King of the Universe”.</i> Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us about the obligation of <i>tefillin</i>.” When he puts them on his head, what does he say? “Praised Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us about the obligation of putting on <i>tefillin</i>.” When he takes them off, what does he say? “Praised Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us to obey His laws.” That follows the opinion that the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:10" href="/Exodus.13.10"><i>Ex.</i> 13:10</a>. In that chapter, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:1" href="/Exodus.13.1">verses 1–8</a> speak of the laws of Passover, v. 9 introduces the commandment of <i>tefillin</i>. V. 10, the last in that paragraph, reads: “You shall keep this law in its time, מימים ימימה.” If the “law” is that of <i>tefillin,</i> one has to translate “from day to day”, meaning that at nighttime the law is either inoperative or that it is forbidden to wear <i>tefillin.</i> If the “law” is that of Passover, one has to translate “from year to year.” The latter meaning is the usual one for the Hebrew expression, but then it would have been rational to expect that verses 9 and 10 traded places.<br>The Yerushalmi refrains from attaching names to the different interpretations. In the Babylonian Talmud (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 96a" href="/Eruvin.96a"><i>Erubin</i> 96a</a>), the first interpretation is that of R. Yose the Galilean, the second one that of R. Aqiba. In the Yerushalmi source <i>Mekhilta deR. Simeon bar Yoḥai</i> (p. 41), the first interpretation is that of R. Aqiba and the second one of R. Eliezer. Since R. Aqiba belongs to the following generation, the basic disagreement can be attributed to Rebbis Yose the Galilean and Eliezer.</i> speaks about the law of <i>tefillin</i>. However, according to those who say that the verse speaks about the law of Passover, that does not apply.
Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Probably the Amora, student of Rebbi Yoḥanan, and not one of the Tannaïm.</i>: He who puts on <i>tefillin</i> in the night transgresses a positive commandment. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:10" href="/Exodus.13.10"><i>Ex.</i> 13:10</a>) “ “You shall keep this law in its time, from day to day;” “days” not night, “to days”<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning certain days, but not all days.</i> to exclude Sabbaths and holidays. But Rebbi Abbahu sat studying at night with his <i>tefillin</i> on his head!<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">How can he transgress his own statement?</i> He put them on the side<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Not between his eyes, so that he was not fulfilling the commandment of wearing them, but he had them on his head to keep them since <i>tefillin</i>, as holy objects, have to be deposited in safe places.</i>; they were like a deposit in his keeping. Some want to say, he only meant not to put them on, but when they were on him during daytime it would be permitted. Some want to say, let us hear it from there (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:9" href="/Exodus.13.9"><i>Ex.</i> 13:9</a>): “It shall be for you a sign,” when you need it for a sign, but not holiday or Sabbaths that are all sign. But is it not written “to days”<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">We do not expect the Torah to repeat commandments needlessly.</i>? You have only what Rebbi Yoḥanan said: Everything that is not clear one supports from many places<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:10" href="/Exodus.13.10"><i>Ex.</i> 13:10</a> may apply to Passover, any derivation from that verse is not clear. In <i>Mekhilta deR. Simeon bar Yoḥai</i>, the first derivation is anonymous, the second one is attributed to Rebbi Aqiba. While the discussion here is of Amoraïm, the entire material is tannaïtic.</i>.
Women from where? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:19" href="/Deuteronomy.11.19"><i>Deut.</i> 11:19</a>) “And you should teach them to your sons”, and not to your daughters.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">The main discussion of this point appears in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:3:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.3.2-11">Chapter 3:3</a>.</i> Anyone who is obliged to study Torah is obliged for <i>tefillin</i>, women who are not obliged to study Torah are not obliged for <i>tefillin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">The proof, explicit in the <i>Mekhiltot</i>, is really from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:9" href="/Exodus.13.9"><i>Ex.</i> 13:9</a>: “It shall be a sign on your hand and a remembrance between your eyes, <i>so that the Torah of the Eternal shall be in your mouth</i>, because with a strong hand the Eternal led you out of Egypt.” Hence, only one who is obliged to study is obliged to wear <i>tefillin</i>. Naturally, for those who declare that <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:10" href="/Exodus.13.10"><i>Ex.</i> 13:10</a> speaks of <i>tefillin</i> and nights are not a time for <i>tefillin</i>, it follows that <i>tefillin</i> is a positive commandment bound to stated times and, as a general principle, women are not obligated. However, since that interpretation of v. 10 is in doubt, it is not used here.</i> They objected, but did not Michal, the daughter of the Kushi<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Saul, addressed as “Kush” in the heading of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 7" href="/Psalms.7">Psalm 7</a>.</i>, wear <i>tefillin</i>, and did not the wife of Jonah make the pilgrimage to the Temple<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, everybody can go to Jerusalem anytime he wishes, and we know from many sources that entire families made the pilgrimage, in particular for Passover. What is meant here is that Jonah’s wife went to Jerusalem to bring the obligatory sacrifices in her own name, either additional to those of her husband or for herself when her husband was away at sea or at Nineveh. She may bring עוֹלת ראייה, the holocaust of appearance, as a voluntary offering, but if she insists on presenting the offering as obligatory for her pilgrimage, then there is a question of the legality of the offering and doubtful sacrifices should not be offered.</i>, and the sages did not object. Rebbi Ḥisqiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: Jonah’s wife was turned back<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Not from Jerusalem, but from presenting her pilgrimage sacrifice in the Temple separately from her husband.</i>, the sages forbade it to Michal the daughter of Kushi.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The first statement, that Michal wore <i>tefillin</i> and that the wife of Jonah made the pilgrimage, is a tannaïtic statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 96a" href="/Eruvin.96a">Babli (<i>Erubin</i> 96a</a>), and the Babli concludes from it that women <i>may</i> exercise all obligations that are bound to a fixed time from which women are freed. The Yerushalmi Amoraïm and later Yerushalmi sources (<i>Pesiqta rabbati</i> Chap. 22) disagree. This disagreement is not mentioned in the Babli; i. e., the argument is rejected.</i>
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:20" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.20">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 2:20</a>; a slightly different version is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 10a" href="/Shabbat.10a">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 10a</a>. One returns to the problem discussed earlier that <i>tefillin</i>, as objects of holiness, cannot be worn on an arm that is not separated from one’s genitals by some clothing. Hence, <i>tefillin</i> cannot be worn when one is naked, or in the presence of naked people. Prayer and religious study go by the same rules, following the verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Amos 4:12" href="/Amos.4.12"><i>Amos</i> 4:12</a>) “Israel, prepare yourself for your God”.</i>: “Entering a bathhouse, in the room where everybody is fully clothed<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">A Roman bathhouse was essentially a sauna. In the hot room, everybody was naked. In the anteroom, one was cooling down after the hot steam, getting massaged by the <i>olearii</i>, and putting on one’s clothes. The outer rooms were used for social affairs, especially in large cities.</i> one may read the Bible, pray<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the Rome manuscript, the Tosephta and R. Solomon Cirillo; the Leyden manuscript and the Venice print have תפילין “<i>tefillin</i>”; but these are separately mentioned later.</i>, and needless to say, one may greet people<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">The problem with the greeting formula “peace with you” is that Peace is one of the names of God, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Judges 6:24" href="/Judges.6.24"><i>Jud.</i> 6:24</a>; hence, greeting somebody with שָּׁלוֹם עֲלֵיכֶם is permitted only under circumstances that would allow prayer. The prohibition does not include greetings in other languages if the name of God is not invoked.</i>. One may put on <i>tefillin</i>, and needless to say, one does not remove them. In the room where most people are naked one may not exchange greetings and needless to say, there is no Bible reading or prayer; one removes one’s <i>tefillin</i> and needless to say, one does not put them on. Where some are naked and some are clothed there is greeting, no Bible reading and no prayer, one does not remove <i>tefillin</i> and one does not put them on. But one does not put them on again until he has completely left the grounds of that bathhouse.” This supports what Rebbi Isaac said about Rebbi Yoḥanan, that he wore them until he came to Jacob, the bath master.
Rebbi Jeremiah asked before Rebbi Zeïra: If it was used as bath house in summer but not in the rainy season, what is the rule<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">May one pray in the room in which people are naked if the installation is in use?</i>? He said to him, a bath house even if it is not in use, a toilet even if it does not contain excrement<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">The rules of toilets, in which all religious acts are forbidden, are explained in Chapter 3, both in Yerushalmi (fol. 6d) and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 26a" href="/Berakhot.26a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 26a</a>).</i>. Mar Uqba<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">It is questionable whether this is a statement of Mar Uqba, <i>Resh Galuta</i>(Head of the Diaspora) in the time of Rav. The author of the statement is either Rabbana Uqba, grandson of Mar Uqba and Rav, or, more likely, Rav Uqba bar Ḥama, student and son-in-law of Rav Ḥisda. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25a" href="/Berakhot.25a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i>25a</a>), the statement is attributed to Rav Papa, student of Rav Ḥisda’s student Rava (brother-in-law of Rav Uqba bar Ḥama).</i> said: a pig is a moving toilet. Rebbi Jonah<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Head of the Yeshivah of Tiberias together with the Amora Rebbi Yose, of the fourth generation of Amoraïm, and a student of Rebbi Jeremiah.</i> investigated: A pebble on the sea shore, what is the rule?<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">May one pray next to a pebble on the seashore covered with excrement, when one has to assume that some human used the pebble to cleanse himself after defecating, but in the meantime waves covered the pebble many times and it does not smell any more?</i> Rebbi Ammi the physician<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora about whom nothing more is known.</i> said: Rebbi Jeremiah taught that one may pass it by <i>pylyvs</i><sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Perhaps compare פיליוס to Latin <i>pileus, pilleus</i>, “bonnet, felt hat”, also Greek πίλινος “of felt”, πιλίον “a bandage” (E. G.). The reading of the Rome manuscript is פיליונס. The word appears as פיליוס in Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 8:1; Rashi there explains the word by old French <i>orel</i>, a scarf; <i>Arukh</i>, in its Italian translation <i>ossi</i>, means a scarf used to cover the mouth. The meaningtherefore is that Rebbi Jeremiah counsels to cover one’s face with a scarf. (Musaphia reads <i>pallium</i>, “coverlet, gown.”)</i>, but one does not trust this ruling<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear whether the rejection of Rebbi Jeremiah’s statement is from Rebbi Ammi the physician or from the editor of the Talmud.</i>.
Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Abba bar Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">A Babylonian Amora (in the Babli he has a title and is called Rabba bar Jeremiah, short for Rav Abba bar Jeremiah), a student of Rav and possibly the son of Rav’s companion Rav Jeremiah bar Abba. From the following it is clear that Rabba bar Jeremiah quotes the ruling as a traditional one from Tannaïm, not a new amoraic ruling. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 23b" href="/Berakhot.23b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 23b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 41b" href="/Sukkah.41b"><i>Sukkah</i> 41b</a>), the second part of his statement, about sleeping, is introduced as an anonymous tannaitic statement (תנו רבנן).</i>: One may eat a snack while wearing them<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>tefillin</i>. A snack is a meal which does not involve bread. The rule about eating is not mentioned in the Babli; hence, the Babli agrees with it.</i>, but one may not eat a regular meal while wearing them; one may doze<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Dozing is defined as “sleeping and not sleeping.” The Babli forbids both dozing and sleeping.</i> while wearing them, but one may not sleep while wearing them. Some Tannaïm formulate: One says the benediction once; some Tannaïm formulate: One says the benediction twice<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">It is also possible to read פְּעָמִין“several times” but the discussion in the next sentence mentions “two times”. The entire sentence is a continuation of the first statement of Abba bar Jeremiah; he is reported by Rebbi Zeïra to have said that one may eat a snack and doze while wearing <i>tefillin</i>, R. Zeïra then reports that some Tannaïm require that one recite the benediction over <i>tefillin</i> once a day, but some others say that the benediction is recited (at least) two times a day. The objection is that (except for a fast day) one has to eat, hence one has to take off one’s <i>tefillin</i> and put them on again, certainly with a benediction. The anwer is that some people eat only snacks during daytime; hence, it is proved that the Tanna agrees with Abba bar Jeremiah that for a snack one does not have to remove his <i>tefillin</i>.</i>. He who says one says the benediction once, how can he be right? He who says, one says the benediction twice, because he ate and then they are not on him. Rebbi Zeïra said, Abba bar Jeremiah talks about one who eats only snacks.
Rebbi Zeïra in the name of (Rebbi) Abba [bar Jeremiah]<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">While all sources have here “Rebbi Abba”, the continuation shows that one must read “(Rav) Abba bar Jeremiah”. This is also required since the next statement of Rebbi Zeïra, unrelated to the subject under discussion, is only quoted because it also is in the name of Abba bar Jeremiah.</i>: A person should not enter a urinal<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eleazar Askari (followed by <i>Pene Moshe</i>) wants to identify the “house of water” with a toilet since in Arabic a toilet is called בַּית אַלמַא “house of water”, but L. Ginzburg already noted that this is impossible; in the Yerushalmi as in the Babli a toilet is called בית הכסא. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 4:5" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.4.5">Tosephta (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 4:8</a>) it is stated that a king, who has to write for himself a Torah that has to accompany him everywhere (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:19" href="/Deuteronomy.17.19"><i>Deut.</i> 17:19</a>), may not take the Torah with him to the “house of water”. This rule is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 21b" href="/Sanhedrin.21b">Babli <i>Sanhedrin</i> 21b</a>, in the reading of R. Ḥananel and ms. ק, in the formulation that he takes the Torah with him neither to the bathhouse, nor to the toilet, nor to urinate. Hence, the toilet and the “house of water” are two different things.</i> with his books or <i>tefillin</i> in his hands. Rebbi Yoḥanan, when he had a book<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 23a" href="/Berakhot.23a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 23a</a>), a book of sermons.</i> in his hand he gave it to somebody else. When his <i>tefillin</i> were on him, he stood in them<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) reports that Rebbi Yoḥanan put the <i>tefillin</i> in a pouch which he kept in his hand, not that he was wearing them. But the Babli does not speak about a urinal (with canalization, after the Roman fashion) but of a toilet, i. e., an outhouse. Roman canalization was unknown in Babylonia. Hence, the seemingly parallel passages in reality deal with different subjects.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Abba bar Jeremiah: A man may enter a urinal with his books or <i>tefillin</i> in his hand. Rebbi Zeïra said: Abba bar Jeremiah refers to one case where he can wear them, and to another case where he cannot wear them<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">This distinction is also reported in the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) in the name of Rebbi Zera (Zeïra). If one takes off the <i>tefillin</i> in the evening, when there is not time anymore to put them on afterwards, one must put the <i>tefillin</i> in a designated bag or chest so as to treat them with respect. Temporary disrespect is only authorized if <i>tefillin</i> have to be ready for immediate use.</i>. For if he cannot perform a <i>mitzwah</i> with them, why should he degrade them?
First they were giving them<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>tefillin</i>, when somebody was entering a toilet. In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 23a" href="/Berakhot.23a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 23a</a>), it is not mentioned that first one had to hand the <i>tefillin</i>, which represent a considerable monetary worth, to other people.</i> to others; these were taking them and fleeing. They decreed that one should put them in holes in the wall. When that incident<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">The incident is decribed in detail in the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>): A prostitute found a pair of <i>tefillin</i> in a hole near a public toilet, took them, and bragged publicly that she had received them for her services from a certain holy man who then committed suicide as a consequence of the public scandal.</i> happened, they decreed that a person should enter and keep them in his hand.
