Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">A colleague of Rebbi Zeïra. The argument here, relating to a toilet, is parallel to the preceding one, relating to a urinal.</i> in the name of Rebbi Zeïra said: but only if there is time left during the day to put them on again. But if there is no time left in the day to put them on, it is forbidden. For if he cannot perform a <i>mitzwah</i> with them, why should he degrade them? Maisha (Moses), grandson of R. Joshua ben Levi, said: He who wants to do it right, makes for them a pouch the size of a hand-breadth and puts them on his heart<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">A pouch with straps so that in case of need one can put the <i>tefillin</i> in the pouch and carry them hanging under his outer garment, the strap going around his neck. Since one needs the pouch anyhow for storing the <i>tefillin</i> during nighttime, the counsel of Rebbi Maishe is only to put the straps on so that the pouch can be used also during daytime. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 24a" href="/Berakhot.24a">Babli (24a</a>) forbids expressly to have the <i>tefillin</i> hanging on its own straps (not those of a pouch).</i>. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 16:8" href="/Psalms.16.8"><i>Ps.</i> 16:8</a>): “I put the Eternal always before me.” There<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. The parallel in the Babli (<i>Šabbat</i> 49a) reads: “Rebbi Yannai said: <i>Tefillin</i> need a clean body, like Elisha of the bird’s wings.” R. Z. Frankel points out that at the start of fol. 4c, the Yerushalmi quotes that “Rebbi Yannai said: <i>Tefillin</i> need a clean body”; hence, the reference to Elisha of the bird-wings is really a Babylonian addition. The story is told only in the Babli, <i>loc. cit.</i>, that Elisha was wearing <i>tefillin</i> when, in the aftermath of the war of Bar Kokhba, wearing <i>tefillin</i> was a capital crime. But he took them off when he saw a policeman and kept them in his hands. When the policeman asked him what he held in his hands, he said: “a couple of bird’s wings.” When he was ordered to open his hands, two birds flew away and his life was saved. (This story shows again that <i>tefillin</i> cases were not supposed to be larger than about 3/8th of an inch square.)<br>The implication of this Babylonian ruling is that nobody can be expected to keep his body perfectly clean for very long; hence, <i>tefillin</i> should be removed after prayers.</i> they say: He who is not like Elisha of the bird’s wings should not put on <i>tefillin</i>.
Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav Abba bar Jeremiah: A person may not enter a cemetery and relieve himself there.<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">The connection with the preceding section is that this is a statement of Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav Abba bar Jeremiah, and it speaks about relieving oneself.</i> When he did it anyway, about him the verse says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 17:5" href="/Proverbs.17.5"><i>Prov.</i> 17:5</a>) “He who makes fun of the poor blasphemes his Maker.”<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">He who relieves himself in the cemetery makes fun of the dead two-fold; first he shows his contempt for the dead and then he does something that the dead can do no more. Even graveside sermons are unacceptable in Judaism since the dead can no longer have any Torah thoughts.</i> Clarification: The great Rebbi Ḥiyya and Rebbi Jonathan<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">The greatest of the preachers of the first generation of Amoraïm, student of R. Simeon bar Yose bar Laqonia, a preacher of the last generation of Tannaïm who was the brother-in-law of the son of R. Simeon bar Yoḥai.</i> were walking before the bier of Rebbi Simeon bar Yose bar Laqonia when Rebbi Jonathan stepped over his grave. The great Rebbi Ḥiyya said to him: About that they will say, tomorrow they will be with us but they hurt us. He answered him, do they know anything? Is it not written: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 9:5" href="/Proverbs.9.5"><i>Prov.</i> 9:5</a>) “But the dead do not know anything.” He told him: you know how to read, you do not know how to preach. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 9:5" href="/Proverbs.9.5"><i>Prov.</i> 9:5</a>) “The living know that they will die”, these are the Just who even in death are considered living; “but the dead do not know anything;” these are the wicked who even in life are called dead. From where that the wicked even in life are called dead? It is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 18:32" href="/Ezekiel.18.32"><i>Ez.</i> 18:32</a>) “For I have no pleasure in the death of the dead;” how can a dead person die? But these are the wicked who even in life are called dead. And from where that the Just even in death are considered living? It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 34:4" href="/Deuteronomy.34.4"><i>Deut.</i> 34:4</a>) “And He said to him: This is the land I had sworn to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, to tell.” Why does the verse say “to tell”? He said to him: go and tell the patriarchs that all I had promised I fulfilled to your descendants after you.
If one connected the letters<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">One speaks here about writing <i>tefillin</i>, <i>mezuzot</i> and Torah scrolls, not about wearing them. The main discussion is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 1:7:2-8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.1.7.2-8.1">Yerushalmi <i>Megillah</i> 1:9</a>; here it is quoted since it is somehow connected with the topic of <i>tefillin</i> but mainly because it belongs to a sequence of statements by Rebbi Idi in the name of Rebbi Simeon in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan, which belong to the topic of prayer. The explanation of this paragraph follows the interpretation of <i>Rashba</i> (Solomon ben Adrat, <i>Responsa</i>, vol. 1, #711).<br>The problem is the legal status of a holy text in which two letters touch one another. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 49a" href="/Menachot.49a">Babli states (<i>Menaḥot</i> 49a</a>) that every letter must be surrounded by white parchment. The Yerushalmi has no equivalent statement but one may assume that it subscribes to the same standard. It is also required that a letter should be written, not carved out. Hence, if a letter is completely written and its foot accidentally touches the following letter, as with a slightly too long foot of נ in נו, one may scratch off the superfluous length and has a complete acceptable letter. But when a letter has its head elongated, so that from the start the letter was not standing free, then the entire letter has to be scratched out and the writing has to start anew. The questionable case is a situation with a letter that is hanging down below the line, as in the combination תך when the small foot of ת meets the downward stroke of ך. In that case, the ת was complete but the ך was not; this case remains unsettled (i. e., for practical rulings both letters have to be erased and rewritten.)</i>; there is a Tanna who stated: it is valid, and there is a Tanna who stated: it is invalid. Rebbi Idi<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">A Babylonian who became a Galilean Amora in the Yeshivah of Rebbi Ammi. The Rebbi Simeon here is Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish.</i> in the name of Rebbi Simeon in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: He who says it is valid, below; he who said it is invalid, on top. For example, ארצך .ארצנו, תפארתנוּ is questionable, תפארתך is questionable.
Rebbi Idi in the name of Rebbi Simeon in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">These are the correct names, appearing in the parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 1:7:2-8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.1.7.2-8.1"><i>Megillah</i> 1:9</a> and in the Rome ms. here. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 10" href="/Berakhot.10">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 10</a>) is aatributed to Rebbi Yose ben R. Ḥanina in the name of the Tanna Rebbi Eliëzer ben Jacob. Venice print: ר׳ אידי בר׳ שמעון בשם ר׳ יוסה.</i>: No man should stand at an elevated place and pray. What is the reason? Rebbi Abba the son of R. Pappai<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that the name must be “son of <i>Rebbi</i> Pappai”; the Galilean Amora Rebbi Abba lived a generation before the Babylonian Amora Rav Pappi, one of the successors of Rava.</i> said: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 130:1" href="/Psalms.130.1"><i>Ps.</i> 130:1</a>) “From the depth I call on You, o Eternal!”
Rebbi Idi in the name of Rebbi Simeon in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan said: No man should pray when he has an urge to go to the bathroom<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 23a" href="/Berakhot.23a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 23a</a>) this appears as a statement of R. Samuel ben Naḥmani in the name of Rebbi Jonathan. It is really a Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 2:18).</i>. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Amos 4:12" href="/Amos.4.12"><i>Amos</i> 4:12</a>) “Prepare yourself before Your God, o Israel!” Rebbi Alexandri said: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 4:17" href="/Ecclesiastes.4.17"><i>Eccl.</i> 4:17</a>) “Watch you feet when you go to God’s house”; watch yourself from the drops that drip from between your feet. That means, for urine. But for defecation, if he can bear it, let him bear it<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli disagrees and states that prayer is only permitted when one is able to walk 4 <i>mil</i> without going to the bathroom (about a 70 minutes’ walk).</i>.
Rebbi Jacob bar Abbai<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">An Israeli Amora of the last generation. His statement is placed here since it gives a different interpretation of the last verse quoted before. In the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) this is also a statement of R. Samuel bar Naḥmani in the name of Rebbi Jonathan, i. e., of the first generations of Israeli Amoraïm.</i> in the name of Rebbi Aḥa: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 4:17" href="/Ecclesiastes.4.17"><i>Eccl.</i> 4:17</a>) “Watch you feet when you go to God’s house”; watch yourself when you are called to God’s house<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., when you die.</i> that you should be pure and innocent. Rebbi Abba said: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 5:18" href="/Proverbs.5.18"><i>Prov.</i> 5:18</a>) “Your fountain shall be blessed”, your being called to the grave shall be blessed. Rebbi Berekhiah said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 3:1" href="/Ecclesiastes.3.1"><i>Eccl.</i> 3:1</a>): “A time to be born and a time to die”, hail to the man whose hour of death is like the hour of his birth; just as at the hour of his birth he was innocent so at the hour of his death may he be innocent.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He who recited the <i>Shema‘</i> and did not make his ear hear, (Rebbi Yehudah says that)<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">In the separate Mishnah at the start of the chapter (fol. 4a), as well as in most Mishnah and Babli manuscripts, the words in parenthesis are missing. However, in some manuscripts both of Mishnah and Babli, the words appear. It seems from the <i>Halakhah</i> that the editors of the Yerushalmi did not read the words in parenthesis and, maybe, considered the full text as a <i>baraita</i>. A similar instance appears in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 15a" href="/Berakhot.15a">Babli (15a</a>) where the Mishnah is presented in this form: He who recited the <i>Shema‘</i> and did not make his ear hear has fulfilled his obligation, and the Gemara two lines later treats this as anonymous statement, but five lines further down quotes the Mishnah (דתנן) as: ‘He who recited the <i>Shema‘</i> and did not make his ear hear has fulfilled his obligation, these are the words of Rebbi Yehudah.’ One of the editors of 18th Cent. editions of the Talmud, R. Joel Sirkes known as <i>Baḥ</i>, wants to cross out the last part of the quote, but the Yerushalmi shows that two versions of the Mishnah did exist and, since it is impossible to write two versions at the same place, one is quoted as a separate Mishnah and the other in the text.</i> he has fulfilled his obligation, Rebbi Yose says that he has not fulfilled his obligation. If he recited and was not exact in its letters<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., he mispronounced or slurred.</i>, Rebbi Yose says that he has fulfilled his obligation, Rebbi Yehudah says that he has not fulfilled his obligation. He who reads backwards has not fulfilled his obligation. If he recited and made a mistake then he should return to the place of the mistake.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rav said: practice follows both of them for leniency<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 15b" href="/Berakhot.15b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 15b</a>), this is a statement of Rebbi Ṭabi in the name of Rebbi Josiah; the latter was a student of Rebbi Yoḥanan. The statement in the Babli is accepted without discussion because, as Rav Haï Gaon points out in his commentary, the Talmud previously did establish that the first statement is Rebbi Yehudah’s and, therefore, the question asked in the Yerushalmi has no place in the Babli.<br>One may assume that the fact that the ruling is attributed to a Babylonian in the Yerushalmi and to a Galilean in the Babli is intentional, to show that this is the universally accepted practice [necessary, because in general borrowing leniencies from opposing points of view is frowned upon.]</i>. If it were not so, what could one say? An anonymous statement and Rebbi Yose, practice follows the anonymous<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Here, the Yerushalmi uses the Mishnah without the clause which identifies Rebbi Yehudah as the author. An anonymous statement in the Mishnah gives the consensus of the Sages and therefore has the force of law.</i>. Rebbi Yose and Rebbi Yehudah, practice follows Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">This is also the position of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 46b" href="/Eruvin.46b">Babli, <i>Erubin</i> 46b</a>. It follows that the statement of Rav seems superfluous.</i>. So why does Rav have to say, practice follows both of them for leniency? Because he had heard Rebbi Ḥiyya formulating it in the name of Rebbi Meïr<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>), Rebbi Meïr states that the obligation of reciting <i>Shema‘</i> “is in the mind”; this implies that one does not have to hear what he himself is saying. Since the Mishnah or an equivalent is never quoted in the name of Rebbi Meïr, R. Zachariah Frankel wants to correct “Rebbi Meïr” to “Rebbi Yehudah” and considers the second version of the Mishnah in both Talmudim as the Mishnah of Rebbi Ḥiyya, in contrast to the Mishnah of Rebbi that is formulated anonymously. However, there is no textual support for such a theory.<br>Practice follows Rebbi Yose even against Rebbi Meïr; hence, the statement of Rav is necessary for the first part of the Mishnah.</i>, he has to say that practice follows both of them for leniency.
It was stated: “He who did pray<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">The thrice daily <i>Amidah</i> prayer.</i> and did not make his ear hear did fulfill his obligation.” For whom do we need that? For Rebbi Yose! For which statement of Rebbi Yose? For that which we have stated: “He who recites the <i>Shema‘</i> and did not make his ear hear has fulfilled his obligation, Rebbi Yose says that he has not fulfilled his obligation.” Rav Mattanah<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph and the following do not really belong here, they refer to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 2:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.2.5.1">Mishnah <i>Megillah</i> 2:4</a>: “The insane, the deaf and dumb, and minors cannot read the <i>Megillah</i> (for others)”. Rav Mattanah notes that, obviously, one does not mean a deaf and dumb person who cannot talk, but a deaf person who cannot hear. Since the Mishnah is anonymous, it must be the consensus of the Sages that one cannot fulfill the obligation of reading the <i>Megillah</i> if one does not hear what he himself is saying. Hence, the general consensus in <i>Megillah</i> is identical with the opinion of Rebbi Yose in <i>Berakhot</i>. The practice, therefore, should follow Rebbi Yose for stringency, in contrast to Rav’s statement in the preceding paragraph.</i> said: That formulation is Rebbi Yose’s. Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">The Amora, one of the compilers of the Jerusalem Talmud.</i> said: We could be of the opinion that the rabbis and Rebbi Yose disagree only about <i>Shema‘</i> since there it is written: “hear!”, but not about any other obligations. Since Rav Mattanah said “that formulation is Rebbi Yose’s”, it is the same for all obligations. What is the reason of Rebbi Yose? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 15:26" href="/Exodus.15.26"><i>Ex.</i> 15:26</a>) “Bend your ear to His commandments”, your ears should hear what your mouth says.
Rav Ḥisda said: The deaf and dumb person is not mentioned, it is a formula.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Since in all legal matters the insane, the deaf and dumb, and minors are equally incapacitated, the people who had to memorize “insane and minors” automatically changed the phrase in their memories to “insane, deaf and dumb, and minors”. After this correction, the Mishnah in <i>Megillah</i> may well be Rebbi Yehudah’s.</i> Then the Mishnah might be Rebbi Yehudah’s. Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">The Amora.</i> said: It is reasonable to think that Rav Ḥisda concedes that the statement from <i>Terumot</i> is from Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Terumah</i>, the heave, is the first gift of grain to the Cohen from the new harvest. There is no amount fixed for <i>terumah</i> in the Pentateuch; it must be consecrated explicitly. Only a person of sound mind can consecrate <i>terumah</i>. The first Mishnah in tractate <i>Terumot</i> reads: “Five categories of people cannot consecrate <i>terumah</i> and if they did it anyhow, their actions are null and void: the deaf and dumb, the insane, minors, one who is not the owner, and a non-Jew.” The sixth Mishnah then reads: “Five categories of people should not consecrate <i>terumah</i> (since <i>a priori</i> it requires the recitation of a benediction) but if they did it anyhow their actions are valid: the speechless, the drunk, the naked, the blind, those impure by emission of semen.” In between it is explained that חרש means a deaf and dumb person who is not legally capable of acting but that the deaf who can talk belongs to the same category as the second group of five.</i>. Rabbi Ḥanina said in the name of Rav Ḥisda, this one is by Rebbi Yose. Rebbi Yose bar Rebbi Abun said: It must be said that that one is Rebbi Yose’s since we have stated the first five cases and did not include it<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">The case of the deaf who is able to speak.</i>, because their <i>terumah</i> is no <i>terumah</i>. Then we have stated the five later ones and did not include it. So in the end you must say, that one is by Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, the second Mishnah in <i>Terumot</i>, explaining that the deaf who is able to speak can give <i>terumah</i>, has to be formulated separately and could not be included in the sixth Mishnah since the first and sixths Mishnayot are Rebbi Yose’s who will object to the inclusion of the deaf-but-not-speechless in the second group.</i>.
These need careful attention: <i>al-lĕvāvĕkhā</i>, <i>al-lĕvavkhem</i>, <i>ēśev bĕśādĕkhā</i>, <i>waăvadt̂em mĕh̃ēr̄āh</i>, <i>hakkānāph pĕt́īl</i>, <i>etkhem mēereẓ</i><sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 15b" href="/Berakhot.15b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 15b</a>) this list is an appendix by Rava to a <i>baraita</i> stating that in reciting the <i>Shema‘</i> one has to differentiate between identical sounds. There is no problem with the words in <i>Shema‘</i> where final and initial 1 and m clash. More of a problem is the clash of soft and hard ב, פ. The late Prof. Y. Kutscher pointed out that in classical Arabic there is a tendency to pronounce fb as bb [<i>Contemporary Studies in North-Western Semitic</i>, Journal of Semitic Studies 10(1965) pp. 21–51, see p. 30] but it seems clear at least for ב which, under the influence of the Greek that was the common vernacular, in Galilee both ב and בּ were pronounced “v”. For example, the technical term מחוור “logically consistent” in the Babli appears as מְחוּבָּר “connected” in Yerushalmi <i>Peah</i> 2:1, fol.l6d. It does not make any sense to derive מחוור from Aramaic חוור “pale”. Hence, Galilean מחבר sounded מחוור in Babylonian ears. (Possibly both ב and בּ were pronounced as “b” in Babylonia, as they still are today in dialects of Jews from Arabic speaking countries.) It is less certain but still possible that פ was pronounced “p-h” rather than “f”.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi Aḥa: <i>ăšer nišb̀a’ ădonay</i><sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">In Biblical times, ע (‘) was a hard glottal sound similar to Arabian Arabic ع but in Talmudic times it was either silent (see the next paragraph) or very weak so that there was (almost) a double vowel a.</i>.
Rebbi Samuel bar Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi Hoshaiah<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">A Babylonian, student of Rav Yehudah and Rav Huna, who later emigrated to Israel and became student of Rebbi Yoḥanan.</i>: “He Who forms light and creates darkness<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">This is the beginning of the first benediction before the <i>Shema‘</i>, it appears here in the context of the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>. The language is that of the verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 45:7" href="/Isaiah.45.7"><i>Is.</i> 45:7</a>) “He Who forms light and creates darkness, makes peace and creates evil.” In prayer, the verse is changed to “He Who forms light and creates darkness, makes peace and creates all” to soften the language. Rebbi Hoshaiah notes that one may not go so far as to eliminate the mention of darkness, in the words of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 12a" href="/Berakhot.12a">Babli (12a</a>) “to mention night at day and day at night”, to negate any Zoroastrian dualism.</i>”; one should not say: “He Who forms light and creates radiance.” Rebbi Ḥaggai<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">A Babylonian who went to study in Tiberias.</i> in the name of Rebbi Abba bar Zavda<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean who went to study temporarily in Babylonia; he was a chief authority in Galilee after the death of Rebbi Yoḥanan. Both authors mentioned here were familiar with the Babylonian prayer ritual.</i>: “There they sang for You<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:6:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.6.2-11">Halakhah 1:9</a>, the Yerushalmi quotes the Babylonian version of a short benediction after <i>Shema‘</i>: “We thank You that You took us out of Egypt and redeemed us from the house of slavery to thank Your Name”. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 14b" href="/Berakhot.14b">Babli (14b</a>) has the corresponding Galilean version: “We thank You that You took us out of Egypt and redeemed us from the house of slavery, did for us wonders and great deeds on the sea, and we sang for You”. The version “There they praised You” seems to be an alternative Babylonian form that is rejected here (since it is not a proper introduction to the required recitation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 15:11" href="/Exodus.15.11"><i>Ex.</i> 15:11</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 15:19" href="/Exodus.15.19">19</a>. In later times, the Israeli standard introduction to these verses was בגילה ברנה בשמחה רבה ואמרו כולם, retained in the Ashkenazic service on holiday nights.)</i>”, one should not say: “There they praised You”. Rebbi Levi, Rebbi Eudaimon<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the second generation. His name Εὐδαίμων “fortunate” shows that the pronounciation of Greek in his time was as today, that υ = f = ב.</i> of Haifa, in the name of Rebbi Levi bar Sisi<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Levi who usually is quoted without title or patronymic.</i>: one has to pronounce <i>tizkeru</i> voiced<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Since voiced z (ז) and voiceless s (שׂ,ס) are similar sounds, care is needed to distinguish between תזכרו (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:40" href="/Numbers.15.40"><i>Num.</i> 15:40</a>) “you shall remember” and תסכרו “you shall dam up”, תשׂכרו “you shall hire”, and even, under the influence of Greek, which knows no <i>sh</i> sound, תשׁכרו “you will get drunk”.</i>. Rebbi Jonah in the name of Rav Ḥisda: one has to pronounce <i>ki lĕ‘ôlām ḥasdȏ</i> voiced<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear why one should pronounce חַסְדּוֹ with a soft <i>s.</i> R. Zachariah Frankel notes that the two Aramaic verbs חֲסַד <i>ḥăsad</i> “to be loving” and חַסַּד <i>ḥassad</i> “to insult, degrade” differ in the quality of its <i>s</i> sound; hence, one has to take care that “truly, His kindness is forever” should not sound as “truly, His insulting is forever”. It seems that while <i>s</i> should not really sound like <i>z</i>, care has to be taken not to make it sound like <i>ss</i>. Maybe the same difference was once heard between Hebrew חסד I “to show kindness” and חסד II “to insult.”</i>. It was stated: One does not take as reader anyone from Haifa, Beth Sheän or Tiv‘on since they read ח like <sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Western Ashkenazic pronunciation treated ח like <i>hh</i> until the middle of the sixteenth Century. Under the influence of Polish, which in contrast to German has only one <i>ch</i>- sound, Ashkenazic pronunciation lost the difference between ח (<i>ḥ</i>) and כ (<i>kh</i>). In all other Jewish dialects, the problem is not the identification of כ,ח but of ע . ח,ה is lost in all Ashkenazic pronunciations; it is retained in Italian and Portuguese Hebrew as <i>ng</i>.</i>ה and ע like א. If his pronunciation was orderly, it would be permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">If he makes an effort and tries to realize the difference, even if he does not quite succeed.</i>.
<b>New Section.</b>He who reads backwards<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Reading sentences out of order; reading words out of order is clearly useless since it makes no sense.</i> has not fulfilled his obligation. Rebbi Jonah said that Rav Naḥman bar Ada<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">A Babylonian, student of Samuel. He probably is identical with “Naḥman the Old”, to distinguish him from later Amoraïm also called Naḥman.</i> stated, Rebbi Yose said that Naḥman the Old stated, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:6" href="/Deuteronomy.6.6"><i>Deut.</i> 6:6</a>) “They shall be”, they shall be unaltered<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Taking the verb היה “to be” in the sense of “to exist”.</i>. We have stated: The same holds for <i>Hallel</i> and the reading of the Esther scroll.
This is fine for the Esther scroll since it is written there (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Esther 9:27" href="/Esther.9.27"><i>Esther</i> 9:27</a>): “As they are written”<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads: “The Jews confirmed and accepted for themselves, not to be cancelled, that they would observe these two days <i>as they are written</i> and it its time, every single year.” Hence, the scroll must be read as it is written.</i>. But for <i>Hallel</i>, since it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 113:3" href="/Psalms.113.3"><i>Ps.</i> 113:3</a>): “From sunrise to sunset, may the name of the Eternal be praised?”<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Since there is no difference between East and West, there should be no difference between before and after.</i> What can you understand from that? Rebbi Abun said: It also is written in order. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 114:1" href="/Psalms.114.1"><i>Ps.</i> 114:1</a>) “When Israel left Egypt” in the past. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 115:1" href="/Psalms.115.1"><i>Ps.</i> 115:1</a>) “Not for us, o Eternal, not for us” in the present<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">In the much more detailed parallel passage in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 118a" href="/Pesachim.118a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 118a</a>), this sentence is applied by Rebbi Yoḥanan either to the oppression by hostile governments or to the sufferings preceding the coming of the Messiah. That may be the meaning of the sentence here also. Alternatively, the psalm is interpreted there as the song of Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah in the fiery oven.</i>. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 116:1" href="/Psalms.116.1"><i>Ps.</i> 116:1</a>) “I loved, truly the Eternal listened to my voice” in the days of the Messiah. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 118:27" href="/Psalms.118.27"><i>Ps.</i> 118:27</a>) “Bind the holiday sacrifice with ropes” in the days of Gog and Magog<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">In the celebration after the final defeat of the forces of evil. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 118:24" href="/Psalms.118.24"><i>Midrash Tehillim</i>, <i>Ps.</i> 118:24</a> “This is the day the Eternal made, let us rejoice and be happy on it” is taken to describe the time when one can be sure that the deliverance will not be followed by another oppression.</i>. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 118:28" href="/Psalms.118.28"><i>Ps.</i> 118:28</a>) “You are my God” in the future world.
Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Also he who composed this prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">The week-day 18 benedictions of the <i>Amidah</i>. Another derivation is given in the following paragraph.</i> composed it in good order. The first three and the last three are the praise of the Omnipresent, the middle ones are the needs of the creatures. Give us knowledge. You gave us knowledge<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">The entire list should be read as a conditional: Assuming that You gave us knowledge (fourth benediction), please accept our repentance (fifth benediction). This is particularly evident in the second part, starting from the prayer for good years, which is a prayer for redemption and therefore future oriented even though the formulation here is in the past tense.</i>, accept our repentance. You accepted our repentance, forgive us. You forgave us, save us. You saved us, heal our diseases. You healed our diseases, bless our years. You blessed our years, gather us in. You gathered us in, judge us in justice. You judged us in justice, subdue those who arise against us.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">While the benediction against apostates was introduced at Jabneh and the rest of the <i>Amidah</i> is an institution of the Men of the Great Assembly, its place was chosen in the spirit of those who first formulated the prayer.</i> You subdued those who arise against us, justify us<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">This is the text of the Rome and Genizah manuscripts, not like the Leyden manuscript and the Venice print which have צדקנו במשפט “justify us in law” that belongs to the benediction before the previous one, not to the one for the elders (and all) of Israel and the converts which follows after the imprecation against apostates.</i>. You justified us, build Your house, listen to our supplications, be pleased with us in it. Is it necessary after “build Your house,” listen to our supplications, be pleased with us in it<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">After a prayer for the rebuilding of Jerusalem and the Temple, the prayers for acceptance of the prayer and the hope that our service be for God’s pleasure may seem superfluous since acceptance of prayer and God’s pleasure are guaranteed in the Temple.</i>? But as the verse is, so is the tradition (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 56:7" href="/Isaiah.56.7"><i>Is.</i> 56:7</a>): “I shall bring them to My holy mountain, make them happy in My house of prayer.<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">A parallel with slightly different treatment of the entire paragraph appears in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 17b-18a" href="/Megillah.17b-18a">Babli <i>Megillah</i> 17b–18a</a>.</i>”
<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">A parallel with slightly different treatment of the entire paragraph appears in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 17b-18a" href="/Megillah.17b-18a">Babli <i>Megillah</i> 17b–18a</a>.</i> Rebbi Jeremiah said: 120 elders, among them more than 80 prophets, instituted this prayer. Why did they follow “the holy God”<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">The third benediction of the <i>Amidah</i>. What follows is a description of the benedictions of the week-day <i>Amidah</i>.</i> by “He Who favors with knowledge”? Because (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 29:23-24" href="/Isaiah.29.23-24"><i>Is.</i> 29:23–24</a>) “they sanctify the Holy One of Jacob” is followed by “and those of erring spirit will know insight.” “Knowledge” followed by “Repentance”, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 6:10" href="/Isaiah.6.10"><i>Is.</i> 6:10</a>) “Makefat the heart of this people, make it hard of hearing and its eyes sticky, that it should not see with its eyes, nor hear with its ears, nor understand with its heart, because if it would repent then it would be healed.” “Repentance” by “Forgiveness”, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 55:7" href="/Isaiah.55.7"><i>Is.</i> 55:7</a>) “He should return to the Lord that He would have mercy on him, and to our God because He forgives much.” “Forgiveness” by “Redemption”, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 103:2-3" href="/Psalms.103.2-3"><i>Ps.</i> 103:2–3</a>) “He Who forgives all your sins, He Who hears all your maladies, He Who redeems your soul from destruction.” Then he should say “Healer of the sick” before that<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Since in the verse redemption comes after healing. (Redemption here is personal redemption; redemption of the people is described by benedictions 9–14).</i>. Rebbi Aḥa said: why did they institute “Redeemer of Israel” as the seventh benediction? To teach you that Israel will be redeemed only in a Seventh Year<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">A Seventh Year (<i>shemiṭṭah</i>) in a Jubilee cycle. The “seventh song” in the next sentence is the seventh of the songs of ascent.</i>. Rebbi Jonah in the name of Rebbi Aḥa: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 126" href="/Psalms.126"><i>Ps.</i> 126</a>) “A song of ascent. When the Eternal will return the returnees of Zion” is the seventh song, to show you that Israel will be redeemed only in a Seventh Year. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said: Why did they institute “Healer of the sick” as the eighth benediction? That is for circumcision which is done on the eighth, following (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Malachi 2:5" href="/Malachi.2.5"><i>Maleachi</i> 2:5</a>) “My covenant was with him: Life”<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><i>The</i> Covenant refers to circumcision.</i>. Rebbi Alexander said: Why did they institute “He Who blesses the years” as the ninth benediction? Corresponding to (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 29:5" href="/Psalms.29.5"><i>Ps.</i> 29:5</a>) “The sound of the Eternal breaks cedars”, since in the future He will break all market manipulators<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Manipulators of prices of basic commodities who are compared to cedars for their (financial) strength. In the Babli, R. Alexander quotes <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 10:15" href="/Psalms.10.15"><i>Ps.</i> 10:15</a>, which in Babylonian (and Rashi’s) count was <i>Ps.</i> 9:36 and, therefore, is appropriate for the Ninth benediction. Our texts of Psalms which split an alphabetic acrostich between <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 9" href="/Psalms.9">Psalms 9</a> and 10 is the Yerushalmi tradition which, therefore, cannot use the verse quoted in the Babli.</i>. Rebbi Levi in the name of Rebbi Aḥa bar Ḥanina: Why did they follow “He Who blesses the years” by “Ingatherer of the dispersed of Israel”? Because of (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 36:8" href="/Ezekiel.36.8"><i>Ez.</i> 36:8</a>) “you, mountains of Israel, sprout your branches and carry your fruits for my people Israel”, why? “because they will soon come.” When the dispersed are gathered in then justice will be done, the evildoers will succumb, and the just will be happy<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">This describes benedictions 10–13. The wicked are Gentile governments that oppress the Jews. The evildoers are Jewish evildoers.</i>. It was stated: One includes the apostates and the wicked in “He Who subdues the evildoers”, the converts and the elders in “refuge of the just”, David in  “Builder of Jerusalem”<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">This is today the practice of Ashkenazic and Sephardic Jews. The Babylonian practice was not to mention the restoration of the Davidic dynasty in the benediction for Jerusalem, but to make it a separate benediction preceding the final benediction “He Who hears prayer”. Only the Yemenite ritual follows the strict Babylonian style; the other Jewish groups pray twice for the Davidic dynasty, once in the Yerushalmi form of “Builder of Jerusalem” and then in the Babylonian form “He Who makes sprout the horn of salvation”.</i>. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 3:5" href="/Hosea.3.5"><i>Hosea</i> 3:5</a>) “Then the children of Israel will repent, seek the Eternal, their God, and their king David.<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">The verse concludes: “They will tremble for the Eternal and His Goodness at the End of Days”, referring to Messianic times.</i>”
The Rebbis say: This King Messiah, if he is from the living, his name is David. If he is from the dead, his name is David. Rebbi Tanḥuma said: I am declaring the reason (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 18:51" href="/Psalms.18.51"><i>Ps.</i> 18:51</a>) “He gives kindness to His anointed, to David.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">The previous discussion ended with the verse from Hosea, which indicates that in Messianic times all twelve tribes will seek their king David; it is clear that Hosea talks about the Messiah and calls him David. This gives rise to an insertion about the Messiah in this and the next paragraph.<br>The second argument is more explicit in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 98b" href="/Sanhedrin.98b">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 98b</a>, where for the first case a verse in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 30:9" href="/Jeremiah.30.9">Jeremiah (30:9</a>) is cited: “They shall serve the Eternal, their God, and their king David whom I shall raise for them” which also is written in the future tense. The second case, that the original David will be resurrected as Messiah, is based on a verse in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 34:24" href="/Ezekiel.34.24">Ezechiel (34:24</a>) “I, the Eternal, shall be for them their God, and My servant David prince in their midst”, seems to refer to the historical David in Messianic times. The Babylonian Talmud points out that a prince is less than a king and, therefore, the new King Messiah will have the status of a Roman Augustus whereas the resurrected David will occupy the position of Caesar, or Crown Prince. In any case, the next paragraph makes is quite clear that the Messiah was born on the day of the destruction of the Temple and that, therefore, nobody with a recorded date of birth can ever be considered as Messiah. There is no reason to believe that the Babli would disagree with this conclusion. In addition, Maimonides in his <i>Letter to Yemen</i> is quite adamant that the Messiah can only appear in the Land of Israel and must be a political figure.</i>’
Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, his name is Ẓemaḥ. Rebbi Yudan, the son of Rebbi Aivu, said his name is Menaḥem<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel to the entire paragraph is in <i>Midrash Ekha rabbati</i> 1(57). The verse of R. Joshua ben Levi is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zechariah 6:12" href="/Zechariah.6.12"><i>Zach.</i> 6:12</a>: “Behold, a man of the name of Ẓemaḥ, he will sprout from below and build the Eternal’s temple.” The verse of Rebbi Yudan is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Lamentations 1:16" href="/Lamentations.1.16"><i>Threni</i> 1:16</a>: “Behold, far from me is Menaḥem who will restore my spirit.”</i>. Ḥanina the son of Rebbi Abbahu said: they have no disagreement since the numerical value of one is the numerical value of the other: Ẓemaḥ is equal to Menaḥem<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">138. צ̇מ̇ח̇ = 90+40+8, מ̇נ̇ח̇ם̇ = 40+50+8+40.</i>. Since Rebbi Yudan the son of Rebbi Aivu said, it happened to a Jew who was plowing in the valley of Arbel<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the Rome ms. and Genizah fragments; the valley of Arbel is West of Tiberias. The place name is missing in the Leyden ms. and the Venice print.</i> that his ox was bellowing. An Arab passed by and heard the bellowing of the ox. He said to him: Jew, Jew, unharness your ox, unharness your plow<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">קנקן usually means a pitcher or a bottle, from late Latin <i>canna</i> “small vessel”. However, this קנקן appears several times also in the Babli (noted in the Rabbinic dictionary <i>‘Arukh</i> under קנקן ב׳) and seems to mean the central peg by which the motion of the plow is controlled; possibly from old Persian <i>gan</i>, “plow”.</i> because the Temple was destroyed. The ox bellowed a second time. He said: Jew, Jew, harness your ox, fix your plow because King Messiah has been born. He said to him: What is his name? Menaḥem. He said to him: What is his father’s name? Ḥizqiah. He said to him: Where is he? He said to him: At the king’s palace in Bethlehem in Judea. He went and sold his ox and plow and made himself a vendor of baby linens. He went to towns and left towns until he came to that town. All the women bought from him but the mother of Menaḥem did not buy. He heard the women say: Menaḥem’s mother, Menaḥem’s mother, come and buy for your son! She said: I would rather strangle him like a hater of Israel because he was born on the day the Temple was destroyed. He said to her: I like him, because for him it was destroyed and for him it will be rebuilt. She said to him, I have no money. He said to her, that does not bother me, come and buy for him! If you have nothing with you today, I shall return another day and I will take it then. After some time he went up to that town and said to her: How is your baby doing? She said to him: After you had seen me there came storms and raised him and tore him from my hands<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Zohar</i> (II, 7b–8b) improves on the story and asserts that the Messiah is living in Paradise at a place known as “bird’s nest”.</i>. Rebbi Abun said: We do not need to learn from that Arab, is it not a full verse (<i>Is.</i> 10:35): “The Lebanon will fall through a noble one”?<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">The use of Lebanon as a figure of speech for the Temple can be traced to the interpretation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 3:25" href="/Deuteronomy.3.25"><i>Deut.</i> 3:25</a>, where Moses begs to see “this good mountain and the Lebanon.” Since God later showed Moses all he wanted to see, but nothing North of the city of Dan, it follows that “Lebanon” here cannot mean the mountain range. The verse here was used by Rabban Joḥanan ben Zakkai to predict to Vespasian that he would be emperor before he could conquer Jerusalem because the Temple could fall only to a noble one (<i>Ekha rabbati</i> 1(32)). In Isaiah, the verse is the introduction to a description of Messianic times.</i> And the next verse is (11:1) “A sprout will come from the stem of Jesse.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">After the digression about the Messiah, one returs to the main theme; the final benediction of the weekday insertion is the fifteenth in the Galilean count, and the mention of God’s name in the verse is the fifteenth in the Psalm.</i> Rebbi Tanḥuma said: Why did they institute “He Who listens to prayer” as the fifteenth benediction? Corresponding to (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 29:10" href="/Psalms.29.10"><i>Ps.</i> 29:10</a>) “The Eternal throned over the Deluge”, that He avert the catastrophy, that it should not come over the world<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">God has sworn that no future Deluge will engulf the entire globe, but one has to pray that partial deluges will be averted.</i>.
Temple service (precedes) Thanksgiving<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Now we are back to the explanation of the sequence of benedictions in the <i>Amidah</i>. The 16th (Israeli count) prays for restoration of the Temple service and acceptance of our prayer as if performed in the Temple. The 17th benediction is Thanksgiving, the 18th is for Peace, following (in the Morning Service) the Priestly Blessings that end in “peace”.</i>: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 50:23" href="/Psalms.50.23"><i>Ps.</i> 50:23</a>) “He who brings a sacrifice of thanksgiving honors Me and shows a path; I shall make him see God’s help.” One finishes with Peace, since all benedictions end with peace<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">The Priestly Blessings end in “peace”, and all other services, prayers and grace, end with “He Who makes peace in His heights, may He give peace to us and all of Israel, Amen.”</i>. Rebbi Simeon bar Ḥalaphta<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">A great preacher of the last generation of Tannaïm; his statement here is the last statement of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Oktzin 3:12" href="/Mishnah_Oktzin.3.12">Mishnah (<i>Uqeẓin</i> 3:12</a>).</i> said: There is no vessel that contains more blessing than peace. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 29:11" href="/Psalms.29.11"><i>Ps.</i> 29:11</a>) “The Eternal gives strength to His people, the Eternal blesses His people with peace.”
“If he recited and made a mistake then he should return to the place of the mistake.”<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the last part of the Mishnah that now will be discussed. The entire paragraph is repeated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 16a" href="/Berakhot.16a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 16a</a>.</i> If he made a mistake between the first and second mention of “writing” he must return to the first “writing”<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Both verses <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:9" href="/Deuteronomy.6.9"><i>Deut.</i> 6:9</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:20" href="/Deuteronomy.11.20">11:20</a>, read: “You shall write them on the doorposts of your house and your gates.” Since the verses are identical, a person who recited <i>Shema‘</i> mechanically has no way of deciding between the two but must start anew from the first verse.</i>. If he made a mistake and does not know where he made the mistake, he returns to the start, to any place that he is sure about<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this is quoted in the language of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:5" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.5">Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 2:5</a>) that one has to return to the start of the section he remembers. Since the language from the start of the paragraph to here is in pure Hebrew, it probably represents an Israeli version of that Tosephta.</i>. An explanation: Rebbi Ḥiyya, Rebbi Yasa, Rebbi Ammi were preparing the wedding canopy<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Probably Latin <i>genialia</i>, <i>ium</i> (n., plur.) “marriage bed, marriage” (E. G.). Rebbi Ḥiyya mentioned here is R. Ḥiyya bar Abba; his name is missing in the Babli.</i> for Rebbi Eleazar. They heard the voice of Rebbi Joḥanan when he explained something new. They said: Who is going down to hear that from him? They said, let Rebbi Eleazar go down since he is very careful. He descended, ascended, and said to them: So says Rebbi Joḥanan, if he recited and found himself at למען<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">In the last verse of the second section of Shema. Since the third section is completely different in wording and style, one may assume that he recited the first two parts correctly.</i> one can be sure that he had the right intention.
Rebbi Lia<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi La or Illaï, Galilean Amora of the third generation.</i>, Rebbi Yasa in the name of the great Rebbi Aḥa<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">He cannot be the Amora Rebbi Aḥa since the latter belongs to the fourth generation. Probably he is the Tanna Rebbi Aḥa of the last generation of Tannaïm.</i>: If he prayed and he found himself in “He Who hears prayer”, he may assume that he prayed with intent<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Since the weekday <i>Amidah</i> is a long prayer, it is probable that he lost concentration on what he was saying somewhere in between but when he realizes that he recited the last of the intermediary benedictions he may assume that he said all others in the required order.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: If he prayed without intent and he knows that the second time he will pray with intent, he may pray a second time; otherwise he should not pray<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that the Yerushalmi requires total concentration for all 18 benedictions for somebody who is not satisfied with the quality of his prayer. The following examples show that such a total concentration over a lengthy period of time is impossible and, hence, repetition of an imperfect prayer is excluded. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 34b" href="/Berakhot.34b">Babli [<i>Berakhot</i> 34b</a>, a statement of Rebbi Ḥiyya (bar Abba) in the name of the Babylonian Rav Safra] requires total concentration only during the first benediction; hence, for the Babli someone who did not concentrate during the first benediction has to repeat the <i>Amidah</i>. {In the <i>Shulḥan Arukh</i> (Sec. 101,1), R. Josef Qaro follows the Babli but R. Moshe Isserles decides Ashkenazic practice according to the Yerushalmi.]</i>. The great Rebbi Ḥiyya said: I never managed to pray with intent, but one time I made an effort to concentrate and I started to think and said to myself, who enters first before the king, the ἀργαπέτης<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">This Greek form was found in a Palmyrenian inscription. Following Fleischer, the title is a composition of Persian ارك <i>ark</i> “citadel”, پد <i>pad</i> (old Persian <i>pat</i>) “master, overseer”. So the title seems to designate the person who overseas the royal castle (Fleischer) or “commandant of a fort” (Liddell &amp; Scott).</i> or the <i>Resh Galuta</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">The Davidic head of Babylonian Jewry, who was a hereditary Noble under the Parthian and Persian rulers and still an important official in Moslem times.</i>? Samuel said: I counted chicks<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">When I consciously attempted total concentration for all the 19 (Babylonian) benedictions of the <i>Amidah</i>.</i>. Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya said: I counted stone rows<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Greek δόμος, “building; rows of stones or bricks in a building.” At other places in the Yerushalmi, the spelling דומדס is found; in the Babli it always is דימוס (which, however, might mean another word, δῆμος).</i>. Rebbi Mattaniah said: I an thankful to my head that when I come to <i>modim</i> it bends down by itself.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Professional workers<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Greek δόμος, “building; rows of stones or bricks in a building.” At other places in the Yerushalmi, the spelling דומדס is found; in the Babli it always is דימוס (which, however, might mean another word, δῆμος).</i> read<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Shema‘</i>; since this recitation needs concentration only for the first verse, we may assume that the professional can concentrate for that short time span without fear of falling down. The rest of <i>Shema‘</i> can be recited by rote from memory. In contrast, prayer (the <i>Amidah</i>) needs concentration from beginning to end and can be recited only on the ground.</i> on top of a tree or on top of a wall in construction; they are not permitted to do this for prayer.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> So<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">The Venice edition has מני which is an interrogatory particle referring to persons and does not make sense here. The Genizah fragments and the commentator of <i>Sefer Ḥaredim</i> read כיני as given here.</i> is the Mishnah: The hourly workers read on top of a tree<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli does not mention hourly workers at all. It is not clear whether the Yerushalmi is of the opinion that work on a tree is unskilled work and, therefore, a careful construction of the Mishnah requires the mention of hourly workers here or that this rule is contrary to the opinion prevalent in Babylonia.</i> and the professionals on top of a wall in construction.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">This is a fragment from a text similar to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:8" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.8"><i>Tosephta Berakhot</i> 2:8</a>: “Hourly workers read on top of a tree and on top of a wall in construction; they pray on top of an olive tree and a fig tree but for all other trees they have to descend and pray. The owner descends in any case for prayer. “A similar text, only with “professionals” instead of “hourly workers”. is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 16a" href="/Berakhot.16a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 16a</a>.</i>: “They pray on top of an olive tree or on top of a fig tree.” Hence<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">This looks like an inference since הא is not a tannaïtic technical term. However, given the parallels in Tosephta and Babli, the word הא “therefore”, may be an interpolation and the rest of the sentence may belong to the Tosephta.</i>, on all other trees he descends and prays on the ground. “The owner descends in all cases and prays on the ground.” And why on top of an olive tree or on top of a fig tree? Rebbi Abba and Rebbi Simon say both, because those are very laborious<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear whether it is very troublesome to come down from these trees and, therefore, too much time would be spent at the expense of the owner, or that olive and fig trees need great care and there is danger that the trees or their fruits would be damaged if the hourly worker would try to go down and up quickly, again to the detriment of the owner. Both explanations are found in the commentaries. Rashi in the Babli (16a) explains that these trees have so many branches that one can stand there securely and may concentrate on prayer without fear; it may be that he agrees that because of the many branches it is very troublesome to come down from the trees.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">This statement is a <i>Tosephta</i>(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 2:7:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.2.7.2-8"><i>Berakhot</i> 2:7</a>) where, however, the exemption for the carrier of a large load is not mentioned.</i>: “The porter may recite the <i>Shema‘</i> even with his load on his shoulders<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">For the same reason as that given for the workman. In the <i>Tosephta</i>, the porter is mentioned before the worker.</i> but he should start neither when he unloads nor when he loads because he cannot then concentrate. In any case he may not pray until he unloads, but if he was carrying a load of 4 <i>qab</i><sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>qab</i> is 4 <i>log</i>, about 2.17 liters. 4 <i>qab</i> are a Roman <i>modius</i>, about a British peck, a fourth of a bushel.<br>The Babli, <i>Baba meẓi‘a</i> 105b, quotes a <i>baraita</i> which states that the porter may pray with his load <i>on his back</i> if the load is less than 4 <i>qab</i>, but not if the load is 4 <i>qab</i> or more. Therefore, it seems that in the Yerushalmi the meaning is that the porter may pray without unloading if his load does not exceed 4 <i>qab</i>, on condition that it be balanced. The two differences between Yerushalmi and Babylonian practice are that for the Babli, the load has to be strictly less than 4 <i>qab</i>, for the Yerushalmi it may reach 4 <i>qab</i>, and for the Babli the load has to be all on the back and not distributed fore and aft.</i> it is permitted.” Rebbi Joḥanan said: only if he is in equilibrium. What means that he is in equilibrium? Two parts on his back and one part in front.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">An extended prohibition to communicate with others by movements of eyes, lips, or hands while reciting the <i>Shema‘</i> is given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 19b" href="/Yoma.19b">Babli, <i>Yoma</i> 19b</a>, in the name of the early Babylonian Amora Rav Isaac bar Samuel Bar Martha. However, the Biblical justification of the prohibition is there given in the name of the early Tanna Rebbi Eleazar Ḥisma. Hence, the statement of the Yerushalmi is a genuine tannïtic one.</i>: “Nobody should give messages with his eyes while reciting.”
It was stated: “The hourly workers who worked for an employer have to recite the first benediction of Grace and subsume that of Jerusalem in the benediction for the Land and close with the benediction for the Land<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation of reciting Grace is biblical but the number of benedictions is a rabbinical ordinance (<i>Beth Yosef</i> on <i>Ṭur Oraḥ Ḥayyim</i> 191). In order to reduce the expense for the employer (and, hence, increase employment for the poor), the hourly workers whose lunchbreak is paid for by their employer recite an abbreviated version of Grace that still contains all required elements. Since the Yerushalmi does not mention the benedictions before the meal it seems that the hourly workers are required to recite these [this is also the reading of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:24" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.24"><i>Tosephta</i> (5:24</a>) and most of the manuscripts of the Babli, against the Venice text of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 16a" href="/Berakhot.16a">Babli (16a</a>)].</i>. But if they were working for him for their meals <sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">For the food only, without cash payment to them.</i> or if the employer was eating with them, then they recite all four benedictions.” Rebbi Mana said: This means that one may not work while reciting Grace. Otherwise, why do we have to say this<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">The abbreviated version of Grace; it is necessary only if it profits the employer.</i>? Let him work and recite the benedictions!
Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">An Israeli Amora of Babylonian origin who in his youth was a student of Rav Huna, the student of Rav.</i> in the name of Rav Ḥuna: One should not stand and pray while he keeps a coin in his hand<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">That one should not come to examine it while praying; having the coin where it cannot be seen is no impediment to prayer.</i>; (having the coin) in front of him is forbidden, at his back it is allowed. Rebbi Yasa used to bind them together and grab them in his hand<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Since bound together they cannot be examined.</i>. And for money matters, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 14:25" href="/Deuteronomy.14.25"><i>Deut.</i> 14:25</a>) “you shall bind the money together in your hand”, only in your hand<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">The verse deals with money that has to be spent in Jerusalem, for which the owner is a kind of trustee. The inference, which is not a strict derivation, is that anybody who is trustee for other people’s money can discharge his obligation of prudent care only by having the money tied together and in his personal control all the time.</i>. Rebbi Yose bar Abun thus taught his son-in-law Rebbi Hillel<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Probably referring to both prayer and trusteeship.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥizqiah and Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa were sitting at one place and Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa had coins on him. There came the time for prayer, he unbound them and gave them to Rebbi Ḥizqiah. He bound them together little by little. They became untied and lost. He asked: What have you left?<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">This story is a counterexample to the prescription given before. Since coins are shown to come untied sometimes, binding them together is no remedy for the worry. Hence, the practical conclusion would be that coins have to be put in a safe place before the start of prayer.</i>
Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">He refers back to the <i>Tosephta</i> that allowed praying if the carrier’s load did not exceed 4 <i>qab</i>. The statement is introduced here since it is explained on the authority of R. Jacob ben Aḥa who was the main person in the preceding section.<br>The water referred to here is water used for the sprinkling with the ashes of the red heifer to cleanse from impurity caused by contact or closeness to the body of a dead Jew, as explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 19" href="/Numbers.19"><i>Num.</i> 19</a> and the Mishnah tractate <i>Parah.</i> The ashes of the red heifer have to be given into מים חיים אל כלי, virgin fresh water in a vessel. This means that after being drawn from flowing water, the water has to be watched so that no kind of work is done with it. A lapse of attention to the water makes it unfit for use in cleansing from impurity. Nevertheless, Rebbi Ḥanina states that one may recite <i>Shema‘</i> and even pray while carrying such water. This statement is obviously difficult to accept. Rav Ḥuna (the second) dismisses Rebbi Ḥanina’s statement as in obvious contradiction to generally accepted principles.</i> said: Also one who has his water on his shoulder may recite <i>Shema‘</i> and pray. Rav Ḥuna said: So the reciting of <i>Shema‘</i> and praying do not require concentration? Rebbi Mana said: I pointed out the difficulty before Rebbi Phineas that even if you say that the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> does not need concentration, does prayer not need concentration<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">Even if one accepts Rebbi Ḥanina’s statement for <i>Shema‘</i>, its reference to prayer must be a mistake even though it refers to a prior statement about prayer only. The sentence is a rhetorical question. In a text from the Cairo Genizah, it is formulated as a declarative sentence: “recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> does not need concentration; prayer needs concentration”. The meaning is the same in both versions.</i>? Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">The Amora, one of the editors of the Yerushalmi.</i> said: I confirmed it following what Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: You got it, the completion of the works of water<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">After the ashes have already been given into the water, when it is clear that the term “living water” no longer applies and there is no indication in the Torah that it has to be guarded as strictly as before. This also explains R. Ḥanina’s expression “his water”, not מי חטאת “the water of sprinkling” that is the technical term used for fresh water guarded for the ashes. It follows that as long as the ashes have not been given into the water, one may neither recite <i>Shema‘</i> nor pray while guarding it.</i> that are not clear from the words of the Torah.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The bridegroom is free from reciting the <i>Shema‘</i> in the first night<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Since he is unable to concentrate in anticipation of his first night with his bride. The bride, as a woman, has no obligation to recite <i>Shema‘</i> since this is a positive commandment occurring at stated times and does not apply to women.</i>; until the end of Sabbath if he did not do the act<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">It was common usage even in seventeenth Century Germany that couples who married Wednesday night had their first sexual relations the night following the Sabbath, cf. <i>Minhagim of the Community of Worms by R. Yospe Shamash</i>, ed. I. Zimer, I. M. Peles, vol. 2, p. 47; there the editor gives several conjectural reasons in note 16. He also indicates that this is a possible reflection of old usages from the Land of Israel, never followed in Babylonia. It seems to me that the usage is quite understandable if it is noted that bride and bridegroom were in their low teens, the girl possibly even a pre-teen. The marriage was arranged by the parents, with minimal involvement of the parties to the wedding. Some time was needed for the parties to get acquainted enough to get intimate.</i>. An action: Rabban Gamliël married and recited in the first night<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Since he already had the title “Rabban” and had students of his own, it is obvious that he was not a teenager and the marriage was not his first. Hence, his level of anxiety was low.</i>. His students said to him: Our teacher, did you not teach us that the bridegroom is free? He said to them: I will not listen to you to lift from me the Kingdom of Heaven even for one hour.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Eleazar ben Antigonos<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">An Israeli Amora of the second generation who always reports in the name of R. Eleazar, son of R. Yannai.</i> in the name of Rebbi Eleazar the son of Rebbi Yannai: This means that it is permitted to start sexual relations on the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Since the groom is free from reciting the <i>Shema‘</i> Friday evening if he did not yet have intercourse with his wife, it follows that we expect him to be anxious about it also Friday night. If he were not allowed to have intercourse, then he could defer his anxiety for a day and recite <i>Shema‘</i>. The problem is that he will make a wound in deflowering his wife and, in the normal case of a very young girl, the making of the wound is automatic. Now, the making of a wound is forbidden on the Sabbath but, according to Rebbi Simeon (bar Yoḥai), any work not done for its own sake is not forbidden, except in the case of an automatic consequence (פסיק רישא “cut off its head, will it not die?’). For the very young girls discussed here, the wound might be an automatic consequence.<br>The entire discussion belongs more to <i>Niddah</i> X:1 where all the parallels in the Babli are found. The second part of the Yerushalmi <i>Niddah</i> is lost and it cannot be ascertained anymore whether the entire discussion of our Mishnah is taken from there.</i>. Rebbi Ḥaggai said before Rebbi Yose: Explain it for a widow where he does not make a wound. He answered him: Did we not formulate “Four nights?<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the first Mishnah in the last chapter of tractate <i>Niddah</i>: “About a young girl who marries before puberty, the House of Shammai say that one allows four nights and the House of Hillel say until the wound is healed” (one does not suspect any blood to be menstrual). While it is quite possible that a very young girl can already be a widow, the Mishnah cannot apply to her since the marriage festivities of a widow are only three days (Thursday, Friday, Sabbath) while those of a virgin are seven days (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:2-17" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.2-17"><i>Ketubot</i> 1:1</a>). Hence, we cannot talk here about a widow.</i>” Can you say four nights for a widow?
Rebbi Jacob bar Savdi<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the fourth generation, probably somewhat older than Rebbi Yose.</i> said: I asked the question before Rebbi Yose: What is the difference between her and him who breaks a clay amphora in order to eat a dried fig from it<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to Mishnah <i>Šabbat</i> XXII:3: “One may break a clay amphora (whose top has been closed off by solid clay) in order to eat a dried fig from its contents, but he may not have the intent to make it into a permanent vessel,” i. e., he may not break the seal open in such a way that it needs no more action after the Sabbath to make the opening a permanent one that is easy to use. This follows the principle quoted before that according to R. Simeon, work not needed for its own sake is not forbidden on the Sabbath. Even R. Yehudah, who disagrees and states that any complete work is forbidden on Sabbath irrespective of intent, will agree that breaking off an irregular piece of the covering does not constitute complete work since it needs further regularization after the Sabbath. Rebbi Yose’s answer is that breaking the hymen is a complete action in itself and, therefore, both R. Simeon and R. Yehudah will forbid it: R. Simeon because of his intent and R. Yehudah because it is a complete action.<br>In the Babli, the deflowered woman is called a vessel; the Yerushalmi only compares her to a vessel.</i>? He said to me: But it says afterwards, “only he should have no intent to make it into a usable vessel.” And here when he has the intention of making her a married woman it is as if he had the intention of making her into a vessel. Rav Isaac bar Rav Meshirshia<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, the name is Mesharshia. He is a Babylonian who was associated with the last editors of the Yerushalmi and the first editor of the Babli. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 6b" href="/Ketubot.6b">Babli (<i>Ketubot</i> 6b</a>), the same question is asked by Rebbi Ammi, the Galilean authority two generations earlier.</i> said similarly: What is the difference between her and him who opens a boil on the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Which is allowed (Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 107a) for the same reason as why the top of an amphora may be broken, with the same restriction as to intent.</i>? He said to him, but it says afterwards: “only he should have no intention of making a permanent opening.” And here when he has the intention of making her a married woman it is as if he had the intention of making her into a vessel<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">In the Rome ms. and Geniza fragments, the last statement reads: לעשות לה פה “(He has the intention) to make her a permanent opening.” Our text probably is dittography.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>baraita</i> is also quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 5b" href="/Ketubot.5b">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 5b</a>, where it is determined that “others” means R. Simeon who states that an action not expressly intended is not forbidden on the Sabbath. It is explained there, that even though R. Simeon forbids actions which automatically imply some other action that desecrates the Sabbath, here he allows a first sex act on Sabbath since splitting the hymen is not a necessary consequence if the male partner is considerate (and, consequently, an intact hymen is no guarantee of virginity.) Since we decide on the Sabbath according to the opinion of Rebbi Simeon and since the medical statement is by Samuel, the greatest medical authority in the Babli, it is clear that the Babli decides that first sex relations on Friday night are permitted. (In the Middle Ages, poor people married on Friday afternoon in order to save expenses for a separate wedding meal.) It is seen here that the Yerushalmi is strictly of the opposite opinion; hence, the identity of “others” is not determined here.</i>: “A man should not have first sexual relations on the Sabbath because he makes a wound; but others allow it.” Rebbi Yose bar Abun said: The reason of the others is that he is intent on his job; the wound results automatically<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, the act is permitted according to R. Simeon.</i>. Assi<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">His alter ego, Ammi, is quoted in the Babli as the first authority who allows it.</i> said, it is forbidden. Benjamin from Ginzak<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">Ginzak (“city of the treasury”) is the capital of Media, called Gazaka by Ptolemy. Another version is told in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 65a" href="/Niddah.65a">Babli, <i>Niddah</i> 65a</a>. According to the version which allows first sex acts on the Sabbath, Benjamin, called there “from Saqasan”, tried to follow a ruling attributed to Rav to the effect that a second sex act would be permitted even without waiting the seven days of a cleansing period regularly required of a menstruating women, and applied to the newlyweds since blood from the breaking of the hymen is indistinguishable from menstrual blood, as discussed in the following section. In the Babylonian version, Benjamin tried to act according to this ruling but he died before he could do so.</i> went out and said in the name of Rab, it is allowed. Samuel heard it and resented it, he [Benjamin] died, he [Samuel] recited for him: praised be He Who smote him<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">“קרי” means “recited a Biblical verse”. There is no such verse but its intent is close to <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:39" href="/I_Samuel.25.39"><i>1Sam.</i> 25:39</a>.</i>. About Rav, he [Samuel] recited: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 12:21" href="/Proverbs.12.21"><i>Prov.</i> 12:21</a>) “The just will cause no wrong.”
Samuel said: All the rules spelled out at the start of the last chapter of <i>Niddah</i> are theoretical and not for practical application<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">The rules allowing more than one sex act with newlywed virgins while either the wound is not healed or seven days had not passed since the wedding night. The same statement of Samuel is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 65a" href="/Niddah.65a">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 65a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yannai fled even from married pre-puberty girls<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">He refrained from touching them, just as it is forbidden to touch a married woman after puberty.</i>. They asked before Rebbi Yoḥanan: What about a second sex act? They said, he did not teach to take all for blood of the wound, how could he rule for a second sex act<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">In the wedding night, where according to him only one sex act is allowed. “He” is R. Yoḥanan.</i>? What we are asking about is the case when there were days of interruption, days of purity, in between<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">That means that when a man married a virgin and the required time has passed since the wedding night it turns out that the first night in which a second sex act is permissible would be a Sabbath. This is a valid question for the Yerushalmi which forbids a first act on the Sabbath; there is some chance that a second act will again produce some minor lesion and some drops of blood.</i>. Rebbi Abbahu said: I was the best man of Rebbi Simeon bar Abba and I asked Rebbi Eleazar: is it possible to have the second sex act? He permitted it, since he holds like Samuel, and Samuel said: One may enter a narrow gap<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">In a dirt wall. The statement of Samuel is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 6b" href="/Ketubot.6b">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 6b</a> and is used there for the same argument as here.</i> on the Sabbath, even if one rubs off some pebbles. Rebbi Ḥaggai said: I was the best man of Rebbi Samuel the Cappadocian<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">Like all other authorities quoted here, an Amora of the third generation, of the circle of students of Rebbi Yoḥanan.</i>; I asked Rebbi Josiah and he shrank from it<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">He refused to give an opinion. It is not 100% clear what Rebbi Ḥaggai asked, but we may assume that his question was identical with that of Rebbi Abbahu.</i>. I asked Rebbi Samuel bar Isaac; he said: now, what is blood of a period and what is blood of virginity<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">It seems impossible to decide, since on the one hand we allow an occasional rubbing off, and, hence, in our case an occasional drop of blood, following Samuel, but on the other hand we treat every drop of blood on female genitals as menstrual and necessitating seven days of cleansing when all bodily contact between spouses is forbidden.</i>?
