It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">In a slightly different wording this is a <i>baraita</i> in <i>Massekhet Kallah</i> 1 (a collection in the Yerushalmi tradition.) At any meal during all seven days after the wedding, seven benedictions are said over a cup of wine for the newlyweds after grace is recited. The bride is required to drink from the cup of which her husband drank, as a fertility rite. Rebbi Eliezer notes that the groom is not allowed to take the cup back from the bride since she has to follow all the rules of the menstruating woman.</i>: “The bride is forbidden for her house all seven days and he may not take from her the cup of blessings, the words of Rebbi Eliezer.” What is the reason of Rebbi Eliezer? It is impossible that not some menstrual blood be mixed in the blood of virginity.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">Rabban Gamliel.</i> took a bath in the first night after his wife died. His students said to him: Did you, our teacher, not teach us that the mourner may not take a bath. He said to them: I am not like most other people, I am asthenic<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἀσθενής. Medical considerations, even if no life-threatening situation is involved, always have precedence over the rules of mourning.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Who<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">This entire discussion belongs to the third chapter of tractate <i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> (<i>Halakhah</i> 5, fol. 62d). There are some textual differences between the two texts, an occurrence rare in the Yerushalmi. But in fact the deviations of the text here from its original in <i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> are all scribal or printer’s errors, as is shown from the Rome ms. and the Genizah fragments. Therefore, the text here follows the <i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> text wherever there is manuscript evidence from <i>Berakhot</i> to support that version.</i> stated that the mourner is forbidden to take a bath during the entire seven days? Rebbi Nathan<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">Usually known as Nathan the Babylonian, a Babylonian from the Davidic family, second in the Synhedrion under Rabban Simeon ben Gamliël.</i>. Something happened to Rebbi Ammi<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">A close relative of Rebbi Ammi died, for whom he had to mourn for seven days.</i>, he asked Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba who instructed him “all seven days following Rebbi Nathan”. Something happened to Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">The fourth generation Amora. It seems that Rebbi Yose felt uncomfortable with the prohibition of bathing; he sent one of his students to ask Rebbi Aḥa, the greatest authority in Lydda, in Judea. In the next section, it will be seen that in the South, in Judea, one did not follow Rebbi Nathan and allowed bathing for the mourner. Nevertheless, Rebbi Aḥa did not want to interfere with the prohibition accepted in Galilee and answered not with his own opinion but with a note that Rebbi Yose himself had taught about two cases where the question had come up in Galilee and was answered in the sense of Rebbi Nathan.</i>; he sent Rebbi Abba bar Cohen to Rebbi Aḥa; he said to him: Rebbi, did you not so teach us that something happened to Rebbi Ammi, he asked Resh Laqish<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish; the abbreviation “Resh Laqish” is standard in the Babli but very infrequent in the Yerushalmi. The abbreviation probably is that of a lazy copyist.</i> who instructed him “all seven days following Rebbi Nathan”. He said to him<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yose to Rebbi Aḥa, that maybe this was only one occasion reported under two different names and, therefore, represents only the opinion of one teacher and not a generally accepted rule that would need at least two supporting authorities.</i>, maybe these were two separate incidents, we say it in the name of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, you say it in the name of Resh Laqish. And also from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">This is Rebbi Aḥa’s answer: Even if you do not agree that Rebbi Ammi asked twice, for two different cases of mourning, and was given the same answer by two different authorities, I have a completely independent occurrence in which Galilean rabbis gave the same ruling and, therefore, you have to accept it.</i>: Something happened to Rebbi Ḥama<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">He is the third generation Amora, father of Rebbi Oshaya the second.</i>, father of Rebbi Oshaya, he asked the rabbis and they forbade it.
Rebbi Yose asked, which rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yose is not satisfied with the second source of Rebbi Aḥa since it speaks of unspecified “rabbis” whose place and importance, as a precedent in Galilee, is indeterminate.</i>? The rabbis here or the rabbis in the South? If you say the rabbis of here, it is fine<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">This is Rebbi Aḥa’s answer: Since the questioner is Galilean and all the important Academies were in Galilee at his time, it is unreasonable to assume that “the rabbis” were Southerners whose opinion, as a minority opinion, would not count as precedent.</i>. If you would say the rabbis from the South, would he have asked minor authorities when greater ones were before him? If you say the rabbis of the South, some of them would allow and some of them would forbid, as we have stated: “At a place where it is customary to bathe after a funeral, one may bathe; in the South one bathes.” Rebbi Yose bar Abun said: He who permits that bath makes it like eating and drinking<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">According to Ramban (<i>Writings</i>, ed. Chavel, p. 175–176), Rebbi Yose bar Abun restricts the bathing to the aftermath of the funeral and says that in the same way that the mourner must have his first meal prepared for him by his relatives and friends, so his relatives and friends must cleanse him after the funeral from dust and germs (שיבתא). Hence, where it is customary, e. g. in the South, the mourner can have one bath, prepared by others, just after the funeral but is forbidden to have another one for the rest of the period of mourning. It then is difficult to understand the question of Rabban Gamliel’s students. Ramban writes that either he lived in a community where that bath was not customary or he was not satisfied with the cold bath prepared for him but took a full warm bath with following rubbing with oil for his asthenic condition.</i>.
That means, about a bath for pleasure. But a bath that is not for pleasure is permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">This is in keeping with Rabban Gamliel’s ruling, that every medically indicated bath is permitted.</i>. An example is the case of Samuel bar Abba who developed scab. They came and asked Rebbi Yose, what is the rule, may he bathe? He said to them: If he does not bathe, would he not die<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">The author of <i>Sepher Ḥaredim</i> takes this as hyperbole since in case of danger to life everything is permitted except murder, incest, and idolatry; he does not consider the remark of Rebbi Yose a restriction on the use of any medically indicated bath.</i>? If he needs it, even on the Ninth of Av. If he needs it, even on Yom Kippur<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">On both days, formal washing is forbidden. The rule is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 77b" href="/Yoma.77b">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 77b</a>.</i>.
They saw Rebbi Yose, son of Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">One of the first students of Rebbi Yoḥanan, preceding the other authorities mentioned up to now.</i>, immersing himself. They did not know whether it was for his emission<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">An emission of semen which requires immersion in a ritual bath as explained in the next chapter. Marital relations are forbidden for the mourner during the entire seven days of mourning.</i>, they did not know whether it was to cool down because bathing in cold water is not called bathing<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">It remains undecided whether taking a cold bath during the mourning period is permitted or not. The Babylonian authorities in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 13a" href="/Taanit.13a">Babli (<i>Taänit</i> 13a</a>) declare that a cold bath is forbidden to a mourner (and, therefore, on the Ninth of Av) but is allowed on fast days (in a year of draught) when the emphasis is on deprivation.</i>.
Rebbi Abba taught like that which was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">This statement does not belong here but either in the last chapter of <i>Yoma</i> (fol. 44d) or the first chapter of <i>Taäniot</i>: “When somebody goes (on the Ninth of Av or Yom Kippur) to see his teacher and has to pass a river on the way, he crosses it without compunction.” The statement is given here to show that, in fact, taking a cold bath by walking through the ford of a river, is no infringement of the prohibition of taking a bath on these fast days.</i>. Rebbi Aḥa taught about him who comes from the road<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">A family member who comes to observe the period of mourning with the family but arrives only after the funeral when the rest of the family already is in full mourning. This ruling of Rebbi Aḥa is not restricted to the place where one allows a bath for the mourner but falls under the heading of medical necessity.<br>This ruling introduces subsequent statements concerning a mourner on a trip, or people on a trip who meet mourners.</i> and his feet ache that he is permitted to wash them with water.
It has been stated: “A mourner and one banned<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote">One put in the ban by rabbinical authority for improper behavior, who should show the signs of mourning.</i> on a trip are permitted to wear sandals<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Even though mourners are not allowed to wear leather shoes or sandals. This again is a medical exemption.</i>. When they come to town they should remove them. The same holds for the Ninth of Av and public fasts<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">The fast days proclaimed in the Land of Israel during a draught, when all the deprivations of Yom Kippur are also in force. The only fast day in the diaspora where these rules also apply is the Ninth of Av.</i>.”
It is stated: “In a place where one is used to greet mourners<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Wishing them well.</i> on the Sabbath one may do so. In the South one does greet.” The great Rebbi Oshaya<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">One of the foremost students of Rebbi, the compiler of the Mishnah, and of Rebbi Ḥiyya. He was from the region of Lod in the South, but he studied in Galilee. In his story, the Aramaic verb for “to see” is חזי in Southern (and Babylonian) Aramaic. In the following story about Rebbi Yose from Galilee, the corresponding verb is Galilean Aramaic חמי.</i> went to some place, saw there mourners on the Sabbath and greeted them. He said to them: “I do not know the custom of your place, but be greeted according the custom of our place.” Rebbi Yose, son of Rebbi Ḥalaphta, praised Rebbi Meïr before the people of Sepphoris: A great, holy, and meek man. At some time, he saw mourners on the Sabbath and greeted them. They said to him<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">In this entire story, the singular refers to Rebbi Yose (the Tanna) and the plural to the people of Sepphoris. We learn that in the region of Sepphoris, lower Galilee, is was not customary to console mourners on the Sabbath. From the conclusion we may infer that under the influence of Rabbis Yose and Meïr the custom of the South was adopted also in Galilee. The disagreement between the people in the South (Judea) and North (Galilee) is also discussed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 23a" href="/Megillah.23a">Babli (<i>Megillah</i> 23a</a>,b); according to that source the dispute was only settled in favor of the Southern stance in the days of Rebbi Yoḥanan.</i>: Is that the one whose praise you proclaim<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Because he seems to be an ignoramus.</i>? He said to them, what are his works? They said to him, he saw mourners on the Sabbath and greeted them. He said to them: you have to recognize his strength; he comes to make you aware that there is no mourning on the Sabbath. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 10:22" href="/Proverbs.10.22"><i>Prov.</i> 10:22</a>): “The blessing of the Lord makes rich,” that is the blessing of Sabbath, “He will not add grief to it,” that is mourning, as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 19:3" href="/II_Samuel.19.3"><i>2Sam.</i> 19:3</a>): “The king is grieving about his son.”<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">This is a lexicographical note about the meaning of the root עצב, which as a verb either means “to grieve, to be pained”, connected with Arabic ע̇צ̇ב, or “to form, create”, close to Arabic עצ̇ב. As a noun, one usually distinguishes עֶצֶב “pain, grief; labor, gain; vessel”, עַצָּב “worker”, and עֹצֶב “idol, pain”. Usually, the noun in the verse in <i>Proverbs</i> is translated by “labor”, but the explanation here substitutes the more common meaning “grief”.</i>

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> And when his<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">Rabban Gamliel’s.</i> slave Tevi died, he received condolences about him. They said to him: Our teacher, did you not teach us that one does not accept condolences for slaves? He said to them: My slave Tevi was not like other slaves, he was honest<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">Since slaves were not liable in civil law, they could not be sued for damages of any kind, and neither could their master for their misdeeds; it was assumed that slaves were thieves, confidence men, and careless with anybody’s property and, when freed, had trouble establishing themselves as trustworthy witnesses.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Hence, about unrelated freed men one accepts condolences? So is the Mishnah: one does not accept condolences for slaves.<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">There are several different explanations of this cryptic piece. The most reasonable is by R. Abraham ben Adrat (Rashba) in his commentary on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 16b" href="/Berakhot.16b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 16b</a>: Since the slave is not related to his master, even if he were free the master would not accept formal condolences for him since these are restricted to those close relatives for which one has to keep a period of formal mourning. The answer is that the Mishnah has to declare explicitly that one does not accept formal condolences since the slave is a member of the household and, presumably, is treated like a family member, parallel to the case of a student for whom the teacher may accept condolences; see the section after the next.</i>
It happened that Rebbi Eliezer’s maidservant died<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">She must have been his personal maidservant. The story is repeated in an enlarged version in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 16b" href="/Berakhot.16b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 16b</a> and, in the Yerushalmi version, in <i>Evel Rabbati</i> 1:9,10.</i> and his students came to him for condolences but he did not accept. He entered the courtyard, they followed him there. He entered the house, they followed him there. He told them: I was thinking that you would be burned by lukewarm water but you are not burned even by boiling water. Did they not say that one does not accept condolences for slaves because slaves are in this like animals? If one does not accept condolences for unrelated free persons, so much more for slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Eliezer disagrees with his brother-in-law Rabban Gamliel and with the statement of the previous section in the Talmud. He will read in the Mishnah “<i>because</i> one does not accept condolences for slaves”, meaning that this is a rule that cannot be waved. In the Babli, his attitude is directly contradicted by Rebbi Yose, the most authoritative of the Tannaïm of the fourth generation. Rebbi Yose even recommends eulogies for honest slaves; this represents the Galilean attitude (not shared in Babylonia) and, while not spelled out in the Yerushalmi, is taken for granted in this passage which immediately after the present story gives examples of model eulogies for rabbis.</i>. If one’s slave or animal died, people say to him: The Omnipresent may replace your loss.
When Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ada<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">A second generation Amora in Galilee. He had the reputation of a saintly man. He might have been a student of the young Rav in the Academy of Rebbi, but his main teacher was R. Simeon ben Laqish.<br>Since the topic of condolences and eulogies is implied in the previous text, a list of sample eulogies follows. Most of these are found (with some change in names) in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shir HaShirim Rabbah 6:2" href="/Shir_HaShirim_Rabbah.6.2"><i>Midrash Rabba, Song of Songs</i> on 6:2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 5:11" href="/Ecclesiastes.5.11"><i>Ecclesiastes</i> on 5:11</a>.</i>, the nephew of Bar Qappara, died did Resh Laqish accept for him since he was his teacher and a student is beloved as a son<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, a teacher may formally mourn a student. In the Babli (<i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> 26b), only a student may formally mourn a teacher.</i>. He went and eulogized him: (<i>Song of Songs</i> 6:2) “My friend descended to his garden, to the spice patch<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">While the masoretic text has “spice patches”, the consonantal spelling here seems to prefer the singular which also is appropriate to the sermon based on this verse. This does not imply that the verse in Resh Laqish’s Bible had here a singular, only that the interpretation as singular is more convenient for his sermon.</i>, to shepherd in the gardens.”<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">As with most Scriptural quotes in the Talmud, the main inference is to be drawn from the part of the verse that is not quoted; the student is expected to recognize the verse and to complete it himself. The spelling is left as in the manuscripts and is not edited to conform to our masoretic texts.</i> It would have been necessary only to say “ “My friend descended to shepherd in the gardens.” But “my friend” is the Holy One, praise to Him. “He descended to His garden”, that is the world. “To the spice patch”, that is Israel. “To shepherd in the gardens”, these are the peoples of the world. “And to collect lilies”, these are the just ones whom He removes from their midst. They gave a parable, to what can this be compared? To a king who had a son whom he loved very much. What did the king do? He planted a garden for him. When the son did the will of his father, the father searched in the entire world for a nice plant and planted it in his garden. When the son was making him angry, he cut down all his plants. So when Israel does the will of the Holy One, praise to Him, he searches the entire world and observes the just person, brings him and attaches him to Israel, like Jethro and Rahab. And when they are making him angry he removes the just ones from amongst them<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Implying that Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ada was collected because of the sins of his generation.</i>.
A clarification. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">In the Rome manuscript, he is identified as the Great Rebbi Ḥiyya (whose full name was Ḥiyya bar Abba bar Aḥa Karsala from Kufra in Iraq), who otherwise is never referred to as “bar Abba” in the Yerushalmi. The sage here cannot be the third generation Amora R. Ḥiyya bar Abba, student of R. Yoḥanan, since not only are the alternate authors Tannaïm of the fourth generation but the story is very explicit in showing that the scholars among themselves are speaking Hebrew and only with the unlearned farmer they speak Aramaic. The Great Rebbi Ḥiyya belongs to the generation of transition between Tannaïm and Amoraïm; even his inclusion is a little late compared to the other two possible sources. This, as noted by Levi Ginzberg (following Eliezer ben Yehudah) is characteristic of Tannaïtic times.<br>It is possible that the author of the<i>Zohar</i> identified this R. Ḥiyya bar Abba as a Tanna of the fourth generation, contemporary of Rebbi Yose, Rebbi Jacob, and, therefore, Rebbi Simeon bar Yoḥai, since he appears there as a major partner in dialogues with the latter.</i> and his group, some say Rebbi Yose bar Ḥalaphta and his group, and some say Rebbi Jacob and his group, were sitting to study Torah under a fig tree. The owner of the fig tree was coming every morning at sunrise and collected figs. They said, maybe he mistrusts us<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote">Since he comes early every morning to check on us. (In the Leyden manuscript and the Venice print, the text is “mistrusts me” but the Rome manuscript can be read as “mistrusts us”).</i>, let us change place. The next day, the owner of the fig tree came to them<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">In the Midrash, it is explained that he went on a systematic search to find his scholars.</i>; he said to them: the one <i>miẓwah</i> that you used to do with me you are withholding from me<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">Since the one who provides the physical means for Torah study, not the scholar, acquires the greater merit from the study, you are depriving me of the merit of Torah study that I cannot acquire on my own.</i>. They said to him: We thought that maybe you mistrust us. During the morning he came and informed them that if the sun shines on ripe figs they get wormy<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, he has to come early every morning to harvest all figs that are ripe because later they become worthless.</i>. At that time they said, the owner of the fig tree knows the best time to collect figs and he collects them. Likewise, the Holy One, praise to Him, knows the time of the just ones to be removed from the world and He removes them<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">In contrast to the Amora Resh Laqish, the Tannaïm do not see in the premature death of a saintly man a consequence of the sins of his contemporaries.</i>.
When Rebbi Abun bar Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote">One of the frequently quoted authorities of the Jerusalem Talmud, a student of Rebbi Yoḥanan and Rebbi Zeïra; he died young as his eulogy shows.</i> died, Rebbi Zeïra ascended his pulpit and eulogized him: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 5:11" href="/Ecclesiastes.5.11"><i>Eccl.</i> 5:11</a>) “Sweet is the year of the worker.” It does not say here “sleeps” but “whether he eats little or much.” To what can Rebbi Bun bar Ḥiyya be likened? To a king who hired many workers and there was one worker who was exceptionally productive in his work. What did the king do? He took him and walked with him the long and the short. In the evening, the workers came to receive their wages and he gave him his total wages with them. The workers complained and said: we were toiling the entire day and this one did toil only for two hours and he gave him his total wages with us! The king told them: This one produced in two hours more than what you produced all day long. So Rebbi Bun produced in Torah in 28 years what an outstanding<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">Or, with the Arabic ותֹיק “constant, resolute”.</i> student cannot learn in a hundred years.
When Rebbi Simon bar Zevid<sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the third generation, also quoted as Rebbi Simon bar Savdi, whose discussions with Rebbi Illaï (Lai) are recorded several times in the Yerushalmi. He was a teacher of the leaders of the fourth generation of Amoraïm, Rebbis Ḥizkiah, Jonah, and Phineas.</i> died, Rebbi Illai ascended and eulogized him: Four things are used in the world and if they are lost, they have replacement, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 28:1" href="/Job.28.1"><i>Job</i> 28:1</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 28:2" href="/Job.28.2">2</a>) “But silver has a source, and a place is where gold is refined; iron is taken from dust, and stone is smelted into copper.” Those, if they are lost, have replacement. But a scholar who died, who can bring us his replacement, who can bring us his substitute? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 28:12" href="/Job.28.12"><i>Job</i> 28:12</a><sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that the preacher wanted to refer to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 28:20" href="/Job.28.20">verse 20</a>: “Wisdom, from where does it come?”</i>,21) “Wisdom, where can it be found, where is the place of understanding? It is hidden from the eyes of all living!” Rebbi Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">Probably a scribal error for Lai. But the parallel in Yerushalmi <i>Horaiot</i>3:8 (fol. 38b) also has Rebbi Levi.</i> said: If the brothers of Joseph lost their spirit because they found something, as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 42:28" href="/Genesis.42.28"><i>Gen.</i> 42:28</a>) “they lost their spirit”, we, who lost Rebbi Simon bar Zevid, so much more!
When Rebbi Levi bar Sisi<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">One of the outstanding students of Rebbi, in the generation of transition between Tannaïm and Amoraïm. Some time after Rebbi’s death he emigrated to Nahardea in Babylonia where he became an associate of Abba bar Abba, the father of Samuel, a descendant of Ḥananiah, the nephew of Rebbi Joshua, who founded the first Talmudic academy in Babylonia at the outbreak of the war of Bar Kokhba. He, like the Great Rebbi Ḥiyya, was a collector of mishnaic material (<i>baraitot</i>); his collection became the foundation of study in Nahardea.</i> died, the father of Samuel came and eulogized him: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:13" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.13"><i>Eccl.</i> 12:13</a>) “Final word: Everything has been heard, fear God.” To what can Rebbi Levi ben Sisi be compared? To a king who had a vineyard with a hundred vines which gave him every year a hundred barrels of wine. He reduced them to 50, to 40, to 30, to 20, to ten, to one, and this one gave him a hundred barrels of wine. This one vine was as dear to him as the entire vineyard. So Rebbi Levi bar Sisi was beloved before the Holy One, praise to Him, like all mankind. This is what is written (<i>loc. cit.</i>) “Because that is all of man,” that one is like all of mankind<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">A kind of pun on the possible interpretations of כל as “all” or “entire”. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 6b" href="/Berakhot.6b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 6b</a>) this is a sermon of Rebbi Abba bar Kahana, a Babylonian who became preacher of the third generation of Amoraïm in Galilee.</i>.
Cahana<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">While the previous section dealt with a Galilean emigrating to Babylonia, we now deal with Babylonians immigrating into Israel. Cahana here is Rav Cahana II; his story can be understood only in connection with the remarks in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 117a" href="/Bava_Kamma.117a">Babli <i>Bava Qama</i>117a</a>,b; the interpretation is Rashi’s (117b).<br>Rav Cahana was a young member of the Academy of Rav when Rav unsuccessfully tried to dissuade a Jew from informing against another Jew before the Persian authorities. Rav Cahana was so outraged that he slapped the would-be informer and broke his neck. Rav pointed out to him that under the new Sassanid regime the Jews had lost the criminal jurisdiction they had under the Parthians and that, therefore, he was liable to be prosecuted. Rav told him to go (“ascend”) to the Land of Israel, to the Academy of Rebbi Yoḥanan, but he warned him not to ask difficult questions from Rebbi Yoḥanan for seven years. This must have happened between the Sassanid victory in 226 C.E. and Rav’s death in 247 C.E. (Since the organization of the new Persian empire must have taken some time, the earliest time for Rav Cahana’s flight is probably around 235 C.E. When Rav Cahana returned to Babylonia, he became a student of Rav’s successors Rav Yehudah and Rav Huna; hence, he returned after 247 C.E.) In Tiberias, Cahana (whose rabbinical title is not recognized in the Yerushalmi) first kept Rav’s injunction but in the end he found a way to get around it and was recognized by Rebbi Yoḥanan as a great scholar. Unfortunately, by a birth defect or an accident, Cahana had unsymmetric lips which gave his face the look of a permanent smirk and Rebbi Yoḥanan got offended. He gave him an evil eye so that Cahana died. When informed that the smirk was no smirk but a bodily feature of Cahana, he went to the cave where Cahana was buried. The entrance to the cave was guarded by a poisonous snake which let Rebbi Yoḥanan enter only after he had publicly acknowledged that he had been a student of Cahana. Then he prayed in the cave and Cahana was resurrected from the dead. This is the basis of the questions asked here by the hoodlums. According to the Babli, Rav Cahana found the presence of R. Yoḥanan too dangerous. This will explain the roundabout way in which he asked for leave from the Academy in the Yerushalmi version.</i> was very young when he came up here. A person in rags saw him and asked him, what is new in Heaven? He answered: The judgment over this man has been sealed. This happened to him and he was stricken. Another one in rags saw him and asked, what is new in Heaven? He answered: The judgment over this man has been sealed. This happened to him. He said: Did I not go up to gain merit, but I am sinning! Did I come up to kill the people of the Land of Israel? I shall go and step down the way I came up. He came to Rebbi Yoḥanan and said to him: A man whose mother wishes him well and whose step mother<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">The land of Babylonia.</i> honors him, should he go there? He said to him, he should go there where he is honored. Cahana descended the way he came up. They came and told Rebbi Yoḥanan that Cahana had descended to Babylonia. He said, how could he go without asking permission? They told him: that question, that he asked of you, was his request for permission.
Rebbi Zeïra went to have himself bled when he ascended here<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">This used to be the general method to heal minor illnesses and also served as a prophylactic. Bleeding required that one must eat enough red meat afterwards to replace the lost substance.</i>. He went and wanted to buy a pound<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">A Roman pound (<i>libra</i>, λίτρα) of twelve Roman ounces, slightly more than 12 avoirdupois ounces. It seems that Rebbi Zeïra incurred the wrath of the butcher by using the correct feminine form <i>litrĕta</i> for the Greek <i>litra</i>, while common usage was <i>litra</i> which in Aramaic really should be masculine (but was not taken as such in popular use).</i> of red meat from a butcher. He asked him: How much is that pound? He said to him, 50 minas and one slap<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">The price of meat can be taken to determine the time of R. Zeïra’s arrival in Israel. A Mina (Μνᾶ͂) was 100 Denar. In old times, a Mina was an enormous sum. But the inflation in the later part of the military anarchy, from the failed currency reform of Aurelianus to the reorganization of the Roman state under Diocletianus, was extreme. All Midrashim telling about exorbitant sums being paid for simple objects of daily use must be dated to that period, from 274–284 C.E. Diocletian introduced new gold coinage based on a price of 50’000 old gold Denars for a Roman pound of gold. This makes one pound of gold (345 g) the equivalent of 1’250’000 old silver denars. At that time, 50 Minas, or 5’000 silver Denars, would therefore be 1.38 g = 0.04 oz of gold or at today’s gold prices, $14.45. This is a very high price but not out of line in a time of extreme decline of farming and ranching. It is quite clear from this and other stories that the obligation to eat meat on holidays was a serious monetary obligation. (The so-called silver coins of that period were copper coins dipped for a second in a silver solution.)<br>קורסם is Greek κρουσμός, ὁ, “striking, smiting, collision”.</i>. He said to him: Take 60, but he did not accept. Take 70, but he did not accept. Take 80, take 90, until he came to 100 and he did not accept. Then he said: Do what is your routine. The next morning he went to the Academy and said to them: Rabbis, what is this bad practice here that nobody can eat a pound of red meat unless they slap him! They said to him: Who is that? He said, the butcher so-and-so. They sent to him to bring him but they found that his coffin was being carried out. They said to him: Our teacher, all that<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Zeïra really had acquired a Babylonian title, “Rav”, before he immigrated to Galilee but, being dissatisfied with the style of Talmudic study in Babylonia, he never used it. Seeing that Heaven was giving him special protection, the members of the academy of Tiberias started giving him the Palestinian title, Rebbi, right away. They wondered that Heaven was so quick in punishing a man who had offended him.</i>? He said to them: That should happen to me, but I was not angry about him<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, I did not wish him dead and I am innocent of his death. This remark connects to the next story.</i>; did I not think that this was general practice?
When Rebbi Yasa ascended here, he went to a barber. He wanted to bathe in a public bath of Tiberias. He met a scoffer who hit him once on his neck and said: The noose<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the Rome manuscript. The Venice print has ענוקא “neck” which cannot be loose or tight, but the noose around the neck can.</i> of this man is loose. There was an admistrator<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">Ἄρχων, “ruler”; in Imperial Rome a local administrator, <i>praefectus</i>.</i> sitting who was interrogating<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">Under threat or by the use of judicial torture. (Referring to a Jewish court, the word would mean “punish”.)</i> a robber<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Greek λῃστής (also a collateral form ληιστής). The word appears in the Babylonian tradition as לִסְטִים.</i>. He<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">The scoffer. The next “he, him, he” refer to the robber.</i> went and stood there all laughing opposite him. The administrator asked him: Who was with you? He looked around and said: The one who is laughing here was with me. He<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">The archon, who fetched the scoffer who then confessed to a murder under the threat of torture.</i> fetched him, interrogated him, and he confessed about one murder. When they both went out, carrying two beams<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">The beams used for their own crucifixion.</i>, Rebbi Yasa passed by going to the bath. He<sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">The scoffer who might have laughed about the trick he played on the scholar but who was caught because the robber thought that he was laughing about the pain inflicted on himself and who took revenge by denouncing the scoffer.</i> said to him: That noose which was loose you already tightened. He answered him: That is the bad luck of this man, is it not written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 28:22" href="/Isaiah.28.22"><i>Is.</i> 28:22</a>): “Now do not scoff, that your fetters should not be tightened.”<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">And, therefore, Rebbi Yasa was not guilty of the scoffer’s death.</i> Rebbi Phineas, Rebbi Jeremiah, in the name of Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote">Since he was a contemporary of Rebbis Zeïra and Yasa, it is not clear whether this is an independent aggadic interpretation, appended here because it uses the same verse that R. Yasa used, or as the source of Rebbi Yasa/Assi’s interpretation.</i>: Scoffing is hard since its start is pain and its end destruction. Its start is pain since it is written “Now do not scoff, that your fetters should not be tightened,” and its end is destruction as it is written (<i>loc. cit.</i>) “For destruction and finality I heard from the Lord of Hosts<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">The Divine Names are not correctly quoted; this relieves the scribe from the necessity of writing down a name which cannot be erased.</i> over the entire earth.”

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The bridegroom may recite the <i>Shema‘</i> in his first night if he wishes. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliël says, not everyone who wants to grab a reputation<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Asserting that he is such a holy man that he can concentrate on his prayers under any circumstances.</i> can do so.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">This <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Taanit (Lieberman) 1:7" href="/Tosefta_Taanit_(Lieberman).1.7">Tosephta (<i>Taäniot</i> 1:7</a>) refers to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 1:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.1.3.1">Mishnah (<i>Taänit</i> 1:4</a>) that if there was no rain by the middle of the month of Ḥeshwan, distinguished people start fasting; public fasts because of the draught start only in Kislev. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel states that in matters that bring pain, everybody can join with the distinguished persons; only in matters that bring prestige, not everyone can join and a scholar cannot join if he has been duly appointed to a position of authority since in that case he has to avoid even the appearance of being better than the people under his authority. The Yerushalmi quotes this Tosephta anonymously, hence it accepts it as valid ruling.</i>: In anything that gives pain, everyone who wants to distinguish himself may do so. A scholar does and may blessing come to him. In anything that gives praise, not everyone who wants to distinguish himself may do so. A scholar does except if he has been appointed to a position of public authority.
It was stated: One may step to one side because of obstacles on the road<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">This is one of the conditions of public use of private land which Joshua imposed on the land distributed to the Israelite tribes (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 81b" href="/Bava_Kamma.81b">Babli <i>Bava Qama</i> 81b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 5:1:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.5.1.2-7">Yerushalmi <i>Bava Batra</i> 5:1</a>). If a road is impassable, one may walk on the shoulder even if the field is planted up to the roadbed.</i>. And when one sinks<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">In the rainy season on an unpaved road.</i>, even into a field full of saffron. Rebbi Abbahu said<sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote">A parallel to this story is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 81b" href="/Bava_Kamma.81b">Babli (<i>Bava Qama</i> 81b</a>) concerning Rebbi, Rebbi Ḥiyya, and Rebbi Yehudah ben Qanosa. The disapproving conclusion, given here in the name of the late Amora R. Zeïra, an immigrant from Babylonia, in the Babli is attributed to Rebbi. This shows that the note of Rebbi Zeïra is a belated accomodation of Galilean practice to Babylonian standards.</i>: It happened that Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Joshua were on the road and stepped on the side because of obstacles on the road when they saw Rebbi Yehudah ben Pappos, who was sinking, coming towards them. Rabban Gamliël said to Rebbi Joshua: Who is this one who makes an exhibition of himself<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">Showing overly great care not to infringe on other people’s property. Since the possession of land is a gift of God, any property rights are from the start subject to the liens enacted by Joshua, and use of the shoulders is no infringement of other people’s property. R. Yehudah ben Pappos’ piety therefore is quite misplaced.</i>? He answered: This is Yehudah ben Pappos, all whose deeds are done for Heaven’s sake. He said to him<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Rabban Gamliel to Rebbi Joshua. The implication is that R. Yehudah ben Pappos, who otherwise is unknown, held a public position and, therefore, was prohibited from exhibiting his piety. (In <i>Kafṭor waperaḥ</i>, R. Astorre Parḥi gives the name as Pappos ben Yehudah, a man known for his extreme habits, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sotah (Lieberman) 5:9" href="/Tosefta_Sotah_(Lieberman).5.9">Tosephta <i>Soṭa</i> 5:9</a>. However, of the two men of this name mentioned in Talmudic literature, one is too early, in Temple times, and the other one is mentioned in the prehistory of the revolt of Bar Kokhba, too late).</i>: Did we not formulate “In anything that gives praise, not everyone who wants to distinguish himself may do so. A scholar does except if he has been appointed to a position of public authority.” He answered him<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Joshua to Rabban Gamliel. Since walking on a wet dirt road is exhausting and very slow, even the holder of public office is permitted to walk on the road.</i>: Did we not also formulate, “In anything that gives pain, everyone who wants to distinguish himself may do so. A scholar does and may blessing come to him.” Rebbi Zeïra said, but only if he does not shame others<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">And here, the leaders of the generation were embarrassed by his unnecessary exhibition of piety.</i>.
Clarification. Rebbi Miasha<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of ms. Rome. The Venice print has “Rebbi Yasa”. The Venice reading explains why R. Samuel is mentioned in second place, since Rebbi Miasha was a student of Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac. Maybe there existed a version in which Rebbi Yasa was mentioned both times.</i> and Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac were sitting and eating in one of the upper synagogues<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">Of Tiberias. Most commentators invert the word order and explain: On the upper floor of a synagogue (since in the synagogue itself one may not eat).</i>. There came the time of prayer and Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac got up to pray. Rebbi Miasha said to him: Teacher, did you not teach us that once one started one does not interrupt<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Šabbat</i> 1:5. If the speaker is Rebbi Yasa, one would have to translate: “Did not Rebbi (the editor of the Mishnah) teach us …”.</i>. And Ḥizkiah stated: Every one who is free from an obligation and does it anyway is called uneducated<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἰδιώτης “private person, individual” (as opposed to the State).</i>. He answered him: Did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">The two Mishnayot from this chapter, that the groom is absolved from reciting <i>Sheina‘</i> but that he may do so if he wishes.</i>: “The bridegroom is free?” The bridegroom, if he wants. He<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Miasha.</i> answered him: Is that not from Rabban Gamliël<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 2:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.2.9.1">Mishnah 9</a>, even though formulated anonymously, is only acceptable to Rabban Gamliel, not to those who disagree with the him. The answer is that the Mishnah is acceptable to all.</i>? He said to him, I can free myself as Rabban Gamliel did; Rabban Gamliel said: I shall not listen to you to lift from me the Kingdom of Heaven.

Chapter 3



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Anyone whose dead is lying before him<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Any close relative who has to mourn for the dead and who has to organize the burial.</i> is free from reciting <i>Shema‘</i> and from <i>tefillin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">This is the text of the Yerushalmi and the Mishnah manuscripts. Most sources of the Babylonian Talmud add “and from all obligations of the Torah”, but the commentary of <i>Talmid Rabbenu Yonah</i> to Alfassi declares that good manuscripts do not contain the addition and it also seems that the addition was not accepted by Tosaphot.</i> The carriers of the bier, their substitutes, and the substitutes of their substitutes, in front of the bier or behind the bier, those that are needed by the bier are free, those that are not needed by the bier are obligated.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: “Those behind the bier are obligated”. Rashi explains that those in front of the bier await their turn to carry the bier to the cemetary but that those behind the bier already did that; they follow only to honor the dead person, but not to actively render any more services. The Yerushalmi does not know of such an organization.</i> All of them are free from the obligation to pray.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">According to Maimonides, the obligation from the Torah is only to say some prayer every day; hence, even if the participants in the burial miss one prayer they still have two others to fulfill the Biblical requirement. According to Nachmanides, the obligation to prayer is entirely rabbinical and is eliminated before the Torah obligation to bury fellow Jew.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">In the first sentence of our Mishnah.</i>: “And from <i>tefillin</i>.”A<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">This is a <i>baraita</i> from <i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> (3:5); a similar <i>baraita</i> (with the names of Rebbis Eliezer and Joshua switched) is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Moed Katan 21a" href="/Moed_Katan.21a">Babli <i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> 21a</a>. All authorities in all sources agree that a mourner may not put on <i>tefillin</i> the entire first day of mourning, even if the burial was conducted in the preceding night. So there is no connection between <i>tefillin</i> and the necessity to attend to the burial.</i> mourner may not put on <i>tefillin</i> on the first day; on the second day he puts on <i>tefillin</i> and when new faces appear during the seven days of mourning he takes them off; these are the words of Rebbi Eliezer. Rebbi Joshua says: On the first and second days he does not put on <i>tefillin</i>; on the third day he puts on <i>tefillin</i> and if new faces come he does not take them off. If he does not put on <i>tefillin</i> even on the second day, why is it necessary to mention “anyone whose dead is lying before him”? Because he stated the one he stated the other<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is necessary to mention that he is free from reciting <i>Shema‘</i>(and from prayer, whether that is stated in the Mishnah or not), the mention of <i>tefillin</i> is added as a memory aid. Since for a long time the Mishnah was transmitted by memory, it could not have been written down. Memory aids are an important part of Mishnah composition.</i>.
Rebbi Zeïra, Rav Jeremiah in the name of Rav: Practice follows Rebbi Eliezer in putting on and Rebbi Joshua in taking off<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The mourner puts on <i>tefillin</i> starting the second day after the funeral and does not take them off for a new visitor. In the Babli, this is a ruling of Ulla, one of the commuters between Babylonia and Galilee in the second generation of Amoraïm.</i>. Rebbi Zeïra inquired: If he put them on on the second day, following Rebbi Eliezer, would Rebbi Eliezer act like Rebbi Joshua, not to take them off? Rebbi Yose bar Abun said: Is it so that Rebbi Eliezer would act like Rebbi Joshua, not to take them off? If it were so, we should say “practice follows Rebbi Eliezer.”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">If on the second day, on which we follow Rebbi Eliezer, he takes off <i>tefillin</i> for new visitors, then the ruling should have been: Practice follows Rebbi Eliezer on the second day and Rebbi Joshua from the third day on. Since days are not mentioned, it is clear that Rebbi Joshua’s opinion, that one does not take off <i>tefillin</i> for visits of condolence, does not depend on the day. In the Babli, this is the ruling of Rava, of the generation following Rebbi Zeïra. The Babli quotes from the early Tanna Rebbi Jehudah ben Tema that one puts on <i>tefillin</i> and takes them off even a hundred times. Since R. Jehudah ben Tema, whose time cannot be determined, precedes Rav in any case, his opinion is not of much practical value.</i>
Rebbi Abun said: It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 16:3" href="/Deuteronomy.16.3"><i>Deut.</i> 16:3</a>) “So that you should remember the day of your exodus from Egypt the totality of the days of your living;” the days when you are occupied with the living, not the days that you are occupied with the dead<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The verse deals with the celebration of Passover but is used to indicate that any obligation of remembrance, and <i>tefillin</i> is one of them, are only for living and are invalid once one has to care for the dead. Rebbi Abun here follows the opponents of Ben Zoma in the first chapter who read כֹל֩, “the entirety” and not “all”. The verse gives a complete justification for the Mishnah, <i>viz</i>., that the entire first day is not for <i>tefillin</i>, even after the burial.</i>.
It was stated: If he wants to be more stringent with himself<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The verse deals with the celebration of Passover but is used to indicate that any obligation of remembrance, and <i>tefillin</i> is one of them, are only for living and are invalid once one has to care for the dead. Rebbi Abun here follows the opponents of Ben Zoma in the first chapter who read כֹל֩, “the entirety” and not “all”. The verse gives a complete justification for the Mishnah, <i>viz</i>., that the entire first day is not for <i>tefillin</i>, even after the burial.</i> one does not listen to him<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">He is forbidden to put on <i>tefillin</i>.</i>. Why? Because of the honor of the deceased or because he has nobody to carry his load<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">In organizing the funeral.</i>? What is the difference between them? If he has someone who is carrying his load; if you say because of the honor of the deceased it is forbidden, but if you say because he has nobody to carry his load, here he has somebody to carry his load. Has it not been stated: he is free from taking the <i>lulab</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The mourner whose deceased has not yet been buried may not weave the <i>lulab</i> on Tabernacles, nor may he blow the <i>shofar</i> on New Year’s Day. While the rule of <i>lulab</i> applies only to the intermediate days when burials are permitted, one never blows <i>shofar</i> as an obligation except on a holiday.</i>? Explain that it refers to weekdays. But has it not been stated: he is free from blowing the <i>shofar</i>. Can you say on weekday? No, on holiday. Rebbi Ḥanina said<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Even though it is forbidden to use the Sabbath to prepare for the next day, in these cases it is permitted to position oneself on the Sabbath so that one can start immediately fulfilling a <i>miẓwah</i> after the end of the Sabbath. The Sabbath domain extends 2000 cubits from the last house of one’s city; one may not move outside that domain on the Sabbath.</i>: Because he is obliged to bring him a casket and burial shrouds as we have stated (<i>Šabbat</i> 23:4): “One waits for nightfall at the borders of the Šabbat<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The Venice (and Leyden) text here, כפיטם, is unintelligible. The text given here is that of the Genizah fragments and the parallel in <i>Śemaḥot</i>.</i> domain to oversee matters for a bride and matters for a deceased to bring for him a casket, burial shrouds, fifes, and women mourners;” it is as if someone was carrying his load.
When does one overturn the couches<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The mourner is not allowed to eat reclining on a couch, but has to eat sitting upright on a chair as a sign of mourning. This duty applies to all those who are required to observe the week of mourning. The <i>baraita</i> is found in <i>Massekhet Śemaḥot</i> IX. The entire discussion is taken from Yerushalmi <i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> 3:5; the <i>baraita</i> is also found <a class="refLink" data-ref="Moed Katan 27a" href="/Moed_Katan.27a">Babli <i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> 27a</a>.</i>? From the moment when the dead left the gate of the courtyard<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">In the Talmud it is assumed that a house has no door leading to the street outside. A number of houses was always clustered around a courtyard, the door of the house lead into the courtyard, and the courtyard had an exit gate. In that way, privacy was always assured. The statement asserts that the moment the funeral procession is on its way is not when the bier leaves the house but when it leaves the outer gate of the courtyard.</i>, the words of Rebbi Eliezer. But Rebbi Joshua says, from when the cover plate was laid on the grave<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The dead was buried on a bier, not in a casket. Hence, the grave had to be covered by a large flat stone, the <i>golal</i>.</i>. And when Rabban Gamliel died, after he left the gate of the courtyard, Rebbi Eliezer said to his students: Overturn the couches<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">When the head of the Synhedrion dies, all are mourners.</i>. And when the cover plate was laid on the grave, Rebbi Joshua said: Overturn the couches. They said to him: We already did turn them over on the orders of the old man<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Even though Rebbi Eliezer was put in the ban since he did not agree with a majority ruling when he knew that the ruling contradicted tradition, it follows from here not only that he continued to lead his Yeshivah but also that in his lifetime, his authority in matters of religious practice remained supreme.</i>. Friday evening he rights his couch, at the end of Sabbat he overturns them<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Since any outward sign of mourning is forbidden on the Sabbath.</i>.
It was stated: “A <i>dargesh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">A kind of bed whose exact nature was unknown even in the time of the Talmud, as seen from the discussion that follows and in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nedarim 56a" href="/Nedarim.56a">Babli <i>Nedarim</i> 56a</a>. Maimonides, in his commentary to <i>Nedarim</i>, defines <i>dargesh</i> as a low couch (used for sitting only in the case of a mourner), much lower than a regular couch called <i>miṭṭah</i>. The Babli tentatively defines <i>dargesh</i> as a couch made of a frame onto which a leather mattress is attached by ropes. This definition may be compatible with the description given in the next section.</i> is put upright<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Most commentators explain that the <i>dargesh</i> is lifted to stand either on its front end or its foot end. But already <i>Rosh</i> (Rabbenu Asher ben Yeḥiël, 14th Century in Mayence and Toledo) has shown in his commentary to Babli <i>Nedarim</i> that this explanation is impossible and that the statement must mean: it is left standing as is. The other commentators are influenced by the version of the Babli which instead of the passive form used here have an active “he stands them up”, which seems to imply an action by the mourner, not passive as is implied here.</i> and is not turned over. Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">In all places where this is quoted in the Babli, the name is <i>Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel</i>, the father of Rebbi and son of Rabban Gamliel. Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar was a Tanna of the last generation who lived to see the start of the second generation of Amoraïm.</i> says, he removes its <i>qlbnṭryn</i><sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The spelling and, therefore, the meaning of the word are uncertain. The spelling here is קלבינטרין, that of the Genizah texts and <i>Śemaḥot</i> is קלמנטרין, the corresponding word in the Babli is קרביטין. The last word, according to Z. Frankel, is Greek τὸ κραβάτιον, Byzantine Greek κραββατάριον, “accessories to the bed”; this seems to be correct but is not very instructive. [Cf. also κράββατος “couch, mattress”; Latin <i>grabatus</i>, from Macedonian κράβατος “low couch, camp bed” (E. G.).]</i> and that is enough<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">There is a question whether the anonymous Tanna requires more or less that Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar. The quote in <i>Śemaḥot</i> XI reads: דרגש המקפת אינה נכפת. רבי שמעון בן אלעזר אומר מוריד קלמנטרין שלה וּמניחה כמות שהיא A surrounding <i>dargesh</i> is not turned over. Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar says, he removes the accessories and leaves it as is.” In this formulation, Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar explains that while the <i>dargesh</i> is not turned over, some sign of mourning has to be made. It seems that this is also the explanation here, that Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar adds a certain requirement to the first statement.</i>.” Rebbi Yosa<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yasa.</i> in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: practice follows Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Yose, a couch whose posts<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Τὰ ἀνάκλιτα, “things to lean on”; according to both Rashi and Arukh the two posts over which the mosquito screen was hung.</i> are upright and removed together with it, he takes them off and that is enough.
What is a couch and what is a <i>dargesh</i>? Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 20" href="/Sanhedrin.20">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 20a/b</a>, this appears in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan.</i> said, one that one plaits<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The couch has a frame and instead of a box spring it has length-and crosswise strips that are plaited together.</i> on its body is a couch and one that one does not plait on its body<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Maybe, according to the Babli, because instead of a plaited bed of strips it has a base of leather that is fastened only in a few places to the frame.</i> is a <i>dargesh</i>. But have we not stated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Kelim 16:1" href="/Mishnah_Kelim.16.1"><i>Kelim</i> 16:1</a>) “Bed and<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Reading of the Rome and Mishnah mss. The conjunction is missing in the Venice print and Leyden ms.</i> crib after he rubs them with fish skin<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah deals with the moment when a wooden implement is finished. Wood in itself cannot become ritually impure but wooden vessels and implements can. The moment when a wooden bed frame is finished so that it can become ritually unclean is the moment when it can be delivered by the carpenter to the customer, after it is polished with the classical equivalent of sand paper.</i>.” If he plaits on its body, why does he rub<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">If the entire frame is covered by the strips forming the base of the bed, who cares how the wooden frame looks?</i>? Rebbi Eleazar said, explain it with those Caesarean cribs that have holes<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">The strips are not wound around the frame but go through the holes in the frame, leaving half of it exposed.</i>.
From where the overturning of beds<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Levi Ginzberg noted correctly that all the sermons here point only to the overturning of beds on which one sleeps, not couches on which one sits. The Yerushalmi does not address the question whether during the day the mourner has to sit on the ground or may sit on an overturned couch.</i>? Rebbi Crispus<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">“Curly haired” (Latin, a Roman surname). A student of Rebbi Joḥanan and R. Simeon ben Laqish, and teacher of Rebbis Jonah and Yose.</i> in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 2:13" href="/Job.2.13"><i>Job</i> 2:13</a>) “They sat with him towards the ground.” It does not say here “on the ground” but “they sat with him towards the ground,” on something close to the ground. It follows that they were sleeping<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Since the friends were sitting with Job for seven days and seven nights, they must have slept “towards the ground”.</i> on overturned couches. Bar Qappara said: A beautiful form<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Greek εἰκών “image”, also “phantom”.</i> I had in your house and you caused me to overturn<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 3:4:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.3.4.2-3"><i>Megillah</i> 3:5</a> has לכופתה “to overturn it” (Babylonian Talmudic Hebrew.) The form לכופפה has no parallel in the Yerushalmi and might be a scribal error.<br>Bar Qappara seems to think that persons die because of the sins of their relatives. This is appropriate only for children who cannot die for their own sins since nobody below the age of 20 is liable before the heavenly court. The following, alternate version also shows that Bar Qappara speaks about mourning for small children.</i> it, you also overturn your bed! Some quote it by the expression “let him overturn; overturn<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The imperative כפה “overturn!” is missing in the parallel <i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> 5:3. The agent is the bed on which one not only sleeps but also has sex. Hence, the couch is the agent which produces the birth of a new baby.</i> the agent!” Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Yose, both in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish. One said, why does he sleep on an overturned coach? So that he should wake up in the night and realize that he is a mourner. The other one said, since he sleeps on an overturned bed he wakes up in the night and realizes that he is a mourner.
<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>baraita</i> is found in almost identical form in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 17b" href="/Berakhot.17b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 17b</a>, <i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> 23b, and the Yerushalmi source <i>Śemaḥot</i> X.</i> All the time that his deceased in lying before him, he eats at his neighbor’s, and if he has no neighbor, he eats in another room. If he has no other room, he makes a wall of separation and eats. If he is unable to make a wall of separation, he turns his face towards the wall and eats. He does not eat reclining; he does neither eat nor drink his fill. He eats neither meat nor drinks wine. One does not allow him to participate in a group to say Grace. If he recited Grace, one does not answer “amen” after him. If others recited Grace, he does not anwer “amen”. That is meant on weekdays. But on the Sabbath, he does eat reclining; he eats meat and drinks wine, eats and drinks his fill. One lets him participate in a group to say Grace. If he recited Grace, one does answer “amen” after him. If others recited Grace, he answers “amen”. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">In Babli sources, the author is Rabban Gamliel. The difference is essential since practice follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel even against a plurality of dissenters, but does not necessarily follow Rabban Gamliel. In the interpretation of the Babli, Rabban Gamliel obliges the married male mourner to fulfill his conjugal duties towards his wife. This is rejected as practice by the Babli which requires only that the enjoyment of Sabbath should not be diminished in any situation that is seen by others. The Yerushalmi makes no distinction between public and private obligations.</i> said: Because I allowed all of these, oblige him for all other obligations of the Torah. If I permitted him temporary life, so much more eternal life<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">And he who does not fulfill his conjugal duties towards his wife on Sabbath transgresses a positive commandment of the Torah. [The emphasis on this probably is anti-Sadducean; for the Sadducees, any sex act on the Sabbath was a Sabbath desecration punishable by death.]</i>. Rebbi Judah ben Pazi in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Practice follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel.
If he<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The deceased. The other “he” denotes the mourner.</i> was handed over to the public<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The public body organizing funerals, the <i>Ḥevrah Qadishah</i>.</i>, he may eat meat and drink wine. If he was handed over to the carriers<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Paid carriers.</i> it is as if he was handed to the public.
When Rebbi Yassa died, Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba received his mourners<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., Rebbi Yasa’s immediate family and possibly students. A mourner returning from the burial has to receive the first meal from others; the mourners were received with food so that they could go home and prepare the next meal themselves. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba did allow meat and wine for this first meal. (In Galilee, under the influence of late Greek, every ב was pronounced ν; ווה stands for בּא in Rebbi Ḥiyya’s name.)</i> and gave them meat to eat and wine to drink. When Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba died, Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac received his mourners and gave them meat to eat and wine to drink. When Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac died, Rebbi Zeïra received his mourners and gave them lentils to eat, saying that this was the tradition<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">It is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 16b" href="/Bava_Batra.16b">Babli <i>Baba batra</i>16b</a> as a Galilean tradition (transmitted by Rabba bar Mari, a student of Rebbi Joḥanan) that Jacob prepared a meal of lentils (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 25:29" href="/Genesis.25.29"><i>Gen.</i> 25:29</a>) for his father Isaac as the first meal after the burial of Abraham. The same tradition is given anonymously in the Galilean <i>Midrash Bereshit rabba</i> 63:16. The substitution of eggs used today instead of lentils is Babylonian (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 16b" href="/Bava_Batra.16b"><i>Baba batra</i> 16b</a>). Even though Rebbi Zeïra was Babylonian, the practice might have been that of the city of Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac.</i>. When Rebbi Zeïra was dying he commanded and said: “You should not accept mourning for me this day, tomorrow consolers.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">It is not very clear what Rebbi Zeïra was commanding to his students; also the text is quoted in very different forms by Nachmanides (<i>Torat Haädam</i>; ed. Chavel, p. 144) and those who quote from the latter. The only consistent interpretation is that of Levi Ginzberg: Rebbi Zeïra told his students not to be among the mourners the first day nor among those who arrange meals of consolation the next day. While he was a Babylonian by birth, he objected to the Babylonian practice that students mourn only one day for their teacher (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Moed Katan 25b" href="/Moed_Katan.25b">Babli <i>Moëd Qaṭan</i> 25b</a>) but wanted them to mourn for him the entire seven days (or not at all).<br>מרזחיּא are those who arrange the meal for the mourners, מַרְזֵחַ; as Levi Ginzberg points out, this meaning in Galilean (not Babylonian) Aramaic is clear from <i>Targum Sheni</i> on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Esther 1:2" href="/Esther.1.2"><i>Esther</i> 1:2</a>, towards the end.</i>”
Rebbi Isaac the son of Rebbi Ḥiyya the Scribe suffered an accident<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., a close relative died.</i>. Rebbis Mana and Yudan went to him. There was good wine, they drank a lot<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">More than the 10 cups allowed. The entire story is an introduction to the following <i>baraita</i> about the cups to be drunk in a house of mourning. (A cup of wine consists of two thirds water and one third wine).</i> and laughed. The next day they wanted to visit him again. He said to them: Rabbis, is that what a man does to his friend? Yesterday, the only thing that was missing for us was that we would get up and dance!
It is stated<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">This is the Yerushalmi formulation, also found in <i>Śemaḥot</i> XIV. The Babli version, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 8b" href="/Ketubot.8b"><i>Ketubot</i> 8b</a>, has 3 cups before the meal, 3 during the meal, and 4 after the meal for the four benedictions of Grace.</i>: Ten cups one drinks in the house of a mourner: two before the meal<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">As an apéritif. The next five are regular drinks to go with the solid food.</i>, five during the meal, and three after the meal. These are the three after the meal: one for Grace<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The regular cup over which Grace is said, as explained in later chapters. Since one may not recite Grace together in the presence of the mourner, one cup is needed for each one of the participants.</i>, one for those who exercise charity<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">In honor of those who gave their time and went out in the funeral procession.</i>, one for those who console mourners<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The outsiders who provided the meal and participate in it.</i>. And when Rabban (Simeon ben)<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">As is seen from the following and the parallel sources, “Simeon ben” is a scribal error.</i> Gamliel died, they added another three: One for the <i>Ḥazzan</i> of the community<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The religious leader of the community who leads the services and all religious activities including the funerals. (A rabbi is only a religious judge; the <i>ḥazzan</i> was not only the reader but also the ritual slaughterer and general servant of the community.)</i>, one for the head of the community<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The president of the congregation, who was responsible for the establishment and upkeep of the cemetery.</i>, and one for Rabban Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">He had himself buried in a simple linen shirt and in a plain unadorned wooden casket. Before his time, people were buried in elaborate clothing in expensive caskets. After him it became the Jewish standard that everybody has to be buried in Rabban Gamliel’s way.</i>. But when the Rabbinical authorities saw that they regularly got drunk they decreed and returned it to the original status<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">The preceding story, from later Galilean Amoras, shows that “the original way” are the prescribed 10 cups; there is no prohibition of wine at the funeral meal.</i>.
May a Cohen defile himself<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">By touching a dead body or carrying his casket (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21" href="/Leviticus.21"><i>Lev.</i> 21</a>). The main place of these discussions is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 7:1:2-22" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.7.1.2-22">Yerushalmi <i>Nazir</i> 7:1</a>.</i> for the honor of his teacher? The father-in-law of Rebbi Yannai the younger<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the fourth Galilean generation; so called to distinguish him from Rebbi Yannai, the teacher of Rebbi Joḥanan. It is implied that he was a Cohen.</i> died. He was both his father-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">A Cohen must defile himself for his wife but may not defile himself for any of her relatives.</i> and his teacher. He asked Rebbi Yose who forbade it. Rebbi Aḥa heard it and said: His students should defile themselves for him. The students of Rebbi Yose defiled themselves for him but ate meat and drank wine<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Before the burial.</i>. Rebbi Mana told them: One of two things you cannot escape. If you are mourners, why did you eat meat and drink wine; if you are not mourners, why did you defile yourselves?
May a Cohen defile himself for the honor of Torah? Rebbi Yose was sitting and teaching when a dead body was brought in<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">To be eulogized in the Yeshivah.</i>. He did not say anything either to those who left or to those who remained sitting<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">He said nothing to those who were Cohanim and did not want to stay in the same house with the dead person even though they were missing some of Rebbi Yose’s lectures, nor to those Cohanim among his students who preferred to study even if it meant staying with the dead person in the same “tent”. Rebbi Yose was undecided whether a Cohen should stay or leave.</i>.
Rebbi Nehemiah the son of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said: My father did not walk under the arch of Caesarea<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ḥiyya bar Abba was a Cohen, as is also clear from the later account of the visit of Diocletian. He did not pass under an arch attached to a building or archway under which there were graves. The Caesarea here is Caesarea Philippi, on the Jordan near Banias. Even though Caesarea Philippi was built by the Herodian family, it is unlikely that the arch belonged to a building containing a Jewish grave and it is accepted in the Babylonian Talmud (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 61a" href="/Yevamot.61a"><i>Yebamot</i> 61a</a>), following R. Simeon bar Yoḥai, that only Jewish graves defile “in a tent” but not Gentile ones. The problem is not mentioned in any of the surviving parts of the Yerushalmi; one might infer from the stories told here that the ruling of the Babli was not that accepted in Galilee. Nachmanides (ענין ההוצאה, תורת אדם ed. Chavel, vol. 2, p. קה) adds: “but R. Ammi (who also was a Cohen) did pass under them.” The rest of the paragraph supports the reading of Nachmanides.</i>. Rebbi Ammi, Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Cohen and Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa went walking on those streets<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>platea</i>, Greek πλατεῖα (<i>scil</i>. ὁδός), “street”.</i> of Sepphoris. They came to the arch and Rebbi Cohen left<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Probably for the same reason that Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba did not pass under the arch of Caesarea.</i>. They reached a place of purity and he returned to them. He asked them: “What were you discussing?” Rebbi Ḥizqiah said to Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa: “Do not tell him anything!” We do not know whether it was because he was angry that he left since one defiles oneself for words of Torah or whether it was because he<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Cohen. (The first “he” refers to R. Ḥizqiah.) Since the problem is unresolved, it seems that in the opinion of the Yerushalmi, as a doubt in matters of Torah, he should not defile himself for Torah study. (This is the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 13a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.13a">Babli, <i>Avodah zarah</i> 13a</a>, for all defilements that have a Biblical basis.)</i> was haughty<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The reading is that of the Leyden manuscript; the <i>editio princeps</i> of Nachmanides has גייסן. The Venice print has טייסן, “a flyer” which makes no sense. The implication seems to be that Rebbi Ḥizqiah, the Rabbinic authority, was piqued by the fact that Rebbi Cohen, a very minor figure, did not ask his opinion whether he might pass under the arc.</i>.
It is stated<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>baraita</i> is in similar form in other Yerushalmi sources, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 7:1:2-22" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.7.1.2-22"><i>Nazir</i> 7:1</a>, <i>Śemaḥot</i> IV:25,26, Tosephta <i>Moëd qaṭan</i> 1:12, <i>Avodah zarah</i> 1:8, and in materially different Babylonian tradition in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 13a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.13a">Babli <i>Avodah zarah</i> 13a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 47a" href="/Eruvin.47a"><i>Erubin</i> 47a</a>.</i>: A Cohen may defile himself by leaving the Land<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear which verse of the Torah declares all land outside the Land of Israel ritually unclean but the fact that it is so, is obvious from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Amos 7:17" href="/Amos.7.17"><i>Amos</i> 7:17</a>.
