(The Babli takes the impurity of the “land of Gentiles” to be rabbinic, but this refers to the time when no ashes of a red heifer were available anymore and every Cohen was impure from the start, whereas the Yerushalmi <i>baraita</i> might refer to earlier times, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.1">Chapter 1, Note 3</a>.) The prohibition for the Cohen to defile himself willingly derives from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:1-15" href="/Leviticus.21.1-15"><i>Lev.</i> 21:1–15</a>.</i> for civil and criminal suits, for the consecration of the New Moon and intercalation of a year<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">In the absence of a computed calendar, the last two activities may be exercised outside the Land of Israel only if political circumstances make the consecration in Israel impossible. (The statements up to this point are missing in the Babli parallels; see the preceding Note.)</i>, to save a field from a Gentile, and he even may leave and lodge a complaint about it<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">“To lodge a complaint” about real estate usually means to claim ownership against a squatter, in particular if there are no written documents for either party.</i>, to study Torah and to marry a wife. Rebbi Judah says, if he has a place to study<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Any place to study in the Land of Israel.</i>, he should not defile himself. Rebbi Yose says, even if he has a place to study, he may defile himself, since a man may not have the luck to learn from every teacher. They said about Joseph the Cohen<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph (called Issi) ben Yehudah (or Aqabiah) from Huẓal in Babylonia who immigrated to Israel and was a student of Rebbis Eleazar ben Shamua and Yose ben Ḥalaphta. He is a Tanna of the last generation and known as the “last of the pious”. If such a holy man leaves Israel to follow his secondary teacher, the practice of leaving the Land for study purposes is well established.</i> that he defiled himself and followed his teacher to Sidon<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Note the Talmudic vocalization Ṣīdān, in contrast to Biblical Ṣīdōn, close to modern Arabic Ṣaidā.</i>. In truth<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">As a rule, any tannaïtic statement label אבל “in truth”, represents established practice. The permission for a priest to leave the Land for marriage is only for an arranged marriage, not for a search for a possible bride.</i>, they said a priest should not go abroad unless one promised him a wife.
May a Cohen defile himself for the lifting of hands<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">The priestly blessing (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 6:24-26" href="/Numbers.6.24-26"><i>Num.</i> 6:24–26</a>) that the Cohen has to recite during morning prayers. Since the priest has to lift his hands for the blessing, in imitation of Aaron the High Priest (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 9:22" href="/Leviticus.9.22"><i>Lev.</i> 9:22</a>), the entire ceremony is called “the lifting of hands”.</i>? Gedilah<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the Rome manuscript. The names given in other sources, מגבילה, גבילה, are not otherwise attested as Semitic names.</i>, the brother of Rebbi Abba bar Cohen<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the fifth generation, student of the Amora Rebbi Yose, two generations after Rebbi Abba bar Kahana.</i> said before Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Aḥa: A Cohen defiles<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Implying that a Cohen <i>must</i> defile himself to fulfill the obligation of reciting the priestly blessing.</i> himself for the lifting of hands. Rebbi Aḥa heard it and said: I never told him anything. On second thoughts he said, maybe he heard from me that which Rebbi Jehudah ben Pazi said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Every Cohen who stays in the synagogue and does not lift his hands transgresses a positive commandment, and he wanted to say that a positive commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation on the Cohen to recite the blessing. The negative commandment is the prohibition for the Cohen to defile himself without good cause.</i> supersedes a negative commandment. I never told him anything<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to recite the priestly blessing is only on a Cohen who happens to be in the synagogue at the right time. But if a coffin is in the synagogue for an eulogy before the funeral, the Cohen cannot be in the synagogue when the priests are called and, hence, would have to enter the synagogue to be defiled at a moment when there is no positive commandment on him. The hypothetical argument of Rebbi Aḥa could only be resolved in favor of Gedilah in the unlikely event that someone in the synagogue dies suddenly while the priests already assemble for the priestly blessing.</i>. Bring him in and I will cause him to be flogged!
Rebbi Abbahu was sitting teaching in the fortified<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the Rome ms., from Syriac מרדא, “fortified”. Graetz’s translation “revolutionary” is phantasy. The word could be from Greek μερίς, -ίδος, ἡ “part, region, district”. In that case, the translation would be “regional synagogue” (E. G.). The reading of the Leyden ms. and the Venice print, מדדתא, “measuring” or “tripping”, does not make any sense.</i> synagogue in Caesarea<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">It is not quite clear whether this was Caesarea on Sea or Caesarea Philippi; the former is usually assumed but it will become clear that the latter is in fact meant.</i>; there was a coffin there. There came the time for lifting the hands and they<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">The Cohanim among his students. They remained sitting for Rebbi Abbahu’s lecture.</i> did not ask him. There came the time for eating and they asked him. He said to them: For the lifting of hands you did not ask me, for eating you are asking me<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Since Rebbi Abbahu did not deliver a ruling, it seems that he had not formed a definite opinion on the matter. Rebbi Yose was one of the last students of Rebbi Abahu; the discussion quoted in the preceding paragraph could not have taken place if a ruling was issued by Rebbi Abbahu.</i>? When they heard this, each one was taking himself away and fled.
Rebbi Yannai said: A Cohen defiles himself in order to see the king. When king Diocletian visited here, Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba was seen stepping over graves at Tyre in order to see him<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Since Diocletian changed the constitution of the Roman empire from a formally republican one to an absolute monarchy, it is not totally clear whether a Cohen may defile himself only for a ruler who also carries the formal title of “king” or whether he should be a ruler who has power over life and death. Since the rule appears here in the name of Rebbi Yannai who lived under the principate, the second alternative is the more likely one. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 19b" href="/Berakhot.19b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 19b</a>), the ruling (and the statement of Rebbi Joḥanan) is not by an early Amora but by a very early Tanna, Rebbi Eleazar bar Ẓadoq, a Cohen who mentions having seen the late Herodian rulers before the destruction of the Temple.<br>It was reported before that Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba was a Cohen. We also saw before that the Yerushalmi does not seem to exclude Gentile graves from the defilement of a “tent”; hence, it is not proven that Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba stepped over Jewish graves at Tyre. (The Babli, <i>loc. cit.</i>, notes that a Cohen is prohibited by Biblical commandment from stepping over a grave only if there is less than a hand-breadth of space between the corpse and the upper cover of the coffin, as explained in Mishnah <i>Ahilot</i> VII; in most cases stepping over a grave is only a rabbinical prohibition which may be lifted in special circumstances.)</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah and Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: There is an obligation to see great persons of government, so that when the kingdom of the dynasty of David will return one will know how to distinguish one government from the other.
When Rebbi Judah the Prince<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi, the son of Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel and editor of the Mishnah.</i> died, Rebbi Yannai proclaimed and said: “There is no priesthood today<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">All priests are obliged to come to the eulogy and funeral.</i>.” When Rebbi Judah the Prince, grandson of Rebbi Judah the Prince, died, Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba did push Rebbi Zeïra<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Who also was a Cohen and did not want to defile himself. While the Prince Judah I was not only patriarch but also recognized as the greatest rabbinic authority of his day, Judah II was patriarch and a competent but not outstanding scholar. Rebbi Zeïra apparently felt that his scholarship did not merit that a Cohen should defile himself, whereas Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, who like Rebbi Zeïra was a greater scholar than Judah II, insisted that the office of patriarch alone deserved this recognition.</i> in the Gufna synagogue of Sepphoris and defiled him. When Nahoraï<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Nahoraï is really a man’s name. In the parallel in Nazir she is called Yehudinaï, which seems to be the better tradition. She was the sister of Judah II.</i>, the sister of Rebbi Judah the prince, died, Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Ḥananiah from Sepphoris, a colleague of Rebbi Mana; see Chap. 2, Note 97.</i> sent for Rebbi Mana but the latter did not come. He said to him, if one does not defile himself for them during their lifetime, so much less in their death. Rebbi Nassa<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Rebbi Eleazar and others; a resident of Caesarea whose name is prominent in the part of the Yerushalmi that was edited in Caesarea (<i>Neziqin</i>.)</i> said, in their death they made them like a corpse of obligation<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">A corpse of obligation is the body of a Jew who is not the known relative of anybody nearby and, therefore, has nobody who could organize his funeral. In such a situation, the first person who finds him must care for him; even the High Priest, who does not defile himself even for father and mother, <i>must</i> defile himself for a corpse of obligation.<br>It is not too clear who is meant. We may assume that Maimonides writes from tradition when he formulates (<i>Hilkhot Evel</i>, 3:10) ’’When a patriarch dies, everybody defiles himself for him, including Cohanim; they made him like a corpse of obligation for everybody because everybody is required to honor him and everybody is stunned by his death.” <i>Hagahot Maimuniot</i> (<i>ad loc.</i>) note that the sentence “they made him like a corpse of obligation” is the statement of Rebbi Nassa. The discussion goes as follows:<br>The sister of the patriarch Judah II died after him. Rebbi Ḥanina demanded that Rebbi Mana, a Cohen, should defile himself for her. Rebbi Mana retorted that, since he would not defile himself for her during the patriarch’s lifetime, when it would have constituted an honor for the patriarch, he might not do so after the patriarch’s death. Rebbi Nassa, in support of Rebbi Mana, explains that the defilement of Cohanim for the patriarch is because he is considered an obligation for all of Israel.</i>.
May a Cohen defile himself in honor of his father and mother<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">As the sequel shows, the only question is whether a Cohen may leave the Holy Land doing something in honor of father or mother. The Biblical prohibitions cannot be violated for the honor of father and mother.</i>? Rebbi Yasa heard that his mother had come to Bostra<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">This city is South of the Hauran mountains, not far from Edreï, on the caravan route to Babylonia. It is not the Biblical Edomite Boṣra. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 31b" href="/Kiddushin.31b">Babli (<i>Qiddushin</i> 31b</a>) is much more explicit, stating that Rebbi Assi’s (Yasa’s) mother was mentally disturbed and that it turned out that her coffin arrived at Bostra.</i>. He went and asked Rebbi Yoḥanan, may I leave? He said to him, if it is because of danger on the road<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">To accompany his mother because of the dangers of the road is clearly allowed since it is a matter of life and death.</i>, leave. If it is in order to honor father and mother, I do not know. Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac said, Rebbi Yoḥanan still needs to answer. He importuned him<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yasa did not accept Rebbi Joḥanan’s answer as final, insisting to have a definite yes or no.</i>, so he said: If you decided to go, return in peace<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Joḥanan would not order any Cohen to leave the Holy Land in order to meet father or mother but neither would he hinder any one who very much wanted to go.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar heard this and said: there is no greater permission than that.
May a Cohen defile himself in honor of the public? It is stated: When there are two acceptable roads, one long and pure, the other one short and impure: If the public was walking<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">In a funeral procession. The <i>baraita</i> is from <i>Semaḥot</i> 4:14. Since the following <i>baraita</i> 15 speaks about digging the grave, the text here speaks of the procession preceding the actual burial. A similar but different <i>baraita</i> in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 19b" href="/Berakhot.19b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 19b</a>) deals with people returning after the burial.</i> on the long one, he goes on the long one; otherwise, he goes on the short one in honor of the public. That refers to impurity by their words<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">If the impurity is not certain but only possible, the prohibition of passage for the Cohen is only rabbinical, not biblical.</i>; also for impurity that is from the words of the Torah? From what Rebbi Zeïra said, so great is the honor of the public that it temporarily pushes aside a prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">It is explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 9:1:8-14" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.9.1.8-14"><i>Kilaim</i> 9:2</a> that if somebody notices that his clothing is forbidden as <i>shaätnez</i>, he may keep his clothes on until he gets home and does not have to stand naked or in his underwear in public.</i>, that means even impurity that is from the words of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli comes to the opposite conclusion but, as noted before, it deals with people returning from the funeral, not a funeral procession as here.</i>.
Rebbi Jonah, Rebbi Yose the Galilean<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the third generation, teacher of Rebbi Jonah.</i>, Rebbi Yasa bar Ḥanina: One does not ask rulings on practice before the bier of a deceased<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 3b" href="/Berakhot.3b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 3b</a>) it is stated more generally, in the name of R. Joshua ben Levi, that words of Torah are forbidden in presence of a coffin. According to Rashi, the reason is (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 17:5" href="/Proverbs.17.5"><i>Prov.</i> 17:5</a>): “He who scoffs at the poor blasphemes his Maker.” Since the dead person can no longer study Torah, he is poor in this respect.</i>. But Rebbi Yoḥanan asked Rebbi Yannai before the bier of Rebbi Simeon ben Yoẓadaq<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">This is the correct reading of the Rome ms. R. Simeon bar Yoẓadaq was an Amora of the first generation, one of the teachers of Rebbi Yoḥanan. The Leyden ms. has שמואל בר יוצדק by a scribal error.</i> about him who dedicated his holocaust sacrifice for the upkeep of the Temple, and he answered him<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah (<i>Temurah</i> 32a) states that a forbidden substitution is valid only from lesser to higher sanctity. The highest sanctity of a sacrifice is the עוֹלָה, the holocaust, which is totally burnt on the altar, whereas gifts for the upkeep of the Temple are only a monetary obligation. So it should be impossible to dedicate an <i>‘olah</i> for the upkeep of the Temple. However, a <i>baraita</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Temurah 32b" href="/Temurah.32b">Babli <i>Temurah</i> 32b</a>) states that a holocaust which afterwards was dedicated for the upkeep of the Temple cannot be slaughtered unless redeemed first and the money given to the Temple. The answer given there (presumably by Rebbi Yannai) is that the obligation of redemption is purely rabbinical, a kind of fine, but that from the Torah the second dedication is invalid.</i>! Let us say when he was far away<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">So that the deceased could not have heard them even were he still alive.</i> or when they were bringing him to the study hall<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Most commentators explain that Rebbis Yoḥanan and Yannai were outside the Bet-Hamidrash. However, that would be the same as “being far away”. Therefore, it seems that the correct interpretation is given by R. Zacariah Frankel, that a eulogy of a Torah teacher in his own school by necessity must involve words of Torah.</i>. But Rebbi Jeremiah asked Rebbi Zeïra before the bier of Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac! Let us say that he answered him when he was far away; when he was close he did not answer him.
It is stated: The carriers<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">The carriers of the bier in the funeral procession, members of the “holy society”.</i> may not wear sandals<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">According to <i>Ṭure Zahav</i> on <i>Shulḥan Arukh Yore Dea</i> 358:3, this applies only to professional carriers, or members of a society that monopolizes the <i>mitzvah</i> of carrying the bier, who will have to walk barefooted. However, it seems that shoes without laces would be permitted by the Yerushalmi.</i> lest a shoelace of one of them break so he would be eliminated from the good deed.
Rebbi Zeïra bent down<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Most commentators explain that Rebbi Zeïra fell down. But the parallels quoted in Levy’s dictionary show that Aramaic שרע is the parallel of biblical Hebrew סרח, “overhanging”. The speaker was leaning down over the railing of his pulpit.</i> during a eulogy. They wanted to straighten him up and found that he tarried<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">The Aramaic עני may mean 1) to become poor, 2) to take one’s time, tarry, 3) to empty oneself. In Yerushalmi sources, the form איעני is found only in meaning 2). The verse quoted reads in full: “It is better to go to a house of mourning than to go to a wedding. Since that is the end of all humanity, let the one who is alive take it to heart.”</i>. They said to him, what is this? He said to them, because we will go there, following (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 7:2" href="/Ecclesiastes.7.2"><i>Eccl.</i> 7:2</a>): “Let the one who is alive take it to heart.”

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> When they buried the deceased and returned, if they are able to start and finish before they form the row<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Before the mourners leave for their home, the other participants of the funeral form two lines and the mourners pass in the row between them. While they pass, words of consolation are spoken to them. Today, that ceremony is performed in the cemetary so that the Mishnah becomes void. In talmudic times, the burial was in the cemetary far from the city, but the ceremony of the row took place at the entrance to the city. There may be a long enough walk from cemetary to town that the prescribed time for <i>Shema‘</i> would pass. The words “start” and “finish” refer to the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>.</i> they should start, otherwise they should not start. Those who stand in the row, the innermost are exempt<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Since the mourners can see and hear them, they are doing a good deed and cannot be distracted by other obligations. The “outer ones” are those who cannot be seen by the mourners.</i> and the outer ones are obliged.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">The entire discussion of this Mishnah is repeated word by word in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 2:2:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.2.2.2-6">Yerushalmi <i>Sanhedrin</i> 2:2</a> (fol. 20a).</i> It is stated: “One does not take the dead for burial close to the recitation of the <i>Shema‘</i> unless one does it one hour in advance or one hour afterwards, so that they may recite and pray.” But did we not formulate: “When they buried the deceased and returned”<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">How can the situation dealt with in the Mishnah ever arise if the <i>baraita</i> is correct?</i>? Explain it for those who thought that they have a free period<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">In the absence of reliable clocks. In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 19a" href="/Berakhot.19a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 19a</a>), it is stated flatly that the restriction of the <i>baraita</i> does not apply to funerals of important persons. In the opinion of the Babli, the situation envisaged by the Mishnah can apply to previously planned funerals.</i> but they did not have a free period.
It is stated<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:11" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.11">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 2:11</a>. This Tosephta comes after the one dealing with the funeral (which will be quoted later in this Halakhah.) Hence, it clearly deals with a eulogy <i>after</i> the funeral. The text of the Tosephta follows that of the Genizah fragments; it is slightly corrupted in the Venice (and Leyden) texts that have ההספד instead of the unusual המהספד (the corresponding word in the Babli would be המספיד.) [A seemingly similar <i>baraita</i> in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 19a" href="/Berakhot.19a">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 19a</a>, deals with a eulogy before burial and has nothing in common with the text given here.]</i>: The eulogizer and all who participate in a eulogy interrupt for the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> and do not interrupt for prayer. It happened that our teachers interrupted for the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> and prayer. Did we not formulate: “If they are able to start and finish”? Our Mishnah speaks of the first day, what is stated for the second day.
Rebbi Samuel ben Eudaimon<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the fifth Galilean generation, student of Rebbi Mana. The paragraph added deals with the problem of whether to start or not; it is a kind of appendix to the first two paragraphs. After that digression, one will return to the discussion of the Mishnah.</i> said: He who enters the synagogue and finds them standing and praying<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">The Amidah prayer.</i>, if he knows that he could start and finish before the reader starts, so that he may answer “Amen”, he may pray, otherwise he should not pray. About which “Amen” did they talk? Two Amoraïm, one says the Amen of “the holy King”<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The third benediction of the Amidah. “He Who hears prayer” is the last of the middle benedictions of weekday prayers (15th in Israel, 16th in Babylonia). The statement refers to the old Galilean usage that <i>Qedushah</i> was recited only on special days; it probably was not recited in the Sabbath afternoon prayers and, hence, it is not mentioned that one should be able to respond to <i>Qedushah</i>.</i> and the other says the Amen of “He Who listens to prayer”. Rebbi Phineas said, they do not disagree. He who said: the Amen of “the holy King”, on the Sabbath, and he who said: the Amen of “He Who listens to prayer” on weekdays.
It is stated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:11" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.11"><i>Tosephta Berakhot</i> 2:11</a>): “Rebbi Judah says, if they all are standing in one row, those who are standing because of honor are obliged, those because of mourning are exempt<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">In the text of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 19b" href="/Berakhot.19b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 19b</a>), Rashi reads: “those who come because of themselves”, not “because of honor”, but most manuscripts and old authors have “because of honor”. Also, in the Babli only the second part of the Tosephta is attributed to Rebbi Yehudah. According to Rashi, only those are obliged to read the <i>Shema‘</i> who come out of curiosity whereas according to most others those who come to honor the dead and his family but do not actively console are not exempt. The Babylonian Talmud makes no comment; we have to assume that it accepts the position of R. Samuel Tosephta.</i>. When they descend for a eulogy, those who see inside are exempt, those who do not see inside are obliged<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Since they cannot be seen by the mourners, the may recite the <i>Shema‘</i> for themselves without offending anybody.</i>.” It would be that what we stated: “Those who stand in the row, the innermost are exempt and the outer ones are obliged” is the last teaching<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">The question is, what is the last teaching? We are informed that the original custom was that the mourners walk between two rows of participants who greet them with words of consolation. When competition grew in Sepphoris, it seems because people were jostling for the best positions (those who did not make it to the front rows could not be seen or heard by the mourners), Rebbi Yose decreed that the mourners should stay put and all others march by them to greet and console them. This is the case dealt with by Rebbi Judah, that there is only one row (moving, not standing). An otherwise unknown Rebbi Samuel declares that the innovation of Rebbi Jose did not stand the test of time and in his time the consolers stand and the mourners move. Rebbi Samuel’s opinion is the “last teaching”, Rebbi Yose’s “the first teaching”. In the first teaching, there are no people in outer rows, so the Mishnah automatically has to apply to the last teaching.</i>, and what is stated: “Those who are standing because of honor are obliged, those because of mourning are exempt”, is the first teaching<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Since the entire Tosephta is Rebbi Judah’s, it speaks of the case where there is only one row. (This argument is not applicable to the text quoted in the Babli.)</i>. And what we have stated there (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 2:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.2.2.1">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 2:2</a>): “When he<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">The High Priest. When he goes out, he is accompanied by his executive officer; when he consoles mourners the executive goes first, the High Priest second, and everybody else in one orderly row after him. This is possible only in the scenario envisaged by Rebbi Yose; it is shown that the practice instituted by Rebbi Yose at Sepphoris (in the second half of the second century C. E.) is in effect an old Jerusalem practice from the time before the destruction of the Temple, as stated explicitly in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 19a" href="/Sanhedrin.19a">Babli <i>Sanhedrin</i>19a</a>, where it is noted that also under that system people quarrelled in Jerusalem. Here the copyist (or the editor) seems to have doubts whether to go with the definition of “first” and “last” as above or to call “first” the first practice reported by Rebbi Ḥanina and “last” the second one. Hence, there are two opinions about the attribution but the meaning is clear. If the uncertainty is the editor’s, then the note “Another opinion: the first” belongs to the text. If it is the scribe’s or some reader’s, then it is a gloss that has entered the text from the margin. For consistency, the hypothesis of a gloss is preferable.</i> consoles others, all the people stand one behind the other and the executive officer becomes a partition between himself and the people”, the last teaching. (Another opinion: the first.) Rebbi Ḥanina said: Originally, all families were standing still and the mourners passed between them. When competition increased in Sepphoris, Rebbi Yose ben Ḥalaphta decreed that the families should pass by and the mourners stand still. Rebbi Samuel Tosephta<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">In the Venice text, “Rebbi Simeon of the Tosephta”. The name given in the text is from the Geniza fragments (Rebbi Samuel Tosephta) and similar to the parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 2:2:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.2.2.2-6">Yerushalmi <i>Sanhedrin</i> 2:2</a> (fol. 20a) “Rebbi Samuel of Sofephta”. Tosephta might be the region of Northern Armenia, called Thospitis by Ptolemy, which was the birthplace of Rabba Tosphaä, one of the later heads of the Academy of Sura in Babylonia.</i> said: Matters returned to their original state.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Women, slaves, and minors are exempt from reciting the <i>Shema‘</i> and from phylacteries but are obliged for prayer, <i>mezuzah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">While both phylacteries and <i>mezuzot</i> are based on verses in <i>Shema‘</i>, their status is different.</i> and Grace for food.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Women from where? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:19" href="/Deuteronomy.11.19"><i>Deut.</i> 11:19</a>) “You must teach them to your sons.” To your sons but not to your daughters<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The father is unconditionally obliged to teach his sons Torah; since this is an integral part of <i>Shema‘</i>, the same is valid for reciting the <i>Shema‘</i>. It is general practice that women <i>may</i> recite <i>Shema‘</i>; it follows that in the opinion of the Yerushalmi, women may study any subjects of Torah they wish. [The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 20b" href="/Berakhot.20b">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 20b</a>, simply notes that <i>Shema‘</i> is an obligation to be executed at stated times, of which women and slaves are automatically exempted. Since the Yerushalmi brings this argument in relation to other things later in this section, it follows that for it the recital of <i>Shema‘</i> is simply an aspect of Torah study and Torah study is required “day and night”, not depending on any particular time.]</i>.
Slaves from where? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:4" href="/Deuteronomy.6.4"><i>Deut.</i> 6:4</a>): “Hear, o Israel, the Eternal, our Power, the Eternal is unique.” He who has only one Lord, this excludes the slave who has another lord<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in the preceding paragraph, the Yerushalmi does not refer to the obligation of reciting <i>Shema‘</i> as an obligation to be performed at stated times; therefore, a separate argument is necessary to free from the obligation slaves who accepted Judaism.</i>.
Minors from where? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:9" href="/Exodus.13.9"><i>Ex.</i> 13:9</a>) “So that the Torah of the Eternal should stay in your mouth”, at a time when he is permanent in it<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is exceedingly difficult for two reasons. 1) It is a generally accepted principle that minors are not obliged to do anything; it is their parents who are obliged to teach them and see to it that they perform <i>miẓwot</i>. 2) The verse deals only with <i>tefillin</i>.<br>In the Yerushalmi tradition, the statement and the tradition are not unquestioned. Both <i>Mekhiltot</i> (<i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael</i>, ed. Horovitz-Rabin, p. 68; <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon bar Ioḥai</i>, p.41), the Tannaïtic commentaries to Exodus, give the same commentary on the next verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:10" href="/Exodus.13.10"><i>Ex.</i> 13:10</a>): “You must preserve this decree in its time, from year to year”. “Why has this been said? Because it has been said (v.9): ‘It shall be for you a sign on your hand’, I might understand this to include minors. And it is logical, since <i>mezuzah</i> is a positive commandment and <i>tefillin</i> are a positive commandment; if you find that <i>mezuzah</i> applies to minors the same way it applies to adults you might think that <i>tefillin</i> apply to minors the same way they apply to adults, but the verse says ‘you must preserve this decree’, I spoke only about those able to watch over their <i>tefillin</i>; from here they said: If a minor knows how to watch his <i>tefillin</i>, his father makes him <i>tefillin</i>.”<br>The argument presupposes the statement that minors are obliged to have <i>mezuzot</i> on their doors (meaning that if they live alone, the rabbinic authorities have to see to it that they have <i>mezuzot</i> on their doors). <i>Mezuzah</i> and <i>tefillin</i> are always mentioned together in the first two paragraphs of <i>Shema‘</i>. Hence, one may assume that they are identical in those details that are not spelled out. Both Yerushalmi and Mekhiltot agree that some explanation is needed to distinguish between the rules for <i>mezuzah</i> and those for <i>tefillin</i>. However, the Mekhiltot extend the obligation of <i>tefillin</i> to all school children whereas the Yerushalmi restricts it to those for whom the study of Torah is a permanent obligation, i. e., from Bar-Miẓwah onwards. In itself the argument about minors is totally irrelevant; it is needed to exclude the opinion of the Mekhiltot.</i>.
They are obliged to pray so that everybody ask mercy for himself<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Here again, we have a divergence between Yerushalmi and Babli. The Yerushalmi states that prayer is an obligation not because it is a Biblical commandment but because the rabbis thought that everybody has to implore divine mercy for himself. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 20b" href="/Berakhot.20b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 20b</a>), the argument of the Yerushalmi is repeated but then it is stated that in Psalms (<i>Ps.</i> 55:18) three times daily are stated for prayer and if that were a general obligation, women would be automatically dispensed from it. Hence, it follows that the rabbinical obligation of prayer for women cannot mean for the Babli an obligation to pray at those stated times, which it could mean in the interpretation of the Yerushalmi. The opinion of the Babli is that of Maimonides, the possible one of the Yerushalmi that of Nachmanides.</i>.
And for <i>mezuzah</i>, as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:9" href="/Deuteronomy.6.9"><i>Deut.</i> 6:9</a>): “You shall write them on the doorpost of your house and your gates<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">This is an obligation of ownership, not of person.</i>.
And grace after meals, as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:10" href="/Deuteronomy.8.10"><i>Deut.</i> 8:10</a>): “You will eat and be satiated; then you must praise the Eternal, your God.<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Yerushalmi, women and slaves are required to recite Grace from the Torah since everybody who eats must give praise. In the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>), this remains questionable.</i>”
There (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.7.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 1:7</a>) we have stated: “Every positive commandment that is activated by time, men are obliged by it but women are exempt. Every positive commandment that is not activated by time, both men and women are obliged by it.” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Kiddushin (Lieberman) 1:10" href="/Tosefta_Kiddushin_(Lieberman).1.10">Tosephta <i>Qiddushin</i> 1:10</a>): “What is a positive commandment that is activated by time? For example <i>sukkah</i>, <i>lulab</i>, <i>shofar</i>, and <i>tefillin</i>. What is a positive commandment that is not activated by time? For example lost articles<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to return found articles and stray animals to their owners in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:1-3" href="/Deuteronomy.22.1-3"><i>Deut.</i> 22:1–3</a>.</i>, sending away the nest<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to send away the mother if eggs or chicks are taken from a nest in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:6-7" href="/Deuteronomy.22.6-7"><i>Deut.</i> 22:6–7</a>.</i>, railing<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to make a fence around a flat roof in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:8" href="/Deuteronomy.22.8"><i>Deut.</i> 22:8</a>.</i>, and <i>ẓiẓit</i><sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to wear ẓ<i>iẓit</i> in the third section of <i>Shema‘</i> where it is stated that they must be seen, so garments, worn exclusively in the night when it is dark, do not need <i>ẓiẓit</i>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 33b-34a" href="/Kiddushin.33b-34a">Babli (<i>Qiddushin</i> 33b–34a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 43a" href="/Menachot.43a"><i>Menaḥot</i> 43a</a>) mentions neither <i>ẓiẓit</i> nor the opinion of Rebbi Simeon in its quotes from the Tosephta; it assumes the position of Rebbi Simeon to be generally accepted.</i>. Rebbi Simeon exempts women from <i>ẓiẓit</i> because it is a positive commandment activated by time.” Because a nightgown is exempt from <i>ẓiẓit</i>. Rebbi Lia said: The reason of the rebbbis is that, if a garment is designated both for daytime and for night, it needs <i>ẓiẓit</i>.
It is stated: “For every obligation that a man is free of, he may help the congregation to fulfill their obligation, except for Grace.” But have we not stated: “Anybody who is not obligated may not help the congregation to fulfill their obligation”? If he were obligated, he could help them to fulfill even if he himself already fulfilled it!<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">“To be free” does not mean the same as “not being obligated” but rather “having already acquitted himself of the obligation.” The first statement means, e. g., that someone who already has heard the <i>shofar</i> on Rosh Hashanah nevertheless may blow the <i>shofar</i> and recite the appropriate benediction for somebody who did not hear the blowing. The only exception mentioned is that of saying Grace. The second statement means, e. g., that a woman, not being obligated to hear the <i>shofar</i>, may not blow the <i>shofar</i> for a man who is obligated. Since everybody is obligated to say Grace after a meal, there seems to be no reason why Grace should be exempted in the first statement.</i> Rebbi Lia said: There is a difference about Grace since it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:10" href="/Deuteronomy.8.10"><i>Deut.</i> 8:10</a>): “You will eat and be satiated, then you must praise the Eternal, your God;” he who ate must give praise. Rebbi Yose and Rebbi Judah ben Pazi were sitting together and saying: It would be reasonable<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">The exemption mentioned for Grace should be extended to the recital of <i>Shema‘</i> and prayer. The argument for <i>Shema‘</i> rests on the expression (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:7" href="/Deuteronomy.6.7"><i>Deut.</i> 6:7</a>) ושננתם ל֩בניך “you should repeat it to your sons”; it implies a personal action and cannot be performed by listening to a reader. The discussion of prayer presupposes the Galilean practice that the reader recite the <i>Amidah</i> aloud, without silent prayer, and it is stated that everyone is required to say the prayer with the reader, not just to respond with “Amen”. In Babylonia the question did not arise since silent prayer was always required before the repetition by the reader.</i> for reciting the <i>Shema‘</i> that every single person should repeat it aloud. It would be reasonable for prayer that every single person should pray for mercy by himself.
What<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that this paragraph is put here because 1) <i>sukkah</i> and <i>lulab</i> were mentioned as examples of temporary obligations and 2) it was the subject of a discussion between Rebbi Yose (the Amora) and one of his colleagues.</i> is the difference between <i>sukkah</i> and <i>lulab? Sukkah</i> does not need a benediction after the first night of the holiday, <i>lulab</i> needs a benediction all seven days<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">This is a shortened version of a <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:9" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.9">Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 6:9</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:10" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.10">10</a>) discussed more in detail later (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:3:8-9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.3.8-9">Halakhah 9:4</a>, fol. 14a) and in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 46a" href="/Sukkah.46a">Babli <i>Sukkah</i> 46a</a>, where Rebbi states that one makes a benediction all seven days of Sukkoth and that Babylonian practice follows Rebbi. Galilean practice followed the rule that the benediction “Who commanded us to dwell in the <i>sukkah</i>” was recited only once during the entire holiday. About <i>lulab</i>, the Babli notes correctly that in the absence of a Temple, taking the <i>lulab</i> after the first day is a rabbinic ordinance, not a Torah commandment; hence, the obligation of the second day cannot be covered by the benediction of the first. It may be that this distinction caused Rebbi Yose to be dissatisfied with the first explanation.</i>. Rebbi Yose and Rebbi Aḥa were sitting and saying, what is the difference between <i>sukkah</i> and <i>lulab? Sukkah</i> applies both nights and days, <i>lulab</i> applies only during daytime<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">While <i>sukkah</i> is one continuous obligation, <i>lulab</i> represents seven distinct periods of obligation of which each one merits a new benediction.</i>. Rebbi Jacob the Southerner objected: But the study of Torah applies by night as by day? How is this? <i>Sukkah</i> will end; the study of Torah, it is impossible that it should ever end<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">It is unreasonable to say that a boy on becoming Bar Miẓwah should recite the benediction for the Torah once and not repeat it for his entire lifetime. <i>Sukkah</i> at least gets a new benediction every year.</i>.
It is stated<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:17" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.17">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:17</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 20b" href="/Berakhot.20b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 20b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 38a" href="/Sukkah.38a"><i>Sukkah</i> 38a</a>. The entire piece is found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 3:9:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.3.9.2"><i>Sukkah</i> 3:11</a>, <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 3:9.</i>: In truth, they said a woman may say Grace for her husband<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">He who does not know how to say Grace may listen to a companion recite Grace aloud. The Yerushalmi has no problem with women or slaves but for the Babli the question remains whether women may in fact recite Grace for males who have an obligation from the Torah, i. e., who actually ate their fill.</i>, a slave for his master, and a minor for his father. Did not Rebbi Aḥa say in the name of Rebbi Yose bar Nahoraï: All they said about a minor is for the latter’s education<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The minor must be educated; there is an obligation on the father to teach him all religious obligations but the minor himself is not obligated and, by the previously mentioned principle, cannot perform any religious duty for others.</i>? Explain it that he recites after him<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">The adult repeats word by word what the minor says, so the adult in fact has recited all benedictions.</i>, as we stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">In some Tosephta collection no longer extant.</i>: “He for whom a slave, a woman, or a minor were reading it, repeats after them what they are saying, and may it be a curse for him. In truth, they said there should be a curse on the man of twenty years who needs the child of ten.”

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He who had <i>qeri</i><sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">An emission of semen.</i> thinks but does not recite any benediction before or after<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">The recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>.</i>; on his food he recites the benedictions afterwards<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Grace, which is an obligation from the Torah. He does not recite the rabbinic benedictions before the meal.</i> but not before. Rebbi Yehudah says, he recites benedictions before and after.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> What does he think of? The benedictions<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">But the <i>Shema‘</i>, which is an obligation from the Torah, he recites normally. But Rashi explains “he thinks the <i>Shema</i>‘ ”, and this also seems to be the opinion of Maimonides in his decision based on the Babli.</i>.
The Mishnah deals with a place where there is no water<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">It will be confirmed in the next <i>Halakhah</i> that even Rebbi Yehudah agrees that after an emission one may not recite unless he washed first. So this statement is agreed to by everybody in the Yerushalmi.</i> and follows Rebbi Meïr, as it is stated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:13" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.13">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 2:13</a>): “He who had <i>qeri</i> but no water to immerse himself reads the <i>Shema‘</i> but not so that he himself can hear it, but he does not recite any benediction before or after; these are the words of Rebbi Meïr. But the Sages say, he reads so that he himself can hear it and recites benedictions before and after.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22a" href="/Berakhot.22a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 22a</a>) quotes a parallel but different <i>baraita</i> in which the position of “the Sages” is in the name of R. Yehudah.</i>”
It is stated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:12" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.12">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 2:12</a>): “A sick person who had <i>qeri</i> on whom fell nine <i>qab</i><sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">One <i>qab</i> equals 4 <i>log</i>, one log is .533 liter or .164 gallons, so that a <i>qab</i> equals approximately .563 gallons, 9 <i>qab</i> about 5.07 U. S. gallons. One <i>seäh</i> is 6 <i>qab</i> or about 3.38 gallons, so 40 <i>seäh</i> equal about 135.2 gallons or 512 liter. In Roman measures, the <i>log</i> corresponds to the <i>sextarius</i>, and the <i>seäh</i> to the <i>urna</i>. That makes 40 <i>seah</i> equal to a Roman <i>culleus</i>.</i> of water (and a pure one on whose head and body fell three <i>log</i> of drawn water)<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">The parenthesis is not in the Tosephta or in the quote in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22b" href="/Berakhot.22b">Babli 22b</a>, and does not belong here. The impurity of the man with emission is Biblical (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:16" href="/Leviticus.15.16"><i>Lev.</i> 15:16</a>) but the prohibition of studying Torah and speaking sacred words is from the institutions of Ezra, i. e., it is pre-rabbinic. On the other hand, the impurity of a person washing himself with drawn water after an immersion in a <i>miqweh</i> belongs to the “18 ordinances” passed by the adherents of the house of Shammai before the Jewish revolt against the Romans and is purely rabbinical. It was passed because most <i>miqwaöt</i> were not built but were water holes in natural caves that were naturally muddy and people had the tendency to wash off the mud after they emerged from the <i>miqweh</i>. The rabbis of the time were afraid that in time washing would supersede immersion as (illegal) means of purification, so they decreed that washing after immersion resurrects some mild form of ritual impurity.</i> is clean for himself but he cannot lead the public in their obligations until he immersed himself in 40 <i>seah</i>. Rebbi Yehudah says, 40 <i>seah</i> in all cases<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">This translation is not guaranteed. The Babli (<i>loc</i>. <i>cit</i>.) takes the statement of Rebbi Yehudah to mean that he requires the stated amount of water but not that it should be in a <i>miqweh</i> that satisfies all rules. However, as Levi Ginzberg points out, that requires the expression בכל מקום which is found in manuscripts of the Babli; it represents the majority opinion in the Babli. The idiomatic translation of מכל מקום is “in every case”, including the sick person. R. Yehudah then is more restrictive than the other sages if water is available, and this may be the meaning of the Yerushalmi. If the parenthesis is genuinely part of this <i>baraita</i>, then the latter interpretation is the only possible one since an impurity imposed to enforce immersion in a genuine <i>miqweh</i> can be removed only by such an immersion.</i>.”
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: <i>Qeri</i> is only from sexual intercourse. Rav Huna said, even if he saw himself enjoying in his dream. They wanted to say, only from a woman. Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Yose, both of them say, even from something else. There (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yoma 8:1:1-13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yoma.8.1.1-13">Mishnah <i>Yoma</i> 8:1</a>) we have stated: Eating, drinking, washing, anointing, wearing shoes, and sexual intercourse are forbidden on <i>Yom Kippur</i>. And it was stated in that respect: Men with <i>qeri</i> immerse themselves secretly in their normal way on <i>Yom Kippur</i><sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yoma (Lieberman) 4:5" href="/Tosefta_Yoma_(Lieberman).4.5">Tosephta <i>Kippurim</i> 4:5</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 88a" href="/Yoma.88a">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 88a</a> the reading is: Men with <i>qeri</i> immerse themselves normally on <i>Yom Kippur;</i> one speaks of a full immersion and “in secret” is not mentioned. The Tosephta seems to be a Babylonian formulation. (The entire paragraph is also found in Yerushalmi <i>Yoma</i> 8:1).</i>. Does this not contradict Rebbi Joshua ben Levi since Rebbi Joshua ben Levi says, <i>qeri</i> is only from sexual intercourse? Explain it if he had intercourse on the previous day and forgot and did not immerse himself. But it is stated: It happened that Rebbi Yose ben Ḥalaphta was seen immersing himself secretly on <i>Yom Kippur</i>. Can you say about that holy body that he forgot<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, the interpretation of Rav Huna is incorrect and that of Rebbis Yose (the Amora) and Jonah is correct.</i>?
Rebbi Jacob bar Abun said: This immersion has only been enacted so that Jews should not be like chickens, that one would have sex: mount, descend, and eat<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">This means that sexual relations should be stripped of their animal nature as much as possible; the sanctification of marital duties applies to all Jews. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22a" href="/Berakhot.22a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 22a</a>, in the name of R. Yose bar Abun) reads: “so that scholars should not be found near their wives like roosters.” One may conclude that there are two main differences between Galilean and Babylonian practice: In the Yerushalmi, the duty of immersion applies uniformly to everybody and requires a kosher <i>miqweh</i>, in the Babli it is necessary only for study and may be done by washing.<br>R. Jacob bar Abun was a Galilean Amora of the third generation, colleague of R. Jeremiah.<br>There is no hint anywhere that one is forbidden to eat after intercourse or before immersion; the expression here is just a graphic expression of the behavior of cocks (commentary of Levi Ginzberg).</i>.
Rebbi Ḥanina passed by the gates of public baths<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Greek δημόσιος, α, ον, adj. “public”, here understood with βαλανεῖα “baths”. The public baths certainly were not open before dawn and Rebbi Ḥanina orders the people there not to waste their time but to study Torah (being from the first Amora generation, he said “to study Mishnah”) since the interpretation given later to <i>qeri</i> only hinders one to pronounce the Divine name (and, hence, to pray) but not to study where the Divine name is seldom mentioned and, if mentioned at all, only by paraphrase. On the other hand, when morning came and the time for morning prayers, he told those that had intercourse to go and immerse themselves before praying.</i> before dawn and said: What are those who have to immerse themselves in the morning doing here? They should go and study Mishnah! In the morning he said: He who has to do it shall go and do it.
What are the rules about thinking<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">About Torah subjects. While this paragraph seems to be somewhat out of place here, it is introduced because of the later discussion of the status of a man with <i>qeri</i> in the study of Torah subjects.</i> in the toilet? Ḥizqiah said it is permitted; Rebbi Yasa said it is forbidden. Rebbi Zeïra said, all difficult arguments that I had became clear to me there. Rebbi Eleazar bar Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">The son of Rebbi Simeon bar Yoḥai. His difficult argument is detailed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 102b" href="/Zevachim.102b">Babli <i>Zebaḥim</i> 102b</a>. In Babylonia (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 24b" href="/Berakhot.24b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 24b</a>) it was accepted by everybody that thinking about Torah subjects in a toilet is forbidden except if the person cannot help doing it. In Galilee the practical rule was to allow it.</i> said, the entire difficult subject of <i>ṭĕbūl yōm</i> became clear to me there.
Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Tanḥum ben Rebbi Ḥiyya: In the days of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi they wanted to abolish this immersion because of the Galilean women who became sterile<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Since in Galilee the immersion was required for everybody, not only for Torah study as in Babylonia, it also applied to women. In winter in upper Galilee, water sometimes freezes and all <i>miqwaöt</i> were cold-water <i>miqwaöt</i>; in a parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22a" href="/Berakhot.22a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 22a</a>, Rav Huna notes that instead of a <i>miqweh</i> one could use a hot bath in Babylonia.</i> because of the cold. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi told them: Do you want to uproot something that fences Israel off from sin? What means: Fences Israel off from sin? It happened that a watchman of vinyards wanted to have an affair with a married woman. By the time they were preparing a place where they could immerse themselves, passers-by came by and the sin was not committed<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">A parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22a" href="/Berakhot.22a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 22a</a> is explicitly designated as a <i>baraita</i>, dating from Mishnaic times, and applying the need for immersion only to the man. [Levi Ginzberg conjectures that the watchman was a bachelor; hence, he could not use the public <i>miqweh</i> (except on holiday eve) without drawing public attention to his unmarried sexual activities. However, it is stated explicitly at the end of this <i>halakhah</i> that a <i>miqweh</i> was not used for this immersion.]</i>. It happened that someone wanted to have an affair with Rebbi’s slave girl. She said to him: If my mistress does not immerse herself, I do not immerse myself<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning that as an unmarried woman she does not frequent the <i>miqweh</i> and, therefore, cannot have sex with any man. The slave girl was quite famous for speaking better classical Hebrew than the rabbis.</i>. He said to her: Are you not like an animal<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">The argument here is not perfectly clear. There is a verse in Ezechiel 23:20, speaking about the heathen, "for the flesh of donkeys is their flesh and the semen of horses is their semen" (where "flesh" as human limb here and elsewhere means the penis, the only boneless limb), but that speaks only about males and, in any case, the slave in a Jewish household is a semi-Jew, becoming a full Jew on manumission without any formality of conversion. Hence, no verse applying to heathen is appropriate here. The real reason seems to be the command given to Adam that "a man shall leave his father and his mother and stick to his wife" (Gen. 2:24); since a slave is not legally able to contract a marriage, he is missing the essential human quality of having to marry. That makes questionable humans out of adults who are bachelors by choice. [The sex life of slaves is not discussed in the Yerushalmi. In the Babli (Niddah 47a) it is stated that slaves may have sex with anybody except a Jew (and a married Gentile woman).]</i>? She said to him: Did you not hear that one who has relations with an animal will be stoned, as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:18" href="/Exodus.22.18">Ex. 22:18</a>): “Anyone lying with an animal shall certainly be executed.”
Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba the Babylonian quotes here the Babylonian tradition that this immersion is appropriate only for Torah scholars, in contrast to the Galilean practice shown be the preceding and the following examples that the unlearned were the most ardent practitioners of the ritual.</i> said: They ordered this immersion essentially only for study. For if you tell him that he is permitted, he is going to say: “I shall go, satisfy my needs, and then come and study what is needed,” but since you say that it is forbidden, he will come and study all he needs<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Not having sex in those nights where study starts before dawn, i. e., all week except Friday night.</i>. There<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Any תמן "there" in the Yerushalmi means Babylonia. The ruling is not mentioned in the Babli explicitly but there is a parallel to the statement attributed to Rebbi Eleazar, and a statement by the 10th century Rav Hai Gaon (Ozar Hageonim Berakhot p. 56), that in his time scholars in Babylonia did not pray until they had cleansed themselves by washing.</i> they said it is even forbidden to hear words of Torah.
Rebbi Judah bar Titus<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora from Caesarea Philippi, of the fourth generation.</i>, Rebbi Aḥa in the name Rebbi Eliezer: as at the start (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 19:11" href="/Exodus.19.11"><i>Ex.</i> 19:11</a>) “They shall be prepared on the third day, do not approach a woman<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">The impurity of <i>qeri</i> for the study of Torah is derived from the theophany at Sinai where the Israelites purified themselves for three days from any impurity caused by marital relations. This gives support to the opinion stated earlier by R. Joshua ben Levi that the impurity of <i>qeri</i> is only caused by sexual intercourse. The Talmud notes (Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 86a, Yerushalmi <i>Šabbat</i> 9:3, fol. 11c) that a separation of three days was needed only for the women since a woman may lose live sperm from her body up to three days after intercourse. For men a simple immersion in water the next day would be enough. This proves that women were included by Divine decree among the original recipients and students of the Torah; the inclusion of women in the Tosephta quoted in the next paragraph is intentional.</i>.”
It is stated<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:12" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.12">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 2:12</a>. In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22a" href="/Berakhot.22a">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 22a</a>, only males are in the list. The <i>baraita</i> in the Babli is a Babylonian formulation of material ascribed to the students of Rebbi Aqiba.</i>: “Males and females with discharges<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">From their genitals, the male <i>zab</i> suffering from gonorrhea and similar diseases, the female bleeding other than menstruating, see <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15" href="/Leviticus.15"><i>Lev.</i> Chapter 15</a>.</i>, menstruating women, and women having given birth<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Whose basic impurity is one week after having a son, two weeks after having a daughter; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 12:1-8" href="/Leviticus.12.1-8"><i>Lev.</i> 12:1–8</a>.</i> read in the Torah and study <i>midrash</i><sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">This is the derivation of practical rules from the Biblical text, as in the <i>Midrĕshē Hălākhāh</i> to the last four books of the Pentateuch.</i>, practical rules, and homiletics; the person with <i>qeri</i> is forbidden all these.” Rebbi Abba bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">The argument here is not perfectly clear. There is a verse in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 23:20" href="/Ezekiel.23.20">Ezechiel 23:20</a>, speaking about the heathen, “for the flesh of donkeys is their flesh and the semen of horses is their semen” (where “flesh” as human limb here and elsewhere means the penis, the only boneless limb), but that speaks only about males and, in any case, the slave in a Jewish household is a semi-Jew, becoming a full Jew on manumission without any formality of conversion. Hence, no verse applying to heathen is appropriate here. The real reason seems to be the command given to Adam that “a man shall leave his father and his mother and stick to his wife” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 2:24" href="/Genesis.2.24"><i>Gen.</i> 2:24</a>); since a slave is not legally able to contract a marriage, he is missing the essential human quality of having to marry. That makes questionable humans out of adults who are bachelors by choice. [The sex life of slaves is not discussed in the Yerushalmi. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 47a" href="/Niddah.47a">Babli (<i>Niddah</i> 47a</a>) it is stated that slaves may have sex with anybody except a Jew (and a married Gentile woman).]</i>: He may study practical rules<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Which need only memorization, not independent thinking, in contrast to the construction of sermons which are supposed to be original with the preacher. In this respect, the rule of Rab would coincide with that given in the name of Rebbi Yose (the Tanna) in the next sentence.</i> but not homiletics. It is stated in the name of Rebbi Yose: He may repeat known rules but he may not expound<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Going into the details and general rules behind the simple casuistic statements of the Mishnah; that requires individual mental effort.</i> the Mishnah. Some want to say, only that he may not mention the Divine Name<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">This is a problem only in prayer, not in study where the Name is never pronounced even in quotes from the Bible.</i>. Rebbi Zeïra asked before Rebbi Yasa: Did my teacher not prepare his lecture together with Rebbi Abun in the night? He said, yes. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba prepared his lecture together with his son Rebbi Neḥemiah in the night. The next morning he said, anybody who has to do should go and do it<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Note that all Amoraïm involved here are originally Babylonians, but this may be a coincidence. The point seems to be that in the night, when immersion is dangerous, the position of a <i>baäl qeri</i> is the same as one who is at a place with no water. While the sources do not discuss the position of Torah study at a place without water, it seems from here and the story about Rebbi Yose in the paragraph following the next that in the night one never goes for the immersion required and that, therefore, all involved here may study Torah during the night and immerse themselves in the morning before prayers.</i>.
It happened that someone was reading the Torah in Nsebin<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Nisibis, a town in northern Mesopotamia, today on the border between Syria and Turkey, known as seat of the family Ben Bathyra from at least the start of the Common Era. The authority quoted here is R. Yehuda ben Bathyra II, a student of R. Aqiba. The reader was reading the Torah in the synagogue. In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22a" href="/Berakhot.22a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 22a</a>), the reason is given that God’s word is compared to fire and fire cannot become impure.</i>; when he came to the Divine Name he started to stutter. Rebbi Yehudah ben Bathyra told him: Open your mouth and let your words shine because words of the .Torah cannot receive impurity. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said: There they act following Rebbi Illaï regarding the first shearing<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">It has to be given to the Cohen, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:4" href="/Deuteronomy.18.4"><i>Deut.</i> 18:4</a>. While it is not spelled out in the Pentateuch that this is an obligation only on sheep owners in Israel, “there” in Babylonia one did not give first shearings to the Cohen. The entire statement is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22a" href="/Berakhot.22a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 22a</a>) in the formulation “people follow these three”, in the name of Rav Naḥman bar Isaac, a Babylonian contemporary of R. Jacob bar Aḥa.</i>, following Rebbi Josiah<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Tanna of the fourth generation, student of R. Ismael, from the town of Huẓal in Babylonia, a contemporary of R. Yehuda ben Bathyra II. All his traditions are from the school of R. Ismael.</i> regarding <i>kilaim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">The prohibition of planting or sowing several species together. The special rules for <i>kilaim</i> in a vineyard are based on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:9" href="/Deuteronomy.22.9"><i>Deut.</i> 22:9</a>: “Do not sow your vineyard <i>kilaim</i>”. Usually, a vineyard is not sown but planted; R. Josiah therefore restricts the prohibition to the case where even the vines are grown from seeds sown, not planted one by one in separate places.</i> in the vineyard, and following Rebbi Yehudah ben Bathyra regarding people with <i>qeri</i>. Following Rebbi Illaï regarding the first shearing. as we have stated: “Rebbi Illaï said: The first shearing applies only in the Land.” Following Rebbi Josiah regarding <i>kilaim</i> as it is stated: “One is never guilty unless one sowed wheat, barley, and grape kernels falling from the same hand.” Following Rebbi Yehudah ben Bathyra regarding people with <i>qeri</i> as it is stated: “Rebbi Yehudah ben Bathyra says, words of the Torah cannot receive impurity.”
Rebbi Yose bar Ḥalaphta came on a footpath<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>semita</i> (the Rome ms. has איסרטא, <i>strata</i> “a paved [street].”) This story belongs to the discussion of the paragraph before the last and shows that in the minds of the people the original intention of the ordinance requiring washing was inverted, that instead of “fencing off Israel from sin” it became a ritual in the minds of the uneducated with which one could wash off even adultery with a menstruating women, combining a capital crime with one punishable by extirpation. Hence, the story supports Rebbi Yehudah ben Bathyra who negates the importance of the ritual even for public reading of the Torah, not only for Torah study.</i> in the night and a donkey driver was walking after him along a ditch. He said to him: This man must wash. He said to him: Do not imperil yourself. He said to him: This man must wash because of a menstruating, married woman. Even so he said to him: Do not imperil yourself. Since he did not listen to him he said: May this man descend and not ascend. And that happened to him.
Rebbi Yose ben Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">One of the last Galilean Amoraïm. It is not known whether he is identical with the poet of the same name, the first of the synagogal poets known by name; neither is it clear whether his name indicates that he was a posthumous child (cf. E. and H. Guggenheimer, <i>Etymologisches Lexikon der jüdischen Familiennamen</i>, Saur, München 1996, p. xviii).</i> came on a ship. He saw one who was tying a rope around himself in order to descend<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">From the ship to the ocean in order to wash. This story makes clear that the washing after sexual intercourse was general practice in Israel down to the time of edition of the Jerusalem Talmud. Its time is six generations after the preceding story. It negates the negative moral implications of the preceding story but retains its emphasis on avoiding life-threatening situations.</i> and wash. He said to him: Do not endanger your life. He said to him: This one needs to eat. He said to him: eat! This man needs to drink. He said to him: drink! When they came to the harbor<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Greek λιμήν.</i>, he said to him: There<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">On the high seas. The problem was not that one may not eat before washing but that one is not allowed to pronounce the Divine Name and, therefore, is unable to utter the benedictions before eating.</i> I permitted it only because of danger to your life but here this man may not taste anything before he washes.
Rebbi Yannai<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yannai, from the first generation of Amoraïm, makes it clear that essentially nobody uses the <i>miqweh</i> for the immersion of <i>qeri</i>; either one uses a regular bath or a running stream or the sea (whose total volume is certainly greater than 40 <i>sĕa</i>.) The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22a" href="/Berakhot.22a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 22a</a>) has only the first part of the statement and no hint of using running water. Running water is required for the cleansing of the male with gonorrhea (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:13" href="/Leviticus.15.13"><i>Lev.</i> 15:13</a>).</i> said: I heard that some take it lightly and some are stringent and every one who is stringent lives a long, good life. Some take it lightly by washing in drawn water; some are stringent to immerse themselves in running water.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If someone was standing and praying<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">The formal <i>Amidah</i>.</i> when he remembered that he had <i>qeri</i>, he should not stop but shorten his prayer. If he descended to immerse himself, if he can ascend, get dressed, and recite<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Shema‘.</i> The leniency mentioned here is not only if otherwise the time for <i>Shema‘</i> would pass but even for the usage of the very religious (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:2:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.2.5">Chapter 1, Note 155</a>) even though it is totally impossible to pray the <i>Amidah</i> while immersed in the water and, therefore, one cannot completely follow the practice of the very religious.</i> by the time of sunrise he should ascend, get dressed, and recite; otherwise, he should cover himself with water and recite. He should cover himself neither with stinking water nor with steeping water unless he diluted them with water. How much does one have to remove oneself from these and excrement? Four cubits.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> The Mishnah refers to someone in public, but if he is alone he interrupts following Rebbi Meïr<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.4.1">Mishnah 4</a> stated that he may not pronounce any benediction and the <i>Amidah</i> is composed of benedictions, it is clear that <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.4.1">Mishnah 4</a> forbids formal praying. Both <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.4.1">Mishnah 4</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.5.1">Mishnah 5</a> are anonymous; an anonymous Mishnah is always supposed to represent the ideas of Rebbi Meïr since the latter’s collection was the basis of Rebbi’s edition of the Mishnah. To avoid two contradicting Mishnayot, it is spelled out here that the public embarrassment that would be caused by the rule of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.4.1">Mishnah 4</a> has to be avoided, see <i>Halakhah</i> 1, note 119. The opinion of R. Yehudah is given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>.</i>. But following Rebbi Yehudah he does not interrupt even when alone, on condition that he have no water to immerse himself. But if he has water to immerse himself even Rebbi Yehudah agrees that he must interrupt.
About a sick person who had intercourse, Rebbi Ammi said: If he caused it by himself, let him immerse himself and die<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, that is an exaggeration since it was shown earlier that even an adulterer should not expose himself to danger because of this immersion; it means simply: let him be inconvenienced.</i>; if it was forced upon him one does not bother him<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">It is difficult to know what “forced intercourse” means. Any possible interpretation depends on the problem discussed in the preceding Halakhah, whether <i>qeri</i> comes only from intercourse or also from involuntary emissions. If the second case is accepted, “forced” does not speak of intercourse but only of involuntary emissions. In the second case, one cannot say that one speaks of a sick man fulfilling his marital duties even if it hurts him since in that case he is free from these duties. Even if he was seduced by his wife, there is really no intercourse against one’s will. Hence, one has to conclude that all authorities here decide that involuntary emissions require immersion in water.</i>. Rebbi Ḥaggai in the name of Rebbi Abba bar Zavda: One does not bother him in any case. A sick person<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">This second paragraph clearly is independent of the previous statements since it contradicts them. It represents the consensus of the editors of the Yerushalmi. In the parallel of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22b" href="/Berakhot.22b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 22b</a>), Rava reports that any מרגיל needs 40 <i>seah</i>. Since the immersion was not practiced in Babylonia, this statement is purely historical or theoretical; the difference between Babylonia and Israel was in the essence of this immersion and not in little details.</i> who does it habitually<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 22a" href="/Berakhot.22a">Babli (22a</a>), Rashi explains מרגיל by: “he draws <i>qeri</i> upon himself by having intercourse.” A strictly grammatical explanation would be: “he causes it to be usual”. However, such a translation would require three categories: 1) one who runs after sex, 2) a normal person, 3) a sick person. Since only two categories are mentioned where one would expect three, Rashi’s explanation is the only consistent one even if it does not explain the particular verb form.</i> needs nine <i>qab</i>, a healthy person who does it habitually needs 40 <i>sĕah</i>. A sick person forced, one does not bother him. A healthy person forced needs nine <i>qab</i>.
Rebbi Zevadiah, the son of Rebbi Jacob bar Zavdi, in the name of Rebbi Jonah: In a city whose well is far away, he may recite the <i>Shema‘</i>, then descends and immerses himself, ascends and prays. If he is blind<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">This translation is not given by any commentator. Usually, מסוים means “definite, outstanding”, from the verbal root <i>swm</i>, but this makes no sense here. In other Talmudic passages “an outstanding man” means a particularly pious one and it is unimaginable that a pious man should claim for himself exemption from some religious duty.
