Hence, the derivation from the root <i>sm’</i> “to blind”, in the passive “to be blinded”, makes much more sense.</i> they made him like a far-away well.
<b>New Section.</b> “Otherwise, he should cover himself with water and recite.”<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah.</i> The Mishnah deals with opaque water, but in clear water it is forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Since prayer is forbidden if the genitals are uncovered. (A different tradition is given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25b" href="/Berakhot.25b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 25b</a>).</i>. And if he is able to make it opaque by stirring with his feet he may make it opaque.
It is stated: One removes himself<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">In order to pray or to recite <i>Shema‘</i>.</i> from human excrement four cubits and from dog’s excrement four cubits, the latter when it is given on skins<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Antique technology of making leather from skins required that the skins were steeped in water containing dog’s excrement for a lengthy period of time. The steeping water had a horrible smell. This <i>baraita</i> explains that “steeping water” in the Mishnah refers to tanner’s steeping water and not to launderer’s steeping water that simply does not smell good.<br>This statement is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:16" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.16">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 2:16</a>; the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25a" href="/Berakhot.25a">Babli (25a</a>) has a different <i>baraita</i> that refers to the paragraph after the next one here.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Zeïra: One must remove hinself four cubits from a stinking carcass. Rebbi Avina said: Does not the Mishnah say all this : “How much does one have to remove himself from these and excrement? Four cubits.” Rebbi Ammi in the name of Rebbi Shammai<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">The tradition of names is impossible since Rebbi Shammai was an Amora of the fifth and last generation in Galilee; he cannot be the author of a tradition of a third generation Amora. The paragraph is quoted by R. Asher ben Yeḥiël (<i>Rosh Berakhot</i>, Chap. 3, #44) in the name of Rebbi Simlaï (without mention of Rebbi Ammi), a preacher and Amora of the first generation.</i>: Explain it by steeping water of launderers. Rebbi Mani<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Mani, Mana, the first. Launderers’ steeping water does not smell so badly that it would need a special entry in the Mishnah. He is a contemporary of Rebbi Simlaï, not Rebbi Ammi.</i> said to him: About steeping waters of launderers, we have stated: “neither with stinking water nor with steeping water.”
It is stated: One removes himself four cubits from excrement and urine of a toddler who can eat grain the volume of an olive<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">In one meal, which in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 42b" href="/Sukkah.42b">Babli (<i>Sukkah</i> 42b</a>) is defined as the time a grown-up can eat half a stuffed pitta. The Yerushalmi does not give a time limit.</i>, but if he cannot yet eat grain the volume of an olive one does not need to remove himself four cubits either from his excrement or from his urine. They asked before Rebbi Abbahu: Why does one separate himself from his excrement and urine? He said to them, because his thoughts are evil. They said to him: But is not he too young? He said to them, is it not written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 8:21" href="/Genesis.8.21"><i>Gen.</i> 8:21</a>): “For the inclination of man’s heart is evil from his youth?” Rebbi Yudan said, it is written “from his awakening<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">The word נעוּריו, even though it has a long vowel <i>ū</i>, is written defective in the Bible; hence, it can be vocalized נִעֲרָיו “his awakenings”, not only puberty, the sexual awakening usually referred to by the root נער but also the first awakening of the baby during birth. According to Rebbi Abbahu, the awakening comes only when the baby is weaned.</i>”, from the moment that the awakes and enters the world.
Rebbi Yose bar Ḥanina said: One removes himself four cubits from animal dung. Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac said, if it is soft, but only from donkeys. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said, if it<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">The donkey. The statements of Rebbis Samuel bar Rav Isaac and Ḥiyya bar Abba restrict the general statement of Rebbi Yose bar Ḥanina to one specific case.</i> arrived from a trip. Levi said, one removes himself four cubits from the excrement of a pig. And it was stated: One removes himself four cubits from the excrement of a pig<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25a" href="/Berakhot.25a">Babli (25a</a>), the excrement of a pig is deemed unacceptable only if it is used in tanning. It seems that in Israel no pig excrement was used in tanning.</i>, four cubits from the excrement of a marten<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">This statement is taken by Medieval commentators to apply also to excrement of cats.</i>, four cubits from the excrement of chickens. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Rav Huna: Only from red<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Some commentators prefer to understand “Edomite”, but the meaning “red” is preferable since red chickens are mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 14b" href="/Avodah_Zarah.14b">Babli <i>Avodah zarah</i> 14b</a> as a separate kind. All these are singled out for their obnoxious smell.</i> ones.
It is stated: One removes himself four cubits from a bad smell<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear from the following that one talks of a source of bad smell which can be identified and seen. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25a" href="/Berakhot.25a">Babli (25a</a>) this is called ריח רע שיש לו עיקר “a bad smell that has a material source.” The opinion of the Yerushalmi corresponds in the Babli to the minority opinion of Rav Ḥisda.</i>. Rebbi Ammi said, four cubits from the end of the bad smell. That means behind his back, but in front of him until he can no longer see it. Like that of Rebbi Lia and his colleagues who were sitting in front of a hostelry<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πανδοκεῖον (also πανδοκίον) “inn”. It is difficult to see what is so bad about a hostelry. Maybe they were sitting close to the outhouse.</i> in the night. They said, may one say words of Torah? He said to them: If it were daytime, we would see what is before us. But<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">The text is elliptic, but we do not know what is missing. Generally, ברם means either “on the other hand” or “in addition”.</i> like that it is forbidden.
It is stated: One must remove himself four cubits from a chamberpot, be it used for excrement or for urine<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Since in the preceding paragraph one dealt with visible excrement, it follows that in this entire paragraph we are dealing with a chamberpot used at night which is empty at present but still smells from its prior use. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:16" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.16">Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 2:16</a>) is quite explicit: “A chamberpot <i>with him in the house</i>, he has to remove himself four cubits.” The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25a" href="/Berakhot.25a">Babli (25a</a>) deals separately with full and empty chamberpots.</i>. If it is before the bed, if he put some water in the pot he may recite<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Shema‘</i>.</i>, otherwise he may not recite. Rebbi Zakkai<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Zakkai the First, Tanna of the fifth generation, contemporary of Rebbi.</i> said, if he put a <i>quartarius</i><sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">A quarter of a <i>log</i> of .533 liter or about 4.5 fl. oz. U.S.</i> of water in, he may recite; otherwise, he may not recite. How many corresponding <i>quartarii</i>? One <i>quartarius</i>, corresponding to one <i>quartarius</i><sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">As much water as was the volume of urine or excrement in the last use.</i>, be the vessel small or large. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, if it stands behind the bed he may recite, before the bed he may not recite. Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar said, even in a dining hall<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>triclinium</i>, from Greek τρικλίνιον “dining room”, a hall of three dining couches arranged in U-shape.</i> large ten-by-ten<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Probably 10 by 10 cubits, which gives a diagonal distance of 14 cubits, taken as an example. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25a" href="/Berakhot.25a">Babli (25a</a>) speaks of a “dining hall of 100 cubits” where “cubits” stands for “square cubits”. [The use of “cubit” for “square cubit” is frequent in Yerushalmi <i>Kilaim</i>.]</i> he may not recite until he covers it up or until he puts it under the couch. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: Rebbi Ḥanina Tortayya<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Rebbi Yoḥanan; his birthplace, Torta, has not been identified. His decision is also quoted in the Babli as decision of the earlier generations, later overruled by Rava (bar Joseph bar Ḥama), the leader of the fifth generation of Amoraïm in Babylonia.</i> ruled following Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar.
Rebbi Benjamin ben Yephet<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Rebbi Yoḥanan. Rebbi Zeïra is on record (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 38b" href="/Berakhot.38b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 38b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 2:5:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.2.5.2-4">Yerushalmi <i>Pesaḥim</i> 2:5</a>) that R. Benjamin is not trustworthy as witness to the opinions of Rebbi Yoḥanan. His statement is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25b" href="/Berakhot.25b">Babli (25b</a>) as original Babylonian tradition.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: A minute amount of excrement can be eliminated by spit. Rebbi Zeïra and Rebbi Jacob bar Zavdi were sitting; they saw some excrement. Rebbi Jacob bar Zavdi got up and spat on it. Rebbi Zeïra said to him: From the sea to the pan<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Greek τήγανον. Rashi (Babli <i>Qiddushin</i> 44a) and <i>‘Arukh</i> (1 טגן) explain this expression to mean: “immediately”, like a fish that has to be fried immediately before it spoils. Most commentators explain that R. Zeïra declares the entire rule invalid since spit dries quickly and afterwards is useless. The Babli avoids the problem by allowing only thick spit, probably from the bronchiae, which does not evaporate. One may consider the treatment of the Babli as answer to R. Zeïra’s criticism.</i>!
<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">After discussing what may or may not be put under one’s bed, one continues with the case of holy scrolls in one’s room, first under the bed and then in the room.</i> A chest full of scrolls one may put under the head of the bed but one may not put it under the foot end of the bed. Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Ḥuna: But only if the bed is 10 hand-breadths<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>ṭefaḥ</i> (hand-breadth) is one-sixth of a cubit. The basic information one has about length is that the distance one may travel from a town on Sabbath is one <i>mil</i> or 2000 cubits. If the <i>mil</i> is taken to be the traditional 1111m = 3648 feet then a cubit is 1.824 ft and a <i>ṭefaḥ</i> is 3.65 inches. (If the <i>mil</i> is taken to be an unlikely Roman mile of 1473.2m = 4833.33 ft, then a cubit is 2.417 ft and a <i>ṭefaḥ</i> is 4.836 inches.)<br>Another approach is based on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Kelim 17:11" href="/Mishnah_Kelim.17.11">Mishnah <i>Kelim</i> 17:11</a> which reports an opinion that fluid measures are Roman. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 109" href="/Pesachim.109">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 109 a/b</a>) defines 40 <i>seah</i> as three cubic cubits. By the data quoted in note 164, the cubit would be 55.47 cm and the <i>ṭefaḥ</i> 9.25 cm or 3.64 in.<br>Anything more than 10 <i>ṭefaḥ</i> above the ground is considered to be in another domain. This reason also applies to the next paragraph.</i> high, and only if the ropes of the bed do not touch the chest. Rebbi Yasa taught the ruling of Rebbi Ḥuna in the town of Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac.
A person should not have sexual intercourse when there is a Torah scroll with him in the room. Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: it is permitted if it was wrapped in a wrapper or if it was in a window opening that is ten hand-breadths above the ground. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi made a small curtain<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Diminutive of כילה “curtain”. (The parallel statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25b" href="/Berakhot.25b">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 25b</a>, states the dangers of sexual intercourse in the presence of a Torah scroll; its connection with the preceding discussion of praying in presence of a chamberpot can be understood only as a commentary on the Yerushalmi.)</i> for it.
A person should not sit on a low bench<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>subsellium</i> “bench”.</i> on which a Torah scroll was placed. It happened that Rebbi Eliezer sat down on a low bench on which a Torah scroll was placed and he recoiled from it as one recoils before a snake<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Massekhet Soferim</i> 3:13, and <i>Massekhet Sefer Torah</i> 3:10 (where it says “he got up as if bitten by a snake”); also quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 32b" href="/Menachot.32b">Babli <i>Menaḥot</i> 32b</a>. The reason given is the verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 26:6" href="/Leviticus.26.6"><i>Lev.</i> 26:6</a>): “You shall fear My holy things.” This is then qualified that one may not sit on a bench on which there is a Torah scroll, but if the scroll is on a separate table or chair, there is no minimum distance to be kept.</i>. If it was placed on something other, it is permitted. How far? Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Ḥuna: One handbreadth. Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Zeïra: Anything.
A double sack<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Greek δισάκκιον, “saddle bag”, a sack made to be carried by a donkey (or horse) hanging down on both sides of the animal. The rule is inserted here in the sequence of rules dealing with the respect due to holy things. The respect shown here is that the sack may not be put on the animal but must be carried on the person even if the latter is riding.</i> full of scrolls or if there were in it bones of a dead person<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">For reburial in an ossuary in a cave.</i>, one carries it on his back and rides.
<i>Tefillin</i> one may hang on the headboard of the bed but one may not hang them at the foot end of the bed<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">For the same reason as before, to show respect.</i>. Rebbi Samuel<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Since he was a student of R. Abbahu and sometimes student of R. Zeïra, the chain of transmission here are four uninterrupted generations. It seems that only R. Samuel made a formal statement out of an informal tradition; however, in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 24a" href="/Berakhot.24a">Babli (24a</a>) the statement is in the name of R. Ḥanina himself.</i>, Rebbi Abbahu, Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Rebbi did hang his <i>tefillin</i> on the headboard of his bed. Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: But only that he should not do in the way of makers of palm leaf baskets but <i>tefillin</i> on top and the straps on the bottom<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">In the interpretation of J. Levy, basket makers put their wares on a rope from which they are hanging down. <i>Tefillin</i> should never hang down. [While דיקולא are palm-leaf baskets, the Latin ending -<i>arius</i> is suspect. It might be better to derive the word from Latin <i>collare</i>, <i>collarium</i> “neck chain, collar”, with the prefix די meaning either “double” or being the Aramaic relative pronoun (E. G.). <i>Tefillin</i> should not hang as a pendant from its chain.]<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 24a" href="/Berakhot.24a">Babli (24a</a>), this is a rejected opinion. One requires there that the <i>tefillin</i> be put in a pouch, the pouch then may be hung at the head of the bed.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥalaphta ben Shaul<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the first generation, of the collectors of <i>baraitot</i>. In the Babli, he mostly appears as Rebbi Taḥlipha ben Shaul. The section here is a continuation of the discussion of respect due to either places of holiness (the synagogue) or acts of holiness (prayer).</i> stated: It is a bad sign if one lets wind during one’s prayer. That means on one’s bottom, but not on one’s top. This parallels what Rebbi Ḥanina said: I saw Rebbi yawning, belching, putting his hand on his mouth, but not spitting<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 24" href="/Berakhot.24">Babli (24a/b</a>), R. Ḥanina reports that he saw Rebbi spitting; this is permitted in the Babli only for people who were disgusted if they had to spit into their garments.</i>. Rebbi Yoḥanan said, one may even spit so that one’s cup<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., one’s mouth.</i> should be clean; forward is forbidden, behind oneself is permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 24b" href="/Berakhot.24b">Babli (24b</a>) this is reported as an act of Rav Ashi, the first editor of the Babylonian Talmud. Its theoretical justification must be sought here in the Yerushalmi.</i>. To one’s right is forbidden, to one’s left is permitted; that is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 91:7" href="/Psalms.91.7"><i>Ps.</i> 91: 7</a>): “On your left hand side will fall a thousand.<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">As usual, the real argument is from the later part of the verse which is not quoted: “On your left hand side will fall a thousand, but ten thousand on your right hand side.” Hence, the right hand side is ten times as important as the left hand side.</i>” Everybody agrees about one who spits toward the stele<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Greek στήλη. The stele in the synagogue was the pulpit on which the Torah scroll was laid for reading and was a place of particular holiness [Cf. Y. Brand, <i>Iẓṭeli</i> n, Lĕšōnēnū 32 (5728), 276–277]. This passage appears in many corrupt versions in early medieval rabbinic authors (e. g., R. Abraham bar David and the student of Rabbenu Jonah) and has given rise to many phantastic conjectures.</i>, that he is forbidden to do so. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi says, he who spits in the synagogue is like one who spits into his own eye<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">A parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 24b" href="/Berakhot.24b">Babli (24b</a>) states “he is as if he spat out before the king.”</i>. Rebbi Jonah spat and rubbed out. Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Samuel bar Ḥalaphta in the name of Rav Ada bar Aḥava: He who prayed should not spit until he walked four cubits. Rebbi Yose bar Rebbi Abun said, similarly he who spat should not pray until he walked four cubits.
Similarly, he who urinates should not pray until he walks four cubits<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 2:19" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).2.19">Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 2:19</a>), the language is more restrictive: “A person should not urinate at the place where he prays unless he removes himself four cubits. Once he urinated he should not pray unless he removed himself four cubits. If it is dry or absorbed (in the earth) it is permitted.” This text is the basis of the discussion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 27b" href="/Megillah.27b">Babli (<i>Megillah</i> 27b</a>) but not of the Yerushalmi.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said: not only that he walks four cubits but even if he waits corresponding to a walk of four cubits. Rebbi Ammi said, if you say that he is forbidden until he removes himself four cubits, I say that maybe somebody else came and urinated there<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">And there is no place in the world where he could pray. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25a" href="/Berakhot.25a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 25a</a>) explicitly rules out this argument and states that one is forbidden only at a place where certainly somebody urinated and the moisture is still recognizable.</i>.
Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav: Excrement until it is hardened like bone, urine all the time it makes moist<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the earlier statement that one has to remove himself from excrement until he no longer sees it, and from urine four cubits. The question is how long excrement legally is in its state.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25a" href="/Berakhot.25a">Babli (25a</a>), the statement of Samuel/R. Yoḥanan is attributed to Rav by Rav Yehudah and Rebbi Abba’s statement about urine to Samuel/Rebbi Yoḥanan. There is no difference between the Talmudim <i>in praxi</i> for urine but the conclusion, that excrement is forbidden even if it is hard like bone, while supported there in the name of R. Yoḥanan, is finally rejected as a matter of common practice.</i>. Ganiva<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">A colleague of Rav in Babylonia. He was an extreme political opponent of the then Resh Galuta and was executed by the Persian king as a trouble maker (without the intervention of the Resh Galuta.) His statement refers to urine and is quoted as such in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 25a" href="/Berakhot.25a">Babli (25a</a>).</i> said: All the time that its impression is visible. Samuel said: Until its<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Refers to excrement only.</i> surface is hardened. Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Until its surface is hardened. Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav: Excrement is forbidden even if it is hard like bone. Samuel said: Until its surface is hardened. Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Until its surface is hardened<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">The seeming repetition shows that Rebbi Zeïra formulated the entire statement concerning the opinions of Rav, Samuel, and R. Yoḥanan. In the first half, the statements of Rebbi Abba, Samuel, and Rebbi Yoḥanan are three independent statements.</i>. Ḥizqiah said: Rebbi Abba is more restrictive for urine than for excrement? Rebbi Mana said to him: From that of Ganiva<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">“As long as it is recognizable” applies both to excrement and to urine. Since excrement is recognizable even if it is hard as bone (Rome ms.: “hard as wood”), it remains forbidden.</i>; he said to him: Even if it is hard like bone it is forbidden because its matter exists; urine’s matter no longer exists<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">As recognizable entity.</i>

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The person with gonorrhea who had an emission of semen, as well as a menstruating woman who lost semen, and the woman who started menstruating while having intercourse, need immersion, but Rebbi Yehudah frees them<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">It is explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15" href="/Leviticus.15"><i>Lev.</i> 15</a> that the man with gonorrhea makes everything around himself impure and cannot be become pure except by a lengthy procedure. Similarly, the menstruating woman needs at least seven days for her purification. If any of these is polluted by the minor impurity of <i>qeri</i> as explained in the preceding <i>halakhah</i>, any immersion for <i>qeri</i> has no influence on the severe impurity already existing (or the one additional in the case of the woman who notices her period while she is already impure by having intercourse). Rebbi Yehudah notes that since the immersion for <i>qeri</i> has no practical consequences, it is not needed. The other sages seem to think that since the immersion does not need <i>miqweh</i> or flowing water and since it is needed to let the persons pray it is of a completely different character and independent of the other impurities. Since the woman noticing her period during intercourse has to stop it immediately, even before emission of semen, it is clear that her impurity is not the Biblical one described in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:16-18" href="/Leviticus.15.16-18"><i>Lev.</i> 15:16–18</a> but the rabbinic one of <i>qeri</i>.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> So far the person with gonorrhea who had an emission of semen; is it good for anything if the person immerses himself who had an emission and afterwards has an episode of gonorrhea? We hear it from this: “The woman who started menstruating while having intercourse needs immersion, but Rebbi Yehudah frees her.<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">In both cases, the impurity of <i>qeri</i> preceded the severe Biblical impurity and, nevertheless, the disagreement between the majority and Rebbi Yehudah is the same as when the severe impurity precedes <i>qeri</i>. This particular case, which is not in the Mishnah, is treated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 26a" href="/Berakhot.26a">Babli 26a</a> where it is stated explicitly not only that Rebbi Yehudah does not require immersion but that the majority require it.</i>”
What is Rebbi Yehudah’s reason? Is it because what would one profit if he immersed himself<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Since the person remains impure as before.</i> or whether there is a name for light impurity in the presence of severe impurity<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">Does the severe impurity eliminate the minor impurity, or does it simply add another level of impurity?</i>? What is the difference between these possibilities? If he saw <i>qeri</i>, if you say what would one profit if he immersed himself, he would profit<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">He eliminates the rabbinic prohibition against studying Torah and reciting <i>Shema‘</i> without washing.</i>! Hence, the only reason is that there is no name for light impurity in the presence of severe impurity!
That is if the light impurity came at the end. Is it even if the severe impurity came at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Does the severe impurity add to the minor impurity or does it supersede the minor impurity?</i>? We may understand it from this: “The woman who started menstruating while having intercourse needs immersion, but Rebbi Yehudah frees her.” That means, one case is like the other case.

Chapter 4



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Morning prayers are until noon; Rebbi Yehudah says, until four hours<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">One hour being one twelfth of the time difference between sunrise and sundown (according to some interpreters of the Babli, from dawn to dusk).</i>. Afternoon<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">“<i>Minḥah</i>” prayers. This expression refers to the Temple service when the flour offering after the afternoon sacrifice signalled the end of the day. The preferred time fixed for this offering was 2h 30min. before sundown. Hence, “half of <i>Minḥah</i>” is 1h 15min. before sundown. The earliest time for the evening sacrifices (on Passover eve) was 30 minutes after noontime. <i>Musaph</i> prayers were added on days when there were additional public sacrifices between morning and afternoon sacrifices.</i> prayers are until evening, Rebbi Yehudah says until half ofʹ <i>Minḥah</i>. Evening prayers have no fixed time. <i>Musaph</i> prayers have all day.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:13" href="/Deuteronomy.11.13"><i>Deut.</i> 11:13</a>) “To love the Eternal, your God, and to work<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The root עבד means “to work, to serve” and implies some physical exertion. In the religious sense, עבודה without qualifier always means the Temple service, the actual offering of sacrifices and all that is connected with it. (Hence, as noted in reference to Daniel, it cannot take place in Babylonia.) In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 2a" href="/Taanit.2a">Babli (<i>Taänit</i> 2a</a>), prayer is explicitly qualified as “service by the heart”.</i> for Him with all yor heart and all your soul,” does there exist work in the heart? This refers to prayer. And so it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 6:17" href="/Daniel.6.17"><i>Dan.</i> 6:17</a>): “Your God, whom you serve permanently, may rescue you.” Is there any service in Babylonia? This refers to prayer.
One might think that one may pray all three<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">It will be explained later that the three daily prayers were either inherited from the patriarchs or they were fashioned after the Temple service. The verse in Daniel is not discussed in the order it is written, neither is the order of the verse preserved in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 3:6" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).3.6">Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 3:6</a>) or in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 31a" href="/Berakhot.31a">Babli (31a</a>), whose text is close to the Tosephta. The last remarks about moving one’s lips is neither in the Babli nor in the Tosephta.</i> together - it is explained in Daniel (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 6:11" href="/Daniel.6.11"><i>Dan.</i> 6:11</a>): “Three times a day he fell on his knees, etc.” One might think that one may pray in any direction one wants - the verse says “slits were open for him in the direction of Jerusalem.” One might think that he started after he went into captivity - the verse says “as was his wont from before that.” One might think that one may pray all three at any time he wishes - already David did explain (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 55:18" href="/Psalms.55.18"><i>Ps.</i> 55:18</a>): “Morning, evening, and afternoon.” One might think that one may pray aloud - it was explained about Hannah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 1:13" href="/I_Samuel.1.13"><i>1Sam.</i> 1:13</a>): “Hannah was speaking to herself.” One might assume that he might simply think - the verse says “only her lips moved.” How is that? One whispers with one’s lips.
Rebbi Yose bar Ḥanina said: From this verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 1:13" href="/I_Samuel.1.13"><i>1Sam.</i> 1:13</a>) you may learn four things. “Hannah was speaking to her heart,” from here that prayer needs attention. “Only her lips moved,” from here that one must whisper with one’s lips. “Her voice was not heard,” from here that nobody should pray at high voice. “And Eli thought that she was drunk,” from here that a drunk is forbidden to pray.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 31a" href="/Berakhot.31a">Babli (31a</a>) in the name of Rav Hamnuna, a Babylonian contemporary of Rebbi Yose bar Ḥanina.</i>
The word of Ḥanan bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The entire paragraph does not belong here but is taken word by word from Chapter 1, Halakhah 8, at note 265 ff.</i> disagrees since Ḥanan bar Abba said to the colleagues: I shall tell you one of the good things that I saw Rav do and, when I told it before Samuel he got up and kissed me on my mouth. At “praised are You”, he bows down. When he comes to mention <i>Hashem</i>, he straightens up. Samuel said: I shall give the reason (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 35:10" href="/Psalms.35.10"><i>Ps.</i> 35:10</a>): “The Lord straightens the bent ones.” Rebbi Ammi said: It is not reasonable, but (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Malachi 2:5" href="/Malachi.2.5"><i>Mal.</i> 2:5</a>): “Before My Name he is low.” Rebbi Abun said: If it were written “at My Name he is low” then you would be right, but it is written “before My Name he is low”, before he mentions <i>Hashem</i> he is low.
Rebbi Abba bar Zavda prayed aloud<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">He opposes the generalization from Hannah’s prayer to general rule. As a student of Rav, he represents Babylonian practice; the following example of Rebbi Jonah shows that two generations later his opinion was accepted in Galilee.</i>. Rebbi Jonah prayed whispering in the synagogue; he prayed aloud in his house so that the people in his house<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">His wife and children.</i> should learn prayer from him. Rebbi Mana<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Mana II, son of Rebbi Jonah.</i> said: Really, the people in my father’s house learned prayer from him.
From where did they learn the three prayers? Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥmani said<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is found <i>in extenso</i>, the next two pragraphs very shortened, in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 68:11" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.68.11"><i>Midrash Bereshit Rabba</i> 68(11</a>). There, the order of prayers is evening, morning, afternoon, and the afternoon prayer is: “just as You let me see the sun in the East, so may You let me see it in the West.” The form of the Midrash is appropriate for early <i>Minḥah</i> (half an hour after noon), the form of the Talmud is appropriate for the standard <i>Minḥah</i>, close to evening. Neither of the two texts is a corruption of the other.</i>: According to the three times that the day changes for man. In the morning, one must say: I thank you, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that you led me from darkness to light. At <i>Minḥah</i>, one must say: I thank you, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that just as You let me see the sun in the East, so I could see it in the West. In the evening, one must say: May it be Your pleasure, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that just as I was in darkness and You led me into light, so may You lead me from darkness into light.
Rebbi Joshua ben Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 26b" href="/Berakhot.26b">Babli (26b</a>), the opinion of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi is ascribed to R. Yose bar Ḥanina and the opinion of “the rabbis” in the following paragraph to R. Joshua ben Levi. The detailed derivation in both cases is declared to be a <i>baraita</i>, meaning that the two Amoraïm quoted do not claim originality, they simply adopt pre-existing ideas.</i> said: They<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The Men of the Great Assembly who instituted formal prayers and benedictions.</i> learned prayers from the patriarchs. Morning prayer from our father Abraham (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 19:27" href="/Genesis.19.27"><i>Gen.</i> 19:27</a>): “Abraham got up early to the place where he had stood there in the presence of the Eternal.” Standing means praying, as it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 106:30" href="/Psalms.106.30"><i>Ps.</i> 106:30</a>) “Phineas stood and prayed<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Usually translated as “judged”.</i>.” <i>Minḥah</i> prayers from our father Isaac. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 24:63" href="/Genesis.24.63"><i>Gen.</i> 24:63</a>) “Isaac went out to speak on the field<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The essential proof is from the part of the verse that is not quoted: “To speak on the field towards evening.” [The Arabic שׁוח, corresponding to Hebrew שׂוח, means “to run, or fly, with outstretched arms”.]</i>.” Speaking means praying, as it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 102:1" href="/Psalms.102.1"><i>Ps.</i> 102:1</a>) “A prayer of the deprived one when he faints and pours out his speech before the Eternal.” Evening prayer from our father Jacob. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 28:11" href="/Genesis.28.11"><i>Gen.</i> 28:11</a>) “He entreated at the Place<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Usually translated “came suddenly upon the place.” For the meaning of “Place”, see H. Guggenheimer, <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah</i>, pp. 268–269.</i>.” Entreaty means prayer, as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 27:18" href="/Jeremiah.27.18"><i>Jer.</i> 27:18</a>) “Please, let them entreat the Eternal of hosts.” And it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 7:16" href="/Jeremiah.7.16"><i>Jer.</i> 7:16</a>): “Do not lift for them (your voice in) a cry and do not entreat me.”
The rabbis said, they inferred prayers from daily sacrifices. The morning prayer from the perpetual sacrifice of the morning (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:4" href="/Numbers.28.4"><i>Num.</i> 28:4</a>): “The first lamb you should present in the morning.” <i>Minḥah</i> prayer from the perpetual sacrifice of the evening: “And the second lamb you should present in the evening.” They did not find anything to peg evening prayers onto it and simply stated it; that is what we have stated: Evening prayers have no fixed time. <i>Musaph</i> prayers are all day. Rebbi Tanḥuma<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 26b" href="/Berakhot.26b">Babli (26b</a>), this statement of a late Amora also is quoted as Tannaïtic.</i> said: In fact, they fixed it corresponding to the consumption of limbs and fat which were consumed on the altar during the entire night.
Rebbi Yehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is found also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 27a" href="/Berakhot.27a">Babli (27a</a>) and in both Mekhiltot (to <i>Ex.</i> 17:21). The second paragraph which connects the derivation to the previous association with sacrifices, and hence, with prayer, is found only in the Yerushalmi.</i> learned from words of the Torah, since Rebbi Ismael stated: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 16:21" href="/Exodus.16.21"><i>Ex.</i> 16:21</a>) “The sun was hot and it melted,” four hours into the day. You say four hours or should it be six hours? When it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 18:1" href="/Genesis.18.1"><i>Gen.</i> 18:1</a>): “In the heat of the day”, that means at six hours. Therefore, how can I interpret: “The sun was hot and it melted,” four hours into the day<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Here and in the next paragraph, one supposes, as in most Talmudic derivations, that the vocabulary of the Torah is uniquely fixed and that different expressions must have different meanings. [The only Bible translation that can be clearly dated to Tannaïtic times, the fragments of Aquilas’s Greek translation from the school of Rebbis Eliezer and Joshua, systematically has one-on-one correspondence between Hebrew and Greek words.]</i>! You derive it from (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 17:21" href="/Exodus.17.21"><i>Ex.</i> 17:21</a>): “In the morning,” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:4" href="/Numbers.28.4"><i>Num.</i> 28:4</a>) “in the morning.” Since the first “morning” meant “four hours”, “morning” mentioned there also means “four hours.” At four hours the sun is warm and the shadow is cool. At six hours both sun and shadow are hot. Rebbi Tanḥuma said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 18:1" href="/Genesis.18.1"><i>Gen.</i> 18:1</a>): “In the heat of the day”, at an hour when there is no shadow for any creature.
Rebbi Yasa prayed at three hours<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">While in theory in Mishnaic times the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> and prayer were separate activities, the practice in Amoraic times was to unite them. It is stated in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 9b" href="/Berakhot.9b">Babli (9b</a>) in the name of Israeli authorities that it is preferable to pray immediately after the last benediction of <i>Shema‘</i>. All authorities quoted here subscribe to this usage; the first two pray at the correct time for the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>, the last one recites <i>Shema‘</i> at the time of prayer according to Rebbi Yehudah.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba prayed at three hours. They saw Rebbi Berekhiah that he recited <i>Shema‘</i> and prayed after three hours. But did we not formulate (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:2:2-9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.2.2-9"><i>Berakhot</i> 1:5</a>): “He who reads after that did not lose, he is like a man reading in the Torah.” We may say that he accepted the yoke of heaven in its time<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">It is current practice to recite the first verse of <i>Shema‘</i> during the preliminary benedictions recited immediately after one gets dressed in the morning. Then the remainder of <i>Shema‘</i> is just recitation of verses of Torah and may be delayed, in particular on Sabbath and holidays.</i>.
Or Rebbi Yehudah learned from testimony<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Since we said that the rules of prayer are imitations of the rules of sacrifices and we do not find that the perpetual sacrifice was ever brought later than four hours in the day. Usually it is brought at first dawn.</i> since Rebbi Simon said in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: In the time of the hellenistic government<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 64b" href="/Menachot.64b">Babli (<i>Menaḥot</i> 64b</a>) telescopes this story and the next into one and dates it at the civil war of the two Hasmonean brothers Hyrkanos and Aristobulos.</i> they<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The officials of the Temple lowered the boxes from the wall of besieged Jerusalem; in each box was payment for the lamb to be placed in it for the daily sacrifice.</i> lowered them two boxes with gold and they gave them two lambs to pull up. Once they lowered them two boxes with gold and they gave them two kid goats<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Which cannot be used for the perpetual sacrifice.</i> to pull up. At that moment the Holy One, praise to Him, enlightened their eyes and they found two certified lambs in the hall of lambs<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Since the verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:3" href="/Numbers.28.3"><i>Num.</i> 28:3</a>) requires that the perpetual sacrifice be “a yearling sheep without blemish”, the sheep were usually held in a separate “hall of lambs” and were inspected three times before being used as sacrifice.</i>. About that time did Rebbi Yehudah bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 27a" href="/Berakhot.27a">Babli (27a</a>), the name is Rebbi Yehudah ben Baba. Levi Ginzberg points out that the name Yehudah bar Abba is found instead of Yehudah ben Baba is some Mishnah manuscripts at <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 6:1" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.6.1"><i>Idiut</i> 6:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 8:2" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.8.2">8:2</a>, <i>Yebamot</i> 16:7 and that R. Yehudah ben Baba, who was killed in the aftermath of the war of Bar Kokhba, is much too late to testify about occurrences in the Temple. Hence, the name “bar Abba” should not be changed.</i> testify that the perpetual morning sacrifice was brought at four hours.
Rebbi Levi said: Also in the days of the present evil government<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">In both Talmudim, the “evil government” or simply “government” is the Roman government.</i> they lowered them two boxes with gold and they gave them two sheep to pull up. Once they lowered them two boxes with gold and they let them pull up two swine<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 64b" href="/Menachot.64b">Babli (<i>Menaḥot</i> 64b</a>), there was only one swine and not only the wall but the entire Land of Israel trembled. (The civil war was at the time when Pompey conquered the East for Rome but the story here clearly speaks of the war of Titus. However, it seems that the Babli tradition in this case is more correct.)</i>. They did not manage to get to half the height of the wall when the swine clawed the wall; the wall trembled, and [the swine] jumped 40 parasangs from the Land of Israel. At that time the sins caused that the perpetual sacrifice was stopped and the Temple destroyed.
What is the reason of the rabbis? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:3" href="/Numbers.28.3"><i>Num.</i> 28:3</a>) “Two for the day”, split the day in two. The reason of Rebbi Yehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Not the reason why prayer and sacrifice has to be finished at four hours but the reason why the verse is written as it is, “two for the day” and not “two in the day”.</i>: “two for the day”, two advocates<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Greek παράκλητος (also meaning “intercessor”.).</i> per day; “two for the day” that they should be slaughtered expressly for the day<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The slaughterer must keep in mind that he slaughters for the perpetual sacrifice of that particular day. A sacrifice becomes invalid if it is slaughtered with the wrong intention.</i>.
“Two for the day”, that their slaughtering should be facing the day. That is what we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Tamid 4:1" href="/Mishnah_Tamid.4.1">Mishnah <i>Tamid</i> 4:1</a>. The entire passage is in <i>Sifra Num.</i> 142, in changed form <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 62a" href="/Yoma.62a">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 62a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tamid 31b" href="/Tamid.31b"><i>Tamid</i> 31b</a>.</i>: The perpetual morning sacrifice was slaughtered at the Northwest corner at the second ring<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">In the wall of the Temple enclosure, where the sacrifice is hung to be skinned and cut into pieces.</i>, facing the day<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., the sun. Every holocaust sacrifice has to be slaughtered North of the altar (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 1:11" href="/Leviticus.1.11"><i>Lev.</i> 1:11</a>).</i>, and the evening one was slaughtered at the Northeast corner at the second ring, facing the day. And<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">This is not a continuation of the previous argument but another interpretation of “two for the day”, that the victims should be selected separately for the sacrifices of the day.</i> that he should know which one was to be slaughtered in the morning and which one in the evening.
Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 28a" href="/Berakhot.28a">Babli (28a</a>), the statement is R. Yoḥanan’s own.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: <i>Minḥah</i> and <i>Musaph</i> prayers<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">If on a day that requires a <i>Musaph</i> prayer, a person has not prayed <i>Musaph</i> before 12:30 pm local time and now he is obligated for two prayers.</i>, the <i>Minḥah</i> prayer has precedence. They wanted to say, that is if there is no time in the day to pray both of them; but if there is time in the day to pray both of them then the <i>Musaph</i> prayer has precedence. Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Even if there is time in the day to pray both of them, the <i>Minḥah</i> prayer has precedence<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Following the general principle: “If a frequent duty and an infrequent one collide, the frequent one has precedence” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 114a" href="/Pesachim.114a">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 114a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 8:1:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.8.1.2-10">Yerushalmi <i>Berakhot</i> 8:1</a>). It is reported in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 28a" href="/Berakhot.28a">Babli (28a</a>) that Rebbi Zeïra learned the rule not from R. Yoḥanan directly but from R. Nathan bar Ṭobi.</i>. Rebbi Nathan bar Ṭobi<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">A student of R. Yoḥanan, whose house was close to the Academy.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Even if there is time in the day to pray both of them, the <i>Minḥah</i> prayer has precedence. But did we not state: “If somebody made <i>Minḥah</i> prayer precede <i>Musaph</i> prayer, he has done his duty.” Retrospectively, but from the start, not so<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning: If somebody did, we let him get away with it. But if somebody comes to ask, we tell him not to do it.</i>. Explain it if the time for prayer has not yet arrived, as in the following: Rebbi Joshua ben Levi commanded his students: If you have lunch<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἄριστον (“breakfast”, later also “main meal”).</i> and the day progressed to six hours before you entered, then pray <i>Minḥah</i> before you enter<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Even though one should not pray before 12:30 pm, it is preferable to pray too early than not to pray at all. In contrast to the recital of <i>Shema‘</i> which is bound to rigid times, prayer may be said too early as explained later in this <i>Halakhah</i>.</i>.
(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 3:1" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).3.1">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 3:1</a>) How much is half of <i>Minḥah</i>? Eleven hours minus a quarter<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 26b" href="/Berakhot.26b">Babli (26b</a>) has a parallel statement in the name of Rebbi Yehudah which is not from the Tosephta.</i>.
There (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 5:1) we have stated: “The perpetual sacrifice is slaughtered at 8:30 hours<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The count starts at sunrise. At the equinox, 8:30 in the day is 2:30 pm (14:30).</i> and brought at 9:30 hours. On Passover Eve days<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The afternoons of the 14th of Nisan and of the 14th of Iyar.</i> it is sacrificed at 7:30 hours and brought at 8:30 hours, whether it be weekday or Sabbath.” Rebbi Jeremiah asked: Here<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Regarding prayer, the Mishnah states that <i>Minḥah</i> is 2½ hours before night. The next “here” refers to the evening sacrifice which on ordinary days is slaughtered at 8:30 hours, 3½ hours before sundown. If the rules of prayer are derived from the rules of sacrifice then the time of <i>Minḥah</i> prayers should be fixed at 3½ hours before sundown!</i> you make <i>Minḥah</i> at two and a half hours and here you make <i>Minḥah at</i> three and a half hours? Rebbi Yose said, <i>Minḥah</i> prayer was not bound to the perpetual sacrifice of evening but to incense burning<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">The evening portion of incense was burned at the time of lighting the candelabra, after all sacrifices had been offered (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 30:8" href="/Exodus.30.8"><i>Ex.</i> 30:8</a>).</i>. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 141:2" href="/Psalms.141.2"><i>Ps.</i> 141:2</a>): “May my prayer be prepared as incense before You, the lifting up of my hands as the gift of evening.” Take one hour for its<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The perpetual sacrifice’s.</i> preparation and you make <i>Minḥah</i> at two and one half hours.
Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina used to pray when the sun set so that the fear of Heaven should be on him the entire day long. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said: May my lot be with those who pray at sunset<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29b" href="/Berakhot.29b">Babli (29b</a>), the statement is attributed to Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan, also Galilean sages. Nevertheless, it is stated there that in “the West”, i. e., the Land of Israel, one curses those who pray at sunset since if anything happens at that time, the time of prayer will have passed whereas if one plans for earlier prayer, one always has space to accomodate emergencies. This opinion must be dated to the time after the work on the Jerusalem Talmud had stopped.<br>The root דמדם appears only in the expression דמדומי חמה. While in the Babli this means “dawn or dusk”, in the Yerushalmi it means only “sunset” as is clear from <i>Pesaḥim</i> 5:1 (fol. 31c), where דמדומי חמה is the opposite of הנץ החמה “sunrise”. The same verbal stem in Arabic means “to eliminate by force.”</i>. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 32:6" href="/Psalms.32.6"><i>Ps.</i> 32:6</a>) “For that, every pious person should pray to You at the time of מצא”, at the time when the day is pushed out<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Replacing the verb מצא “to find” by מצה “to squeeze dry, suck dry”.</i>.
The maternal uncle of Rebbi Ada<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Rav Ada bar Ahava.</i> had rolled up the kaftan of Rav on the Great Fastday<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Yom Kippur. The Babylonian scholars never prayed without wearing the kaftan with the precribed belt. It seems that the Yeshivah of Rav had an intermission between <i>Musaph</i> and <i>Minḥah</i> on Yom Kippur.</i>. He said to him: When you see the sun on top of the date palms<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Since their synagogues were outside the cities in the fields, the sun on top of the date palms may indicate a rather early hour but probably inside the timeframe admitted by Rebbi Yehudah.</i>, give me my kaftan so that we may pray <i>Minḥah.</i> And when the sun is on top of the date palms it is daytime. As<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The text הכא makes no sense. In the absence of manuscript evidence, the text has been left unchanged but the translation follows Levi Ginzberg’s conjecture that one has to read כְּהָא “As to that”, by a simple metathesis of two letters. The argument is that in a deep valley running N-S, the sun on the top of trees on the slopes of the valley designates a rather early time.</i> Rebbi Yoḥanan said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 44:27" href="/Isaiah.44.27"><i>Is.</i> 44:27</a>): “He Who said to the deep: dry up!”, that is Babylonia, the filth<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>situs</i> “situation; filth”.</i> of the world. Rebbi Yoḥanan said<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is an aggadic interruption about Babylonia; the discussion of Rav’s action is continued in the following paragraph. This group of sermons is also found three times in <i>Midrash rabba</i>: <i>Gen.</i><i>rabba 37:4, Threni rabba, Petiḥta</i> 23, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kohelet Rabbah 12:7" href="/Kohelet_Rabbah.12.7"><i>Eccl. rabba</i> 12:7</a>. In the first two, there is an additional explanation of Shinear: A land whose (Jewish) rulers study Torah as youths (but do not continue studying as adults.)</i>: Why is it called “the deep”, because there the dead of the Deluge were submerged, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 51:49" href="/Jeremiah.51.49"><i>Jer.</i> 51:49</a>) “Also in Babylonia the slain of Israel will fall, also in Babylonia the corpses of all the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Only in the Deluge the slain were of all mankind.</i> did fall.” It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 11:2" href="/Genesis.11.2"><i>Gen.</i> 11:2</a>) “They found a valley in the land Shinear and dwelt there.” Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, why is it called Shinear? Because there the dead of the Deluge were thrown<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Taking שנער as <i>shaf‘el</i> of the root נער “to pour out”; a later explanation refers to נער “to be a youth”.</i>. Another explanation: Because they die in strangulation<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">In the Targumim, תשנוּק means “strangulation.” However, in Syriac the words means “suffering”, which makes sense here.</i>, without light<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Since they had no olive oil, they had to use sesame oil which does not adhere well to wicks. Public hot baths were a characteristic institution of the provinces of the Roman empire.</i> or public baths. Another explanation: Shinear, because they are stripped of <i>miẓwot,</i> without <i>terumah</i> and without tithes<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">While in old times the exiles tried to fulfill the “obligations that are incumbent on the Land of Israel” also in Babylonia, in Talmudic times they were no longer observed there.</i>. Another explanation: Shinear, because its rulers die as youths. Another explanation: Shinear, because it produced a hater and enemy of the Holy One, praise to Him. Who is that? That is Nebuchadnezzar the evil one.
Rav acted according to Rebbi Yehudah. If you do it following the rabbis, Rebbi Yehudah will not agree. If you do it following Rebbi Yehudah, the rabbis also will agree<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">The previous questionable interpretation based on the topography of Babylonia (which is a double valley, but a very flat one) is unnecessary: Since the time frame of Rebbi Yehudah is more restrictive than that of the majority, if one follows Rebbi Yehudah one prays in a time frame acceptable to everybody.</i>.
From where about <i>Neïlah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The additional, fifth prayer close to the end of Yom Kippur and the major fasts in a draught.</i>? Rebbi Levi said: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 1:15" href="/Isaiah.1.15"><i>Is.</i> 1:15</a>) “Even if you prolong your prayers.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">The argument is from the full sentence: “Even if you augment your prayers, I shall not hear.” Since Isaiah presents this as a particular curse, it follows that, otherwise, if the people increase their prayers they will be heard.</i>” From here that everyone who increases his prayers will be answered. The argument of Rebbi Levi is inverted. There says Rebbi Abba, the son of Rebbi Pappai<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Amora of the fourth generation, student of Rebbi Joshua from Sikhnin (Suknin in Lower Galilee), a student of Rebbi Levi. Only aggadic material is transmitted by these two sages.</i>, Rebbi Joshua of Sikhnin in the name of Rebbi Levi (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 14:23" href="/Proverbs.14.23"><i>Prov.</i> 14:23</a>) “In all excitement there is something superfluous; and the word of the lips is but for deficit.” Hannah, because she prayed too long, reduced the years of Samuel because she said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 1:22" href="/I_Samuel.1.22"><i>1Sam.</i> 1:22</a>) “He shall dwell there forever” but “forever” for a Levite is only 50 years, as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 8:25" href="/Numbers.8.25"><i>Num.</i> 8:25</a>): “At age fifty he should return from the worshipping hosts<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">In fact, Hannah gave that detailed dedication not in her prayer but only when she explained to her husband that she would not come with him to Shiloh until she had weaned the baby, so that the boy could stay in the Tabernacle for the rest of his life. A Levite could serve (as carrier) only to age 50.</i>”. But in fact it was 52<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">There is no Biblical source that gives Samuel 52 years; this Yerushalmi tradition is the result of a computation detailed in <i>Midrash Seder Olam</i>, Chap.13, and is based on the assertion (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 13:1" href="/I_Samuel.13.1"><i>1Sam.</i> 13:1</a>) that Saul ruled only for two years, and on certain not obvious principles of interpretation of the Bible. Shiloh was destroyed when Samuel was still relatively young and afterwards he never lived near the Tabernacle again.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said two years until she weaned him. And here you say so<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">That additional prayer is always good. The answer is that additional prayers are guaranteed to be heard only if the entire congregation prays together.</i>? If he ever said it, one for private the other for public prayers. Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ḥiyya bar Abba. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 32b" href="/Berakhot.32b">Babli (32b</a>) he supports the negative opinion of Rebbi Levi in the name of R. Yoḥanan, at least in the case that somebody prays with the certain idea that he must be heard. The Yerushalmi clearly accepts the first statement of R. Levi but not the second one.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan, Rebbi Simeon bar Ḥalaphta in the name of Rebbi Meïr (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 1:12" href="/I_Samuel.1.12"><i>1Sam.</i> 1:12</a>): “When she prayed very long before the Eternal,” it follows that everyone who extends his prayers will be answered.
When is <i>Neïlah</i>? The rabbis of Caesarea say: Rav and Rebbi Yoḥanan disagree. Rav said, when the gates of Heaven are locked<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear when the Gates of Heaven are locked. Maybe it is at sundown when the sun disappears, but it is more likely sometime after that when on a very clear day one may notice a sudden darkening of the sky in the middle of the gradual dusk. The gates of the Temple were locked for the public at the time of the lighting of the candelabra in the Sanctuary, which must be before sundown.</i>. And Rebbi Yoḥanan said, when the gates of the Temple are locked. Rebbi Yudan Antordaya<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the later generations who must be younger than the Amora R. Yose. His name appears variously as אנתורדיא, אנתודריא, ענתודריא, ענתוריא. The name probably is a toponymie [from Antarados, on the Phoenician coast opposite the island city of Arados (Arwad). Antarados is mentioned in an old commentary to Pliny (V 20). (E. G.)]</i> said: A Mishnah supports Rebbi Yoḥanan (<i>Taäniot</i> 4:1): “On three occasions do the Cohanim lift their hands four times in one day, mornings, <i>Musaph, Minḥah,</i> and at the locking of the gates: on fastdays<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Publicly declared additional fastdays in case of a draught.</i>, at support services<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Since the perpetual sacrifices were offered from public money and in the name of the public, some public representatives had to be present at the sacrifice. For this purpose, the Land of Israel was divided into districts and each district sent a few representatives to Jerusalem for the week to which it was appointed. During that week, the people of that district conducted special services with prayers that the sacrifices should be accepted by God; at these prayers the Cohanim recited the priestly blessing an additional time before nightfall, to coincide with an additional prayer for that purpose. It follows that the additional prayer was said year round on weekdays but every week at another district.</i>, and on Yom Kippur. May you say that the gates of heaven are locked while it is still daytime<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Since the priestly blessing may be recited only during daytime, the “locking of the gates” mentioned in the Mishnah must have been during daytime and cannot have been in the night, maybe not after sundown.</i>?
The maternal uncle of Rebbi Ada had rolled up the kaftan of Rav on the great fast. He said to him: When you see the sun on the top of the date palms, give me my kaftan so that we may pray the Locking of the Gates. The argument of Rav is inverted. There he says “the locking of the Gates of Heaven” and here he says “the locking of the gates of the Temple.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Since the sun is on the top of the date palms quite some time before sunset, Rav cannot possibly pray at the Locking of the Gates of Heaven. Hence, his deeds contradict his teachings.</i>” Rav Mattanah said: Since Rav needed a lot of time to pray, he reached the Locking of the Gates of Heaven<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear from here that prayer may start before the closing of any gates, it just may not end earlier. This is the interpretation of Maimonides. {Levi Ginzberg explains that Rav, in whose Yeshivah the Galilean <i>Minhag</i> of reciting poetic inserts was accepted, did spend the time until sundown in reciting prayers before the <i>Amidah</i> of <i>Neïlah.</i> This interpretation is impossible since “prayer” always means “the <i>Amidah.</i>”]</i>.
May <i>Neïlah</i> free one from evening prayers? Rebbi Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Abba, the student of Rav Huna, taught the statement in the name of Rav Huna when he came to Galilee and mentioned his own objection to Rav Huna’s teaching.</i>, Rav Ḥuna in the name of Rav: <i>Neïlah</i> frees one from evening prayers<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rav’s original opinion that one prays at the Locking of the Gates of Heaven, <i>Neïlah</i> may be started only when evening prayers may already be said. It does not make sense to recite two prayers at one time.</i>. Rebbi Abba said to Rav Ḥuna: How may he mention <i>havdalah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">It will be explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 5:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.5.2.1">Mishnah 5:2</a> that at the end of Sabbath or holiday work is permitted only if <i>havdalah</i> (“distinction”) was recited in the evening <i>Amidah</i>. Hence, Rav’s decision seems to be impossible. (Even though it is possible, but undesirable, to recite <i>havdalah</i> only on a cup of wine, in particular after Yom Kippur when no fire is lit for <i>havdalah</i>.)</i>? Rebbi Jonah said to Rebbi Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Jonah, of the fifth generation of Galilean Amoraïm, apparently knew Rebbi Abba of the third generation.</i>: How may seven<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">The seven benedictions of the holiday <i>Amidah</i>.</i> free one from eighteen? He said to him, did I not already contradict it? He said to him: Because you contradicted it, should it be abandoned<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">If somebody could find a satisfactory answer to your question, there would be no reason to abandon the ruling of Rav.</i>? Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">The Amora, contemporary of Rebbi Jonah.</i> said, what Rebbi Abba asked is truly difficult. What Rebbi Jonah asked is not at all difficult, they made it easy on people because of the fast, that seven should free one from eighteen. Rebbi Abba bar Mamal<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Or, from Mamal (Khirbet Mamleh in the valley of Genezareth), Amora of the second/third generation. He seems to refer to the decision of Babylonian scholars, reported by Rebbi Abba the Babylonian. This contradicts the position of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 87b" href="/Yoma.87b">Babli (<i>Yoma</i> 87b</a>) which reports the opinion of Rav that <i>Neïlah</i> does free one from evening prayers and explains that, in the opinion of Rav, the evening <i>Amidah</i> is not really obligatory (and, hence, is eliminated by the contemporaneous <i>Neïlah</i>) <i>Havdalah</i> is said over a cup of wine.<br>The next statement in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi is strictly from the Land of Israel.</i> said to his colleagues: From all of them I understand that <i>Neïlah</i> does not free one from evening prayers. Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: <i>Neïlah</i> does not free one from evening prayers. Rebbi Yose bar Abun said: Did not Rebbi Ḥiyya state this: “Every day one prays eighteen benedictions, including the end of Sabbath, end of Yom Kippur, and end of public fast days<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>baraita</i> is a commentary on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.3.1">Mishnah 3</a>; it explains the opinion of Rabban Gamliel that a full 18 benedictions have to be prayed three times every day (see the end of this Halakhah), including the end of Sabbath and Yom Kippur (against the opinion of Rebbi Aqiba that on those occasions there are 19 benedictions, including a separate benediction for <i>havdalah</i>), and the end of public fasts for rain, to exclude the opinion that <i>Neïlah</i> eliminates the evening prayer. The Israeli position is thus supported by a tannaïtic statement.</i>.”
Rebbi Isaac bar Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">These rules are inserted here because they are about statements of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi in the order of <i>Amidah</i> prayers.</i>: If Yom Kippur happens to be on the Sabbath, one mentions Sabbath in <i>Neïlah</i> even though there is no <i>Neïlah</i> for Sabbath. They added to it: If the New Moon happens to be on a public fast-day, one mentions the New Moon in <i>Neïlah</i> even though there is no <i>Neïlah</i> for the New Moon<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">In general, fasting is forbidden on the days of the New Moon. The one exception is in the case of a prolonged draught when one fasts while praying for rain. In such a case, once they started the severe fasts, they continue Mondays and Thursdays without interruptions as explained in Tractate <i>Taäniot</i>.</i>. Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: On a Sabbath that falls on Ḥanukkah, one mentions Ḥanukkah for <i>Musaph</i> even though there is no <i>Musaph</i> for Ḥanukkah. They added to it the New Moon that happens to be in it, one mentions Ḥanukkah for <i>Musaph</i> even though there is no <i>Musaph</i> for Ḥanukkah<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 34b" href="/Shabbat.34b">Babli (<i>Šabbat</i> 34b</a>) is in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi only, there the reason is stated that “the day requires four (or five) prayers”, and since the addition is required for some of the prayers it is required for all of them.</i>.
When the New Moon falls on a fast day, how does one mention the New Moon<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is extremely difficult to understand and the greatest authorities of the Middle Ages, Rashba (R. Abraham ben Adrat, on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 32b" href="/Berakhot.32b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 32b</a>) and Rosh (R. Asher ben Yeḥiël, to Chap. 5, #10) felt compelled to emend the text. Since three of the four prayers of the New Moon are weekday prayers with an addition added in “Temple service” (רצה, the 16th benediction in the Yerushalmi version) as given later in Chapter 5, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:2:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.2.2-8">Halakhah 2</a>, the only question can be about <i>Musaph</i>. However, we never hear that the particular inserts in the morning prayers of a fast day were recited also for <i>Musaph</i>. On the other hand, as Rosh points out, the previous paragraph certainly implies that the one benediction recited on <i>all</i> fast-days except Yom Kippur, not only on those for rain, known as עננו, must be recited also for <i>Musaph</i> since the day requires that the benediction be inserted in all prayers. One may at least understand the position of Rebbi Abba that on a fast day for rain which coincides with a day of the New Moon, one recites the usual <i>Musaph</i> with an additional fifth benediction which deals with the fast day, after the fourth for the New Moon. The dissenting opinions of Rebbis Zeïra and Abba bar Mamal seem to imply that <i>Musaph</i> on a fast day consisted of the introductory and final benedictions that are common to all prayers and the additional benedictions for the fast day, whereas the section on the New Moon, for which <i>Musaph</i> is recited in the first place, is moved from its regular place to an insert in either the 16th or the 17th (מודים, “thanksgiving”, a place usually reserved for thanksgiving for past miracles) benediction.</i>? Rebbi Zeïra said, in “thanksgiving”. Rebbi Abba bar Mamal said, in “Temple service”. Rebbi Avina said, he says it as the fourth benediction. Rebbi Abba said, how do we find everywhere that he says it as the fourth benediction, here also as the fourth benediction. And so it was acted upon according to Rebbi Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">A reported action on an opinion is the best proof that this is accepted practice, see Chap. 1, Note 125.</i>.
What does one read? Rebbi Yose said, one reads blessings and curses<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Both on the day of the New Moon and on fast days one reads in the Torah. The readings are explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 3:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.3.5.1">Mishnah <i>Megillah</i> 3:6</a>. On the day of the New Moon, one reads abouts its sacrifices, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:11-15" href="/Numbers.28.11-15"><i>Num.</i> 28:11–15</a> (in Babylonia, 28:1–15), and on fast days for rain, blessings and curses, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 26:3-46" href="/Leviticus.26.3-46"><i>Lev.</i> 26:3–46</a>. (In Babylonia on other fast days, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 32:11-14" href="/Exodus.32.11-14"><i>Ex.</i> 32:11–14</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 34:1-10" href="/Exodus.34.1-10">34:1–10</a>). In Babylonia there would be no problem since there two Torah scrolls were used to read both portions, giving each person a larger share to read. However, in Israel the Torah was not read in the Babylonian one-year cycle but in an irregular three-year cycle with shorter readings and where the regular reading was postponed for any special one. For example, on Sabbath Ḥanukkah, in Israel <i>only</i> the corresponding part of the dedication sacrifices (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 7" href="/Numbers.7"><i>Num.</i> 7</a>) was read, whereas in Babylonia that was simply the reading from the second Torah scroll. Similarly, for a Sabbath New Moon one read in Israel only <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:1-15" href="/Numbers.28.1-15"><i>Num.</i> 28:1–15</a> and not the regular Torah reading. Hence, there is a serious question which portion to read on the New Moon which is also a fast day.</i>. Rebbi Mana said to him: For example to tell them about the fast day? They are lying on their bellies<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning, falling on their faces for private prayer after the <i>Amidah,</i> a penitential service (נפילת אפים) that is forbidden on semi-holidays like the day of the New Moon.</i> and should not know that it is a fast day? He said to him: To tell you that one reads blessings and curses<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Not that the reading is to proclaim a fast day, but it is the reading appropriate for a fast day. If one already eliminates the prohibition of fasting on the New Moon, the occasion is so serious that the Torah reading also is eliminated.</i>. Rebbi Yudan the Kappadokian<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">A scholar from Kappadokia in Anatolia; he is always mentioned in connection with the Amora Rebbi Yose.</i> said before Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Yehudah ben Pazi: One reads about the New Moon. Rebbi Yose met Rebbi Yehudah ben Pazi. He asked him: Did you hear that from your father? He said to him: My father did not say so, except that at Eyn Ṭab<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">After the destruction of the Academy of Jabneh and the move of the Patriarchate to Galilee, the declaration of New Moons and New Years (before the publication of the permanent calendar) did always take place at Eyn Ṭab “beautiful spring”, known in Greek as <i>Kallirrhoë</i> (καλλιρρόη “the beautifully flowing one”); it possibly is Ḥamat Gader. Since the sequence of 30 day and 29 day months was not determined beforehand, only at Eyn Ṭab was the day of the New Moon fixed. Everywhere else one knew that it was certainly a fast day and probably a day of the New Moon; the certain has precedence over the probable.</i>, since they know for sure that it is the New Moon, they read about the New Moon. Hence, at all other places one reads blessings and curses.
Jeremiah the Scribe<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">A scholar not otherwise known. As explained before, in Israel one interrupted the regular sequence of Torah reading, not just the reading for the <i>maphtir</i> as in Babylonia. The parallel discussion of this and the next paragraph is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 29b" href="/Megillah.29b">Babli <i>Megillah</i> 29b</a>.</i> asked before Rebbi Jeremiah: What does one read if the day of the New Moon is a Sabbath? He said to him: One reads about the New Moon. Rebbi Ḥelbo said before Rebbi Ammi: The Mishnah says so (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 3:5:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.3.5.2-4"><i>Megillah</i> 3:6</a>), “One interrupts for everything, for New Moons, for Ḥanukkah, and for Purim.”
