Isaac the trader asked Rebbi Isaac: What does one read on a New Moon that falls in Ḥanukkah? He said to him: Three for the New Moon and one for Ḥanukkah. Rebbi Phineas and Rebbi Simon, Rebbi Abba bar Zamina<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Rebbi Zeïra.</i> brought it in the name of Rebbi Eudaimon of Haifa<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">A teacher of Rebbi Zeïra, Amora of the second/third generation. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 29b" href="/Megillah.29b">Babli (<i>Megillah</i> 29b</a>) he is called Rebbi Dimi.</i>: Three read of Ḥanukka and one of the New Moon, to tell you that the fourth one comes only because of the New Moon<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Usually on Ḥanukkah only three people read from the Torah, since it is a regular workday. On the day of the New Moon, four persons read since it is a day with a <i>Musaph</i> sacrifice in the Temple. On the Sabbath, seven read (and the <i>maphtir</i> reads one additional portion). Hence, it seems impossible that the fourth person should read about Hanukkah.</i>. Bar Shelemiah the scribe asked Rebbi Mana: Think of it, if the New Moon of Ḥanukkah falls on a Sabbath, do not seven read? How can you say, to tell you that the fourth one comes only because of the New Moon? They asked the scribe<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">This phrase is missing in the parallels (Yerushalmi <i>Taäniot</i> 4:1, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 3:3:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.3.3.2-3"><i>Megillah</i> 3:4</a>) but it may be justified to assume that the question was not his, but that he was asked by others on his authority as scribe to the rabbi. Most probably, as conjectured by Levi Ginzberg, it is a second version of Rebbi Mana’s answer, that this is a really stupid question from a scribe who has not learned to think by himself: Since one interrupts for the Sabbath, it is clear that the reading of the New Moon, which occurs at least 16 times a year, has precedence over Ḥanukkah which occurs only 8 times.</i>; he said to him: That is a true question of a scribe.
Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">After the discussion of the side issues introduced by the mention of <i>Neïlah</i> and fast days, the discussion returns to the last part of the Mishnah. The text appears in modified form also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 8:10" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.8.10"><i>Bereshit rabba</i> 8:10</a>, <i>Pesiqta rabbati</i> 23; the parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 27b" href="/Berakhot.27b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 27b</a> disagrees fundamentally with the practice explained here.<br>According to the Mishnah, the time of <i>Minḥah</i> is until 5/4 hours before sundown for Rebbi Yehudah and until sundown for the other sages. As a corollary, the time of evening prayers starts at 5/4 hours before sundown for Rebbi Yehudah and at sundown for the others. Since Rebbi was a student of Rebbi Yehudah, it is possible that he simply followed his teacher and himself was followed by his own student R. Ḥiyya. Perhaps it is assumed here that we already know the result of the next paragraph, that evening prayer is not obligatory (this is also accepted in the Babli), and that because of this one permits evening prayer before sundown because it is a minor obligation and in Galilee apparently was not recited in the synagogue. This is the medieval Ashkenazic tradition. [The Babli states that evening prayers should be said in the night, that this is also Rebbi’s position, but that in case of error, under very dark clouds, one does not have to repeat the prayer which in Babylonia was recited in the synagogue.]</i> commanded his speaker Abdan<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that his name was Abba Yudan. In the talmudic academies, the head of the academy never raised his voice to speak to a large class; he explained what he had to say to one or more speakers, <i>Amoraïm,</i> who spoke in a loud voice. It is probable that the situation described here is that of Sabbath afternoon when everybody came to listen to the sermon, since the audience is called “congregation” and not “students”, who were the weekday audience.</i>: Proclaim before the congregation that he who wants to pray, should pray evening prayers as long as it is still daylight. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rebbi Ḥiyya the Great, in Rebbi’s Academy, not the student of R. Yoḥanan.</i> commanded his speaker: Proclaim before the congregation that he who wants to pray should pray evening prayers as long as it is still daylight. Rebbi Ḥanina said: Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Ben Ḥalaphta, the Tanna.</i> drew me to an inn and said to me: Here my father prayed Saturday (Friday night) prayers on Friday. Rebbi Ammi said: Rebbi Yoḥanan disagrees<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">And insists that Evening prayers may be said only after sundown.</i> but he should not have disagreed since one adds from the profane to the holy time<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">It is an obligation to start the Sabbath (and holidays) before sundown and end it after sundown, not exactly at sundown. This obligation is not spelled out in the Babli; its source is here in the Yerushalmi.</i>; in addition, donkey drivers come from Arab<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">The village of Arrabeh, North of Kafr Kanah in lower Galilee.</i> to Sepphoris and say, Rebbi Ḥanina ben Dosa already did consecrate the Sabbath in his town. But so it has been said, that Rebbi Ḥanina said: Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose drew me to an inn and said to me, here my father prayed Saturday night prayers on the Sabbath. But even with that he should not have disagreed, since Rebbi commanded his speaker Abdan: Proclaim before the congregation that he who wants to pray should pray evening prayers as long as it is still daylight. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba commanded his speaker: Proclaim before the congregation that he who wants to pray should pray evening prayers as long as it is still daylight. In the house of Rebbi Yannaï they said: If a man went to bed, one does not bother him to get up<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">If one forgot to recite evening prayers. R. Yannai certainly agrees that evening prayers are not obligatory.</i>. Rebbi Zeïra said, all the time that I followed this rule, I was afraid in the night<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Even though evening prayers are not obligatory, it is the practice to recite them for peace of mind, subject to the leniencies of Rebbi and Rebbi Ḥiyya.</i>. You have only what Rebbi commanded his speaker Abdan: Proclaim before the congregation that he who wants to pray should pray evening prayers as long as it is still daylight. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba commanded etc.
Rebbi Jacob bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">An Israeli Amora of the second generation, student of Rav in Babylonia. His tradition from “there” (Babylonia) and the following story are reported at great length in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 27b" href="/Berakhot.27b">Babli 27b</a>.</i> said: There, they did state, what is the status of evening prayer? Rabban Gamliel said, it is obligatory. Rebbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">In a dispute between Rebbi Joshua and Rabban Gamliel, practice always follows Rebbi Joshua. There is never a doubt that the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> is obligatory.</i> said, it is voluntary. Rebbi Ḥanina said, this difference parallels the other difference: He who holds that evening prayer is obligatory, holds that <i>Neïlah</i> does not free one from evening prayers. He who holds that it is voluntary, holds that <i>Neïlah</i> frees one from evening prayers<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">But, as stated before, evening prayers are still needed for mental health.</i>.
It happened that one student came and asked Rebbi Joshua: What is about evening prayer? He said to him: It is voluntary. He asked Rabban Gamliel: What is about evening prayer? He said to him: It is obligatory. He said to him: But Rebbi Joshua told me that it was voluntary. He said to him: Tomorrow, when I enter the assembly hall, stand up and ask me about this practice. The next day, this student stood up and asked Rabban Gamliel: What is about evening prayer? He said to him: It is obligatory. He said to him: But Rebbi Joshua told me that it was voluntary. Rabban Gamliel said to Rebbi Joshua: Are you the one who says it is voluntary? He answered him: No<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Since Rabban Gamliel went to great lengths to insist on uniformity, not only of practice, but also of doctrine, Rebbi Joshua, the most important member of the generation preceding Rabban Gamliel, did not want to start a quarrel.</i>. He said to him: Stand up on your feet so that they may testify against you. Then Rabban Gamliel was sitting down and lecturing while Rebbi Joshua was standing up until the people started talking and said to Rebbi Ḥuẓpit the interpreter<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The “Amora” of Rabban Gamliel, one of the “Ten Martyrs”.</i>: Send the people home. They said to Rebbi Zenon the <i>ḥazan</i><sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>ḥazan</i> was not only the reader in congregational prayers, but also the general organizer of religious affairs. In outlying communities he was the ritual slaughterer and the conduit through whom questions of religious practice were addressed to the Academies. Here it seems that he had to recite the prayer at the end of a study session discussed in the next Halakhah, that it was customary to start with a Bible verse and that the people spontaneously chose one which was a curse on the speaker.</i>: Start! He said: Start! All the people stood up and said to him (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Nahum 3:19" href="/Nahum.3.19"><i>Nahum</i> 3:19</a>): “Certainly, on whom did your evil not pass always?” They went and appointed<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">In the Yerushalmi, “appoint” (מנה) is the equivalent of the Babli’s “ordain” (סמך). Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah was ordained the same day he was appointed head of the Synhedrion.</i> Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah to the Yeshivah when he was 16 years old<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">In pre-war Poland, that was the usual age for <i>sĕmikha.</i> (In the Babli, the age is given as 18 years.) The difficulty of this age determination is discussed at length by the author in <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah,</i> p. 265–266.</i>; his head became all white. Rebbi Aqiba sat and was sad; he said, not that he is a greater Torah scholar than I am, but he comes from a greater family than I do; hail to the man whose forefathers created merit for him, hail to the man who has a peg to hang on to. What was Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah’s peg? He was the tenth generation after Ezra<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">His family was of equal rank with that of the Patriarch. In the Rome manuscript, there is an addition that he alone was as rich as the Patriarch (and, hence, had the money to deal with the Roman government).</i>. How many seats were there<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">This insertion is more detailed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 28a" href="/Berakhot.28a">Babli (28a</a>), where the question is discussed how many seats <i>were added</i> when, with the deposition of Rabban Gamliel, also his elitistic exclusionary policies of admission to the Yeshivah were scrapped. The insertion is Amoraïc, as is shown by the names of the authorities and the quotes from the Mishnah. The previous paragraph and the following one are Tannaïtic.</i>? Rebbi Jacob ben Sisi<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the fourth generation, contemporary of the Amora R. Yose, older than R. Yose ben R. Abun.</i> said: Eighty seats were there of accomplished scholars, not to count those standing behind the railing. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said 300 were there, not to count those standing behind the railing. As we have stated there (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Zevachim 1:3" href="/Mishnah_Zevachim.1.3">Mishnah <i>Zebaḥim</i> 1:3</a>) “On the day Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah was appointed to the Academy.”<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">In the tradition of the Babli, all of tractate <i>Idiut</i> was presented on that day.</i> There (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.6.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 4:6</a>) we have stated: “This inference did Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah present before the sages at the vineyard of Jabneh.” Was there a vineyard? It means that the scholars sat there in rows like vines in a vineyard. Rabban Gamliel went immediately to pacify each one in his house. He came to Rebbi Joshua and found him occupied with the making of needles<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, his profession is given as charcoal-burner.</i>. He asked him: This is how you earn your living? He answered him: Until now you did not know? Woe to the generation whose caretaker you are! He said to him: I humble myself before you. They sent a washerman to Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah, but some say that it was Rebbi Aqiba. He told him: The sprinkler, son of a sprinkler, should sprinkle. Should anyone who is neither a sprinkler nor the son of a sprinkler say to the sprinkler: your water is water from a cave and your ashes are ashes from a fireplace<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">The argument is taken from the ritual of the ashes of the red heifer. The ashes have to be given into “living” water, drawn from a stream. Sprinkling the water was not a reserved profession, but it may be assumed that the care of the ashes, and supervision of the cleansing ritual, was in the hands of the priests, of whom R. Eleazar ben Azariah was one. Hence, it was intimated to him that just as a non-Cohen should not presume upon his duties, so an outsider should not presume upon the duties of the Patriarch.</i>? He said to him: You made your peace with him! I and you shall go in the morning to Rabban Gamliel’s door. Nevertheless they did not remove him from his dignity but made him head of the court.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Neḥoniah ben Haqqanah<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">A Tanna of the second generation, teacher of Rebbi Ismael. In Medieval mysticism he is credited with authorship of <i>Sefer Habahir</i> and many mystical teachings.</i> used to recite a short prayer when he entered and when he left the house of study. They asked him, what kind of prayer is this? He told them: When I enter, I pray that no mishap should come through me and when I leave I give thanks for my lot.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> What does he say when he enters<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">The text in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 28b" href="/Berakhot.28b">Babli (28b</a>) is similar in content but different in formulation. The manuscripts of the Babli and the quotes in Medieval authors differ widely in language.</i>? May it be Your pleasure, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that I should not be offended by my colleagues and my colleagues should not be offended by me; that we should not declare impure that which is pure, nor declare pure what is impure; that we should not forbid that which is permitted, nor permit what is forbidden and I would be ashamed in this world and the world to come. What does he say when he leaves? I thank You, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that You ordained my lot with those who sit in the house of study and in synagogues and You did not ordain my lot in theaters and circuses<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">This does <i>not</i> imply that Rebbi Neḥonia accepted the doctrine of predestination as conjectured by L. Finkelstein (מבוא לפרקי אבות ואבות דרבי נתן, ניו יורק תשי״א, נספח ב).</i>. For I toil and they toil, I am diligent and they are diligent. I toil to inherit the Garden of Eden, but they toil for the pit of destruction as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 16:10" href="/Psalms.16.10"><i>Ps.</i> 16:10</a>): “Certainly, You will not abandon my soul to the pit, You will not let Your pious ones see destruction.”
Rebbi Pedat in the name of Rebbi Jacob bar Idi<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">A list of similar prayers after the <i>Amidah</i> is given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 16b-17a" href="/Berakhot.16b-17a">Babli, 16b–17a</a>, where a different text appears in the name of Rebbi Eleazar. It is remarkable that Rebbi Pedat, son of Rebbi Eleazar (ben Pedat), gives his father’s text in the name of Rebbi Jacob bar Idi, student of Rebbi Yoḥanan and colleague of Rebbi Eleazar, rather than from his own knowledge of his father’s practices. He also emphasizes that his father prayed three times, including evening prayers, as noted in the previous Halakhah.</i>: Rebbi Eleazar used to recite three prayers. What did he say after his prayer? May it please You, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that nobody should come to hate us in his heart nor should we hate anybody in our hearts, that nobody should be envious of us nor we envious of anybody. May Your Torah be our occupation all the days of our life and may our words be supplications before You. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba added: Make our hearts singleminded in the fear of Your name, remove us from all You hate and bring us close to all You love, and deal with us in charity for Your name’s sake.
In the house of Rebbi Yannai they say: He who awakes from his sleep must say “Praised are You, o Eternal, Who resurrects the dead. My Lord, I sinned before You. May it please You, o Eternal, my God, that You might give me a good heart, good part, good inclinations, good hope, good repute, benevolent eye, good soul, meek soul and meek spirit. Your Name should not be desecrated by us; do not make us a byword in the mouths of all creatures; our future should not end in destruction, nor our hope in sorrow. Do not let us need the gifts of flesh and blood, do not deliver our subsistence into the hands of flesh and blood, for their gifts are small but the shame is big. Give our part in Your Torah with those who do Your will, build Your house, Your Temple, Your city, Your Sanctuary quickly, in our days<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph appears among the morning benedictions in the <i>Siddur</i> of Rav Amram Gaon. In modern prayer rites, the corresponding Babylonian prayer (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60b" href="/Berakhot.60b">Babli 60b</a>) is universally accepted.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba prayed<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">This is Rebbi Ḥiyyȧ bar Abba’s personal prayer. The previous text mentioned in his name was his version of Rebbi Eleazar’s prayer.</i>: May it please You, o Eternal, our God and God of our fathers, that You may put into our hearts to do complete repentance before You so that we should not be ashamed before our forefathers in the World to Come. Rebbi Yudan ben Rebbi Ismael<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Galilean Amora of the third generation who was known for his great piety and assiduous study.</i> made it permanent that his Amora should say this after his explanations.
Rebbi Tanḥum the scholar<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">A title, σχολαστικός “scholar”, also found in ancient synagogue inscriptions. The prayer, with minor variations, is reported in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 17a" href="/Berakhot.17a">Babli (17a</a>) in the name of Rebbi Alexandri.בר may mean “son of”; it also may mean “endowed with the quality of”.</i> prayed: May it please You, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that You may break and remove the yoke of evil inclinations from our hearts since so You created us to do Your will, and we are required to do Your will. You desire it and we desire it, who obstructs? The sour matter in the dough! It is obvious and known that we have no power to resist. But may it be Your pleasure, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that You may remove it from us, subdue it, so that we may do Your will as our own with a willing heart.
Rebbi Yoḥanan prayed<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">The prayer of Rebbi Yoḥanan in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 16b" href="/Berakhot.16b">Babli (16b</a>) is completely different. The first prayer uses the wording of the last benediction at a wedding; the meaning seems to be that he prays for a marriage that always retains the feelings of the wedding day. “Future and hope” means “existence in the Future World.”</i>: May it please You, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that You may make dwell in our marriage couches love and understanding, peace and friendship. Let our end suceed in future and hope, increase the students in our boundaries. May we enjoy our part in paradise; grant us a good heart and a good colleague; may we get up and find<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Find the solutions of all problems that remained unsolved the previous evening.</i>, and may the quiet of our minds come before You in kindness.
“When I leave I give thanks for my lot<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Quote of the last clause in the Mishnah. Rebbi Abun seems to free the mindless from responsibility if they do not live a religious life.</i>.” Rebbi Abun said, to God Who alotted me knowledge and good works.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rabban Gamliel says: Every day one prays<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">For the <i>Amidah</i>. The shortened version of Rebbi Joshua will be discussed in the Halakhah.</i> eighteen benedictions; Rebbi Joshua says, similar to eighteen benedictions. Rebbi Aqiba says, if he is fluent in his prayer then he prays eighteen benedictions, otherwise similar to eighteen benedictions.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> And why 18<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">The list of the Yerushalmi is quoted at length in <i>Tanḥuma Wayyera</i> 1, and from there in other Midrashim. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 28b" href="/Berakhot.28b">Babli (28b</a>) has a shorter list with different names; many allusions given here are not in that list.</i>? Rebbi Joshua ben Levi says, corresponding to the 18 psalms that are written from the start of Psalms to (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 20:2" href="/Psalms.20.2"><i>Ps.</i> 20:2</a>): “May the Lord listen to you on the day of need.” If somebody would say to you they are 19, tell him (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 2:1" href="/Psalms.2.1"><i>Ps.</i> 2:1</a>) “Why are the Gentiles in upheaval” is not in the count<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">In most of Talmudic sources, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 1" href="/Psalms.1">Psalms 1</a> and 2 form one song. To compensate, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 116" href="/Psalms.116"><i>Ps.</i> 116</a> is divided in two.</i>. From here they said that one who prayed and was not answered needs to fast. Rebbi Mana said, a hint that a Torah student must say to his teacher: May your prayers be answered<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 20:2" href="/Psalms.20.2"><i>Ps.</i> 20:2</a> is adressed to David by his students (or the Synhedrion).</i>.
Rebbi Simon said, corresponding to the 18 bones in the spine since when a person prays he has to bend all of them bowing down. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 35:10" href="/Psalms.35.10"><i>Ps.</i> 35:10</a>) “All my bones shall say, o Eternal, who is like You?<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 28b" href="/Berakhot.28b">Babli (28b</a>), this reason for the number 18 is given by Rebbi Tanḥum in the name of R. Joshua ben Levi who notes that, when bowing down in prayer, all joints must be moved.</i>”
Rebbi Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this is a statement of Rebbi Hillel, the son of Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥmani. Also the following discussion has a parallel in the Babli.</i> said, corresponding to the 18 Divine Names written in (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 29" href="/Psalms.29"><i>Ps.</i> 29</a>) “Give to the Eternal, o sons of the mighty.” Rebbi Ḥuna said: If it were said that they are 17, tell him the one against sectarians the Sages fixed already at Jabneh<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Ḥuna’s question is an attack against all who try to find a reason for the eighteen benedictions by pointing out that in the 500 years between the institution of formalized prayer by the Men of the Great Assembly and the Synhedrion of Rabban Gamliel, the <i>Amidah</i> prayer consisted of only 17 benedictions. Rebbi Ḥuna’s answer, not very satisfactory, is that the eighteenth benediction is also an institution of the Synhedrion, the legal successor of the Great Assembly, and, therefore, all eighteen benedictions have the same status.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Yose objected before Rebbi Yose, but is it not written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 29:3" href="/Psalms.29.3"><i>Ps.</i> 29:3</a>) “the God of Glory thundered<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">The mention of God introduces a nineteenth Divine name.</i>”? He said to him: Has it not been stated: He takes together the one against sectarians and sinners in “He Who subdues offenders”<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">This implies that the benediction containing the curse upon apostates and sectarians (i. e., Christians) was not newly introduced at Jabneh but that it was a modification of an old benediction directed at those who wantonly transgress the commandments of the Torah. Hence, the original number of benedictions instituted by the Great Assembly was 18. The benediction has been changed in Christian surroundings beyond recognition. The text of Jabneh must have been close to today’s Yemenite version: למשומדים אל תהי תקוה, כל המינים והמוסרים כרגע יאבדו ומלכות זדון תעקור ותשבור מהרה בימינו. ברוך אתה יי֨ שובר אויבים ומכניע זדים.</i>, the one for elders and proselytes in “Assurance to the righteous”, and the one for David in “He Who builds Jerusalem.”<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">This is the Israeli version which has no separate benediction asking for the return of the Davidic rulers. The Babylonian version has no mention of the Davidic dynasty in the prayer for rebuilding Jerusalem; it is retained in today’s Yemenite prayerbook. Current Ashkenazic and Sephardic versions combine the Israeli prayer, for Jerusalem and the Davidic dynasty in benediction 14, with the Babylonian one for the Davidic dynasty alone in benediction 15. Hence, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 29" href="/Psalms.29">Psalm 29</a> accomodates both the Galilean (18) benedictions based on the number of mentions of the Tetragrammaton, and the Babylonian (19) versions, based on all invocations of the Deity in the Psalm.</i> Then you have enough to have a Divine name<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">The parallels הזכרות, אדכרה in this paragraph show that in the times of the Yerushalmi the sounds of ז /<i>z</i>/ and soft ד /<i>ð</i>/ (voiced <i>th</i>) were almost indistinguishable.</i> for each one of them.
Rebbi Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi Phineas: Corresponding to the eighteen times the Patriarchs are mentioned together in the Torah, Abraham, Isaac, Jacob. If somebody will tell you that there are nineteen, tell him that (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 23:13" href="/Genesis.23.13"><i>Gen.</i> 23:13</a>) “Behold, the Eternal was standing over him” is not counted<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Since Jacob is not mentioned in that verse.</i>. If somebody will tell you that there are seventeen, tell him that (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 48:16" href="/Genesis.48.16"><i>Gen.</i> 48:16</a>) “My name should be called over them, as well the names of my fathers Abraham and Isaac” is counted<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Since Jacob is mentioned implicitly; he speaks about “my name”.</i>.
Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥmani in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Corresponding to the eighteen times “commandment” is mentioned in the second description of the tabernacle<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">The description of the actual construction of the tabernacle.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said, only from (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 38:23" href="/Exodus.38.23"><i>Ex.</i> 38:23</a>) “And with him Aholiab ben Aḥisamakh” to the end of the book<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Since from the start of the section, v. 21, there would be 19 times mentioned that “the Eternal commanded Moses”.</i>.
The seven<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Benedictions of the <i>Amidah.</i> There is no need to ask for a reason for the seven benedictions of a holiday since holidays in everything imitate the Sabbath. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29a" href="/Berakhot.29a">Babli (29a</a>) only the first reason is given, in the name of R. Ḥalaphta ben Shaul.<br>In a <i>Midrash Yelamdenu</i> quoted in <i>Yalqut Shim‘oni Psalms</i> #863, the seven voices are said to refer to the seven kinds of voices heard at the theophany at Sinai, which was on a Sabbath.</i> of Sabbath, from where? Rebbi Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora from the circle of Rebbi Yoḥanan.</i> said, corresponding to the seven “voices” written in (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 29" href="/Psalms.29"><i>Ps.</i> 29</a>) “Give to the Eternal, o sons of the mighty.” Rebbi Yudan Antoraya said, corresponding to the seven Divine Names in (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 92" href="/Psalms.92"><i>Ps.</i> 92</a>) “Psalm, Song for the Sabbath Day.”
Nine of New Year’s Day, from where? Rebbi Abba from Carthage<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">An Israeli Amora of the circle of Rebbi Yoḥanan and Resh Laqish. He is either from Carthage in North Africa or from Cartagena in Spain.</i> said: Corresponding to the nine Divine Names in Hanna’s prayer; there it is written at the end: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 2:10" href="/I_Samuel.2.10"><i>1Sam</i> 2:10</a>) “The Eternal will judge the ends of the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">This is reported in shortened form in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29a" href="/Berakhot.29a">Babli 29a</a>. The entire series of analogous numbers is given only by Israeli Amoraïm; the Yerushalmi is the source for all abbreviated statements in the Babli. The verse from Hannah’s prayer, not quoted in the Babli, is the reason that Hannah’s prayer forms the Haphtarah of the first day of the New Year.</i>.”
The twenty-four of fast days<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Public fasts for rain in a year of draught. The argument is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29a" href="/Berakhot.29a">Babli (29a</a>) in the name of Rebbi Ḥelbo alone.</i>, from where? Rebbi Ḥelbo and Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Naḥman both say, corresponding to the twenty-four times that entreaty, prayer, and supplication are mentioned in Solomon’s prayer (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 8" href="/I_Kings.8"><i>1Kings</i> 8</a>).
Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav Jeremiah, a private person has to mention the occasion on a public fast day<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">The following discussions belong to tractate <i>Taäniot</i> (fol. 65c). They are inserted here because the 24 benedictions of fast days were mentioned. On the other hand, the correspondences to the 18, 7, and 9 benedictions on other days belong here and are repeated in <i>Taäniot</i> only because of the following text.<br>The 24 benedictions are recited by the reader in public prayer. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 13b-14a" href="/Taanit.13b-14a">Babli (<i>Taänit</i> 13b–14a</a>) the opinion quoted here in the name of Rav Jeremiah (bar Abba, one of the most important students of Rav in Babylonia) is attributed to Rav himself.</i>. Where does he say it? Between “Redeemer of Israel” and “Healer of the sick.”<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Between the Seventh and Eighth benedictions, as a separate benediction.</i> What does he say? “Answer us, o Eternal, answer us in this time and season because we are in great trouble, do not hide Your presence from us, do not be oblivious to our supplications, because You, o Eternal, will answer in time of trouble, redeem and save in any time of distress. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 107:6" href="/Psalms.107.6"><i>Ps.</i> 107.6</a>) “They cried to the Eternal in their trouble, He led them out from their distress.”<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">The Galilean practice was to end every benediction in prayer or Grace with a verse from the Bible. This practice has survived only sporadically. Even though this prayer text is given only in the Yerushalmi, (the Babli usually assumes that all texts are known) there are many variants already in the extant prayer manuals from the 8th to the 10th centuries.</i> Praise to You, o Eternal, Answering in times of trouble. Rebbi Yannai ben Rebbi Ismael<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the Rome ms. here and the Venice text in the parallel version in <i>Taäniot</i> 65c. Rebbi Yannai ben R. Ismael was a student of R. Yoḥanan and a colleague of R. Zeïra. (The Venice text here has בשם instead of בר.)</i> in the name of the House of Rebbi Yannai<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">The Yeshivah established by Rebbi Yannai in the first generation of Amoraïm; it continued after its founder’s death.</i> says: In “He Who hears prayer.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">In the 15th benediction. In the Babylonian rite we never find that a private person adds a benediction to his prayer. The House of Rebbi Yannai omitted the final benediction in Rav Jeremiah’s text.</i>”
Rebbi Jonah in the name of Rav: Even an individual who decreed a fast day on himself has to mention the occasion<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">He also has to recite עננו. [In practice, the fastdays of the 3rd of Tishre, 10th of Tevet, 13th of Adar, and 17th of Tammuz, follow the rules of private fast days.]</i>. Where does he say it? Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav Ḥuna: Similar to Friday night and Sabbath day<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">During every prayer he has to recite that day.</i>. Rebbi Mani said: I, who did not check whether one follows Rav Jeremiah or Rebbi Yannai the son of Rebbi Ismael, went to the study hall and I heard: “Rav Ḥuna in the name of Rav: Even an individual who decreed a fast day on himself has to mention the occasion. Rebbi Yose objected that a <i>baraitha</i> disagrees: Every day one prays eighteen benedictions, including the night after Sabbath and the nights after Yom Kippur and after Public Fasts<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">See <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:24" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.24">Halakhah 1, Note 86</a>.</i>.” Since Rebbi Yose said, this <i>baraita</i> disagrees<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Mani’s argument goes as follows: Since R. Yose stated that the <i>baraita</i> contradicts Rav, he takes the <i>baraita</i> to mean that a private person <i>always</i> recites 18 benedictions on weekdays, <i>never</i> 19, even on fast days. The additional days are mentioned to point out that insertions for a private person are always accomodated in an existing benediction, never as an additional one, in contrast to the opinion of R. Aqiba who states in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 5:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.5.2.1">Mishnah 5:2</a> that <i>Havdalah</i> Saturday nights is a separate benediction. In addition, it is stated that on those days when <i>Neïlah</i> is recited, Yom Kippur and fast days for a severe draught, the <i>Neïlah</i> prayer does not replace the following night’s prayer as discussed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:1:2-33" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.1.2-33">Halakhah 1</a>. The Yerushalmi does not address the question what the reader says on a public fast day which is not a fast for rain; the Babli decides that the reader will recite עננוּ as a separate benediction between “Redeemer of Israel” and “Healer of the sick.” This decision does not go against R. Mani’s argument.</i>, it contradicts the statement: between “Redeemer of Israel” and “Healer of the sick.”
Rebbi Aḥa bar Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">An Israeli Amora of the third generation, companion of Rebbi Abba bar Mamal and contemporary of Rebbi Zeïra.</i> in the name of the older Rebbi Huna of Sepphoris<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">A student of R. Yohanan whose sayings are reported by several sages of the third and fourth generations in Galilee. The name is correctly given in the Rome ms. and in the Venice text in Taäniot.</i>: An individual must mention the occasion on the Ninth of Av. What does he say? “Have mercy, o Eternal, our God, in Your great mercy and your trusted kindness, towards us, Your people Israel, Your city Jerusalem, Zion the dwelling place of Your glory, and on the mourning, ruined, destroyed, and desolate city that is given into the hand of strangers, trampled down by haughty peoples, that was inherited by legions and desecrated by idol worshippers, when You had given her to Your people Israel as property, and let her be inherited by the seed of Yeshurun, for in fire You set her on fire and with fire You will build her in the future as it has been said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Zechariah 2:9" href="/Zechariah.2.9"><i>Zach.</i> 2:9</a>): “But I shall be for her, says the Eternal, a wall of fire around, and Glory I shall be in her midst.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">This is the only text of the prayer in Talmudic sources; it is quoted in the manuals of Rif (R. Isaac Fassi) and Rosh (R. Asher ben Yehiël). However, Maimonides has a different text from Gaonic sources and the currently used versions are derived from his. Also, most rituals have replaced רחם “have mercy” by נחם “console” as more appropriate in a prayer for Jerusalem.</i>”
Rebbi Eudaimon of Sepphoris<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the fifth generation, student of R. Mana.</i> asked before Rebbi Mana: Where does one say this? He said to him: You still do not understand? Anything for the future one says in “Service”<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">The 16th benediction in the Galilean service, a prayer for the restitution of the Temple service. In the opinion of the Yerushalmi, that is the correct place for the insertion of the prayer for the Ninth of Ab. However, in all historical documents we have from Gaonic times and later, the insertion is made in the 14th benediction, which is a prayer for the rebuilding of Jerusalem. This is either a popular custom or a Gaonic institution. It is justified since the place is fitting and the later discussion will show that occasional variations in the prayer text are welcomed.</i> and anything about the past one says in “Thanksgiving”<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">The 17th benediction, the natural place for the mention of the miracles of Ḥanukkah and Purim.</i>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.5.1">Mishnah (<i>Berakhot</i> 9:6</a>) says as much: “One gives thanks for the past and cries about the future.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">After the digression about prayers on special days one returns to the discussion of the Mishnah and the statement of Rebbi Joshua that a private prayer on weekdays is “similar to the eighteen benedictions” recited by the reader in public service.</i> What are “seven similar to eighteen”? Rav says the end of each benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Rav requires the first three and the last three benedictions in full and of the twelve benedictions in between only the final doxology of each: Praise to You, o Eternal, Who bestows knowledge as a favor. Praise to You, o Eternal, Who desires repentance, etc., without any other text.</i> and Samuel says the head of each benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Samuel also requires the first and last three benedictions in full but of the text of the intermediate ones only a few words, as explained in full in the next paragraph. The statements of Rav and Samuel are in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29a" href="/Berakhot.29a">Babli 29a</a>, the following connection with tannaïtic statements appears only in the Yerushalmi.</i>. Some formulate “seven similar to eighteen” and some formulate “eighteen similar to eighteen.”<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">The disagreement of Rav and Samuel did not originate with them, but they follow different tannaïtic traditions.</i> He who says “seven similar to eighteen” supports Samuel, he who says “eighteen similar to eighteen” supports Rav.
Rebbi Zeïra sent Rebbi Naḥum<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Probably identical with Rebbi Naḥum, the organizer of the Yeshivah of Rebbi Abbahu.</i> to Rebbi Yannai ben Rebbi Ismael and said to him: What are the “seven similar to eighteen” of Samuel? He said to him:<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">The text in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29a" href="/Berakhot.29a">Babli (29a</a>) is different but based on the same principles.</i> Give us understanding, have pleasure in our repentance, forgive us, redeem us, heal our sicknesses, bless our years [Rebbi Ḥaggai said, in the rainy season one says: with blessed rains, in the season of dew one says: with blessed dew<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29a" href="/Berakhot.29a">Babli (29a</a>) forbids the recitation of the shortened prayer in winter time because the change would disturb the memory of the person who prays. It seems that in Babylonia the text of the prayer for blessed agricultural years was similar to today’s Sephardic and Oriental versions where the summer prayer is short (in Rabbenu Saadia’s <i>siddur</i> 19 words) and the winter prayer is long (in Rabbenu Saadia’s <i>siddur</i> 48 words) and this change is not adaptable to the short prayer. In contrast, in the Ashkenazic tradition based on Yerushalmi sources, the difference between summer and winter prayer is just two words. One may note that the French <i>Maḥzor Vitry</i> from the school of Rashi combines the Babylonian text of הביננו with the Israeli versions for summer and winter and, hence, allows the short prayer for the entire year following the Jerusalem Talmud.</i>], for You gather in the dispersed, Yours it is to judge the misguided, put down Your hand on the wicked, but in You may rejoice all who hope for You to rebuild Your city, to renew Your Temple with the offspring of Your servant David, because before we call You will answer as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">The obligatory verse before the end of a longer benediction in the Israeli tradition. This verse is used in the middle of the currently used text of עננוּ on fast days.</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 65:24" href="/Isaiah.65.24"><i>Is.</i> 65:24</a>): “It shall be before they call that I shall answer, they still shall be talking while I will listen.” Praise to You, o Eternal, Who hears prayer. And he says the first three and the last three benedictions. And he says<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">As private prayer after all seven required prayers.</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 28:6" href="/Psalms.28.6"><i>Ps.</i> 28:6</a>): Praised be the Eternal, Who certainly hears the voice of my supplications.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Eliezer says: If one makes his prayers fixed, his prayer is not a supplication<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">The Gemara to this statement is found in the preceding Halakha.</i>. Rebbi Joshua says: He who passes through a place of danger recites a short prayer (similar to eighteen prayers)<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">This phrase is only found in Mishnah codices of the Israeli tradition, never in the Babylonian Mishnah. It seems that for R. Joshua in the Yerushalmi the short prayer is a replacement for Samuel’s text of the middle part of the short <i>Amidah</i> as explained here later by (the Babylonian!) Rav Ḥisda, but in Babylon it is interpreted as an independent prayer that must be complemented by a full <i>Amidah</i> once the danger has passed.</i> and says: Help, o Eternal, your people Israel; in all passing situations may their needs be before You. Praised are You, o Eternal, Who hears prayer (and entreaties)<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">This is only in the Mishnah text in the Yerushalmi Halakhah (not in the Mishnah preceding the Chapter) and in a few Mishnah manuscripts.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Eliezer says: If one makes his prayer fixed, his prayer is not supplication<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">This belongs to the next Mishnah; the paragraph explains this statement. Most newer editions of the Yerushalmi move the section from here to the end of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:3:2-4:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.3.2-4.5">Halakhah 3</a> or to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:4:6-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.4.6-11">Halakhah 4</a>. However, it seems that the error is not with the copyists of the Yerushalmi but with the copyists of the Mishnah and that the statement of Rebbi Eliezer belongs to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.3.1">Mishnah 3</a> where Rabban Gamliel says that everybody always prays 18 fixed benedictions. R. Joshua says everybody prays a shortened but fixed version, and R. Aqiba notes that one should follow either course depending on one’s knowledge. But Rebbi Eliezer insists that the appropriate form of prayer depends only on intent. In the first prints of the Babli, Soncino and Venice 5280, the statement of R. Eliezer belongs to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.3.1">Mishnah 3</a>.</i>.” Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Only that one should not be like one who reads a letter<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29b" href="/Berakhot.29b">Babli (29b</a>), it is the opinion of the anonymous rabbis that one should pronounce the prayers in form and intent of supplication.</i>. Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Yose: One has to say something new every day<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">While this explanation seems to fit best the standard Hebrew אין קבע, it appears in the Babli only as an opinion of the third generation Amoraïm Rabba and Rav Joseph, and here as an opinion of the fourth generation R. Yose; hence, it is not acceptable as original intention of R. Eliezer. R. Zera (= R. Zeïra) is also the one in the Babylonian Talmud who points out the practical impossibility of finding a new formulation in a fixed framework of 18 benedictions every day. One may also note that the statement of R. Simeon ben Nethanael (<i>Abot</i> 2:13) “do not make your prayer קבע” appears in <i>Abot deR. Nathan A</i> 17:8 as “do not make your prayer (idle) talk”; this agrees with the interpretation of Rebbi Eleazar.</i>. Aḥitophel<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">In Agadah, he is the paradigm of a person who knows everything.</i> used to say three new prayers every day. Rebbi Zeïra said: Any time that I was trying to do that, I was committing errors. Therefore, one has only what Rebbi Abbahu said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Only that one should not be like one who reads a letter. Rebbi Eleazar used to say a new prayer every day. Rebbi Abbahu used to recite a new benediction every day<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">While Rebbis Eleazar and Aḥa are the authors of the lenient interpretation, that the use of a formulaic text is accepted by all sages, they did not want to use this leniency for themselves, R. Eleazar for the <i>Amidah</i> prayer and R. Aḥa for any of the permanent benedictions, possibly those to be recited in the morning before prayer.</i>.
Rebbi Yose from Sidon<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Rebbi Jeremiah, from the city of Sidon. The statements of R. Yoḥanan are in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 9b" href="/Berakhot.9b">Babli 9b</a>. There the requirement of recitation of these verses is noted as “institutions of the Rabbis”; the Babli would not tolerate the action of Rebbi Yudan.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Before one’s prayer one says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 51:17" href="/Psalms.51.17"><i>Ps.</i> 51:17</a>) “Master, open my lips that my mouth may proclaim Your praise.” After one’s prayer, one says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 19:15" href="/Psalms.19.15"><i>Ps.</i> 19:15</a>): “May the sayings of my mouth be agreeable and the thoughts of my heart, before You, my Rock and my Redeemer.” Rebbi Yudan used to say both of them before his prayer.
If one was praying and remembered that he already had prayed, Rav says, he cuts short, and Samuel says, he does not cut short. Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">The statement of Rebbi Yoḥanan and his problem have been explained in Chapter One, Notes 16 ff. The shortened parallel to this and the following paragraph appear in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 21a" href="/Berakhot.21a">Babli 21a</a>.</i>: If only one would pray the whole day long, why, because prayer is never in vain. Rebbi Zeïra asked before Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rebbi Yasa (Assi).</i>: Did not Rebbi Yoḥanan say that if one is in doubt whether he did pray or not, that he should not pray? He did not give him an answer. Rebbi Abbahu came in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: If one is in doubt whether he did pray or not, he should not pray. Rebbi Ḥanina did not say so but: They asked before Rebbi Yoḥanan, if one is in doubt whether he did pray or not? He told them, if only one would pray the whole day long, why, because prayer is never in vain.
If one was standing praying on the Sabbath; he forgot about the Sabbath and prayed for weekday. Rebbi Ḥuna said, Rav Naḥman bar Jacob<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">He appears as Rav Naḥman in the Babli, a student of Samuel and of the <i>Resh Galuta</i> Rabba bar Abuh, who became his father-in-law and appointed Rav Naḥman as chief judge of the Jews in Babylonia. Hence, the opinions of Rav Naḥman have the weight of Supreme Court decisions in all money matters. He is reported in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 21a" href="/Berakhot.21a">Babli (21a</a>) to require that the benediction that was started must be finished. The contrary opinion, which therefore must be attributed to Rav Sheshet, is not mentioned in the Babli.</i> and Rav Sheshet<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Rav Sheshet was a contemporary of Rav Naḥman, a student of Rav. He was blind and the greatest expert in Tannaïtic literature in his time. In the Babli, it is a Gaonic tradition that in disagreements between Rav Sheshet and Rav Naḥman, practice follows Rav Sheshet in all matters that do not involve money. Hence, it is clear that the Babli, which wants to establish the rule that one must finish the benediction, cannot mention Rav Sheshet.</i> disagree, one says he cuts the benediction short and the other says, he finishes the benediction. All agree that he finishes “Gracious Giver of knowledge”<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">The first of the weekday benedictions, a prayer for knowledge and insight.</i>. This follows Rebbi, since Rebbi said: I wonder why they eliminated “Gracious Giver of knowledge” on Sabbath; if there is no knowledge, from where comes prayer? Rebbi Isaac said: Knowledge is great because it is in the middle between two mentions of divine names as it is said (<i>1Samuel</i> 2:3): “Certainly, a God of knowledge is the Eternal”. Some want to understand from here (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 2:5" href="/Proverbs.2.5"><i>Prov.</i>2:5</a>): “Then you will understand the fear of the Eternal and the knowledge of God you will find.”
Rebbi Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Any travel is presumed to be dangerous<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">And an occasion for the prayer of Rebbi Joshua.</i>. Rebbi Yannai, when he went abroad<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ξενία “hospitality; guest chamber”.</i>, commanded his household<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Made his will and settled his affairs as if he expected to die.</i>. Rebbi Mana commanded his household when he went to a bathhouse that was heated<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">In Roman thermal baths, the water was heated in a room directly below the sauna room. If the floor was falling down, the people in the sauna would be in danger of being burned to death. This does not apply to geothermal bathhouses as in Tiberias; he made his will only when he went to thermal baths that were artificially heated.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina the son of Rebbi Abbahu<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Son of Rebbi Abbahu of Caesarea; studied in Tiberias and became his father’s successor in Caesarea.</i>, Rebbi Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Every sickness is presumed to be dangerous.
<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Here starts the discussion of R. Joshua’s text, in particular the meaning of בכל שעת העיבור. The explanations of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29b" href="/Berakhot.29b">Babli (29b</a>) of this cryptic expression are varied and totally different. In Galilee, the reader passes (עובר) before the ark, in Babylonia he descends (יורד) before the ark. Hence, only in Galilee can the prayer of R. Joshua refer to the prayer of the cantor in the synagogue.</i> Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Assi: Everything that the representative of the congregation passes by before the Ark and requests the needs of Your people before You. Rebbi Phineas, Rebbi Levi, Rebbi Yoḥanan, in the name of Menaḥem from Gallia<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">A Tanna of the last generation. His sayings are usually transmitted by R. Yoḥanan.</i>: He<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">The person in charge of organizing services.</i> does not say to the one who steps before the Ark “come and pray for us” but “come and present our presentation<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">קרב may mean “battle” (explained here by “wars”) or “to come near” (explained by “pacify for us”) but in the liturgie sense, used here as main sense, it means a poem either inserted in the regular <i>Amidah</i> or replacing the <i>Amidah</i> prayer, as recognized by L. Ginzberg. Religious poetry was very important in Israel in these times; in Babylonia it was banned from synagogues except in the Yeshivah of Rav who was trained in Galilee. Hence, the Babylonian Talmud could not accept the interpretation given here.</i>, work our needs, wage our wars, pacify for us.”
Others say<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">This prayer is reported in Babylonian style (without the Biblical verse preceding the doxology) together with the prayers formulated by other rabbis in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29b" href="/Berakhot.29b">Babli 29b</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 3:7" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).3.7">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 3:7</a>. The statement that practice follows this text is Rav Huna’s in the Babli.</i>: “The needs of Your people are many and their minds are dull. May it be pleasure before You, o Eternal, our God and God of our fathers, that You may give every single creature its needs and to every single body according to his want. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 28:6" href="/Psalms.28.6"><i>Ps.</i> 28:6</a>) Praised be the Eternal, certainly He heard the sound of my supplications. Praised are You, o Eternal, Who hears prayer.” Rav Ḥisda said: Practice follows “others”. Rav Ḥisda said, the first and last three benedictions<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">The “short prayer” is the middle one between the first and the last three of the <i>Amidah</i>; see the commentary to the Mishnah.</i>.
Some Tannaïm have stated: One should first pray and then ask for one’s personal needs. Some Tannaïm have stated: One should first ask for one’s personal needs and then pray.<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 7b" href="/Avodah_Zarah.7b">Babli <i>Avodah zarah</i> 7b</a>, the first opinion is R. Joshua’s, the second one R. Eliezer’s. [If the Yerushalmi had mentioned the names, the order of the <i>baraitot</i> would have been inverted.] R. Joshua, whose opinion always prevails against R. Eliezer, requires that private prayers be said following completion of the prescribed 18 benedictions. This is accepted as a possible practice in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 8a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.8a">Babli <i>Avodah zarah</i> 8a</a>.</i> He who says, one should first pray and then ask for one’s personal needs (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 102:1" href="/Psalms.102.1"><i>Ps.</i> 102:1</a>) “Prayer of the deprived one who wraps himself up<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Usually translated: “who faints”, but used here in the sense of “who wraps himself in his prayer coat or shawl.” The Babli uses the verse for the opposite argument since “prayer” is mentioned first.</i>” and afterwards “and before the Eternal he pours out his speech.” But he who says, one should first ask for one’s personal needs and then pray, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 8:28" href="/I_Kings.8.28"><i>1Kings</i> 8:28</a>) “To listen to lamentation<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 31a" href="/Berakhot.31a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 31a</a>) is forced to re-interpret רנה as “prayer”.</i>” and after that “and to prayer.” The opinion of the sages<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">The consensus of the Amoraïm.</i>: Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav Ḥuna, the private person asks for his personal needs in “He Who hears prayer”<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">But public entreaties are said either in the form of extra benedictions for rain fasts, or as penitential prayers in the sixth benediction “Merciful, Who forgives much.”</i>.
Rebbi Abba, Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ḥiyya bar Abba.</i>, in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: A person has to pray at a place that is dedicated for prayer. What is the reason? (<i>Ex.</i> 20:24) “At every place where I shall let My name be mentioned<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">The verse ends: “I shall come there and bless you.” One has to pray in the synagogue because only there is God’s blessing guaranteed for one’s prayers.</i>.” It does not say “where you will mention” but “at every place where I shall let My name be mentioned.” Rebbi Tanḥum bar Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Probably identical with Rebbi Tanḥum bar Ḥanilaï, a specialist in Aggadah in the second generation who was in contact both with R. Yoḥanan and with R. Joshua ben Levi, as well as with R. Ḥiyya bar Abba of the following generation. A statement similar to his, but not restricted to a synagogue, is attributed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 6b" href="/Berakhot.6b">Babli (6b</a>) to R. Ḥelbo in the name of Rav Huna.</i> said: A person has to select a fixed place in the synagogue where he prays. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 15:32" href="/II_Samuel.15.32"><i>2Sam.</i> 15:32</a>) “David came to the top”, it does not say “where he prostrated himself before God” but “where he was used to prostrate himself before God.”
Rebbi Yasa, Rebbi Ḥelbo. Rebbi Berekhiah, Rebbi Ḥelbo comes to it in the name of Rebbi Eudaimon from Ḥaifa: A person has to turn his face to the wall in order to pray. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 38:2" href="/Isaiah.38.2"><i>Is.</i> 38:2</a>) “Hezekiah turned his face to the wall.” Which wall did he lift his eyes to? Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, he lifted his eyes to Raḥab’s wall, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 2:15" href="/Joshua.2.15"><i>Jos.</i> 2:15</a>) “For her house was on the wall of the fortification.” He said before Him: Master of the world, Raḥab the inn-keeper saved two souls for You, and see how many souls You saved for her. [That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 6:23" href="/Joshua.6.23"><i>Jos.</i>6:23</a>): “The youths came, etc.” Rebbi Simeon bar Yoḥai said, even if her family was 200 persons strong and they furthermore were related to another 200 families, all of these were saved by her merit<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">The argument, as usual, refers to the part of the verse not quoted in the text: “The youths, the spies, came and removed Raḥab, her father, her mother, her brothers, and all her belongings; and they removed <i>all her families</i> and deposited them outside of the camp of Israel.” One would have expected “all her family” but it says “all her families”.</i>.] My forefathers who brought to You all these proselytes, so much more<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">This expression is elliptic, see the last two paragraphs.</i>. Rebbi Ḥananiah bar Pappus<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, he is called Rebbi Ḥanina bar Pappus. He belongs to the circle of the students of R. Yoḥanan, but it is not known whether he was himself one of the latter’s students. His authority was accepted by Abbaie and Rava, the undisputed leaders of the fourth generation of Amoraïm in Babylonia.</i> said, he lifted his eyes to the wall of the Temple. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 43:8" href="/Ezekiel.43.8"><i>Ez.</i> 43:8</a>) “When they put their lintel next to My lintel, their doorposts next to My doorpost, with the wall between Me and them<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">This verse ends with a curse upon the people addressed, the bad kings of Judea. But since the royal palace and the Temple were designed by David and built by Solomon, one must assume that the layout and use were done by praiseworthy kings.</i>.” They were important people, they could not go and pray in the Temple every time, so they prayed in their house and the Holy One, praise to Him, considers it as if they had prayed in the Temple. My fathers who built for You all this glory, so much more. Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 10b" href="/Berakhot.10b">Babli (10b</a>), this sermon is by Rebbi Levi and the following one by R. Simeon ben Laqish.</i> said, he lifted his eyes to the wall of the woman from Sunem, as it was said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 4:10" href="/II_Kings.4.10"><i>2Kings</i> 4:10</a>): “Let us make a small upper storey on the wall”. He said before Him: Master of the world, the woman from Sunem made one wall for Elisha and You revived her son. My forefathers who built for You all this glory, so much more that You should give me my life. The rabbis say, he lifted his eyes to the walls of his heart. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 4:19" href="/Jeremiah.4.19"><i>Jer.</i> 4:19</a>) “My innards, my innards I make tremble, the walls of my heart are in uproar.” He said before Him: Master of the world, I checked all my 248 limbs<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">This number is given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Oholot 1:8" href="/Mishnah_Oholot.1.8">Mishnah <i>Ahilut</i> 1:8</a> where they are all enumerated in anatomic detail.</i> that You gave me and I did not find one of them I offended You with; so much more that You should give me my life.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If one was riding on a donkey<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">If it is close to the end of the time alotted for the prayer, so that he must pray now.</i>, he should descend. If he cannot descend<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Either because of danger or because he is in a caravan that would not stop.</i>, he should turn his head; if he cannot even turn his head, he should focus his intent towards the Holiest of Holies<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">In praying, he should imagine himself praying in the direction of the Temple.</i>. If he was riding in a ship or on a raft, he should focus his intent towards the Holiest of Holies.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> It has been stated<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 3:18" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).3.18">Tosephta <i>Berakot</i> 3:18</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 30a" href="/Berakhot.30a">Babli 30a</a> (in slightly changed wording).</i>: One who was riding on a donkey, if he has somebody to hold his donkey, he should descend and pray on the ground, otherwise he should pray where he is. Rebbi says, in any case he should pray where he is because then his mind will be at peace<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">This is explained in <i>Midrash Tanḥuma, Ḥayye Śarah</i> 1: He should not descend because he will be worried about valuables he has on the donkey or because of Gentiles.</i>. Rebbi Judah ben Pazi in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Practice follows Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">This ruling is given in the Babli in the names of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi and Rava. Since the Babylonian Rava (son of Rav Joseph bar Ḥama, the last Babylonian mentioned in the Yerushalmi) lived about 100 years after R. Joshua ben Levi, it appears that it took about 100 years for this Israeli practice to be accepted in Babylonia.</i>.
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa: It has been stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia, where the direction towards the Temple in Jerusalem would be to the West.</i>, in all directions one does not stop him except in the Eastern direction<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">When somebody turns his back to Jerusalem, he cannot pray. This formulation is not mentioned in the Babli except that the blind Rav Sheshet ordered his servant not to let him pray in an Eastern direction because that was a Christian custom (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 25a" href="/Bava_Batra.25a"><i>Bava Batra</i> 25a</a>).</i>. Rebbi Yose bar Abun said, as of old (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 8:16" href="/Ezekiel.8.16"><i>Ez.</i> 8:16</a>)<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">In Ezechiel’s vision of all the abominations for which Jerusalem will be destroyed.</i>: “Their backs to the Temple of the Eternal and their faces turned East, they were prostrating themselves Eastwards before the sun.”
It has been stated<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Shortened versions are in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 3:13-16" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).3.13-16">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 3:13–16</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 30a" href="/Berakhot.30a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 30a</a>; the entire text to the end of the Halakhah is in <i>Shir rabba</i> 4:11 with minor deviations. The tradition of the verses is somewhat garbled in order to make the point of the derivation clearer.</i>: One who is blind and one who cannot determine directions should have in mind to pray to Heaven as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 8:44" href="/I_Kings.8.44"><i>1Kings</i> 8:44</a>) “They shall pray to the Eternal”. Those who are praying outside the Land turn their faces towards the Land of Israel. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 8:48" href="/I_Kings.8.48"><i>1Kings</i> 8:48</a>) “They will pray to You through their Land that You gave to their forefathers.” Those who are praying in the Land of Israel turn their faces towards Jerusalem. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 6:34" href="/II_Chronicles.6.34"><i>2Chr.</i> 6:34</a>) “They shall pray to You by way of this city that You chose.” Those who are praying in Jerusalem turn their faces towards the Temple Mount, as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 8:48" href="/I_Kings.8.48"><i>1Kings</i> 8:48</a>): “And the Temple that I built for Your Name.” Those who are praying on the Temple Mount turn their faces towards the Holiest of Holies. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 8:30" href="/I_Kings.8.30"><i>1Kings</i> 8:30</a>) “They will pray to this place and You will hear at Your dwelling place in Heaven, You will hear and forgive.” Those who stand North will be facing South, those who stand South will be facing North, those who stand East will be facing West, those who stand West will be facing East. It turns out that all of Israel pray towards one place. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 56:7" href="/Isaiah.56.7"><i>Is.</i> 56:7</a>) “For My house will be called a house of prayer for all people.”
Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 6:17" href="/I_Kings.6.17"><i>1Kings</i> 6:17</a>) “That is the Temple לִפְנָי”, Inside<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">The word לפנים is missing in the Rome manuscript and in the quotes in Yalqut; it seems to be a marginal gloss that found its way into the text, to explain the unintelligible term לִפְנָי that in <i>1Kings</i> really seems to mean what Rabbinic לִפְנִים “inside” expresses. [There is an expression in the Babylonian Talmud for the Holiest of Holies, לפני ולפנים, which probably should be vocalized לִפְנָי וְלִפְנִים, based on this Yerushalmi.] The explanation here suggests to read לִפְנָי as shorthand for לְפָנִים פּוֹנִים, “for faces to turn.”</i>. A Temple towards which all turn. So far when it<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">The Temple. The problem is, how do we know to pray in the direction of the Temple after its destruction.</i> is standing. In its destruction, from where? Rebbi Abun said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Song of Songs 4:4" href="/Song_of_Songs.4.4"><i>Cant.</i> 4:4</a>): “Built for <i>talpiot</i>”, a mound (תל) on which all mouths (פיות) pray, in Grace, recitation of <i>Shema</i>, and <i>Amidah</i>. In Grace, “Builder of Jerusalem”. In <i>Amidah</i>, “God of David Who builds Jerusalem<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">The standard Yerushalmi ending for benediction 14, see above Note 146.</i>”. In the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>, “He Who spreads a hut of peace over us and His people Israel, Consoler of Zion and Builder of Jerusalem.<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">The first part of this blessing is the Babylonian (current) version of the second benediction after the <i>Shema‘</i> on Sabbaths and holidays. The entire benediction was the Yerushalmi version for everyday. The phrase “Consoler of Zion” is missing in the Leyden manuscript and Venice print but it is in the Rome manuscript and Genizah fragments and is supported by what is known of the Israeli prayer rites in the times of the Cairo Genizah.</i>”
One verse says (<i>Hosea</i> 5:19) “I shall go, I shall return to My place”. Another verse says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 9:3" href="/I_Kings.9.3"><i>1Kings</i> 9:3</a>) “My eyes and attention shall be there forever.” How is that? One’s face upwards, one’s eyes and attention downwards<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">(The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 105b" href="/Yevamot.105b">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 105b</a>, replaces the verse from Hosea by one from Threni. The ruling here is credited there to R. Yose the Tanna.) The two verses speak of God. The first asserts that God has left the earth and is found only in Heaven, the second that God’s attention is always given to the Temple here on earth. Since prayer adresses God, it is necessary to adress it in the correct direction and how can one pray in two distinct directions?</i>.
“And if not he should focus his intent towards the Holiest of Holies.<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">This is a shortened quote from the Mishnah, about the person who cannot stand and pray in the direction of the Temple.</i>” Toward which Holiest of Holies? The Great Rebbi Ḥiyya: towards the Heavenly Holiest of Holies. Rebbi Simeon ben Ḥalaphta said, towards the earthly Holiest of Holies. Rebbi Phineas said, they do not disagree, the earthly Holiest of Holies corresponds to the Heavenly Holiest of Holies. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 15:16" href="/Exodus.15.16"><i>Ex.</i> 15:16</a>) “A base for Your throne”, corresponding to Your throne<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Phineas takes מכון to be derived not from the Biblical Hebrew root כון “to be based, solid”, but from Aramaic/Rabbinic Hebrew כון “to direct”.</i>.
(<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 3:1" href="/II_Chronicles.3.1"><i>2Chr.</i> 3:1</a>) On Mount Moriah<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">This Aggadah is a continuation of the previous discussion about the place of the Holiest of Holies, which was on Mount Moriah. An enlarged parallel is in <i>Berešit rabba</i> 55(9); a very shortened version is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 16a" href="/Taanit.16a">Babli <i>Taänit</i> 16a</a>.<br>מוֹריה is taken either from the root הוֹרה “to teach, direct” or from מוֹרָא “fear”. ארוֹן is taken either as abstractum from אוֹר “light” or from ארה “to curse” (the unbelievers). The use of דִּבֵּר “Divine inspiration” in the explanation of דביר is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 5:13" href="/Jeremiah.5.13"><i>Jer.</i> 5:13</a>. דבר denoting one of the Ten Commandments is found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 4:13" href="/Deuteronomy.4.13"><i>Deut.</i> 4:13</a>.</i>. The Great Rebbi Ḥiyya and Rebbi Yannai, one of them said that from there teaching goes out to the world, the other one said that from there fear goes out to the world. Ark. The Great Rebbi Ḥiyya and Rebbi Yannai, one of them said that from there light goes out to the world, the other one said that from there curse goes out to the world. Temple Hall. Rebbi Ḥiyya and Rebbi Yannai, one of them said that from there inspiration goes out to the world, the other one said that from there the commandments go out to the world.
<i>Assada</i> is the same as σχεδία, which is the same as <i>raphsodot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">The end of the Halakhah explains the unusual word used for “raft” at the end of the Mishnah. The verse refers to the logs of cedar delivered by Hiram of Tyre to Solomon for the building of the Temple.</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 2:15" href="/II_Chronicles.2.15"><i>2Chr.</i> 2:15</a>) “We shall bring them to you as rafts.”

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah says, <i>Musaph</i> prayer is said only in an organized community, but the Sages say, with and without an organized community. Rebbi Yehudah says in his name<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah’s name. He disputes the tradition in the name of R. Eleazar that <i>Musaph</i> cannot be recited outside an organized community. According to Rebbi Yehudah, <i>Musaph</i> has to be recited everywhere, but in a town with an organized synagogue it is enough to listen to the public prayer of the reader that he recited without a corresponding silent prayer of the congregation.</i>, at any place where there is an organized community a private person is free from reciting <i>Musaph</i> prayers.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Bibi<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Probably his name was Vivianus, an Amora of the third generation. Rebbi Ḥana’s name appears twice in the Talmudim; he seems to have been a student of Rebbi Jeremiah. Neither Rebbi Bibi nor Rebbi Ḥana are great authorities. In the Babli (30a-b), the author of the ruling is Ḥiyya, the son of Rav.</i> in the name of Rebbi Ḥana: Practice follows Rebbi Yehudah who said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah. What we know of Samuel means the same; for Samuel said: I never prayed <i>Musaph</i> except once when the son of the <i>Resh Galuta</i> died and there was no public prayer, then I prayed<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">The story of Samuel in the Babli refers to a time when there was a military occupation of Nahardea.</i>.
The words of the rabbis disagree since Rebbi Jacob bar Idi said in the name of Rebbi Simeon the pious<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the first Galilean generation.</i>: For shepherds and field guards<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Persons whose occupation prevents them from going to the synagogue. They probably were unable to pray <i>Musaph</i> by themselves since they were uneducated and prayerbooks were unknown at the time. Other uneducated people can attend the synagogue and fulfill their duty by attentively follow the reader’s repetition of the prayer word-by-word, but not shepherds and watchmen; hence a way has to be found to help them.</i>. Hence, the Mishnah spoke only for shepherds and field guards; therefore, everybody else is obliged.
