The words of Rebbi Yoḥanan agree since Rebbi Yoḥanan said: I saw Rebbi Yannai standing in the market of Sepphoris praying; then he walked four cubits and prayed <i>Musaph</i><sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">A shortened version, speaking only about the <i>Musaph</i> prayer, is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 30b" href="/Berakhot.30b">Babli 30b</a>. In both Talmudim, it is clear that the sages who reject R. Yehudah’s tradition are Galilean in the tradition of R. Yannai.</i>. Is there no organized community in Sepphoris? You infer from this three conclusions. You infer that the markets of Sepphoris have the status of Sepphoris<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">“Organized community” refers to the whole town and not only to the buildings that are the property of the Jewish community.</i>. You infer that one disagrees with Rebbi Yehudah who spoke in the name of Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah. You infer that a person may pray, walk four cubits, and then pray <i>Musaph</i>. Rebbi Abba said, not necessarily four cubits but even if he waited the time necessary to walk four cubits<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 30b" href="/Berakhot.30b">Babli (30b</a>) requires time to concentrate one’s attention without giving a numerical estimate; that tradition is in the name of the Babylonian Rav Huna and the Babylonian-born Rebbi Ḥiyya. One may assume that the statement of Rebbi Abba reflects the opinions of his teacher Rav Huna.</i>.
Rav says, one must change the text<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Since the <i>Musaph</i> sacrifices are distinct for every holiday, the prayer must accomodate this distinction.</i>, but Samuel says, one does not have to change the text. Rebbi Zeïra asked before Rebbi Yose: What is the practice, to change the text? He said to him: even if one said only: “And we shall bring before You what is our duty, the perpetual sacrifice of the day and the <i>Musaph</i> sacrifices<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Every holiday has its own set of <i>Musaph</i> sacrifices but the language is uniform for all holidays. A <i>Musaph</i> prayer is acceptable if the sentence quoted here is the only addition to the <i>Amidah</i> prayer for holidays, cf. Ezra Fleischer, תפילה ומנהגי תפילה ארץ־ישראליים בתקופת הגניזה, Jerusalem 1988.</i>”, he has satisfied his duty.
Rebbi Shila<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">The head of the Yeshivah of Nahardea at the end of the Mishnaic period. His title shows that he must have studied and obtained ordination in the Land of Israel.</i> in the name of Rav Ḥananel<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">He appears in both Talmudim as a student of Rav, who was younger than Rebbi Shila. The tradition here is difficult to accept but is not impossible; it might be that Rebbi Shila accepted the position of the school of Rav in this matter. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 21" href="/Berakhot.21">Babli (21a/b</a>) quotes only the position of Samuel that one may repeat prayer with the community only if one is able to pray a new text, different from the one already used. The tradition here seems to be based on the opinion, rejected in the Babli, that private prayer is considered nonexistent if compared to prayer in public with a quorum of ten adult males.</i>: If he had prayed and found ten people who were praying, he prays with them. Rebbi Zeïra and Rav Naḥman bar Jacob were sitting. After they had prayed there came prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">The congregation assembling for public prayer. The entire story happens in Babylonia; Rebbi Zeïra represents the opinion of Samuel and Rav Naḥman that of Rav.</i>. Rav Naḥman bar Jacob got up and prayed. Rebbi Zeïra said to him: Did we not pray already? He said to him: I pray and pray again, since Rebbi Shila said in the name of Rav Ḥananel: If he had prayed and found ten people who were praying, he would pray with them.
Rebbi Aḥa, Rebbi Jonah, in the name of Rebbi Zeïra: If one had said the morning prayers and came and found them praying <i>Musaph</i>, he prays with them. If he did not pray the morning prayers and came and found them praying <i>Musaph</i>, if he knows that he may start and finish<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">The morning prayer that has to precede <i>Musaph</i>.</i> before the reader begins and he can answer “Amen”, he may start, otherwise he may not start. About<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Since one speaks about <i>Musaph</i> prayer that has only seven benedictions, the paragraph is out of place. It is copied word by word from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:2:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.2.2-5">Halakhah 3:2</a>.</i> which “Amen” did they talk? Two Amoraïm, one says the Amen of “the holy King” and the other says the Amen of “He Who listens to prayer”. Rebbi Phineas said, they do not disagree. He who said: the Amen of “the holy King”, on Sabbath, and he who said: the Amen of “He Who listens to prayer”, on weekdays.
There<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">In the last Mishnah of <i>Rosh Hashanah</i>. The entire piece is from the end of tractate <i>Rosh Hashanah</i>; at two places where the text of the Venice print here deviates from the one in <i>Rosh Hashanah</i>, the text follows the latter version. (The first, “Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel” instead of “Rabban Gamliel” is a clear scribal error, the second אתת for את is an echo of the previous story of R. Zeïra and Rav Naḥman.)</i> we have stated: Rabban Gamliel says, the reader frees the public from their obligation<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah deals with the <i>Musaph</i> prayer of New Year’s day which contains nine benedictions; each of the middle benedictions requires the quoting of at least 10 verses from the Bible. In the absence of prayerbooks, that prayer was possible only for learned specialists. In the time of later Gaonim (<i>Oẓar Hagĕonim Rosh Hashanah</i>, p. 68–69), two different Babylonian practices are reported. One, which seems to be alluded to in Babli <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 35a, is that individuals first prayed a silent <i>Musaph</i> prayer of the usual seven benedictions for holidays and then listened to the nine benedictions of the reader (with shofar blowing) from beginning to end. The second, which seems to be alluded to here, was that there was no silent <i>Musaph</i> prayer at all on <i>Rosh Hashanah</i>.</i>. The older Rebbi Huna from Sepphoris in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Practice follows Rabban Gamliel for the prayer accompanying the blowing of the Shofar<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah of Rabban Gamliel deals only with <i>Musaph</i> of Rosh Hashanah. From the statement of Rebbi Huna it seems that Rabban Gamliel held that a private person, even if educated, never needs to pray <i>Musaph</i> if he listens attentively to the reader in the synagogue. This remains a conjecture in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 34b-35a" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.34b-35a">Babli (<i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 34b–35a</a>).</i>. Rebbi Zeïra and Rav Ḥisda were sitting there<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. Perhaps “staying” would be better than “sitting”.</i> for the blowing of the Shofar. After they finished the prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">From the following, it seems clear that they did not pray <i>Musaph</i> for themselves but listened to the reader from start to end.</i>, Rav Ḥisda got up and prayed. Rebbi Zeïra said to him: Did we not pray just now? He said to him, I prayed and I am repeating the prayer, because Westerners came down and said in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Practice follows Rabban Gamliel for the prayer accompanying the blowing of the Shofar, but I was inattentive. If I had been attentive, I would have fulfilled my duty. Rebbi Zeïra said, that is fine<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Since Rav Ḥisda, the head of a Yeshivah, certainly is competent to recite his own nine benedictions for <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> from memory.</i>. All Tannaïm<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">These <i>Tannaïm</i> are not the teachers of the Mishnaic period but the people who memorize Mishnah and <i>baraitot</i> to recite them in the Yeshivah when they are needed.</i> state it in the name of Rabban Gamliel, Rebbi Hoshaia states it in the name of the Sages<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Most Tannaïm imply that in the days of Rabban Gamliel his opinion was a minority opinion, which became generally accepted only through the decision of Rebbi Yoḥanan. Rebbi Hoshaiah implies that Rabban Gamliel’s was the generally accepted practice already in Mishnaic times.</i>. Rebbi Ada from Caesarea<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">Another student of R. Yoḥanan, of the third generation of Galilean Amoraïm.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: This is only if he attended from the start. Rebbi Tanḥum said, the Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 4:5, implying that the prayer is valid only if it is recited in the correct order. Hence, it is valid for the listener only if he listened in the correct order, starting from the very first word.</i> expresses this: The order of benediction, one says “Forefathers”, “Greatness”, and “Sanctification of the Name”.

Chapter 5



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One starts to pray only in a serious frame of mind. The first <i>Ḥasidim</i> waited one hour<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In preparation, reciting Psalms.</i> before praying in order to be able to concentrate. Even if the king greets one, he should not respond. Even if a snake is wound around one’s heel<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in the Halakhah, if one sees a snake attacking from a distance one must interrupt and flee, or kill the snake. The Mishnah speaks only about the snake already being wound around his leg without biting; probably that is a nonpoisonous snake.</i>, he should not interrupt.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Abba: Prayer is forbidden to him who comes from a trip. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 51:21" href="/Isaiah.51.21"><i>Is.</i> 51:21</a>) “Listen to that, poor woman, drunk and not from wine.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">This proves that there is drunkenness not induced by alcohol. Formal prayer, the <i>Amidah</i>, is forbidden to a drunk. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 65a" href="/Eruvin.65a">Babli (<i>Eruvin</i> 65a</a>) even notes that after a lengthy caravan trip one needs three days to get one’s thoughts together.</i>” Rebbi Zeriqan, Rebbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rebbi Eliezer, son of Rebbi Yose the Galilean<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Tanna of the fourth generation, active in the aftermath of the war of Bar Kokhba. He tried to systematize aggadic interpretation of the Bible.</i>: Prayer is forbidden to one in pain; is that not our verse: “Listen to that, poor woman, drunk and not from wine”?
It is stated<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">We have three versions of this formulation, in the Yerushalmi, the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 31a" href="/Berakhot.31a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 31a</a>), and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 3:21" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).3.21">Tosephta (3:21</a>). The main difference in formulation is between the Tosephta and the Talmudim, since the Tosephta requires that one start prayer מתיך דברים של חכמה. In Mishnaic Hebrew, as in Modern Sephardic Hebrew usage, the <i>Ḥakham</i> is the rabbi, and <i>dibrē ḥokhmāh</i> are halakhic rulings; as in the following paragraph, practices universally accepted and not subject to doubt or discussion. From the order of the Yerushalmi it seems that in practice the text of the Yerushalmi should be interpreted as implying the statement of the Tosephta. The tradition of the Babli is uncertain; see <i>Diqduqe Soferim, Berakhot</i>, p. 160, note ר. The Venice print of the Babli requires that one start prayer “out of joy over commandments”. Rashi, the Munich manuscript of the Babli, Halakhot Gedolot and the students of Rabbenu Jonah have simply “out of joy.” The Koronel manuscript and <i>Menorat Hamaör</i> have “out of joy of Torah”, parallel to the Yerushalmi. A Florence manuscript that is typically Sephardic has “out of joy of Halakhah”, directly parallel to the Tosephta. Rabbenu Asher ben Yeḥiel (Rosh) has “out of words of joy”; the insistence on “words” is parallel to Yerushalmi and Tosephta. While the Babli in the printed version would refer to the state of mind required for the <i>Amidah</i>, as implied in the two rulings preceding this Tosephta in the Yerushalmi, the Tosephta and the Yerushalmi require the correct state of mind before one starts with the preparatory sections of prayer, even preceding the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>. This seems also to be confirmed by the preparatory prayer reported later by R. Ḥizqiah in the name of R. Abbahu. Most of the variants of the Babli text would demand an interpretation similar to that of the Tosephta. All three versions agree that one should start afternoon prayers with a word of Torah or Halakhah directly before the <i>Amidah</i>.</i>: “One should pray neither out of conversation, nor out of jokes, nor out of frivolities, nor out of idle occupations, but out of words of Torah. Similarly, one should not take leave from one’s friend either out of conversation, or out of jokes, or out of frivolities, or out of idle occupations, but out of words of Torah, since we find that the earlier prophets were closing their words with expressions of praise and consolation.” Rebbi Eleazar said, except for Jeremiah who closed with words of reprobation. Rebbi Yoḥanan said to him, still he closed with words of consolation and said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 51:64" href="/Jeremiah.51.64"><i>Jer.</i> 51:64</a>) “So Babylon shall sink.” Because Jeremiah continued to prophesy about the Temple. One could think that he closed with the destruction of the Temple, but the verse states (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 51:64" href="/Jeremiah.51.64"><i>Jer.</i> 51:64</a>) “So far the words of Jeremiah,” he finished with the downfall of its destroyers, he did not close with words of reprobation<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The last chapter of the book of Jeremiah is not attributed by the Talmud to Jeremiah; it is a historical addition by the editor, Barukh ben Neriah.</i>. But is it not written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 66:24" href="/Isaiah.66.24"><i>Is.</i> 66:24</a>): “They will be a horror for all flesh?<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Last verse in Isaiah.</i>” That verse deals with Gentiles. But is it not written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Lamentations 5:22" href="/Lamentations.5.22"><i>Lament.</i> 5:22</a>): “But You much despised us<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Last verse of Lamentations. A possible interpretation of the statement is that the last two verses of the book, chapter 5, were considered as one; then the book ends with a prayer.</i>”? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Lamentations 5:21" href="/Lamentations.5.21"><i>Lament.</i> 5:21</a>) “Make us return” replaces “But You much despised us”. Also Elijah did take leave from Elisha only out of words of Torah, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 2:11" href="/II_Kings.2.11"><i>2Kings</i> 2:11</a>) “they walked talking.” What did they talk of? Rebbi Aḥawa the son of Rebbi Zeïra<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, his name is R. Ahavah, son of Rebbi Zera, son of the famous Rebbi Zeïra. He was <i>Tanna</i>, a memorizer of tannaitic material, in his father’s Yeshivah. The entire section is a digression induced by the ancillary statements of the Tosephta.</i> said, they discussed the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:7" href="/Deuteronomy.6.7"><i>Deut.</i> 6:7</a>) “you should talk about them.” Rebbi Judah ben Pazi said, they were discussing Creation, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 33:6" href="/Psalms.33.6"><i>Ps.</i> 33:6</a>) “through the word of the Eternal the heavens were made.” Rebbi Yudan, the son of Rebbi Ayvu<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Ayvu was one of the main promoters of <i>Aggadah</i> in the third generation of Amoraïm. He learned from all Galilean Amoraïm of the second generation. His son Rebbi Yudan might be the Rebbi Yudan who otherwise is quoted without mention of his father’s name.</i>, said, they were occupied with the consolations of Jerusalem, as you say (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 40:2" href="/Isaiah.40.2"><i>Is.</i> 40:2</a>) “Speak to Jerusalem’s heart.” But the rabbis say, they were occupied with the Divine Chariot, as you say (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 2:11" href="/II_Kings.2.11"><i>2Kings</i> 2:11</a>) “behold, a chariot of fire and horses of fire, etc.”
Rav Jeremiah said, one should start to pray only from a practical rule<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 31a" href="/Berakhot.31a">Babli (31a</a>), this is a <i>baraita</i> and is considered a contrast to, not an explanation of, the requirement of the Mishnah that one pray only in a serious frame of mind. In the Yerushalmi it is considered to be the genuine interpretation of the Mishnah. דין של הלכה means a practical ruling that is well established, that gives no cause for discussion which could interfere with the concentration needed for prayer. The Babli and the personalities whose practices in preparation of prayer are reported are so early that the name here must be Rav Jeremiah and not Rebbi Jeremiah.</i>. Rav Jeremiah said, he who deals with public needs is like him who studies Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">This Halakhah is not found in the Babli, so it is accepted there.</i>. Rav Ḥuna said: a woman who saw a spot like a mustard seed sits and watches seven days of purification because of it<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">This appears in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 31a" href="/Berakhot.31a">Babli (31a</a>) in the name of Rav Huna’s student Rebbi Zeïra. A menstruating woman is ritually unclean and prohibited from having sexual contact until seven days have passed. On the other hand, a woman having a discharge looking like blood is subject to quite different rules that are more lenient for an occasional occurence and much more strict for recurrent discharges. A decision about the character of the discharge can be made only by a competent rabbi. In theory all women should show their discharges to a rabbi. Even in the time of the Temple, that was a practice only of wives of Cohanim who had to minimize their time of impurity by all means. It may be assumed that all other women chose to follow the method described here, to consider any discharge as a recurrent discharge and to wait seven days after the last day of discharge. In that way, no problems arise that would require a rabbi in intimate matters. Since this is a stringency adopted by Jewish women in excess of the strict Biblical law, there cannot be any rabbinic discussion about limits or details.</i>; then he stood up and prayed. Zeïra bar Ḥinena<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Galilean Amora of the second generation. He was once imprisoned by Zenobia, queen of Palmyra, and saved by the intervention of Rebbi Ammi and Rebbi Samuel. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 31a" href="/Berakhot.31a">Babli (31a</a>) is ascribed to Zeïri, a contemporary of Zeïra and student of Rav.</i> said: He who draws blood from a dedicated animal committed larceny<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">An animal dedicated as sacrifice in the Temple cannot be used for any other purpose whatsoever, not even to draw blood from it.</i>; that is one of the decided practices. Bar Qappara stated: Eleven days between periods is a practice taught to Moses at Sinai<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">If a woman has a discharge between the 8th and the 19th day of the begin of her last period, that discharge cannot be menstrual blood and must be treated by the rules of -זבה discharge. This is a tradition ascribed to Moses and, therefore, is a fact not subject to discussion.</i>. Rebbi Hoshaiah stated: One may add produce on the stalk and be tricky in order to free it from tithes<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Grain is subject to <i>Terumah</i> and tithes after the harvest, when it is separated from the stalk and collected in heaps or silos. By a rabbinic ordinance, it is forbidden to eat grain on the stalk as a meal, once it has been transported from the field to the farmhouse or barn. However, eating it as snack from the grain on the stalk is still permitted. Now Rebbi Hoshaiah approves of setting aside as much of the produce for animal feed as one desires, without incurring an obligation for <i>Terumah</i> and tithes. This is also quoted as beyond doubt in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 31a" href="/Berakhot.31a">Babli 31a</a>.</i>. Abdan asked Rebbi: How many levels<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Of derivative impurity. If originally impure matter (אב הטומאה “father of impurity”) touches something that can become impure, the latter becomes “first in impurity”. If a “first in impurity” touches other secular matter, nothing happens except if that matter is food, it will become “second in impurity”. If “second in impurity” touches anything secular, nothing happens, but if it touches either <i>terumah</i> or sacrificial meat, these become “third in impurity”. Sacrifial meat only can become “fourth in impurity” which will make it unusable either for the altar or for consumption by Cohanim. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Chagigah 2:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Chagigah.2.3.1">Mishnah <i>Ḥagigah</i> 2:3</a>, <i>Tahorot</i> 2:1). The additional levels of impurity are a rabbinic institution, not subject to discussion.</i> are there for dedicated things? He answered him: four. And how many levels for <i>Terumah</i>? He answered: three, then he stood up and prayed.
Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: The following verse should never leave your lips<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning, they should be mentioned in every prayer service. However, in current rituals, the verses are used only in the morning service and the קדושה דסדרא.</i>: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 46:12" href="/Psalms.46.12"><i>Ps.</i> 46:12</a>) “The Eternal of hosts is with us, the God of Jacob is a refuge to us, Selah”. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abin, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan and the colleagues: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 84:13" href="/Psalms.84.13"><i>Ps.</i> 84:13</a>) “O Eternal of hosts, hail to the man who trusts in You”.
Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: May it be please You, o Eternal, our God and God of our fathers, that You may save us from agressive, hard, evil hours that organize to come upon the world<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">This is clearly a supplication to be recited before the start of formal prayers, see the discussion above; in our prayerbooks its equivalent is a modification of a prayer of Rav (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 16b" href="/Berakhot.16b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 16b</a>).</i>.
“One starts to pray only in a serious frame of mind.”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">With this quote from the Mishnah, the detailed discussion starts. The following verses seek to prove that a serious state of mind is required in a place of holiness (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 30b" href="/Berakhot.30b">Babli 30b</a>).</i> Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 29:2" href="/Psalms.29.2"><i>Ps.</i> 29:2</a>) “Bow down before the Eternal in the splendor of the sanctuary,” in fear of the holy<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">In some Galilean and all Babylonian dialects, ה and ח sounded the same and were not distinguished. In other dialects, the sounds were close.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 2:11" href="/Psalms.2.11"><i>Ps.</i> 2:11</a>) “Serve the Eternal in fear, rejoice in trembling.” Rebbi Aḥa said, when an evil day should come, you may rejoice<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The person to rejoice even in bad times is the Just, who has nothing to fear. In the opinion of Tosaphot (<i>Berakhot</i> 31a, s. v. במקום), R. Aḥa gives the simple sense of the verse, in contrast to the homiletics of R. Yose ben R. Ḥanina.</i>.
Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, he who is about to pray has to sit down twice. Once before he prays and once after he prays. Before he prays, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 84:5" href="/Psalms.84.5"><i>Ps.</i> 84:5</a>) “Hail to those who sit in Your house.” Once after he prays, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 140:14" href="/Psalms.140.14"><i>Ps.</i> 140:14</a>) “But the righteous will thank Your name, the upright ones will sit before You.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Under the influence of the tradition given in the next paragraph, the parallel of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 32b" href="/Berakhot.32b">Babli (32b</a>) requires in the name of R. Joshua ben Levi that one sit in the synagogue one hour each before and after prayer. “One hour” probably means “some time.” The argument given here is that in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 84" href="/Psalms.84">Ps. 84</a> there is no qualification for those in God’s house, but in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 140" href="/Psalms.140">Ps. 140</a> this is restricted to the righteous, those who have fulfilled their obligation in praying.</i>”
“The first <i>Ḥasidim</i> waited one hour before praying,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah.</i>” they prayed for one hour and waited an hour after their prayer. When did they study Torah? When did they work? Rebbi Isaac ben Rebbi Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The explanation of R. Isaac ben R. Eleazar is part of the <i>baraita</i> in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 32b" href="/Berakhot.32b">Babli (32b</a>); this may indicate that the author here is the earlier of two Amoraïm of that name, a student of R. Yoḥanan. The Babli, which notes explicitly that the pious were spending 9 hours in prayer, must take “an hour” in its exact sense; the Yerushalmi may accept “an hour” as “some time”. On the other hand, the replacement of “sitting down” by “waiting” may indicate that in this paragraph ישב has its original Biblical meaning of “being occupied, being at one’s regular place of business.”</i> said, because they were pious, their study was blessed and their work was blessed.
Ḥuna<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 6b" href="/Berakhot.6b">Babli (6b</a>) shows that this is Rav Huna, the Babylonian. Authors of later generations in the Babli attenuate this statement to label as criminals only those who pray behind the synagogue facing away from the building; this is not accepted in the Yerushalmi.</i> said, he who prays behind the synagogue is called criminal as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 12:9" href="/Psalms.12.9"><i>Ps.</i> 12:9</a>) “Criminals walk around.” Rav Ḥuna<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">In the (Yerushalmi) <i>Midrash Tehillim</i> the parallel statement is one of R. Joshua ben Levi, the author of the preceding homiletics, and is part of his homiletics on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 84:5" href="/Psalms.84.5"><i>Ps.</i> 84:5</a>.</i> said, one who does not enter a synagogue in this world will not enter the synagogue in the future world. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 12:9" href="/Psalms.12.9"><i>Ps.</i> 12:9</a>) “Criminals walk around.”
Rebbi Yoḥanan said: He who prays in his own house is as if he were surrounded by an iron wall<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., his prayer is not heard because he is enclosed by such a wall. (Interpretation of R. Solomon Cirillo.)</i>. The argument of Rebbi Yoḥanan is inverted. There<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 4, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 5:3:4-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.5.3.4-11">Halakhah 4</a>.</i> Rebbi Abba said, Rebbi Ḥiyya said in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan, one has to pray at a place that is dedicated to prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Not necessarily in the synagogue, but in one’s own house only at a place that is dedicated to prayer. Hence, private prayer is acceptable and no wall will hinder the prayer from being heard.</i>. And here he says that? One is about a single person, the other about the public<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">A person living at a place where there is no synagogue has to pray at a dedicated place in his house. If, however, there is public prayer at his place of residence then private prayer in one’s house will not be heard. However, that statement is relativized by the statement of Rebbi Abbahu below that a place of Torah study is equal (or superior) to a synagogue.</i>.
Rebbi Phineas in the name of Rebbi Hoshaiah: He who prays in the synagogue is as if he had sacrificed a pure flour offering. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 66:20" href="/Isaiah.66.20"><i>Is.</i> 66:20</a>) “As the children of Israel bring flour offering in a pure vessel in the Eternal’s House.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Since the actual flour offering was brought by the Cohanim, the prophet speaks here of a symbolic act.</i>” Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 55:6" href="/Isaiah.55.6"><i>Is.</i> 55:6</a>) “Seek the Eternal where He is to be found”. Where is He to be found? In synagogues and houses of study. “Call on Him when He is close.” Where is He close? In synagogues and houses of study. Rebbi Isaac ben Rebbi Eleazar said, not only that but their God stands over them. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 82:1" href="/Psalms.82.1"><i>Ps.</i> 82:1</a>) “God stands in the assembly of the mighty; from the inside God will judge.”
Rav Ḥisda said: He who enters the synagogue must enter inside two doors. What is the reason (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 8:34" href="/Proverbs.8.34"><i>Prov.</i> 8:34</a>) “Hail to the man who listens to Me, always to be diligent at My doors<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is spoken by Wisdom (or the Torah) but is interpreted as God’s word.</i>.” My doors and not my door. Doorposts and not doorpost<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the end of the verse which is omitted here: “To guard the doorposts of my entrances always.”</i>. If he did that, what is written there? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 8:35" href="/Proverbs.8.35"><i>Prov.</i> 8:35</a>) “Because he who found Me found life.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 8b" href="/Berakhot.8b">Babli (8b</a>), the statement of Rav Ḥisda appears without justification, but it follows a statement of R. Joshua ben Levi that he who frequents the synagogue will live long and which is supported by the two verses quoted here. Hence, the Babli is dependent on the Yerushalmi in this case.</i>”
Rav Ḥuna said: He who goes to the synagogue must be light-footed. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 6:3" href="/Hosea.6.3"><i>Hos.</i> 6:3</a>) “We shall know, let us run to know the Eternal.” But when one leaves, one has to go in small steps. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 14:16" href="/Job.14.16"><i>Job</i> 14:16</a>) “For now You will count my steps.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 6b" href="/Berakhot.6b">Babli (6b</a>), Rav Ḥuna is credited only with the second statement (without supporting verse). The first statement, with the supporting verse, is given by Abbaye, two generations later; clearly under the influence of the Yerushalmi tradition.</i>”
Rebbi Yoḥanan said: A covenant is sealed that he who labors at his studies in the synagogue will not quickly forget. Rebbi Ḥanina from Ein Tana said: A covenant is sealed that he who labors at his studies in modesty will not quickly forget. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 11:2" href="/Proverbs.11.2"><i>Prov.</i> 11:2</a>) “Wisdom is with the modest.” Rebbi Yoḥanan said: A covenant is sealed that he who studies homiletics from a book will not quickly forget. Rebbi Tanḥum said: He who understands what he has learned will not quickly forget. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 4:9" href="/Deuteronomy.4.9"><i>Deut.</i> 4:9</a>) “That you shall not forget the things your eyes understood.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The order of the items is not correct; it is better in the Rome manuscript and the fragments of the Yerushalmi from the Genizah: First come the two statements of the second generation Rebbi Yoḥanan. The first one is a continuation of the description of good behavior in the synagogue; the synagogue is a good place for study between times for prayer. The second statement appears here because it is from R. Yoḥanan; it is a polemic against the opinion of R. Joshua ben Levi (Yerushalmi <i>Šabbat</i> 16:1) that homiletics is a part of “oral Torah” that may not be written down. Next comes the statement of R. Ḥanina of Ein Tana, Amora of the fourth generation and student of R. Zeïra. (His name is corrupted in the Venice print to R. Yoḥanan of Ein Tana; it is correct in the Rome ms. Ein Tana was a place near Sepphoris.) At the end comes the statement of the fifth generation Rebbi Tanḥum (Tanḥuma bar Abba, the first known author of a collection of <i>Midrashim</i> and greatest of the preachers of the period of the Talmud Yerushalmi).</i>”
Rebbi Jonah in the name of Rebbi Tanḥum ben Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 55b" href="/Berakhot.55b">Babli (55b</a>) contains two traditions. The first one, attributed to the earlier R. Yoḥanan, is that one should assemble three people (a court of law) and declare before them: I saw a good dream. They should answer: It is good, should be good, the All-Merciful shall turn it into a good one sevenfold; may they decree from heaven that it should be good. Then they should recite the verses given here at the end, add three verses of peace and three of redemption. The second one, of Rav Ashi, Amemar, and Mar Zuṭra, two generations later than the authors in the Yerushalmi, has a text similar to the one given here but without the verses. Hence, the Yerushalmi represents an intermediate stage in the development of this prayer. The Babli requires, in contrast to the Yerushalmi, that the prayer be said during the priestly blessing given at morning prayers.</i>, He who sees a disquieting dream must say: “May it be Your pleasure, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that all my dreams that I dreamed, in this night or in any other night, whether I dreamed or others dreamed about me, if they are good they should be fulfilled for me in enjoyment and joy, blessing and life. If they are something else then, just as You turned bitter water to sweet waters, the waters of Jericho to sweet ones through Elisha, and the curse of the son of Beör to a blessing, so may You turn all bad dreams, including what others dreamed about me, to good, blessing, healing, life, joy and enjoyment, and peace. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 30:12-13" href="/Psalms.30.12-13"><i>Ps.</i> 30:12–13</a>) ‘You turned my wailing into a dance, you opened my sackcloth and girded me with joy. So that the liver may sing to You and never be silent; o Eternal, my God, I shall eternally thank You! (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:6" href="/Deuteronomy.23.6"><i>Deut.</i> 23:6</a>) The Eternal, your God, refused to listen to Bileam, the Eternal, your God, turned curse into blessing since the Eternal, your God, loves you. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 31:12" href="/Jeremiah.31.12"><i>Jer.</i> 31:12</a>) Then the maiden will rejoice in dance, young and old men together; I shall turn their mourning to enjoyment and I shall console them and give them joy out of their hurt.’ ”
“Even if the king greets one, he should not respond.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah, title of the following discussion. The statement of R. Aḥa is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 32b" href="/Berakhot.32b">Babli (32b</a>) in the name of the slightly earlier Rav Joseph.</i>” Rebbi Aḥa said, that is, if the greeter is a king of Israel. But one returns greeting from a Gentile king. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Slightly different versions appear in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 3:22" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).3.22">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i>3:22</a>,<i>Massekhet Soferim</i> 5:6.</i>: If one is writing a Divine name, then even if the king greets him, he should not respond. If he is writing two or three Names, e. g. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 22:22" href="/Joshua.22.22"><i>Jos.</i> 22:22</a>) “Powerful, God, Eternal”, he finishes one of them<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The one he is currently writing.</i> and then responds to the greeting.
Rebbi Yoḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The following notes show that the permission to accomodate Gentile rulers is not prescriptive but can be disregarded by genuinely holy men (though not by any other Jew.) The stories are ordered by rank of the Gentile involved. Rebbi Yoḥanan was reciting <i>Shema‘</i> when the ἄρχων, the prefect of the district, passed by. He was in danger to be beaten up by prefect’s bodygard but, as ruler of a city with an important Jewish population, he was acquainted with their behavior and their adherence to the νόμος, “the law” of the Torah.</i> was sitting and reciting in front of the Babylonian synagogue of Sepphoris. The prefect passed by and he did not get up before him. They wanted to whip him; he said to them: Let him, he is occupied in the laws of his Creator. Rebbi Ḥanina and Rebbi Joshua ben Levi appeared before the proconsul<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Ἀνθύπατος “proconsul”, the Roman governor of an entire province. Both prefect and proconsul were also the local military commanders.</i> of Caesarea. He saw them and rose before them. They said to him, you get up before these Jews? He said to them, I saw faces of angels. Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Jose appeared before Ursicinus<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The general in charge of all of Syria and Palestine under the Caesar Gallus, around 350 C. E.</i> in Antiochia. He saw them and rose before them. They said to him, you get up before these Jews? He said, I win in battle if I see the faces of these. Rebbi Abun appeared before the king<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">The “king” is either the emperor Diocletian or one of his immediate successors, so probably R. Abun here is R. Abun II. Diocletian changed the formally republican Roman principate into an absolute monarchy in which the sacred person of the emperor required veneration as a godlike person (this was not abolished by his Christian successors.) In particular, after an audience the visitor was supposed to walk backwards with his face always towards the throne. R. Abun’s act was one of denial of the godlike nature of the king. After this incident, R. Abun escaped to Babylonia, as noted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 106a" href="/Chullin.106a">Babli <i>Ḥulin</i> 106a</a>, “when Rabin came, it was because he was in danger of being killed.”</i>. When he left, he turned his neck. They came and wanted to kill him but they saw two sparks of fire emanating from his neck, so they let him go, to affirm what is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 28:10" href="/Deuteronomy.28.10"><i>Deut.</i> 28:10</a>): “All peoples of the earth will see that the Name of the Eternal is called over you and they will be afraid of you.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">This is a reference to a statement in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 6a" href="/Berakhot.6a">Babli 6a</a>: “All peoples of the earth will see that the name of the Eternal is called over you and they will be afraid of you;” the great Rebbi Eliezer said: These are the <i>tefillin</i> on the head. It can be safely assumed that this statement of an Israeli Tanna was known to the editors of the Yerushalmi, so they had no need for an explicit statement that the sparks came from the straps of R. Abun’s <i>tefillin</i>.</i>”
Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai stated: “All peoples of the earth will see that the name of the Eternal is called over you”, all - even spirits and demons. Rebbi Yannai and Rebbi Jonathan were promenading in a forest<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The hapax אסלטין seems to be Latin <i>saltus</i>, “forest”. The Rome ms. reading is אסרטין, Latin <i>strata</i>, “street”, Genizah fragments read אסטדין “stadion.” The forest is a more likely place to find promenading rabbis greeted by a demon.</i>. One saw them, greeted them, and said: “Peace upon you, rabbis.” They said, even the religious title does not harm us.
Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is a connection between the preceding and the following ones. First, it shows that great scholars are apt to be absent-minded (and, hence, may not notice the presence of potentially dangerous men or situations) and, second, to show that even snakes can be helpful to Torah sages.</i> was thinking very hard about Torah. He overstepped the Sabbath boundary without noticing it, to confirm (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 5:19" href="/Proverbs.5.19"><i>Prov.</i> 5:19</a>): “In its love you will always err.” Rebbi Yudan ben Rebbi Ismael was thinking very hard about Torah. His toga slipped off from him and he did not notice it, to confirm: “In its love you will always err.” Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon was thinking very hard about Torah. His toga slipped off from him but a viper was caring for it. His students told him: Teacher, your toga has slipped off. He said to them, does this evil one not care for it?
“Even if a snake is wound around one’s heel, one should not interrupt.” Rebbi Ḥuna in the name of Rebbi Yose: They mentioned only a snake, but for a scorpion he interrupts<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33a" href="/Berakhot.33a">Babli (33a</a>), the statement is in the name of the earlier Rav Sheshet; no reason is given there.</i>. Why, because it stings repeatedly. Rebbi Ilaï said: They stated only “wound around”, but if a snake is attacking him, he hides before him but he should not interrupt his prayer. It is stated: If he was praying in a thoroughfare or on a square<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πλατεῖα (ὁδός) “wide open” (road). “Cart” is from Greek κάρρος, κάρρον. “Thoroughfare” is also found in Arabic as صرآط צִרַאט.</i> he removes himself from before a donkey or before a cart but he should not interrupt his prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 32a" href="/Berakhot.32a">Babli (32a</a>) states that one should shorten his prayer (by reciting only the final doxologies of all the remaining benedictions). R. Isaac Alfassi’s version is: “If he can shorten, he should shorten, and if not, he should interrupt.” In the Yerushalmi, one is permitted in an emergency to change his place and then continue with prayer at another place, but in the Babli the prayer is interrupted automatically if one moves.</i>.
They said about Rebbi Ḥanina ben Dosa<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Tanna of the first generation, from lower Galilee, companion of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai. He is the perfectly holy man who never committed a single sin. All his traditions are about ethical maxims. A text close to the present one [without the Aramaic insert] appears in Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 3:30; a very different version is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33a" href="/Berakhot.33a">Babli 33a</a>.</i> that he was standing in prayer when a brightly dotted snake<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In Biblical Hebrew, חברברוֹת are the spots of a leopard. The root חבר “to shine” appears once more in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 16:4" href="/Job.16.4">Bible (<i>Job</i> 16:4</a>); in Arabic the parallel root is חבר “to be richly ornamented” [distinguished from Hebrew חבר, Arabic ח̇בר, “to be joined”.] The word could also denote a brightly striped snake. The more brightly a snake is colored, the more poisonous it is.</i> came and bit him. He did not interrupt his prayer. They went and found that dotted snake lying dead at the entrance of its hole. They said, woe to the human who is bitten by a dotted snake, but woe to the dotted snake that bites Rebbi Ḥanina ben Dosa. [What is the nature of that dotted snake? If it bites a human and the human reaches water first, the dotted snake dies, but if the dotted snake reaches water first, the human dies.] His students asked him: Rabbi, did you not notice? He said to them: There should happen to me these things<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">A formula of affirmation, taking the place of an oath.</i>; I was concentrating on my prayer and did not notice! Rebbi Isaac ben Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">This Amoraic addition belongs to the explanation given in the insert and is not part of the <i>baraita</i> tradition.</i> said, the Holy One, praise to Him, created a well under his foot soles, to confirm what has been said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 145:19" href="/Psalms.145.19"><i>Ps.</i> 145: 19</a>): “He will do the will of those who fear Him, He will hear their entreaties and save them.”

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One mentions the power of rains in “resurrection of the dead<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The second benediction of the <i>Amidah</i>. The benediction “for years” is the ninth, a prayer for a plentiful harvest. <i>Havdalah</i> is the required declaration of a “difference” between Sabbath (or holiday) and weekday, after the end of the Sabbath or holiday. No work may be performed before some form of <i>Havdalah</i>. The benediction for being granted knowledge is the fourth, the one for thanksgiving the 17th.</i>”; one prays for rain in the benediction “of years” and <i>Havdalah</i> in “He Who by His grace grants knowledge;” Rebbi Aqiba said: it is recited as separate fourth benediction; Rebbi Eliezer says, in “thanksgiving”.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Just as the resurrection of the dead brings life to the world, so rains bring life to the world<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">These are all arguments that God has to be praised for rain in the prayer for resurrection during the rainy season. The first verse of Hosea clearly speaks of resurrection, the second one ends: “it (knowing God) will come like rain to us, like late rains that pour on the Land.”</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba understood it from here (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 6:2-3" href="/Hosea.6.2-3"><i>Hos.</i> 6:2–3</a>): “He will resurrect us after two days, on the third day He will raise us up and we shall live before Him. We shall know, we shall pursue to know the Eternal, like morning his appearance is well-based<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">These verses are further discussed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 1:1:2-18" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.1.1.2-18">Yerushalmi <i>Taäniot</i> 1:1</a> (fol. 63d), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:6:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.6.2-5"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 11:8</a> (fol. 30c), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 31a" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.31a">Babli <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 31a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 97a" href="/Sanhedrin.97a"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 97a</a>.</i>.”
It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 17:1" href="/I_Kings.17.1"><i>1Kings</i> 17:1</a>) “Elijah the Tisbite, from the inhabitants of Gilead, said to Aḥab: By the Living Eternal One, the God of Israel, before Whom I stood, there will not be dew nor rain these years except by my word.” Rebbi Berekhia said, Rebbi Yasa and the rabbis. One of them said, he was heard both for dew and for rain; the other one said, he was heard for rain but was not heard for dew, from (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 18:1" href="/I_Kings.18.1"><i>1Kings</i> 18:1</a>): “Go, appear before Aḥab and I shall give rain<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">But dew is not mentioned. The entire piece, whose main place is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 1:1:2-18" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.1.1.2-18"><i>Taäniot</i> 1:1</a>, is included to explain the connection of the (summer) praise for dew in the benediction on “resurrection”. The praise for dew was included in the Yerushalmi prayer rite.</i>, etc.” And he who said, he was heard both for dew and for rain, where was the vow of dew dissolved? Rebbi Tanḥuma from Edreï<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">He is mentioned only here (and in the parallel in <i>Taäniot</i>). Since he appears together with Rebbi Berekhiah, he must belong to the last generation of Amoraïm in Israel.<br>It is the minority opinion of Rebbi Aqiba (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 9:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.9.6.2"><i>Nedarim</i> 9:6</a>) that if in an earthly court part of a vow is annulled because it was executed under false intent, then the entire vow is annulled. This is not the majority opinion, hence, it is not the practice and does not imply Heavenly standards.</i> said, they are of the opinion that a vow that was dissolved partially is dissolved totally. Some want to say, on the occasion of the son of the woman from Sarepta, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 17:20" href="/I_Kings.17.20"><i>1Kings</i> 17:20</a>) “He called on the Eternal and said, o Eternal, my God, etc.” Rebbi Judah ben Pazi said, about one who stole a doctor’s bag<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Greek νάρθηξ, a plant (<i>Ferula communis</i>), word also used for “casket for unguents”, and title of medical works. Hesiod has Prometheus carry off the fire in the stalk of a νάρθηξ.</i>. When he left, his son was injured.He returned to him and said: Please, sir doctor, heal my son. He said to him: Go and return my bag because it is full of medicines, and I shall heal your son. So the Holy One, praise to Him, said to Elijah: Go and lift the vow of dew because the dead are resurrected only by dew, then I shall resurrect the son of the Sareptan. And from where that the dead will live only by dew? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 26:19" href="/Isaiah.26.19"><i>Is.</i> 26:19</a>) “Your dead will live, the corpses will arise. Wake up and jubilate, those who dwell in dust! For a dew of light is Your dew, וְאֶרֶץ רְפָאִים תַּפִּיל.” Rebbi Tanḥum from Edreï said, “the earth will give up those that are deposited in it.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Tanḥum from Edreï explains the difficult phrase וְאֶרֶץ רְפָאִים תַּפִּיל “it will fell Netherworlds” by taking תַּפִּיל in the sense of Rabbinic Hebrew, “having a miscarriage”, the Netherworld will expel what is in it.</i>”
Rebbi Jacob from Kefar Ḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph explains the reason of those who say that Elijah’s prediction that there would be no dew never came true. The homily belongs to the school of R. Simeon ben Laqish (Resh Laqish). R. Jacob from Kefar Ḥanan was his student in homiletics.</i> in the name of Resh Laqish: When Abraham their forefather did My will, I swore to him that dew will never move away from his descendants forever; what is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 110:3" href="/Psalms.110.3"><i>Ps.</i> 110:3</a>) “You have the dew of your youth.” And it is written after that (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 110:4" href="/Psalms.110.4"><i>Ps.</i> 110:4</a>) “The Eternal swore and He will not change His intention.” Rebbi Judah ben Pazi said, by a will<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Greek διαθήκη “will, permanent disposition.”</i> I gave it to Abraham, as a gift I gave it to him. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 27:28" href="/Genesis.27.28">Gen. 27:28</a>) “God may give you from the dew of heaven.” Rebbi Samuel ben Naḥmani said, when Israel sin and do evil the rains are arrested. They bring an old man like Rebbi Yose the Galilean, he prays for them and the rains come. But dew does not descend by the merit of any creature, what is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Micah 5:6" href="/Micah.5.6"><i>Micah</i> 5:6</a>) “Like dew from the Eternal, like light showers on grass, that do not listen to anybody nor wait for humans.”
Rebbi Zeïra in the name if Rebbi Ḥanina: When someone stood [praying] in the rainy season and mentioned dew one does not make him repeat. In the season of dew and he mentioned rain one makes him repeat. But is it not stated<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The discussion follows the general pattern: If a statement contains statements A and then B, the discussion will discuss first B, then A. Hence, the first clause of the <i>baraita</i> will be repeated before the discussion turns to it. The statement of Rebbi Ḥanina and the discussion of its last part is quoted in Alfassi <i>Taänit</i> 1:1 where it is added to the tradition of the same Rebbi Ḥanina in the Babylonian Talmud (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 3b" href="/Taanit.3b"><i>Taänit</i> 3b</a>): “In summertime, one who says ‘He Who makes the wind blow’ does not have to repeat; if he says ‘He Who makes rain descend,’ he has to repeat. In wintertime, one who omits ‘He Who makes the wind blow’ does not have to repeat; if he omits ‘He Who makes rain descend,’ he has to repeat.” Alfassi gives no interpretation of the Yerushalmi he quotes but the early Medieval authorities R. Zeraḥia Halevi, R. Abraham ben David, Nachmanides, and R. Nissim Gerondi all have different interpretations (mutually contradictory) and most of them also have different readings. Among manuscripts, the expression דְּלָא מַצְלִי וְלָא מֵיקַל appears with or without one or both לָא. The following interpretation follows Nachmanides closely. [Most commentaries agree with R. Nissim Gerondi in taking מיקל as a <i>Pa‘el</i> form of a contracted form of קלל “to curse”; such a form קול is nowhere attested, but קיל “to take, make easy” is frequent.]</i>: The sages did not oblige one to mention dew and winds but if he wants to mention them, he may mention? One cannot compare one who takes it easy<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">And does not mention the dew which he needs, but mentions the rain out of season.</i> to one who does not pray and does not take it easy<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Who prays neither for dew, nor for rain, nor for winds, and therefore does not slight anything.</i>. “When he stood in the rainy season and mentioned dew one does not make him repeat.” But is it not stated: If he did not ask for it in the benediction “for years”, or he did not mention the power of rains in “resurrection of the dead”, one makes him repeat? That is about one who mentioned neither dew nor rain.
Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rebbi Ḥuna: If he did not ask<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The request for rain is made only in the rainy season, “under duress” when rain is urgently needed. The mention of rain in the second benediction already starts “under easy circumstances” around the time of the fall equinox, some weeks before rain is needed. The benediction “He Who hears prayer” is the last of the middle benedictions, #15 on weekdays.</i> in the benediction “for years” he says it in “He Who hears prayer”. Similarly, if he did not mention the power of rains in “resurrection of the dead” he says it in “He Who hears prayer”. If the request, made under duress, may be recited in “He Who hears prayer,” the mention, made under easy circumstances, so much more! But is it not stated: If he did not ask in the benediction “for years” or that he did not mention the power of rains in “resurrection of the dead”, one makes him repeat<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">As a tannaïtic statement, this has precedence over the statement of Rebbi Ḥuna. How can R. Ḥuna present his statement about power of rains? [The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 29a" href="/Berakhot.29a">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 29a</a>, has the statement formulated here in the name of Rav Assi from the Yeshivah of Rav in Babylonia; the Babli mentions neither the statement of Rebbi Ḥuna nor the explanation of Rebbi Eudaimon.]</i>? Rebbi Eudaimon the brother of Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Brother of the Amora R. Yose of the fourth generation.</i> said, if he did not say it in “He Who hears prayer”!
Where does he return to<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">If he forgot either prayer for or mention of rain, and realizes his omission at the end of the <i>Amidah</i>.</i>? Just as Rebbi Simeon bar Abba said in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: On the day of the New Moon<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">When the day has to be mentioned in “Temple service”, the first of the last three benedictions; cf. Chapter 3, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 5:1:2-22" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.5.1.2-22">Halakhah 1</a>.</i>, if he had moved his feet<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">During <i>Amidah</i> it is forbidden to move one’s feet since the angels do not move their feet. Hence, moving after prayer is the outward sign that prayer is finished.</i> he repeats from the start, otherwise from “Temple service”. Here also, if he had moved his feet he repeats from the start<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Otherwise, he returns to “He Who hears prayer.”</i>.
At Nineveh<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">This is not Biblical Niniveh but Naveh in the center of the Bashan plateau, see <i>Demay</i> 2:1. (Eusebius mentions that the Jews call it Nineveh.) On the Golan plain, one needs spring rains if the winter was relatively dry.</i> they needed to make a fast-day after Passover<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">This again is a text from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 1:1:2-18" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.1.1.2-18"><i>Taäniot</i> 1:1</a>; the question and the answer, without the discussion, are mentioned succinctly in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 14b" href="/Taanit.14b">Babli <i>Taänit</i> 14b</a>.</i>. They came to ask Rebbi. He told them, go ahead and make one but do not change the form of prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Do not mention the power of rain in “Resurrection” nor a prayer for rain in “years.” On the other hand, if one already fasts for rain one must pray for rain in one’s <i>Amidah</i>.</i>. Where may he say it? Rebbi Jeremiah thought to say that he says it in “He Who hears prayer.” Rebbi Yose said to him: Did not Rebbi Zeïra say in the name of Rebbi Ḥuna: If he did notask in the benediction “for years”, or that he failed to mention the power of rains in “resurrection of the dead”, one makes him repeat at “He Who hears prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in <i>Taäniot</i> the text is easier to understand; there it says “he says” instead of “one makes him repeat”; meaning that a prayer for rain at “He Who hears prayer” belongs to the regular form of prayer in winter and, therefore, by Rebbi’s statement is excluded from summer prayer.</i>?” But Rebbi said to them, go ahead and make one but do not change the form of prayer! According to the opinion of Rebbi Yose, where does one say it? In the six that he adds<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Six additional benedictions that the reader inserts in the public prayer of fast days for rain, as explained in the second chapter of Mishnah <i>Taänit</i>. Rebbi Yose must imply that even a local fast for rain is a public fast.</i>. That works for the public which has six. A private person who does not have six, where? Rebbi Ḥanina said, did not Rebbi Zeïra say in the name of Rav Ḥuna<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:4:6-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.4.6-11">Halakhah 4:4</a>.</i>, a private person asks for his personal needs in “He Who hears prayer,” and these are his needs.
“And <i>Havdalah</i> in ‘He Who by His grace grants knowledge’ ”<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah to indicate the text to be discussed now.</i>. Simeon bar Abba asked before Rebbi Yoḥanan: Something that one does all the time, and the Sages differ about it? He said to him: Since its main place is over a cup they forgot it in prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The discussion is quoted more in detail in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33a" href="/Berakhot.33a">Babli 33a</a>: “Rebbi Simeon bar Abba asked Rebbi Yoḥanan: Since the Men of the Great Assembly instituted the forms of benedictions, prayers, <i>Qiddush</i> and <i>Havdalah</i>, why does one not check and see what they instituted? He answered him: Originally, they instituted <i>Havdalah</i> in prayer. When they got rich, they instituted it over a cup of wine. When they became poor again, they went back and instituted it back in prayer.” This implies that the differences of opinion expressed in the Mishnah refer to the second institution of prayer and that the order of the first institution therefore is irrelevant. In the Yerushalmi, the question is, how can there arise a difference of usage in something that every Jew has been doing every week since the times of the Great Assembly? The answer also here is that there was a time where only <i>Havdalah</i> over a cup of wine was practiced.</i>. His statement means that its main place is over a cup<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>Havdalah</i> over a cup was not disestablished, the mention in prayer is additional.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Idi in the name of the old Rebbi Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">His full name was Rebbi Isaac bar Eudaimon, a Tanna of the first generation, a member of Rebbi’s Academy. He is called “old” to distinguish him from Rav Isaac bar Eudaimon, a Babylonian Amora of the third generation.</i>: If he said it over a cup he must repeat it in prayer; it was<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Havdalah</i> was said over the cup only to teach children.</i> in order to let children participate. His statement means that its main place is in prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33a" href="/Berakhot.33a">Babli (33a</a>), this is a statement of the Babylonian Rav Naḥman bar Isaac.</i>. Rebbi Zeïra, Rav Yehudah in the name of Samuel: If he said it over a cup he must repeat it in prayer, if he said it in prayer he must repeat it over a cup. His statement means that its main place is here as well as there<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">In contrast to Rebbi Yoḥanan, Samuel insists that the later institution did not replace the benediction over a cup of wine by a benediction inserted in prayer, but that prayer is additional to the benediction over a cup of wine. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33b" href="/Berakhot.33b">Babli (33b</a>) this is the final statement of the later Amora Rava. In the Yerushalmi also, the last statement has to be taken as the final one.</i>.
“Rebbi Eliezer says, in ‘thanksgiving’ ”. Rebbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rebbi: One is inclined toward Rebbi Eliezer’s opinion on a holiday that falls immediately after the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Privately, one prefers to act in the sense of Rebbi Eliezer but one does not declare it publicly. The first two statements of this paragraph are quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33b" href="/Berakhot.33b">Babli (33b</a>) as Israeli practice, whereas in Babylonia one follows Rav and Samuel in an insertion in the middle benediction of the <i>Amidah</i> for the holiday. The last two statements are quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 8a" href="/Niddah.8a">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 8a</a>.</i>. The old Rebbi Isaac in the name of Rebbi: Practice follows Rebbi Eliezer on a holiday that falls after the Sabbath. Rebbi Isaac bar Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The oldest son of Rabban Gamliel I of Jabneh, brother of Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel. It seems that he died before the Patriarchate was reestablished after a long interruption in the aftermath of the war of Bar Kokhba.</i>: Practice follows Rebbi Eliezer at all times. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Practice follows Rebbi Eliezer at all times. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, not because because there are two traditions, but because Rebbi Isaac bar Naḥman and Rebbi Eleazar both say in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel: Practice follows Rebbi Eliezer at all times.
“And <i>Havdalah</i> in “He Who in His grace grants knowledge”, the words of the Sages. Rebbi Aqibah said: one says it as separate fourth benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Almost a quote from the Mishnah, to introduce discussion on the way <i>Havdalah</i> has to be recited according to Rebbi Aqiba, even though his way of doing it is not accepted as practice. Hence, the discussion in this paragraph is purely theoretical.</i>” Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Samuel: He says it as fourth benediction. Rebbi Yudan says, the text of the benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">The text of the regular fourth benediction, “He Who in His grace grants knowledge”. This is the meaning of the phrase also in the statement of Rebbi Isaac bar Eleazar.</i> and after that he says <i>Havdalah</i>. His version agrees with Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">His opinion parallels that of Rebbi. [A slightly different version is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33a" href="/Berakhot.33a">Babli 33a</a> in the name of Rav Joseph: “Since <i>Havdalah</i> presupposes knowledge, it was incorporated in the benediction for knowledge.”]</i>, since Rebbi said: I wonder why they eliminated “He Who in His grace grants knowledge” on Sabbath; if there is no knowledge, where is prayer? And here, if there is no knowledge, where is <i>Havdalah</i>? Rebbi Isaac ben Eleazar said, he says <i>Havdalah</i> and afterwards adds the text of the benediction.
Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Hoshaiah<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Son of Rebbi Hoshaiah (see Chap. 2, Note 169). The statement is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 103b-104a" href="/Pesachim.103b-104a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 103b–104a</a>) in the name of Rebbi Oshaya (Babylonian form of Hoshaiah). The entire paragraph has the appearance of being written by a person unable to pronounce an “h”.</i>: Only one should not mention less than three separations. Rebbi Yoḥanan said, they said that he who says little should not say less than three and he who adds should not add more than seven separations. Levi said, but only separations mentioned in the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">For example, He Who separates between holy and private (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 10:10" href="/Leviticus.10.10"><i>Lev.</i> 10:10</a>), between light and darkness (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:4" href="/Genesis.1.4"><i>Gen.</i> 1:4</a>), between Israel and the Gentiles (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:26" href="/Leviticus.20.26"><i>Lev.</i> 20:26</a>). There are no more than seven separations mentioned in the Torah. [The other four are between upper and lower waters, between day and night, between pure and impure, between Levites and other Israelites.]</i>. Naḥum<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Also called Menaḥem ben R. Simai, an Amora of the first generation who was renowned for his holiness.</i> ben Rebbi Simai went out and said in his father’s name: even one separation. But Rebbi Abbahu said, one must seal with “separation”. Rebbi Mana objected, even if he started by “He Who separates between holy and worldly” and ends, seals by “He Who separates between holy and worldly”<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Would Rebbi Abbahu agree with R. Naḥum ben R. Simai that a benediction would be: “Praise to You, o Eternal, our God, King of the universe, Who separates between holy and wordly. Praise to You, Eternal, Who separates between holy and wordly”? That text looks too silly to be acceptable.</i>? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, is it not from the benedictions that one starts with “praised” and ends with “praised”<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">As stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:38" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.38">Halakhah 1:4</a>. However, Rebbi Abbahu is more specific and requires the final benediction to contain the word המבדיל. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 104a" href="/Pesachim.104a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 104a</a>) there is a discussion whether the separation referred to in the concluding benediction is the first or the last one of the list. In any case, it is clear that R. Abbahu cannot agree with R. Naḥum bar Simai to produce the meaningless formula of R. Mana. Hence, the opinion of R. Naḥum must be rejected.</i>?
Rebbi Eleazar ben Antigonos in the name of Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Yannai<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Tanna of the last generation; his only known student is R. Eleazar ben Antigonos. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 150b" href="/Shabbat.150b">Babli (<i>Sabbath</i> 150b</a>), the statement is in the name of Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob, one of the last students of Rebbi Aqiba and a major authority. In the Babli, the statement is relativized to mean that one does not even have to pray but just to recite “Praise to Him Who separates between holy and wordly” to be able to do any work. There is no such relativization in the Yerushalmi; however, it is implied by the next paragraph.</i>: That means<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Refers to the majority opinion in the Mishnah, that <i>Havdalah</i> has to be inserted in the first weekday benediction of the <i>Amidah</i>. Hence, it is the first thing that one has to do. The argument in this paragraph takes this up: Since it was ordained that <i>Havdalah</i> precedes the weekday prayer with its supplications for wordly needs, it also must precede worldly deeds. [The first weekday benediction also contains a supplication but, as Rebbi is quoted in an earlier paragraph, a prayer for knowledge is acceptable also for the Sabbath.]</i> that one is forbidden from doing any work before one recites <i>Havdalah</i>. As he said, he said that one is forbidden from doing any work before one recites <i>Havdalah</i>, and similarly one is forbidden to pray for one’s needs before one recites <i>Havdalah</i>.
Rebbi Zeïra, Rebbi Eleazar ben Antigonos in the name of Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Yannai in the name of the important Rebbi Yehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rebbi Yehudah bar Illaī. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 106a" href="/Pesachim.106a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 106a</a>), R. Zeïra is quoted as permitting the recitation of <i>Havdalah</i> only until Wednesday afternoon.</i>: If he did not recite <i>Havdalah</i> at the end of Sabbath, he recites even on Thursday. That is restricted to <i>Havdalah</i> proper, but “illuminating fire” he may say only immediately<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">At nightfall one is permitted to light a new fire. The benediction has been formulated because at the end of the first Sabbath of Creation, Adam invented artificial fire as the first engineering feat of newly created man (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 12b:8" href="/Berakhot.12b.8">Yerushalmi <i>Berakhot</i> 12b (8:6</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 54a" href="/Pesachim.54a">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 54a</a>). Hence, it makes no sense to recite the benediction at any other time. The rule proclaimed here is attributed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 54a" href="/Pesachim.54a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 54a</a>) to R. Jacob ben Idi.</i>.
Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav Yehudah, Rebbi Abba in the name of Abba bar Jeremiah: Even if a holiday falls in the middle of the week onerecites “He Who separates between Sabbath and the six workdays<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">This is the last “separation” in <i>Havdalah</i> before the final doxology. That “separation” is not in the Torah and not in the list of 3 - 7 separations, but necessitated by the circumstances. The statement really means that the text of <i>Havdalah</i> for holidays is identical with that for the Sabbath. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 26b" href="/Chullin.26b">Babli (<i>Ḥulin</i> 26b</a>) the statement is attributed to R. Zeïra only, without discussion.</i>” Rebbi Zeïra said to Rav Yehudah: Has one six workdays before him? He said to him: Has one impurity and purity before him<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">This is one of the seven “separations” mentioned in the Torah but today purity is impossible for us.</i>?
Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi: One must say, “start the days, the six coming workdays<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">“The six coming workdays” is missing in the Rome ms. and might be superfluous. It is not in the received Ashkenazic prayer texts of <i>Havdalah</i>. Sephardic and Oriental rites do not have the phrase.</i>, for peace.” Rebbi Abba adds: “And let us hear in them rejoicing and joy.” Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah: “Let us understand and teach us.” Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah: Those who answer Amen<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Since they want to discharge their own obligation by listening to another person making <i>Havdalah</i> over a cup, they must see what he is doing.</i> have to look at the cup and the candle. Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">In order to complete the list of traditions of Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah regarding holidays, this extraneous tradition is included. In the parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 35b" href="/Sukkah.35b">Babli <i>Sukkah</i> 35b</a>, it is stated that no obligation connected with things that grow can be executed other than using them in the way they grew (bottom down, head up). [In the Babli, “Ḥizqiah” should be “Rebbi Ḥizqiah” since “Ḥizqiah” without title refers to the son of Rebbi Ḥiyya, older than Rebbi Zeïra.]</i>: The four kinds of the <i>lulav</i> must be taken in the direction of their growth.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One silences someone<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The reader in public prayer.</i> who says “Your mercy will reach over a bird’s nest,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Probably in the benediction “He Who hears prayer” where one prays for Divine mercy. The reference is to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:6-8" href="/Deuteronomy.22.6-8"><i>Deut.</i> 22:6–8</a>.</i>” “Your name shall be remembered on good things,” “we thank, we thank.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">In the benediction “Thanksgiving.”</i>” <sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">In the separate Mishnah, this is the start of Mishnah 4. Hence, in the Gemara text, the next Mishnah will be #5.</i> If the one standing before the arc<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">The “emissary of the congregation”, שליח צבוּר, in English texts usually called “the reader” but who in Talmudic times was not a reader but leader of the congregation in prayers recited by heart or prayers of his own composition. If he stumbled, there was no way to correct him from a written text and one had to try another person.</i> makes a mistake, another person should replace him and he should not refuse at that moment<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Usually, if a nonprofessional is asked to perform as “emissary of the congregation”, he is supposed to point out his unworthiness and accede to the summons only at the third call. In an emergency, if he knows that he can do the job, he has to agree immediately.</i>. Where does he start? From the start of the benediction where the other person made the mistake.
