<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Phineas in the name of Rebbi Simeon: He is like one who quarrels with the measures of the Holy One, praise to Him: Your mercies reached<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">All Mishnah manuscripts, all Yerushalmi sources of the Mishnah, and all <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33b" href="/Berakhot.33b">Babli sources (<i>Berakhot</i> 33b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 25a" href="/Megillah.25a"><i>Megillah</i> 25a</a>) have יגיעוּ but all texts in the discussion have הגיעוּ.</i> over a bird’s nest but did not reach this man<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">“This man” in Talmudic speech means “me”. {The same usage is found in Greek (ὅδε) and Latin (<i>hic</i>), (E. G.).}</i>! Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Simeon: He is like one who makes finite the measures of the Holy One, praise to Him: Your mercies reach down to the bird’s nest<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">His mercies reach down to a bird’s nest but not to insects and worms.</i>. Some Tannaïm formulate “over”, some Tannaïm formulate “to”. He who says “over” supports Rebbi Phineas, he who says “to” supports Rebbi Yose. Rebbi Yose bar Abun said<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">In Babli sources (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33b" href="/Berakhot.33b"><i>Berakhot</i> 33b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 25a" href="/Megillah.25a"><i>Megillah</i> 25a</a>), the statement is attributed either to R. Yose bar Abun or to R. Yose bar Zabida.</i>: They do not act well who declare the measures of the Holy One, praise to Him, to be mercy. And those<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Targum Yerushalmi (Pseudo-Jonathan) to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:28" href="/Leviticus.22.28"><i>Lev.</i> 22:28</a>, with minor changes.</i> who translate (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:21" href="/Leviticus.22.21"><i>Lev.</i> 22:21</a>) “My people Israel, just as I am merciful in Heaven so you should be merciful on earth. A cow or a mother sheep, it and its young you should not slaughter together on one day,” they do not act well because they declare the measures of the Holy One, praise to Him, to be mercy.
“One silences one who says ‘we thank, we thank.’<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah, to be discussed.</i>” Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 63:12" href="/Psalms.63.12"><i>Ps.</i> 63:12</a>): “For the mouth of those who speak lies will be dammed up.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">This verse explains that it is an obligation to “dam up, wall in” the mouths of those who speak lies. Its is not explained what the lies are of those who repeat “we thank.” In the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) it is explained that the one who says so, like the one who wants to mention God’s name only on good things, gives the impression that there are two independent forces, God for the good and Satan–Ahriman for the bad. The Babli objects to the opinion expressed here that any repetition of sections of prayer texts is permitted in private for emphasis.</i>” That is, in public. But in private it is supplication.
“If the one standing before the arc makes a mistake.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah. However, the following statements apply mainly to one who errs in his private prayer.</i>” Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi Ḥananiah<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">A/k/a R. Ḥanina ben Gamliel.</i> ben Gamliel: If one erred in one of the first three benedictions, he starts anew<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Even though the Mishnah states that one returns to the start of the incorrect benediction, this does not apply to the first and last three benedictions, which are an obligatory part of any <i>Amidah</i>. Each one of these groups has the status of a single benediction in this respect.</i>. Ada bar bar Ḥana<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">There exists no Babylonian Amora of that name. The name is similarly corrupt in the Rome manuscript and the Genizah fragments. It must be either Abba bar bar Ḥana, cousin of Rav, or his father Abba bar Ḥana.</i>, Ganiva in the name of Rav: If one erred in one of the last three benedictions, he returns to “Temple Service.” Rebbi Ḥelbo, Rav Huna in the name of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">There is no discrepancy between this statement and the prior ones, except that Rebbi Ḥelbo insists that the entire statement is Rav’s and that he adds the prescription how to behave if the error is committed in the middle benedictions. The last rule is parallel to the one given for errors in the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 2:4:2-16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.2.4.2-16">Halakhah 2:4</a>.</i>: If one erred in one of the first three benedictions, he starts anew; in one of the last three benedictions, he returns to “Temple Service”; if he erred and he cannot remember where he erred he returns to the place that is clear to him.
Rebbi Aḥa and Rebbi Judah ben Pazy were sitting in a synagogue. One came and stood before the arc and forgot one benediction. They went and asked Rebbi Simon. Rebbi Simon said to them in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: One does not remove an emissary of the congregation who forgot two or three benedictions<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">But an individual has to repeat following the standards of the Mishnah.</i>. They found a formulation that made a difference: One does not remove him for anything except if he did not say “He Who revives the dead”, “He Who subdues evildoers”, “He Who builds Jerusalem;” I say that he is a sectarian<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">If he does not believe in resurrection of the body, he is a Sadducee. If he refrains from uttering the deprecation against Christians or expressing the hope that Jerusalem will be rebuilt before a Second Coming, he is a Christian.</i>. Samuel Minor<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">A Tanna of the second generation. He was the person who formulated the prayer against Christians in the first place (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 28b-29a" href="/Berakhot.28b-29a">Babli 28b–29a</a>), but after that he forgot what he himself had formulated. He is called “minor” because his stature was not as great as that of the prophet Samuel, but greater than everybody else in his generation.</i> stood before the ark and forgot “He Who subdues evildoers.” At the end he started looking at them<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">When at the end he realized that he had forgotten the benediction and also remembered that with the introduction of his formulation came the order to remove any “emissary of the congregation” who omitted that benediction, he started wondering about the reaction of his audience which according to the Babli was the Synhedrion at Jabneh. The Babli goes into a lengthy discussion why they did not remove him under suspicion of a belated sympathy with Christians. One answers that he started the benediction and only got lost in the middle; one removes only an emissary who leaves it out altogether. This is clearly in contradiction to the version of the Yerushalmi.<br>In Israel, the holy ark was movable and for prayer it was transported in front of the congregation; the emissary of the congregation then stood in front of the ark. Therefore, removal of the reader is denoted in the Yerushalmi by מחזירין “one returns him (to his seat in the synagogue)”. In Babylonia, the ark was built-in and the place of the reader was lower than the floor of the synagogue; hence removal of the reader in the Babli is expressed by מעלין “one moves him up (from the low place of the reader)”.</i>. They said to him, the Sages did not take you as a yardstick.
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: If one is in doubt whether he mentioned the New Moon or not, one makes him repeat. Where does he return to? Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan, if he had moved his feet, he repeats from the start, otherwise from “Temple Service.”<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">All this has been explained earlier in this chapter, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.5.2">Halakhah 2, Notes 79–80</a>.</i> Rebbi Judah ben Pazi said, if he let his thoughts wander that is as if he had moved his feet<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">If the person praying did not move his feet but started thinking of other things, it is as if he had moved his feet.</i>. The private supplications<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Private prayers said after the conclusion of the official 18 benedictions of the <i>Amidah</i>, as exemplified in the texts presented in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:2:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.2.2-8">Halakhah 4:2</a>. They are certainly part of prayer and recited while standing still, but not part of official prayers. Hence, their status in respect to repetition is unclear.</i> are a problem.
Rebbi Abba the son of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Torah reading is discussed in tractate <i>Megillah</i>. The main place of this paragraph is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 4:5:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.4.5.2-7"><i>Megillah</i> Halakhah 4:5</a>.</i>: If one became paralyzed while reading in the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">In public, where every section read in public needs a benediction before and one after the reading. [Ezra Fleischer has recently published Genizah texts which might imply that private Bible readings also need benedictions before and after the reading: קטעים מקובצי תפילה ארץ־ישראליים מן הגניזה, קובץ על יד יג (כג) תשנ״ו.]</i>, the one who steps in for him should start from the place the first one started. For if you say from the place he stopped, the first verses would have been blessed before them but not after them, the last ones after them but not before them, but it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 19:8" href="/Psalms.19.8"><i>Ps.</i> 19:8</a>): “The Torah of the Eternal is perfect, restores the soul”, that it should be totally perfect.
It has been stated<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Megillah (Lieberman) 3:20" href="/Tosefta_Megillah_(Lieberman).3.20">Tosephta <i>Megillah</i> 3:20</a>. The parallel to this discussion is found in Yerushalmi <i>Megillah</i> 4:1. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 27a" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.27a">Babli (<i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 27a</a>) quotes only the result of the present discussion.</i>: Two should not read the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Simultaneously, in public.</i> and one translate<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">It was the usage, as it is still today in some Yemenite congregations, that someone read one verse in the Torah and then another person, the <i>meturgeman</i>, translated the verse into Aramaic (Onkelos for Eastern, Yerushalmi for Western congregations). In Greek speaking congregations, the Greek text (Septuagint, later Aquila, Symmachos, or Theodotion) was used.</i>. Rebbi Zeïra said, because of the benedictions<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">On one text, only one set of benedictions is admissible.</i>. But has it not been stated: Two should not translate and one read; could you say that is because of the benedictions? But it is because two voices do not enter into one ear.
It has been stated: “Two may read in the Torah but two may not read the <i>haphtarah</i> in the prophets.” Rebbi Ulla<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Rebbis Yoḥanan and Eleazar who used to commute between Babylonia and Galilee.</i> said, one calls several people to the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>baraita</i> does not speak of simultaneous, but of successive readers. It asserts that the <i>haphtarah</i> after the Torah reading on Sabbaths, holidays, and fastdays, cannot be split between different readers, but the Torah reading should be split among different people for different sections.</i> but one does not call several people for the prophets.
Rebbi Joshua the Southerner<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the fourth generation, student of R. Jonah and R. Aḥa. A similar statement is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 34a" href="/Berakhot.34a">Babli (34a</a>) as tannaïtic text.</i> said: There are three things of which too little or too much is bad and average is good: sour dough, salt, and refusal<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the part of the Mishnah which declares that in an emergency, if a reader has to be removed, his replacement should not refuse. It follows that without an emergency one should refuse; the rules are spelled out here.</i>. The first time he refuses, the second time he hesitates, the third time he runs and comes. Rebbi Ḥuna<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">In the Rome ms.: Rebbi Eleazar, the better reading.</i> was sitting in a synagogue. The organizer came and importuned one<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Asked him more than three times and did not realize that if somebody refuses three times, he must have a valid reason not to be “emissary of the congregation.”</i> to go up and he did not accept it. At the end, that one came to Rebbi Eleazar and said to him: My master should not be angry with me; I did not go up because I was not fully awake. He said to him: I am not mad at you but at the one who importuned.
Batitay was paralized at <i>ophanim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">The second part of the <i>Qedušah,</i> the recitiation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 6:3" href="/Isaiah.6.3"><i>Is.</i> 6:3</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 3:12" href="/Ezekiel.3.12"><i>Ez.</i> 3:12</a> in the middle of the first benediction of <i>Shema‘</i>. [The paragraph cannot deal with <i>Qedušah</i> in the <i>Amidah</i> since there <i>ophanim</i> are not mentioned in the introductory sentence and any error in the first three benedictions requires restarting anyhow.] Rebbi Abun’s answer shows that Baṭiṭai the reader was paralyzed not during, but after his recitation of the sentence connecting <a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 6:3" href="/Isaiah.6.3"><i>Is.</i> 6:3</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 3:12" href="/Ezekiel.3.12"><i>Ez.</i> 3:12</a> since the congregation already had answered the second verse.<br>The first part of the benediction speaks of the creation of the world and leads up to <i>Qedušah;</i> the second part after <i>Qedušah</i> is a hymn to God in His relation to man; it has a different subject. The Yerushalmi here assumes that the <i>Qedušah</i> before the <i>Shema‘</i> could not be recited in private prayers. Hence, the two parts of the benediction, both of which can be recited in private prayer, in public service have the status of two distinct benedictions in the sense of the Mishnah.</i>. They went and asked Rebbi Abun. Rebbi Abun said to them in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: His replacement should start at the place where he interrupted. They said to him: But did we not state: “He starts from the start of the benediction where the other person made the error?” He said to them: Since you answered <i>Qedušah,</i> it is as if you started a new benediction.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He who stands before the arc should not answer Amen after the Cohanim because of the distraction<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">The “emissary of the congregation” who stands before the arc and has to recite the priestly blessing (between the last two benedictions) so that the Cohanim may repeat the blessing aloud should not say “Amen” after each sentence of the priesly blessing because he must go on reciting the appropriate words (and the following last benediction) without the help of a prayer book.</i>. If there is no Cohen there but him, he should not lift his hands. But if he is sure that he can lift his hands and return to his prayer, he may do so<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Devarim Rabbah 7:1" href="/Devarim_Rabbah.7.1"><i>Midrash Rabba Devarim</i> 7(1</a>), an early Israeli <i>Yelammedenu</i> Midrash, extends the last sentence, “but if he is sure that he can return to his prayer, he may do so,” also to answering Amen after the Cohanim, “because there is nothing greater before the Holy One, praise to Him, than the Amen which Israel answer.” It is very likely that when this Midrash was composed, the flowering of synagogal poetry already had led to the writing of prayer books for the reader.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Megillah (Lieberman) 3:27" href="/Tosefta_Megillah_(Lieberman).3.27">Tosephta <i>Megillah</i> 3:27</a> is similar to this text.</i>: He who recites the blessings for the <i>Shema‘</i><sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew expression meant different things at different times. The translation follows the consensus of the Gaonic responsa that פורס means “recites the benediction” on basis of <i>Targum Jonathan</i> to <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 9:13" href="/I_Samuel.9.13"><i>1Sam.</i> 9:13</a> where הוא יברך הזבח is rendered by הוּא פָרִיס מְזוֹנָא. The Gaonic interpretation is that, even though at the end of a full prayer one may recite Amen on his own prayer, this does not apply to the benedictions after the <i>Shema‘</i>. Most Medieval commentators take פורס to mean “to parcel out” and apply the term to a group of people who prayed with less than a quorum and after the <i>Amidah</i> found themselves with 10 adult males; they then may appoint a reader who recites half <i>Kaddish,</i> ברכוּ, possibly the first benediction for the <i>Shema‘</i>, and the repetition of the <i>Amidah</i> with <i>Qedushah</i> and the priestly blessings. The Ashkenazic interpretation is supported by the reading of the Tosephta (<i>loc. cit.</i>) where פורס clearly means “breaking, parcel out”.</i>, he who stands before the ark, he who lifts his hands, he who reads in the Torah, he who recites <i>Haphtarah</i> from the prophets, and he who recites any blessing for obligations spelled out in the Torah, should not recite Amen after his own benediction. If he answered, he is uncivilized. Some Tannaïm have stated: he is uncivilized; and some Tannaïm have stated: he is wise. Rav Ḥisda said: He who said “he is wise” refers to him who answers at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">In Sephardic and Oriental interpretation, this refers to all prayers, when one recites “Amen” after one’s own benediction at the end of a well defined unit of several benedictions which form a whole that can stand for itself (except the benedictions for the recitation of <i>Shema‘</i>). This is the reasonable interpretation of the Yerushalmi here. In the Babli, the parallel discussion is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 45b" href="/Berakhot.45b"><i>Berakhot</i> 45b</a> on reciting Grace after the meal, where Amen separates the part which is a Biblical obligation from the rest which is purely rabbinic. Hence, Ashkenazic interpretation restricts “Amen” after one’s own benediction to the third benediction of Grace.</i>, but he who says “he is uncivilized” refers to him who answers every single benediction.
Rebbi Ḥanina said<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Mishnah speaks about the priestly blessing, some rules are added here about the preference given to Cohanim in the society of Non-Cohanim. The parallel to the second statement of R. Ḥanina is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 37a" href="/Yoma.37a">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 37a</a>.</i>: Two Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Jews who are not Cohanim. Levites seem to be included in the general denomination of “Israel”.</i> and one Cohen, one takes the Cohen in the middle<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">To give the place of honor to the Cohen.</i>. That is, when they are all equal. But if one of them is learned, one takes the one with a title<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">A rabbinic title. A compacted version of the Yerushalmi is quoted in <i>Raviah</i> #577.</i> in the middle.
Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said: I never recited Grace<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Reciting Grace aloud for all the participants in a meal. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi was the greatest authority in his generation; nevertheless he refused for himself the precedence granted the rabbinical authority by Rebbi Ḥanina. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 28a" href="/Megillah.28a">Babli, <i>Megillah</i> 28a</a>, that is rather vehemently opposed by R. Yoḥanan.</i> in the presence of a Cohen and I never let an Israel say Grace before me<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:9:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.9.2-10">Yerushalmi <i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:9</a>, the reading is “before him”, meaning the Cohen. In that version, R. Joshua ben Levi negates the entire ruling of R. Ḥanina and states that the Cohen always has precedence. Nevertheless, since his statement is formulated as a personal act, not as a precept for everybody, the Yerushalmi <i>Giṭṭin</i> proves by this statement that the precedence given the Cohen is a Rabbinic ordinance, not a Torah law. [R. Eliahu Fulda and R. Z. Frankel hold that R. Joshua was a Levite and extends the rule of R. Ḥanina to place the Levite between Cohen and Israel in order of precedence.]</i>.
Rebbi Judah ben Pazi in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Every Cohen who stays in the synagogue and does not lift his hands transgresses a positive commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">This statement has been discussed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:1:19" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.1.19">Halakha 3:1, Notes 84–89</a>. The two tradents here were both Cohanim and they had different ways to evade their duty if they felt sick or weak. [In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 38b" href="/Sotah.38b">Babli (<i>Soṭah</i> 38b</a>) three positive commandments are enumerated that the Cohen transgresses by his inaction.]</i>. When Rebbi Judah ben Pazi was weak he supported his head<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Possibly he bandaged his head so that is was clear to everybody that he was not well.</i> and stood behind a pillar. Rebbi Eleazar went outside.
Rebbi Aḥa, Rebbi Tanḥuma ben Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Simlai: They lift their hands in a town where all are Cohanim<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">And there is nobody left in the men’s section of the synagogue whom they could bless. In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 38b" href="/Sotah.38b">Babli (<i>Soṭa</i> 38b</a>) it is required that 10 Cohanim remain in their places in order to answer Amen after the blessings. The Babli is everywhere opposed to giving women a place in services or study. From here to the end of the Halakhah, the text is found (almost) word by word in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:9:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.9.2-10">Yerushalmi <i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:9</a>.</i>. Whom do they bless? Their brethren in North, South, East, and West. Who answers Amen after them? Women and small children.
Abbaye ben Rebbi Benjamin<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 38b" href="/Sotah.38b">Babli (<i>Soṭah</i> 38b</a>) he is called Abba the son of Rav Minyamin bar Ḥiyya, a Babylonian Amora of the third generation.</i> stated: Those who stand behind the Cohanim are not included in their blessing. Those who stand before the Cohanim; Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said the blessing even cuts through an iron wall<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) this is a tradition of R. Joshua ben Levi.</i>. About those who stand on the side, we may understand from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Parah 12:2" href="/Mishnah_Parah.12.2">Mishnah <i>Parah</i> 12:2</a>, dealing with a man who wants to sprinkle from the water mixed with ashes from the red heifer on a person impure by contact with a dead body. It is a general rule that the water used for this purpose becomes invalid if, after it was taken from a flowing source, the person in charge of the water lets it slip from his mind. An action that contradicts the intention has the status of a slip of mind.</i>: If he wanted to sprinkle before him and he sprinkled behind him, behind him and he sprinkled before him, his sprinkling is invalid. Before him and he sprinkled on his sides, his sprinkling is valid. This implies that those who stand on the side are included in the blessing<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Cohanim intend to bless the people before them, this intention automatically includes those who stand on their sides and excludes only those behind their backs. (The same reason is given in the Babli, <i>loc. cit.</i>)</i>.
Rav Ḥisda said, the organizer<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">In old sources, the חזן is not the person who sings in the service but the organizer of the community. The statement of the Yerushalmi implies that the call “Cohanim” to alert the priests to recite the benediction preceding the priestly blessing is not pronounced by the reader (who has to pronounce every word of the priestly blessing before it is recited aloud by the Cohanim) but by the organizer (or the servant) of the community.</i> must be an Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 38a" href="/Sotah.38a">Babli (<i>Soṭah</i> 38a</a>), Rav Ḥisda is quoted to the opposite effect that only a Cohen may call “Cohanim”. However, in one manuscript (Rome) of the Babli, the reading is not “a Cohen may call ‘Cohanim’ ” but “one Cohen calls ‘Cohanim’ ” and then the statement would be parallel to the Yerushalmi. This reading of the Babli is the basis of the interpretation of (the Italian) <i>Shibbole Halleqet</i>.</i>. Rav Naḥman bar Jacob said, if there was one Cohen he calls “Cohen”<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>), Abbaye declares that one Cohen is not called at all but he starts by himself.</i>, if there are two they call “Cohanim”. Rav Ḥisda<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">In Yerushalmi <i>Giṭṭin</i>, the author of this statement is Rav Ḥuna.</i> said, even if there was only one Cohen he says “Cohanim”, because he only calls the tribe.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> It is a bad sign for him who prays when he makes a mistake. And if he is an emissary of the congregation, it is a bad sign for those who sent him because the emissary of somebody is like that person. They said about Rebbi Ḥanina ben Dosa that he was praying for sick people and saying that this one was going to live and that one was dying. They asked him, how do you know? He said to them, if my prayer comes easily from my lips I know that he has been accepted; otherwise, I know that he is being torn.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rav Aḥa bar Jacob said, only at “Forefathers.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Is it a bad omen if he errs there. The tradent here is Babylonian. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 34b" href="/Berakhot.34b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 34b</a>), the parallel statement is attributed to the Babylonian-born Rebbi Ḥiyya (bar Abba) in the name of (the third generation) Babylonian Rav Safra. The statement must be Babylonian since the Yerushalmi requires attention for the entire <i>Amidah</i>.</i>”
It happened that the son of Rabban Gamliel fell ill and he sent two scholars to Rebbi Ḥanina ben Dosa in the latter’s city. He said to them, wait until I go to the upper floor. He went to the upper floor, came back, and said to them: I am sure that Rabban Gamliel’s son will get respite from his sickness. They noted that at this hour he asked for food<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 34b" href="/Berakhot.34b">Babli (34b</a>) he is reported to have asked for water.</i>. Rebbi Samuel ben Rebbi Naḥmani said: If you were able to concentrate your attention on your prayer, you are told that your prayer was heard. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 10:17" href="/Psalms.10.17"><i>Ps.</i> 10:17</a>) “You prepare their hearts, You will listen with Your ears.<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">The first “you” refers to the person, the others to God.</i>” Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said: If a person’s lips bore fruit<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Not only that he concentrated his attention as required by R. Samuel ben Naḥmani, but that his lips produced a well-formed result.</i> he is told that his prayer was heard. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 57:19" href="/Isaiah.57.19"><i>Is.</i> 57:19</a>) “He Who created the fruit of lips: peace, peace to the far and the near said the Eternal, I shall heal him.”

Chapter 6



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Which benedictions are recited on produce<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Before one eats of these fruits, as will be explained in the Halakhah. All benedictions start with “Praise to You, Eternal, our God, King of the Universe”. This formula is understood and does not have to be repeated.</i>? On tree-grown fruits one says “Creator of the fruit of the tree” except for wine, because on wine one says “Creator of the fruit of the vine.” But on fruits of the land one says “Creator of the fruit of the soil” except for bread, because on bread<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The words “because on bread” are not in the Venice print but since they appear in the Leyden manuscript the omission seems to be a printer’s error.</i> one says “He Who produces bread from the earth.” On vegetables one says “Creator of the fruit of the soil”, Rebbi Yehudah says: “Creator of kinds of vegetables<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yehudah insists that benedictions should be exact and vegetables without seeds do not qualify as “fruits”.</i>.”
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 24:1" href="/Psalms.24.1"><i>Ps.</i> 24:1</a>): “The Eternal’s are the earth and what is in it, the dry land and its inhabitants.” He who profits from the world commits larceny<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Since he uses God’s property, not his own.</i> until good deeds will permit him<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to say Grace after a meal is spelled out in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:10" href="/Deuteronomy.8.10"><i>Deut.</i> 8:10</a>. The obligation to recite blessings before one eats is not mentioned explicitly in the Torah. Since Grace is only treated in the next Chapter, one has to find here Biblical allusions to this duty and (in the next section) to the duty of reciting a benediction before fulfilling specified commandments.<br>The verse appears in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 35a" href="/Berakhot.35a">Babli (35a</a>) in the name of Samuel. R. Levi compares the verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 115:16" href="/Psalms.115.16"><i>Ps.</i> 115:16</a>) “Heaven is the Eternal’s heaven but the earth He gave to mankind”, explaining that before a benediction everything is the Eternal’s property but after a benediction it becomes human property. While Rebbi Levi is a Galilean teacher, the Yerushalmi rejects his combination since in the third paragraph earthly enjoyment is only “<i>as</i> if one ate from one’s own”. The text of the Yerushalmi is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:1" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.1">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:1</a> which is identical with the Talmudic text except that there it says “until all good deeds will permit him”, meaning that only if the preparation of food is completely within the commandments of the Torah then the last step of the preparation, the recitation of the benediction, will allow the food to be given to man as his own.</i>. Rebbi Abbahu said, it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:9" href="/Deuteronomy.22.9"><i>Deut.</i> 22:9</a>) “Lest the fullness of the seed that you sow and the yield of the vineyard should be forbidden.” The entire world and its contents are like a vineyard. What is its redemption? The benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">This argument is very difficult to understand and the commentators either chose to ignore it or give very incongruous explanations. The best explanation is that of R. Eliahu Fulda who in his Yerushalmi edition suppresses the word פֶּן “lest”. One would have to assume that Rebbi Abbahu’s text did not have the word but that later scribes added it from memory. By it the negative implication of the verse (which speaks about growing different kinds of plants in a vineyard) are changed to a positive one which now should be translated: “That you shall sanctify the fullness of the seed that you sow and the yield of the vineyard.” Since the sanctity is not that of sacrifices, the sanctity may be removed by redemption (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:11" href="/Leviticus.27.11"><i>Lev.</i> 27:11</a>). However, there can be no monetary redemption of anything not explicitly authorized in the Torah. Hence, the redemption is non-monetary and is the traditional praise given to God in benedictions. [The simple sense of the verse is that produce grown in a vineyard becomes forbidden for private use as if it were dedicated for sacrifice.]</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 16:2" href="/Psalms.16.2"><i>Ps.</i> 16:2</a>) “Say to the Eternal, You are my Master<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The translation follows the Biblical text, not the text written here.</i>, my good is only with You.” If you ate and recited the benedictions then it is as if you ate from your own. Another explanation<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is extremely hard to understand; the next two interpretations have nothing to do with the topic on hand; they are only added to indicate translations that might be considered if בל is not a negation but a verb form derived from בלל, which may mean either “to give food” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Judges 19:24" href="/Judges.19.24"><i>Jud.</i> 19:24</a>) or, more frequently, “mixed with fluid, moistened.”</i>: “My good is בל with you”, I am feeding My goodness to your body. Another explanation: “My good is בל with you”, all good things may be mixed together and come to you. Rebbi Aḥa said, what is “only with you?” I shall not bring any good things to the world without you. As it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 41:44" href="/Genesis.41.44"><i>Gen.</i> 41:44</a>) “Without you nobody may lift his hand.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Taking בל as shorthand for בִּלְעֲדֵי “without”.</i>” Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:24" href="/Leviticus.19.24"><i>Lev.</i> 19:24</a>) “Holy for praises”, this shows that it needs benediction before and after. From here did Rebbi Aqiba say that nobody should taste anything before he gives praise<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">This is also quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 35a" href="/Berakhot.35a">Babli (35a</a>); the source of both Talmudim is <i>Sifra</i> on the verse. The verse speaks of the fruits of a vineyard in its fourth year when the grapes can be used for the first time after having been forbidden for the first three years. This is only a hint for any other food.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥaggai and Rebbi Jeremiah went to the Bazaar<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The translation is tentative; בית חנוותא means “the house of stores”, which might be a description of a <i>shuq</i> even though it is difficult to explain why the word שׁוּקָא was not used. It is not clear what kind of <i>miẓwah</i> the two rabbis performed in the market. In the opinion of R. Eleazar Askari they were <i>agoranomoi</i>, overseers of weights and measures, and Rebbi Ḥaggai recited a benediction before starting to go from stall to stall and checking the balances for correctness since that is a Biblical commandment repeated several times in the Pentateuch (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:15" href="/Deuteronomy.25.15"><i>Deut.</i> 25:15</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:36" href="/Leviticus.19.36"><i>Lev.</i> 19:36</a>) in addition to the prohibition of fraudulent business practices.<br>The Rome manuscript has instead of בית חנוותא the expression לְמֵי חַטָּאתָה “the water for the ashes of the read heifer”, the drawing of which certainly would need a benediction. The Talmud reports that Rebbi Ḥaggai finished his Talmud studies with Rav Ḥuna I at age 18 and lived to be 160 years old; so, as shown in the commentary to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1:1</a>, he still could have seen ashes of the read heifer, but these could not have been preserved at the time of Rebbi Jeremiah who lived during the third and fourth generations of Amoraïm, even if these ashes were uniquely reserved for Cohanim eating <i>Terumah</i>.<br>R. Zachariah Frankel wants to emend to בֵּית חַתְנוּתָא “place of a wedding” but his reading has no basis in antique or medieval sources.</i>. Rebbi Ḥaggai was quick to recite a blessing. Rebbi Jeremiah said to him: You acted correctly because all commandments need a benediction. And from where that all commandments<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">After establishing benedictions before the consumption of food one establishes now the need for benedictions before the execution of positive commandments (by tradition, only those to be performed at specific times or occasions, not those that are always valid).</i> need a benediction? Rebbi Tanḥuma, Rebbi Abba bar Cahana in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 24:12" href="/Exodus.24.12"><i>Ex.</i> 24:12</a>) “I want to give you the stone tablets, the Torah and the commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The verse really reads: “both Torah and Commandments”. The double <i>vaw</i> in the verse is essential for R. Eleazar’s argument.</i>.” It brackets Torah and commandment. Just as Torah needs a benediction, a commandment also needs benediction.
Rebbi Yoḥanan took an olive<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Here starts the actual discussion of the rules given in the Mishnah. R. Ḥiyya bar Abba’s report on the story appears also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 38b-39a" href="/Berakhot.38b-39a">Babli (38b–39a</a>) but there the argument and the inferences drawn are totally different. In the Babli, R. Ḥiyya bar Abba reports that the olive was salted, which seems natural since raw olives are bitter. The discussion in the Babli is whether pickling or cooking changes the applicable benediction; it is clear from this paragraph that at least for the “Seven Kinds” the Yerushalmi does not contemplate any change in benedictions.</i> and recited a benediction before and after. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba was looking at him. Rebbi Yoḥanan said to him: Babylonian, why are you looking at me? Don’t you agree that everything from the Seven Kinds<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The Seven Kinds are “the fruits for which the Land of Israel is praised”, enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:8" href="/Deuteronomy.8.8"><i>Deut.</i> 8:8</a>: “A land of wheat and barley, vine and fig, and pomegranate; a land of oil olive and (date) honey.” Since in v. 10 it is stated “when you will eat and be satiated, you must praise the Eternal, your God, for the good land that He gave you,” it follows that these kinds need a benediction afterwards that contains praise for food, land, (and Jerusalem.) This is called “one benediction in the kind of three”; the three benedictions are reserved for grain eaten in the form of bread. The benediction before is the applicable one of those mentioned in the Mishnah.</i> needs a benediction before and after? He agrees. What is his problem? Because its pit reduces it<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In general, anything smaller than the volume of an average olive is too insignificant to require a benediction. The edible part of an olive is much smaller than the volume of an average olive.</i>. Does Rebbi Yoḥanan agree that its pit reduces it? What Rebbi Yoḥanan did was because of a creature<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) conjectures that R. Yoḥanan ate a large olive which even if pitted still has the size of an average olive. The Yerushalmi here is emphatic that any complete edible fruit needs a benediction before and after it is eaten, irrespective of size.</i>. The word of Rebbi Yoḥanan implies that even one berry from a pomegranate needs a benediction before and after<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A pomegranate is full of seeds; each seed is surrounded by fruit flesh encased in a membrane. One such cell containing the seed and the fruit flesh is a berry. Without the seed it would not be a creature and without the fruit flesh it would not be edible but with both it needs benediction before and after if the membrane is untouched.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Parallel texts in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:3" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.3">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:3</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50b" href="/Berakhot.50b">Babli 50b</a>.</i>“Wine in its natural state<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">A heavy subtropical wine with an alcohol content of close to 15%, unmixed with any water.</i>, one says for it ‘Creator of the fruit of the tree’<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eliezer holds that no human will want to drink such a heavy dose of alcohol or at least it is not admissible to have such unmixed wine at a formal dinner.</i> and one may not use it to wash his hands<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Hands must be washed with water and while fruit juice is considered water, in the opinion of R. Eliezer pure wine is not.</i>; when it is mixed<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Standard mixing is one part wine to two parts water for an alcohol content of about 5%, Mishnah <i>Niddah</i>2:7.</i>, one says for it ‘Creator of the fruit of the vine’ and one may use it to wash his hands; these are the words of Rebbi Eliezer. But the Sages say, both pure and mixed one says over it ‘Creator of the fruit of the vine’ and one may use it to wash his hands<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">All sources of the Tosephta read everywhere “one may not” where the Yerushalmi has “one may”, and “one may” where the Yerushalmi has “one may not”. In the Babli, all sources read “one may” the first and last time but in the second instance some manuscripts and authorities follow readings of the Tosephta and some (Munich manuscript and some Medieval authorities) the readings of the Yerushalmi.</i>.” Rebbi Abba said, it is not forbidden because of wasting food<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">In general, wilful spoiling of food is a sin. It seems that the Yerushalmi restricts the use of fruit juice for washing of the hands to the ritual washing before eating bread, since that is part of the meal, but that washing with fruit juice just for cleansing is forbidden. The Gaonic <i>Halakhot Gedolot</i> explains that the prohibition of the Sages (in the version of the Babli) refers to the sin of wasting food.</i>.
Rebbi Jacob bar Zavdi in the name of Rebbi Abbahu<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 35b" href="/Berakhot.35b">Babli (35b</a>) this is a statement of R. Yoḥanan. The argument of R. Ḥiyya bar Pappus is purely Yerushalmi.</i>: On olive oil one recites “Creator of the fruit of the tree.” Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Pappus<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">An otherwise unknown Galilean Amora. In the Rome manuscript, his name is Rebbi Ḥinena bar Pappus.</i> said before Rebbi Zeïra: The Mishnah says so. “Except for wine because on wine one says ‘Creator of the fruit of the vine’.” Is wine not mashed<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Grape juice is really pressed, but so is olive oil, and only second and third pressings of oil are from ground olives. In any case, wine goes through a fermentation process and cannot be described as being “recognizable in its state.”</i>? But it says only “except for wine”, hence all other things even if they are mashed are recognizable in their state.
Rebbi Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 38b" href="/Berakhot.38b">Babli (38b</a>), Samuel is said to hold a different opinion. The Galilean authorities quoted there are those of the next paragraph. The interpretations of Babli and Yerushalmi differ.</i> said: Rav and Samuel both say, on cooked vegetable one says “that everything was created by His word.” Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Samuel: Large cooked<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">שלוק “cooked in water” in contrast to מבושל “cooked in broth”.</i> pieces of <i>liftan</i><sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">As a plant, לפתן means “beets”, but generally it means cooked vegetables served as main dish with bread (pitta bread to be used as fork and spoon in the absence of tableware except knives.) Meat was only eaten on special occasions, such as Sabbath, holidays, visits of important people, and after bleeding.</i>, if they are recognizable one says on them “Creator of the fruit of the earth;” if one mashed them one says “He, by Whose word everything was created.” Rebbi Yose said, does the Mishnah say so? “Except for bread because on bread one says ‘He Who produces bread from the earth.’.” Is bread not mashed<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Flour is ground (“mashed”) grain, one of the Seven Kinds.</i>? But it says only “except for bread”, hence all other things even if they are mashed are recognizable in their state<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, the statement of Rebbi Abba is superior to that of Rebbi Zeïra. This conclusion is the opposite of that of the Babli.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The entire paragraph is also found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 2:5:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.2.5.2-4"><i>Pesaḥim</i> 2:5</a>. One word in the current text has been corrected following that Yerushalmi text.</i> Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: One says “Creator of the fruit of the tree” on marinated<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">This is the exact meaning of the corresponding Arabic כַּבַּסַ.</i> olives. Rebbi Benjamin bar Jephet in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: One says “By Whose word everything was created<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The general benediction on everything not expressly mentioned in the Mishnah.</i>” on water-cooked vegetables. Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac said: a Mishnah supports Rebbi Benjamin bar Yephet: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 2:6:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.2.6.2-3"><i>Pesaḥim</i>2:6</a>) “but not marinated or cooked in water or cooked in broth<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah enumerates all herbs which qualify as “bitter herbs” on Passover, adding that these herbs are not usable if cooked or marinated. The implication is that after treatment they are no longer herbs but general food.</i>”; if they were recognizable in their state one could fulfill his duty with them on Passover. Rebbi Zeïra said, who understands well what Rebbi Yoḥanan said, Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba or Rebbi Benjamin bar Yephet? Not Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba?<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ḥiyya bar Abba studied much more intensively than R. Benjamin bar Yephet. This is the argument and conclusion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 38b" href="/Berakhot.38b">Babli (38b</a>). The refutation of Rebbi Zeïra’s argument is not in that Talmud.</i> And in addition from the fact that we see great rabbis going to a mourner’s meal, eat lupines<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Greek θέρμος. Raw lupines are cattle feed, too bitter for human consumption. They become edible only after long cooking. This statement supports R. Ḥiyya bar Abba.</i> and recite on them “Creator of the fruit of the earth;” Are not lupines certainly cooked? If you want, you may say there is a difference, since the Torah said “bitter herbs”, and cooked lupines have lost their bitterness. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, they<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ḥiyya bar Abba and R. Benjamin bar Yephet.</i> have no disagreement. Since olives usually are eaten fresh, they are recognizable in their state even if they are marinated. Vegetables are changed once they are cooked<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">One must assume that roots of lupine keep their shape and general appearance in cooking just as olives do. The rule that vegetables which are inedible unless cooked require the blessing “Creator of the fruit of the earth” is the opinion of Rav Ḥisda in the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>).</i>.
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa: Rebbi Neḥemiah and the rabbis disagree. Rebbi Neḥemiah said: “Who produced bread from the earth.” But the rabbis say, “Who produces bread from the earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 38a" href="/Berakhot.38a">Babli (38a</a>), the opinion ascribed here to the rabbis is that of Rebbi Neḥemiah and vice versa. This eliminates the question which the Yerushalmi raises about the current text of the benediction. In the opinion of the Babli, the preferred version (R. Neḥemiah here, the rabbis in the Babli) takes the present participle in an atemporal sense.</i>” This disagreement is like that disagreement: לפת, Rebbi Ḥinena bar Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">A preacher of the third generation of Galilean Amoraïm. The name of his teacher is unknown.</i> and Rebbi Samuel bar Immi<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the third generation who also appears as R. Samuel bar Ammi. His father and father-in-law also were rabbis.</i>; one said “<i>lefet</i>, was it not bread?<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the third generation who also appears as R. Samuel bar Ammi. His father and father-in-law also were rabbis.</i>” and the other one said “<i>lefet</i>, will it not be bread”? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 72:16" href="/Psalms.72.16"><i>Ps.</i> 72:16</a>) “There will be a piece of flour on the land, on mountain tops.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Since flour cannot form a loaf until it is baked, this means that bread will grow on mountain tops. This is a homily of R. Yoḥanan in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 92:6" href="/Psalms.92.6"><i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 92(6</a>), which appears in the name of several other Amoraïm in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 30b" href="/Shabbat.30b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 30b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 111b" href="/Ketubot.111b"><i>Ketubot</i> 111b</a>.</i>” Rebbi Jeremiah recited before Rebbi Zeïra “Who produced bread from the earth” and the latter praised him. Following Rebbi Neḥemiah<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">One is not supposed to follow a minority of one, much less to be praised for it.</i>? Not to amalgamate the letters<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">So that הָעוֹלָם מוֹצִיא should not be pronounced <i>ha‘ôlāmôẓî,</i> but clearly be said in two distinct words.</i>! If it is so, הַמִּין הָאָרֶץ<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Since לֶחֶם מִן also has two consecutive <i>mem</i> and could be read together. However, the change proposed here makes no sense; nobody wants to pronounce a meaningless benediction that would be close to blasphemy. The question does not merit an answer.</i>? In the opinion of Rebbi Neḥemiah<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">One wonders why they disagree only about the language for bread and not for wine.</i>, “He Who created the fruit of the vine”; in the opinion of the rabbis “Who creates the fruit of the vine.”
Rebbi Zeriqan said: Rebbi Zeïra asked: He who took a lupine and was reciting the benediction over it when it fell from his hand, does he have to recite a second benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Since the cooked lupine root becomes inedible when it falls into the dust, he has to take another one, not the one for which the benediction was intended.</i>? What is the difference between that and a water canal<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Since one has to say the benediction on water before one starts to drink, the water drops one drinks are not those that were in the same place at the moment of the benediction.</i>? They said, there he intended it from the start, but here he did not intend it from the start. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: One recites the benediction on bread only when one breaks it<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The formulation in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 39a" href="/Berakhot.39a">Babli (39a</a>) is: Rebbi Ḥiyya said, the benediction and the breaking of the bread must be finished simultaneously. This is accepted practice in the Yerushalmi, but is rejected in the Babli in favor of a ruling of the much later, fourth generation Babylonian Amora Rava who requires that the benediction be completely recited before one starts to break the bread.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said: This means that he who took a loaf<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The usual expression פַּת for bread designates a pittah; עִיגוּל here is a loaf of bread; it might be a round cake of pressed figs. R. Asher ben Yeḥiel copies the passage (Chapter 6, #20) which has פּוּגְלָא “a radish” instead of “a loaf”. That reading seems to be a copyist’s error.</i> and pronounced the benediction on it before it came to his hand, must recite a second benediction. Rebbi Tanḥum bar Yudan<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora whose time cannot be determined.</i> said, he must say “Praised be the Name of the Glory of His kingdom forever and ever,” in order not to utter the Name of Heaven in vain<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">By a statement of R. Yoḥanan and R. Simeon ben Laqish in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33a" href="/Berakhot.33a">Babli (33a</a>), any unnecessary benediction is a violation of the Fifth Commandment.</i>.
How far may he break<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">There are two connected problems here. The first one, what is the minimum size of a piece of bread (or any other food) that requires a benediction beforehand; the second, if one person makes a benediction over bread for an entire company (with the other participants answering “Amen” instead of reciting their own benedictions), what is the minimal size of a piece of bread that every participant has to receive and eat after the benediction. For Grace after meals, the situation is clear. The requirement from the Torah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:10" href="/Deuteronomy.8.10"><i>Deut.</i> 8:10</a>) is “when you will have eaten and will be satiated then you must praise the Eternal …”; the Biblical obligation applies only after a full meal. The rabbinic obligation explicitly applies to food that fills at least the volume of an olive; smaller amounts do not require Grace and, according the preceding paragraph, one may not recite Grace for such minute amounts. But since benedictions before eating are all rabbinic institutions, the problem is whether food in an amount less than the volume of an average olive must (or may) have a benediction and, if a benediction is recited on a larger loaf, whether the piece eaten immediately after the recitation of the benediction must be the size of an olive or not.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 37b" href="/Berakhot.37b">Babli (37b</a>) has another angle to the problem. Since bread has a separate benediction from cereal and cakes, how small may the recognizable pieces of bread in cereal or soup be so that it still falls under the category of bread rather than cereal or soup?</i>? Rebbi Ḥinena and Rebbi Mana, one says down to the size of an olive, the other says even smaller than the size of an olive. He who says down to the size of an olive, as it is stated “all<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Menachot 7:4" href="/Mishnah_Menachot.7.4">Mishnah <i>Menaḥot</i>7:4</a> that all flour offerings prepared in a vessel (baked or fried) must be broken into pieces before a handful of them is burned on the altar. There are two opinions on the size of admissible pieces (also reported <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 37a" href="/Berakhot.37a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 37a</a>).</i> are crumbled into olive-size pieces.” He who says, smaller than the size of an olive: “Rebbi Ismael stated, even if he reduced it<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The baked or fried flour-offering.</i> to its original form of fine flour.” It has been stated<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The first half of this statement appears in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:7" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.7">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:7</a>.</i>: “On everything that needs three benedictions at the end one says ‘He Who produces bread from the earth’ at the start, but on everything that does not need three benedictions at the end one does not say ‘He Who produces bread from the earth’ at the start.” They objected: But if it is less than the size of an olive, one does not say three benedictions at the end. Does this mean that one should not say “He Who produces bread from the earth” at the start? Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said, it is needed for other kinds<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The statement does not refer to size, but to kinds of food; if it is not bread it does not receive the benediction for bread. Hence, no conclusion as to the correct practice can be drawn.</i>.
Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav: Those assembled may not taste anything before the one who recited the benediction did taste. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said: They may drink even if he did not drink. Do they disagree? Rav said in case all need the same loaf<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Which is the normal case if there is a real loaf of bread and not pittot. But wine everybody drinks from his own glass that was filled beforehand. The question whether the one who recites the benediction should eat first and then distribute the bread or vice versa is addressed in the next paragraph. [The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 47a" href="/Berakhot.47a">Babli (47a</a>) has only the statement of Rav; there it is explained that לטעום “to taste”, usually applied to drinking, here means “eating” as is clear from the Yerushalmi.]</i> but Rebbi Joshua said when each one had his own cup in his hand.
It has been stated: The one who recited the benediction takes first<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">From the food on his plate (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 47a" href="/Berakhot.47a">Babli 47a</a>).</i> but if he wants to honor his teacher or someone who is greater than himself in Torah, he has the right to do so. When Rav was breaking bread he was eating with his left hand and distributing with his right hand<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">To minimize the time between the benediction and the actual eating by the other participants in the meal.</i>. Rav Huna said: “Take and recite a benediction, take and recite a benediction” is not an interruption for the benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is needed for the other person’s benediction, it will not cause the person who made the original benediction to forget that he made the benediction in order to eat.</i>; “give hay to the oxen” is an interruption for the benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 40a" href="/Berakhot.40a">Babli (40a</a>) this is the opinion of R. Yoḥanan (i. e., the Yerushalmi), but there practice follows R. Sheshet who quotes Rav to the effect that nobody may eat as long as his animals are hungry; hence, the order to feed the oxen is a necessary step in preparing to eat.</i>.
Rab Ḥuna said: On <i>shatita</i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The Aramaic <i>shatita</i> is the same as Latin <i>moretum</i>, a dish made by mixing pounded roasted flour or pounded roasted pea meal with water or vinegar (and other ingredients.) Its preparation is described in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 36b" href="/Avodah_Zarah.36b">Babli <i>Avodah zarah</i> 36b</a> and in great detail in the poem <i>Moretum</i> in <i>Appendix Vergiliana</i> [cf. E. and H. Guggenheimer, לשוננוּ vol. 36 (5733) pp. 105–112]. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 31a" href="/Berakhot.31a">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 31a</a>), the rule of R. Huna applies only to watery <i>moretum</i>. This and the following rule are placed here to collect all formal statements of Rav Huna on benedictions for food. [An intermediate between <i>šĕtîtā</i> and <i>moretum</i> may be Greek μυττωτός “dish composed of pounded ingredients”, title of a poem by Virgil’s teacher Parthenios and model of Virgil’s <i>moretum</i>(E. G.).]</i>, which is ground <i>moretum</i>, one recites “that everything was created by His word”.
Rav Huna said: If one put something into his mouth and forgot to recite the benediction, if it is fluid he spits it out, if it is food he puts it to one side<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50b-51a" href="/Berakhot.50b-51a">Babli (50b–51a</a>), Rav Yehudah, a student of Rav but mainly of Samuel, has three categories: Fluids he swallows, food that can be taken out he takes out, food that one cannot touch once it is in the mouth he puts into one cheek. In the Babli, the verse of R. Yoḥanan is quoted to prove that food which can be taken out without problems must be taken out. While the Yerushalmi states a clear difference between Babylonian and Israeli practice, the Babli harmonizes both practices.</i>. Rebbi Isaac bar Mari<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">His name appears only here. In the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) he is called רִבִּי יִצְחָק קַסְקַסָּאָה, cf. Latin <i>cascus</i> “old, old-fashioned” (E. G.). [The word קסקסים that appears in Tosephta and Babli is explained by Rashi as weeds, by S. Lieberman as rock outcrops in a field, from קשקשים “fins”, by J. Levy as clumps of earth or stones hewn from a rock.]</i> before Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan even if it is food he takes it out since it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 71:8" href="/Psalms.71.8"><i>Ps.</i> 71:8</a>) “May my mouth be full of Your praise<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">This text is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:6" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.6">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:6</a>. It is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 37a" href="/Berakhot.37a">Babli 37a</a> where, however, the formula “Creator of kinds of seeds” is replaced by “Creator of the fruit of the earth” since the Babli does not recognize any benediction for produce not mentioned by the majority opinion in the Mishnah.</i>, all day long of Your glory.”
He who chews wheat kernels says on them “Creator of kinds of seeds.” If he baked or cooked them, as long as pieces are recognizable he recites on them “He Who produces bread from the earth” and afterwards three benedictions. If the pieces are not recognizable, he recites “Creator of kinds of food” and afterwards one benediction in the kind of three<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">This text is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:6" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.6">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:6</a>. It is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 37a" href="/Berakhot.37a">Babli 37a</a> where, however, the formula “Creator of kinds of seeds” is replaced by “Creator of the fruit of the earth” since the Babli does not recognize any benediction for produce not mentioned by the majority opinion in the Mishnah.</i>. Down to which size are there pieces? Rebbi Yose bar Rebbi Abun, Cahana bar Malkiah<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Rav Cahana bar Malkio in the Babli, whose quote of a statement of Rav is quoted by Rebbi Jeremiah. Hence, his time has to be fixed between Rav and the emigration of Rebbi Jeremiah from Babylonia. The statement here is not identical with the earlier one that dealt with pieces of bread eaten by themselves. In the interpretation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Berakhot 37b" href="/Tosafot_on_Berakhot.37b">Tosaphot (37b</a>), his statement is rejected by the Babli.</i> in the name of Rav: down to olive-sized bits.
He who chews rice<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ὄρυζα.</i> says for it: “Creator of kinds of seeds.” If he baked or cooked it, even if there are recognizable pieces he says for it: “Creator of kinds of food” and he does not have to recite a benediction afterwards<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:7" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.7">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:7</a>. Rebbi Jeremiah quotes the Tosephta in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 37a" href="/Berakhot.37a">Babli (37a</a>) which also disagrees about the concluding benediction. The next paragraph will show that “no benediction afterwards” really means “no lengthy benediction afterwards”, only the short form.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah said, “Creator of the fruit of the earth.” Bar Marina recited before Rebbi Zeïra and Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba “By Whose word everything was created.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">From their silence one may infer that they agreed.</i>” Rebbi Simeon the pious said “Creator of all sorts of delicacies.” Rebbi Yose bar Rebbi Abun said: They do not disagree. He who says “Creator of kinds of food”, if he made it into a ball. He who said “Creator of the fruit of the earth”, if it is separated<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">If the individual kernels are still recognizable, in contrast to the ball (Latin <i>bulla</i>) in which no individual kernels are visible.</i>. He who said “By Whose word everything was created”, if it is cooked in water a long time<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">If it is a mash.</i>. He who said “Creator of all sorts of delicacies”, if it is torn<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">If one bakes any kind of rice product with spices, except whole grains. [The Babli does not admit different benedictions for different cases.]</i>.
That is beforehand. Afterwards, Rebbi Jonah in the name of Rebbi Simeon the pious: “He Who created all sorts of delicacies to delight with them the souls of all living. Praise to You, Eternal, for the Land and its delicacies.”<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">It is implied that the four admissible benedictions for baked or cooked rice (and all other food not covered otherwise) requires a final benediction adapted to the corresponding intial benediction. [Again, the Babli has only one form of the short final benediction, the one given in the Yerushalmi for meat.]</i>
Rebbi Abba bar Jacob in the name of the great Rebbi Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rebbi Isaac (Nappaḥa), Amora of the second generation. His formula is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 37a" href="/Berakhot.37a">Babli (37a</a>) for cooked cereal but without the final doxology. [Current practice is to include the doxology without invoking the Name, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Berakhot 37a:3:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Berakhot.37a.3.1">Tosaphot 37a, s. v. בורא</a>.]</i>: When Rebbi was eating meat or an egg he used to say: “Creator of many living things to sustain with them all living souls. Praise to You, Eternal, Life of the worlds.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">If the vocalization is חֵי הָעוֹלָמִים (rejected by Maimonides), the translation would be: “Eternally living.”</i>
That is at the end. At the start? Rebbi Ḥaggai said: “Creator of kinds of living things.” Rebbi Yose objected, does not the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 6:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.6.4.1">Mishnah (6:4</a>) disagree? “On vinegar, on locusts, and on fallen fruits he says: “By Whose word everything was created.” And is a locust not a living thing<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah states explicitly that “on everything that is not growing from the earth one says ‘By Whose word everything was created.’ ” The mention of vinegar (soured wine) and fallen fruits is meant to show that even produce that has become almost worthless needs this benediction; (edible) locusts are a scourge and the emphasis is that nevertheless they need a benediction if roasted and eaten. Hence, the statement of Rebbi Ḥaggai has no justification. In Hebrew and Aramaic, “living” applies only to animals but not to plants.</i>?
The statement of Rebbi Simeon the pious<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">He requires a formal “benediction in the kind of three” for delicacies made from any kind of flour. We now return to the main topic after the digression about non-vegetable food.</i> turns out like that of Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">He requires a final doxology from “Creator of many living things.”</i> and both of them like Rabban Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">The second statement of his is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:7" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.7">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:7</a>. The first part of this Tosephta is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 37a" href="/Berakhot.37a">Babli 37a</a>.</i>, as it was stated: “The following is the principle: Rebbi Yehudah said in the name of Rabban Gamliel that on everything that is of the Seven Kinds but is not flour, or flour<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Including grain flour that is not enumerated in the verse, e. g., rye and spelt.</i> but not baked as bread, Rabban Gamliel says that he recites afterwards three benedictions; but the Sages say, one benediction. On everything that is neither from the Seven Kinds nor a kind of flour, Rabban Gamliel says he recites benedictions before and after, but the sages say before, but not after<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning “Creator of all kinds of living things” without the final doxology; it is not considered a formal benediction. Rebbi Simeon the Pious and Rebbi follow Rabban Gamliel who in this case does not spell out which benediction he requires at the end.</i>.”
Rebbi Jacob bar Idi in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Everything that is cereal and like dough put in boiling water and is of the Five Kinds<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">The five kinds of flour that are admissible for <i>matzot</i> on Passover because they can become sour: Wheat, barley, oats, rye, and spelt. Only these produce bread that needs full Grace and pastries that need “one benediction imitating three (or, in our text today, four) benedictions,” i. e., its text contains one sentence each for each benediction of full Grace.</i>, over it one says “Creator of kinds of foods”, and one recites after it one benediction imitating three. And everything that is cereal and like dough put in boiling water, but is not of the Five Kinds, Rebbi Jonah said that Rebbi Zeïra sent to those of the Yeshivah of Rebbi Yannai<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Still existing two generations after the death of Rebbi Yannai.</i> and they told him, but I do not know what they told him. What is it? Rebbi Yose said, it is reasonable to assume “That everything was created by His word.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">The catch-all for all food not covered by anything else and that will allow one to eat all foods.</i>” Rebbi Jeremiah inquired: He who ate cereal, what does he recite at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">“One benediction imitating three” or “Creator of many living things.”</i>? Rebbi Yose said, and therefore Rebbi Jeremiah never ate any cereal<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Except in a meal that was covered by the benediction over bread at the start and Grace afterwards.</i>. That is the only one thing about which he was in doubt<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">צורכא, a technical expression, frequent in the Yerushalmi in this sense, and difficult to translate verbally.</i>.
Why does one finish<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">The “benediction imitating three” is recited for wine, the Seven Fruits, and baked goods other than bread. That benediction first gives praise for the food, then for the Land of Israel, then prays for the rebuilding of Jerusalem (and adds a sentence for the Rabbinic fourth benediction of Grace, praising God as source of all good.) The question is why only the first two themes are repeated at the end since the final doxology reads in all cases: “Praise to You, Eternal, for the Land and … (here the specific food is named).”</i> with “the Land”? It is similar to Grace for day laborers. As has been stated<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:24" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.24">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:24</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 16a" href="/Berakhot.16a">Babli 16a</a>. Day laborers who are paid by the hour and whose lunch break counts as worked time have the obligation to spend as little time as possible on their lunch and, in any case, their worship of God should not be paid by the employer except for the legal minimum.</i>: “Workers who were doing work with the owner shall recite the first benediction, include Jerusalem in the benediction for the Land and finish with ‘the Land.’ But if they were working for their food<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Without any cash payments the employer is legally required to give them time for full standard Grace.</i> or if the employer was eating with them, then they recite four benedictions.” In the school of Rebbi Yannai they treated it as a formula of benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">They formulated the fixed “benediction imitating three” and did not tolerate any deviation.</i>.
Does one have to mention in it the occasion<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Does one have to mention the Sabbath, holidays, and the days of the New Moon in the “benediction imitating three”?</i>? Rebbi Abba bar Zamina said that Rebbi Zeïra used to mention the occasion in it. Rebbi Jeremiah said: Since Rebbi Zeïra took notice of it, so we have to take notice<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, one has to mention Sabbath and holidays. (This was adopted as formal practice by Maimonides from the Yerushalmi, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 39a" href="/Berakhot.39a">Babli 39a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Berakhot 44a:13:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Berakhot.44a.13.1">Tosaphot s. v. על העץ</a>).</i>.
It has been stated<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:15" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.15">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:15</a>; a small part of it is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 39b" href="/Berakhot.39b">Babli 39b</a> as statement of Amoraïm. The problem is that only the first bread of a meal needs a benediction; all other foods of that meal can then be eaten without additional benedictions. The food that is chosen for benediction should be distinguished.</i>: “One recites the benediction on the better kind of flour. Rolls<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Greek, singular κόλλιξ, “roll”.</i> and a full home baked loaf, one recites over a roll. A broken roll and a full home baked loaf, one recites on the full home baked loaf. Wheat bread and barley bread, one recites on wheat bread. A broken loaf of wheat bread and a full loaf of barley bread, one recites on the broken wheat bread. Barley bread and spelt bread, one recites on barley bread. But is not spelt bread better?
