But this is from one of the Seven Kinds, that one is not of the Seven Kinds.” Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Zeïra: This is from Rebbi Yehudah, since Rebbi Yehudah said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 6:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.6.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>), “if there is<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">On a fruit plate; one has to choose one fruit to eat first for a benediction, on the strength of which one may then eat all other fruits without additional benediction. The sages opposing Rebbi Yehudah assert that one makes the benediction over the fruit (or here, bread) one prefers, to let God’s praise come from a full heart. The Babli in practice follows the Sages but the Yerushalmi follows Rebbi Yehudah.</i> among them a fruit of the Seven Kinds, on it he recites the benediction.” Impure bread and pure bread, Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said, he recites on the pure one<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">In the time of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, this was a theoretical question only, since at that time nobody was free from the impurity associated with the dead. It must be assumed that the food in question is secular and impure by transfer from something that is the source of impurity; in that case, it cannot pollute the person who touches and eats it with due care.</i>. Impure white bread and pure coarse<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Levy declares it to be from Greek κυρηβία, τά (plur.) “bran, shells of grain kernels,” Krauss and Löw from <i>cibarius</i>(<i>panis</i>) “coarse bread.”</i> bread, Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ada in the name of Rebbi Aḥa: He may recite on the one that he prefers<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Since each one has good and bad qualities.</i>.
Young palm shoots. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Samuel: He recites on it “Creator of the fruit of the tree<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 36a" href="/Berakhot.36a">Babli (36a</a>), the opinion of Rav Yehudah, accepted by his teacher Samuel, is to say “Creator of the fruit of the earth” since it is a vegetable growth but cannot qualify as “fruit” of the tree, since it will turn into inedible wood.</i>.” Rebbi Ḥalaphta ben Saul stated, “By Whose word everything was created<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">This is the original opinion of Samuel in the Babli, since nobody grows date palms for the few shoots one can eat each spring. Hence, it does not qualify as “fruit” of anything.</i>.” Rebbi Joshua stated: “Creator of kinds of grasses.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">This is the only genuinly old tradition quoted, but it is rejected even by the Yerushalmi which admits a variety of formulas of benedictions, since young palm shoots cannot qualify as grasses. As the following list shows, thistles and thorny plants may qualify as grasses.<br>While it is clear that in the Babli קורא means “heart of the palm”, in the statement of R. Joshua the word might refer to Arabic קֻרַּה “cardamine, meadow cress”</i>” The <i>baraita</i> of Rebbi Oshaiah disagrees: “The following are the kinds of grasses: artichoke<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κυνάρα, κινάρα.</i>, <i>ḥalimah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">This plant is defined by <i>Arukh</i>, the talmudic dictionary of 11th cent. R. Nathan of Rome, as mallow or okra. However, the Syriac dictionaries define the word as equivalent of Latin <i>anchusa</i>, “ox tongue”.</i>, <i>demua</i><sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">An otherwise unknown grassy plant; the corresponding Arabic word دماع is explained in classical Arabic dictionaries as “seemingly the name of a plant.”</i>, and lycium<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">A spiny plant frequent in the Jordan valley.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he pronounced the benediction “Creator of the fruit of the soil” on fruits of the tree, he has fulfilled his obligation, on fruits of the soil “Creator of the fruit of the tree”, he has not fulfilled his obligation. On all of them if he pronounced “everything was created<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">“By Whose word everything was created.” While this is not the preferred benediction, the statement is true and therefore admissible.</i>”, he has fulfilled his obligation.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa: This is Rebbi Yehuda’s since Rebbi Yehudah makes trees like straws<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 40a" href="/Berakhot.40a">Babli (40a</a>) this is the accepted opinion, in the name of Rav Naḥman. The proof is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 1:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.1.7.1">Mishnah <i>Bikkurim</i> 1:8</a> which states that if a tree was felled, its owner may not bring the first fruits of that tree to the Temple, but Rebbi Yehudah insists that he may. Since everybody agrees that grain may be offered as first-fruits, and grain can be brought only after it was cut and separated from the straw, it follows that Rebbi Yehudah treats trees simply as stalks for their fruits.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, it is everybody’s opinion since fruits of a tree are also fruits of the soil but fruits of the soil are not fruits of the tree<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">In contrast to the opinion of the Tanna R. Yose quoted in the next paragraph, every true statement about food is acceptable.</i>. Rav Huna said<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 40b" href="/Berakhot.40b">Babli 40b</a>. His opinion is rejected in the Babli in favor of a dissenting one of Rebbi Yoḥanan not mentioned in the Yerushalmi. The next paragraph, which relativizes the statement of Rav Huna, requires a separate benediction for bread even if it is not the one formulated by the Men of the Great Assembly.</i>, except for bread and wine. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 6:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.6.1.1">Mishnah (6:1</a>) says so: Except for wine because on wine one says “Creator of the fruit of the vine;” except for bread because on bread one says “He Who produces bread from the earth.”
It has been stated<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:5" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.5">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:5</a>.</i>: Rebbi Yose says, anyone who changes the formula established by the Sages did not fulfill his duty. Rebbi Yehudah says, everything that has been changed from the way it was created but one did not change its benediction, he did not fulfill his duty<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yose accepts only the formulas established by the Men of the Great Assembly. Rebbi Yehudah accepts these formulas as guidelines which have to be adapted to varying circumstances and this adaptation is more important than using the approved formulas. The great number of different formulas of benediction in the Yerushalmi and fragments of Yerushalmi rite prayer books show that the opinion of Rebbi Yehudah was the dominant one in the Land of Israel. In staying with this attitude, it was even discussed at the start of this <i>halakhah</i> that the anonymous Mishnah should present the opinion of Rebbi Yehudah. In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 40b" href="/Berakhot.40b">Babli (40b</a>), Rebbi Yehudah’s opinion is not even quoted; in Babylonia only the opinions of Rebbi Yose (for those who know Hebrew) and of Rebbi Meïr (for the illiterate) are accepted.</i>. Rebbi Meïr says, even if he says: “Praised be He Who created this property, how beautiful it is,” he has fulfilled his duty. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Samuel: practice follows Rebbi Meïr. The words of Rav also say so. A Persian<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">A Persian Jew. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 40b" href="/Berakhot.40b">Babli (40b</a>), he is called Benjamin the shepherd.</i> came before Rav: “Since I am eating my piece of bread, but I do not know how to recite the benediction over it, I use to say: ‘Praise to Him Who created this piece of bread,’ did I fulfill my duty?” He said to him: yes.
Rav Yehudah in the name of Abba bar bar Ḥana<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rabba bar bar Ḥana. A slightly different version is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 39a" href="/Berakhot.39a">Babli 39a</a> as a tannaïtic statement.</i>: Bar Qappara and two of his students were with the innkeeper at the “inn of blessings”. He brought before them partridge, orach<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">A salty plant, <i>Atriplex rosea</i>, growing mainly in salt marshes, that was used as (relatively cheap) vegetable. [The identification of the plant (and of the bird species) is Rashi’s in the Babli, reported in the name of R. Isaac ben R. Yehudah of Worms.] The vegetable cannot be eaten raw, but must be cooked and, therefore, must have a changed benediction according to Rebbi Yehudah.</i>, and leeks<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κεφαλωτός, “having a head”. The identification as leeks is from Rashi in Babli <i>Yom Ṭov</i> and the use of the word in Syriac.</i>. They said, if we recite the benediction on leeks<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that these leeks were raw; hence, their benediction is “Creator of the fruit of the soil” and that will serve also for the cooked vegetable by the reasoning given in the Mishnah; however, a benediction over the cooked vegetable, which is a changed one following Rebbi Yehudah, cannot serve for raw leeks.</i>, it will serve also for orach but not for the partridge<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">The benediction for patridge is “everything.” The story makes two points. First, that in benedictions one did follow Rebbi Yehudah in frequently changing the wording of benedictions. [This principle, absent in the Babli, is the cause that the reports about and conclusions from this story in the two Talmudim are not comparable.] The second, more important one, is that the language of the Mishnah, “On all of them if he pronounced ‘everything’, he has fulfilled his obligation” does <i>not</i> mean that one may recite that benediction on anything that specifically needs it and then extend it to fruits and vegetables, only that if one recited the benediction on agricultural produce it also is valid, but not preferred.</i>. If we recite on orach, it will not serve for anything else. One of them jumped the gun and recited “by Whose word everything was created” on the partridge. His colleague<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The Aramaic text seems to have a scribal error for חַבְרֵיהּ.</i> laughed at him. Bar Qappara said to that one, not about that glutton but about you scoffer<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">I am angry.</i>. This one acted in his gluttony, why did you laugh? And to the other one he said, is there no rabbi here, is there no old man here? They said, within a year they both died. Rebbi Yose said, there two are gone and we did not learn anything from the incident. What is it? It is reasonable that one recites the benediction on leeks because “By Whose word everything was created” is secondary for vegetables<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of the statement is that one should not start with the benediction over the quail because that benediction is also applicable to vegetables and, hence, cannot be recited a second time for the same meal without taking God’s name in vain. But, as explained earlier, the benediction “everything” is not valid for vegetables if recited on meat and, in any case, is undesirable for plants that have their own more specific benediction. Hence, the person reciting the benediction first on partridge cannot eat of the vegetables. On the other hand, if he makes the first benediction “Creator of the fruit of the soil” for the vegetables, then he can make a second benediction “that all was by His word” for the bird and all is fine.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> On food that is not grown on the soil one recites “that all was by His word.” On vinegar<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Vinegar which came from wine turned sour, not vinegar that was produced as such from the start.</i>, on locusts, and on wind-fall fruit one recites “that all was by His word.” Rebbi Yehudah says, one does not recite a benediction on a kind that comes from a curse.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> If his wine turned sour, he recites “praise to the True Judge”<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">The standard benediction on bad news, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.5.1">Mishnah 9:6</a>.</i>. When he consumes it, he recites “that all was by His word.” If he sees a locust<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">The edible locusts come in swarms which destroy crops. Hence seeing one presages disaster.</i>, he recites “praise to the True Judge”. When he consumes it, he recites “that all was by His word.” If he sees fallen fruit, he recites “praise to the True Judge”. When he consumes it, he recites “that all was by His word.”

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If there were many kinds before him<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">He wants to eat of all of them, they all require the same benediction, and he may recite one benediction only.</i>, Rebbi Yehudah said, if among them is one of the Seven Kinds<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The Seven Kinds are “the fruits for which the Land of Israel is praised”, enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:8" href="/Deuteronomy.8.8"><i>Deut.</i> 8:8</a>: “A land of wheat and barley, vine and fig, and pomegranate; a land of oil olive and (date) honey.” Since in v. 10 it is stated “when you will eat and be satiated, you must praise the Eternal, your God, for the good land that He gave you,” it follows that these kinds need a benediction afterwards that contains praise for food, land, (and Jerusalem.) This is called “one benediction in the kind of three”; the three benedictions are reserved for grain eaten in the form of bread. The benediction before is the applicable one of those mentioned in the Mishnah.</i> that is the one over which he recites the benediction. But the Sages say, on any one that he wishes<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 41a" href="/Berakhot.41a">Babli (41a</a>) interprets the Sages to mean that the fruit to be chosen for benediction should be the one that he likes best personally. It seems that the Yerushalmi means quite literally “any one that he wants”.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, Rebbi Yehudah and the rabbis disagree only when he intended afterwards to eat bread<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">If the fruits are eaten as appetizers to be followed by a meal, then the benediction over bread for the main meal is a benediction over one of the Seven Kinds, even over the most important of the Seven Kinds. Hence, a benediction on some other fruit is no slight for the Land of Israel. But if the snack of fruits is not followed by bread and Grace after the meal then the fruits of the Land of Israel take precedence since they require at the end a “benediction imitating three benedictions” whereas other fruits only require the short benediction “Creator of living things” that earlier was considered to be “nothing”.</i>, but if he did not intend to eat bread afterwards, everybody agrees that if among them one is of the Seven Kinds, that is the one over which he recites the benediction. Rebbi Abba said, he has to recite a benediction at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Even if Grace is recited afterwards.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, the statement of Rebbi Abba disagrees with Rebbi Joshua ben Levi since Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, Rebbi Yehudah and the rabbis disagree only when he intended afterwards to eat bread, but if he did not intend to eat bread afterwards everybody agrees that if among them is one of the Seven Kinds, that is the one over which he recites the benediction; but Rebbi Abba said, he has to recite a benediction at the end. If he did not recite a benediction at the end it<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">The fruit eaten as appetizer.</i> became an accessory and we have stated there (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 7:1:1-4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.7.1.1-4.1">Mishna 7</a>): “In every situation where there is a main course and side dishes, one recites the benediction for the main course and thereby frees the side dishes.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, bread being the most important food and requiring recitation of full Grace, any fruit eaten beforehand becomes a side dish for the bread and should be covered by Grace. The Yerushalmi takes <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 6:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.6.7.1">Mishnah 7</a> to apply also to benedictions after the meal, not only before the meal.</i>”
<i>Garizmata</i><sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">The exact meaning of the word, its vocalization and etymology are unknown. It is clear from Midrashim (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 9" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.9"><i>Lev. rabba</i> 9, <i>Thr. rabba</i> introduction</a>) that it refers to a dessert. The <i>Arukh</i> translates the word by Italian קוציאי which Perles misread as <i>guscio</i> “trestle; shell, hull”. Even <i>coccio</i> “potsherd” does not make much sense. The older commentaries to the Yerushalmi were misled by a scribal “correction” in the <i>Arukh</i> that identified <i>gryzmth</i> with lupines, which refers to the next word in the text. Levy’s dictionary, following Perles, derives the word from a non-existing Greek word γαρίσμη [but compare γαρισκός, ὁ, “an unknown fish”, γάρος, ὁ “paste of brine and small fish”, γάρον, τὸ “fish sauce”.] Jastrow considers the word as Par‘el from (Hebrew and Arabic) גזם “to cut in pieces”. From the usage in the next Halakhah it seems that one speaks of baked, in contrast to cooked, goods. It is possible to connect the word with Arabic جردو, גרדם “to devour voraciously” (said of worms and other pests.)<br>The background of the remark is that this kind of dessert at a formal dinner, being extraordinary and not part of a regular meal, is not covered by the benediction over the bread at the start of the meal and, hence, needs its own benediction.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Ammi, he recites the benediction over the lupine<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">He may make the benediction even on lupines even though they probably are the cheapest dish on the plate.</i>. Rebbi Levi said, because of (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 22:22" href="/Proverbs.22.22"><i>Prov.</i> 22:22</a>) “do not rob a poor one<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Of its benediction.</i> because he is poor.”
That is if it is his intention to eat bread<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">One returns to the opinion of the Sages in the Mishnah and the interpretation given by R. Joshua ben Levi.</i>. But if it is not his intention to eat bread, that does not apply. (Rabban) Gamliel the twin<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">The name of his twin brother was Hillel. He was an Amora of the third generation who usually appears asking questions from his contemporaries, not formulating his own rules. The title “Rabban” was given to him here by a thoughtless scribe; everywhere else his name appears without title.</i> went to those of the house of Rebbi Yannai. He saw them eat an olive<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">As an appetizer before a meal with bread.</i> and recite the benediction before and afterwards. He said to them: Does one do that? Rebbi Zeïra sent and asked Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman. Rebbi Cahana<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Cohen at other places in the Talmud.</i> in the name of Rebbi Avina<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Ganiva, also of Rav Huna and Rav Yehudah, who immigrated into Israel and was ordained in the Yeshivah of Rebbi Ammi.</i>: Everybody agrees that if among them was one of the Seven Kinds, that is the one over which he recites the benediction. Rebbi Zeïra said, that must be correct, since we see the rabbis assembling for the proclamation of the New Moon and eat grapes but they do not recite a benediction afterwards. That is because it is his<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">It is their intention to have a full meal after the formal proclamation of the New Moon.</i> intention to eat bread.
If there were before him of the Seven Kinds, on which one does he recite the benediction? There<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 41a" href="/Berakhot.41a">Babli 41a</a>.</i> they say: Everything that has precedence in the verse has precedence for benediction and everything that is close to “the Land” has precedence over everything else<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, the orders of preference are (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:6" href="/Deuteronomy.8.6"><i>Deut.</i> 8:6</a>): “A land of (1) wheat and (2) barley, (3) grapes, and (4) figs, and (5) pomegranates; a land of (1) oil olives and (2) date honey.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If one recited the benediction on wine before the meal<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Given as an appetizer. They drank wine after the main meal but before Grace was recited. Since Grace covers all food, it is obvious that anything consumed after Grace needs a new benediction. Both wine and cookies were served before and after the meal only on festive dinners as explained in Chapter 8; they do not belong to everyday meals. Their rules need to be spelled out.</i>, he also covers wine after the meal. If one recited the benediction on little pieces<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">The verb פרר means “to break into little pieces, crumble”. It is possible that פרפר is a <i>pilpel</i> form of פרר. This is the opinion of the dictionaries. It is more likely that פרפרת is derived from παραφέρω “to serve, bring to one’s side” (food), or the passive “set on table, served” (definitions of Liddell &amp; Scott). The correct translation then is “side dish before or after meal; appetizer or dessert, snacks.” The vocalization should be פָּרָפֶרֶת (E. G.).</i> before the meal, he also covers little pieces after the meal. If one recited the benediction on bread, he also covers little pieces; if one recited the benediction on little pieces, he did not cover bread; the House of Shammai say, neither did he cover cooked food.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rav Ḥisda said, we stated only “if one recited the benediction on wine before the meal, he also covers wine after the meal”, but if one recited the benediction for wine during the meal<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">When wine serves only to wash down the food. But wine after the meal is consumed for its own sake.</i>, he did not cover the wine after the meal. There<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia, where wine was a rarity and only used on Sabbath and holidays. Their usual drink was beer made from date syrup. The entire discussion is Babylonian, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 42b" href="/Berakhot.42b">Babli 42b</a>.</i> they say, even if one recited the benediction on wine before the meal, he did not cover wine after the meal. But did we not state “if one recited the benediction on wine before the meal, he also covers wine after the meal”? Rav Huna and Rebbi Joshua ben Levi, one of them said, if he drank spiced wine<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>conditum</i> (scil., <i>vinum</i>); this wine cannot be compared to regular wine and therefore needs an extra benediction.</i>, the other one said, if he drank wine after the bath<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>balnea, -orum</i> (plur.), a sauna. Since the first wine after return from the sauna is taken for medical reasons, its benediction does not cover wine consumed as food.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥelbo, Rav Huna, Rav, in the name of the great Rebbi Ḥiyya: Bread that comes <i>kisnīn</i><sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Rav Hai Gaon explains that <i>kisnīn</i>-bread is called כעכ in Arabic. This is “pastry, small baked goods” in common Arabic, “donuts” in Syrian dialect. Rabbenu Ḥananel and Rashi explain that it is a baked shell filled with candied almonds and other nuts. Since it is baked it needs a benediction, but since it is not baked as bread it is not covered by the benediction over bread. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 42a" href="/Berakhot.42a">Babli (42a</a>) quotes only the opinion of Samuel who seems to agree with Rebbi Yoḥanan here.</i> needs a benediction before and after. Rebbi Ammi said that Rebbi Yoḥanan disagrees. Rebbi Mana asked Rebbi Ḥizqiah, in what does he disagree? When one ate from the same food<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">The Rome ms. has here המין, conforming to the next two sentences.</i> during the meal? He said to him, even if one did not eat from the same kind during the meal. Rav Ḥaggai came in the name of Rebbi Zeïra: Even if one did not eat from the same kind during the meal<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Any baked goods eaten after the benediction over bread and before Grace are covered by these two benedictions.</i>.
From the Patriarch they sent Nicolaus dates<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">A kind of large Syrian dates, in Arabic אַנקִילַא.</i> to Rebbi Ḥanina bar Sisai<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">He is also called Ininai bar Sisai (in the Yerushalmi) and Anani bar Sason (in the Babli); Amora of the second generation and student of Rebbi Ḥanina.</i>. He left them for dessert after his meal and recited a benediction over them before and after. Rav Ḥuna ate dates with his bread. Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said to him, are you disagreeing with your teacher<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Rav, who said that food eaten after the main meal, without bread, needs separate benedictions.</i>? Leave them for dessert after your meal and you may recite a benediction over them before and after. He said to him, they are the main thing my teeth get to bite. Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Yose went to the marriage feast of Rebbi Ḥanina Eyntanaya. They brought before them <i>kisnīn</i> bread after the meal. They said, let us leave our learning and let us bring a <i>baraita</i>: Rebbi Mana stated in the name of Rebbi Yehudah, who said in the name of Rebbi Yose the Galilean: Bread that comes <i>kisnīn</i> after the meal needs a benediction before and after. They said, since they are the minority and the rabbis disagree with them, let us act following the rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">That bread covers all food which comes regularly with a meal, whether during the main course or as a dessert. This, as report of an action, is the final decision in the matter.</i>.
Marinos, the son of Rebbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">At other places in the Yerushalmi, he is called Marinos, the son of the great Rebbi Oshayah; an Israeli Amora between the first and second generations.</i> said: He who ate dessert<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">The exact meaning of the word, its vocalization and etymology are unknown. It is clear from Midrashim (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 9" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.9"><i>Lev. rabba</i> 9, <i>Thr. rabba</i> introduction</a>) that it refers to a dessert. The <i>Arukh</i> translates the word by Italian קוציאי which Perles misread as <i>guscio</i> “trestle; shell, hull”. Even <i>coccio</i> “potsherd” does not make much sense. The older commentaries to the Yerushalmi were misled by a scribal “correction” in the <i>Arukh</i> that identified <i>gryzmth</i> with lupines, which refers to the next word in the text. Levy’s dictionary, following Perles, derives the word from a non-existing Greek word γαρίσμη [but compare γαρισκός, ὁ, “an unknown fish”, γάρος, ὁ “paste of brine and small fish”, γάρον, τὸ “fish sauce”.] Jastrow considers the word as Par‘el from (Hebrew and Arabic) גזם “to cut in pieces”. From the usage in the next Halakhah it seems that one speaks of baked, in contrast to cooked, goods. It is possible to connect the word with Arabic جردو, גרדם “to devour voraciously” (said of worms and other pests.)<br>The background of the remark is that this kind of dessert at a formal dinner, being extraordinary and not part of a regular meal, is not covered by the benediction over the bread at the start of the meal and, hence, needs its own benediction.</i> and cereal<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Cereal made from flour or flakes of grain that can be used to make bread.</i>, even though he recites a benediction on the dessert at the end, he did not cover cereal<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Since vegetable dessert needs only a short benediction afterwards but cereal needs a “benediction imitating three.”</i>. Is he like the House of Shammai, since the House of Shammai say<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mishnah. Except if it is explicitly stated, practice never follows the House of Shammai; Marinos should not follow it.</i>, “neither cooked food?” Rebbi Yose said, this is everybody’s opinion. If one recited the benediction on bread, he also covers little pieces and cooked food; the House of Shammai say, neither did he cover cooked food. But if one first recited the benediction over little pieces, everybody agrees that he covered neither bread nor cooked food<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">They need the “benediction imitating three.” The Yerushalmi takes it as obvious that the remark on the House of Shammai refers to the sentence just preceding their remark. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 42b" href="/Berakhot.42b">Babli (42b</a>) it remains undecided whether the House of Shammai refer to the first or the second clause in the Mishnah.</i>. Rebbi Abba, the son of Rebbi Ḥaggai asked: He who ate cereal and he has the intention of later eating bread, does he have to recite a separate benediction for cereal at the end? The rabbis of Caesarea find it obvious that he has to recite a separate benediction at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">In Israel, one never ate cereal with bread. R. Zeïra (himself a native Babylonian) is quoted in the Babli (<i>Beẓa</i> 16a) as making fun of “those stupid Babylonians who eat bread with bread” because they eat bread with cereal. Hence, in Caesarea, someone eating cereal is not presumed to have the intention to eat bread.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If they were sitting<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">In a sitting room, not in a dining room, either for talk or before a meal. (Some Mishnah manuscripts have “sitting before a meal” but the addition seems irrelevant.) In Mishnaic times, a formal meal was always taken lying down on couches, supporting oneself with one’s left arm and eating with the right hand.</i>, every one makes the benediction for himself<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">For wine, pastries, or fruit.</i>. If they were lying on couches<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Assembled to eat a meal as a company.</i>, one would make the benediction for everybody<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">On bread and/or wine. The other participants must answer “Amen” so that the benediction is counted also for them.</i>. If wine were served to them in the middle of the meal, everyone would make the benediction for himself<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Since people may be eating, their mouth is not free to answer “Amen”.</i>; after the meal one person makes the benediction for everybody, and he makes the benediction on <i>mugmar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew verb גּמּר, Arabic גַמַּרַ, means “to roast on burning coals”. <i>Mugmar</i> are spices or incense roasted on burning coals, used as air-freshener after a meal and also to perfume garments.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, the Mishnah deals with a party for circumcision<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">And similar festive occasions when a formal dinner takes place.</i>. Hence, it does not apply to a man in his own house<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Since all members of the household look to the head of the house to start the meal, he should make the benediction for all of them even if they are sitting and not reclining, since not every apartment has a formal dining room.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">In one of his <i>baraitot.</i> He allows a common benediction only in a formal dining room. The disagreement between him and R. Joshua ben Levi is not resolved; both are authorities of equal standing.</i>, even a man in his own house.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:8" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.8">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:8</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 43a" href="/Berakhot.43a">Babli 43a</a>. This Tosephta explains the background of the Mishnah.</i>: The order of a formal meal: Guests enter and sit on low benches<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>subsellium</i>.</i> or on chairs<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Greek καθέδρα.</i> until all of them are assembled. They are served wine; everyone makes the benediction for himself. They bringthem water, everyone washes one hand. They bring them snacks, everyone makes the benediction for himself. When they entered<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">The dining room. הסב means “to lie on couches” in Mishnaic Hebrew.</i> and lie down on couches they are served wine; even though one made the benediction on the first one, he must now make the benediction on the second one; one of them makes the benediction for all of them. They bring them water; even though one had washed one hand, he now has to wash both hands. When they are served snacks, one makes the benediction for all of them. No guest may enter after three servings of snacks.
There (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.4.4.1">Mishnah <i>Sukkah</i> 4:5</a>) we have stated: “Sukkah seven days, how is this<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">The holiday of Sukkot is seven days; the eighth day, <i>Shemini Aẓeret</i>, is an additional festive day, where the obligation to live in a <i>sukkah</i> does not apply. Since one may not add to the commandments of the Torah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:1" href="/Deuteronomy.13.1"><i>Deut.</i> 13:1</a>), in Israel, where holidays are only one day, one may not live in the <i>sukkah</i> on the eighth day.</i>? If he finished to eat he should not take down his <i>sukkah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to live in the <i>sukkah</i> extends until nightfall of the eighth day.</i>, but he takes out the vessels starting from the time of afternoon prayers because of the honor due to the last holiday.” Rebbi Abba bar Cahana, Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi in the name of Rav: A person must make his <i>sukkah</i> invalid<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">That it would no longer qualify as <i>sukkah</i>. At the end of the discussion, the interpretation is that one must make the <i>sukkah</i> invalid as <i>sukkah</i> only if one intends to eat in the <i>sukkah</i> during the holiday of <i>Shemini Aẓeret</i>. One makes the <i>sukkah</i> invalid either by removing some of the roofing, or by putting up a sheet of cloth under the roofing, or in a similar way.</i> as long as it is still day. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, a person must make <i>Qiddush</i><sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">The sanctification of (Sabbath and) holidays, pronounced over a cup of wine.</i> inside his house<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">On <i>Shemini Aẓeret</i>, irrespective of the place of the meal.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Samuel: If one made <i>Qiddush</i> in one house and changed his mind to eat in another house he must make <i>Qiddush</i><sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">This parallels the statement of Samuel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 101a" href="/Pesachim.101a">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 101a</a> that “there cannot be <i>Qiddush</i> except at the place of the holiday meal.”</i>. Rebbi Aḥa, Rebbi Ḥinena in the name of Rebbi Hoshaiah<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">The Venice text reads: Rebbi Joshua; the text here is from the Rome manuscript. The correct text is in the parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 4:5:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.4.5.2-4"><i>Sukkah</i> 4:5</a>: Rebbi Hoshaiah in the name of Rav. In the sequel, this statement will be referred to either as Rebbi Hoshaiah’s or Rav’s.</i>: He who loves his <i>sukkah</i> makes <i>Qiddush</i> of the last holiday in his house and goes to eat in his <i>sukkah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Contradicting the statement of Samuel, that <i>Qiddush</i> must be said at the place of the meal.</i>. Rebbi Abun said, they do not disagree. What Rav said was, if he did not have the intention to eat in another house<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">So that at the moment of recitation of <i>Qiddush</i>, his intention was valid; a valid benediction cannot be voided retroactively.</i>. But what Samuel said was if he had the intention to eat in another house. Rebbi Mana said<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">The explanation of R. Abun is impossible since then we would have two contradictory statements in the name of Rav. Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said in his name that one must make the <i>sukkah</i> invalid before the start of the eighth day if one wants to use it during that day; hence, if Rebbi Hoshaiah requires in Rav’s name that one make <i>Qiddush</i> in the house it is obvious that he had the prior intention to eat in the <i>sukkah</i>. Hence, Rav must disagree with Samuel. If Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi made his statement without reference to Rav we may refer to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 100b" href="/Pesachim.100b">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 100b</a>) that Rav disagrees explicitly with Samuel but that Rav Huna, Rav’s foremost student, agrees with Samuel. Rav Huna would not have gone against Rav if not at least one of the latter’s colleagues in his Yeshivah, e. g., Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi, had supported Samuel. Hence, the attribution of the statement of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi to Rav seems to be in error, even though it is supported by both manuscripts of the Yerushalmi.</i>, Samuel comes like Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Scribal error for “Rav”. Since Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi requires that one eat in an invalid <i>sukkah</i> he must require that <i>Qiddush</i> be in that invalid <i>sukkah</i>.</i> Ḥiyya and Rebbi Hoshaiah like Rebbi Joshua ben Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">This seemingly unrelated topic is discussed here because it has an implicit relationship with the foregoing Tosephta and the Mishnah. According to R. Joshua ben Levi, one may make <i>Qiddush</i> in the house and then continue eating and drinking wine in the <i>sukkah</i>. This means that one may start drinking wine at one place and then continue drinking at another place without reciting a new benediction. This contradicts the previous Tosephta that the benediction over wine in the sitting room does not free one from reciting a new benediction in the dining room. Samuel (seconded by Rebbi Yoḥanan in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 101" href="/Pesachim.101">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 101a/b</a>) will agree to the conclusion from the Tosephta.</i>.
They asked Ben Zoma<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:12" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.12">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:12</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 43a" href="/Berakhot.43a">Babli 43a</a>.</i>: Why, if wine was served to them in the middle of the meal, everyone makes the benediction for himself? He said to them, because the place of swallowing is not empty<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Talking during swallowing may bring food into one’s windpipe and cause one’s death by asphyxiation.</i>. Rebbi Mana said, this means that if someone sneezes during the meal one may not say to him “for health<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἴασις. The <i>Arukh</i> reads here זפ, Greek ζήτω “for life!” The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Shabbat (Lieberman) 7:5" href="/Tosefta_Shabbat_(Lieberman).7.5">Tosephta (<i>Šabbat</i> 7:5</a>) declares this to be a non-Jewish custom.</i>” because of danger to one’s life.
What is the difference between <i>mugmar</i> and wine? Everybody smells <i>mugmar</i>, each person tastes wine. Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">The entire discussion is paralleled in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 43" href="/Berakhot.43">Babli 43a/b</a>.</i>: One has to recite the benediction for <i>mugmar</i> as soon as the smoke rises. Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">The text, “Rebbi”, is in error since Rebbi Zeïra was the student of Rav Jeremiah in Babylonia and the teacher of Rebbi Jeremiah in Galilee.</i> Jeremiah wanted to examine Rebbi Zeïra. He said to him, which benediction does one recite on perfumed oil? He said, “He Who gave pleasant fragrance in perfumed oil.” He said to him, “He Who gave pleasant fragrance in spice wood.” Isaac bar Abba from Meḥasiah<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">A Babylonian; twice mentioned as associate of Rav Ḥananel. Mata (“City of”) Meḥasia was the place of Rav’s Yeshivah.</i> and Rav Ḥananel were sitting. One said, “Praise to Him Who gave pleasant fragrance in spice wood.” The other one said, “Praise to Him Who gave pleasant fragrance in the plants of the earth.” He who said “in the plants of the earth” objected to him who said “in spice wood”: are they wood? He answered him, is it not written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 2:6" href="/Joshua.2.6"><i>Jos.</i> 2:6</a>) “She hid them in the hemp of wood”, are these wood? They went to the Yeshivah of Rav and heard Rav Huna<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Head of the Yeshivah of Rav after Rav’s death.</i> in the name of Rav: “He Who gave pleasant fragrance in spice wood.” Ganiva said, he who uses oil for dirt<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">If the oil is used primarily for cleaning and it does not matter that it is perfumed This applies to all other cleaning fluids also.</i> does not have to recite a benediction. Rebbi Yudan said, even if he collects it into his hand. Rebbi Ḥelbo, Rav Huna in the name of Rav: He who sprinkles <i>olentia</i><sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>olens, olentis</i> “sweet smelling” (E. G.). Most authors equate the word with <i>oleamentum</i>, “ointment made from olive oil”; this fits neither the spelling of the word nor the context.</i> in his house<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">If the main intent is to either bind the dirt or to get rid of bad odors, not to produce the pleasant fragrance.</i> does not have to recite a benediction. Rav Ḥisda said, on everything he recites “He Who gave pleasant fragrance in spice wood” except for musk on which he recites “He who gave pleasant fragrance in all kinds of spices.<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Musk is of animal, not vegetable, origin. The statement of Rav Ḥisda in the Babli is quoted in the name of Rav; but there the benediction for musk is accepted for everything except for balsamum.</i>”

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If salted fish<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">This is the usual interpretation of “salted” and is the correct interpretation of Mishnah and Yerushalmi by the testimony of the <i>Arukh</i> who quotes the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 6:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.6.2.1">Mishnah <i>Nedarim</i> 6:3</a>: “He who makes a vow not to eat any salted foods, is forbidden only salted fish.”</i> was brought before him with bread, one recites the benediction over the salted fish and frees the bread<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">From having to recite the benediction because salted fish cannot be eaten without bread; hence, the bread would not have been eaten were it not for the salted fish.</i> because the bread is accessory. The following is the principle: Anything that is the main dish and comes with a side dish, one recites the benediction on the main dish and this frees the side dish.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Jonathan<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Israeli Amora of the first generation, close to R. Joshua ben Levi, Rebbi Ḥiyya the Great and R. Ḥanina.</i>: The Mishnah was from before they learned royal meals and at a place where the salted fish is the main food, but at a place where salted fish is not the main food that does not apply<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, for the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 44a" href="/Berakhot.44a">Babli (44a</a>) it no longer applies.</i>. Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Again, “Rebbi” is scribal error.</i> Jeremiah in the name of Rav, <i>pitta</i> bread and morsels, one recites on the morsels at a place where the morsels are the main food<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">This does not contradict the stament in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 6:1:2-26" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.6.1.2-26">Halakhah 1</a> that one makes the benediction on a complete loaf of bread if at all possible since the morsels here are not eaten as morsels, but are collected and milk is poured over them; the whole is left standing until it gets moldy. The result was considered in Babylonia to be an exquisite delicacy called “Babylonian <i>kutaḥ</i>”. The authorities involved here are all Babylonian.</i>. But at a place where morsels are not the main food that does not apply. Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish, <i>šeqizmi</i><sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">An unidentified word. [<i>Pne Mosheh</i> (Margalit), followed by Levy in his dictionary, takes the word to mean a delicacy made from almonds (שקד) with ז replacing soft ד. <i>Pne Mosheh</i> (Ben Ḥabib) identifies <i>šeqizmi</i> as kinds of fruit.]</i> and bread, one recites on the <i>šeqizmi</i> at a place where the <i>šeqizmi</i> are the main food. But at a place where <i>šeqizmi</i> are not the main food that does not apply.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One who ate figs, grapes, or pomegranates<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Or any other of the “Seven Fruits” that has not been made into bread; see note 15.</i> recites for them three benedictions<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Full grace; this Mishnah is the introduction to the subject of Grace which will occupy the next two chapters.</i>, the words of Rabban Gamliel; but the Sagessay, one benediction imitating three. Rebbi Aqiba says, even if one ate cooked food and that is his meal he recites for it three benedictions<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Since the verse says: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:10" href="/Deuteronomy.8.10"><i>Deut.</i> 8:10</a>) “When you will eat and will have been satiated then you must praise the Eternal, your God, for the good land that He has given you.” There is no mention of bread. The three benedictions are (1) for the food, (2) for the Land, (3) for Jerusalem.</i>. He who drinks water for his thirst<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">He drinks water for itself and not to accompany or wash down food.</i> says “By Whose word everything was created.” Rebbi Tarphon<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Probably the Greek name Τρυφῶν. He was old enough to have served as a priest in the Temple before its destruction. The text of the Yerushalmi in the Halakhah, a manuscript of the Babli, and some quotes from Medieval authorities have “R. Yehudah” instead of “R. Tarphon”. Since the main thrust of the Mishnah is about concluding benedictions, it is not clear whether R. Tarphon/Yehudah speaks of a first benediction, contradicting R. Aqiba, or about the concluding benediction for food that needs neither “three benedictions” nor “one benediction imitating three.”</i> said, “Creator of many living things”<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Some Mishnah manuscripts have here the full text of the minor benediction after food.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Simon, Rebbi Thaddeus<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Israeli Amora of the second generation. His sayings are reported either by R. Simon or by R. Abba.</i>, in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: If one ate East of a fig tree and then changed to West of it<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Assuming that the fig tree is very old and large enough so that he cannot see his old place from the new one.</i> to eat, he must make a benediction. Abba bar Rav Huna said: old wine, new wine, he has to recite a benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Since the benediction, as explained later in this Halakhah, is for the quality of the wine, one would expect that the change from new to old wine should require a benediction rather than the other way around. However, one has to assume that one deals with wine stored in cheap pottery amphoras rather than in extremely expensive glass bottles. The amphoras are porous and most of the alcohol will have vanished by the time the amphora is opened and also the flavor will have deteriorated under the influence of the air seeping in from the outside. Hence, the text here is justified.</i>. Change of wine he does not have to make a benediction. Change of place he has to make a benediction. If he took his mind off<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">After some time has passed. If one then returns to drink, it is a new activity.</i> it is equal to change of place. Rebbi was reciting a benediction on any wine amphora that he was opening. What did he say? The old Rebbi Isaac in the name of Rebbi: “He Who is good and does good<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Benediction on getting good news.</i>.” When Rebbi Aqiba was making a marriage feast for his son Simeon, he said a benediction over every wine amphora that he opened and said: “Good wine for the rabbis and their students.”
“<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah.</i> He who drinks water for his thirst says ‘That everything was created by His word.’” Rebbi Jonah said, except pick-axe water<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">As is clear from the text, this is water drunk only for medicinal purposes.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, on any water that he thirsts for<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">If somebody drinks medicinal waters for his thirst, he has to recite the benediction for water, not that for medicinal waters. If he drinks water not for his thirst (in the language of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 44b" href="/Berakhot.44b">Babli, 44b</a>, if a piece of food is stuck in his esophagus,) he does not have to recite any benediction.</i>. Rebbi Abun said, he who drinks pick-axe water, what does he say? “Praise to Him Who created medicinal waters.”<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">The fact that a benediction is due is also noted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 38a" href="/Berakhot.38a">Babli (38a</a>), but the text is given only here.</i> Some Tannaïm state “<i>deqarim</i> water”, other Tannaïm state “<i>deqalim</i> waters”. He who said <i>deqarim</i> (pick-axe) waters, because they pierce the gall bladder. And he who says <i>deqalim</i> (date palm) waters, because they gush forth between two palm trees<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Compare Latin <i>decalicator</i> “hard drinker”, one who is able to empty a <i>calix</i>, a goblet, at one draught (E. G.).</i>.

Chapter 7



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Three persons who ate together are required to “invite”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Three adult males who ate together are obliged to recite Grace as a group and start with a special invitation to all participants to join in the praise of the Lord by Whose kindness we live. The text of the “invitation” is given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 7:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.7.3.1">Mishnah 3</a>.</i>. If one ate <i>demai</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Newly harvested produce is subject to several obligatory gifts and tithes. The first one is the heave, תְּרוּמָה, that can be given to any Cohen. This <i>terumah</i> must be eaten by a Cohen’s family in ritual purity. There is no rate set for <i>terumah</i> in the Torah but in times when ritual purity can be observed, the rabbinically established rate was 2 percent. Next, the tithe of 10% must be given to a Levite. This <i>maäser</i> again is subject to a 10% <i>terumah of the tithe</i> to be given to the Cohen. The remainder of this <i>first tithe</i> is secular private property of the Levite and need not be kept in purity. However, consumption by a non-Cohen of any food containing still <i>terumah</i> (and of impure <i>terumah</i> by a Cohen) is a deadly sin. In Temple times it was established that all Jews, educated and uneducated, observant and nonobservant alike, did separate <i>terumah</i> and give it to a Cohen. However, the first tithe was not given by a substantial minority of uneducated and nonobservant. Since untithed produce still contains the <i>terumah of the tithe</i> and its consumption would be a deadly sin, it was instituted that observant Jews have to separate at least the <i>terumah of the tithe</i> for produce bought from unreliable sources. Since a majority of all agricultural producers did give the tithe, the obligation to tithe is conditional and is waved for the poor. Produce sold by unreliable persons is called <i>demai</i>; the rules under which <i>demai</i> has to be given are spelled out in a separate Tractate. In any case, since any person might give away all his property and then become poor and eat <i>demai</i> without tithing, <i>demai</i> is potentially permitted food for everybody and the person who eats it does not commit blasphemy in reciting Grace.</i>, or first tithe of which the heave was taken<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli explains, even if the heave was taken somewhat irregularly. There is no mention of that in the Yerushalmi.</i>, or second tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The second tithe remains the property of the farmer but either it must be eaten in Jerusalem or it must be redeemed and the proceeds taken to Jerusalem and spent there for food. Second tithe that was redeemed is normal food permitted to everybody.</i> or dedicated foods<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">This is food from an animal not of the kind that may be sacrificed, or vegetables that may not be sacrificed, but were given to support the upkeep of the Temple. These gifts are then sold and the money used for the Temple. After the sale, the food is profane, for everybody to eat. Also, an animal dedicated for the altar that develops a blemish before it is sacrificed, can be redeemed and then becomes secular food which, however, must be consumed in a dignified manner.</i> that were redeemed, or the waiter who ate the volume of an olive<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Nobody may recite Grace who did not eat at least food of the volume of an average olive. The waiter is acceptable even though he did not sit down with the guests he served.</i>, or a Samaritan<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The descendants of the people settled in Samaria by the king of Assyria (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 17" href="/II_Kings.17"><i>2Kings</i> 17</a>) who accepted the written Torah but not the oral law. [Since they did not resist the effort made by Diocletian to unify the Roman Empire in pagan rite, this statement of the Mishnah no longer applies. It does apply, however, to Karaites.]</i>, these can be invited. But if one ate untithed produce, or first tithe of which the heave was not taken, or the second tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Outside of Jerusalem.</i> or dedicated foods that were not redeemed<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Except for the second tithe, the consumption of the foods mentioned here is a deadly sin; hence, pronouncing a benediction over that food would be the additional sin of blasphemy.</i>, or the waiter who ate less than the volume of an olive, or a Gentile<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">He is not obliged to recite Grace and has no part in the Land for which we give praise.</i>, these cannot be invited.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Here<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 7:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.7.4.1">Mishnah 5</a>: Three who ate together are not allowed to split. [There the emphasis is on the fact that six people who ate together may split into two groups of three.] The Yerushalmi is discussed at length by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Berakhot 45a" href="/Tosafot_on_Berakhot.45a"><i>Tosaphot Berakhot</i> 45a</a> and <i>Talmid Rabbenu Jonah</i>,<i>Rosh</i> on Mishnah 5.</i> it has been said “they are not allowed to split” and here it has been said “they are required to ‘invite’ ”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The two Mishnayot seem to say the same thing, so one of them would be superfluous.</i>. Samuel said, one is at the start and one is at the end. What means “beginning” and what means “end”? Two Amoraïm; one said if they decided to eat together that is the start<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">They are no longer allowed to split.</i>, when they ate the volume of an olive that is the end<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">They are required to recite Grace together with the formal “invitation.”</i>. But the other one said, if they ate the volume of an olive that is the start<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">They are no longer allowed to eat each one for himself.</i>, when they finished their meal that is the end<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">They must recite Grace together; if one of them finishes early he is not allowed to recite Grace for himself and then leave.</i>.
Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav Huna, Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Abba bar Jeremiah: Three are required, two have permission. Rebbi Zeïra said this before Rebbi Yasa. He said to him: I have only the Mishnah, three who ate together are required to “invite”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">But two may not recite Grace together with the formula of invitation. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 45" href="/Berakhot.45">Babli (45a/b</a>) comes to the same conclusion that the old tradition of Babylonia was that two may say Grace together but three must do it, but the Israeli tradition was always to exclude two if three are required.</i>. The rabbis of here stick by their opinion, the rabbis of there<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Babylonia. The disagreement between Samuel and R. Yoḥanan / R. Simeon ben Laqish belongs to tractate <i>Sanhedrin</i>; in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 5b-6a" href="/Sanhedrin.5b-6a">Babli <i>Sanhedrin</i> (5b/6a</a>) this is a disagreement between Samuel and Rebbi Abbahu, student of R. Simeon ben Laqish and R. Yoḥanan. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 45b" href="/Berakhot.45b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 45b</a>) only hints that the difference has its roots in different local traditions.</i> stick by their opinion. Samuel said, two who judged, their judgment is valid but they are called an insolent court. Rebbi Yoḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both say, two who judged, their judgment is invalid.
Rav Huna said, three who ate each one by himself<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Different food at different tables, or at one table but they are strangers to one another and each one eats his own food that he brought with him. The disagreement between Rav Huna and Rav Ḥisda is explained differently in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50a" href="/Berakhot.50a">Babli, 50a</a>.</i> and then came together<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">At one table (or on one group of couches) befor they recited Grace.</i> do “invite”. Rav Ḥisda said, only if they came from three groups<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Every one of the three was required to recite Grace with “invitation”; he may fulfill his obligation even in another group. But if three people were not obligated to “invite” during their meal they cannot become subject to “inviting” after they had finished eating.</i>. According to the opinion of Rebbi Zeïra<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Here he is called by his Babylonian name זירא since, under the influence of Accadic, the Jews in Babylonia early on had lost the sound of ע. While his Israeli name appears in the list of R. Jonah, the entire piece seems to have had a Babylonian editor; so it uses the Babylonian Aramaic חזי “to see” instead of the usual Israeli חמי.</i> and his group, only if all three ate together<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">From the start. (In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50a" href="/Berakhot.50a">Babli, 50a</a>, this is the opinion of Samuel, but here it is the opinion only of the rabbis in Israel). Connected with this is the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:23" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.23"><i>Tosephta</i> (<i>Berakhot</i> 5:23</a>, cf. end of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 7:4:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.7.4.2-5">Halakhah 5</a>) that people in a caravan, if they eat while walking, cannot recite Grace together even if they all ate from the same food, but if they sit together at a rest stop, they must recite Grace together even if everyone ate his own provisions. In contrast to the Babli, the Yerushalmi never entertains the thought that for common Grace one would have to lie down on couches.</i>. Rebbi Jonah on that of Rav Huna: If he dipped three stalks of hyssop each one by himself and then took them together, he may sprinkle with it<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Used for cleansing a person or utensils impure by contact with a corpse; cleansing needs sprinkling with a bunch of hyssop that was dipped in water in which some of the ashes of a red heifer were dissolved (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 19" href="/Numbers.19"><i>Num.</i> 19</a>, Mishnah <i>Parah</i>). A “bunch” is a minimum of three stalks. The opinions here are attributed to the older authorities by Rebbi Jonah.</i>. Rav Ḥisda said, only if they came from three bundles. According to the opinion of Rebbi Zeïra and his group, only if all three were dipped together. If you want to say that we do not infer rules of hyssop from rules of benedictions, do we not see the rabbis deal with <i>sukkah</i> and learn from pourable mud?<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">This proof that one requires logical consistency even in fields that are rather remote from each other is also a belated justification of the previous comparison of the rules of Grace with the composition of a court of law.</i>. As we have stated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 1:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.1.10.1">Mishnah <i>Sukkah</i> 1:10</a>): “If the roofing was three hand-breadths away from the walls it is invalid.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The essence of the <i>sukkah</i> is that its roof must be botanical (but only materials that cannot become ritually unclean). The branches or other material must be arranged so that there is more shadow than sun inside the <i>sukkah</i>. If there is a place where that condition is not satisfied for three hand-breadths horizontally from a wall, the <i>sukkah</i> cannot be used to fulfill the commandment “to dwell” in it (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 23:42" href="/Leviticus.23.42"><i>Lev.</i> 23:42</a>).</i>” Hence less than that is acceptable. May one sleep under that<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The place, less than two hand-breadths wide, under which there is more sun than shadow. Instead of sleeping, the question could have been asked about eating.</i>? Rebbi Isaac ben Elyashib<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">An Israeli Amora of the fourth generation, colleague of Rebbi Mana; a holy man and worker of miracles.</i> answered, pourable mud completes a <i>miqweh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">A ritual bath can be used for cleansing impurities only if it contains 40 <i>seäh</i>, about 135 gallons. If there is not enough clear water, the desired volume can be obtained by adding mud that is so moist that it can be poured from a bucket (Mishnah <i>Miqwaöt</i> 7:1). The complete argument is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 1:11:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.1.11.2">Yerushalmi <i>Sukkah</i> 1:10</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 19a" href="/Sukkah.19a">Babli <i>Sukkah</i> 19a</a>.</i> but one may not immerse in it, here also it completes the <i>sukkah</i> but one may not sleep under it.
Three who ate together and one wants to leave, Rav said he should recite the first benediction, then he may leave. What is the first benediction? In the Yeshivah of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">After Rav’s death.</i> they said, the benediction of invitation. Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav Jeremiah: that is “He Who feeds all.”<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The first benediction of Grace when recited without “invitation”. It seems that Rebbi Zeïra also agrees that the one who wants to leave has to recite the benediction “of invitation” aloud so that the other two may answer and fulfill their duty to recite Grace with “invitation”; the disagreement is only about how much he has to recite aloud, whether only the “invitation” or also the first benediction of Grace proper. [If all three recite Grace together, the one who recites the “invitation” has to recite all of Grace aloud; this custom has disappeared in Eastern European Ashkenazic Jewry after the invention of printing and the availability of inexpensive prayer books for everyone.]</i> Rebbi Ḥelbo, Rav Ḥanan in the name of Rav: that is “He Who feeds all.” Rav Sheshet objected, but a <i>baraita</i> disagrees: “Two, three are obliged to recite Grace.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">It is generally agreed that ברכת הזימון is a scribal error and that the correct reading is that of Alfassi ברכת המזון “Grace”. The explanation of the elliptic <i>baraita</i> is according to Alfassi: If two or three people sit together and neither of them knows how to recite the entire Grace but each of them knows one or two benedictions that the others do not, then they take turns in reciting the benedictions and they all have fulfilled their obligations, the one reciting by pronouncing the benediction and the others by listening and answering “Amen”. The numbers are important to show that we require one person to recite an entire benediction; it is not permissible to split one benediction among several people. Hence, the maximal number of people who can share in reciting Grace is the number of benedictions in Grace.</i>” If you want to say the benediction of invitation is the first one, one should state “four.” They found stated “four.” If you want to say this is “He Who feeds all”, it is difficult. If you want to say that it<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">The fourth benediction according to him who requires the first benediction to include “He Who feeds all.”</i> is “He Who is good and does good”, you cannot do that, there is a difference<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Between the first three benedictions that are Torah obligations and the fourth one who seems to be Rabbinic in character.</i> because Rav Huna said that “He Who is good and does good” was fixed<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">It says “fixed”, not “instituted” as in the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 48b" href="/Berakhot.48b">Babli (48b</a>). According to the Yerushalmi, the fourth benediction is old, probably Biblical, but it was not permanently required in earlier times; the problem is discussed in the author’s <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah</i> (Northvale NJ, 1995) p. 358–359.</i> after permission was received to bury the slain of Betar<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Roman law did not allow the burial of rebels against the government. Hence, the dead of Betar, the last of Bar Kokhba’s fortresses, could certainly not be buried during Hadrian’s lifetime. It is not known which of his successors gave permission to bury the dead. We may assume that it was the same emperor who permitted the re-establishment of the Synhedrion.</i>, “He Who is good” because the dead did not decompose and “He Who does good” that they could be buried. Rav Huna said, you may explain it following Rebbi Ismael since Rebbi Ismael said<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mekhilta deR. Ismael</i> Ba 16.</i>, “He Who is good and does good” is an obligation from the Torah as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:10" href="/Deuteronomy.8.10"><i>Deut.</i>8:10</a>): <i>You will eat and be satiated, then you must praise</i>, that is the benediction of invitation; t<i>he Eternal, your God</i>, that is “He Who feeds all”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Since the name “God” represents God as Creator of the physical world.</i>; <i>for the Land</i>, that is the benediction over the Land; <i>the good one</i>, that is the benediction “builder of Jerusalem” [and so it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 3:25" href="/Deuteronomy.3.25"><i>Deut.</i> 3:25</a>) “this good mountain and the Lebanon<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">“Lebanon” means the Temple; this identification goes back at least to the time of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai who predicted to Vespasian that he would become emperor, since he would destroy the Temple and it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 10:34" href="/Isaiah.10.34"><i>Is.</i> 10:34</a>) “the Lebanon will fall through a powerful one” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 56b" href="/Gittin.56b">Babli <i>Giṭṭin</i> 56b</a>; Yerushalmi sources: <i>Abot deR. Nathan</i> 4, <i>Midrash Ekha rabba</i> 1).</i>”]; <i>that He gave you</i>, that is “He Who is good and does good”.
For Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Torah study, including Torah reading.</i> there is written a benediction before, but no benediction is written after. What is written before it? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 32:3" href="/Deuteronomy.32.3"><i>Deut.</i> 32:3</a>) “For I am invoking the name of the Eternal, attribute greatness to our God.” For food there is written a benediction after, but no benediction is written before. What is written after it? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:10" href="/Deuteronomy.8.10"><i>Deut.</i> 8:10</a>): “You will eat and be satiated, then you must praise”. From where that which is said about one on the other and vice-versa? Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥmani in the name of Rebbi Jonathan: The Name is mentioned in both verses as parallel expressions<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">In general, it is assumed in the system of Rebbi Aqiba that a word can have only one meaning. A stronger implication, agreed to by all tannaïtic authorities, is a “parallel expression”. The formal definition of the school of R. Ismael is that <i>if</i> one has a tradition that two equal or synonymous expressions are written in the Torah for purposes of comparison and <i>if</i> these two words are not used for any other inference, <i>then</i> all laws connected with one word apply to the other and vice-versa. The derivation here does not fulfill these conditions; hence, it is labelled to follow the rules of R. Aqiba who is not known to require too much formality in case the verse is used to give a biblical base to an old tradition.</i>. Just as the Name that is mentioned concerning Torah implies a benediction before, so the Name that is mentioned concerning food implies a benediction before. And just as the Name that is mentioned concerning food implies a benediction after, so the Name that is mentioned concerning Torah implies a benediction after. That follows Rebbi Aqiba<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Who is an exponent of intensional interpretation, whereas R. Ismael is an exponent of extensional interpretation. The rules of R. Ismael are systematized in his “13 rules” given in the introduction to the halakhic Midrash <i>Sifra</i> on <i>Leviticus</i>. The problem of both Rebbi Aqiba and Rebbi Ismael is that in its mishnaic-talmudic form, the rules of Jewish conduct form a logically consistent whole. It was shown earlier in this chapter, Notes 24 – 29, that rules must be consistent from one application to the next, such as rules of Grace and forming a court of law. But the basis of these laws, the words of the Torah, are unsystematic, fragmentary, and sometimes appear contradictory. Hence, one needs a method of translating the aphoristic text of the Torah in a legally consistent new language; cf. the author’s <i>Logical problems in Jewish tradition</i>, in: Confrontations with Judaism, ed. P. Longworth, Blond, London 1966, 171–196. The rules are discussed in the medieval texts <i>Introduction to the Talmud</i> by R. Samuel Hanaggid and <i>Sefer Keritut</i> of R. Simson of Sens.</i>. What following Rebbi Ismael? Rebbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rebbi Ismael, an inference from the lesser to the greater<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">קל וחוֹמר, the first rule of R. Ismael. If there are two commandments, A and B, and if every rule for A is no more stringent than the corresponding rule for B, then a rule expressed for A that has no equivalent for B is valid also for B. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 21a" href="/Berakhot.21a">Babli (21a</a>) quotes the following <i>qal waḥomer</i> in the name of R. Yoḥanan only and points out that the application here is not justified since it is self-contradictory. The Yerushalmi seems to be of the opinion that in the formulation given here, with “not more stringent” instead of “less stringent”, the argument is logically admissible.</i>. If food that needs no explicit benediction before, needs a benediction afterwards, regarding Torah that needs a benediction before, it is only logical that it should need a benediction afterwards. That works for Torah; what about food? If Torah that needs no benediction afterwards, needs a benediction before, regarding food that needs a benediction afterwards, it is only logical that it should need a benediction before. Rebbi Isaac and Rebbi Nathan say, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 9:13" href="/I_Samuel.9.13"><i>1Sam.</i> 9:13</a>): “For he will recite the benediction over the sacrifice and after that the invited guests will eat.”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 48b" href="/Berakhot.48b">Babli (48b</a>) and in the <i>Mekhilta</i> (<i>loc. cit.</i>) this is given in the name of R. Nathan only. A verse from Samuel (Biblical but not Pentateuchal) cannot prove a commandment but can prove a practice.</i> Rebbi Nathan<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli and the Mekhilta, this appears in the name of Rebbi Isaac.</i> said, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:24" href="/Exodus.23.24"><i>Ex.</i> 23:24</a>) “you shall serve the Eternal, your God and give praise for your bread and your water”; when is it called your bread and your water, before you eat<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The full verse seems to read: “You shall serve the Eternal, your God, then He will bless your bread and your water and I will remove sickness from your midst.” The switch from third to first person is awkward in any case. In the Babli (in particular, in the Sephardic incunabula print) it is spelled out: Do not read וּבֵרַךְ “He will bless” but וּבָרֵךְ “and praise”. However, the Bible Concordance of G. Lisowsky (Stuttgart 1958) takes the verse, as it stands, to mean “You shall serve the Eternal, your God, and praise for your bread and your water, then I will remove sickness from your midst.” One may recite a benediction one one’s bread and one’s water only before it is consumed; afterwards one may speak only of nourishment and sustenance.</i>.
