Rebbi said, if he has to give praise when he ate and is satiated, somuch more at a time when he is hungry for food. That is for food, what about Torah? If food, which sustains only temporary life, needs a benediction before and after, Torah, which sustains eternal life, so much more<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli and the <i>Mekhilta</i> this is a קל וחוֹמר of Rebbi Ismael.</i>.
Rebbi Zeïra asked: These three that are called<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">For reading the Torah in public. Since the preceding arguments tied benedictions over Torah reading to Grace, one has to ask in which way they are comparable. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 21b" href="/Megillah.21b">Babli <i>Megillah</i> 21b</a> there is a <i>baraita</i>: “(In reading the Torah) he who starts recites the benediction before and he who finishes recites the benediction after.” On that, the Gemara notes: But today, all recite benedictions before and after. This “today” may be long after the work on the Yerushalmi stopped. In any case, the <i>baraita</i> seems to represent the early Babylonian practice; we do not know of any direct Yerushalmi source that let people read the Torah without benediction. Rebbi Zeïra, the Galilean head of academy who had come from Babylonia, is the right person to ask for the reasons and the correct practice. Since his questions remain without answers, both practices might be acceptable. Both the preceding paragraph and R. Zeïra’s question presuppose that private Torah reading requires benedictions before and after, cf. מסכת סופרים Chap. 13 and Ezra Fleischer, קטעים מקובצי תפילה ארץ־ישראליים מן הגניזה, קובץ על יד יג (כג) 139–141, 188–189.</i>, how are you treating them? As three who ate together or as three who ate each one for himself? If you treat them as three who ate together then the first one recites the benediction before, the last one recites the benediction after, and the middle one does not recite any benediction at all. If you treat them as three who ate each one for himself then even the middle one recites benedictions before and after. Rebbi Samuel ben Eudaimon said, they did learn the benedictions for the Torah from Grace<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Text of the parallel in <i>Megillah</i> 4:1; the Venice print has here “benediction of ‘invitation’ ”, a scribal error הזימון for המזון.</i> only in public<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">R. Samuel ben Eudaimon seems to object to reciting a benediction after Torah study. Also, since Torah study is a permanent obligation (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 1:8" href="/Joshua.1.8"><i>Jos.</i> 1:8</a>), one benediction in the morning is enough to cover all Torah study during the day and evening; one does not have to recite a new benediction for study after an interruption. The prayer manuals of Yerushalmi type (see <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 7:1:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.7.1.7">Note 48</a>) which have benedictions after the reading of Pentateuch, Prophets, and Hagiographs require these only for reading the Bible, not oral Torah study.</i>. If in public, then in private one should not recite any benediction! Rebbi Abba Mari, the brother of Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the fourth generation who is never mentioned in the Babli.</i>, said: They made it equal to other commandments of the Torah. Just as other commandments of the Torah need benedictions, this also needs a benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Most commandments need only a benediction before, not after their execution. Thus, the benediction for the Torah in private study follows the general rule of benedictions over commandments. The quote for benediction for the Torah before the reading, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 32:3" href="/Deuteronomy.32.3"><i>Deut.</i> 32:3</a>, is clearly addressed to the public and, therefore, not applicable to private study.</i>.
“If one ate <i>demay</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah.</i> This means that, if one ate produce which perhaps was tithed<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Food of which <i>terumah</i> and <i>terumah of the tithe</i> were taken so that it may be consumed without incurring guilt</i> and perhaps was not tithed, one invites him. Rebbi Simeon, the brother of Rebbi Berekhiah<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">He is not otherwise mentioned in the Talmud.</i>: At the time when they were instituting <i>demai</i>, most of the unlearned brought the harvest into their houses<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to give <i>terumah</i> and tithe starts when produce is brought through the door of the house (or barn). The expression here implies that most of the unlearned followed the rules and ate only produce that was in order; only because of the severity of the offense of eating <i>ṭevel</i> was the rule of <i>demai</i> decreed since a minority of uneducated did not follow the rules for produce sold; in that case the probablity of having produce that was not in order was less than 50%. There is therefore no inference possible for the problem under discussion, where the probability of things being wrong is 50%.</i>. Which one says that<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Which part of the Mishnah does speak to our problem?</i>? “One invites the Samaritan.” And is that Samaritan not doubtful<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Since Samaritans do not follow rabbinic rules, we cannot check on the status of their produce.</i>? Rebbi Abba said, explain it following what is said<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Referring to the opinion of Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel in the <i>baraita;</i> for him the Mishnah simply declares that Samaritans are counted as Jews and no inference is possible for our case. The question is left without answer.</i>: A Samaritan is like a Gentile, the words of Rebbi. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, a Samaritan is like a Jew in all respects.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One does not ‘invite’<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">To recite the invitation aloud and to count them for a group of three. [The Babli notes that women for themselves and slaves for themselves may recite Grace with “invitation”; we cannot know what was the position of the Yerushalmi in that matter.]</i> women, slaves, and minors. What is the minimum to ‘invite’? Down to the size of an olive, Rebbi Yehudah says to the size of an egg<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">That the total food consumed by each person is at least the volume of an average olive or chicken egg.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi, Rebbi Yose ben Shaul in the name of Rebbi: One makes a minor an appendix for ten<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The next Mishnah explains that the formula of “invitation” for three is “let us praise Him of Whose bounty we ate” whereas for ten it is “let us praise our God of Whose bounty we ate”. The question is whether the ten all have to be male adults or whether they have to be just ten males (of which nine are certain adults and the tenth possibly a minor as “appendix”.) In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 47b-48a" href="/Berakhot.47b-48a">Babli (47b/48a</a>), R. Joshua ben Levi is quoted as permitting the tenth (for reciting Grace) even to be a baby lying in a crib. However, from the continuation of the discussion here it seems that the Yerushalmi does not even consider allowing a minor to join for the long form of “invitation” but only for Torah reading or other <i>public</i> services.<br>Rebbi Yose ben Shaul was a student of Rebbi. He transmits sayings of Rebbi only.</i>. But did we not state: One does not investigate a minor<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">One version of the full <i>baraita</i> is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 47b" href="/Berakhot.47b">Babli 47b</a>: “A minor who grew two pubic hairs may take part in ‘invitation’, a minor who did not grow two pubic hairs may not take part in ‘invitation’ but one does not investigate a minor.” The other version is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:18" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.18">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:18</a>: “A minor who can eat an olive may take part in ‘invitation’, a minor who cannot eat an olive may not take part in ‘invitation’; one does not investigate a minor.” Most commentators refer the Yerushalmi to the version in Berakhot but it seems clear that the Yerushalmi is based on a text close to the Tosephta and emphatically disagrees with the Babli, cf. <i>Tosephta Kifshutah</i>, <i>ad loc.</i></i>? Rebbi Yose said, one confirms Rebbi Simon, Rebbi Ḥanina, Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The entire text is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 91" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.91"><i>Bereshit rabba</i> 91</a>; there it says correctly “Rebbi Yose said, one confirms Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi”.<br>The last part of the Tosephta implies that if a boy is on the threshhold of manhood (<i>bar miẓwah</i>), one can make him take part in any ceremony that needs ten adults by simply asking him if he is of age; one does not have to investigate if what he says is true. The implication here is that if one has a boy who looks younger than the age of puberty, one certainly cannot take him as tenth man.</i>: it<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">The Tosephta which insists that one does not investigate but that the boy should not look too young.</i> is needed for two minors; if he is a minor, one considers him doubtful, if he is doubtful<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">If he has reached the age, but we do not know whether he started growing pubic hair. The sentence speaks of all other occasions where one needs ten adult males, such as public prayer and Torah reading, but not of Grace which depends only on whether the child is able to eat an olive-size piece made of grain (in a country and time where children were usually nursed for between three and five years.)</i>, one considers him certain. Rebbi Yehudah ben Pazi in the name of Rebbi Yose: nine that look like ten<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Where the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 47b" href="/Berakhot.47b">Babli (47b</a>) agrees that one may recite the invitation formula for ten adults.</i>, does one “invite” only those that are certain? Also if a minor was among them?
Rebbi Berekhiah said that Rebbi Jacob bar Zavdi asked before Rebbi Yose: “What are we dealing with? There<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">In the case of public reading of the Torah, as given in the next paragraph.</i> one makes him an appendix for ten, one should say that here<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Reciting Grace.</i> one should make him an appendix for three. Since there one makes him an appendix for the mention of the Divine Name, here, when one does not mention the Divine Name, <i>a fortiori</i> should one make him an appendix.” He answered him: “It is not <i>a fortiori</i>! There, since they must mention the Name<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">In an obligatory public service.</i>, one makes him anappendix; here, since one does not recite the Name<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">In private.</i>, there is no need to make him an appendix!”
It has been stated: One may take a minor and a Torah scroll as appendix. Rebbi Judan said: So is the <i>baraita</i>: One may take a minor as appendix for the purpose of Torah reading<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">But the Torah scroll is not a human and one never will get by with only eight adult males. The original <i>baraita</i> is close to a statement of Rav Huna in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 47b" href="/Berakhot.47b">Babli (47b</a>) which there is corrected differently.</i>.
When does one start to make him an appendix? Rebbi Avina said: Rab Ḥuna and Rav Yehudah disagreed, both in the name of Samuel. One said, that he has to understand the nature of a benediction; the other one said that he has to understand to Whom one has to recite the benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 48a" href="/Berakhot.48a">Babli (48a</a>), this is the opinion of Rav Naḥman, another student of Samuel.</i>. Rebbi Nassa said, many times did I eat with my father Taḥlipha and my uncle Aninia bar Sisai and they did not recite the ‘invitation’ with me until I grew two pubic hairs<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Since report of an action is the best proof, it is shown that one never uses a minor as appendix for reciting Grace with ‘invitation’.</i>.
Samuel bar Shilat<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Rav who is regarded as the ideal teacher in the Babli. For nine years he did not have time to tend his garden because he was caring about the children in his school. The title “Ribbi” given him in the next sentence is a scribal error.</i> asked before Rav, but some say that it was asked before Rav Samuel bar Shilat: Nine ate bread and one ate vegetable<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Nine are required to recite Grace. The tenth is only required to recite the short formula but he is there to form a quorum of ten adult males for the invocation of the Name.</i>? He said to them: One ‘invites’. Eight ate bread and two ate vegetable? He said to them: One ‘invites’. Seven ate bread and two ate vegetable? He said to them: One ‘invites’. Rebbi Avina asked: What is the rule for half and half<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Does one need a majority of those who are required to recite Grace or is it enough to have ten adult males present. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 48a" href="/Berakhot.48a">Babli (48a</a>), Rebbi Zeïra is of the opinion that not only does one need a majority but one even needs a qualified majority and seven is the minimal number for reciting the ‘invitation’ with the Name.</i>? Rebbi Zeïra said, as long as I was there, I would have needed that. I regret that I did not ask.
Rebbi Jeremiah asked: May he who ate vegetable recite Grace? Rebbi Jeremiah seems to contradict himself<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The contradiction will be explained in the following lengthy story.</i>! It has been stated: 300 <i>nezirim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">People who made a vow to abstain from all grape products, let their hair grow, and kept themselves in strict ritual purity for a certain amount of time. At the end of that time, the <i>nazir</i> could terminate his vow only if he offered a sheep as holocaust sacrifice, a female sheep for a sin-offering, and a goat for a family sacrifice (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 6" href="/Numbers.6"><i>Num.</i> 6</a>). Most of these <i>nezirim</i> were poor people who relied on charity to fulfill their obligations in the Temple.</i> came in the days of Simeon ben Shetaḥ<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">President of the Synhedrion in the times of the Hasmonean king Alexander Yannai and brother of queen Shlomẓion (Salome Alexandra).</i>. For 150 of them he found an opening<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">An “opening of regrets”, an argument that made the <i>nazir</i> regret his original decision to become a <i>nazir</i>; this invalidates the vow retroactively so that no sacrifice may be brought.</i>, for 150 of them he did not find an opening. He came to king Yannai and said to him: There are here 300 <i>nezirim</i> who need 900 sacrifices. You should give half of them from your side, I shall give half from my side. The king sent him 450 animals. An informer went around and said that the other one had not given anything from his own money. King Yannai heard about it and got angry. Simeon ben Shetaḥ feared and fled<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in the Babli (48ab), Simeon ben Shetaḥ went into hiding because Alexander Yannai sided with the Sadducees when it was reported to him that some Pharisees thought him to be unfit as priest.</i>. After some time, important people from the Persian empire came to king Yannai<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">During all of the Second Commonwealth and certainly during the reign of Alexander Yannai, the Jewish state relied on contributions from the Jews in the diaspora, both from Rome and from Persia (then, Parthia). It may be assumed that the delegation brought the yearly subsidy and, therefore, was in a position to enforce their will.</i>. At the meal, they said to him: We remember that there was here an old man who gave us a rabbinic discourse. He told them what had happened. They said to him, send and bring him! He sent and gave him his word<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">That it was safe and nothing would happen to him. In the Babli, it was the queen, Simeon’s sister, who arranged matters.</i>; he came and sat between king and queen. He said to him, why did you trick me? He said, I did not trick you; you with your money and I with my learning, as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 7:12" href="/Ecclesiastes.7.12"><i>Eccl.</i> 7:12</a>) “In the shadow of wisdom, in the shadow of money<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Wisdom and money are equivalent to give protection.</i>.” He said to him, why did you disappear? He said to him, I heard that my lord was angry with me and I wanted to fulfill the verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 26:20" href="/Isaiah.26.20"><i>Is.</i> 26:20</a>) “Hide a little bit until the rage passes;” he used about himself (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 7:12" href="/Ecclesiastes.7.12"><i>Eccl.</i> 7:12</a>): “Knowledge is an advantage, wisdom lets its possessor live.” He said to him, why did you sit between king and queen? He said to him, it is written in the book of Ben Sirach<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">This verse cannot be reconstructed with confidence, since the manuscripts of the Babli and parallel sources all have different versions.</i>: “Esteem it and it will raise you and set you between princes.” He said, bring him a cup that he may recite Grace. He took the cup and said: “Let us give praise for the food that Yannai and his company ate.” He said to him, are you still obstinate as ever? He said to him, what should I say, “for the food that we did not eat?” He said, bring him something that he may eat. They brought, he ate and recited: “For the food that we ate.” Rebbi Yoḥanan said, his colleagues disagree with Simeon ben Shetaḥ. Rebbi Jeremiah said, about the first action<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">That he tricked Yannai to give the animals for sacrifices under false pretenses, even though formally Simeon ben Shetaḥ was correct. The second action was that he refused to recite Grace without having eaten at least a minimal meal.<br>The text here is clearly corrupt since by the statement of the Talmud, Rebbi Jeremiah disagrees with Simeon ben Shetaḥ about the recitation of Grace. The correct text, that R. Abba refers to the first action and R. Jeremiah to the second, is in the Yerushalmi source <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 51" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.51"><i>Midrash Bereshit rabba</i> 51</a>. [In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 48a" href="/Berakhot.48a">Babli, 48a</a>, it is R. Abba the son of R. Ḥiyya bar Abba in the name of R. Yoḥanan who declares that Grace cannot be recited by someone who did not eat bread. But the Babli cannot be used for the text of the Yerushalmi.]</i>; Rebbi Abba said, about the second action. Rebbi Jeremiah seems to contradict himself! There he wondered about it and here<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">In his theoretical question he wonders, in his critique of Simeon ben Shetaḥ following R. Yoḥanan he is certain.</i> it is obvious for him! He wondered following the Sages; it is obvious for him following Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel. We have stated about this: If one was lying on a couch and ate<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">In the Midrash, the Rome manuscript, the Tosephta, (and the Babli) “dipped (some vegetable in broth)”. Both in the Yerushalmi, here and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 5:3:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.5.3.2-4"><i>Nazir</i> 5:5</a>, and the prints of the Midrash, this is labelled “words of the Sages.” But in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:20" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.20">Tosephta (5:20</a>) and manuscripts of the Midrash (and in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 48a" href="/Berakhot.48a">Babli 48a</a>), the statement is attributed to Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel. It seems that the attribution here to the Sages is a scribal error since the opinion attributed to Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel in the last <i>baraita</i> is the one given in the Tosephta and R. Jeremiah is reported as following the latter’s opinion in the interpretation of the story of Simeon ben Shetaḥ.</i> with them, even if he did not eat grain the volume of an olive one ‘invites’ with him, the words of the Sages. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: One never ‘invites’ anyone unless he had eaten grain the volume of an olive<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">In the restrictive spirit of the Yerushalmi as explained earlier.</i>. But did we not formulate, “two bread and one vegetable, then one ‘invites’?” This <i>baraita</i> follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> How does one ‘invite’? If there are three, he says: let us praise<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">The changes apply only to the start of the invitation; in all cases one continues with “Him, Whose food we ate”.</i>. If there are three in addition to himself, he says: praise!<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Since there are three without him, he may address them without including himself.</i> If there are ten, he says: let us praise our God. If there are ten in addition to himself, he says: praise! There is no difference between ten and ten myriads<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">This is the majority opinion; the rest of the Mishnah is Rebbi Yose the Galilean’s, as explained at the end of the Mishnah.</i>. If there are a hundred, he says: let us praise the Eternal, our God. If there are a hundred in addition to himself, he says: praise! If there are a thousand, he says: let us praise the Eternal, our God, the God of Israel. If there are a thousand in addition to himself, he says: praise! If there are ten thousand, he says: let us praise the Eternal, our God, the God of Israel, God of Hosts, Who thrones over the Cherubim, for the food that we ate. Rebbi Yose the Galilean says, the praise has to be according to the multitude of the assembled, as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 68:27" href="/Psalms.68.27"><i>Ps.</i> 68:27</a>): “In assemblies<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">It will be clear in the Halakhah that the difference between the Sages and R. Yose the Galilean is in the interpretation of this word, whether it means “assemblies”, i. e., different assemblies recite different praises, or “choirs” that all sing together.</i> praise God, the Lord, from the root of Israel.”<br>Rebbi Aqiba said, do we not find in the synagoge that one recites “Praise the Eternal” whether there are many or few? Rebbi Ismael says, “Praise the Eternal, the Praised One!”<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah is sequel to the preceding one and presents the argument of the Sages against Rebbi Yose the Galilean. The difference in text between the two authorities already was discussed in the preceding Halakhah.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Clarification. Rebbi Zeïra, Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, and Rebbi Ḥanina the colleague of the rabbis, were sitting and eating together. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa took the cup<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The cup of wine over which Grace is recited. Since there were four sages eating together, the Mishnah would require that he start with “praise!”.</i> and said “let us praise”, he did not say: “praise!”. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba asked him, why did you not say “praise!” He said to him, did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:18" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.18">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:18</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50a" href="/Berakhot.50a">Babli 50a</a>.</i>: “One does not insist on the formulation. Whether he says ‘let us praise’, or he says ‘praise!’, one does not criticize him, but the pedants<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The reading of the <i>Arukh</i> is נקרנין “nitpickers.” The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50a" href="/Berakhot.50a">Babli (50a</a>) interprets the Tosephta to mean that “praise!” is acceptable but not preferred; the Yerushalmi seems to accept Samuel’s statement (also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 49b" href="/Berakhot.49b">Babli 49b</a>) at face value that “praise!” should not be used in practice.</i> criticize him for that.” Rebbi Zeïra felt badly that Rebbi Jacob bar Abba had called Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba a pedant.
Samuel said: I do not want to exclude myself from the group<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, Samuel is quoted as saying “nobody should exclude himself from the group” as obligatory ruling, whereas here he is quoted as stating his personal preference for נברך against the Mishnah.</i>. They objected: look at the benediction for the Torah where he says “praise!” Rebbi Abun said, since he will conclude by “the Praised One”, he does not exclude himself from the group.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">It is explained in the next Mishnah that the benediction for reading the Torah starts with “Praise the Eternal” according to Rebbi Aqiba, and “Praise the Eternal, the Praised One” according to Rebbi Ismael. Rebbi Abun indicates that practice follows Rebbi Ismael. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50a" href="/Berakhot.50a">Babli (50a</a>) indicates that in Torah reading, the people forced adherence to the opinion of R. Ismael, apparently against the resistance of some rabbis (called “black vessels” by Rava) who preferred to follow Rebbi Aqiba. It seems that R. Ḥiyya bar Abba, a native Babylonian, felt that R. Jacob bar Aḥa was following the uneducated, but in Galilee everybody followed Samuel and popular opinion.</i>
Rebbi Abba bar Zamina waited upon Zeïra and mixed him a cup. He<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">The last two words are not in the Rome manuscript and are probably dittography.</i> said to him: Old man, make the benediction, and have the intention of drinking another one, as we have stated: The waiter makes a benediction for every single cup<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Since he cannot expect to get another cup, he cannot have the intention to make one benediction for more than one cup. On the other hand, in the opinion of the Yerushalmi the waiter will always have occasion to eat some food from the kitchen, hence he may make a benediction for the future. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 107b" href="/Chullin.107b">Babli (<i>Ḥulin</i> 107b</a>), this <i>baraita</i> is a statement of Rav and is restricted there to formal dinners. The Babli also quotes an opinion of the Galilean R. Yoḥanan that for solid food also the waiter cannot make a benediction for the uncertain future; since this is not mentioned here one has to conclude that the Yerushalmi rejects the distinction made in the Babli.</i> but not for every morsel. He answered him: Just as I have the intention of absolving you of your obligation by the benediction so you must have the intention of absolving me of my obligation<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">All commentators except R. Moshe Margalit declare this passage to be corrupt and that it should read מַפְקָא יְדֵי חוֹבָתָךְ “fulfill your obligation”; this seems to be required by the following quote (which is formulated for sounding the <i>shofar</i> but is valid for all obligations that may be fulfilled by listening.)</i> by “Amen”. Rebbi Tanḥum bar Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">A student of R. Mana II of the fifth generation.</i> said, a Mishnah (<i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 4:8) states this: The absent-minded<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">The word means usually “absentminded” but can also mean “practicing” and that probably is the primary meaning in this Mishnah, that one who blows the <i>shofar</i> in order to learn the technique cannot by the same act fulfill his obligation, neither can anyone who hears him. But in our application, the intended meaning is “absent-minded.” R. Abba bar Zamina’s implication is that in hearing a benediction one must answer “Amen” in order to make sure that the listener is not absent-minded either. This explains the placing of this paragraph here, following another one where also one person recites Grace in order for all others (even a hundred thousand) to be freed from their obligation.</i> did not fulfill his obligation and he who heard from the absent-minded did not fulfill his obligation.
“If there are a hundred” etc. Rebbi Yoḥanan said, these are the words of Rebbi Jose the Galilean, but the Sages say “there is no difference between ten and ten myriads”. Rava<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that here an apostrophe is missing and the name is R. Abba who is frequently mentioned in the Yerushalmi, rather than Rava (Rav Abba), one of the architects of dialectics in the Babli who lived at the time when the work on the Yerushalmi came to an end. The latter is mentioned only once in the Yerushalmi [<i>Beẓa</i> 1:3 (fol. 60b)] as Rebbi (!) Abba bar Josef [in the parallel in the Babli, based on the Yerushalmi, his full name is given as Rava bar Rav Josef bar Ḥama in contrast to Babylonian material where his name consistently is only Rava]. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50a" href="/Berakhot.50a">Babli, (50a</a>) Rava is quoted as saying that “the people follow R. Ismael”, i. e., there is no binding ruling in the matter but a silent consensus, whereas the statement in the Yerushalmi indicates a rabbinic ruling.</i> said, practice follows him who states that there is no difference between ten and ten myriads.
From where that “congregation” means ten people<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">The discussion here is to prove that for a public invocation of the Name one needs a congregation of at least ten adult males. The relevant verses are <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:2" href="/Leviticus.19.2"><i>Lev.</i> 19:2</a> “Speak to the entire congregation of the children of Israel and tell them: conduct yourselves in holiness because I, The Eternal, your God, Am Holy” and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:32" href="/Leviticus.22.32"><i>Lev.</i> 22:32</a> “I shall be sanctified in the midst of the children of Israel.” The same discussion is reported <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 4:4:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.4.4.2-8"><i>Megillah</i> 4:4</a>, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 1:4. The parallel discussion in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 23a" href="/Megillah.23a">Babli, <i>Megillah</i> 23a</a>, in the name of the first generation Rebbi Ḥiyya, is based on the second verse and is intelligible only if it is understood as reference to the derivation in the Yerushalmi.</i>? Rebbi Abba and Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: It is said here “congregation” and it says there<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">“Here” refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:2" href="/Leviticus.19.2"><i>Lev.</i> 19:2</a>, “there” to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 14:27" href="/Numbers.14.27"><i>Num.</i> 14:27</a>: “How long for this evil congregation”, speaking of the ten spies who argued against entering the Land. There were twelve spies in all; Joshua and Caleb were in the opposition; accordingly there were ten evil persons who formed the congregation.</i> “congregation”. Since “congregation” mentioned there means ten, so also “congregation” mentioned here must mean ten. Rebbi Simon said, it is said here “in the midst” and it is said there “in the midst” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 42:5" href="/Genesis.42.5"><i>Gen.</i> 42:5</a>): “The sons of Israel came to buy grain in the midst of those who came.” Since “in the midst” said there means ten, so also here it must mean ten. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said to him, if you deduce from “in the midst”, there are too many of them<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">In particular, in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:32" href="/Leviticus.22.32"><i>Lev.</i> 22:32</a>, “in the midst” must mean 600’000 adult males. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:32" href="/Leviticus.22.32">Babli, <i>Lev.</i> 22:32</a> is used to establish a formal parallel, known as <i>gezerah shawah</i>, between this verse and the one from Genesis. The latter verse is then used to arrive at the number ten (since of the twelve tribes, Joseph and Benjamin were missing). From the Babli it seems that there was a tradition linking the two verses (since in its opinion, <i>gezerah shawah</i> must be based on a tradition) and, therefore, R. Simon is forced to quote a verse that in itself seems to be less adequate than the one used before.</i>. But it is said here “the children of Israel” and it is said there “the children of Israel.” Since “children of Israel” said there means ten, so here it also must mean ten.
How do the Sages use the reason of Rebbi Yose the Galilean? “In assemblies”, in each separate congregation. Rebbi Ḥanina the son of Rebbi Abbahu said, it is written במקהלת<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">The opinion of the sages is that the plural “assemblies” points to different assemblies at different places and not to different categories of the same assembly. R. Ḥanina notes that in R. Yose the Galilean’s tradition, the word was written defective and could be read as a singular מִקְהֶלֶת “assembly”. Hence, if the word is vocalized as a plural, it is an ideal plural that refers to different stages of the same assembly. In all our sources, the word in Psalms is written <i>plene</i> to support the position of the Sages; the Masorah to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 32:25-26" href="/Numbers.32.25-26"><i>Num.</i> 32:25/26</a> (composed several centuries after the conclusion of the Talmudim) notes that מקהלת appears as geographical name only in <i>Num.</i> and that in Psalms, מקהלוֹת is a <i>hapax legomenon</i>. The parallel <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50a" href="/Berakhot.50a">Babli (50a</a>) refers the verse in Psalms, in the name of R. Meir, to the choir of children at the Red Sea, a tradition more justly attributed to Rabban Gamliel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:4:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.4.2-3">Yerushalmi <i>Soṭa</i> 5:6</a>.</i>.
Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi rose to read in the Torah and said “Praise the Eternal,” he did not add “the Praised One!” They wanted to silence him. Rav said to them, let him, because he follows Rebbi Aqiba<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">The title “Rebbi” found twice in the text is a scribal error; Rav Ḥiyya Bar Ashi never went to Israel.<br>It seems that Rav, when he returned to Babylonia from his studies in Galilee, followed the Galilean order of prayers. [Even centuries later, we still find that Rav’s Yeshivah in Surah followed the <i>minhag Eretz Israel</i> in reciting liturgical poems in the prayers, whereas the autochthonous Yeshivah of Pum Beditha (Nahardea) never recited them.] Rav Ḥiyya Bar Ashi became a member of Rav’s Yeshivah but kept the old Babylonian <i>minhag</i> following Rebbi Aqiba. Rav had to explain to his students that this way also is acceptable. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50a" href="/Berakhot.50a">Babli (50a</a>) tells a similar story about Rafrem bar Papa, a student of Rav’s student Rav Huna; there, Rava notes that even in Babylonia “the people follow Rebbi Ismaël.” This shows that common practice was settled only three generations after Rav. (The Rome ms. has “Rav Ada” instead of “Rav”. Since Rav Ada was one of Rav’s students, ranking much below Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi, the reading has to be rejected.)</i>. Rebbi Zeïra rose to read as Cohen in place of a Levite and recited the benediction before and after. They wanted to silence him. Rav Hiyya bar Ashi said to them, let him, because that is their way of doing it<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">This second story deals with another subject. The original practice, as spelled out in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 3:1:1-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.3.1.1-11">Mishnah <i>Megillah</i> 3:1</a>, was that the first to read in the Torah pronounced the benediction before the reading and the last one the benediction after the reading. Even in Mishnaic times it became customary that every reader recited his own benediction. Here, Rebbi Zeïra had read his portion as Cohen; in the absence of a Levite he was called a second time to read and he started by reciting the benedictions again. It is reported in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 16b" href="/Avodah_Zarah.16b">Babli (<i>Avodah Zarah</i> 16b</a>) that R. Zeïra studied some time in the Yeshivah of R. Ḥiyya bar Ashi after having been ordained by Rav Yehudah and before his immigration to Galilee. The action of R. Zeïra, therefore, reflects the practice of the Yeshivah of Nahardea.</i>.
It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 8:6" href="/Nehemiah.8.6"><i>Neh.</i> 8:6</a>): “Ezra praised the Eternal, the great God.” In what did he declare Him great? He declared Him great by the Explicit Name<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">The name YHWH pronounced with the correct vocalization that is unknown to us.</i>. Rav Mattanah said, he declared Him great by a benediction. Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Why are they called the Men of the Great Assembly<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 3:7:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.3.7.2-6"><i>Megillah</i> 3:8</a>; in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 69b" href="/Yoma.69b">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 69b</a> it is spelled out that Rav Mattanah means the first benediction of the <i>‘Amidah</i> that contains the sentence “the Great, Strong, and Awesome God” chosen by the Men of the Great Assembly, and the observation of R. Joshua ben Levi is intended to buttress the argument of Rav Mattanah.</i>? Because they returned the Crown to its former status. Rebbi Phineas said, Moses fixed the formula of benediction, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 10:17" href="/Deuteronomy.10.17"><i>Deut.</i> 10:17</a>) “the Great, Strong, and Awesome God.” Jeremiah said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 32:18" href="/Jeremiah.32.18"><i>Jer.</i> 32:18</a>): “the Great, Strong God,” but he left out “Awesome.” Why did he say “the Strong”? He may rightly be called strong because He sees the destruction and is silent. And why did he not say “the Awesome”? Awesome is only the Temple, as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 68:36" href="/Psalms.68.36"><i>Ps.</i> 68:36</a>): “Awesome is the Eternal from Your holy place.” Daniel said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 9:4" href="/Daniel.9.4"><i>Dan.</i> 9:4</a>)<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The same expression is used by Nehemiah, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 1:5" href="/Nehemiah.1.5"><i>Neh.</i> 1:5</a>.</i>: “the Great and Awesome God,” he did not say “the Strong”; His sons are put in neck-irons<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>collare</i> “neck-iron.”</i>, where is His strength? Why did he say: “the Awesome?” He may well be called “the Awesome” by the wonders He did for us in the fiery oven. But when the Men of the Great Assembly came,they restituted Greatness to its former place, “the Great, Strong, and Awesome God.” Does flesh and blood have power to set limits in these matters? Rebbi Isaac ben Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">There were two sages of this name, one a student of R. Yoḥanan and the other in the fourth generation, a colleague of R. Mana. In the Babli, the statement is attributed to R. Eleazar.</i> said, the prophets know that their God is Truth and they will not fawn before him.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Three who ate together are not permitted to split<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Since three together are required to recite the “invitation” whereas two or one do not recite it; the minimum number required for two separate recitations of Grace is six. Nine may form three groups, but ten are required to recite the “invitation” with an invocation of the Name. Hence, 10 to 19 people in a group may not split in the recitation of Grace.</i>, neither are four or five. Six may split and so on up to ten. Ten may not split and so on unless they are twenty.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> It was stated: If one was eating sitting down on Sabbath and forgot and did not mention Sabbath, Rav said: he must repeat, and Samuel said: he need not repeat<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 49b" href="/Berakhot.49b">Babli, 49b</a>, the opinion of Samuel is not mentioned; even Rav Naḥman, the student of Samuel, is reported to follow the ruling of Rav. Later commentators state that, since on the Sabbath one may not fast, eating on the Sabbath is a consequence of it being Sabbath and the Sabbath has to be mentioned in reciting Grace. Samuel might be of the opinion that anything not mentioned in the verse <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:10" href="/Deuteronomy.8.10"><i>Deut.</i> 8:10</a> cannot be a reason for repeating Grace.</i>.
Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: If one is in doubt whether he mentioned the New Moon or did not mention it, one does not make him repeat<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 49b" href="/Berakhot.49b">Babli (49b</a>) there is a similar statement by Rav Naḥman in the name of Samuel that, if someone forgot the day of the New Moon in Grace, one does not make him repeat. According to the Yerushalmi, that seems obvious as the opinion of Samuel. However, the mention of Samuel is not in the Munich manuscript of the Babli, and the Spanish incunabula prints of <i>Berakhot</i> Babli have “Rav” instead of “Samuel”; this seems to be the correct reading. According to the Babli, one does not have to repeat even if he is sure that he did not mention the day; according to the way the Yerushalmi quotes the formulation, one has to repeat even if there was only a doubt that he did not mention the day.</i>. They found a dissenting statement: On every day that has a <i>Musaph</i> sacrifice (e. g., the day of the new moon and the intermediate days of holidays,) he must mention the occasion and if he did not mention it, one makes him repeat. But on every day that has no <i>Musaph</i> sacrifice (e. g., Hanukkah and Purim,) he must mention the occasion but if he did not, one does not make him repeat.
Ḥanan bar Abba and the colleagues were eating on Sabbath. After they had eaten and recited Grace he got up and left. When he returned, he found them reciting Grace. He said, did we not recite Grace already? They said to him, we recited, but now we recite again because we forgot to mention the Sabbath. Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">The titles of Huna and Jeremiah must be Rav, not Rebbi as in the Hebrew text, since the entire discussion is between students of Rav.</i> Huna (Rav Jeremiah extends it in the name of Rav) did not say so: If he forgot to mention the Sabbath, he says: He<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">The full benediction would be: Praised are You, Eternal, our God, King of the universe, Who gave.…</i> Who gave rest to His people Israel. Here<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">One has to repeat if he turned from reciting Grace to other activities; one recites an addtional benediction if he realizes the omission before he has finished. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 49" href="/Berakhot.49">Babli (49a/b</a>) gives the full text of this benediction and the corresponding one for holidays, but there it is authorized only (in the name of Rav) if one realizes the omission before one starts the next benediction. This certainly is not the position of the Yerushalmi.</i> if he turned<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">הסיע “he moved away”, appears in the Babli as הסיח ; ע or ח were inaudible in Babylonian speech.</i> his mind away, there if he did not turn his mind away.
It is stated<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text appears in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 42a" href="/Berakhot.42a">Babli 42a</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:23" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.23">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:23</a>. In both these texts, the second sentence reads “if they sat down to eat”; this is interpreted in the Babli to mean that they are sitting together by a common decision. Hence, they form a group and have to recite Grace together. The language of the Yerushalmi, “they sat down and ate,” points to a spontaneous act that would not require Grace to be recited in common in the opinion of the Babli.</i>: Ten people walking on the road, even if all of them eat from the same loaf, each one recites Grace for himself. If they sat down and ate, even though each one eats his own loaf, one recites Grace for all of them. Rebbi Jeremiah “invited” his colleagues at an inn<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">It is assumed that everybody pays for his own meal (or, if the hostelry has no restaurant, eats from his own provisions) in an inn and, also, that the formation of the group is casual rather than planned. Nevertheless, they have to recite Grace together; see the preceding note.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Two groups that ate in one house, if some of one group saw some of the other group they join in “invitation”; otherwise, each group recites the “invitation” for itself. One does not recite a benediction over wine<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">It is assumed that everybody pays for his own meal (or, if the hostelry has no restaurant, eats from his own provisions) in an inn and, also, that the formation of the group is casual rather than planned. Nevertheless, they have to recite Grace together; see the preceding note.</i> unless he added water; these are the words of Rebbi Eliezer. But the Sages say, one may recite the benediction.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Abba bar Zamina in the name of Rebbi Zeïra: For two houses, there is a problem<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah gives the rule for two groups assembled at different places in one house. The problem of two groups which eat in different houses but see one another is not treated and one may make arguments both ways. {Tosaphot in <i>Babli</i> 50b read the statement as: “[The Mishnah] is only needed for two houses,” the inference being that if they see one another they can join in saying Grace. This transfers the meaning of Babylonian צריכא (“it is necessary”) to the Palestinian expression נצרכה (“it is problematic”) used here!}</i>.
Rebbi Yoḥanan said, it applies only if they entered with that in mind<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">R. Yoḥanan refers to the Mishnah: Two groups not in the same room may recite common Grace only if they started the meal with that intention. This corresponds to the opinion of Babli and Tosephta in the case of the caravan travelling together, discussed at the end of the previous Halakhah. However, since it is necessary to state this rule for people in two different rooms, it follows that the Yerushalmi does not require common intent for people in one room; R. Yoḥanan agrees with his student’s student R. Jeremiah in the preceding Halakhah.</i>.
What do you do with those at the house of the patriarch, like one house or like two houses<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50a" href="/Berakhot.50a">Babli (50a</a>) notes that at a dinner in the house of the Resh Galuta, the head of the Jews of Babylonia, one recites Grace in small groups since the place is so noisy that one could not hear a person at the dais reciting Grace. Here it seems that the Patriarch held his formal dinners in a very large hall with several groups forming circles and not communicating with one another. The question is whether the room acts as a common enclosure for all these groups or not.</i>? Let us say that if they usually walk over from one group to the other then they “invite” together; otherwise they do not “invite” together. Rebbi Berekhiah used to place his speaker in the middle of the door of the house of study and he recited the “invitation” together with both groups<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">The meals in the Yeshivah were taken in two adjacent rooms. A similar note in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 50b" href="/Berakhot.50b">Babli (50b</a>) states that if the same waiter waits upon several groups in a very large room, the waiter makes them one group.</i>.
“One does not recite a benediction over wine unless he added water; these are the words of Rebbi Eliezer. But the Sages say, one may recite the benediction.” Rebbi Zeriqa in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: The Sages agree with Rebbi Eliezer that one has to add a small amount of water into the cup used for Grace<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Because that is the civilized way of acting and religious obligations should be executed with dignity.</i>. The rabbis do so for the <i>Qiddush</i> cup. The statement of Rebbi Yose disagrees with Rebbi Jonah, for Rebbi Jonah tasted it and restored it<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Jonah tasted from the cup for <i>Qiddush</i> of Friday evening, then left the rest standing in the cup and “repaired” it the next morning by filling it again with more wine. As will be explained later in this Halakhah, a cup that has been drunk from cannot be used for another benediction; hence, it has to be replenished. The question is, if R. Jonah put water into his <i>Qiddush</i> cup, how could he leave it standing half full through the night?</i>. If you imply that it was mixed, did we not formulate: He who drinks mixed drinks that were standing through the night, his blood is on his head. Rebbi Yoḥanan said, that is only if it was standing in metal vessels<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">The last two statements are also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 17a" href="/Niddah.17a">Babli (<i>Niddah</i> 17a</a>); the <i>baraita</i> is very close to the text in <i>Derekh Ereẓ Rabba,</i> Chapter 11. Both of these sources give a list of things that are dangerous to one’s health. In the Yerushalmi, the statement of R. Yoḥanan answers the question raised: R. Jonah might add water to his wine as long as his cup was not of metal.</i>.
Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 51a" href="/Berakhot.51a">Babli (51a</a>) is in the name of R. Ḥiyya bar Abba. The inferences are not given there but they follow from the parallel to the next statement.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: The first generations asked whether the left hand may help the right hand with the cup used for reciting Grace. You may infer from this three things. You infer that one must hold the cup with his right hand<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">If the left hand only is required to help, the main action is done by the right hand.</i>, that one’s hand must be lifted from the table at least a hand-breadth<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">For a lesser height than a handbreadth (one sixth of a cubit), no help would be necessary.</i>, and that one has to look at the cup<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Otherwise, it would not be necessary to lift the cup during recital of the benedictions.</i>.
Rebbi Aḥa said: Three things were said about the cup of Grace: full, decorated, and washed. All three come from one verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 33:23" href="/Deuteronomy.33.23"><i>Deut.</i> 33:23</a>): “Naphtali is satiated with goodwill, full of the blessings of the Eternal.” Satiated - decorated<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">There are different lists in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 51a" href="/Berakhot.51a">Babli (51a</a>); one also mentions “decorated” and different interpretations are given. Rav Yehudah is reported to have surrounded himself with his students when he recited Grace over a cup of wine; Rav Ḥisda surrounded the (larger) cup of benediction with smaller cups that presumably were filled with wine. This second interpretation seems to be the one original with the Yerushalmi which identifies satiated with decorated, i. e., more than enough wine to fulfill every desire.</i>, goodwill - washed<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">So that everybody would willingly take the cup and drink from it. The Babli is a little more explicit and requires “rinsed and dried.”</i>, full as its acception. Rebbi Ḥanina said, if you did so, what is written there: “West and South his inheritance,” you merit to inherit this world and the world to come<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">This homily is given in the Babli in the name of R. Yose ben R. Ḥanina; R. Yoḥanan says that he is given boundless property. Both seem to note the incongruence of Naphtali inheriting West and South when in fact his territory was the North-Eastern corner of the Land of Israel. Hence, the allusion cannot be meant to describe his territory but is either a geographic amplification or refers to another world.</i>.
Rebbi Eleazar said: One does not recite benedictions on a damaged cup. If one tasted from it, he damaged it. You may infer from this three things. You infer that one does not recite benedictions on a damaged cup. And that it must contain a measure. And if one tasted from it, he damaged it<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Two of the three statements are exactly what Rebbi Eleazar said. The only inference to be drawn from the fact that the cup should not be “damaged” is that it must contain a minimum measure (a <i>reviït,</i> a quarter <i>log</i>) to be valid. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 105b-106b" href="/Pesachim.105b-106b">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 105b/106</a> a), the derivation is both from the argument given here and from a <i>baraita</i> about <i>Havdalah</i> after the Sabbath. The parallel argument would have been to derive the necessity of a minimal volume of wine from the next paragraph which implies that if one does not have enough wine for <i>Qiddush</i> both Friday night and Sabbath morning one leaves all the wine for the morning. Otherwise, one simply could divide the wine and drink the volume of a liquor glass each time. The order of topics here does not exclude that this also is the Yerushalmi reasoning.</i>.
Rebbi Tanḥum bar Yudan said: The honor of the day takes precedence over the honor of the night. The <i>Qiddush</i> of the night takes precedence over the <i>Qiddush</i> of the day. What is the honor of the day? Rebbi Yosi in the name of Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, and Rebbi Eleazar bar Joseph<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">An otherwise unknown student of Rav.</i> in the name of Rav: “He Who created the fruit of the vine.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">This means that the primary obligation of reciting <i>Qiddush</i> is in the night. The obligation of honoring the Sabbath is mainly during the day. Hence, if there is only one cup of wine, <i>Qiddush</i> of the night should be recited over bread. The <i>honor</i> of the day, referred to in the Babli euphemistically as “great <i>Qiddush</i>,” consists in reciting the benediction over wine only, without any additions, over a specially dedicated cup of wine. This is reported and endorsed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 106a" href="/Pesachim.106a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 106a</a>) as the action “of an old man,” confirming a Yerushalmi practice.</i>”
Rebbi Zeriqan, son of the father-in-law of Rebbi Zeriqan, mentioned Ḥanukkah in “the Land” and they praised him<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">It was stated in an earlier <i>baraita</i> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 7:4:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.7.4.2-5">Halakhah 5</a> that Ḥanukkah should be mentioned. Here, the place of the mention is fixed in the second benediction of Grace. The Babli (<i>Šabbath</i> 24a) concurs, but notes that the mention is not obligatory.</i>. Rebbi Abba, son of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, mentioned “the true Judge<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">The prayer in a house of mourning. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 46b" href="/Berakhot.46b">Babli (<i>Berakhot</i> 46b</a>) quotes a <i>baraita</i> in the name of Rebbi Aqiba which seems to imply that in a house of mourning the benediction “He Who is good” is replaced by “the True Judge”; the Talmud then reinterprets the <i>baraita</i> to mean that “the True Judge” is inserted in “He Who is good.” The Yerushalmi here gives a date for the re-interpretation.</i>” in “He Who is good and does good” and they praised him.
Rebbi Abba, son of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: If one eats walking, he stands still for Grace. If one eats standing, he sits down for Grace. If one eats sitting, he reclines<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">On a couch, as for a formal dinner. The statement, that for Grace one always increases one step in dignity, is reported in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 51b" href="/Berakhot.51b">Babli (51b</a>) as a <i>baraita</i> but is rejected. There it is declared that one always recites Grace sitting upright. There as here, this is the end of the Chapter; one has to see in the Babli an intentional answer to the Yerushalmi.</i> for Grace. If one eats reclining, he wraps himself in his toga<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>tallit</i> with <i>tzitzit.</i></i> for Grace. If one acts in this fashion, he is like an Angel of Service<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">The angels who serve the Divine Presence.</i>. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 6:2" href="/Isaiah.6.2"><i>Is.</i> 6:2</a>) “With two [wings] he would cover his face, and with two [wings] he would cover his feet.”

Chapter 8



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> These are the matters between the House of Shammai and the House of Hillel about meals. The House of Shammai say, one pronounces the benediction of the day<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Qiddush</i> of Friday night and holidays that has to precede the meal.</i> and then the one over wine. But the House of Hillel say, one pronounces the benediction over wine and aftewards the one of the day.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> What<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The entire section is paralleled in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 10:2:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.10.2.2-5">Yerushalmi <i>Pesaḥim</i> 10:2</a> (with a slightly better text). The content of this paragraph is paralleled in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 51b" href="/Berakhot.51b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 51b</a> and, in language very close to the Babli, in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:25" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.25">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i>5:25</a>. Both Babli and Tosephta add that “practice follows the House of Hillel,” a seemingly unnecessary statement since practice always follows the House of Hillel (except if noted otherwise.) It seems that the Tosephta is very old, from before the times of Rabban Gamliel. The Yerushalmi either suppressed the note that was no longer relevant or quotes another source which never had that statement.</i> is the reason of the House of Shammai? The Sanctification of the Day causes the wine to be served; he was obligated for the Sanctification of the Day<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Since there is a Biblical injunction (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:8" href="/Exodus.20.8"><i>Ex.</i> 20:8</a>): “Remember the Sabbath Day to declare it holy” and this obligation starts immediately at nightfall, whereas the meal is held later for technical reasons. The laws of <i>Qiddush</i> are discussed in Chapter 10 of <i>Pesaḥim</i> and reviewed in the author’s <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah,</i> pp. 209–227.</i> before the wine was served. What is the reason of the House of Hillel? The wine causes the Sanctification of the Day to be recited<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The Sanctification cannot be recited without food especially designated for the Sabbath. (However, <i>Qiddush</i> may also be recited over the Sabbath bread but this is not the preferred way, at least not in the Land of Israel where wine was and is abundant.)</i>. Another explanation: The wine is frequent, Sanctification is less frequent<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The principle of sacral actions is: The more frequent action (or benediction) has precedence. This is spelled out by the Babli here; Yerushalmi sources are: <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yoma 2:1:18-2:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yoma.2.1.18-2.9"><i>Yoma</i> 2:3</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Shekalim 8:4:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Shekalim.8.4.2-4"><i>Šeqalim</i> 8:6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 5:6:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.5.6.2-7"><i>Sukkah</i> 5:6</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 4:3:4-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.4.3.4-5"><i>Taäniot</i> 4:5</a>. The principle is implied by the Yerushalmi here. Both Houses have two reasons for their positions. Wine is more frequent since it is also used during weekdays and it may also be used for <i>Havdalah.</i></i>.
Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">He is R. Yasa (Assi), colleague of R. Mana I.</i> said: From the words of both of them<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The Houses of Hillel and Shammai.</i> it follows that for wine and <i>Havdalah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The “separation” between Sabbath and weekdays that has to be recited at the end of Sabbath. The obligation of reciting <i>Havdalah</i> starts at the very moment of nightfall.</i>, the wine comes first. Is not the reason of the House of Shammai that the Sanctification of the Day causes the wine to be served? But here, <i>Havdalah</i> does not cause the wine to be served<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Havdalah</i> may be recited over any alcoholic beverage (in the opinion of the Babli, over any beverage, other than water, that is common in the country.) <i>Qiddush</i> may be recited only over wine or possibly the Sabbath bread.</i>; wine therefore has precedence. Is not the reason of the House of Hillel that the wine is frequent, Sanctification of the Day is less frequent? Also here, wine is frequent and <i>Havdalah</i> is less frequent: the wine has precedence. Rebbi Mana said: From the words of both of them it follows that for wine and <i>Havdalah</i>,<i>Havdalah</i> comes first. Is not the reason of the House of Shammai that he was obligated for the Sanctification of the Day before the wine came? Also here, since he is obligated for <i>Havdalah</i> before the wine came, <i>Havdalah</i> has precedence. Is not the reason of the House of Hillel that the wine causes the Sanctification of the Day to be recited? But here, the wine does not cause <i>Havdalah</i> to be recited: <i>Havdalah</i> has precedence<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Havdalah</i> may be recited over any alcoholic beverage (in the opinion of the Babli, over any beverage, other than water, that is common in the country.) <i>Qiddush</i> may be recited only over wine or possibly the Sabbath bread.</i>.
Rebbi Zeïra said: One infers from the words of both of them<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yose and Rebbi Mana.</i> that one may make <i>Havdalah</i> without wine but one may not make <i>Qiddush</i> without wine<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Whereas the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 106b" href="/Pesachim.106b">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 106b</a>) allows one to make <i>Qiddush</i> over bread, at least in Babylonia where wine is hard to come by.</i>. That is the opinion of Rebbi Zeïra since Rebbi Zeïra said: One makes <i>Havdalah</i> on alcoholic beverages<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Any alcoholic beverage, including low grade beer. The opinion of the Babli is not clearly stated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 107a" href="/Pesachim.107a"><i>Pesaḥim</i>107a</a>), but the practice there is spelled out that any alcoholic beverage common in a country may be used for <i>Havdalah.</i> Current practice allows even non-alcoholic beverages, except water, as long as they are commonly used (<i>Oraḥ Ḥayyim</i> 296(2)).</i> but one goes from one place<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The physical exertion of the walk may interfere with one’s Sabbath rest but the duty to hear <i>Qiddush</i> recited over wine has precedence.</i> to another to hear <i>Qiddush.</i>
The Great Rebbi Yose said: Over there<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia.</i>, they have the custom that at a place without wine, the reader stands before the Ark<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">For a formal prayer, a kind of shortened repetition of the <i>‘Amidah.</i> Normally, evening prayers are communal without a reader.</i>, recites one benediction that contains seven<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The middle portion of the prayer by the reader contains allusions to all seven benedictions of the Sabbath <i>‘Amidah</i>: “(1) Shield of the Patriarch, (2) He Who revives the dead by His command, (3) the Holy God, (4) Who gives rest to His people, (5) before Him we shall serve (6) and give thanks to His name, God of thanksgiving, (7) Master of peace.” Today, the benediction is recited always except the first night of Passover when everybody is required to drink four cups of wine; thus, there is no reason to replace <i>Qiddush</i> by public prayer. In Babylonian sources, the benediction is not mentioned explicitly; in Medieval sources, a different reason is given for the benediction.</i>, and closes by “He Who sanctifies Israel and the Sabbath Day<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">This is the Israeli formula. The Babylonian one has only “He Who sanctifies the Sabbath,” probably because the Sabbath is a cosmic day of rest in contrast to holidays that exist only in Jewish history.</i>.”
It is difficult in the opinion of the House of Shammai, how to proceed on Friday evening if someone was sitting and eating on Friday afternoon, it got dark, and there was only one cup of wine<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">One returns to the discussion of the Mishnah. One may not start a meal Friday afternoon close to the Sabbath (Mishnah <i>Shabbat</i> 1:2) but one may start earlier and continue until nightfall. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 100a" href="/Pesachim.100a">Talmud (Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i>100a</a>, Yerushalmi <i>Pesaḥim</i> 10:1, fol. 37b) reports that R. Yehudah bar Illai requires one to stop before nightfall, but R. Yose bar Ḥalaphta lets him continue, and practice follows R. Yose. It is assumed here that even the House of Shammai will accept the position of R. Yose.</i>? You must say that he reserves the cup until after the recitation of Grace and includes all other benedictions. Obviously, if he would want to pronounce the benediction for the day, Grace has precedence<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Even if one continues, the Sabbath meal must be separate since eating on Sabbath is a religious obligation. Hence, Grace must be said for the preceding meal and, if one has wine, it must be recited over a cup of wine.</i>. If he wants to recite the benediction over wine, the day has precedence<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">According to the House of Shammai.</i>. One may infer this from the following (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 8:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.8.8.1"><i>Mishnah</i> 8:9</a>): “If wine was brought to them after the meal and there was only one cup.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">In that situation, the House of Shammai say that one starts Grace with the benediction over wine while the House of Hillel require the benediction for wine after Grace. It would seem that in our situation also, the wine could come before <i>Qiddush.</i></i>” Rebbi Abba said: Because it is a very short benediction, he might forget and drink<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">He might inadvertently drink from the wine after Grace without a benediction. This is a special situation and the House of Shammai will not agree to apply that Mishnah to it.</i>. But here, he connects everything with the cup of wine and he will not forget. How should he proceed according to the House of Shammai? He should recite Grace first, after that he makes <i>Qidddush,</i> and only after that he recites the benediction over the wine.
It is difficult in the opinion of the House of Hillel, how may one proceed at the end of the Sabbath if someone was sitting and eating on Sabbath, it got dark, and there was only one cup of wine? You say, he reserves it<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The cup of wine that should follow Grace and precede <i>Havdalah.</i></i> until after the meal and connects everything to it. What can you say? Shall he recite the benediction for the wine, Grace has precedence. Shall he recite Grace, the light has precedence<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">After the end of the Sabbath, one has to recite not only <i>Havdalah</i> but with it a benediction for man-made fire (that was forbidden on the Sabbath and now can be kindled anew) and spices (to make up for the loss of the intensified pleasure one derives from the Sabbath that now is being lost.) The invention of man-made fire is traditionally attributed to Adam at the end of his first Sabbath, see <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 8:5:5-9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.8.5.5-9">Halakhah 6</a>. The problem here is that one must make the benediction for the light as soon as one profits from newly lit fire.</i>. Shall he recite for the light, <i>Havdalah</i> has precedence. We may infer from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:30" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.30">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:30</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 52a" href="/Berakhot.52a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 52a</a>. In both of these sources, the House of Shammai is reported to require light before spices and the House of Hillel spices before light. R. Arieh Leib Yellin in his <i>Yephe Enayim</i> points out that the text of the Yerushalmi is consistent with all the inferences drawn here and in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 8:5:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.8.5.2-4">Halakhah 5</a>. Hence, there is a genuine difference in tradition between Galilee and Babylonia.</i>: “Rebbi Yehudah said, the house of Shammai and the house of Hillel do not disagree that Grace comes first and <i>Havdalah</i> at the end. They disagree only over light and spices because the House of Shammai say spices and afterwards light, but the house of Hillel say light and afterwards spices.” Rebbi Abba and Rav Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Two Babylonians, one an authority in Galilee, the other in Babylonia. They are responsible for enforcing uniformity in Jewish custom in both countries.</i>: Practice follows him who says spices and afterwards light. What should he do following the opinion of the House of Hillel? He should say Grace first, afterwards he should recite the benediction over wine and afterwards <i>Havdalah.</i>
A holiday that starts at the end of Sabbath. Rebbi Yoḥanan said YQNH, wine, <i>Qiddush</i>, light, <i>Havdalah.</i> Ḥanan bar Abba said in the name of Rav: Wine, <i>Qiddush</i>, light, <i>Havdalah, sukkah</i>, time<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">He agrees with Rebbi Yoḥanan but includes all possibilities that may be appropriate for a holiday. The benediction for time is: “He Who let us live, kept us, and let us reach this time.” This benediction is not recited on the last day of Passover. Hence, Rebbi Yoḥanan gives the minimal formula as pointed out in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 101b" href="/Pesachim.101b">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i>101b</a>).</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina said, NHYQ<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Light, <i>Havdalah,</i> wine, <i>Qiddush.</i> In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 102a" href="/Pesachim.102a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 102a</a>), this order is attributed to R. Joshua, the early highest authority who is given his full name, R. Joshua ben Ḥananiah. It is possible that this led to the substitution of “R. Joshua ben Levi” for “Samuel” in the following parable. However, Rashbam (R. Samuel ben Meïr), in his commentary to Babli <i>Pesaḥim,</i> quotes R. Ḥanina as requiring YNHQ, wine, light, <i>Havdalah, Qiddush.</i> But this is the undisputed order of Levi here who is described as taking a middle road between R. Ḥanina and R. Yoḥanan. The Venice print of the Yerushalmi has the impossible reading YNHYQ which is a confluence of the codes attributed to R. Ḥanina in the Babli and the Yerushalmi.</i>. Samuel follows the opinion of Rebbi Ḥanina since Rebbi Aḥa said in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Rashbam quotes “in the name of Samuel”. In the Babli, as mentioned earlier, this parable is from “R. Ḥanina illustrating the words of R. Joshua ben Ḥananiah.”</i>: A king<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">The king is the Sabbath and the subordinate prefect is the holiday; the Sabbath has to be mentioned first, including the light that belongs to the ceremony of Sabbath end, before making <i>Qiddush</i> for the holiday. Since holidays also give one spiritual ease, spices are not added at the end of a Sabbath that is the start of a holiday.</i> leaves and a prefect comes. One accompanies the king and only afterwards does one receive the prefect. Levi said YNHQ<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Wine, light, <i>Havdalah, Qiddush</i>; first the full <i>Havdalah</i> and then an appended <i>Qiddush.</i> In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 102a" href="/Pesachim.102a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i>102a</a>), Levi is reported as requiring QNYH, in opposition to everybody mentioned here.</i>. It seems that Levi says it both ways<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">He puts wine first following R. Yoḥanan and <i>Havdalah</i> before <i>Qiddush</i> following R. Ḥanina.</i>. Rebbi Zeïra asked before Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">R. Yasa (Assi) elsewhere. The Babylonian R. Zeïra inquired from the Tiberian R. Assi whether the practice in Galilee was identical with the Babylonian.</i>: What does one do in practice? He said to him: one follows Rav and Rebbi Yoḥanan. And so it became the practice following Rav and Rebbi Yoḥanan.
When Rebbi Abbahu went to the South<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The region of Lod, the only remaining Jewish settlement in Judea and the Southern plain. R. Abbahu lived in Caesarea and personally followed the rule of R. Ḥanina who always speaks in the name of the authority of Rebbi.</i>, he followed Rebbi Ḥanina. When he descended<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Tiberias is below sea level. From Caesarea Philippi (Banias) one has to descend, from Caesarea Maritima via Bet Sheän one would ascend.</i> to Tiberias, he followed Rebbi Yoḥanan in order not to disagree with anybody in his home town.
The opinion of Rebbi Ḥanina is understandable. It is difficult to understand Rebbi Yoḥanan: Does one not pronounce the benediction over the light at all other days that one should extinguish it<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Since the light is for celebration only; it is extinguished after <i>Havdalah.</i> The light for <i>Havdalah</i> is preferably a torch, but the light for a meal is from a lamp.</i>? And here, he makes the benediction over the light so that he should not extinguish it<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">On a holiday, one may light a fire (from an existing one) but one may not extinguish it. Hence, the light in our case is a light for the meal, not for <i>Havdalah,</i> and should precede <i>Qiddush</i> irrespective of the order of <i>Qiddush</i> and <i>Havdalah.</i> [In current practice, the wife lights the candles first with her own benediction and the husband then recites his benediction (after <i>Qiddush</i>) over the same lights.
