That does not seem to be reasonable. It may be assumed that R. Ḥanina requires either husband or wife to recite the first benediction over light.]</i>. How does Rebbi Yoḥanan handle this? Since he has wine<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">For a full meal for which the light is needed.</i>, his light will not go out. Then he might say the benediction over the light at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">When the light is really needed for the food.</i>. In order not to disturb its timing from other Sabbaths<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">To keep the order wine - (spices) - light - <i>Havdalah</i> as a matter of course.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The House of Shammai say that one washes his hands and after that he mixes the cup, but the House of Hillel say that one mixes the cup first and then he washes his hands<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The cup here is the <i>Qiddush</i> cup. <i>Qiddush</i> is followed by a meal with bread for which one must wash his hands. The details and reasons are spelled out in the Halakhah. This disagreement has nothing to do with the question whether one washes his hands before (following R. Moses Isserls) or after (following R. Joseph Caro) <i>Qiddush</i>; in both cases, the cup is filled before one washes his hands.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> What is the reason of the House of Shammai? The fluids on the back of the cup should not become impure from his hands and in their turn defile the cup<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The Biblical principles on ritual impurity are spelled out in the book of <i>Leviticus.</i> A Biblical source of impurity is called אב הטוּמאה “father of impurity”. The only possible objects of impurity are humans, vessels, and food. Any object that becomes impure secondarily, usually by contact, is “first in impurity.” For profane objects, the two stages are the only ones. However, by rabbinic tradition there exists a “second in impurity” for profane and “third, fourth” for certain holy objects. The general principle is that any transmitted impurity decreases by one degree. There is one important exception. Since body fluids of a person with gonorrhea are “fathers of impurity”, it was decreed that any impurity involving fluids is at least “first in impurity.” Also, unwashed hands are always assumed to be “second in impurity.” If one touches a dry cup with unwashed hands, nothing happens. But if there should be drops of wine on the outside of the cup, these drops will become “first in impurity” and defile the contents of the cup. It is the characteristic of Rabbinic (pharisaic) Judaism that one tries to eat one’s profane meals in a way reasonably consistent with rules of ritual purity. It seems that the House of Shammai assumes that a “full cup” required for <i>Qiddush</i> is full to the rim, kept together only by surface tension, and, hence, it is unlikely that the back of the cup will be dry. (For pottery vessels, other rules apply.)<br>The text of the explanation is from the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:26" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.26">Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 5:26</a>).</i>.
What is the reason of the House of Hillel? The back of the cup is always impure<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The back of the cup is impure (“second in impurity”) by Rabbinic decree, as explained in the next paragraph. If one washes his hands first and does not dry them very thorougly, then the hands will become “first in impurity” by holding the cup, as explained in the previous note, and one is worse off than with unwashed hands. (This is also the explanation of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 52a" href="/Berakhot.52a">Babli, 52a</a>.) The House of Hillel assume that a “full cup” is one filled close to the rim but leaving a reasonable safety margin as hedge against a spill.</i>. Another explanation: Washing of the hands should be as close as possible to the benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear whether the benediction in question is that over bread (R. Joseph Caro) or the wine for <i>Qiddush</i> (R. Moshe Isserls). Here also both explanations are from the Tosephta (<i>loc. cit.</i>)</i>.
Rebbi Vivan<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the third generation, student of all the great Amoraïm of R. Joḥanan’s generation. His name probably was Vivianus. In other quotes, his name is shortened to Bibi, Vivi.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: It turns out that the House of Shammai is consistent with Rebbi Yose and the House of Hillel with Rebbi Meïr<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">This is paradoxical since practice follows the House of Hillel and Rebbi Yose. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 52" href="/Berakhot.52">Babli (52a/b</a>) explains otherwise, that the Houses of Shammai and Hillel disagree on whether one may use a cup which is impure outside at all if one cares about consuming food in purity.</i>, since we have stated there (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Kelim 25:7" href="/Mishnah_Kelim.25.7">Mishnah <i>Kelim</i> 25:7</a>)<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 25 starts: “All vessels have an inside and an outside.” For earthenware vessels, it is a decree of the Torah that they become impure only if an impure “father of impurity” is found in the volume enclosed by the vessel (even without touching the walls,) never from the outside (even if the “father of impurity” touches the wall.) From this is derived a Rabbinic decree that also all other vessels, e. g. metal vessels that become impure from a biblical “father of impurity” by simple touch, cannot become impure inside if a Rabbinic impurity touches from the outside (but not vice versa.) <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 8:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.8.6.1">Mishnah 7</a> then reads: “All vessels have an outside, an inside, and a rim. Rebbi Tarphon said, [one speaks of] a large wooden trough, Rebbi Aqiba said, of cups. Rebbi Meïr said for impure and pure hands, R. Yose said, they spoke only about pure hands.” Since inside and outside have been discussed before, the opinions of Rabbis Meïr and Yose, students of R. Aqiba, deal with the rim, the part of the outside of the cup that is slightly bent outward or otherwise distinguished as place for the lips when one drinks from the cup. The explanation of the Mishnah is given in Tosephta <i>Kelim Baba bathra</i>3:9–10: “R. Meïr said: How is it for impure hands? If one’s hands are impure, the outside of the cup is pure; if it has moist spots then he may hold the cup by its rim without worry. R. Yose said: How is it for pure hands? If his hands were pure and moist, but the outside of the cup impure, then he may hold the cup at the rim without worrying that the moisture of his hand should become impure from the outside and then defile his hand.” It follows that for R. Yose, the hands have to be pure (i. e., washed) and for R. Meïr they may be impure.</i>: “Rebbi Meïr said, for impure and pure hands. Rebbi Yose said, they spoke only about pure hands.”
Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">He is R. Yasa (Assi).</i> in the name of Rebbi Sabbatai<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">An Israeli Amora of the first generation, student of Ḥizqiah the son of Rebbi Ḥiyya.</i> and Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba.</i> in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: For <i>ḥallah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ḥallah</i> is the gift for the Cohen from newly kneaded dough. It has the status of holiness of <i>Terumah</i>; hence, it has to be separated from the dough in purity which, in all cases, means also that in the Land of Israel one has to wash his hands before taking it. (All other countries are impure anyhow and their <i>ḥallah</i> must be burned.)</i> and for washing one’s hands<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">For any action for which the washing of one’s hands is required.</i>, he has to walk<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">If no water is available one has to wait, e. g., to eat bread, until he has washed his hands. If the distance to water is greater than 4 <i>mil</i> then the Babli declares in the name of the Galilean sages that one should clean his hands with sand or any other cleaning material.</i> up to four <i>mil.</i> Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Ḥanina: That is, going forward; but one does not bother him to return on his way<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 15a" href="/Berakhot.15a">Babli (15a</a>) has a different rule, that one has to return if the distance required is less than one <i>mil.</i></i>.
How does one treat watchmen in gardens and orchards, as before them, as after them<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Do they have to go up to four <i>mil</i> in search of water or may they clean their hands with sand or other cleansers?</i>? Let us hear it from this (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Challah 2:2:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Challah.2.2.4">Mishnah <i>Ḥallah</i> 2:3</a>): “A woman may sit down naked and separate her <i>ḥallah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Since the separation of <i>ḥallah</i> needs a benediction, it may not be done if one’s genitals are visible. A woman may hide her genitals by sitting down but a man cannot do that.</i> because she can cover herself, but a man may not.” Is that woman not sitting inside her house<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">And, presumably, has some clothes there that she could put on. The entire argument is possible only for the Yerushalmi which does not require any retracing of one’s steps at all in the search for water; it is impossible for the Babli which requires retracing one’s steps, if only for a reduced distance.</i> and you say that one does not bother her? Also here, one does not bother him<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">One does not bother him at all and if there is no water at his place, he need not leave it in his search for water.</i>.
It has been stated<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">The language is close to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:13" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.13">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:13</a>. Since the Mishnah introduces laws of washing one’s hands, the details are discussed from here on.</i>: “Water before the meal is conditional<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">In the language of the Babli, רשות means “permitted.” However, in the language of the Mishnah and the Yerushalmi, i. e., the language of the Land of Israel, רשות means “a minor obligation” as shown by S. Lieberman [תיקוני ירושלמי, <i>Tarbiẓ</i> 5 (5694), pp. 97–110]. The same language is found in the Tosephta, in <i>Tanḥuma Balaq</i> 15, and in other Galilean Midrashim. The <i>Tanḥuma</i> explains the expression “conditional” for something that is required, by “it is optional in the sense that if one decides not to eat bread with his meal, he does not have to wash his hands.”</i>, after the meal it is obligatory. Only that for the first one he takes and interrupts<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Most commentators explain this expression from the Mishnah <i>Yadayim</i>2:1–3 that rules, if one washed his hands with less than a <i>revi‘it</i> of water for each hand then he has to wash each hand twice. However, in that case it is not true that one may interrupt the washing because if he does not keep his mind concentrated on watching his hands they become impure again. As S. Lieberman points out, one might follow the interpretation of R. Isaiah I of Trani (<i>Pisqe RYD</i> on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 52a" href="/Berakhot.52a"><i>Berakhot</i> 52a</a>) that the Yerushalmi here stays with the previous topic of <i>Qiddush</i> and speaks of washing one’s hands twice, once for <i>Qiddush</i> for cleanliness and after that for food for ritual purity. This agrees with <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 4:8" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).4.8">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 4:8</a>, which requires the washing of one hand for the wine drunk as appetizer before a formal dinner.</i>; for the second he takes and may not interrupt<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Washing one’s hands after the meal is not a ritual requirement. Since spoons and forks were not used, the hands were dirty by necessity. Washing one’s hands after any meal involving sauces was a necessity for cleanliness (in the opinion of the Yerushalmi, later in this Halakhah) or for health reasons (in the opinion of the Babli). In any case, since no ritual impurity is involved, there is no required minimum volume of water and one does not have to repeat the washing.</i>.” What is: “He takes and interrupts”? Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said, he takes<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Takes water and pours it over his hands.</i> and repeats. Rebbi Samuel bar Isaac said<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in <i>Ḥallah</i> it reads: “Rebbi <i>Jacob</i> bar Isaac asked: …” This language is somewhat easier but the reading R. <i>Samuel</i> bar Isaac is better; since it refers to an Amora also otherwise known, there is no reason to cross out the word “said” here. In the Rome ms., the reading is: רבי שמואל בר יצחק את מימר דבעי ואת אמרת רשות “R. Samuel bar Isaac: You say that it is needed and you say that it is conditional?”</i>, I asked: “He takes and interrupts<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">In peremptory language.</i>” and you say it is conditional?
Rebbi Jacob bar Idi said: Because of the first<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The water used for washing one’s hands before the meal. The text is given in the name of Rav Dimi in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 106a" href="/Chullin.106a">Babli <i>Ḥulin</i> 106a</a>, the opinion of “some say” is ascribed there to Ravin (Rebbi Abin). The full story is in <i>Tanḥuma Buber Balaq</i> 24 [quoted also in <i>Tanḥuma Balaq</i> 15, <i>Bemidbar rabba Balaq</i> 2(20)]: In a time of persecution, when one could not show one’s Jewishness openly, a shopkeeper had both kosher and non-kosher food prepared. Since he could not ask his customers whether they were Jewish, he gave the kosher food to people who washed before eating bread and pig’s meat to customers who did not wash. When a man came in who did not wash his hands, he was taken for a Gentile and served non-kosher food. [For halakhic consequences of this story, see <i>Šulḥan ‘Arukh Yore Deä</i> 178, Note #4 of <i>Śifte Cohen.</i>]</i>, pork was eaten. Because of the second<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The washing of one’s hands after the meal. The story is told in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 83b" href="/Yoma.83b">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 83b</a> of a man who unlawfully kept a money-pouch that was deposited with him. He did not wash his hands, so the victimized person saw that he had eaten peas, went to the wife of the thief and told her that her husband wanted her to give him the pouch and as sign of recognition he told him to tell her that their last meal was peas. The wife then gave him back the money pouch. When the husband came back, he was so incensed that he killed his wife. It seems that the Yerushalmi has a first version in which the husband simply divorced his wife and in the second version he killed his wife, the intended victim, and himself. In the Yerushalmi source, <i>Tanḥuma Buber,</i> quoted above, the husband was not a thief, but he was the victim of a man who tricked the wife out of a precious ring by the identification of the food of his last meal.</i>, a woman had to leave her house; some say, three persons were killed.
Samuel went to visit Rav and saw him eating with his hands covered by cloth. He asked him, what is that<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">He thought that Rav did not wash his hands and used the cloth, which cannot become impure from one’s hands, to eat bread without incurring an obligation to wash. Samuel wondered, since that subterfuge is permitted only for people who would have to walk more than four <i>mil</i> to the next water source. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 107a" href="/Chullin.107a">Babli is <i>Ḥulin</i> 107a</a>.</i>? He answered him, I am asthenic<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">I washed my hands but am unable to eat without gloves.</i>. When Rebbi Zeïra immigrated here, he saw Cohanim eating with their hands covered by cloth<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Without washing their hands.</i>. He told them, was not that of Rav and Samuel explained away? Rebbi Yose bar bar Cahana<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">In the Rome manuscript, the name is R. Yose bar Huna Cahana. Neither of these names appears a second time; it is impossible to decide between the readings. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 107" href="/Chullin.107">Babli (<i>Ḥullin</i> 107a/b</a>), the name is Rav Taḥlifa bar Abime, a known student of Samuel.</i> came in the name of Samuel: Handwashing is for profane food<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">If someone wants to eat profane food “in the discipline of <i>terumah</i>,” he must wash his hands. While this washing is taken from the discipline of <i>terumah</i>, one opinion allows Cohanim to eat <i>terumah</i> without washing but wearing gloves since a Cohen knows that eating impure <i>terumah</i> is a deadly sin, so he will avoid any contact between his hands and the food. But for profane food where washing is simply a matter of discipline (although taken from the rules of <i>terumah,</i>) it cannot be circumvented, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 106a" href="/Chullin.106a">Babli <i>Ḥullin</i> 106a</a>.</i>, not for <i>terumah.</i> Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">He seems to be the Tanna R. Yose (ben Ḥalaphta.)</i> says, for <i>terumah</i> and for profane food.
Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, and Rebbi Jonah, and Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi in the name of Rav: Handwashing for <i>terumah</i> is to the wrist but for profane food it is to the finger joints. Maisha, the grandson of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said: If someone wanted to eat with my grandfather and he did not rinse his hands to the wrist, he would not eat with him<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 106" href="/Chullin.106">Babli <i>Ḥullin</i>106a/b</a>. Since R. Joshua ben Levi is a higher authority than Rav, practice in both Talmudim requires washing to the wrist also for profane food. The identification of פרק as wrist and קשרי אצבעות as the joint of fingers to the hand follows <i>Raviah</i> (R. Eliezer ben Joel Halevi), not Rashi and Tosaphot in their commentaries on the Babli.</i>.
Rav Huna said: Handwashing is only for bread. Rebbi Hoshaya stated: For anything getting dirty by a fluid<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">This is also reported in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 115a" href="/Pesachim.115a">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 115a</a> to explain why at the <i>Seder</i> ceremony one has to wash his hands before touching the vegetable that is to be dipped in fluid. For any sacred food like <i>terumah</i> or the Passover sacrifice, it is obvious that one has to wash his hands before touching fluids since the secondary impurity of hands causes primary impurity for the fluid. Hence, for the <i>Seder</i> it is only a question whether one should pronounce a benediction, as in the times of the Temple, or whether one washes his hands as a remembrance of Temple times. Here, the question is posed for everyday food, since handwashing for profane food comes from the “discipline of <i>terumah.</i>” Rav is of the opinion that the Rabbinic institution of handwashing applies only to bread whereas Rebbi Hoshaya requires handwashing for profane food in all situations where it would be required for <i>terumah.</i> In Antiquity, in the absence of spoons most foods in sauce were scooped up with pitta bread. Hence, the real difference between Rav and R. Hoshaya was in food handling as explained by R. Zeïra.</i>. Rebbi Zeïra said: Even when cutting lupines<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">They do not contain much sap.</i>, he used to wash his hands.
Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 106b-107a" href="/Chullin.106b-107a">Babli (<i>Ḥullin</i> 106b/107a</a>), Rav is quoted as requiring an explicit declaration to make the washing of the hands valid for the entire day and Rebbi Avina seems to restrict this to desert-like conditions where water is not easily found. The latter interpretation is then rejected by the Talmud. In the Yerushalmi it seems that Rav is reported to require only one washing per day and Rebbi Avina restricts it to people like donkey drivers who cannot easily find water. Since he is the Israeli authority, it may be presumed that the Yerushalmi prefers the interpretation that is rejected in the Babli.</i> said: If one washed his hands in the morning, one does not bother him in the evening. Rebbi Avina commanded the donkey drivers: If you find water to wash, wash your hands and condition them for the entire day.
Rebbi Zeïra went up to Rebbi Abbahu in Caesarea. When he met him he said: Come to eat. He [R. Abbahu] gave him a loaf to break and told him: Take it and recite the benediction. He [R. Zeïra] said to him: The householder knows best the qualities of his loaf. After they had eaten, he [R. Abbahu] said to him: Start and recite Grace. He [R. Zeïra] said to him: The rabbi knows Rav Huna who is a great man and he used to say that he who starts is the one who finishes<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel to this story is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 46a" href="/Berakhot.46a">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i> 46a</a>. There, the Babli adds that practice follows R. Joḥanan (in the name of R. Simeon bar Yoḥai) who declares that the head of the household should recite the benediction for the bread since he is the host but that the guest should recite Grace and add to it a public blessing for the host. Even though the two authors quoted are Israeli, it follows from the Yerushalmi here that the public blessing for the host was never accepted practice in Galilee.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rav Huna, as it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">A similar formulation is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:6" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.6">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:6</a> and a different one in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 46b" href="/Berakhot.46b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 46b</a>. It seems that the three texts represent three different traditions.</i>: “The order of washing of the hands<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Tahorot 4:11" href="/Mishnah_Tahorot.4.11">Mishnah <i>Ṭahorot</i> 4:11</a>: “In doubtful cases involving hands to become impure, to transmit impurity, or to be pure, they are declared pure.” Hence, since the House of Shammai agree that the entire matter is one of doubt, there is no problem since the hands of the person eating remain pure.</i>. Up to five persons, one starts with the most important personality. More than that, one starts with the least important one<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Since one cannot ask the V.I.P. to wait a long time between washing and breaking the bread. Once the hands are washed, one may not let his attention be diverted from them, otherwise he has to wash again.</i>. In the middle of the meal one starts with the most important one<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tosephta, this sentence does not refer to washing one’s hands at all, but to pouring wine. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 105" href="/Chullin.105">Babli (<i>Ḥullin</i> 105a/b</a>) quotes a <i>baraita</i> that declares washing of hands in the middle of the meal (between courses) to be voluntary; the exact halakhic meaning of this statement is in doubt.</i>. After the meal one starts with him who will recite Grace.” Does that not mean that he may prepare himself for reciting Grace<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 46b" href="/Berakhot.46b">Babli (46b</a>) brings a story that Rebbi asked Rav to wash his hands first, meaning that he should recite Grace aloud for the entire company. It follows that Rebbi emphatically denies the rule of Rav Huna that, as noted earlier, was never accepted in Babylonia.</i>? If you say that the one who starts is the one who finishes, he already is prepared! Rebbi Isaac said, explain it for those who come separately and do not know who will recite Grace.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The House of Shammai say, one dries his hands<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">After washing one’s hands for the meal.</i> with a towel and puts the latter on the table; the House of Hillel say, on the pillow.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> The Mishnah deals with a table of marble or one of parts screwed together that cannot become impure<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The House of Shammai can prefer the table over the pillow only if the table cannot become impure and, hence, not impart any impurity to the fluids on the towel. No vessel made of stone can become impure; that includes marble tables. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Kelim Batra 1:3" href="/Tosefta_Kelim_Batra.1.3">Tosephta (<i>Kelim Bava bathra</i> 1:10</a>) even states that a wooden table that contains a frame into which a marble table top is put cannot become impure since wooden implements become impure only if they enclose a volume and in this case the frame is filled with material that cannot become impure. The table whose legs are screwed in and can be unscrewed without tools is covered by the Tosephta (<i>loc. cit.</i> 1:11): “Restaurant chairs, even those having holes, that have their legs screwed in are permanently pure; if legs are fixed with a nail then they may become impure.” The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 52b" href="/Berakhot.52b">Babli (52b</a>) states that the House of Shammai will forbid the use of a table that is ritually unclean; both Babli and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:27" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.27">Tosephta (5:27</a>) note that the House of Hillel will never allow one to put the towel on the table because the fluid on the towel might touch the food and render it impure in the second degree (and by eating from it an amount greater than the volume of two eggs one’s body becomes impure in the second degree, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Tahorot 2:2" href="/Mishnah_Tahorot.2.2">Mishnah <i>Ṭahorot</i> 2:2</a>). The arguments of the Babli are incompatible with those of the Yerushalmi.</i>. What is the reason of the House of Shammai? That the fluids on the towel should not become impure from the pillow<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Since fluids in contact with primary or secondary impurity become a primary source of impurity and, while a human can become impure only from a “father of impurity”, his hands become secondarily impure from contact with primary impurity. The arrangement would be more logical if the order of these two sentences were inverted.</i> and in turn defile his hands.
What is the reason of the House of Hillel? In case of doubt, fluids and hands are considered pure<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Tahorot 4:11" href="/Mishnah_Tahorot.4.11">Mishnah <i>Ṭahorot</i> 4:11</a>: “In doubtful cases involving hands to become impure, to transmit impurity, or to be pure, they are declared pure.” Hence, since the House of Shammai agree that the entire matter is one of doubt, there is no problem since the hands of the person eating remain pure.</i>. Another explanation: “Hands” are not for profane food<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">The entire institution of secondary impurity for hands has no Biblical basis for profane food; it has been instituted following “the discipline of <i>terumah.</i>” Hence, there is no reason to follow strict rules in case of doubt since it is a principle that doubts regarding Rabbinic institutions must be resolved leniently.</i>.
Do the House of Shammai hold that “hands” are for profane food<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Given the explanation of the House of Hillel, they seem to presuppose that the secondary impurity of hands has a Biblical root. This is incredible.</i>? Explain it either following Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar or following Rebbi Eleazar, son of Rebbi Ẓadoq. Following Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar as it has been stated<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Tahorot 1:5" href="/Tosefta_Tahorot.1.5">Tosephta <i>Tahorot</i> 1:6</a> in the reading of Rabbenu Simson of Sens. In the printed editions and the Vienna manuscript, the reading is “hands are of primary impurity for sacrifices.” That reading is rejected by R. David Pardo in his commentary on the Tosephta. The statement is quoted several times in the Yerushalmi and also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 33b" href="/Chullin.33b">Babli <i>Ḥulin</i> 33b</a>. The interpretation here is that profane food can become impure only from the source of impurity or primary impurity. Hence, unwashed hands must be of primary impurity in order to influence profane food. In contrast, <i>terumah</i> becomes unusable if it was in contact with secondary impurity; hence, primary impurity causes the same result for profane food as secondary impurity for <i>terumah.</i> This seems to be the opinion of Maimonides (הלכוֹת אבוֹת הטוּמאה יא׃טו), who often is influenced by the Yerushalmi, also in <i>Ḥulin</i>; it is incompatible with Rashi’s interpretation of the text in <i>Ḥulin.</i> There it is stated that hands can become primarily impure only if held into the windows of a house afflicted with leprosy. That would not make a good reason for the House of Shammai.</i>: “Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar said in the name of Rebbi Meïr, hands are primarily impure for profane food and secondarily for <i>terumah.</i>” Or following Rebbi Eleazar, son of Rebbi Ẓadoq, as we have stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Tahorot 2:8" href="/Mishnah_Tahorot.2.8">Mishnah <i>Ṭahorot</i> 2:8</a>, quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chagigah 20a" href="/Chagigah.20a">Babli <i>Ḥagigah</i> 20a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 35b" href="/Chullin.35b"><i>Ḥulin</i> 35b</a>. Profane food can receive only primary impurity. <i>Terumah</i> can receive both primary and secondary impurity; the third stage is called “unusable” since it cannot be eaten, but it does not transmit the impurity further. Sacrifices become impure also in a tertiary way; only the fourth stage is “unusable.”</i>: “Profane food that was prepared under the rules of purity of sacrifices is still profane food. Rebbi Eleazar, the son of Rebbi Ẓadoq said, it is like <i>terumah</i> becoming impure in two stages and unusable in a third.”
There (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 4:6" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.4.6">Mishnah <i>Idiut</i> 4:6</a>) we have stated: “Someone who rubbed himself with pure oil, then he became impure, he descended<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">He descended into the <i>miqweh</i> for purification.</i> and immersed himself. The House of Shammai say, he is pure even if it<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">The oil was not washed off but is still on his body. Since his body is pure, so is the rubbing oil which became part of his body.</i> drips, but the House of Hillel say impure<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that they declare only the oil to remain impure, but one can also make the argument that the person remains impure since the water of the <i>miqweh</i> cannot touch his skin where it is covered by oil.</i>. But if the oil was impure to start out with, the House of Shammai say, up to the anointing of a small limb<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Both Talmudim (Yerushalmi <i>Šabbat</i> 8:1, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 77a" href="/Shabbat.77a">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 77a</a>) agree that “a small limb” is a small limb of a newborn. This is the maximum amount that can become pure by immersion of one’s body.</i>; but the House of Hillel say, moist fluid<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">It feels moist but does not transfer moisture to anything that touches it.</i>. Rebbi Yehudah says in the name of the House of Hillel, moist and making moist.” The opinions of the House of Hillel are reversed! There they say “impure” and here they say “pure.” There it is visible, here it is absorbed in the towel.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The House of Shammai say, one sweeps the house and after that one washes his hands<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">One sweeps the house if he ate sitting on the floor, or the table if he ate reclining on a couch. The washing of hands here is that after the meal; the problem of the House of Shammai is that spilled water from washing may spoil bits of food still lying around. The rule of the House of Hillel is optional; that of the House of Shammai is obligatory.</i>. But the House of Hillel say, one washes his hands and after that he sweeps the house.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> What<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 52b" href="/Berakhot.52b">Babli (52b</a>) and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:28" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.28">Tosephta (5:28</a>) speak only about morsels the size of an olive. The Tosephta also includes the reason given here for the House of Shammai in its text.</i> is the reason of the House of Shammai? Because of loss of food. But what is the reason of the House of Hillel? If the waiter is intelligent he removes the leftovers, even less than the volume of an olive; then one may wash his hands and after that sweep the house<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli and the Tosephta are unanimous that morsels smaller than the size of an olive may be deliberately spoiled; only larger morsels count as food and fall under the Biblical prohibition to destroy usable things. A second difference between Yerushalmi and Babli is that the Yerushalmi permits washing first if the waiter is intelligent; in Babli and Tosephta it is required that the waiter be learned.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The House of Shammai say: Light, Grace, spices and <i>Havdalah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Order of benedictions if the Sabbath meal extended until after nightfall when <i>Havdalah</i> is required in addition to Grace.</i>. But the House of Hillel say, Light, spices, Grace, and <i>Havdalah.</i><br>The House of Shammai say: “He Who created illumination by fire.” But the House of Hillel say, “He Who is creating illuminations by fire.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">There are two differences between the formulas of the two Houses for the benediction over the light at the end of Sabbath. For the House of Shammai, the creation is complete and in the past. For the House of Hillel, creation is a continuous process and comprises many kinds of light, including light created by human engineering that in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 54a" href="/Pesachim.54a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 54a</a>) is called “divine inspiration.”</i>”
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> It was stated: “Rebbi Yehudah said, the house of Shammai and the house of Hillel did not disagree that Grace comes first and <i>Havdalah</i> at the end. They disagree only over light and spices because the House of Shammai say spices and afterwards light, but the house of Hillel say light and afterwards spices.” Rebbi Abba and Rav Yehudah: Practice follows him who says spices and afterwards light<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">The entire paragraph was discussed in Halakha 1, fol. 11d.</i>.
The<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:29" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.29">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:29</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 43b" href="/Berakhot.43b">Babli 43b</a>. The text of the Tosephta manuscripts is close to the Yerushalmi. In the Babli and the traditional printed text of the Tosephta, the rôles of the Houses of Shammai and Hillel are reversed. The Babli starts: “When they brought to them oil and wine …” meaning that it was brought in the middle of the dinner for enjoyment. This is the opinion of R. Abraham ben David. According to Maimonides (<i>Berakhot</i> 7:14), wine and spiced oil were brought after dinner, to recite Grace over them. According to Rashi, this wine was brought after Grace had already been recited.</i> House of Shammai say, the cup in his right hand and perfumed oil<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">As an air freshener.</i> in his left hand; first he says the benediction over the cup and then over the perfumed oil. The House of Hillel say, perfumed oil in his right hand and the cup in his left hand, he recites the benediction over the perfumed oil and rubs it on the head of the waiter<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">To have some use for it since he must get rid of the perfumed oil in order not to walk around perfumed.</i>. But if the waiter was learned, he would rub it on the wall because it does no credit<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli is more explicit and calls it “a shame.”</i> to the learned to walk around perfumed.
Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">There is a parallel to this story in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezra 8" href="/Ezra.8"><i>Yalquṭ Šim‘oni Ezra</i> 1089(8</a>); there the names are Rebbi Abba and Rav Ḥuna. This is more reasonable, but there the names do not fit either since it says that Rav Huna insulted Rebbi Zeïra and Rebbi Abba told him to get up and serve. This is totally impossible since both Rebbis Abba and Zeïra were students of Rav Huna. On the other hand, the reading אבוי “his father” is impossible in the Yerushalmi since R. Abba bar bar Ḥana’s full name was R. Abba bar R. Abba bar Ḥana, which shows that he was a posthumous child and his father could not get angry with him. The most reasonable scenario is that R. Abba insulted the much younger R. Zeïra and R. Huna ordered them to switch places; but this has no manuscript evidence.</i> bar bar Ḥana and Rav Ḥuna were sitting down and eating and Rebbi Zeïra was standing and serving them. He came and carried both in one hand<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that Rebbi Zeïra knew the diverging traditions about the sayings of the Houses of Hillel and Shammai in this matter, as explained in the preceding paragraph, and, therefore, decided to circumvent all problems (since practice has to follow the House of Hillel) by carrying both wine and perfumed oil in one hand.</i>. Abba bar bar Ḥana said to him: Is your other hand cut off? His father got angry with him and said to him: “Is it not enough for you that you are reclining and he stands and serves? But in addition, he is a Cohen and you make fun of him when Samuel said that he who uses a Cohen commits larceny<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Meïlah,</i> the particular larceny committed in using Temple property for profane ends (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:14-16" href="/Leviticus.5.14-16"><i>Lev.</i> 5:14–16</a>).</i>. I order that he should recline and you get up and serve in his stead.” From where that he who uses a Cohen commits larceny? Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Samuel said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezra 8:28" href="/Ezra.8.28"><i>Ezra</i> 8:28</a>): “I said to them, you are holy and the vessels are holy.” Since one who uses the Temple vessels commits larceny, also one who uses a Cohen commits larceny!
According to the opinion of the House of Shammai, should one not say: “He Who created the fruit of the vine?” According to the opinion of the House of Hillel, one should say: “Creator of the fruit of the vine.”<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">There is no source that would even hint at the proposed formula of the House of Shammai. Hence, the House of Shammai will not insist on using the past in the benediction for wine.</i> Wine is new<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">With a different taste. Hence, the past would be inappropriate here.</i> every year; fire is not different every hour.
Fire and hybrids were not created in the six days of Creation but they were in the Divine plan of the six days of Creation<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:31" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.31">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:31</a>, as reason for the benediction over fire as will be explained later. In the Tosephta, R. Yose disagrees and says the fire of hell was created on the Second Day; in the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 54a" href="/Pesachim.54a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 54a</a>) hell and its fire precede the Creation. The Yerushalmi takes no position on this. The text of this and the following two sections are also in <i>Bereshit rabba</i> 82(17); there is a parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 54a" href="/Pesachim.54a">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 54a</a>.<br>As is normal in the Talmudim, a proposition of subjects A B is discussed in order B A.</i>. Hybrids (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 36:24" href="/Genesis.36.24"><i>Gen.</i>36:24</a>): “These are the sons of Ẓiv‘on, Ayyah and Anah. He is the Anah who invented the <i>yemim</i> in the prairie.” What is <i>yemim</i>? Rebbi Yehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Son of Rebbi Simon, an Amora of the third/fourth generation in Galilee, known as preacher.</i> ben Simon said ἡμίονος (“Half she-ass, mule”) and the rabbis say ἥμισυς (“half”), half horse and half donkey. These<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">This and the following sentence are redundant. The sentences are copied here from <i>Kil’aim</i> 8:3. The reading “R. Jonah” is from the Venice print in <i>Kil’aim,</i> the Rome manuscript here, and <i>Bereshit rabba.</i> There is no Amora who is called Rebbi Jehudah (reading of the Venice print and Leyden ms.) without mention of his father’s name. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 79a" href="/Chullin.79a">Babli (<i>Ḥullin</i>79a</a>), the criterion is ascribed to Rav Papa, fifth generation Babylonian Amora.</i> are its signs: Rebbi Jonah says, if it has small ears, its mother is a horse and its father a donkey. If they are large, its mother is a donkey and its father a horse. Rebbi Mana ordered those of the patriarch’s estate: If you want to buy a mule<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>mulus</i>,<i>i, m.</i> “mule”.</i>, you should buy one with small ears whose mother is a horse and whose father is a donkey.
What did<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">The text here is difficult. The parallel in <i>Bereshit rabba</i> has only "Anah" and is in the singular throughout, but here it starts with two persons but then in the middle of God's speech switches from plural to singular. One has to assume that there were two texts, one dealing only with Anah and the other with Ziv'on and Anah and that our text here is a confluence of both of them.</i> Ẓiv‘on and Anah do? He prepared a female donkey and mated her with a male horse; a mule came out from them. The Holy One, praise to Him, said to them: You brought into the world a harmful thing, I shall bring over that man something that will harm him. What did the Holy One, praise to Him, do? He prepared a snake and mated her with a Ḥardaun<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Arabic name of a large kind of lizard.</i>; a brightly colored snake<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Arabic حب “embellish, decorate”.</i> came out of them. Nobody will ever tell you that he was bitten by a brightly colored snake and survived, bitten by a rabid dog and survived, hit by a mule and survived (but only by a white female mule<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 7b" href="/Chullin.7b">Babli (<i>Ḥulin</i> 7b</a>) adds that the only mule that kills with its hoof is a white one even whose hoofs are white.</i>.)
R. Levi in the name of Bar Nazira<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Name from the parallel in the Midrash. The text here has ר׳ בזירה, an otherwise unknown person.</i>: Thirty-six hours did Man enjoy the light that was created on the First Day of Creation<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">The vanished light of the Creation is reserved for the just in the future world (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Chagigah 12a" href="/Chagigah.12a">Babli <i>Ḥagigah</i> 12a</a>). Psalm 139 is ascribed to David in the Book of Psalms, but in all of talmudic literature it is taken to describe the experiences of Adam.</i>, twelve on Friday, twelve in the night of Sabbath, and twelve during the day of Sabbath; in this light Adam saw from one end of the world to the other. In this unending light, the entire Creation started singing God’s praise as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 37:2" href="/Job.37.2"><i>Job</i> 37:2</a>), “All under the heavens sing to Him, His light is on the corners of the world.” When the Sabbath ended, darkness came. Adam was afraid that this was what was said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 3:15" href="/Genesis.3.15"><i>Gen.</i> 3:15</a>): “You will crush its head and it will crush your heel;” certainly it will crush me, so he said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 139:11" href="/Psalms.139.11"><i>Ps.</i>139:11</a>), “But the darkness will crush me.” R. Levi said: At this moment the Holy One, praised be He, let him find two flintstones that he knocked against each other<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 54a" href="/Pesachim.54a">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 54a</a>), the discovery of man-made fire is called “a heavenly inspiration.”</i> and made fire; that is what is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 139:11" href="/Psalms.139.11"><i>Ps.</i> 139:11</a>), “Now the night is light for me,” and he praised the Creator of the illuminating fire. Samuel says: Therefore we give praise for the [man-made] fire at the end of Sabbath because that was the time of its first production.
Rav Huna in the name of Rav, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: At the end of Yom Kippur one also recites the benediction since the light had rested all that day long<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">But, as noted in the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>), one does not recite the benediction over <i>newly lit</i> fire.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One does not recite a benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">For <i>Havdalah.</i></i> over a lamp and spices of Gentiles, or over lamp and spices for the dead<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Light and perfumes set before a casket.</i>, or over lamp and spices set before an idol. Also, one does not recite the benediction over a lamp unless he has profited from its light.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Jacob stated<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Not that he formulated it, but he quoted the tannaïtic formulation in the Yeshivah of R. Jeremiah.</i> before Rebbi Jeremiah: One recites a benediction over spices of Gentiles. How can he disagree? Uphold it for someone who burns spices in front of his store<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">He does it to attract customers, not for idolatrous practices. The reason of the original prohibition is that any perfuming by Gentiles is done for their idols.</i>.
One may make the benediction over a lantern even if it did not go out<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">This is the language of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:31" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.31">Tosephta (5:31</a>) following the Erfurth manuscript. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53a" href="/Berakhot.53a">Babli (53a</a>) has a slightly different formulation for the same statement. Since one permits a benediction over light that was burning at nightfall, the Tosephta must deal with the benediction after <i>Yom Kippur</i>.</i>. A lamp in his bosom or in a lantern<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Greek φανός, “torch, light”.</i> or in glass<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>specularia</i> “transparence; window panes, window (adj., plur. n.)”. This term is missing in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:31" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.31">Tosephta (5:31</a>) and the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53b" href="/Berakhot.53b">Babli (53b</a>).</i>, if he sees the flame and does not use its light, or uses the light but does not see the flame, one never recites the benediction until one sees the flame and uses the light.
Five<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Beitzah (Lieberman) 4:7" href="/Tosefta_Beitzah_(Lieberman).4.7">Tosephta <i>Beẓah</i> 4:7</a>. There is a similar <i>baraita</i> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Beitzah 29a" href="/Beitzah.29a">Babli <i>Beẓah</i> 29a</a> but it has no reference to <i>Havdalah.</i></i> things were said about burning charcoal and five about the flame. One commits larceny with the burning charcoal of the Temple; one may not use its flame but one cannot commit larceny with the latter<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Coal is a material, so if one takes it for unauthorized use he commits larceny. A flame is essentially immaterial; the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Beitzah 29a" href="/Beitzah.29a">Babli (<i>Beẓah</i> 29a</a>) declares the prohibition of its use as Rabbinic decree. The following cases all derive from the same principle.</i>. Burning charcoal of idolatry is forbidden, its flame is allowed. He who makes a vow not to use anything of another person may not use his burning charcoal but is allowed his flame. He who carries out burning charcoal into the public domain<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">On the Sabbath. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Beitzah 29a" href="/Beitzah.29a">Babli (<i>Beẓah</i> 29a</a>) discusses how one could possibly move the flame without the underlying coal.</i> is guilty but for the flame he is free of punishment. One makes the benediction over the flame but not over glowing charcoal. Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi in the name of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53b" href="/Berakhot.53b">Babli (53b</a>) this is a <i>baraita</i> which specifies explicitly that glowing but not crackling coals are not to be used for the benediction. [The title “Rebbi” in the text is again a scribal error.]</i>: If the charcoal was crackling one makes the benediction. Rebbi Yoḥanan from Karẓion<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora whose time cannot be determined since he appears only here. Karẓion is today’s Kaẓion in Upper Galilee; the reading קייציון of the Rome ms. might be better.</i> in the name of Rebbi Naḥum bar Simai: Only if [the flame] is jumping off<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">More or less this is the definition of “crackling.”</i>.
It was stated “A Gentile who lit from a Jew and a Jew who lit from a Gentile.<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:31" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.31">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:31</a>. The text continues: “One recites the benediction.” In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53a" href="/Berakhot.53a">Babli (53a</a>) there is a <i>baraita</i> that combines the two formulations of the Yerushalmi.</i>” One understands a Gentile who lit from a Jew<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Jew made new fire after the end of Sabbath. Similarly, one considers the act of lighting a fire from the existing fire of a Gentile as creation of a new light by a Jew after the end of Sabbath. But a Gentile lighting from a Gentile cannot do this since he never had a moment when making a fire was forbidden to him.</i>, but then even a Gentile who lit from a Gentile? It was found that it was stated: “One does not recite the benediction if a Gentile [lit] from a Gentile.”
Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: A dead end street of Gentiles and one Jew lives in it, if light comes from there one recites the benediction because of the one Jew who is there<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">If the one who sees the light knows the Jew living there.</i>. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: One does not recite the benediction on the spices<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, here one does not speak about <i>Havdalah</i> but about the benediction that is required for the enjoyment of perfume. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53a" href="/Berakhot.53a">Babli (53a</a>), R. Joḥanan is more explicit and says that these perfumes are burned to disinfect clothes; hence, they are not produced for human enjoyment.</i> of Friday afternoon in Tiberias, nor on the spices of Sabbath night of Sepphoris, nor on light<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">The mention of light here makes no sense, but it is found in both mss.</i> and spices of Friday Eve in Sepphoris, because they are for other purposes.
“Nor over lamp and spices for the dead.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah.</i>” Rebbi Ḥizqiah and Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Yose, son of Rebbi Ḥanina: That is, if they are put at the head of the bier. But if they are put in front of the bier one may recite the benediction; I say they are put there for the honor of the living<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">The reason that one may not recite the benediction over perfumes and light arranged for the deceased is that one may not have any use from things given to the dead. But if they are arranged for the convenience of the living who are paying their respects, one may use them for a benediction. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53a" href="/Berakhot.53a">Babli (53a</a>) has another definition: Light burning only in the night is acceptable; that which burns day and night is not.</i>.
“Nor over lamp and spices set before an idol.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah.</i>” Is not that of Gentiles identical<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Why are light of idolatry and light of Gentiles mentioned as separate items in the Mishnah?</i> with that of idolatry? Explain it with the idol of a Jew.
“Also, one does not recite the benediction over a lamp unless one has profited from its light.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Quote from the Mishnah.</i>” Rebbi Zeïra, the son of Rebbi Abbahu, preached: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:4" href="/Genesis.1.4"><i>Gen.</i> 1:4</a>) “God saw the light that it was good” and after that, “God separated between the light and the darkness.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>imitatio Dei,</i> one should not make <i>Havdalah</i> until he saw the light and that it is useful. The same paragraph is found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 3:7" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.3.7"><i>Bereshit rabba</i>3(7</a>) in slightly more explicit language.</i>”. Rebbi Berekhiah said: The following was preached by the two greats of the world, Rebbi Yoḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: “God separated,” a true separation. Rebbi Yehudah, the son of Rebbi Simon, said: He separated it for Himself<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">That this is the light of the <i>Shekhinah.</i></i>. But the rabbis say, He separated it for the just in the future world. They gave a parable, to what can this situation be compared? To a king who had two generals<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Greek (sing.) στρατηγός.</i>; both of them said: “I want to command during the day.” He called the first one and told him: day shall be your domain. He called the second one and told him: night shall be your domain. That is what is written: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:5" href="/Genesis.1.5"><i>Gen.</i> 1:5</a>) “God called the light ‘day’, etc.” To the light he said: day shall be your domain; but to the darkness he said: night shall be your domain. Rebbi Yoḥanan said, that it is which the Holy One, praise to Him, said to Job: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 38:12" href="/Job.38.12"><i>Job</i> 38:12</a>) “Did you ever command the morning, did you inform the morning of its place?” Do you know the place where the light of the Six Days of Creation was hidden? Rebbi Tanḥuma said: I shall give its reason. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 45:7" href="/Isaiah.45.7"><i>Is.</i> 45:7</a>) “He Who fashioned the light and created darkness, He makes peace.” When it left<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Bereshit rabba</i>: “From the moment that they were created, He is making peace.”</i>, it made peace between them.
“One does not recite the benediction over a lamp unless one has profited from its light.” Rav says <i>y</i><sup class="footnote-marker">e</sup><i>’utu</i>, and Samuel says <i>y</i><sup class="footnote-marker">e</sup><i>‘utu</i><sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Under the influence of Accadic, Babylonian Jews early on had lost the difference between <i>aleph</i> (’) and <i>ayin</i>(‘) (and <i>he, ḥet</i>); they re-acquired the differences only later under the influence of Arabic. Similarly, under the influence of Greek, in the speech of most Galileans also <i>aleph</i> and <i>ayin</i> had become silent. Since the Mishnah was transmitted orally, there was no difference in pronunciation between the two silent consonants and the interpretation of the words depended on whether one was imagining one or the other.<br>The particular case here is not discussed in the Babli. The examples from <i>Eruvin</i> and <i>Avodah zarah</i> are discussed following these Mishnayot in the Babli where at other places one also finds examples of a silent ח (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Beitzah 35b" href="/Beitzah.35b"><i>Beẓah</i>35b</a>) and switches between ס (s) and צ (ss) (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 116b" href="/Bava_Kamma.116b"><i>Bava qama</i> 116b</a>). In most cases, roots of Rabbinic expressions are sought in Biblical Hebrew.</i>. He who says <i>y</i><sup class="footnote-marker">e</sup><i>’utu</i>, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 34:15" href="/Genesis.34.15"><i>Gen.</i> 34:15</a>) “But with this we shall be agreeable (<i>nē’ôt</i>) to you.” He who says <i>y</i><sup class="footnote-marker">e</sup><i>‘utu</i>, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 50:4" href="/Isaiah.50.4"><i>Is.</i> 50:4</a>) “To know, to inform (<i>lā</i>‘<i>ût</i>) the weary of wisdom.” There (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Eruvin 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Eruvin.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Erubin</i> 5:1</a>) we have stated: How does one complete cities<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">“Completion” is the determination of a rectangle oriented NS, EW whose edges are distant 2000 cubits from the last house of the city in that direction.</i>? Rav says <i>m</i><sup class="footnote-marker">e</sup><i>’abb</i><sup class="footnote-marker">e</sup><i>rin,</i> and Samuel says <i>m</i><sup class="footnote-marker">e</sup><i>‘abb</i><sup>e</sup><i>rin.</i> He who says <i>m</i><sup>e</sup><i>’abb</i><sup>e</sup><i>rin,</i> one adds a limb (אבר) to it. And he who says <i>m</i><sup>e</sup><i>‘abb</i><sup>e</sup><i>rin,</i> like a pregnant (עוברה) woman. There (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Avodah Zarah 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Avodah_Zarah.1.1.1">Mishnah <i>Avodah Zarah</i> 1:1</a>) we have stated: Before the holidays of the Gentiles<sup>159</sup><i class="footnote">One may not trade with them.</i>. Rav says <i>‘êdêhen</i> and Samuel says <i>’êdêhen.</i> He who says <i>’êdêhen</i>, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 32:35" href="/Deuteronomy.32.35"><i>Deut.</i> 32:35</a>) “For the day of their misfortune (אידם) is near.” He who says <i>‘êdêhen</i>, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 44:9" href="/Isaiah.44.9"><i>Is.</i>44:9</a>) “They<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">The idols. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 2a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.2a">Babli (<i>Avodah zarah</i> 2a</a>), the interpretation of this verse takes up several pages.</i> are their witnesses (עידיהם), may they neither see nor know, so that they may come to naught.” How does Samuel deal with Rav’s reason? They are their witnesses, in the future they will bring to naught their worshippers on the day of judgment.
“One does not recite the benediction over a lamp unless he has profited from its light.” Rav Yehudah in the name of Samuel: So that women would be able to spin by its light. Rebbi Yoḥanan said: So that his eye should see what is in the cup or in the bowl. Rav Ḥinena said, so that he should be able to distinguish between two coins<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Rav Yehudah is the most restrictive, following the old Babylonian custom. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53b" href="/Berakhot.53b">Babli (53b</a>) there are two opinions, both by early Galilean authorities; so it seems that R. Ḥinena, the student of R. Yoḥanan, is referring to earlier statements. In the opinion of Ulla, one must be able to distinguish between an <i>as</i> (1/24 <i>denarius</i>) and a <i>dupondius</i> (1/12 <i>denarius</i>); in the opinion of Ḥizqiah, one has to distinguish between local coins of the same weight and value but different mints. Since R. Ḥinena is the student of R. Yoḥanan, it seems that he is following Ulla’s opinion.</i>.
Rebbi Oshaia stated: Even if it was a banquet hall of ten by ten<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Since the <i>triclinium</i> is a banquet hall in the Roman style, the “ten” probably are not Jewish cubits but Roman <i>passus</i>, of 4.5 feet each. Then the distance from a light kindled in one corner to the observer in the corner diagonally opposed would be about 67 feet; based on cubits it would be 48 feet, still a great distance in an otherwise dark room.</i>, one recites the benediction. Rebbi Zeïra went close to the light. His students told him: Why does our teacher make it so difficult for us, did not Rebbi Oshaya formulate: “even if it was a banquet hall of ten by ten, one recites the benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53a" href="/Berakhot.53a">Babli (53a</a>), R. Zeïra is quoted that originally he insisted on making the benediction over his own light (following an old Babylonian custom), but that he changed his opinion after hearing that great authorities allow one to make the benediction even over fire lit by other people in their houses, as explained earlier in this Halakhah. That report must date from the time when he visited Babylonia after becoming head of his own Yeshivah in Galilee.</i>?”

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He who ate, forgot, and did not recite Grace. The House of Shammai say, he should return to his place<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">The place of the meal.</i> and recite. The House of Hillel say, he should recite at the place where he remembers it. How long<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">After the end of the meal, so that he should not by guilty of disregarding a biblical commandment.</i> may he recite? Until the food is digested in his bowels.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Justus bar Shunem<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">A late Amora, student of Rebbi Mana II.</i> said: Two Amoraïm, one proposed the reason of the House of Shammai and the other proposed the reason of the House of Hillel. He who proposed the reason of the House of Shammai: If he had forgotten there a wallet full of precious stones and pearls, would he not go back and retrieve his wallet? Here also, let him return to his place and recite Grace. He who proposed the reason of the House of Hillel: A worker who worked at the top of a date palm or at the bottom of a cistern, would one bother him to return and recite Grace? No, he should recite at the place where he remembers. So here also, he should recite at the place where he remembers<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">In the formulation here, it is agreed that a worker at a dangerous place does not have to return (a) to expose himself to unnecessary danger and (b) to spend unproductive time at the expense of his employer who is required to pay his entire day. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53b" href="/Berakhot.53b">Babli (53b</a>), the entire discussion is a <i>baraita</i> and the argument of the House of Hillel precedes that of the House of Shammai. Hence, its implication is that the House of Shammai require the worker to return to his dangerous place and his employer to pay for the time lost. In this case, it seems that the Yerushalmi reports a deliberate change from earlier practice in order to embody a change in labor law.</i>.
How long may he recite? Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Samuel, until the food in his bowels is digested. But the sages say, all the time that he is thirsty because of that meal<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Presumably, if he did not drink during the meal.</i>. Rebbi Yoḥanan says, until he gets hungry again<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53b" href="/Berakhot.53b">Babli (53b</a>) quotes R. Yoḥanan as is he quoted here and attributes the statement of the Sages (that would guide practice here) to R. Simeon ben Laqish, whose opinion carries less weight than that of R. Yoḥanan. Another statement of R. Simeon ben Laqish, who gives as maximum the time it would take to walk four <i>mil</i>, 1 hour 12 min., has no parallel in the Yerushalmi. The difference between the Galilean יתאכל and the Babylonian יתעכל is dialectal; the Babylonian Mishnah has יתעכל. Since Samuel was a medical doctor, his explanation “until the food was digested” may have been practical for him; it certainly is not practical for everybody else. It is therefore not necessary to say that R. Yoḥanan is more restrictive than the Mishnah (as is the opinion of the student of Rabbenu Jonah in his commentary on Alfassi.)</i>.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If wine was brought to them after the meal and there was only one cup. The House of Shammai say, he recites the benediction over wine and afterwards says Grace, but the House of Hillel say, he recites Grace and afterwards the benediction over wine. One answers “Amen” after a Jew but one does not answer “Amen” after a Samaritan unless one has heard the entire benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Samaritan follows a non-standard form of Judaism, one may not answer after his benediction unless one has ascertained that his benediction is compatible with our rules.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Abba said: Because it is a very short benediction, he might forget and drink<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">While Grace should be recited over an untouched cup of wine, in the opinion of the House of Shammai this does not apply here; see the start of Halakhah 1. The next sentence belongs only there (Note 23); it was copied here by mistake.</i>. But here, he connects everything with the cup of wine and will not forget.
Hence<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">This is implied by the last sentence of the Mishnah.</i>, one answers “Amen” after a Jew even though one did not hear. Did we not formulate: If he heard<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Any of the obligatory prayers (if he himself is unable to recite them, or under the conditions discussed in the next paragraph) or benedictions may be performed by listening to an equally obliged person.</i> but did not answer, he did his duty. If he answered but did not hear, he did not do his duty. Ḥiyya, the son of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">The only known son of Rav, who had the best of Rav’s students as teachers; hence, he must have been born to Rav rather late in his life. After the death of Rav, he was a student of Samuel. He is usually quoted without any title (maybe he did not want to be addressed with a title that was the commonly used nickname of his father) but it is known that he acted in a Rabbinical capacity. He had a son who also was a scholar.</i>, said: when he did not eat with them the volume of an olive<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">He answers: “Amen” for the benediction but not in order to fulfill his own obligation. The parallel, without the question asked, appears in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53b" href="/Berakhot.53b">Babli 53b</a>.</i>.
Here<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is a copy of the corresponding one in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 3:10:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.3.10.2-6"><i>Sukkah</i> 3:12</a>; “here” refers to the discussion of <i>Hallel</i> in that tractate. The entire paragraph deals with the recitation of <i>Hallel</i>; the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 38b" href="/Sukkah.38b">Babli is <i>Sukkah</i> 38b</a>.</i>, a <i>baraita</i> states: “If he heard but did not answer, he did his duty. If he answered but did not hear, he did not do his duty.” Rav in the name of Abba bar Ḥana<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">A cousin of Rav who studied with him under their common uncle R. Ḥiyya. In contrast to Rav, Rebbi Abba bar Ḥana did not return to Babylonia permanently. In the Babli, the statement is reported in the name of Rav’s son-in-law Rav Ḥanan bar Abba.</i>, or, as some say, Abba bar Ḥana in the name of Rav, that is only if he answered the beginnings of chapters. Rebbi Zeïra inquired, what are beginnings of chapters? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 113:1" href="/Psalms.113.1"><i>Ps.</i> 113:1</a>) “Hallelujah, praise, you servants of the Eternal, praise the name of the Eternal.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Neither here nor in the Babli is it clear whether “headings” means only the first sentence of <i>Hallel</i> or the first sentence of every Psalm to be recited; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Sukkah 38b:2:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Sukkah.38b.2.1">Tosaphot <i>Sukkah</i> 38b, <i>s. v.</i> מכאן</a>.</i>” They asked before Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, from where do we know that if somebody heard but did not answer, that he fulfilled his duty? He said, because we see great rabbis acting accordingly. They stand in the congregation where some say (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 118:26" href="/Psalms.118.26"><i>Ps.</i> 118:26</a>): “Blessed he who comes,” and the others say: “in the name of the Eternal,” and all have fulfilled their duty<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, it is unnecessary in the recitation of Psalms or synagogal poetry that in responsively recited pieces everyone should pronounce everything; the practice given here is also endorsed by the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 38b" href="/Sukkah.38b">Babli (<i>Sukkah</i> 38b</a>) and is accepted in most Jewish groups.</i>.
Rebbi Oshaya stated: One answers “Amen” even if he did not eat<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">This is the rule formulated by Ḥiyya bar Rav. The second rule was illustrated by R. Simeon ben Shetaḥ and king Yannai, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 7:2:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.7.2.2-7">Halakhah 7:2</a>.</i>, but he may not say: “Let us bless Him, of Whose bounty we ate,” except if he did eat.
It is stated<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Megillah (Lieberman) 3:27" href="/Tosefta_Megillah_(Lieberman).3.27">Tosephta <i>Megillah</i> 3:27</a>, also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 47a" href="/Berakhot.47a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 47a</a>.</i>: “One answers neither an orphan Amen, nor a plucked<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Amen not completely pronounced.</i> Amen, nor a hurried Amen. Ben Azai said, if one answered an orphan Amen, may his children be orphans; hurried, may the end of his days be hurried; plucked, may his soul be plucked off. For a long Amen, they lengthen his days and years in a good way.” What is an orphan Amen? Rav Huna said, that is one who sits to recite a blessing, he answers Amen, and is not conscious for what he answered Amen.
It is stated: One answers Amen after a Gentile who recited a benediction for the Eternal, [but if he recited a benediction with the Name one does not answer<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">The text in parenthesis is from the Rome manuscript; it seems that it is missing from the Leyden manuscript and the Venice print because here also, the final clause “one answers only if one heard the entire benediction” is missing since it is implied by the Mishnah. The complete text is that of most sources of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:21" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.21">Tosephta (<i>Berakhot</i> 5:21</a>). The correct interpretation seems to be that given by R. Saul Lieberman in <i>Tosephta kifshutah</i>: Since the Gentile is not subject to our rules, if he praises the Eternal, one answers after him Amen. But if he uses a Jewish formula, one may not answer after him Amen unless one has ascertained that he conformed with our rules.</i>.] Rebbi Tanḥuma said, if a Gentile blesses you, answer after him Amen since it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 7:14" href="/Deuteronomy.7.14"><i>Deut.</i> 7:14</a>) “You shall be blessed by all peoples.” A Gentile met Rebbi Joshua and blessed him. He answered: The word about you has already been said. He met a second one who cursed him; he answered: The word about you has already been said. His students said to him: Rebbi, did you say to the one what you said to the other? He said to them, so it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 27:29" href="/Genesis.27.29"><i>Gen.</i> 27:29</a>): “Those who curse you are cursed, but those who bless you are blessed.”

Chapter 9



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He who sees a place where wonders were done for Israel, says: Praise to Him<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In all these Mishnayot, “Praise to Him” stands for “Praised are You, Eternal, our God, King of the Universe, Who …</i> Who did wonders for our forefathers at this place.<br>At a place from which paganism was uprooted<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">While there are numerous verses declaring Israel as His people, it belongs to the style of a sermon to close with a verse promising a better future. The quote may indicate that עם should be translated as “relative”; this is the meaning attributed to the root in theophorous names.</i>, one says: Praise to Him Who uprooted paganism from our Land.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> The Mishnah deals with wonders of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pne Mosheh</i> (Margalit) notes that probably “Israel” here means “more than 50% of all of Israel” as in other circumstances.</i>. But for wonders of a single person that happened to him<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Happened to that single person, not to the person who passes by the place.</i>, one does not have to recite a benediction.
Does one have to recite a benediction for the wonders that were done for his father or his teacher<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">From the question it follows that a person who had a miraculous escape from danger must recite the benediction (“Who did wonders for me at this place.”) This is explicit in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 54a" href="/Berakhot.54a">Babli (54a</a>).</i>? Or if he was a famous person like Joab ben Ẓeruiah and his companions? Or a man through whom the Name of Heaven was sanctified, for example Ḥananiah, Mishael, and Azariah<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">This is the text of the Leyden manuscript and the Venice print; in this version, only the last question has an answer, all others are left dangling. However, <i>Rosh</i> [Rabbenu Asher ben Yeḥiel] has a different reading: “Does one have to recite a benediction for the wonders that were done for his father or his teacher? Or if he was a famous person like Joab ben Ẓeruiah and his companions? Or a man through whom the Name of Heaven was sanctified, for example Daniel and his companions? He recites a benediction.” In this version, all questions are being answered and the next sentence starts a new paragraph. <i>Rosh</i> also quotes from Rav Hai Gaon a reading in the Babli, referring to the previous paragraph, that for a miraculous escape a man, his son, and his grandson have to recite the (appropriate) benediction.</i>? About wonders done for one of the tribes?
