According to him who said<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yehudah and Rebbi Simeon in <i>Horayot</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:3:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.3.2-3">Yerushalmi 1:6</a>, fol. 46a; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 5b" href="/Berakhot.5b">Babli 5b</a>). The opposite opinion is that of Rebbi Meïr.</i> that each tribe is called “assembly”, one has to recite the benediction; but according to him who said that only all tribes together are called “assembly”, one does not have to recite the benediction.
He who sees Babylon has to recite five benedictions<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli (57b), this is a sermon of Rav Hamnuna, in a slightly different order. In travel reports of Medieval travelers, it is reported that the ruin labelled “house of Nabucadnezzar” is outside of the ruins of the main wall, confirming the order of the Yerushalmi against the Babli.</i>. If he sees the Euphrates, he says: “Praise to Him Who made the Creation.” If he sees a (statue of) Mercury<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">According to both Talmudim, in the Eastern provinces of the Roman Empire, a Hermes (or Mercury) could be simply a heap of stones to which passers-by added in order to show their respect. [Note Greek ἑρμολογέω (τάφον) “build with loose stones (grave)” (E. G.)]. The benediction refers to the fact that God allows idols to exist; the Hermes is singled out since it was ubiquitous at intersections of roads.</i>, he says: “Praise to Him, Who is patient.” If he sees the house of Nabucadnezzar, he says: “Praise to Him, Who destroyed the house of that evil one.” If he sees the fiery oven<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Traditionally shown at Babylon even though the story in Daniel is set in the valley of Dura. This sentence confirms the reading of the Rome manuscript in the previous paragraph, that all questions asked were answered positively.</i> or the lions’ den, he says: “Praise to Him, Who did wonders for our forefathers at this place.” If he sees a place from which one takes dust<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., uses old Babylon as a quarry. The decrees referred to which are upheld are the prophecies of doom pronounced over Babylon in the books of Isaiah and Jeremiah.</i>, he says: “Praise to Him, Who pronounces and does, decrees and upholds.” If one sees Babylon, he says (<i>Is.</i> 14:23): “I shall sweep her out with the broom of destruction<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli it is told that Mar, son of Ravina, a colleague of Rava in the fourth generation, when he visited the ruins of Babylon, collected some dust and recited the verse from Isaiah. It seems that he followed a Yerushalmi custom.</i>.”
Rebbi Zeïra and Rebbi Yehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Since he is mentioned after Rebbi Zeïra, he must be Rebbi Yehudah Neśia, Patriarch and grandson of Rebbi.</i> in the name of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 40b" href="/Berakhot.40b">Babli (40b</a>), Rav is reported to have said that no benediction is valid without mention of the Name (YHWH), and Rebbi Yoḥanan notes that, in addition, the Kingdom must be mentioned. [The formula for the Kingdom: “our God, King of the Universe,” probably was introduced to counter Christian ideas that God’s kingdom is not of this world.] In addition, Abbaye notes in the Babli that Rav will not require R. Yoḥanan’s addition. The formulation of the Yerushalmi shows that in Galilee, they interpreted the statement of Rav that one is required to say “You” to mean that one has to say “You, o Eternal,” since in adressing somebody in the second person one must specify the adressee. Hence, the statement of R. Yoḥanan in the Babli was meant as clarification of Rav’s statement, not a new requirement; it does not have to be mentioned since Rebbi Yoḥanan would disclaim any originality. Only in Babylonia they adopted a narrow interpretation of Rav’s words. [In practice, reference to the Kingdom is required only for benedictions that either stand alone or start a series of benedictions.]</i>: Any benediction without mention of the Kingdom is no benediction. Rebbi Tanḥuma said, I shall give the reason (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 145:1" href="/Psalms.145.1"><i>Ps.</i> 145:1</a>): “I shall elevate You, my God, o King!” Rav said, one has to say “You,” but Samuel said, one does not have to say “You<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">A practical reminder of Samuel’s opinion is the formula of Grace for people who are too ignorant to pray in Hebrew: “Praised be the All-merciful, Owner of this bread.”</i>.”
Rebbi Yoḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The Rome ms. has “R. Ḥanina” and that must be the correct reading since R. Yoḥanan belongs to the generation after R. Jonathan but R. Ḥanina (the Amora) was an older colleague of R. Jonathan and should be mentioned first.</i> and Rebbi Jonathan went to make peace in the Southern settlements. They came to a place where they found the reader saying<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In the first benediction of the <i>‘Amidah</i>. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 33b" href="/Berakhot.33b">Babli (33b</a>) is in the name of R. Ḥanina only who notes there that the three attributes we mention are only permitted because Moses used them in the Torah and the Men of the Great Assembly adopted them for prayer.<br>In the Babli, R. Ḥanina let the reader finish and only afterwards asked him: Did you finish all that can be said about your Creator? This argument also is accepted by the Yerushalmi since the explanations of the verses that follow are based on the principle that God’s infinity cannot be expressed in finite words. In the Yerushalmi tradition, anyone who deviates from the pattern instituted by the Sages has to be stopped in the middle of his prayer.</i>: “The great God, the strong and awe-inspiring, the noble and overpowering;” they stopped him and told him: you are not permitted to add to the formula the Sages coined for benedictions. Rav Huna in the name of Rav: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 37:23" href="/Job.37.23"><i>Job</i> 37:23</a>) “The All-powerful, we did not find for Him the fullness of His might,” we did not find out the might and strength of the Holy One, praise to Him<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">It is too much for finite man.</i>! Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 37:20" href="/Job.37.20"><i>Job</i> 37:20</a>) “Can it be told to Him if I should speak, if a man tells, he certainly will be swallowed up.” If a man comes to tell the strengths of the Holy One, praise to Him, he sets himself up to be swallowed away from the world. Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 106:2" href="/Psalms.106.2"><i>Ps.</i> 106:2</a>) “Who can tell the strengths of the Eternal?” For example, I and my colleagues<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Not Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman but King David, meaning that Psalms cannot be composed without inspiration. This side remark is only brought as preliminary to Rebbi Abun’s interpretation.</i>. Rebbi Abun said: “Who can ever tell the strengths of the Eternal?” Jacob<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 18a" href="/Megillah.18a">Babli (<i>Megillah</i> 18a</a>) he is called Rebbi Yehudah from Kefar Giboraia. His birthplace is a village North of Safed. He is mentioned as being in Tyre, where Rebbi Ḥaggai had him whipped because he proposed the principle of patrilineal descent for Jews [<i>Midrash Qohelet rabba</i> 7(44), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 7:3" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.7.3"><i>Bereshit rabba</i> 7(3</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 19" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.19"><i>Bemidbar rabba</i> 19</a>].</i> of Kefar Naburaia explained in Tyre: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 65:2" href="/Psalms.65.2"><i>Ps.</i> 65:2</a>) “Silence is praise for You, God in Zion!” The medicine for everything is silence; like a priceless<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Greek τιμή “value, price”.</i> jewel: everyone who adorns himself with it, diminishes it.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:20" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.20">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 6:20</a>; an older source dealing with a different set of circumstances; see the last note in this paragraph.</i>: He who starts<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">A longer benediction, that should start with the formula: “Praise to You, o Eternal, our God, King of the universe …” and ends: “Praise to You, o Eternal.” In the normal form, there are two invocations of the Name, YHWH, one at the start and one at the end. Anyone following this format is wise.</i> with YH and closes with YH is wise, with ’L<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">If instead of the Name <i>ădōnāy</i>, standing in for the unpronounceable YHWH, he uses <i>ėlōhīm</i> “God”; he fails to specify God’s name.</i> and closes with ’L is ignorant, with ’L and closes with YH is average<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Since he specifies that God’s name is YHWH.</i>, with YH and closes with ’L is not Jewish<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Since he starts with the Name YHWH and ends with the plural form <i>ėlōhīm</i>, he asserts that YHWH is a name common to a trinity. Hence, he is not Jewish but a Christian. This statement introduces the following discussions of Rebbi Simlai with Jewish Christians. [R. Saul Liebermann points out that the Tosephta may deal with a different period in Jewish history. In the Tosephta, the sequence ’L-’L is termed “not Jewish” and YH-’L as “ignorant.” He conjectures that the Tosephta is directed against sects similar to the Dead Sea sect in whose “Discipline of the community”, 1QS, one finds a formula: ברוך אתה אלי “Praise to You, my God (singular form).” (The prayer manual of the sect, 1QH, always uses the <i>ădônāi</i> as replacement for YHWH.) In the time of the Yerushalmi, such sects no longer existed.]</i>.
(Jewish) Christians asked Rebbi Simlai: How many aspects of divinity created the world? He answered them: Are you asking me? Go and ask the first Adam, as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 4:32" href="/Deuteronomy.4.32"><i>Deut.</i> 4:32</a>): “Please ask the first days etc<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">“Please ask the first days that were before you, starting from the day that God created man on the earth …”</i>.” It does not say there “when gods created man on the earth” but “from the day that God created man on the earth”. They said to him, but it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:1" href="/Genesis.1.1"><i>Gen.</i> 1:1</a>): “In the beginning, <i>ĕlōhīm</i> created …” He said to them: Is it written “they created” (plural)? It says “he created” (singular). Rebbi Simlai said, every place where the Christians read heretic meanings<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">That <i>ĕlōhīm</i> is a genuine plural, not one of majesty.</i>, their answer is at that place.
They came back and asked him: What is that which is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:26" href="/Genesis.1.26"><i>Gen.</i> 1:26</a>): “Let us make a human in our image, as in our pattern.” He answered them, it is not written: “<i>ĕlōhīm</i> created man in their image” but (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:27" href="/Genesis.1.27"><i>Gen.</i> 1:27</a>): “God created man in His image.” His students told him: these you pushed away with a stick, what can you answer us<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The verse presents a real difficulty, not for the plural, which is one of majesty, but for shape and form which cannot be attributes of God.</i>? He said to them: Adam was created from dust, Eve was created from Adam. After Adam “in our image, like our pattern;” it is impossible for a man without a woman, or for a woman without a man, and for both of them without the <i>Shekhinah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 31a" href="/Niddah.31a">Babli (<i>Niddah</i> 31a</a>) this is formulated as: There are three partners in the creation of a child: Father, mother, and the Holy One, praise to Him (who gives soul and intelligence.)</i>.
They came back and asked him: What is that which is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 22:22" href="/Joshua.22.22"><i>Jos.</i> 22:22</a>): “God, <i>ĕlōhīm</i>, Eternal, God, <i>ĕlōhīm</i>, Eternal<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Three names for the Divinity, twice repeated.</i>, He knows.” He answered them, it is not written: “they know”, but “He knows.” His students told him: Teacher, these you pushed away with a stick, what can you answer us? He said to them: All three are one name, as if a man would say “King<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Greek βασιλεύς.</i>, Caesar, Augustus.”
They came back and asked him: What is that which is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 50:2" href="/Psalms.50.2"><i>Ps.</i> 50:2</a>): “God, <i>ĕlōhīm</i>, Eternal, He spoke and called the earth.” He answered them, it is not written: “they spoke and called”, but “He spoke and called.” His students told him: Teacher, these you pushed away with a stick, what can you answer us? He said to them: All three are one name, as if a man would say “professional, builder, architect<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἀρχιτέκτων. The first נ probably should be a ו. This paragraph is missing in <i>Bereshit rabba</i>.</i>.”
They came back and asked him: What is that which is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 24:19" href="/Joshua.24.19"><i>Jos.</i> 24:19</a>): “For He is a holy God.” He answered them, it is not written: “they”, but “He,” “He is a jealous God.” His students told him: Teacher, these you pushed away with a stick, what can you answer us? Rebbi Isaac said, He is holy in all kinds of holiness, as Rebbi Yudan said in the name of Rebbi Aḥa: The Holy One, praise to Him, is holy in all kinds of holiness. His speech is in holiness, His throning is in holiness, the baring of His arm is in holiness, God is awesome and majestic in holiness. His way is in holiness, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 77:14" href="/Psalms.77.14"><i>Ps.</i> 77:14</a>) “God, Your way is in holiness.” His walking is in holiness, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 68:25" href="/Psalms.68.25"><i>Ps.</i> 68:25</a>) “the course of my God, my King, in holiness.” His throning is in holiness, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 47:9" href="/Psalms.47.9"><i>Ps.</i> 47:9</a>) “God throned on His holy throne.” His speech is in holiness, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 60:8" href="/Psalms.60.8"><i>Ps.</i> 60:8</a>) “God spoke [in His holiness].” The baring of His arm is in holiness, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 52:10" href="/Isaiah.52.10"><i>Is.</i> 52:10</a>) “The Eternal bared His holy arm.” He is awesome and glorious in holiness, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 15:11" href="/Exodus.15.11"><i>Ex.</i> 15:11</a>) “Who is like You, glorious in holiness!”
They<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">This is the start of a lengthy sermon that continues to the end of the Halakhah. It has been subdivided for the benefit of the reader. Since the name of Rebbi Berekhiah, one of the authors and collectors of <i>Midrash Bereshit rabba</i>, is mentioned in this sermon, one may take it as a proof that <i>Midrash Shemot rabba</i>, which in the middle switches from a style identical to that of <i>Midrash Bereshit rabba</i> to extended sermons based on the starting verses of the weekly portions, does not necessarily have two different collectors or editors.</i> came back and asked him: What is that which is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 4:8" href="/Deuteronomy.4.8"><i>Deut.</i> 4:8</a>): “Where is a great people that has <i>ĕlōhīm</i> close<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Plural.</i> to them?” He answered them, it is not written: “Like the Eternal, our <i>ĕlōhīm</i>, always when we call on them”, but “always when we call on Him.” His students told him: Teacher, these you pushed away with a stick, what can you answer us? He said to them, he is close in all kinds of closeness, as Rebbi Phineas said in the name of Rebbi Yehudah bar Simon: Idolatry seems close but is very far. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 46:7" href="/Isaiah.46.7"><i>Is.</i> 46:7</a>) “They take it on the shoulder, carry it, etc.” Finally, his god is with him in the house and he cries until he dies but that one will not hear and not save him from his distress. But the Holy One, praise to Him, seems to be far away when there is no one closer than Him<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The following argument is in disagreement with the generally accepted doctrine of R. Yose bar Ḥalaphta that God is the place of the world but the world is not His place [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 68:8" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.68.8"><i>Bereshit rabba</i> 68(8</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shemot Rabbah 45:6" href="/Shemot_Rabbah.45.6"><i>Shemot rabba</i> 45(6</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 90" href="/Psalms.90"><i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 90</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 30:11-34:35" href="/Exodus.30.11-34.35"><i>Tanḥuma Ki Tissa</i> 27</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 30:11-34:35" href="/Exodus.30.11-34.35"><i>Tanḥuma Buber Ki Tissa</i> 16</a>, <i>Yalqut Shim‘oni</i> 117, 563, 841]. The piece is a homily and not a theological essay.</i>, as Levi said<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Without attribution of a name, the statement has been quoted in Chapter 1, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:1:2-24" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.1.2-24">Halakhah 1</a>.</i>: From the earth to the (first) heaven is a distance of 500 years’ walk. From one heaven to the next is a distance of 500 years’ walk. The thickness of each heaven is a distance of 500 years’ walk. And Rebbi Berekhiah and Rebbi Ḥelbo in the name of Red Rebbi Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">A third generation Galilean Amora whose sermons were collected by Rebbi Berekhiah.</i> said, also the toes of the heavenly <i>Ḥayot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">They carry the Throne of Heavenly Glory in the vision of Ezechiel (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 1" href="/Ezekiel.1"><i>Ez.</i> 1</a>).</i> are a length of 515 years’ walk, the number YŠRH<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The homily disregards the conclusion drawn from the verse in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:2-31" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.2-31">Halakhah 1:1</a> (fol. 2c), that one has to pray with feet parallel one to the other. The numerical value of ישרה is 10+300+200+5 = 515.</i>. See how much higher He is than His world! But a person enters the synagogue, stands behind a pillar, prays in a whisper, and the Holy One, praise to Him, listens to his prayer, as it has been said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 1:13" href="/I_Samuel.1.13"><i>1Sam.</i> 1:13</a>): “Hannah spoke to herself, only her lips were moving, but her voice was not heard.” But the Holy One, praise to Him, listened to her prayer. And so it is with all His creatures, as it has been said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 102:1" href="/Psalms.102.1"><i>Ps.</i> 102:1</a>): “Prayer of the poor when he wraps himself up<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Usually, יעטף is translated “he faints.” But here, it is taken in the Mishnaic sense of “wrapping oneself in a garment,” a toga or prayer shawl, to exclude the world from one’s prayers.</i>,” just like a man whispering into the ear of his friend and the latter understands. Can you have a God who is closer than that to His creatures, from mouth to ear?”
Rebbi Yudan in the name of Rebbi Isaac said it in four versions. Flesh and blood has a protector<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>patronus</i>, who was obliged to protect his <i>clients</i>.</i>. When they tell him, your client was arrested, he will say: I will protect him. When they tell him, he is going before a court, he will say: I will protect him. When they tell him, he is taken to be hanged, where is he and where is his protector? But the Holy One, praise to Him, saved Moses from the sword of Pharao; that is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 18:4" href="/Exodus.18.4"><i>Ex.</i> 18:4</a>): “He saved me from the sword of Pharao.” Rebbi Yannai said<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Most of the following is also in <i>Exodus rabba</i> 1(37).</i>, it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 2:15" href="/Exodus.2.15"><i>Ex.</i> 2:15</a>): “Moses fled from before Pharao.” Is it possible for flesh and blood to flee from the government?<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">R. Yannai takes the sentence to mean that “Moses fled from before the face of Pharao,” as translated here, and not “Moses fled because of Pharao,” as usually understood.</i> But at the moment when Pharao arrested Moses, he sentenced him to have him beheaded. The sword slipped off the neck of Moses and broke. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Song of Songs 7:5" href="/Song_of_Songs.7.5"><i>Songs</i> 7:5</a>): “Your neck is like the ivory tower,” that is Moses’s neck. Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The name of the tradent is missing; he cannot be Rebbi since R. Eviathar belongs to the second generation of Amoraïm and exchanged letters with Rav Ḥisda and Rav Sheshet. The sentence is missing in <i>Shemot rabba</i>.</i> said, Rebbi Eviathar: Not only that, but He moved the sword from the neck of Moses on the neck of the executioner and killed him. That is what is written: “He saved me from the sword of Pharao.” He saved <i>me</i>, but killed the executioner. Rebbi Berekhiah quoted on this (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 21:18" href="/Proverbs.21.18"><i>Prov.</i> 21:18</a>) “The evil one is ransom for the just one.” Rebbi Abun quoted on this (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 11:8" href="/Proverbs.11.8"><i>Prov.</i> 11:8</a>): “The just will be extricated from distress, the evil one will take his place.” Bar Qappara stated: An angel came down and appeared to them in the shape of Moses. They arrested the angel and Moses fled. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said: when Moses fled from before Pharao, all his troops<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Semitic plural of Greek ὄχλος, “multitude” (of people, troops).</i> became dumb, deaf, or blind. He asked the dumb, where is Moses? But they could not speak. He asked the deaf, they could not hear. He asked the blind, they could not see. That is what the Holy One, praise to Him, said to Moses (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 4:11" href="/Exodus.4.11"><i>Ex.</i> 4:11</a>): “Who gave man a mouth, or who makes dumb?” There it upheld you and here you do not want to uphold. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 4:8" href="/Deuteronomy.4.8"><i>Deut.</i> 4:8</a>): “Who is like the Eternal, our <i>ĕlōhīm</i>, always when we call on Him!”
Rebbi Yudan in the name of Rebbi Isaac said in another version: Flesh and blood has a protector. When they tell him, your client was arrested, he will say: I will protect him. When they tell him, he is going before a court, he will say: I will protect him. When they tell him, he is being thrown into the water, where is he and where is his protector? But the Holy One, praise to Him, saved Jonah from inside the fish, since it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jonah 2:11" href="/Jonah.2.11"><i>Jonah</i> 2:11</a>): “The Eternal commanded the fish and it threw Jonah up.”
Rebbi Yudan in the name of Rebbi Isaac in another version. Flesh and blood has a protector. When they tell him, your client was arrested, he will say: I will protect him. When they tell him, he is going before a court, he will say: I will protect him. When they tell him, he is being thrown into fire, where is he and where is his protector? But the Holy One, praise to Him, saved Ḥananiah, Mishael, and Azariah from the fiery oven; this is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 3:14" href="/Daniel.3.14"><i>Dan.</i> 3:14</a>): “Nebucadnezzar declared and said, praised be the God of Shadrakh, Meshakh, and Abed Nego, etc.”
Rebbi Yudan in the name of Rebbi Isaac said in another version: Flesh and blood has a protector, etc. until: he is being thrown to the wild beasts. But the Holy One, praise to Him, saved Daniel from the lions’ den. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 6:23" href="/Daniel.6.23"><i>Dan.</i> 6:23</a>): “My God sent his angel who closed the mouth of the lions, etc.”
Rebbi Judan said in his own name<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Yalqut Shim‘oni Joel</i> (#537), the paragraph and the next one are quoted in a shortened form in the name of Rebbi Yehudah in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah.</i>: Flesh and blood has a protector. If someone is in trouble, he does not enter the protector’s place suddenly but rather stands at his door and calls his slave or familiar and that one will say: the man X is standing at the door of your courtyard. Maybe he will make him enter, maybe he will let him stand. But the Holy One, praise to Him, is not like this: If a human is in trouble, he should cry neither to Michael nor to Gabriel, rather he should cry to Me and I shall answer him immediately; that is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joel 3:5" href="/Joel.3.5"><i>Joel</i> 3:5</a>): “Every one who calls on<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The sentence is slightly ambiguous; one could also translate “who invokes the Name”; that is the meaning given to the verse in the next paragraph.</i> the name of the Eternal will escape.”
Rebbi Phineas said: It happened to Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in <i>Yalqut Joel</i>, the story is told of “some man.” This seems to be a more correct version, since Rav spent his time in the Yeshivah of Rebbi in Shephar‘am and Beth She‘arim in Western Galilee. Also, the setting fits much more the time of the military anarchy after the murder of Alexander Severus when Rav had long since returned to Babylonia.</i> that he was ascending from the hot springs of Tiberias<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">“Of Tiberias” is missing in the Rome manuscript.</i> that he met Romans. They asked him, of whose party are you? He said, of Sophianus<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Yalqut Joel</i>, the name is Popianus. The name is unidentifiable [could be Pompeianus (E. G.)]. [Z. Frankel wants to emend the name to (Septimius) Severus; but this identification is impossible for many reasons (it would require that Rav stayed at the Yeshiva of Rebbi at least 25 years, that Severus should have ever been in Galilee, and that in Galilee one spoke Hebrew with a German pronunciation that identified <i>waw</i> and <i>phe, v</i> and <i>f</i>.)] The setting looks much more like that of a local conflict that was possible only during the military anarchy. The history of that period is not detailed enough to enumerate all local rulers. (There is a Roman surname Sophus.)</i>; they let him go. The next morning, they came to him and asked him, how long did you carry on with these Jews? He asked them, why? They said to him, we met a Jew and asked him, of whose party are you? He said, of Sophianus. He asked them, what did you do to him? They said to him, it was enough, we let him go. He said to them, you did well. And if a person who attaches himself on to the party of a human is saved, someone who attaches himself to the Holy One, praise to Him, so much more. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joel 3:5" href="/Joel.3.5"><i>Joel</i> 3:5</a>): “Every one who calls on<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The sentence is slightly ambiguous; one could also translate “who invokes the Name”; that is the meaning given to the verse in the next paragraph.</i> the name of the Eternal will escape.”
Rebbi Alexandri said, it happened that a prefect by the name of Alexander sat and judged a robber<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Note the exact transliteration of Greek λῃστής.</i>. He asked him, what is your name? Alexander! He said, Alexander, go to Alexandria<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">So that people should not say, Alexander was executed. Alexandria was a very big city in which one more robber would not make a difference.</i>. And if a person whose name is the name of a human is saved, someone whose name is that of the Holy One, praise to Him, so much more. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joel 3:5" href="/Joel.3.5"><i>Joel</i> 3:5</a>): “Every one who is called by the name of the Eternal will escape.”
Rebbi Phineas gave on this subject two sermons, one in the name of Rebbi Zeïra, the other in the name of Rebbi Tanḥum bar Ḥanilai. Rebbi Phineas said in the name of Rebbi Zeïra, flesh and blood has a protector. If he bothers him too much, he will say: “There is X who will bother me.” But the Holy One, praise to Him, is not like that; He will receive you with all that you might bother him with. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 55:23" href="/Psalms.55.23"><i>Ps.</i> 55:23</a>) “Throw on the Eternal your burden and He will provide for you!” Rebbi Phineas said in the name of Rebbi Tanḥum bar Ḥanilai, flesh and blood has a protector. Enemies come and grab him at the door of his protector’s courtyard. While he is crying and before someone could come out, the sword already passes over his neck and kills him. But the Holy One, praise to Him, saved Jehoshaphat from the sword of the Syrians as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 18:34" href="/II_Chronicles.18.34"><i>2Chr.</i> 18:34</a>): “Jehoshaphat cried, the Eternal helped him and God turned them away from him.” That shows that only the cutting off of the head was missing, but God deflected them from him.
Rebbi Zeīra, son of Rebbi Abbahu, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Eleazar (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 146:5" href="/Psalms.146.5"><i>Ps.</i> 146:5</a>): “Happy is he whom the God of Jacob helps.” What is written after that (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 146:6" href="/Psalms.146.6"><i>Ps.</i> 146:6</a>): “He makes Heaven and Earth.” What has one to do with the other? But a king of flesh and blood needs a protector<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">“King” was a title forbidden in Rome; a ‘king’ is a small local potentate who needs a Roman (or, possibly, a Persian) emperor as a protector.</i>, he rules over one district<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἐπαρχία.</i> but not over another district. A universal ruler<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κοσμοκράτωρ. In the parallel, <i>Avodah zarah</i> 1:1, the word is written קוזמוקרטור. There, the universal ruler is Alexander the Great.</i> rules over dry land; does he rule over the ocean? But the Holy One, praise to Him, rules over ocean and dry land. He saves in the ocean from the water and on the dry land from the fire. He saved Moses from Pharao’s sword. He saved Jonah from inside the fish, Ḥananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, from the fiery oven, Daniel from the lions’ den. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 146:6" href="/Psalms.146.6"><i>Ps.</i> 146:6</a>) “He makes Heaven and Earth, the oceans and all that is in them.”
Rebbi Tanḥuma said: A happening with a ship of Gentiles that sailed the great sea and on it was a Jewish child. There came upon them a big storm; each one got up, took his idol in his hand and called upon it, without result. When they saw that it was of no use, they said to that Jew: Son, get up, call on your God, for we heard that He answers you when you cry and He is strong. The child immediately got up with a full heart and cried; the Holy One, praise to Him, received his prayer and the sea quited down. When they came to dry land, each one descended to buy his needs. They said to that child, do you not want to buy anything for yourself? He said to them, what do you want from that unhappy stranger<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">At other places in the Yerushalmi, the spelling is אכסניי, Greek ξένος “stranger, guest”, with prothetic א.</i>. They said to him: Are you an unhappy stranger? They are an unhappy stranger; they are here and their errors<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Their idols.</i> are in Babylonia, they are here and their errors are in Rome, they are here and their errors are with them, but are of no use to them. But you, everywhere you go, your God is with you. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 4:7" href="/Deuteronomy.4.7"><i>Deut.</i> 4:7</a>): “Like the Eternal, our God, always when we call on Him!”
Rebbi Simeon bar Laqish said, flesh and blood has a relative. If he is rich, he acknowledges him. If he is poor, he disawovs him. But the Holy One, praise to Him, is not like this; even if Israel is in deepest distress, He calls them My brothers and My friends. What is the reason (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 122:8" href="/Psalms.122.8"><i>Ps.</i> 122:8</a>): “For My brothers and friends.” Rebbi Abun, Rebbi Aḥa, and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: flesh and blood has a relative. If he is a philosopher, he says: “This X is related to us.” But the Holy One, praise to Him, calls all of Israel relatives; that is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 148:14" href="/Psalms.148.14"><i>Ps.</i> 148:14</a>): “He raises the fortunes of His people.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">While there are numerous verses declaring Israel as His people, it belongs to the style of a sermon to close with a verse promising a better future. The quote may indicate that עם should be translated as “relative”; this is the meaning attributed to the root in theophorous names.</i>”
Our Mishnah if it was uprooted from all places of the Land of Israel, but if it was uprooted only from one place, he says: “Praise to Him Who uprooted paganism from this place.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">This version is not found in the parallels, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 57b" href="/Berakhot.57b">Babli 57b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:2" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.2">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i>6:2</a>, <i>Ruth rabba</i> 3(2); they all apply the text of the Mishnah to a single destroyed temple, even though <i>Ruth rabba</i> is a (later) text in the Galilean tradition. The following three sentences appear in the version of the Mishnah in these three sources.</i>” If it was uprooted from one place but established at another place, there where it was reestablished he says: “Praise to Him Who is patient.” Where it was uprooted from, he says: “Praise to Him Who uprooted paganism from this place. May it be Your pleasure, our God and God of our fathers, that just as You uprooted it from this place, so uproot it from all other places and turn the heart of its worshippers to worship You.” Does he not pray for pagan worshippers<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The answer to this question is given piecemeal in the next paragraphs.</i>? It was stated: Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Reading of the Rome manuscript; the Venice print has “R. Ismael ben Gamliel” who otherwise is unknown. In the Babli, the name is R. Simeon ben Eleazar and it is explained that even the first Tanna requires the benediction to be recited, only without the following prayer. There, R. Simeon’s reason is that at the End of Days all peoples will abandon paganism.</i> ben Gamliel says, also outside of the Land he must say this.
Rebbi Yoḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in <i>Ruth rabba</i>, this paragraph and the one after the next are taken together; the insertion of the next paragraph is difficult to understand.<br>The argument of R. Yoḥanan refers mostly to the parts of this and the preceding verses that are not quoted. “That is evil in all which is done under the sun, that the same happens to all; also, the heart of humans is full of evil, hooliganism is in their thoughts during their lifetime, but their end is with the dead. Who <i>is being joined</i>, all living beings have confidence; truly a living dog is better than a dead lion.” <i>Is being joined</i> is the <i>qere</i>, the way the word is read, but “may choose” is the <i>ketib</i>, the way it is written. The interpretation given the <i>ketib</i> here is: All the living can have confidence that they may choose (the way of virtue), but death is final; nothing can be changed after death. Hence, a living dog (a living sinner) is better (might by repentance attain a higher state of holiness) than a dead lion (a good person.)</i> said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 9:4" href="/Ecclesiastes.9.4"><i>Eccl.</i> 9:4</a>): “Who is it that has been connected?” It is written: “may choose.” All living beings have the certitude that as long as a human is alive, he has hope. When he dies, his hope is lost. What is the reason (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 11:7" href="/Proverbs.11.7"><i>Prov.</i> 11:7</a>): “When an evil man dies, hope becomes lost.”
It has been stated: Rebbi Yehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">In the print of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 43b" href="/Menachot.43b">Babli, <i>Menaḥot</i> 43b</a>, “R. Meïr.” However, R. Rabbinowitz notes a German and an Egyptian manuscript of the Babli that have “R. Yehudah”, as well R. Isaac Fasi and <i>Rosh</i>, in line with the Yerushalmi and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:17" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.17">Tosephta, <i>Berakhot</i> 6:17</a>. The entire paragraph is from R. Yehudah in the Tosephta.</i> says, three things a man has to recite every day: Praise to Him Who did not make me a Gentile. Praise to Him Who did not make me uncivilized<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The uncivilized person is one who knows no Bible, no Mishnah, and no trade. Since he cannot know what is forbidden, he cannot fear sin. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 43b-44a" href="/Menachot.43b-44a">Babli (<i>Menaḥot</i> 43b–44a</a>) it is reported that R. Jacob bar Aḥa changed this benediction to “Who did not make me a slave,” since an uncivilized person can become civilized; his state of ignorance is not God-given.</i>. Praise to Him Who did not make me a woman. “Praise to Him Who did not make me a Gentile,” because Gentiles are not considered to be anything, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 40:17" href="/Isaiah.40.17"><i>Is.</i> 40:17</a>) “all Gentiles are nothing before Him.” “Praise to Him Who did not make me uncivilized,” because an uncivilized person cannot fear sin<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Pirkei Avot 2:6" href="/Pirkei_Avot.2.6">Mishnah <i>Pirqe Avot</i> 2:6</a>.</i>. “Praise to Him Who did not make me a woman,” because women are not commanded about benedictions<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Here מצוות cannot mean “commandments”, not even “positive commandments tied to a fixed time” that do not apply to women, but “benedictions”, as in Chapter 6, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:1:2-24" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.1.2-24">Halakhah 1</a>, first paragraph.</i>.
Rebbi Aḥa said, “Who is it that has been connected<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Aḥa explains the verse such as it is written, who is the one who is connected to God and the future world? Every human, as long as he is alive, has this possibility. The paragraph is inserted here because the verse was mentioned.</i>?” Even those that stretched out their arms against the Sanctuary<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Tried to destroy the Temple or helped in destroying it. By necessity, these are Gentiles.</i> have certitude. It is impossible to bring them near since they stretched out their arms against the Sanctuary. It is impossible to keep them far since they repented. On them it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 51:39" href="/Jeremiah.51.39"><i>Jer.</i> 51:39</a>): “They will sleep eternal sleep and never awake.” The rabbis of Caesarea say, Gentile minors<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Who, as minors, are incapable of sin, but who, growing up as idolators, cannot have merit. [In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 13:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.13.1">Tosephta <i>Sanhedrin</i> 13:1</a>, the opinion of Rabban Gamliel is quoted that children of (Jewish) evil doers (who die in infancy) have no part in the Future World, against the (prevailing) opinion of R. Joshua that all who die as children have part in the Future World, as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 116:6" href="/Psalms.116.6"><i>Ps.</i> 116:6</a>): “The Eternal is the guardian of the simple ones.”]</i> and the armies of Nebuchadnezzar<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Who destroyed the Temple but who, in contrast to the Romans, did not do so out of hatred of Jews and Judaism. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 13:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.13.1">Tosephta <i>Sanhedrin</i> 13:5</a> it is said that “for those who stretched out their arms against the Sanctuary, the gates of hell will be locked and they will be punished there for all eternity.” It is explained here that this is valid only if they did not repent.</i> will not live, but never will they be judged. On them Scripture says: “They will sleep eternal sleep, etc.”
He who passes by a pagan temple says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 15:25" href="/Proverbs.15.25"><i>Prov.</i> 15:25</a>): “The Eternal will tear down the house of the haughty.” Rebbi Yose, son of Rebbi Abun, in the name of Rebbi Levi: “If he saw them sacrificing<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the Rome manuscript. The Venice print has מזבלין “bringing manure,” meaning the same, but using language of contempt.</i> to an idol, he says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:19" href="/Exodus.22.19"><i>Ex.</i> 22:19</a>): He who sacrifices to gods shall be devoted to destruction.”
He who sees a black man<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">“Black man” here does not mean a Negro but a Caucasian with a swarthy complexion since it is stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 45b" href="/Bekhorot.45b">Babli <i>Bekhorot</i> 45b</a> that a “black” man should not marry a “black” woman lest their children would be genuinely “black”.</i>, a red man, an albino<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Greek λευκός “white”.</i>, a beanstalk<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 58b" href="/Berakhot.58b">Babli (58b</a>), written קפח, in the Tosephta כיפיח. Rashi gives two explanations: 1) a potbelly, 2) a tall person with a bloated face. However, the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 45b" href="/Bekhorot.45b">Babli <i>Bekhorot</i> 45b</a> defines קפח as a tall person whose frame is much too thin; the Mayence commentary ascribed to Rabbenu Gershom is the source of Rashi’s second explanation.</i>, or a dwarf, says: Praise to Him who makes unusual creatures; the amputee, the blind, or a person covered with boils, he says: Praise to the True Judge. This <i>baraitha</i> if they were whole and then changed. But if they were so from the mother’s womb: Praise to Him who makes unusual creatures.
He who sees beautiful trees or beautiful people says: Praise to Him Who created beautiful creatures in His world<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 58b" href="/Berakhot.58b">Babli (58b</a>) and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:4" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.4">Tosephta (6:4</a>), the formula is “Who has beautiful creatures in His world,” without reference to Creation.</i>. It happened that Rabban Gamliel saw a beautiful Gentile woman and recited a benediction over her. Did not say Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rebbi Yose bar Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 7:2" href="/Deuteronomy.7.2"><i>Deut.</i> 7:2</a>): “Do not favour them,” do not ascribe charm to them? He did not say “may there be no harm” but “Who created beautiful creatures in His world,” since even if one sees a beautiful horse or a beautiful donkey, one says: Praise to Him Who created beautiful creatures in His world. Does Rabban Gamliel usually look at women? It was a curved road, like a <i>pwpsdws</i><sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">This word is unexplained. In the parallel in <i>Avodah zarah</i> and in <i>Arukh</i>, the spelling is פסווריס, R. Salomon Cirillo has פיוסרס. R. J. Levy conjectures Greek σπεῖρα “a spiral (road)”. R. M. Margalit (פני משה) thinks the word is Latinate, similar to Italian <i>passavia</i> “passageway; bridge.” It could be Greek περίοδος, ἡ “way around, circuit, circular path” (E. G.).</i>; he looked at her because he could not avoid her.
If the cock crowed, one says: Praise to Him Who is wise in secrets; (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 38:36" href="/Job.38.36"><i>Job</i>38:36</a>) “Who put wisdom in kidneys?<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">The full verse is: Who put wisdom into kidneys, who gave insight to the <i>śekhwi</i>?” The insight of the <i>śekhwi</i> is compared to the hidden knowledge of the kidneys, only accessible to God. The verse lends itself better to the Babylonian version (60b): “Praise to Him Who gave insight to the <i>śekhwi</i> to distinguish between day and night.” The text of the Galilean benediction is a disapproved version of a benediction to be recited if one sees a great scholar, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 58b" href="/Berakhot.58b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 58b</a>. The following explanation of words, parallel to one given in Babli <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 26a, refers to the determination of the meaning of the word <i>śekhwi</i> (that is not quoted, only understood, at this moment.)</i>”. Rebbi Levi said, in Arabia one calls sheep <i>yovel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">The same identification is given by R. Aqiba in Babli <i>Rosh Hashanah</i>26a; it must refer to the Hebrew usage of Jewish tribes in Arabia, not to Arabic. [There is an Arabic word וַבַלַ “giving lots of milk”.]</i>; (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 6:5" href="/Joshua.6.5"><i>Jos.</i> 6:5</a>) “it will be when the ram’s horn is blown.” In Africa<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, the place referred to is Gallia (or Galatia). The etymology of the word has connections with Arabic גַלמַד, גֻלמוּד “rock.”</i>, the menstruating woman is called <i>galmudah</i>, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 49:21" href="/Isaiah.49.21"><i>Is.</i> 49:21</a>) “I am childless and barren.” In Rome<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, on the authority of R. Simeon ben Laqish, the place is Greek-speaking <i>Kenisrin</i>, near Aleppo.</i>, one calls a chicken <i>śekhwi</i>(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 38:36" href="/Job.38.36"><i>Job</i> 38:36</a>) “who gave understanding to the <i>śekhwi</i>?”
He<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">All three sections are in almost identical form also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 58a" href="/Berakhot.58a">Babli (58a</a>) and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:2" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.2">Tosephta (6:2</a>). In both Babli and Tosephta, the good guest appears before the bad one; then for the quote from Job one has to return to the good guest. Hence, the version of the Yerushalmi looks more original.</i> who sees multitudes says: Praise to Him Who is wise in secrets! Just as their faces are not similar one to the other, so the opinions of one are not similar to another’s. When ben Zoma saw multitudes in Jerusalem, he said: Praise to Him Who created all these to serve me. How much did Adam toil until he could eat one piece of bread! He plowed, sowed, harrowed, weeded, harvested, bound sheaves, threshed, winnowed, selected, milled, sifted, made dough, split it, baked, and only after that could he eat a piece of bread. But I get up in the morning and find everything before me. See, how much toil Adam had to expend until he obtained a garment to wear! He sheared, bleached, separated the fibers, dyed, spun, weaved, washed, sewed, and after that he obtained a garment to wear. But I get up in the morning and find all before me. How many professionals work mornings and evenings! But I get up in the morning and find all before me. Similarly, ben Zoma said: What does a bad guest say? What did I eat from the householder, what did I drink from the householder? One piece I ate from him, one cup of wine I drank from him. All the effort he put in he did only for his wife and children! But a good guest says, praised be the householder, may the householder be remembered in a good way! How much wine did he bring before me, how many cuts did he bring before me! How much work did he do for me! All that effort he did only for me! And so it says (<i>Job.</i> 36:24): “Remember to magnify his work that people saw!”

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> On <i>ziqin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The Yerushalmi does not define זיקא. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 58b" href="/Berakhot.58b">Babli (58b</a>), Samuel defines it as “star with a tail”, which may mean either a comet (<i>Arukh</i> s. v. ככב) or a meteorite (Rashi). <i>Arukh</i> s. v. זק quotes Rav Hai Gaon as defining זיקא as thunderless lightning that illuminates an entire cloud. The latter determination is probably the correct one since it fits the context of the Mishnah and its author has the highest authority among those who explain difficult words in the Talmudim.</i>, earthquakes, lightning, thunder, and hurricanes, one says: Praise to Him Whose power<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">In the Rome manuscript and in many (mostly Ashkenazic) manuscripts of the Babli and the Mishnah, one adds וּגְבוּרָתוֹ “and His strength.”</i> fills the world. On mountains, hills, seas, rivers, and deserts, one says: Praise to the Maker of Creation<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The same manuscripts that add “His strength” in the first sentence, add “the work of Creation” here.</i>. Rebbi Yehudah says, he who sees the ocean says: Praise to Him Who made the ocean; if he sees it at intervals<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of all manuscripts of Yerushalmi, Babli, and Mishnah, except the Leyden manuscript and the Venice print who have this language only in the Mishnah, but the quote in the Halakhah reads: “Rebbi Yehudah says, he who sees the ocean says: Praise to Him Who made the ocean; if he sees it at intervals, he says: Praise to the Maker of Creation.” However, from the discussion in the Talmud it is clear that this is a scribal error.</i>. On rains<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In Israel, where there is only one rainy season.</i> and good tidings one says: Praise to Him Who is good and does good. On bad news, one says: Praise to the True Judge. 
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Bar Kappara stated: One blows the <i>shofar</i> because of an earthquake<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Blowing the <i>shofar</i> on days other than Rosh Hashanah was only done on public fast days. This means that Bar Qappara declares an earthquake a catastrophy which requires repentance; hence, he disagrees with the Mishnah and requires the benediction “the True Judge” for an earthquake.</i>.
Samuel said: If that <i>ziqa</i> would pass by <i>Kesil</i><sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Janaḥ defines <i>kesil</i> as the star that in Arabic is called <i>suhail</i>, “Canopus”. Ibn Ezra identifies the word as meaning “Pleiades”. Since the Pleiades are seen only during summertime in the Northern Hemisphere, this might justify the characterization of <i>kesil</i> as “hot” in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 58b" href="/Berakhot.58b">Babli (58b</a>).<br>The statement of Samuel and his qualifications are also quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 58b" href="/Berakhot.58b">Babli (58b</a>). The text of the Yerushalmi is quoted in slightly changed form in <i>Arukh</i>, s. v. ככב.</i>, it would destroy the world. They objected to Samuel: Do we not see that it passes by it? He said to them: It is impossible; either above or below it. Samuel said: I know the places<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Derivative of שוּק “market place,” [maybe a pun on שחקים “skies” (E. G.)].</i> of heaven like the places of my city Nahardea; except for that <i>ziqa</i>, I do not know what that is. Did Samuel ascend to heaven? No, following (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 38:37" href="/Job.38.37"><i>Job</i> 38:37</a>): “Who may discourse about heaven in wisdom<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., be an astronomer.</i>?”
Elijah, may he be well remembered<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">This is the regular honorific given to Elijah when he is mentioned in his dealings with men. One cannot say “his remembrance for a blessing” as is done for people who died, since he did not die.</i>, asked Rebbi Nehorai<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Rebbis Joshua and Tarphon, of the fourth generation of Tannaïm; his statements are mostly aggadic.</i>: Why do earthquakes occur in the world? He said to him, because of sin concerning heave and tithes. One verse says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:12" href="/Deuteronomy.11.12"><i>Deut.</i> 11:12</a>): The eyes of the Eternal, your God, are permanently on it. Another verse says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 104:32" href="/Psalms.104.32"><i>Ps.</i> 104:32</a>): He who gazes on the Earth and it trembles, He touches mountains and they smoke. How can these two verses coexist? If Israel fulfill the will of the Omnipresent and separate their tithes following the rules, “the eyes of the Eternal, your God, are permanently on it from the start to the end of the year” and they will not be hurt by anything. If Israel do not fulfill the will of the Omnipresent and do not separate their tithes following the rules, “He gazes on the Earth and it trembles.” He said to him, my son, that is the reasonable explanation. But the main thing is that if the Holy One, praise to Him, sees theatres and circuses existing in safety and quiet, but His temple is destroyed, He is menacing<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἀπειλῶν.</i> His world to destroy it; that is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 25:30" href="/Jeremiah.25.30"><i>Jer.</i> 25:30</a>): “He will roar on His Place,” about His place. Rebbi Aḥa<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">This shows that in homilies, precedents (even from such an authority as the prophet Elijah) do not count.</i> said, because of homosexual activity. The Holy One, praise to Him, said: You made your member tremble for something that is not for you; by your life, I shall make My world tremble because of that man. But the rabbis said, because of quarrels (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Zechariah 14:5" href="/Zechariah.14.5">Zach. 14:5</a>): “You will flee by the valley of the mountains, for the valley of the mountains will reach Aẓel<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">The relevant part of the verse is the one not quoted: “You shall flee as you fled because of the earthquake in the days of Uzziah, king of Judah.” Uzziah quarreled with the priests and wanted to usurp their functions in the Temple. The earthquake was on that day, when Isaiah saw the Seraphim flying in the Temple (<i>Seder Olam</i> Chap. 20).</i>.” Rebbi Samuel said, an earthquake presages a change of government, as one says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 51:29" href="/Jeremiah.51.29"><i>Jer.</i> 51:29</a>): “The earth quaked and trembled,” why? “for the intentions of the Eternal overtake Babylon.”
Elijah, may he be well remembered, asked Rebbi Nehorai: Why did the Holy One, praise to Him, create abominable and crawling animals in His world? He said to him, they fill a need because, when men sin, He gazes at those and says, if I am keeping those who have no utility, certainly I shall keep these who might have utility. He said to him, still they have utility<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">A similar statement is found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 77b" href="/Shabbat.77b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 77b</a>, by Rav Yehudah in the name of Rav.</i>: a fly for wasps<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi in Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 77b explains that as antidote for the poison of the sting of a wasp, one grinds up some flies and puts them as ointment on the sting. He explains the same for the use of <i>semamit</i> for the sting of a scorpion, but the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) notes that the scorpion is afraid of the <i>semamit</i>. Hence, it seems more likely that flies carry diseases into wasp’s nests and therefore curb their numbers, and <i>semamiot</i> eat scorpions.</i>, bedbugs for a leech, snail for skin rash<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">The last two must certainly be explained as medical uses.</i>, <i>semamit</i><sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Arukh</i> gives two Italian explanations of this word, the first <i>ragnatello</i>“spider” is also given by Rashi (<i>araignée</i>) in Babli <i>Šabbat</i>, the second <i>lucertola</i> “lizard” is more probable, in particular the gecko, Arabic סַאם אַבּרַצ, which is known to eat scorpions. Arabic סַאמָּה “poisonous animal”, but cf. Accadic <i>summatu</i> “pidgeon”, <i>simmatu</i> “poisoning”.</i> for the scorpion.
“On lightning.” Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Zeïra in the name of Rav Ḥasdai<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rav Ḥisda.</i>: It is enough once a day. Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">From the following, it is clear that this is Rebbi Yose II, colleague of R. Jonah.</i> said, what are we talking about? If it is permanent<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">From Biblical דלף טוֹרד “unceasing downpour”.</i>, once a day is enough. If it is intermittent, one recites the benediction for each occurrence. The force of Rebbi Yose from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 5:32" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).5.32">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 5:32</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 53a" href="/Berakhot.53a">Babli 53a</a>.</i>: If he was sitting in the perfumer’s store all day long, he would recite the benediction only once. But if he enters and leaves, enters and leaves, he recites a benediction every time. It came<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Somebody came with a collection of older formulations and showed that the discussion was already settled in earlier generations.</i>, it was said by Rebbi Aḥa (and)<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">This is a scribal error; R. Aḥa cannot be concurrent with his teacher’s father.</i> Rebbi Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">He is either the Amora R. Yasa (Assi) or the Tanna R. Yose.</i>: If it is permanent, once a day is enough. If it is intermittent, one recites the benediction for each occurrence.
If one was sitting in the bathroom or the room of filth<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">And he sees lightning while there.<br>It seems that the second word is simply a Latinate form of the first, the bathroom or it may mean “garbage room”. In the Rome manuscript and the text of R. S. Cirillo, the reading is ספיקלריא, with change of liquids <i>r - l</i>. The Latin would be <i>faecaria</i>, “dregs, filthy matter”; Kohut compares Greek σφέκλη “dregs”.</i>, if he can exit and recite the benediction in time for one sentence<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Defined earlier as time to say: “Peace on you, my teacher.”</i>, he should exit, but if not, he should not exit<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">This implies that the benediction over lightning must be recited within this time span after the lightning was observed.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah asked: If he was sitting naked in his house, should he make the house a garment<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Since one may not mention the Divine Name with one’s genitals uncovered.</i>, lean his head out of the window and recite the benediction? If he was sitting naked in a “tower”<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">The “tower” is no tower, but one kind of sedan chair. Mishnah and Talmudim always speak of three kinds of sedan chairs, שידה תיבה וּמגדל, the exact definitions of these are unknown. But in any case, the “tower” is a wooden chest-like implement. The new question implies that the first question was answered in the negative (it is noted so in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 10b" href="/Sukkah.10b">Babli <i>Sukkah</i> 10b</a>), that a house, or any “tent”, can never be a garment. The substitute question now is whether a wooden movable cover can take the place of a textile cover. A similar question is asked in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 10b" href="/Sukkah.10b">Babli <i>Sukkah</i> 10b</a> for somebody lying naked in bed and covered by a mosquito net; the answer is that it is possible only if the bed assembly does not qualify as a “tent.” The question here goes unanswered because, characteristic for R. Jeremiah, it is asked in a totally unrealistic form. [In contrast to the Babli, the Yerushalmi never requires that heart and genitals should be covered by separate garments.]</i>, should he make it a garment, lean his head out of the window and recite the benediction?
“On winds what does he say? Praise to Him, Whose power and might fill the world.” The Mishnah if they come destructively. But if they come quietly, one says: Praise to the Maker of Creation.
Rebbi Joshua ben Ḥananiah said: When the wind goes out into the world, the Holy One, praise to Him, breaks it on mountains, lets it stumble on hills, and tells it: Be careful not to hurt my creatures. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 57:16" href="/Isaiah.57.16"><i>Is.</i> 57:16</a>) “The wind becomes faint before Me.” He makes it tired, as one says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jonah 2:8" href="/Jonah.2.8"><i>Jonah</i> 2:8</a>): “When I am fainting.” All that why? Rebbi Ḥuna in the name of Rebbi Aḥa (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 57:16" href="/Isaiah.57.16"><i>Is.</i> 57:16</a>): “And I made souls;” because of the souls that I made.
Rebbi Ḥuna said, in three places did the wind come out without measure and desired to destroy the entire world; once in the time of Jonah, once in the time of Elijah, and once in the time of Job. In the time of Jonah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jonah 1:4" href="/Jonah.1.4"><i>Jonah</i> 1:4</a>): “The Eternal sent a strong wind.” In the time of Job (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 1:19" href="/Job.1.19"><i>Job</i> 1:19</a>): “A great wind came across the desert.” In the time of Elijah, from where? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 19:19" href="/I_Kings.19.19"><i>1K.</i> 19: 19:11</a>) “Lo, the Eternal passes, and a great, strong wind, shattering mountains.” Rebbi Yudan ben Shalom<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">A late Galilean Amora, also called Rebbi Yehudah Halevi, infrequently appearing in halakhic discussions; he is a major source of the early <i>Tanḥuma</i> Midrash.</i> said, let us say that the one of Job was for him only<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">It took place just around the house it destroyed.</i>, that of Jonah was for him only. You have only that of Elijah which was worldwide<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κοσμικόν.</i> “Lo, the Eternal passes, etc. After that an earthquake<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">The earthquake by its nature is felt at great distances.</i> and after the earthquake fire, but the Eternal was not in the fire.”
“Rebbi Yehudah says, he who sees the ocean says: Praise to Him Who made the ocean, if he sees it at intervals.” What is an interval? Once in thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 59b" href="/Berakhot.59b">Babli (59b</a>), this is a statement of the Palestinian Rebbi Isaac; it seems that he brought the Galilean tradition to Babylonia.</i>. Simeon the hard-working man<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Greek καματηρός “laborious, hardworking” (E. G.). This person is mentioned only here and in the following <i>Aggadah</i> (which appears here because it mentions Simeon Qamateria.) As a learned man, he is addressed in Hebrew, not in Aramaic.</i> asked Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: Since I am a donkey driver and go up to Jerusalem all the time<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of the Rome manuscript. The Venice print has בכל שנה “every year”, which does not fit the context.</i>, how do I have to tear<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Just as one has to tear one’s clothes upon hearing of the death of a close relative, so one has to tear one’s clothes when seeing Jerusalem in a state of destruction.</i>? He said to him: If it is within thirty days, you do not have to tear, after thirty days you have to tear.
Rebbi Ḥuna and Simeon Qamateria in the name of Rebbi Samuel ben Naḥman (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Judges 18:30" href="/Judges.18.30"><i>Jud.</i> 18:30</a>): “Jonathan ben Gershom ben Manasseh,” a hanging נ<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">In Bible manuscripts and prints, the name is יהונתן בן גרשם בן מ<sup class="footnote-marker">נ</sup>שה, to hide the fact that a grandson of Moses was priest of the idol at Dan. Manasseh is the bad king of Judah, son of king Hezekiah. The parallels to this paragraph are <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:4:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.4.2-4">Yerushalmi <i>Sanhedrin</i>11:5</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 110a" href="/Bava_Batra.110a">Babli <i>Bava Batra</i> 110a</a>.</i>. If he merits it, ben Mosheh. If he does not merit it, ben Manasseh. The colleagues asked before Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman: He was a priest of idol worship and lived so long<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads: “Jonathan ben Gershom ben Mo(n)sheh, he and his sons, were priests for the tribe of Dan, until the day the land was exiled. They put up for themselves the idol of Micah, that the latter had made, all the days that the House of God was at Shiloh.” There are several interpretations of “the day the land was exiled.” Rashi takes it to mean the exile of Dan by the Assyrians, Babylonian tradition (<i>Seder Olam</i> Chapter 24) takes it as the time of captivity of king Manasse in Babylon; most later Medieval commentators (Ibn Ezra, Gersonides, R. Isaiah of Trani) take it to refer to the destruction of Shiloh (since Jeroboam put up a new Golden Calf at Dan, the original idol can no longer have survived.) However, as Y. Yadin has pointed out, already in the Song of Deborah there is a reference to the tribe of Dan who “went to dwell on ships.” Rashi’s interpretation is that of the Talmudim (the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 110a" href="/Bava_Batra.110a">Babli is <i>Bava Bathra</i> 110a</a>), since both have Jonathan (not just one of his descendants) alive and active at the time of David, about 300 years after the conquest of Laish by the tribe of Dan.</i>? He said to them, because <i>he</i> [Jonathan] was grudging to his idol. How was he grudging to his idol? If a man came to sacrifice an ox, a sheep, or a goat to the idol and told him: Make it favorably inclined towards me, <i>he</i> would say: What use does it have for you? It neither sees, nor hears, nor eats, nor drinks, nor does good or evil, and does not talk. He said to him, by your life, what should we do? <i>He</i> said to him, go, make, and bring me a wooden vessel<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πίναξ, “wooden platter”.</i> full of fine flour and put on it ten eggs, then <i>I</i> shall prepare it before that one and <i>it</i> will eat from all that comes and <i>I</i> shall make <i>it</i> favorably inclined towards you! After he left, <i>he</i> would eat it. One day, a son of pashas came and <i>he</i> said that to him. He said to <i>him</i>, if it is of no use, what are you doing here? <i>He</i> said to him, because of my livelihood. When David became king, he sent and brought <i>him</i>. He said to <i>him</i>, you are the grandson of that righteous man and you worship idols? <i>He</i> said to him: <i>I</i> have a tradition from my grandfather’s house: Sell yourself to idol worship<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">In Hebrew, “strange work”.</i> rather than need other people<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">To take money from charity.</i>. He said to <i>him</i>: Heaven forbid! He did not say so, but sell yourself to work that is strange to you rather than to need other people. When David saw that he loved money, he made him count<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>comes</i>, a high official in post-Diocletian Rome. “Treasury” from Greek θησαυρός.</i> of his treasuries. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 26:24" href="/I_Chronicles.26.24"><i>1Chr.</i> 26:24</a>): “Shabuel ben Gershom ben Moshe, overseer of the treasuries.” “Shabuel” because he returned to God with all his heart and all his might. “Overseer of the treasuries,” that he made him count of the treasuries. They objected to Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Judges 18:30" href="/Judges.18.30"><i>Jud.</i> 18:30</a>): “Until the day the land went into exile.” He said to them, when David died, Shelomo rose and exchanged all his counselors<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Greek singular σύγκλητος (βουλή) “summoned (council, senate)”, also συγκλητικός “of senatorial rank”, with Aramaic plural ending. <i>Seder Olam</i>, quoted earlier, seems to assume that he stayed in Jerusalem after that.</i>. <i>He</i> returned to his former bad ways. That is what is written: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 13:11" href="/I_Kings.13.11"><i>1K.</i> 13:11</a>) “An old prophet<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Since prophets are usually experienced people, this one must have been very old.</i> was dwelling at Beth El;” they say that this was <i>he</i>.
He who sees the sun at its turning point<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">According to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 59b" href="/Berakhot.59b">Babli (59b</a>), this is the moment when the sun would stand at the point where it was created if the Julianic calendar could be extrapolated backwards. It is not permissible to read the Yerushalmi by the interpretations of the Babli. Usually, a “turning point” of the sun is either a solstice or an equinox; it also could just mean “the sun turning”. The latter meaning is implied by the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:6" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.6">Tosephta (6:6</a>): “He who sees sun, moon, fixed stars, planets, says: Praise to the Maker of Creation. Rebbi Yehudah says, he who recites a benediction over the sun is on the way of heretics. Similarly, Rebbi Yehudah used to say, he who sees the ocean frequently has to recite a benediction if it has changed.” Here it is clear that the entire statement refers to weather-related phenomena; the following statement of R. Ḥuna therefore should not be taken to refer to the clear sky only (as it is taken in the Babli) but for all celestial phenomena when they are observed in an unpolluted sky. The coastline of the ocean may have changed during a storm; after the clearing of the sky R. Jehudah requires a new benediction.</i>, the moon at its turning point, and the sky in its purity, says: Praise to the Maker of Creation. Rebbi Ḥuna says, that means in the rainy season and only after three days. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 37:21" href="/Job.37.21"><i>Job</i> 37:21</a>): “Now they do not see light, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The end of the verse: “He is lucent in the skies, a wind passed by and purified them,” shows that the sky is really radiant only if the sun comes out after a long rain.<br>A parallel Yerushalmi source, Midrash <i>Wayiqra rabba</i> 23(8) reads: “ ‘Now they do not see light,’ we have formulated: He who sees the sun at its turning point, the moon in its spherical shape, the stars in their paths, the planets in their order, says: Praise to the Maker of Creation. Rebbi Ḥuna says, that means in the rainy season and only after three days.” Rabbenu Ḥananel, in his commentary to the Babli, takes sun, moon, stars, and planets all together and requires a benediction if any of them has not been seen for a prolonged time.</i>”
He who sees the moon in its renewal says: Praise to Him Who renews months<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 42a" href="/Sanhedrin.42a">Babli (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 42a</a>) notes that in Galilee one recites simply: “Praised are You, Eternal, our God, King of the Universe, Who renews months,” and that this is the formula used by women in Babylonia, but men in Babylonia use the formula “Praised are You, Eternal, our God, King of the Universe, Who renews months” only as conclusion of a longer prayer.</i>. Until when? Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rebbi Assi; in the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) he is reported to have said in the name of R. Yoḥanan that one recites the benediction “until its (the moon’s) missing part is filled” and Rebbi Jacob bar Idi interprets this to mean that the appearance of the moon is no longer concave, i. e. that its visible circumference looks like a semicircle with its diameter (ascribed here to R. Jacob bar Aḥa). The people of Nehardea say, until after the 15th of the month, an interpretation which is more lenient than any opinion expressed here.</i>: Until it is seen like half a stick. Rebbi Aḥa and Rebbi Ḥinena in the name of Rebbi Yose: Until its missing part is filled. The rabbis of Caesarea say, until the fourteenth day. Rebbi Yose bar Abun said, that is correct; the missing part is never filled before the fourteenth day. Hence, all fourteen days one needs to recite the benediction.
In prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Musaph</i> prayer of the day of the New Moon.</i>, Rebbi Yose bar Nahorai said: “He Who sanctifies Israel, renews months.” Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said: “He Who sanctifies Israel and the New Moon.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">This is the Babylonian version, given by a Babylonian.</i>” Samuel said, one must say “bestow on us<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">The formula used on holidays to introduce the final paragraph of the middle benediction of the <i>Amidah</i>: “Bestow on us, o Eternal, our God, the blessing of Your holiday.” There is no mention of this and the following statement of Rav in any Babylonian source. Even though this might indicate concurrence of the Babli, the requirements of Samuel and Rav are not followed. [The Yerushalmi prayer texts from the Cairo Genizah show the <i>Musaph</i> Amidah of the days of the New Moon following the text of the holiday Amidah.]</i>.” Rav said, one must mention “time.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Recite on the day of New Moon the benediction: “Praise to You, Eternal, our God, King of the Universe, Who made us live, sustained us, and let us reach this time.”</i>” Rebbi Hoshaya stated: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:14" href="/Genesis.1.14"><i>Gen.</i> 1:14</a>) “They should be for signs and appointed times, days and years.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">The explanation is given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 6:3" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.6.3"><i>Bereshit rabba</i> 6(3</a>): “They shall be for signs”, these are the Sabbaths, “and appointed times,” these are the holidays of pilgrimage, “days,” these are the days of the New Moon, “and years,” that is the sanctification of years. [The Sabbath is called a sign in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 31:13" href="/Exodus.31.13"><i>Ex.</i> 31:13</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 31:17" href="/Exodus.31.17">17</a>. The sanctification of years is the solemn declaration of a Jubilee year by the Synhedrion.] In this interpretation, the days of the New Moon are on the same level as holidays.</i>”
What says he who passes between graves<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 58a" href="/Berakhot.58a">Babli (58a</a>) quotes a <i>baraita</i> that parallels the statement of R. Ḥanina here. An addition in the name of Rav Naḥman gives the second text of R. Yoḥanan here. The conclusion is simply “He Who makes the dead live.” In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:6" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.6">Tosephta (6:6</a>), the text is that of R.
