Yoḥanan with the longer conclusion of R. Yoḥanan. The medieval quotes of these texts differ widely, cf. <i>Diqduqe Soferim Berakhot</i> p. 330, <i>Toseftakifshutah Berakhot</i> p. 109. It seems that the original benediction was simply: Praised are You, Eternal, Who makes the dead live. The longer texts are additions of Tannaïm of the last and Amoraïm of the first generations.</i>? Praised are You, Eternal, Who makes the dead live. Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Here and in the following it is always R. Ḥiyya bar Abba.</i> in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Who is true to His word and makes the dead live. Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: He Who knows your number will wake you up and remove the dust from upon your eyes. Praised are You, Eternal, Who makes the dead live. Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Who created You by judgment, fed you by judgment, and removed you by judgment, He will in the future make you live by judgment. He Who knows your number will remove the dust from upon your eyes. Praised be He Who makes the dead live. That is, for Jewish dead. But for the dead of the Gentiles, he says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 50:12" href="/Jeremiah.50.12"><i>Jer.</i> 50:12</a>): Your mother is very shameful, the one who bore you is ashamed<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">The end of the verse is: “Lo, the future of the Gentiles is desert, wilderness and steppe,” not the blissful afterlife. The Babli quotes the same verse.</i> ….
He who sees the rainbow in the clouds says: Praised are You, Eternal, Who remembers the Covenant. Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: Who is faithful to His Covenant and remembers the Covenant<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">This is the formulation of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:5" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.5">Tosephta (6:5</a>); the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 59a" href="/Berakhot.59a">Babli (59a</a>) has a different formulation from a <i>baraita</i>. The formula is not original with R. Yoḥanan; he simply chose one among several that were current.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah: No rainbow was seen all the days of Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Since the rainbow is a sign that God will not bring a deluge over humankind even though their misdeeds would justify it; one single perfectly just person does by his existence exclude the possibility of a deluge and, therefore, the rainbow does not have to appear in his lifetime. It follows that a person in whose lifetime (probably meaning, from age 20 and onward) a rainbow is sighted cannot be perfect. This paragraph is inserted as addition to the topic of the rainbow.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah: Rebbi Simeon bar Yoḥai used to say, “Valley, valley, get filled with gold denars,” and it got filled<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Simeon is the only Tanna (except Simeon ben Azai who died very young) about whom it is reported positively that he spent <i>all</i> his time in the study of Torah and did not earn money. Since it has been shown in the story of Jonathan ben Gershom that one may not take money from charity or contributions if one can avoid it at all, it is clear that he must have lived off his own money; otherwise he could not have been a just person.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah: Rebbi Simeon bar Yoḥai used to say, I saw the people of the Future World and they are few<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 45b" href="/Sukkah.45b">Babli (<i>Sukkah</i> 45b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 97b" href="/Sanhedrin.97b"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 97b</a>) explains that this refers only to the highest state attainable in the Future World. This is also implied by the rest of the paragraph where R. Simeon declares that he can bring practically everybody to the Future World. [It is obvious that in both places in the Babli, one has to read “Rebbi Ḥizqiah” instead of “Ḥizqiah” (in the current text), who would be the son of Rebbi Ḥiyya, preceding R. Jeremiah by two generations.]</i>. If they are three, I and my son are of them. If they are two, they are me and my son. Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah: Rebbi Simeon bar Yoḥai used to say, Abraham should bring near from his back to my back<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Rescue everybody from punishment and bring him to the Future world.</i>; I shall bring near from my back to the end of all generations. Otherwise, Aḥiya from Shiloh<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Seder Olam</i>, Chapter 1, end.</i> should join me and I shall bring everybody near.
What reason did they have to take together<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mishnah, having the same formula of thanks for good news and winter rain.</i> good news and rains? Rebbi Berekhiah in the name of Rebbi Lewi: Because of (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 25:25" href="/Proverbs.25.25"><i>Pr.</i> 25:25</a>) “cold water on a weary person and good news from a distant land.”
How<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The almost exact parallel is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 1:3:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.1.3.2-8"><i>Taäniot</i> 1:3</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 13:16" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.13.16"><i>Bereshit rabba</i> 13(16</a>). The text here follows the one in Taänit where it is supported by the Rome manuscript.</i> much rain should fall that a man is required to recite a benediction? Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: At the start<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">After it was dry for at least thirty days (in the Middle East, usually for six months.)</i>, that it should fertilize<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">The definition is discussed in the second paragraph after this one.</i>, at the end that the surface should be wet<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Taänit</i> and <i>Bereshit rabba</i>, “that a brick should be wet.”</i>. Rebbi Yannai ben Ismael in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: At the start, that it should fertilize, at the end that the seal of the amphora should be soaked<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Wine and oil were kept in clay amphoras (חבית) that were closed with clumps of clay. The measure is that the clay should become wet inside.</i>. Is the seal ever soaked? But it is as if it were soaked. Rebbi Yose in the name of Rav Yehudah, Rebbi Jonah, Rav Yehudah in the name of Samuel: At the start, that it should fertilize, atthe end even a minimal amount. Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Zeïra: It was said for fast days<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">If there was a draught and a fast-day was decreed, when it has started to rain in the night before services begin in the synagogue, one stops and eats if there was enough rain to fertilize the earth. If they already started to recite the liturgy for fast days during daytime, then one stops according to one of the rules given above. [The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 25b" href="/Taanit.25b">Babli, <i>Taänit</i> 25b</a>, knows only of the rule of fertilizing.]</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Naḥum, and Rav Ada bar Abimi<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">He is mentioned only here.</i> were sitting. Rebbi Naḥum said to Rav Ada bar Abimi: Is it not reasonable that this was said for the benediction; he answered: Yes. Rebbi Ḥizqiah said to Rav Ada bar Abimi: Is it not reasonable that this was said for fast days; he answered: Yes. He said to him, why did you say “yes” here? He said to him, it is the argumentation of my teacher. Rebbi Mana asked Rebbi Ḥizqiah, who is his teacher? He said to him, Rebbi Zeïra. He said to him, but we say: Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Zeïra: It was said for fast days<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">The rules have been formulated for fast days only.</i>.
Rav Yehudah bar Ezechiel<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rav Yehudah who is frequently quoted in both Talmudim. The texts given are only an introduction to the doxology required by the Mishnah, “He Who is good and does good.” In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 6b" href="/Taanit.6b">Babli (<i>Taänit</i> 6b</a>), Rav Yehudah quotes a shorter text in the name of Rav. A longer text, patterned on the benediction after the recitation of Psalms on Sabbath and holidays with a different final doxology, is reported there in the name of R. Yoḥanan. It seems that long texts were never accepted in Galilee.</i> said, my father used to recite for rainfall: May Your Name be magnified, sanctified, praised, and elevated, our King, for every drop that You bring down to us, and you make them refrain one from the other. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 36:27" href="/Job.36.27"><i>Job</i> 36:27</a>) “For He reduces water drippings;” as one says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:18" href="/Leviticus.27.18"><i>Lev.</i> 27:18</a>): “Your value will be reduced.” Rebbi Yudan said, not only that, but He brings them down in measure, as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 28:25" href="/Job.28.25"><i>Job</i> 28:25</a>): “Water He determined by measure.” Rebbi Yose bar Jacob<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">He always is quoted together with R. Yudan of Migdal; he might be R. Yose bar Jacob bar Idi mentioned in Midrashim.</i> went to visit Rebbi Yudan from Migdal<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the fourth generation, living in Migdal Nunia North of Tiberias.</i>. While he was there, rain started to come down and he heard his (R. Yudan’s) voice saying: Thousands of thousands and myriads of myriads we are obliged to thank Your Name, our King, for every drop that You bring down to us, for You do good things for the guilty ones. He said to him: From where do you have this? He said to him: This is the benediction that Rebbi Simon recited for rainfall.
How<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">There are two parallel traditions, both of Galilean origin. The text here is almost identical with <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Taanit (Lieberman) 1:4" href="/Tosefta_Taanit_(Lieberman).1.4">Tosephta <i>Taäniot</i> 1:4</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 25b" href="/Taanit.25b">Babli (<i>Taänit</i> 25b</a>) and the Yerushalmi source <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 13:13" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.13.13"><i>Bereshit rabba</i> 13(13</a>), Rebbi Meïr is reported to require that the rains penetrate the depth of the penetration of the plough-share (which is assumed to be three hand-breadths,) whereas R. Yehudah says that for dry earth, one hand-breadth was enough, for average ground two hand-breadths, and for well worked ground, three hand-breadths. If these are two equivalent formulations, then the text here has to be interpreted in the light of the text in Babli/Midrash: Not that R. Meïr requires a rainfall of three hand-breadths (10.8 inches) in one storm (or R. Yehudah rainfalls of 3.6, 7.2, 10.8 inches, respectively) but that the moisture has to penetrate the earth to the depth indicated. In that case, “dry earth” is simply the earth after the rainless summer months, average earth is the earth after the first winter storms, and well worked ground is the earth after an uninterrupted rain of seven days (the first, second, and third fertilizing periods in the language of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Taanit (Lieberman) 1:4" href="/Tosefta_Taanit_(Lieberman).1.4">Tosephta <i>Taäniot</i> 1:4</a>). R. Simeon ben Eleazar seems to object to both R. Meïr and R. Yehudah because rain will make the ground water level rise by twice the amount of rain water; hence, moisture in the ground can come from below as well as from above. One must assume that in the Yerushalmi also the measurements are those of moist spots in the earth and not of rainfall in the modern sense.</i> much rain should fall that it is considered fertilizing? If it fills a vessel of three hand-breadths, the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rebbi Yehudah says, the first rainfall one hand-breadth, the second one two hand breadths, and the third one three hand-breadths. It has been stated: Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar says, there is no hand-breadth that falls from above that the earth does not raise two hand-breadths towards it. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 42:8" href="/Psalms.42.8"><i>Ps.</i> 42:8</a>) “The deep calls to the deep<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi explains in Babli <i>Taänit</i> that clouds also are called “deep”.</i> by the sound of Your water spouts.”
And Rebbi Levi said: The upper waters are male and the lower ones female. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 45:8" href="/Isaiah.45.8"><i>Is.</i> 45:8</a>)<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">The verse starts: “The heavens should pour down from high, and the skies should flow with justice,” speaking of rain. The Babli has two contradictory sermons in this matter. Rav Yehudah is reported in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 6b" href="/Taanit.6b"><i>Taänit</i> 6b</a> that rain is the earth’s husband because in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 55:10" href="/Isaiah.55.10"><i>Is.</i> 55:10</a> it is said that rain makes the earth give birth, while Rebbi Abbahu (there and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 59b" href="/Berakhot.59b"><i>Berakhot</i> 59b</a>) says that a benediction is recited only if “the bridegroom goes towards the bride,” meaning that drops jump up from the earth towards the descending rain. [This is the traditional interpretation, given by Ashkenazic Rabbenu Gershom and Sephardic Rabbenu Ḥanan‘el. Rashi, sensing the apparent contradiction, has a prosaic interpretation, that on both sides of the street the gutters will spout water one towards the other.]</i> “The earth shall open,” like a female who opens before a male; “they should bear fruit of help,” that is being fruitful and multiplying; “and justice shall sprout together,” that is rainfall; “I, the Eternal, did create it,” for that I created it, for the well-being of the world. Rebbi Aḥa stated it in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">This is the end of Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar’s text in Tosephta <i>Taäniot</i>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 6b" href="/Taanit.6b">Babli (<i>Taänit</i> 6b</a>), this passage appears as a statement of the Amora Rebbi Abbahu.</i>: Why is it called “fertilizing,” because it impregnates the earth.
Rebbi Ḥanina bar Yaqqa<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the third generation who studied under Rav Yehudah in Babylonia and only reports sayings of Rav Yehudah. The paragraph has three parallels, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 1:3:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.1.3.2-8">Yerushalmi <i>Taäniot</i> 1:3</a>, <i>Avodah zarah</i> 3:6, Midrash <i>Bereshit rabba</i> 13(19). In <i>Taäniot</i>, the name is R. Ḥanania bar Yaqqa, in <i>Avodah zarah</i> it is R. Ḥaninah bar Yasa, and in the Midrash it is R. Ḥanina ben R. ‘Izqa in the name of Rebbi (!) Yehudah.</i> in the name of Rav Yehudah: The roots of wheat split the earth to a depth of 50 cubits. The soft roots of a fig tree split rock. It has been stated: Rebbi Ismael ben Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Taäniot</i> and <i>Avodah zara</i>, as well as here in the Rome ms., correctly R. Simeon ben Eleazar; in the printed Midrash R. Eleazar ben R. Simeon, R. Simeon ben Eleazar in manuscripts.</i> says, the earth drinks only according to its hardness<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">The harder the soil, the less it is penetrated by moisture.</i>. If this is so, what do the roots of the carob do? What do the roots of the sycamore do<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">These trees grow mainly wild, mostly in places unsuited for more delicate fruit trees because of the hardness of the soil. Their roots are very deep.</i>? Rebbi Ḥanina said, once every thirty days the abyss wells up and drenches them. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 27:3" href="/Isaiah.27.3"><i>Is.</i> 27:3</a>) “I, the Eternal, watch over it<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">The desirable vineyard.</i> and water it in moments.”
Rebbi Zeïra<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Here starts the discussion of the last part of the Mishnah, what to recite for good news and what for bad news. One has first to define good and bad news.</i> said, it is stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia.</i>: If one notices cheapness<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Falling prices for consumers, disinflation.</i> coming to the world, plenty coming to the world, or a river supplying<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">A river (or, in Babylonian terms, an arm of a river) changing its course and now suppliying a town with flowing water when before they had to draw water from wells. In Israel, rivers are not fed by melting snow, so this kind of spring flood does not happen there; it is truly a Babylonian formulation.</i> a city, one recites: He Who is good and does good.
If he was told that his father had died, he says: “Praise to the True Judge.” He died and made him an heir, he says: “Praise to Him Who is good and does good<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Here starts the discussion of the last part (in the Mishnah collection, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.3.1">Mishnah 4</a>).</i>.”

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mishnah, this is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.3.1">Mishnah 4</a>. However, in the Halakhah, the discussion belongs to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:2:2-3:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.2.2-3.7">Halakhah 3</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:3:8-9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.3.8-9">Halakhot 4</a>,5,6,7 belong to Mishnayot 5,6,7,8, respectively. The numbering of Mishnayot has been changed to correspond to that of the Halakhot.</i> If one built a new house or bought new garments, he says: Praise to Him Who let us reach this time. One recites the benediction for bad news containing good and for good ones containing bad<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is not commented on in the Halakhah; hence, the translation follows the interpretation of the Babli: If his crop was ruined by a flood that deposited a layer of new earth on his field, it is bad news now and requires the benediction for bad news, even though he will gain an advantage when it is time to plant next year’s crop.</i>. <br>But if one cries about the past, that is a vain prayer. How is that? If his wife was pregnant and he said: May it be (God’s) pleasure that my wife would give birth to a male, that is a vain prayer. If he came from a trip, heard wailing in town, and said: May it be (God’s) pleasure that this should not be in my house, that is a vain prayer.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If one built a new house or bought new garments, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Here starts the discussion of the last part (in the Mishnah collection, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.3.1">Mishnah 4</a>).</i>” Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said: Not only new ones, but even used ones if they are new for him<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">If he cannot afford to buy new ones, second hand clothes have the same status for him as new ones for a richer person. [In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 59b-60a" href="/Berakhot.59b-60a">Babli, 59b–60a</a>, the Babylonian opinion is that (for rich Babylonians) one only makes a benediction for genuinely new articles, not for a new set of what he already has, whereas the opinion of the less wealthy Galileans is that any new garment deserves a benediction.]</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Zavdi said in the name of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: If he bought [a garment], he says: “Praise to Him Who made us live, preserved us, and let us reach this time.” If it was given to him, he says: “Praise to Him Who is good and does good.” Rebbi Abba, father of Rebbi Abba Mari, in the name of Rebbi Aḥa: If he bought, he says: “Praise to Him Who let us reach this time.” If it was given to him, he says: “Praise to Him Who is good and does good.” If he wears the garment, he says: “Praise to Him Who clothes the naked.”
He<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">There is a similar statement in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:9" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.9">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 6:9</a> which is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 46a" href="/Sukkah.46a">Babli <i>Sukkah</i> 46a</a>; the note about the benediction when making a <i>sukkah</i> or <i>lulav</i> for somebody else is found only here. Hence, the source here is not the Tosephta which also starts with a general declaration that: “A person performing any <i>miẓwah</i> recites a benediction over it.” The practice of the Babli does not follow the discussion in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 46a" href="/Sukkah.46a"><i>Sukkah</i> 46a</a> but a statement in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 42b" href="/Menachot.42b"><i>Menaḥot</i> 42b</a> that no benediction is due for a preparatory action, such as making the <i>sukkah</i> or the <i>lulav</i>, but only for the required act itself such as living in the <i>sukkah</i> or taking the <i>lulav</i>.</i> who makes a <i>sukkah</i> for himself, says: “He Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us to make a <i>sukkah</i>.” For others: “to make a <i>sukkah</i> in that one’s name<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">The usual interpretation is that one makes the benediction: “To make a <i>sukkah</i>” and that the person has in mind the name of the person for whom he is doing it. It seems rather that one has to pronounce the recipient’s name at the place reserved for לשמו.</i>.” If he enters it, he says: “Praise to Him Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us to dwell in a <i>sukkah</i>.” After he recited the benediction in the first night of the holiday he does not have to recite it again<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>), this is the opinion of the Babylonian Samuel, supported by the Tosephta. In the name of the Galilean R. Yoḥanan, it is reported that one has to recite the benediction every day. Since R. Yohanan is a higher authority than Samuel, Babylonian practice followed what there is declared to be Galilean.</i>. He who makes a <i>lulav</i> for himself, says: “He Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us to make a <i>lulav</i>.” For others: “to make a <i>lulav</i> in that one’s name.” If he uses it, he says: “Praise to Him Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us to take a <i>lulav</i>,” and “He Who let us live.” He recites the benediction every time that he takes it<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">The difference between <i>sukkah</i> and <i>lulav</i> has been explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:3:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.3.2-11">Halakhah 3:3</a>.</i>.
He who makes a <i>mezuzah</i> for himself, says “to make a <i>mezuzah</i>.” For somebody else, “to make a <i>mezuzah</i> for his name.” When he nails it to the doorpost, he recites: “Praise to Him Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us to about <i>mezuzah</i>.” He who makes <i>tefillin</i> for himself<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">“Praise to You, o Eternal, our God, King of the Universe, Who has sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us to make <i>tefillin</i>.”</i>, etc. For somebody else, etc. When he puts them on, he says “about the commandment of <i>tefillin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">The tannaïtic text of the Yerushalmi here clearly requires only one benediction when both <i>tefillin</i> are put on, in contrast to the amoraïc text of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 2:3:2-19" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.2.3.2-19">Halakhah 2:3</a>, that requires two benedictions, one for <i>tefillin</i> on the arm and one for the head. Similarly, the discussion below on the timing of benedictions is based on having only one benediction. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:10" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.10">Tosephta (6:10</a>), representing the Babylonian text as always, does not have the notes on working for somebody else and requires here the formula “to put on <i>tefillin</i>,” which is the main benediction in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 42b" href="/Menachot.42b">Babli (<i>Menaḥot</i> 42b</a>), followed in Sephardic practice.</i>” He who makes <i>ẓiẓit</i> for himself, etc. For somebody else etc. When he wraps himself in them, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">He says, “Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us about the commandment of <i>ẓiẓit</i>.” The Babylonian formula is “to wrap ourselves in <i>ẓiẓit</i>.”</i>. He who separates <i>terumah</i> and tithes says: “Praise to Him Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us to separate <i>terumah</i> and tithes.” For somebody else, “to separate <i>terumah</i> and tithes for his name.” He who slaughters must say: “Praise to You, Eternal, our God, King of the Universe, Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us about <i>šeḥitah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that the Yerushalmi chooses the wording “about”, על, if the action must be done by the person who pronounces the benediction, but “to”, ל, if the action is done in delegation.</i>.” He who covers [the blood<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Of slaughtered fowl and wild animals, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 17:13" href="/Leviticus.17.13"><i>Lev.</i> 17:13</a>.</i>] says, “about covering the blood.”
He<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:12" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.12">Tosephta 6:12</a> and in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 127b" href="/Shabbat.127b">Babli <i>Sabbath</i> 127b</a>. The text of the Tosephta is closer to the Babli than to the Yerushalmi.</i> who circumcizes must say: “Praised Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us about circumcision.” The child’s father says: “Praised Who sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us to induce him into the covenant of our forefather Abraham.” Those who are standing there must say: “Just as you made him enter the covenant, so make him enter Torah and the marriage canopy<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta and Babli add: “and good deeds.” The Rome manuscript has only “the marriage canopy.”</i>.” He who recites the benediction must say: “Praised Who sanctified the beloved<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">The commentators of the Babli have identified the “beloved” as either Abraham, Isaac, or Jacob. The text of the Babli is slightly longer than that of Yerushalmi and Tosephta.</i> from the womb, Who put a statute in his flesh, and sealed his descendants with a holy sign of covenant; therefore, as a reward for this, o living God, our part, our rock, command to save the beloved of our flesh from destruction. Praised are You, o Eternal, Who seals the covenant.”
When does one recite the benediction for commandments? Rebbi Yoḥanan said, just before he starts doing them<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">The Babylonian tradition (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 7b" href="/Pesachim.7b"><i>Pesaḥim</i> 7b</a>) is: “Everybody agrees that one makes the benediction beforehand, as Rav Yehudah said in the name of Samuel: On all commandments one recites the benediction just before he starts doing them.” This tradition must be later when the authority of R. Yoḥanan overrode earlier Babylonian practices.</i>. Rav Huna said, when he does it. Rav Huna agrees with Samuel, since Rebbi Yose bar Abun said in the name of Samuel: All commandments need a benediction while one is doing them except blowing<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">The shofer on <i>Rosh Hashanah</i>, sine obviously one cannot blow and recite the benediction at the same time.</i> and immersion<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">In the <i>miqweh</i>, when one is naked and forbidden to recite a benediction. The Yerushalmi requires a benediction before immersion. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 7b" href="/Pesachim.7b">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 7b</a>), the statement about blowing and immersion is an addition to the statement that all benedictions must precede the action. It is clear that the mention of blowing in that context makes no sense; that statement is then dropped and only immersion is left for a benediction <i>after</i> the act. The Yerushalmi shows that in the Babli we have a later confluence of older (Rav Huna) Babylonian tradition with the adoption of Galilean (R. Yoḥanan) practice by the editors of the Talmud.</i>, and, some say, <i>qiddušin</i> by sexual relations<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Qiddušin</i> is the first stage of a marriage in which the bride becomes bound to the husband, in preparation for <i>ḥuppah</i>, which lets the couple live together. Usually, <i>qiddušin</i> is effected by the groom giving a valuable gift (usually a gold ring) to the bride. But the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.1.1">Mishnah (<i>Qiddušin</i> 1:1</a>) lists sexual relations (in front of two witnesses) as a possible form of <i>qiddušin</i>. One may assume that in Israel this option was never used. In Babylonia it seems to have been used since the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 12b" href="/Kiddushin.12b">Babli (<i>Qiddušin</i> 12b</a>) reports that Rav had people whipped (for indecent exposure) who married by public sex act. In any case, the required benediction cannot be pronounced while the parties are naked.</i>. Rebbi Jonah said, you have others: <i>Tefillin</i> on the hand before he takes them off, and on the head before he puts<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">The spelling ייבה is dialectal for יהבה, root <i>yhb</i> “to give.”</i> them on<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">As noted before, the text presumes that only one benediction is required for the two <i>tefillin</i> and, as explained earlier (2:3), in Galilee a benediction was recited when <i>tefillin</i> were taken off. Since the Torah mentions <i>ṭoṭaphot</i> (<i>tefillin</i>) on the hand always before those on the head, one must put on first those for the arm and take off first those for the head. Even Rav Huna agrees that the benediction for removal was recited before <i>tefillin</i> were removed from the arm and the one for putting them on was recited before those of the head were put on.</i>. Before he puts them on? When he puts on<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>tefillin</i> on the arm and on the head are always mentioned together in one verse, the putting on (or taking off) of both is one act and the recitation of the benediction covers both <i>tefillin</i>.</i>, he puts them on!
When does one recite the benediction for <i>šeḥiṭah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Since ritual slaughter is a commandment, its execution requires a benediction.</i>? Rebbi Yoḥanan says, if he prepares to slaughter. Yose ben Nehorai<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">A Palestinian authority of the first generation of Amoraïm, one of the teachers of R. Joḥanan.</i> says, after he slaughtered. Why? Maybe its slaughtering is producing a carcass<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">If during the act of slaughter, one of the technical rules was violated (for example, if pressure was exerted on the knife), the animal was not slaughtered but killed in a way that makes its meat unfit for consumption; then the benediction would have been in vain.</i>. Now, should he not first check the signs<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, only esophagus and windpipe are called “signs”; the tiniest of holes in the esophagus makes an animal <i>terepha</i>, “torn” and unfit for consumption. The Yerushalmi seems to extend the meaning of “signs” to all internal organs, especially lungs and the digestive system, holes of which render an animal unfit for consumption. The question here is: why not wait with the benediction until the entire animal has been dissected and checked for possible <i>terepha</i>?</i>? The <i>ḥazaqah</i> of intestines is that they are in order<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Since we do not have a Yerushalmi on tractate <i>Ḥulin</i>, the interpretation here by necessity has to follow the Babylonian tradition. The position of the latter has been formulated by Rav Huna: A living animal is in the continuing state (<i>ḥazaqah</i>) of being forbidden until it has been ascertained that it was correctly slaughtered; once it has been correctly slaughtered, it is in the continuing state (<i>ḥazaqah</i>) of being permitted food until it has been ascertained whether and why it is <i>terepha</i>. If the slaughter was ascertained to be correct and inner parts were then taken by an animal before they were checked, the meat remains permitted food.</i>. It was stated: If it was slaughtered and the wolves took its innards, it is in order<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">As kosher food.</i>. Should one question whether they were pierced<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">If the intestines were later retrieved in a torn state, could it not be that the intestines of the living animal had a hole there where the wolves bit, and this <i>terepha</i> cannot now be ascertained?</i>? Rebbi Abba in the name of the rabbis from there<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">It is reported in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 9a" href="/Chullin.9a">Babli <i>Ḥulin</i> 9a</a> that Rebbi Abba asked precisely this question from Rav Huna.</i>: Intestines have <i>ḥazaqah</i> that they are in order<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">The entire discussion seems to suggest that the Yerushalmi follows Yose ben Nehorai. The problem is not mentioned in the Babli, but it is assumed there and in the halakhic literature that one follows Rebbi Yoḥanan (except in the case of an emergency slaughter when the opinion of Yose ben Nehorai is considered.)</i>.
In the house of Yannai they said, if she is sitting on the birthing stool. Hence, before that he should pray, because of (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 18:6" href="/Jeremiah.18.6"><i>Jer.</i> 18:6</a>) “Lo, like clay in the potter’s hand<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">“… Are you in My hand, House of Israel.” This seems to imply, in the opinion of the Yerushalmi, that for Gentiles the laws of nature will not be changed and the sex of the child is determined at conception, or, in the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60a" href="/Berakhot.60a">Babli (60a</a>), in extraordinary cases at least during the first 40 days of pregnancy when the fetus is not yet a living being. The Babli declares that in all cases, the laws of nature prevail and that the sex change of Dinah is no proof since “one does not bring a proof from miracles.” It would be presumptuous for anybody to assume that he is on the level of the Patriarchs for whom God used to perform wonders.</i> …” Rebbi Yehudah ben Pazi<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">The name is missing here in the Venice print and the Leyden manuscript. It is given in the Rome manuscript and the parallel <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 72:6" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.72.6"><i>Bereshit rabba</i> 72(6</a>). In the latter source, R. Jehudah ben Pazi is in opposition to the house of Rebbi Yannai and says that even if labor has started, as long as the baby is not born one may pray because of the verse from Jeremiah.</i> in the name of the house of Yannai: The main pregnancy of Dinah was as a male. After the prayer of Rachel, she became a female. That is (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 30:21" href="/Genesis.30.21"><i>Gen.</i> 30:21</a>): “Afterwards, she gave birth to a daughter and called her name Dinah.” After the prayer of Rachel, she became a female. And Rebbi Yehudah ben Pazi in the name of the house of Rebbi Yannai: Our mother Rachel was of the early prophetesses<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">In both versions of the <i>Tanḥuma</i> (Buber <i>Wayeẓe</i> 19, Standard <i>Wayeẓe</i> 8), Leah was the prophetess who knew that Jacob would have 12 sons and if she had 7 sons then her sister would be left with only one son, less than any of the maids. She therefore prayed that her pregnancy should be that of a girl. All Midrashim derive the name of Dinah not from דין “law, lawsuit”, but from די “enough”, meaning “we already have enough boys.”</i>. She said, another one will be from me. That is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 30:24" href="/Genesis.30.24"><i>Gen.</i> 30:24</a>): “May the Eternal add me another son.” She did not say <i>other sons</i>, but <i>another son</i> will be from me.
If he returns from a trip, what does he say<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">When he hears wailing in town and cannot pray that it should not be in his house.</i>: I am sure that these are not in my house. Hillel the elder said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 112:7" href="/Psalms.112.7"><i>Ps.</i> 112:7</a>): “He will not be afraid of bad news.”

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He who enters a fortified place<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Greek χάραξ “palisade”. A Roman fortified camp with soldiers and police not under the control of the local authorities.</i> prays two prayers, one when he enters and one when he leaves. Ben Azai said four, two when he enters and two when he leaves. He gives thanks for the past and implores for the future.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “He who enters a fortified place says two prayers, one when he enters and one when he leaves.” What does he say when he enters? May it be Your pleasure, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that You will bring me into this fortress for peace. When he leaves, he says: May it be Your pleasure, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, etc. “Ben Azai said four, two when he enters and two when he leaves.” When he is about to enter, he says: May it be Your pleasure, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that You will bring me into this fortress for peace. After he entered, he says: I thank You, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that I entered in peace; so may it be Your pleasure that You will lead me out of it for peace. When he wants to leave, he says: May it be Your pleasure, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that You will lead me out from this fortress in peace. When he left, he says: I thank You, o Eternal, my God and God of my fathers, that You made me leave in peace; so may it be Your pleasure that You will lead me to my house for peace (or, to place X for peace.)<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">There are parallels to these prayers in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:16" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.16">Tosephta (6:16</a>) and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60a" href="/Berakhot.60a">Babli (60a</a>). The Tosephta has only three prayers: Before entry, after entry and after exit. It is to be noted that in the version of the Yerushalmi, the prayer after entry really is also a prayer for safe exit and the third prayer repeats the second part of the prayer after safe entry. The printed version of the Babli has four prayers; the prayer after safe entry only gives thanks for that and is not a prospective prayer for safe exit. This would best be described by the words of Ben Azai. The Spanish print in <i>Śeridei Bavli</i> (Dimitrovsky) fol. 49 has only two prayers, corresponding to the opinion of the first Tanna in the Mishnah, which is disregarded in the other versions: “What does he say when he enters? May it be Your pleasure, o Eternal, my God, that you will let me leave this fortress for peace. When he left, he says: I thank You that You guided me out of this fortress for peace, and just as You led me out in peace, so let me travel in peace, lead me in peace, and save me from the hand of any enemy or ambush on the road. Praise to You, Eternal, Who listens to prayer.” The doxology that makes this a benediction is found only in the Spanish incunabula print and in <i>Kolbo</i> §87; it is expressly denied, in the tradition of the Babli, by Ravad (R. Abraham ben David of Posquières) in his critique of R. Zeraḥiah Halevi in <i>Alfassi</i>.</i> That means<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">This is an editorial note; in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60a" href="/Berakhot.60a">Babli (60a</a>) a slightly different version is attributed to Rav Mattanah. The prayer has to be said only if there is an actual danger in entering the fortress. The difference between Gentile and Jewish populations is not in the Babli; there the problem is the question whether “one judges and kills” in the fortress. In the first version, one does not have to recite the benediction if there are courts that enforce the laws by executing criminals; in the second version one has to recite the prayer anyhow since the police, when confronted with an unsolved crime, might be tempted to frame a stranger who, not knowing any good local lawyer, is in grave danger of being convicted. By contrast, so the interpretation of R. Abraham al-Ashbili, the Yerushalmi recommends the prayer even at a Jewish place if lawless and criminal elements there can kill with impunity.</i>, if it is inhabited by Gentiles, but if it is inhabited by Jews, he does not have to recite the benedictions. But if it was a place where they kill, even in a Jewish dwelling he must recite the benediction.
If one enters the toilet, he recites two benedictions<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">It really means “two prayers.”</i>, one before and one after. When he enters, what does he say? Honor<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">This is not a prayer but an address to the guardian angels who accompany everybody (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 91:11" href="/Psalms.91.11"><i>Ps.</i> 91:11</a>) that they should let him go alone to a place unworthy of their presence. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60b" href="/Berakhot.60b">Babli (60b</a>), Abbai objects to a similar version since it might imply permanent dismissal of the guardian angels.</i> to you, honored, holy servants, this is the way of the world, let me go. Praise to the God of glory! When he leaves, what does he say? Praise to Him Who created man in wisdom<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60b" href="/Berakhot.60b">Babli (60b</a>) has a much enlarged version. It may be that the version of the Yerushalmi is the complete text that was recited originally, but the Rome manuscript has a text similar to the Babylonian one: ברוּך אשר יצר את האדם בחכמה ועשיתה אותו נקבים נקבים חלולים חלולים כניניות כגיניות שאם יפתח אחד מהן אִפשר לו להחיות ברוּך רופא כל בשר ומפליא לעשות. “Praised Who created man in wisdom and You made him many orifices, many cavities, many secret places. If one of them were be opened it would be impossible to continue living. Praised Who heals all flesh and does wonders.”<br>The word כניניוֹת appears only here; in the form כונניות it is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 56b" href="/Chullin.56b">Babli <i>Ḥulin</i> 56b</a>. For the translation it was derived from Arabic כַּנִין “hiding places”. [Also compare Latin <i>cannula</i> “reed, pipe”. Since חלולים can mean “round pipes”, חלולים כניניות would be Semitic-Latinate synonyms “pipes-pipes” (E. G.).]</i>.
When one enters the thermal bath<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">A Roman thermal bath had a sauna room whose water was heated in a boiler room below. Sometimes the floor caved in from the continuous exposure to steam and hot water, and the bathers might fall into the open fire below.</i>, he prays twice; once on entering and once on leaving. When he enters, he says: “May it be Your pleasure, o Eternal, my God, that You may save me from being burned in fire, damaged by hot water or from collapse. Nothing should happen to me, but if it happens let my death be atonement for all my sins; save me from this and from the similar one<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">The fire of hell.</i> in the future world.” When he leaves, he says: “I thank You, o Eternal, my God, that You saved me from fire<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">There are parallels in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60a" href="/Berakhot.60a">Babli (60a</a>) and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:17" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.17">Tosephta (6:17</a>); the manuscripts of the Babli have widely diverging texts. The later Amoraïm in the Babli disapproved of the text of the prayer when entering, since one should not mention accidents lest they happen. This attitude is unknown to the Yerushalmi and mishnaic sources.</i>.” Rebbi Abbahu said, that is for a thermal bath which is heated. But in a thermal bath that is not<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">A geothermal bath, as in Tiberias.</i> heated, he says only “from damage by hot water”. Rebbi Ḥilqiah<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the fourth generation, student of R. Simon, from the region of Lod.</i> and Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: The prayer at a bathhouse does not require standing<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear whether it does not require standing up (i. e., not sitting) or not even standing still (i. e., not walking).</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One is required to recite a benediction for bad things the same way<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60b" href="/Berakhot.60b">Babli (60b</a>) points out that the Mishnah cannot mean that one has to use the same formula for bad news as for good since the opposite was declared in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:5:13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.5.13">Mishnah 3</a>. Here one talks only about the spirit in which the benedictions should be recited.</i> it is said for good things, as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:5" href="/Deuteronomy.6.5"><i>Deut.</i> 6:5</a>): “You must love the Eternal, your God, with all your heart, all your soul, and all your force.” “With all your heart,” with your two instincts, the goodinstinct and the bad instinct. “With all your soul,” even if He takes your soul. “With all your force,” with all your money. Another explanation: “With all your force,” for every measure<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">This sermon identifies the roots מאד “power, plenty”, מדד “measure,” ידה, מדה “thanking.” It supports the early grammarians who reduced Semitic roots to two letters.</i> that He measures for you, for everything thank him very much.<br>A person should not behave improperly before the Eastern gate, which lies in a straight line with the Holiest of Holies<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">The Eastern gate in the wall of the Temple Mount (which at the same time was the city wall) was in a straight line with the Eastern gate of the Temple courtyard, the Temple gate, and the Holiest of Holies, because the priest who was burning the red heifer on the Mount of Olives had to see the Temple door through the gate of the wall and the gate of the Temple court. One must assume that in Mishnaic times, the Temple itself was totally obliterated (since, after the war of Bar Kochba, Hadrian had constructed a temple of Jupiter on its site) but that the original Eastern gate was still there and the place of the Temple could be determined on a line perpendicular to the wall at that gate.</i>. And one should not enter the Temple Mount with his walking stick, sandals<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">All service by priests in the Temple had to be performed barefoot. Hence, also laymen entering the Temple precinct had to be barefoot. [To show the difference between the Temple and a synagogue, shoes may not be removed in a synagogue.]</i>, money belt<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>funda</i>.</i>, or dust on his feet<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">One may not enter with unwashed feet.</i>. Also one should not use it as a short cut<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>compendiaria</i> (<i>via</i>), cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.13">Chapter 1, Note 36</a>.</i>, and certainly not spit there. All endings of benedictions in the Temple were “from eternity<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">Instead of “Amen”, the answer to a benediction was “Praised be the Eternal, the God of Israel, from eternity”. This is the answer asserted to be given during the existence of the first Temple. When the second Temple was inaugurated, the formula was (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 9:5" href="/Nehemiah.9.5"><i>Neh.</i> 9:5</a>): “Praised be the Eternal, the God of Israel, from eternity to eternity,” to emphasize the two worlds, the existing one and the one to come. The heretics here cannot be Sadducees who started about three hundred years later; the Qumran documents show that it is totally false to impute a denial of the future world to Sadducees. [That “heretics” are called “Sadducees” in many editions of the Babli here is due to Christian censors who misunderstood the use of the word מין which in general, but not here, means “Christians.”]</i>.” When heretics did err and said that there was only one world, they ordained that one should say “from eternity to eternity.” They also instituted that one should greet his friend by the Name, as it was said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 2:4" href="/Ruth.2.4"><i>Ruth</i> 2:4</a>): “Lo, Boaz came from Bethlehem and said to the harvesters: The Eternal be with you!” And it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 23:22" href="/Proverbs.23.22"><i>Pr.</i> 23:22</a>): “Be not contemptuous because your mother got old.<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi in the Babli explains: Even though the action of Boaz looks wrong, since God’s name is used for wordly greeting, one should follow him since he is one of the elders of the people. In the verse, the harvesters answered: “May the Eternal bless you,” following Boas’s example.</i>” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 119:126" href="/Psalms.119.126"><i>Ps.</i> 119:126</a>) “It is time to work for the Eternal; they violated Your Torah.” Rebbi Nathan says, they<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">The men of the Great Assembly, who instituted the response to the benedictions in the Temple and the way of greeting in the Name of God, violated the prescription of the Torah that God’s name may not be taken in vain (i. e., for secular purposes) in order to further God’s work and to instill religious feelings in the people.</i> violated Your Torah, it is time to work for the Eternal.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Berekhia in the name of Rebbi Levi: <sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">One is required to recite a benediction for bad things the same way it is said for good things.</i> Because of (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 92:5" href="/Psalms.92.5"><i>Ps.</i> 92:5</a>) “You are always exalted, o Eternal!” Your position is always the strongest<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">This is a term from civil law; the person whose position is strongest is the one who does not have to prove his point, but the adversary has to. An example is a case in which one party bases its position on a written contract; the contract makes his position strongest.</i>. Usually in the world, if a king of flesh and blood sits in judgment, if he dismisses<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>dimissio</i>, throwing out the indictment.</i>, everybody acclaims him; if he sentences to execution<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>spiculum</i> “thorn, dart, pointed instrument; arrow”.</i>, everybody says bad things about him since he is sweeping in his sentences. But the Holy One, praise to Him, is not so, rather: “You are always exalted, o Eternal!” Your position is always the strongest.
Rebbi Ḥuna in the name of Rebbi Aḥa<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">In the printed edition of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60b" href="/Berakhot.60b">Babli (60b</a>), this homily of R. Aḥa is described as having R. Levi as first author. There are many other names given in manuscripts of the Babli.</i>: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 101:1" href="/Psalms.101.1"><i>Ps.</i> 101:1</a>) “A song of David. Kindness and justice I shall sing, to You, o Eternal, I shall chant.” David said before the Holy One, praise to Him: If You act in kindness towards me, I shall sing. If You act in judgment towards me, I shall sing. In any case, I shall chant.
Rebbi Tanḥuma ben Yehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">In the printed edition of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60b" href="/Berakhot.60b">Babli (60b</a>), this homily of R. Aḥa is described as having R. Levi as first author. There are many other names given in manuscripts of the Babli.</i> said, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 56:11" href="/Psalms.56.11"><i>Ps.</i> 56:11</a>) “In God I will praise words, in the Eternal<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">The name “God”, majestic plural of <i>ēl</i> “power”, is always interpreted in the Talmud as “the measure of justice” acting by the immovable laws of the Creation. “Eternal” is traditionally interpreted as designating God the Merciful, Whose mercy is not subject to natural law.</i> I will praise words.” On measures of judgment as on measures of mercy I shall praise words.
But the sages<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 60b" href="/Berakhot.60b">Babli (60b</a>) this is ascribed to R. Tanḥum, the following statement of R. Yudan bar Pelaiah is attributed to “rabbis”.</i> say (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 116:13" href="/Psalms.116.13"><i>Ps.</i> 116:13</a>): “I lift the cup of salvation, I call on the Name of the Eternal, trouble and sorrow I will find, but on the Name of the Eternal I shall call.” Whatever may happen to me, I shall call on the Name of the Eternal. Rebbi Yudan bar Pelaya<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">A late Amora, student of R. Jonah, whose name is frequently corrupted in Talmud and Midrashim.</i> said: This is what Job said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 1:21" href="/Job.1.21"><i>Job</i> 1:21</a>): “The Eternal gave, and the Eternal took, may the Name of the Eternal be praised!” When He gave, He gave in mercy; when He took, He took in mercy. In addition, when He gave, He did not consult anybody, but when He took, He consulted His Court<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">The proof is in the next sentence. The text is elliptic and one has to add: “As R. Eleazar said” (three generations before R. Yudan; otherwise the homilies are arranged chronologically.) The court is the Heavenly Court of Law.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said, everwhere it says “<i>and</i> the Eternal” it means Him and His Court. The paradigm<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Literally “Father’s building.” The theory behind this expression is that each word in the Torah has a unique meaning. If the meaning of a term is clear in one verse, “this built a father for all occurrences of this word,” one of the hermeneutical rules of R. Ismael for the understanding of the Torah. Its validity is extended to all of the Bible as rule #8 of the 32 rules of R. Eliezer, son of R. Yose the Galilean.</i> of this is (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 22:23" href="/I_Kings.22.23"><i>1K.</i> 22:23</a>): “And the Eternal spoke woe over you<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">The prophecy of Michaihu starts with his vision of the Eternal surrounded by all the Hosts of Heaven.</i>.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">This and the next paragraphs are from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:3:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.3.2-4"><i>Soṭa</i> 5:5</a>; in the transcription the introductory sentences were lost. There, the question is raised that one verse in Deuteronomy says: “You must love the Eternal, your God,” as quoted in our Mishnah, but another verse declares: “The Eternal, your God, you must fear.” How does one square these two verses? The answer is that both are required, as explained in the following.</i> Act from love and act from fear. Act from love, because if you are tempted to hate<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">The obligations that the Jewish religion puts upon you.</i>, know that you must love and a lover is no hater. Act from fear, because if you are tempted to rebel, know that you must fear and one who fears does not rebel.
There are seven kinds of religious people<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">The same list appears in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:3:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.3.2-4">Yerushalmi <i>Soṭa</i> 5:5</a>; a slightly different list with completely different interpretations in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 22b" href="/Sotah.22b">Babli <i>Soṭa</i> 22b</a> declares explicitly that the first five are “destroyers of the world.” In the Yerushalmi, it is clear that the first five are considered in a negative light but they are still considered better than one who performs no commandments whatsoever.<br>פרוּש “Pharisee” is the designation of anybody who separates himself from impurity; in particular, one who follows the teachings of the rabbis.</i>: Religious on the shoulder, religious on credit, religious balancing, religious “what is the deduction,” religious “I shall do it when I realize my guilt,” religious from fear, religious from love. Religious on the shoulder, he carries his deeds<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Openly, for everybody to see.</i> onhis shoulder. Religious on credit, “give me credit that I can perform commandments.<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Every commentator has a different interpretation: One who asks for a loan pretending he needs it for a <i>miẓwah,</i> while he only wants the money and has no intention of performing the <i>miẓwah</i> (<i>Qorban haëdah, Eliahu Fulda</i>); I cannot pay now because I am occupied with a <i>miẓwah</i> (<i>Pne Mosheh</i>); give me money because I am so holy that I cannot go and earn money (Z. <i>Frankel</i>).</i>” Religious balancing, he commits one sin and observes one commandment and balances one against the other. Religious “what is the deduction,” what I have that is what I am using to deduct for doing a commandment. Religious “I shall do it when I realize my guilt,” I committed that sin and therefore I shall do this good deed to counteract it<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">While this is clearly disapproved of here, it is approved in the Babli and also in Medieval catalogues of “actions of penitence” which, under the influence of Catholic practices, prescribed just such a course of action.</i>. Religious from fear, like Job. Religious from love, like Abraham. No one is beloved as much as the religious from love, like Abraham.
Our forefather Abraham turned the evil instincts into good ones as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 9:8" href="/Nehemiah.9.8"><i>Neh.</i> 9:8</a>): “You found his heart trustworthy before You.” Rebbi Aḥa said, he compromised, from “concluding a covenant with him<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham compromised with his evil instincts, taking “him” to refer to the evil instincts residing in the heart, not to Abraham.</i>.” But David could not stand them and killed them in his heart. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 109:22" href="/Psalms.109.22"><i>Ps.</i> 109:22</a>) “But my heart is slain<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Taking חלל from the noun חָלָל “corpse” (or from Rabbinic Hebrew “empty space”), not from Biblical חיל “to tremble.”</i> in me.”
Rebbi Aqiba was tortured before the evil Tineius Rufus<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Governor of Palestine under the emperor Hadrian. The form of the name Tinejus is accepted by Mommsen, Renan and Schürer. (Graetz writes Tinnius or Titus Annius.) Babylonian sources give the name as טורנוס רופוס, this can be read as Turianus Rufus, traditionally interpreted as “Tyrant Rufus.” According to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nedarim 50b" href="/Nedarim.50b">Babli (<i>Nedarim</i> 50b</a>), Rufus’s rich wife had divorced him, converted to Judaism, and married Rebbi Aqiba. A story closely similar to the one given here is told in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 61a" href="/Berakhot.61a">Babli (61a</a>).</i>. There came the time for reciting the <i>Shema‘</i>. He started to read and laughed. He said to him: Old man, you are either a sorcerer or one contemptuous of suffering. He said to him: The spirit of this man should be blown away; I am neither a sorcerer nor contemptuous of sufferings. But all my life I read this verse and said, when will I have occasion for these three (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:5" href="/Deuteronomy.6.5"><i>Deut.</i> 6:5</a>): “You must love the Eternal, your God, with all your heart, all your soul, and all your force.” I loved Him with all my heart. I loved Himwith all my money. But whether with all my soul I could not test. But now, when “with all your soul” came, the time of reciting the <i>Shema‘</i> has arrived and my mind has not wavered, therefore I am reciting and laughing. He had not finished speaking when his soul flew away.
Neḥemiah from Emmaus<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonian sources, Naḥum from Gimzo (<i>Shevuöt</i> 26a) or Neḥemiah from Emmaus (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 22b" href="/Pesachim.22b"><i>Pesaḥim</i> 22b</a>) was the teacher of Rebbi Aqiva; Naḥum is also quoted as teacher in Yerushalmi sources (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 22" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.22"><i>Bereshit rabba</i> 22</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 53" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.53">53</a>) but in a very critical sense. Hence, it seems that Naḥum was the developer of a rudimentary method of explaining the Torah by looking at expressions that mean inclusions or exclusions, that the method was made satisfactory only by R. Aqiba, and that Neḥemia was R. Aqiba’s student. (The tradition of the name in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 22b" href="/Pesachim.22b"><i>Pesaḥim</i> 22b</a> is doubtful.)<br>The method of inclusions and exclusions is much more general than the limited use made here in identifying particles which have extending or limiting character; its use is always called “the method of R. Aqiba”, in contrast to the “method of R. Ismael”, which is based on generalities and specifications.</i> served Rebbi Aqiba for 20 years and he taught him “את and גם mean additions, אך and רק mean exclusions<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">The particles denoting exclusion are רַק “only”, אַךְ “but only”. Those denoting inclusion are גַּם “also”, and אֶת, which either is the particle of the accusative or means “and”. In R. Aqiba’s theory, all accusative particles also have the meaning of “and.” This is not original with him; in the Greek translation of Aquila, a student of Rebbis Eliezer and Joshua, every את is translated as καί “and”, whether it makes sense or not. In the verse in question, it is the accusative participle used as “and” that seems to result in a meaning unacceptable to pure monotheism.</i>.” He asked him: What means that which is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:13" href="/Deuteronomy.6.13"><i>Deut.</i> 6:13</a>) “את the Eternal, your God, you must fear.” He said to him, Him and His Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">A geothermal bath, as in Tiberias.</i>.
It was stated: He who urinates turns his face towards North<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">In post-Hadrianic Jerusalem, situated North of the Temple Mount. He will face a direction pointing away from the Temple.</i>. He who spreads his feet<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">To defecate; then his face is towards the Temple and his back away from it.</i> turns his face towards South. Rebbi Yose bar Abun<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Both R. Eleazar Askari and R. Zacharias Frankel prefer to cross out the words “bar Abun said, this <i>baraita</i> deals with” since in the next formulation, and in the parallel to that in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 61b" href="/Berakhot.61b">Babli (61b</a>), R. Yose the Tanna is quoted that these rules hold only if one can see Jerusalem. But one should hesitate to follow them since in the comment of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 61b" href="/Berakhot.61b">Babli (61b</a>) on the prohibitions of the Mishnah, the statement attributed here to the fifth generation R. Yose bar Abun is there credited to the fourth generation R. Abba, son of R. Ḥiyya bar Abba, in the name of R. Yoḥanan; it is clearly Amoraic. But R. Abba adds that all the rules apply only when the Temple exists (following R. Yehudah in the next <i>baraita</i>), and this is emphatically negated by the Yerushalmi.</i> said, this <i>baraita</i> is from Mount Scopus towards the interior. Rebbi Aqiba says, everywhere<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Even outside of the Land of Israel, in the interpretation of the Babli. The Babli also takes the rules of the <i>baraita</i> quite strictly, E-W and N-S, not the direction towards Jerusalem. They seem to suggest that everybody has to feel himself to be in Jerusalem everywhere in the world. It is impossible to say what the opinion of the Yerushalmi would be in this question.</i> but only where there is no wall<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">Separating between him and the forbidden direction.</i>. If was stated: He who spreads his feet should not face East with his back facing West but at an angle<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Here in the Yerushalmi, צדדין denotes a position that is not in one of the four cardinal directions. In the parallel in the Babli, the same word means a place that is not N, E, S, W from Jerusalem!</i>. Rebbi Yehudah says, when the Temple exists. Rebbi Yose said, from Mount Scopus towards the interior. Rebbi Aqiba says, everywhere but only where there is no wall.
Rebbi Aqiba said, I entered once after Rebbi Joshua to see the action<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">How he behaves in the bathroom.</i>. They asked him, what did you see? He said to them, I saw him sitting and his side was towards the West<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">At Jabneh, East of Jerusalem, he was facing either North or South.</i>; he did not undress until he was sitting, he did not sit down before he rubbed<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">He cleaned the place before he sat down. There is an alternative explanation given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 62a" href="/Berakhot.62a">Babli (62a</a>, bottom) that is impossible here.</i>, and he did not cleanse himself with his right hand but with his left hand<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli and the Yerushalmi source <i>Derekh Ereẓ</i> 7 explain that R. Eliezer says, because one eats with his right hand; R. Joshua says, because one writes (words of Torah) with the right hand; R. Aqiba says, because one uses the right hand to show the musical signs when reciting the Torah.</i>. Simeon ben Azai also said so: I entered once after Rebbi Aqiba to see the action. They asked him, what did you see? Etc.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:19" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.19">Tosephta <i>Berakhot</i> 6:19</a>.</i>: Nobody should enter the Temple Mount in shoes, with dust on his feet, or his coins tied up in his head-scarf, or his money belt on him outside. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 4:17" href="/Ecclesiastes.4.17"><i>Eccl.</i> 4:17</a>) “Watch your feet when you go to God’s house.” Rebbi Yose ben Yehudah says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Esther 4:2" href="/Esther.4.2"><i>Esth.</i> 4:2</a>): “He came as far as the king’s gate because nobody may enter the king’s gate in sackcloth.” He said, if it is so for a foul smelling drop<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">The semen from which the king was conceived.</i>, so much more for the gate of the Omnipresent!
“<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">Except for the quote from the Mishnah, this is the continuation of the previous Tosephta.</i> One should not use it as a short cut, and certainly one should not spit there<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">This is quoted here to explain the expression “certainly”, or “so much more”.</i>.” If you say that wearing shoes, which is a respectful way, is forbidden, spitting, which is disrespectful, so much more.
If was stated: One did not say “Amen” in the Temple. What did they say<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">In the second Temple.</i>? “Praised be His glorious name forever and ever.” From where<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">A formulaic word meaning: “From which verse do we know that such and such is true?”</i> that one did not say “Amen” in the Temple? The verse says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 9:5" href="/Nehemiah.9.5"><i>Neh.</i> 9:5</a>): “Rise up and praise the Eternal, etc.” From where that this is for every single benediction, the verse says: “And Elevated for every benediction and praise.<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">The full verse is: Rise up and praise the Eternal, your God, <i>from eternity to eternity</i> they shall praise Your glorious name and Elevated <i>for every benediction</i> and praise. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:22" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.22">Tosephta (6:22</a>), quoted <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 63a" href="/Berakhot.63a">Babli 63a</a>, explains that this means: For every single benediction and every single praise.</i>”
Rebbi Joshua the Southerner<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Joshua ben Levi.</i> said: Three things did the earthly court decree and the Heavenly Court agreed with them, and they are the following: The ban on Jericho, the Esther scroll, and greeting people using the Name. The ban on Jericho (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 7:11" href="/Joshua.7.11"><i>Jos.</i> 7:11</a>): “Israel sinned<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua decreed a ban on all property of the city of Jericho as <i>ḥērem</i> for the Eternal. After Akhan had taken property for himself, Israel was defeated at the Ai and Joshua was informed that “Israel sinned,” i. e., a transgression of his command was equated with a transgression of a divine command. Hence, Heaven accepted his human decree in the Heavenly Court. [While everybody can declare his own possession <i>ḥērem</i> or <i>qorbān</i> whereby its use is forbidden by a divine command (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27" href="/Leviticus.27"><i>Lev.</i> 27</a>), Joshua here forbade the use of things that did not belong to him and, under usual circumstances, his decree would be invalid in a court of law.]</i>.” But was not Joshua the one who decreed it? This certainly implies that the Heavenly Court agreed with them. The Esther scroll (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Esther 9:27" href="/Esther.9.27"><i>Esth.</i> 9:27</a>): “They confirmed and accepted, etc.” Rav said, “accepted” is written in singular<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">It is written קבל and read קִבְּלוּ.</i>; this implies that they<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">In fact, He (God) accepted it.</i> accepted. Greeting people using the Name (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 2:4" href="/Ruth.2.4"><i>Ruth</i> 2:4</a>): “Lo, Boaz came from Bethlehem.” And from where that the Heavenly court agreed with them? The verse says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Judges 6:12" href="/Judges.6.12"><i>Jud.</i> 6:12</a>): “The Eternal is with you, o hero!<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">This is the greeting of the angel to Gideon, telling him to fight the Midianites. This shows that heavenly beings adapted the human manner of greeting as exemplified by Boaz. The argument implies that Gideon, who was quite early in the time of Judges, came after Boaz. This is explicit in <i>Midrash Seder Olam</i> Chap. 12 (in the author’s edition and commentary, Northvale N.J. 1998, p. 121–123.) Boaz was the grandson of Naḥshon ben Aminadav, prince of Judah during the wanderings in the desert (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 4:20-21" href="/Ruth.4.20-21"><i>Ruth</i> 4:20–21</a>.)</i>” Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Also tithes, as it is said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Malachi 3:10" href="/Malachi.3.10"><i>Mal.</i> 3:10</a>): “Bring all tithes<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">The problem alluded to here is discussed in Yerushalmi <i>Shevi‘it</i> 6:1, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:8:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.8.2-6"><i>Qiddushin</i> 1:9</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Arakhin 32b" href="/Arakhin.32b">Babli <i>Arakhin</i> 32b</a>, referring to the obligations of the farmer regarding the produce of the Holy Land. It is spelled out in the Torah many times that these obligations (the heave for the priests, tithes for the Levites and the poor, the Sabbatical Year, etc.) come into force “when you come to the Land and inherit it,” as duties on the land distributed as family heritage to the tribes by Moses and Joshua. These commandments became obsolete when the tribes were led into captivity, including the obligations of the remaining Israelite population of Galilee who, according to our sources, were never exiled and who reappear in history at the time of the Hasmonean revolt without any record of resettlement in Galilee. The continued obligation to observe the Laws that depend on the Land therefore is derived only from the voluntary covenant enacted by the people in the time of Ezra and Nehemia (<i>Shevi‘it</i> 6:1): “Rebbi Lezer says: they voluntarily accepted the duties of the tithes. Why do I say this? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 10:1" href="/Nehemiah.10.1"><i>Neh.</i> 10:1</a>) ‘With all this, we enact a written trust and covenant signed by our princes, Levites, and priests.’ How does R. Lezer explain the inclusion (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 10:37" href="/Nehemiah.10.37"><i>Neh.</i> 10:37</a>) of ‘the firstborn of our cattle and flocks’ [an obligation that does not depend on the Land and therefore is universal]? Since they accepted the obligations (of heave and tithes) that they could have avoided, Scripture gives them credit for those obligations which they had to fulfill anyhow as if they had accepted these also voluntarily.” The same idea is also expressed by an opponent of rabbinic Judaism who is reported (<i>Shevi‘it</i> 9:9) to have said: “<i>Ḥallah</i> (the heave to be taken from bread dough) is a biblical obligation (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:20" href="/Numbers.15.20"><i>Num.</i> 15:20</a>) but the Sabbatical year is now an obligation only by the authority of Rabban Gamliel and his colleagues.” [Cf. the author’s <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah,</i> p. 280–281, and <i>Seder Olam</i> p. 248–250.]</i>, etc.” What is: “<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Malachi 3:10" href="/Malachi.3.10"><i>Mal.</i> 3:10</a>: “Bring the full tithe into the (Temple) storehouse, so that there may be food in My House, test Me in this,” said the Eternal of Hosts, “if I will not open for you the skylights of heaven, and I shall pour out for you blessing until ‘without enough.’ ” The obligation accepted by the people on Earth without Heavenly Command gives Divine Reward. Hence, the obligation was accepted as Divine Command of human origin.</i> Until ‘without enough?’ ” Rebbi Yose bar<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">The Rome manuscript does not have the words “Yose bar”. A son of R. Simeon bar Abba is otherwise unknown but the attribution is possible. R. Shelomo Cirillo has the reading “R. Yose in the name of R. Simeon bar Abba.”</i> Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: The thing about which it is impossible to say “enough”, that is blessing.
