Rebbi Berekhiah and Rebbi Chelbo and Rebbi Abba bar Ilaï in the name of Rav: Until your lips will wear out<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">This is explained in detail in <i>Midrash Samuel</i> 1:1 (which contains an enlarged version of the Yerushalmi here to the end of the tractate) that Elkanah went to Siloh four times a year, three times for the three holidays of pilgrimage and once for his private vow as explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 1:2" href="/I_Samuel.1.2"><i>1Sam.</i> 1:2</a>, and that every year he chose a different road to tell people to go to Shiloh for the holidays. A similar version is in <i>Tanna dbe Eliahu</i> I:8.</i> saying, we have enough blessings, we have enough blessings.
(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 23:22" href="/Proverbs.23.22"><i>Pr.</i> 23:22</a>): “Be not contemptuous because your mother got old.” Rebbi Yose bar Abun said, if words of Torah become old in your mouth, do not become contemptuous about them. What is the reason? “Be not contemptuous because your mother got old.” Rebbi Zeïra said, when your people got old, get up and repair it the way Elkanah did who instructed Israel in the pilgrimage for holidays. That is what is written: (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 1:2" href="/I_Samuel.1.2"><i>1Sam.</i> 1:2</a>) “This man went up from his town<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">This is explained in detail in <i>Midrash Samuel</i> 1:1 (which contains an enlarged version of the Yerushalmi here to the end of the tractate) that Elkanah went to Siloh four times a year, three times for the three holidays of pilgrimage and once for his private vow as explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 1:2" href="/I_Samuel.1.2"><i>1Sam.</i> 1:2</a>, and that every year he chose a different road to tell people to go to Shiloh for the holidays. A similar version is in <i>Tanna dbe Eliahu</i> I:8.</i>, etc.”
(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 119:126" href="/Psalms.119.126"><i>Ps.</i> 119:126</a>) “It is time to work for the Eternal, they violated Your Torah.” Rebbi Nathan inverts the verse: “They violated Your Torah, it is time to work for the Eternal.” Rebbi Ḥilqiah in the name of Rebbi Simon: He who restricts his Torah to fixed times breaches the covenant. What is the reason? “They violated Your Torah, it is time to work for the Eternal.” It was stated: Rebbi Simeon ben Yoḥai says: If you see that people have given up on Torah, get up and strengthen yourself in it and you will receive the reward of all of them. What is the reason? “They violated Your Torah, it is time to work for the Eternal!”
Hillel the elder<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">This is Hillel, contemporary of Shammai and ancestor of the house of the Patriarchs. The same sayings appear in Hebrew in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 63a" href="/Berakhot.63a">Babli 63a</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Berakhot (Lieberman) 6:24" href="/Tosefta_Berakhot_(Lieberman).6.24">Tosephta 6:24</a>.</i> used to say: When they collect, spread<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">If people teach the select few, you should teach only large masses, and vice-versa.</i>. And when they spread, collect. So Hillel used to say, if you see that the Torah is beloved by Israel and everybody enjoys it, spread. And if not, collect.Rebbi Eleazar said, just as the baby needs to suckle at all times of the day, so every Jew needs to exert himself in Torah all all times of the day. Rebbi Jonah in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Gezirah<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">An otherwise unknown Amora, but he might be identical with R. Yose Quẓira, son-in-law of R. Yose ben Yose, of the fourth/fifth generation of Amoraim in Galilee. [A similar statement appears in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 89a" href="/Chullin.89a">Babli <i>Ḥulin</i> 89a</a> in the name of the earlier Galilean R. Isaac.]</i>, all small talk is bad but small talk of Torah is good. All lies are good and the lies of Torah are bad<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is unintelligible. In the quotes of the sentence in works of medieval authors, one finds many different versions. In the commentary of Rabbenu Jonah to <i>Pirqe Avot</i>, the reading is Aramaic כרבייא “plowings” instead of כדבייא “lies.” This has support in the introduction of R. Zeraḥiah Halevi to his <i>Maör haqaṭan,</i> who reads Hebrew חרשיא “plowings.” Since the roots חרש (Arabic חרת̇) “to plow” and חרש (Arabic ח̇רשׂ) “to be silent” are identical in Hebrew, both authors give the interpretation” silence” also to the Aramaic equivalent כרב. The author of <i>‘En Yaaqob</i> reads ברכייא, “blessings.” All these authors read first “bad” then “good” as in the preceding sentence; Rabbenu Jonah even quotes the sentence about silence as alternative reading for “small talk.” Many commentators write here that the sentence should be: All lies are bad and the lies of Torah are good, referring to lies such as Eliezer’s when he met Rebecca, first gave her gold rings and then inquired after her family but in his recital to them pretended to first having asked about her family and only afterwards given her the heavy gold jewelry, to keep within accepted norms of behavior.</i>.
Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said: In a scroll of the pious<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">This kind of literature has not been identified. It might be similar to some of the Sadducee Qumran scrolls.</i> they found written: If you abandon me<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote">The Torah.</i> for one day, I shall abandon you for two days. An example of two people who went, one from Tiberias and one from Sepphoris, and met at a certain shelter. As soon as they parted and each one went one <i>mil</i>, they were separated two <i>mil</i>. Or a woman who sat and waited for a man. All the time that he intended to marry her, she sat and waited for him. When he put her out of his mind, she went and married another.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta Menaḥot 6:24–25, a parallel to the entire paragraph in slightly different language. A parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 43b" href="/Menachot.43b">Babli (<i>Menaḥot</i> 43b</a>) has the formulation that “every man in Israel is obliged to recite 100 benedictions every day.” In the Yerushalmi and the Tosephta, not only benedictions are counted but all religious deeds, and it is asserted that the number 100 is reached automatically.</i> in the name of Rebbi Meïr: There is no one in Israel who does not perform 100 commandments every day. He recites the <i>Shema‘</i> and benedictions before and after, eats his bread and recitesbenedictions before and after, prays 18 benedictions three times and then he performs other commandments and recites benedictions after them. Similarly, Rebbi Meïr used to say: There is no man in Israel who is not surrounded by commandments: <i>Tefillin</i> on his head, <i>tefillin</i> on his arm, a <i>mezuzah</i> on his door, circumcision in his flesh, and the four <i>ẓiẓiot</i> of his <i>tallit</i> surround him. That is what David said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 119:164" href="/Psalms.119.164"><i>Ps.</i> 119:164</a>): I praised You sevenfold every day for Your just laws<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">In order to end up with a count of seven, the Yerushalmi (and the Yerushalmi source <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 12" href="/Psalms.12"><i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 12</a>) must consider <i>tefillin</i> as one commandment. In Babli and Tosephta, circumcision is not counted, probably because the fact of circumcision goes to the credit of the parents, not the baby, and, therefore, <i>tefillin</i> must count for two commandments.</i>. And so it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 34:8" href="/Psalms.34.8"><i>Ps.</i> 34:8</a>): The angel of the Eternal camps around those that fear Him and rescues them<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">The implication being that the angel is created by the good deeds of the person protected.</i>. When he<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">David.</i> entered the bath house, he saw himself naked. He said, woe to me that I am stripped of commandmends. When he looked at his circumcision, he started to acclaim the Holy One, praise to Him (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 12:1" href="/Psalms.12.1"><i>Ps.</i> 12:1</a>): For the director, on the eighth<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Taken not as an eight-stringed harp but the commandment performed on the eighth day.</i>, a song from David.
Rebbi Eleazar said in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">A similar homily is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 64a" href="/Berakhot.64a">Babli 64a</a> as conclusion of the tractate; there, the expression “students of the sages” means “rabbis” but here it genuinely means “students.”</i>: The students of the Sages increase peace in the world. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 54:13" href="/Isaiah.54.13"><i>Is.</i> 54:13</a>) “All your sons are students of the Eternal, and ample peace is for your sons.”
